Menachot



Daf 1a



Daf 1b



Daf 2a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> When one brings a meal offering to the Temple, the priest removes a handful from it, places the handful into a service vessel, conveys it to the altar, and burns it. At that point, the remainder is permitted to the priests for consumption and the owner has fulfilled his obligation. In this context, the mishna teaches: <b>All the meal offerings</b> from <b>which a handful was removed not for their sake</b> but for the sake of another meal offering <b>are fit</b> for sacrifice. <b>But</b> these offerings <b>did not satisfy the obligation of the owner,</b> who must therefore bring another offering. This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all meal offerings <b>except for the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy,</b> which is brought as part of the rite of a woman suspected by her husband of having been unfaithful [<i>sota</i>]. In those cases, if the priest removed the handful not for its own sake, the offering is disqualified.
With regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy</b> from <b>which</b> the priest <b>removed a handful not for their sake,</b> or where <b>he placed</b> a handful from them <b>in a vessel, or conveyed</b> the handful to the altar, <b>or burned</b> the handful on the altar, <b>not for their sake, or for their sake and not for their sake, or not for their sake and for their sake,</b> they <b>are disqualified.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>How</b> are these rites performed <b>for their sake and not for their sake?</b> It is in a case where one removed the handful with two intentions: <b>For the sake of the meal offering of a sinner and for the sake of a voluntary meal offering.</b> How are these rites performed <b>not for their sake and for their sake?</b> It is in a case where one removed the handful with two intentions: <b>For the sake of a voluntary meal offering and for the sake of the meal offering of a sinner.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: All the meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake but for the sake of another meal offering are fit for sacrifice, but these offerings did not satisfy the obligation of the owner. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach: But</b> these offerings did not <b>[<i>ella</i></b> <i>shelo</i>] satisfy the obligation of the owner? <b>Let it teach</b> simply: <b>And they did not [<i>velo</i>] satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b> What does the word <i>ella</i> add?
The Gemara responds: By adding this word, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that the only deficiency of these offerings is that <b>they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner; but the meal offering itself</b> is <b>valid and</b> it is still <b>prohibited to deviate</b> from the protocol of its sacrificial process. For example, if a handful was removed from a meal offering not for its own sake, it is prohibited to also burn it not for its own sake. This <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Rava, as Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>a burnt offering that one slaughtered not for its own sake,</b> it is still <b>prohibited to sprinkle its blood</b> on the altar <b>not for its own sake.</b>
The Gemara adds: <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument</b> to support this statement; <b>and if you wish, cite a verse</b> as proof. The Gemara elaborates: <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument:</b> Just <b>because one deviated</b> from protocol <b>in its</b> sacrifice once, by removing the handful, could it be that <b>he should continue to deviate</b> from protocol <b>in all</b> the rest of the sacrificial rites? One deviation does not justify additional deviations.
<b>And if you wish, cite a verse: “That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do; according to what you have vowed as a gift offering to the Lord your God,</b> that which you have promised with your mouth” (Deuteronomy 23:24). The Gemara analyzes the verse: Is it <b>a gift</b> offering? <b>It is a vow</b> offering. Why does the verse first <b>call it a vow</b> offering <b>and</b> subsequently <b>call it a gift</b> offering? <b>Rather,</b> the verse teaches that <b>if you acted in accordance with how you vowed,</b> i.e., if you sacrificed the offering for its own sake, your obligation to fulfill your <b>vow will be</b> fulfilled; <b>but if</b> you did <b>not</b> act in accordance with your vow, it does not fulfill the obligation incurred by the vow, and <b>will be</b> considered <b>a gift</b> offering.

Daf 2b

The Gemara concludes the proof from the verse: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a gift</b> offering, <b>is it permitted to deviate</b> from <b>its</b> protocol <i>ab initio</i>? Clearly one may not do so. Accordingly, if one of the sacrificial rites of a meal offering was performed for the sake of a different meal offering, it is still prohibited to perform any of its other sacrificial rites improperly.
§ The mishna teaches that all the meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake are fit for sacrifice but they do not fulfill the obligation of the owner. The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say that the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All the meal offerings</b> from <b>which a handful was removed not for their sake are fit</b> for sacrifice <b>and they</b> even <b>satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Conversely, consecrated animals that were sacrificed not for their sake do not fulfill the obligation of the owner, <b>as</b> in this regard <b>meal offerings are not similar to slaughtered offerings.</b> The difference is <b>that</b> when <b>one removes a handful</b> from <b>a pan</b> meal offering <b>for the sake of a deep-pan</b> meal offering, <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is in fact <b>for the sake of a pan</b> meal offering, as the two offerings differ in appearance. Similarly, with regard to <b>a dry</b> meal offering, e.g., the meal offering of a sinner, which contains no oil, whose handful is removed <b>for the sake of</b> a meal offering that is <b>mixed</b> with oil, <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is <b>for the sake of a dry</b> meal offering, and one’s improper intent is therefore disregarded.
<b>But with regard to slaughtered offerings it is not so, as</b> there is <b>one</b> manner of <b>slaughter for all</b> offerings, <b>and one</b> manner of <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>for all</b> offerings, <b>and one</b> manner of <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>for all</b> offerings. Since the differentiation between slaughtered offerings is established only through intention, one who sacrifices an animal offering not for its own sake does not fulfill the obligation of the owner. Rabbi Shimon apparently disagrees with the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna on two counts: First, he claims that if the handful of a meal offering was removed not for its own sake it satisfies the obligation of the owner, whereas the mishna teaches that the obligation is not fulfilled. Second, Rabbi Shimon does not differentiate between the meal offering of a sinner or the meal offering of jealousy, and the other types of meal offerings.
The Gemara comments: <b>This works out well,</b> i.e., the mishna can be explained in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, <b>according to Rav Ashi, who says</b> (3b), in a resolution of two apparently contradictory statements of Rabbi Shimon: <b>Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering is fit and fulfills the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where</b> one states that he is <b>removing a handful</b> from <b>a pan</b> meal offering <b>for the sake of a deep pan,</b> i.e., he mentions only the vessel, not the type of meal offering. Conversely, <b>there,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering does not satisfy the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where</b> one states that he is <b>removing a handful</b> from <b>a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering.</b>
Accordingly, it can be explained that <b>the mishna is</b> referring to a case where one removes a handful from <b>a meal offering for the sake of</b> another <b>meal offering,</b> which is why it does not satisfy the obligation of the owner. <b>But according to</b> the statements of <b>Rabba and Rava,</b> who resolved that contradiction in a different manner, <b>what can be said?</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>And if you would say</b> that the contradiction addressed by Rav Ashi is resolved <b>as Rabba answers,</b> this is problematic. Rabba resolved the contradiction as follows: <b>Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering satisfies the owner’s obligation, he is referring <b>to a change of sanctity,</b> i.e., it was sacrificed for the sake of another type of meal offering, whereas <b>there,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that it does not fulfill the owner’s obligation, he is referring <b>to a change of owner,</b> e.g., the meal offering of Reuven was sacrificed for the sake of Shimon.
The Gemara explains that the reason this is problematic is that if one accepts Rabba’s resolution, how can the mishna be explained in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon? <b>The mishna is</b> clearly discussing the case of <b>a change of sanctity, as it teaches: How</b> are these rites performed <b>for their sake and</b> then <b>not for their sake,</b> whereby the offering does not satisfy the owner’s obligation? It is in a case where one initially removed the handful <b>for the sake of the meal offering of a sinner and</b> then <b>for the sake of a voluntary meal offering.</b> This is a change involving a different type of meal offering.
<b>And alternatively,</b> if you would say that the contradiction addressed by Rav Ashi is resolved <b>as Rava answers,</b> this is equally problematic. Rava resolved the contradiction as follows: <b>Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering satisfies the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where one removes a handful</b> from <b>a meal offering for the sake of</b> another <b>meal offering,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that it does not satisfy the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where one removes a handful</b> from <b>a meal offering for the sake of a slaughtered offering.</b>
The Gemara explains that if one accepts Rava’s resolution, the mishna cannot be in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: <b>The mishna is</b> discussing a case where one removes a handful from <b>a meal offering for the sake of</b> another <b>meal offering, as it teaches:</b> How are these rites performed <b>not for their sake and for their sake?</b> It is a case where one removed the handful <b>for the sake of a voluntary meal offering</b> and then <b>for the sake of the meal offering of a sinner.</b> The Gemara concludes: <b>Rather, according to</b> the resolutions offered by <b>Rabba and Rava, it is clear</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b>
§ The Gemara cites the <i>baraita</i> that is the basis for the apparent contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Shimon, which was mentioned in the previous discussion: <b>And</b> a Sage <b>raises a contradiction</b> from one statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon and</b> another statement <b>of Rabbi Shimon, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that the verse written concerning the meal offering: <b>“It is most sacred, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:10), indicates that <b>there are some</b> meal offerings whose <i>halakha</i> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a sin offering, and there are some</b> whose <i>halakha</i> is <b>like</b> that of <b>a guilt offering.</b>
Rabbi Shimon elaborates: The <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner is like</b> that of <b>a sin offering. Therefore,</b> if one <b>removed a handful</b> from <b>it not for its own sake,</b> it is <b>disqualified,</b> just <b>like a sin offering</b> that was slaughtered not for its own sake. Conversely, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a voluntary meal offering is like</b> that of <b>a guilt offering. Therefore,</b> if one <b>removed a handful</b> from <b>it not for its own sake,</b> it is <b>valid,</b> like a guilt offering that was slaughtered not for its own sake.
Rabbi Shimon adds: <b>And</b> a voluntary meal offering is <b>like a guilt offering</b> in another aspect as well: <b>Just as a guilt offering</b> is <b>valid but it does not effect acceptance,</b> i.e., it does not satisfy the owner’s obligation, <b>so too, a voluntary meal offering</b> is <b>valid but it does not effect acceptance.</b> Rabbi Shimon here apparently contradicts his ruling that all meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake satisfy the obligation of the owner.
<b>Rabba said</b> in resolution of this contradiction: This is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering satisfies the owner’s obligation, he is referring <b>to a change of sanctity,</b> i.e., it was sacrificed for the sake of another type of meal offering, whereas <b>there,</b> where he says that it does not fulfill the owner’s obligation, he is referring <b>to a change of owner,</b> e.g., the meal offering of Reuven was sacrificed for the sake of Shimon.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba: <b>Now</b> consider, the fact <b>that the Merciful One disqualifies</b> a meal offering due to improper <b>intent is</b> derived from the Torah’s <b>comparison</b> of meal offerings to sin offerings and guilt offerings. If so, <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if there was <b>a change of sanctity,</b> and <b>what</b> difference is there <b>to me</b> if there was <b>a change of owner?</b> In the case of a guilt offering either of these changes prevents it from satisfying the obligation of the owner.
Rabba <b>said to</b> Abaye: The claim that <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> one’s intent, <b>which Rabbi Shimon states</b> in explanation of why offerings are disqualified through improper intent, <b>is</b> based on <b>logical reasoning, as Rabbi Shimon interprets the reason</b> behind the mitzva <b>in the verse</b> and draws halakhic conclusions based on that interpretation.
Rabba continues: This is significant, as Rabbi Shimon holds that <b>the Merciful One disqualifies</b> improper <b>intent that is not recognizably</b> false, i.e., when the intent is not in clear contradiction to the sacrificial rites performed. The intent to sacrifice an offering for the sake of another owner does not include a change in the sacrificial rites and it therefore disqualifies the offering. <b>The Merciful One does not disqualify</b> improper <b>intent that is recognizably</b> false and contradicts the sacrificial rites performed, e.g., if one removes a handful from a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering, as the different substance itself indicates that it is a pan meal offering.
The Gemara lists several questions with regard to Rabba’s statement, for which it provides <b>a mnemonic: Burnt offering, burnt offering, pinched and squeezed, bird sin offering, offerings of the most sacred order, offerings of lesser sanctity.</b>
The Gemara first asks: But <b>if that is so,</b> that only intent that is not recognizably false disqualifies an offering, then in the case of <b>a bird burnt offering where one pinched</b> the nape of <b>its</b> neck <b>above</b> the red line that divides the upper and lower halves of the altar <b>for the sake of a bird sin offering,</b> it <b>should effect acceptance</b> according to Rabbi Shimon. The reason is <b>the actions</b> performed <b>on it prove that it is a bird burnt offering. Because if it is</b> in fact <b>a bird sin offering, he would have performed</b> the pinching <b>below</b> the red line while standing beside the altar. Nevertheless, Rabbi Shimon agrees with the ruling of the mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 64b) that this bird offering does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Is that to say</b> that a case of <b>a bird sin offering</b> that is pinched <b>above</b> the red line <b>is not</b> possible? <b>Didn’t the Master say:</b> The <b>pinching</b> of a bird sin offering that is performed <b>in any place on the altar</b> is <b>valid</b> after the fact? Accordingly, there is no discernible difference between the pinching of a bird burnt offering and the pinching of a bird sin offering, so the owner’s obligation is not fulfilled.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: If recognizably false intent does not disqualify an offering, then <b>a bird burnt offering where</b> a priest <b>squeezed its blood above</b> the red line <b>for the sake of a bird sin offering should effect acceptance,</b> as <b>the actions</b> performed <b>on it prove that it is a bird burnt offering. Because if it is</b> in fact <b>a bird sin offering, he would have performed</b> the required act of holding the body of the bird and <b>sprinkling</b> its blood <b>below</b> the red line, instead of squeezing out its blood above that line.

Daf 3a

The Gemara responds: This is not considered recognizably false intent, as people might <b>say: Perhaps</b> it is actually a sin offering and he has already sprinkled its blood below the red line. And as for the fact that he squeezed its blood above the red line, they will say: <b>It is the squeezing that follows sprinkling,</b> which may be performed above the red line in the case of a sin offering. <b>As the Master said:</b> If one <b>squeezed the blood of</b> a bird sin offering <b>in any place on the altar,</b> the offering is <b>valid.</b> Since people might erroneously think that this bird is actually a sin offering, this intent is not considered recognizably false, so the offering is disqualified.
The Gemara asks another question: According to Rabba’s resolution, <b>a bird sin offering whose blood</b> a priest <b>sprinkled below</b> the red line <b>for the sake of a bird burnt offering should effect acceptance, as the actions</b> performed <b>on it prove that it is a bird sin offering. Because if it is</b> in fact <b>a bird burnt offering, he would have performed it above</b> the red line, <b>and he would have performed</b> the act of <b>squeezing</b> instead of sprinkling.
The Gemara responds: <b>Indeed,</b> according to Rabbi Shimon such a bird offering effects acceptance and fulfills the obligation of the owner. In fact, bird offerings were not discussed by Rabbi Shimon at all. <b>Rather, he said: Because meal offerings are not similar to slaughtered offerings,</b> which means that they are not similar <b>to slaughtered</b> animal <b>offerings, but</b> he did not say that they are <b>not</b> similar <b>to bird</b> offerings.
The Gemara asks: But if so, then <b>offerings of the most sacred order that one slaughtered in the northern</b> part of the Temple courtyard, which is a requirement that applies only to offerings of the most sacred order, <b>for the sake of offerings of lesser sanctity, should effect acceptance</b> for their owners, as <b>the actions</b> performed <b>on them prove that they are offerings of the most sacred order. Because if</b> they are in fact <b>offerings of lesser sanctity, he would have performed their</b> slaughter <b>in the southern</b> part of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara answers: The slaughter of an offering in the northern part of the Temple courtyard is not indicative of the type of offering one intends it to be, as one can <b>say that the Merciful One states</b> that offerings of lesser sanctity may be slaughtered <b>even in the southern</b> part of the courtyard. <b>Did</b> He <b>say</b> that these offerings must be slaughtered specifically <b>in the southern</b> part <b>and not in the northern</b> part? This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 55a), that <b>the slaughter of</b> offerings of lesser sanctity may be performed <b>in any place within the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b>
The Gemara asks: If so, then <b>offerings of lesser sanctity that one slaughtered in the southern</b> part of the Temple courtyard <b>for the sake of offerings of the most sacred order should effect acceptance</b> for their owners, as <b>the actions</b> performed <b>on them prove that they are offerings of lesser sanctity. Because if</b> they are in fact <b>offerings of the most sacred order, he would have performed their</b> slaughter <b>in the northern</b> part of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara responds: The fact that an offering was slaughtered in the southern part of the Temple courtyard is not a clear indication that it was intended as an offering of lesser sanctity, as people might <b>say: They are</b> in fact <b>offerings of the most sacred order, but</b> the priest <b>transgressed</b> the mitzva to slaughter them in the northern part of the courtyard <b>and slaughtered them in the southern</b> part.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if people might suspect an individual of performing the rite of an offering in an improper manner, then if a priest removes a handful from <b>a pan</b> meal offering <b>for the sake of a deep-pan</b> meal offering <b>as well,</b> one who sees <b>that this</b> priest <b>removes a handful for</b> the sake of <b>a deep-pan</b> meal offering might <b>say: This</b> owner <b>took a vow</b> to bring a meal offering <b>in a deep pan, and</b> as for the fact <b>that he brings it in a pan, it is</b> actually the meal offering <b>of a deep pan and</b> the owner <b>transgressed</b> the mitzva to bring it in a deep pan, <b>and brought it in a pan.</b> Why, then, does Rabbi Shimon maintain that such a meal offering satisfies the obligation of its owner?
The Gemara explains: <b>There,</b> where the priest removed the handful from a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering, <b>even if</b> the owner <b>took a vow</b> to bring a meal offering <b>in a deep pan, when he brings it in a pan it is</b> considered a valid <b>pan</b> meal offering, and therefore the priest’s intention is recognizably false.
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (102b): <b>One who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring a meal offering prepared <b>in a pan, and he brought</b> it <b>in a deep pan,</b> or if he says: It is incumbent upon me to bring a meal offering prepared <b>in a deep pan, and he brought</b> it <b>in a pan,</b> the meal offering <b>that he brought, he brought,</b> i.e., it is valid and the priest performs the rites of the meal offering that he actually brought, <b>but he did not fulfill</b> the obligation resulting from <b>his vow,</b> and he must bring another meal offering to fulfill that obligation.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> even so, the priest’s improper intent remains indiscernible, as people might think: <b>Perhaps</b> the owner <b>said: This</b> tenth of an ephah of flour is a meal offering that I must <b>bring in a pan, and</b> in spite of this <b>he brought</b> it <b>in a deep pan.</b> Such a meal offering is disqualified and is not considered a valid pan meal offering, <b>as we learned</b> in that same mishna: One who took a vow, saying: <b>This</b> tenth of an ephah of flour is a meal offering that I must <b>bring in a pan, and he brought</b> it <b>in a deep pan,</b> or if he vowed: This tenth of an ephah of flour is a meal offering that I must bring <b>in a deep pan, and he brought</b> it <b>in a pan, it is disqualified,</b> as he did not fulfill his vow. If so, how can Rabbi Shimon say that such a meal offering satisfies the owner’s obligation, when the intent is not recognizably false?
The Gemara responds: <b>According to the Rabbis,</b> i.e., according to the opinion of the mishna just cited, there is <b>indeed</b> a difficulty. But <b>according to Rabbi Shimon</b> there is no difficulty, <b>since</b> with regard to a case where one took a vow, saying: It is incumbent upon me to bring a pan meal offering, and then he brought it in a deep pan, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: He has fulfilled even</b> the obligation resulting from <b>his vow. Evidently, the designation of the vessel</b> for a meal offering <b>is nothing</b> according to Rabbi Shimon, <b>and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> in this regard whether <b>he said: This</b> is for a particular type of meal offering, <b>and there is no difference</b> whether <b>he said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring a particular meal offering. In both instances the unique actions of each particular meal offering prove its identity, and therefore the owner fulfills his obligation regardless of the priest’s improper intent.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that in a case where the manner of its preparation proves the identity of an offering the owner fulfills his obligation, then <b>a burnt offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering should effect acceptance.</b> His actions prove that it is a burnt offering, <b>as this,</b> a burnt offering, is always <b>male, and that,</b> a sin offering, is <b>female.</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since there is</b> one sin offering, <b>the goat of</b> the <b><i>Nasi</i>, which is male, it is unknown</b> whether this animal was a burnt offering or the sin offering of the <i>Nasi</i>, and its gender is not conclusive proof.
The Gemara continues to ask: But in a case where one <b>said:</b> I am hereby slaughtering this animal <b>for the sake of a sin offering of an individual,</b> which is always female, <b>what can be said?</b> Since a male animal cannot be mistaken for such a sin offering, why doesn’t this burnt offering satisfy the obligation of the owner? <b>And furthermore, a sin offering of an individual that one slaughtered for the sake of a burnt offering should effect acceptance, as</b> such <b>a sin offering</b> is always <b>female, and a burnt offering</b> is always <b>male.</b> The Gemara responds: It is difficult to discern whether a lamb is male or female, as its genitals are <b>covered by</b> its <b>tail.</b> Accordingly, its gender is not considered proof of the type of offering being sacrificed.
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well</b> in a case <b>where one brought a female lamb</b> as his sin offering, as its tail makes it difficult to discern its sex. But in a case where he <b>brought a female goat, what can be said?</b> Its gender is easily recognized, as goats do not have tails that cover their genitals. The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> discerning <b>between males and females is not on people’s minds,</b> i.e., they do not take notice of the offering’s gender and therefore this aspect of an animal is not considered discernible.
The Gemara continues to challenge the opinion of Rabba: <b>A Paschal offering that one slaughtered for the sake of a guilt offering should effect acceptance, as this,</b> the Paschal offering, is <b>in its</b> first <b>year, and that,</b> a guilt offering, is <b>in its second</b> year. The Gemara answers: <b>Since there are</b> two guilt offerings that are brought from lambs in their first year, i.e., <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> (see Numbers 6:12) <b>and the guilt offering of a leper</b> (see Leviticus 14:10), <b>it is not definitively</b> clear <b>to</b> an onlooker what type of offering this lamb is.
The Gemara asks: But if one <b>said:</b> I am hereby slaughtering this lamb <b>for the sake of a guilt offering for robbery, or</b> if he said: I am slaughtering it <b>for the sake of a guilt offering for misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>what can be said?</b> These guilt offerings must each be brought from an animal in its second year, and therefore they cannot be mistaken for a Paschal offering, which is in its first year. <b>And furthermore, a guilt offering for robbery or a guilt offering for misuse</b> of consecrated property <b>that one slaughtered for the sake of a Paschal offering should effect acceptance, as a Paschal offering is</b> always <b>in its</b> first <b>year, and these are in their second year.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the difference in appearance <b>between</b> an animal that is <b>in its</b> first <b>year and</b> one that is <b>in its second year is not on people’s minds,</b> i.e., this is not a clearly recognizable difference, <b>as there</b> can <b>be</b> an animal <b>in its</b> first <b>year that appears as</b> though it is <b>in its second</b> year, <b>and there</b> can <b>be</b> an animal <b>in its second</b> year <b>that appears as</b> though it is <b>in its</b> first <b>year.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>A goat</b> sin offering <b>that one slaughtered for the sake of a guilt offering should effect acceptance.</b> It is clearly not a guilt offering, <b>as this,</b> a guilt offering, is a ram, with white <b>wool, and that,</b> a goat, has black <b>hair.</b> The Gemara responds: People will <b>say</b> that this goat <b>is</b> actually <b>a black ram,</b> and they may indeed mistake it for a guilt offering.
The Gemara challenges: <b>A calf or a bull that one slaughtered for the sake of</b> either <b>a Paschal offering or a guilt offering should effect acceptance.</b> It is clear that such animals cannot be either offering, <b>as a calf or bull</b> offering <b>is not</b> sacrificed either <b>as a Paschal offering or</b> as <b>a guilt offering.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> it <b>is indeed so,</b> as according to Rabbi Shimon such offerings effect acceptance for their owners.

Daf 3b

<b>And what</b> does Rabbi Shimon mean when he says that meal offerings are not similar to <b>slaughtered offerings?</b> He means that they are not similar to <b>most slaughtered offerings.</b> There are, however, certain slaughtered offerings whose preparation, which is unique to that particular offering, is proof that it is that offering. In those instances, Rabbi Shimon maintains that the offerings fulfill the obligations of their respective owners despite the improper intent.
§ The Gemara cites another resolution of the apparent contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> that report conflicting opinions of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that a meal offering that was sacrificed not for its own sake fulfills the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where one removes a handful</b> from <b>a meal offering for the sake of a meal offering. There,</b> where he says that it does not fulfill the owner’s obligation, he is referring to a case <b>where one removes a handful</b> from <b>a meal offering for the sake of a slaughtered offering.</b>
Rava elaborates: If one removes a handful from <b>a meal offering for the sake of</b> a different <b>meal offering</b> he fulfills his obligation, as the verse states: <b>“And this is the law of the meal offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:7). This indicates that there is <b>one law for all the meal offerings,</b> i.e., they are all considered variations of the same offering, and are different only with regard to how they should be sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>. Conversely, if one sacrificed <b>a meal offering for the sake of a slaughtered offering,</b> since the phrase: <b>And this is the law of the meal offering and a slaughtered offering, is not written</b> anywhere, there is no reason to conclude that one fulfills his obligation under such circumstances.
The Gemara questions how Rava can say that the verse “And this is the law of the meal offering” serves as the basis for the opinion of Rabbi Shimon: <b>But doesn’t the <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon, <b>say</b> that his reasoning is <b>that</b> for any particular meal offering, <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> what <b>it</b> is? The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying: Even though</b> sacrificing a meal offering for the sake of a different meal offering is a case <b>where it is not recognizable</b> that the <b>intention</b> fits the offering, i.e., the intent does not match the rites being performed, <b>and</b> the offering <b>should</b> therefore <b>be disqualified,</b> the verse states: <b>“And this is the law of the meal offering,”</b> which teaches that there is <b>one law for all the meal offerings.</b>
<b>And what</b> does Rabbi Shimon mean when he says: <b>But with regard to slaughtered offerings it is not so?</b> This clause indicates that the similarity between the rites of various slaughtered offerings is a reason why they should not be valid, whereas according to the above reasoning the opposite is so.
The Gemara explains this part of Rabbi Shimon’s statement: <b>Even though</b> there is <b>one</b> manner of <b>slaughter for all</b> animal offerings, and therefore one might think that the owner has fulfilled his obligation despite the improper intent, the phrase: <b>And this is the law of the meal offering and a slaughtered offering, is not written.</b> In other words, it is not stated: This is the law of a slaughtered offering, in the manner that a verse states: “This is the law of the meal offering.” Therefore, the owner of a slaughtered offering does not fulfill his obligation if there is improper intent, notwithstanding the similarity between the acts of slaughter.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the phrase “And this is the law of the meal offering” teaches that a meal offering is not disqualified despite the improper intent for a different meal offering, then analogously, <b>a sin offering</b> brought to atone for eating forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering</b> to atone for drinking <b>blood,</b> or <b>for the sake of a sin offering</b> to atone for <b>idol worship,</b> or <b>for the sake of a sin offering of a nazirite,</b> or <b>for the sake of a sin offering of a leper should be valid and effect acceptance. As the Merciful One states: “And this is the law of the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:18), from which it should be derived that there is <b>one law for all sin offerings.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> such a sin offering is <b>indeed</b> valid and effects acceptance for its owner. The Gemara notes: <b>According to the Rabbis,</b> Rava <b>says: A sin offering</b> brought to atone for eating forbidden <b>fat that one slaughtered for the sake of a sin offering</b> to atone for drinking <b>blood</b> or <b>for the sake of a sin offering</b> to atone for <b>idol worship</b> is <b>valid.</b> But if he slaughtered it <b>for the sake of a sin offering of a nazirite</b> or for the sake of a sin offering of <b>a leper</b> it is <b>disqualified, as</b> with regard to <b>these</b> offerings, <b>there are burnt offerings</b> brought together <b>with them.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, teaches</b> that Rava holds that the <i>halakha</i> in <b>all of these</b> cases is <b>disqualification</b> of the sin offering. The reason is that the verse states: <b>“And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33). The word “it” indicates that it must be sacrificed <b>for the sake of that</b> particular <b>sin offering,</b> and it may not be slaughtered for the sake of a different one.
§ The Gemara cites a third resolution of the apparent contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> that report conflicting opinions of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Rav Ashi said</b> that it is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> where Rabbi Shimon says that the meal offering is fit and fulfills the obligation of the owner, he is referring to a case <b>where</b> one states that he is <b>removing a handful</b> from <b>a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep pan,</b> i.e., he mentions only the vessel and not the offering. <b>There, where</b> it does not fulfill the owner’s obligation, <b>he</b> states that he is <b>removing a handful</b> from <b>a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering.</b>
Rav Ashi elaborates: When one bringing a pan meal offering states that he is removing a handful from <b>a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep pan, he has intent</b> only <b>with regard to</b> the type of <b>vessel, and intention with regard to</b> the type of <b>vessel does not disqualify</b> offerings, as he is not sacrificing the vessel, and therefore the owner’s obligation is fulfilled. By contrast, when he states that he is removing a handful from <b>a pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering, he has intent with regard to</b> the type of <b>meal offering, which</b> improper <b>intention does disqualify.</b> Consequently, the owner’s obligation is not fulfilled.
The Gemara questions how Rav Ashi can maintain that this is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon: <b>But doesn’t the <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., Rabbi Shimon, <b>say</b> that his reasoning is <b>that</b> for any particular meal offering, <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> what <b>it</b> is? The Gemara explains that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying: Even though</b> when he removes a handful from a pan meal offering explicitly for the sake of a deep pan, it is a case where the falseness of the <b>intention is recognizable</b> and the offering <b>should</b> therefore <b>be disqualified,</b> it is nevertheless valid and fulfills the owner’s obligation, as intentions with regard to the vessel are irrelevant.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> does Rabbi Shimon mean when he says: <b>But with regard to slaughtered offerings it is not so?</b> He means that <b>even though</b> there is <b>one</b> manner of <b>slaughter for all</b> offerings, and <b>one</b> manner of <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>for all</b> offerings, and <b>one</b> manner of <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>for all</b> offerings, i.e., if one performs any of these rites for the sake of a different offering it is not recognizable that his intent is false, and therefore it might have been thought that the owner does fulfill his obligation, nevertheless he <b>has</b> improper <b>intent with regard to</b> an aspect of <b>slaughtering,</b> such as slaughtering a burnt offering for the sake of a peace offering, <b>which</b> improper <b>intention does disqualify.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> If this is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon, then with regard to a case where one removes a handful from <b>a dry</b> meal offering <b>for the sake of</b> a meal offering <b>mixed</b> with oil, <b>why did Rabbi Shimon say</b> that it fulfills the owner’s obligation? Since his intent concerns the meal offering itself, it should disqualify the offering. Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> When Rabbi Shimon says that such a meal offering fulfills the owner’s obligation he is referring to a case where one removes a handful <b>merely for the sake of mixing,</b> not for the sake of a meal offering mixed with oil.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then when one slaughters a burnt offering <b>for the sake of a peace offering as well,</b> one can say that his intent is <b>merely for the sake of peace [<i>shelamim</i>]</b> between himself and God. Why then does Rabbi Shimon say that this burnt offering does not fulfill the obligation of the owner?
The Gemara rejects this challenge: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> the <b>offering itself is called <i>shelamim</i>, as it is written: “Who sacrifices the blood of the peace offering [<i>shelamim</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 7:33), and it is also written: <b>“Who sprinkles the blood of the peace offering”</b> (Leviticus 7:14). <b>Here,</b> by contrast, <b>is a meal offering itself called mixed?</b> It <b>is written: “And every meal offering, mixed with oil”</b> (Leviticus 7:10), indicating that there is a meal offering that <b>is called: Mixed with oil,</b> but <b>it is not simply called: Mixed.</b> One’s intent to sacrifice a dry meal offering for the sake of mixing is therefore not a reference to the offering itself.
§ Three resolutions have been suggested for the apparent contradiction between the statements of Rabbi Shimon in two <i>baraitot</i> concerning whether or not a meal offering whose handful was removed not for its own sake fulfills the obligation of its owner. Rabba’s answer was that there is a difference between intent for another meal offering, in which case the owner fulfills his obligation, as the intent is recognizably improper, and intent for someone else, which is not recognizably improper. The Gemara comments: <b>All</b> the other Sages, i.e., Rava and Rav Ashi, <b>do not say as Rabba</b> did in resolving the contradiction, as they do not accept his reasoning, claiming <b>that on the contrary, the Merciful One disqualifies recognizably</b> false <b>intent.</b>
The Gemara continues: Rava resolved the contradiction by saying that a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of another meal offering effects acceptance for the owner, as the verse states: “And this is the law of the meal offering” (Leviticus 6:7), indicating that there is one law for all meal offerings, whereas a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of an animal offering does not effect acceptance. Rabba and Rav Ashi <b>do not say as Rava</b> did in resolving the contradiction, as the verse that states: <b>“And this is the law</b> of the meal offering,” <b>does not indicate to them</b> that there should be one law for all meal offerings.
The Gemara continues: Rav Ashi resolved the contradiction by saying that when one removes the handful from a meal offering for the sake of a vessel the meal offering effects acceptance for the owner, as intent concerning the vessel itself is inconsequential, whereas when one removes the handful for the sake of another meal offering, the meal offering does not fulfill the owner’s obligation. Rabba and Rava <b>did not say as Rav Ashi</b> did in resolving the contradiction <b>because of the difficulty</b> posed <b>by Rav Aḥa, son of Rava,</b> from a case where one removes the handful of a dry meal offering for the sake of a mixed one. Rabbi Shimon holds that such a meal offering fulfills the owner’s obligation even though his intent concerns the meal offering itself, not the vessel.
The Gemara notes: <b>The matter that is obvious to Rabba in one way,</b> i.e., that with regard to meal offerings recognizably false intention is disregarded, but when the false intention is not recognizable the offering does not fulfill the owner’s obligation, <b>and</b> that is obvious <b>to Rava in the other way,</b> i.e., that in cases of recognizably false intention the offering should not fulfill the owner’s obligation, <b>is a dilemma for Rav Hoshaya. As Rav Hoshaya raises a dilemma, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Hoshaya raises</b> this <b>dilemma before Rav Asi:</b> In the case of one who sacrifices <b>a meal offering for the sake of a slaughtered offering,</b>

Daf 4a

<b>what</b> should <b>I</b> understand that <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> with regard to such a case? Is <b>the reason of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who says that a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of another meal offering is valid and effects acceptance, <b>that intent that is recognizably</b> false <b>does not disqualify</b> an offering? <b>And</b> if so, <b>this</b> meal offering from which a handful is removed for the sake of an animal offering <b>is</b> also a case of <b>intent that is recognizably</b> false, and therefore the meal offering should not be disqualified.
<b>Or perhaps the reason of Rabbi Shimon is that it is written: “And this is the law of the meal offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:7), which indicates that there is one law for all meal offerings. If so, then a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of an animal offering should be disqualified, since it <b>is not written:</b> And this is the law of the meal offering <b>and a slaughtered offering.</b> Rav Asi <b>said to</b> Rav Hoshaya: <b>Have we ascertained the depth of the opinion of Rabbi Shimon</b> in this matter? In other words, Rabbi Shimon’s reasoning is not known.
The Gemara explains why Rav Asi did not resolve this dilemma. Rav Asi <b>did not resolve</b> the dilemma of Rav Hoshaya in accordance <b>with</b> the resolution stated by <b>Rabba,</b> that there is a distinction between one who removes the handful of a meal offering for the sake of another meal offering and one who removes it for the sake of another owner, <b>because of the difficulty</b> posed by <b>Abaye</b> (2b), that the <i>halakha</i> of both these cases is derived from the same comparison in the Torah between meal offerings and animal offerings.
Likewise, Rav Asi <b>did not resolve</b> the dilemma <b>in accordance with</b> the resolution stated by <b>Rava,</b> that the verse “And this is the law of the meal offering” teaches that a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of another meal offering is valid, whereas a meal offering from which a handful was removed for the sake of an animal offering is disqualified. This is <b>because of the difficulty</b> arising from the verse: <b>“And this is the law of the sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:18), i.e., despite this verse, the <i>halakha</i> is that a sin offering that was slaughtered for the sake of another sin offering is not valid.
Finally, Rav Asi <b>did not resolve</b> the dilemma <b>in accordance with</b> the resolution stated by <b>Rav Ashi,</b> that there is a distinction between one who removes the handful of a meal offering prepared in one vessel for the sake of a different vessel, and one who removes it for the sake of a meal offering prepared in a different vessel, <b>because of the difficulty</b> posed by <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava.</b> This difficulty concerns a case where one removes the handful of a dry meal offering for the sake of one mixed with oil; Rabbi Shimon holds that such a meal offering is valid despite the fact that the person’s intent referred to the meal offering itself, not the vessel.
§ The mishna teaches that all meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake but for the sake of another meal offering are fit for sacrifice, <b>except for the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, the meal offering of a sinner</b> is disqualified when a handful is removed from it not for its own sake, as <b>the Merciful One calls it a sin offering,</b> in the verse: <b>“He shall put no oil upon it, neither shall he put any frankincense upon it, for it is a sin offering.</b> And he shall bring it to the priest, and the priest shall take his handful” (Leviticus 5:11–12). This verse indicates that just as a sin offering is disqualified when sacrificed not for its own sake, so too, the meal offering of a sinner is disqualified when a handful is removed from it not for its own sake. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>the meal offering of jealousy, from where do we</b> derive that this is the <i>halakha</i>?
The Gemara answers that this <i>halakha</i> may be derived from a <i>baraita</i>, <b>as a <i>tanna</i> taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to money that was designated for <b>a meal offering of jealousy, its surplus,</b> i.e., the money remaining after the purchase of the meal offering, is used to purchase communal <b>gift</b> offerings.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: You are saying well,</b> as <b>it is written with regard to</b> a meal offering of jealousy: <b>“Bringing iniquity to remembrance”</b> (Numbers 5:15), <b>and it is written with regard to a sin offering: “And He has given it you to bear the iniquity of the congregation”</b> (Leviticus 10:17). A verbal analogy is drawn between the two uses of the term “iniquity” in these verses. This teaches that <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>a sin offering, its surplus</b> is used to purchase communal <b>gift</b> offerings, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering of jealousy, its surplus</b> is used to purchase communal <b>gift</b> offerings. <b>And</b> a meal offering of jealousy is also <b>like a sin offering</b> in another aspect: <b>Just as a sin offering is disqualified</b> when sacrificed <b>not for its own sake, so too, a meal offering of jealousy is disqualified</b> when a handful is removed from it <b>not for its own sake.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of a meal offering of jealousy is derived from a verbal analogy to a sin offering based on the word “iniquity,” then <b>a guilt offering should</b> also <b>be disqualified</b> if it was sacrificed <b>not for its own sake, as</b> a similar verbal analogy may be <b>derived from</b> the verse that states: “The <b>iniquity [<i>avon</i>]</b> of the congregation” (Leviticus 10:17), with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> and the verse that states: “And shall bear his <b>iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 5:17), in connection with a guilt offering.
The Gemara responds: <b>One derives</b> a verbal analogy based on the word <b>“iniquity” from</b> a verse that likewise uses the term <b>“iniquity,” but one does not derive</b> a verbal analogy based on the term <b>“his iniquity [<i>avono</i>]” from</b> a verse that uses the term <b>“iniquity.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is</b> there? <b>Didn’t the school of Rabbi Yishmael teach</b> the following verbal analogy with regard to leprosy of houses? The verse states: <b>“And the priest shall return [<i>veshav</i>]</b> on the seventh day” (Leviticus 14:39), and another verse concerning the priest’s visit seven days later states: <b>“And the priest shall come [<i>uva</i>]</b> and look” (Leviticus 14:44). <b>This returning</b> and <b>this coming</b> have the same meaning, and one can therefore derive by verbal analogy that the <i>halakha</i> that applies if the leprosy had spread at the conclusion of the first week applies if it had spread again by the end of the following week. All the more so should a less pronounced difference of one letter between <i>avon</i> and <i>avono</i> not prevent the teaching of a verbal analogy.
<b>And furthermore, let one derive</b> a verbal analogy through the term <b>“his iniquity”</b> stated with regard to a guilt offering, and the term <b>“his iniquity” from</b> the verse concerning the sin offering brought for the <b>iniquity for hearing the voice,</b> i.e., the sin offering of one who takes a false oath that he does not have any information relevant to a matter when another requests that he testify about it, <b>as it is written: “If he does not utter it, then he shall bear his iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 5:1).
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>when the verbal analogy was derived, it was derived</b> only with regard <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>surplus</b> from the money designated for a meal offering of jealousy is used to purchase communal <b>gift</b> offerings, and not with regard to the <i>halakha</i> that a meal offering of jealousy from which a handful was removed not for its own sake is disqualified.
<b>And if you would say</b> that there is a principle that <b>there is no partial verbal analogy,</b> that principle does not apply in this instance. As <b>the Merciful One revealed with regard to a sin offering</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of other offerings may not be derived from this case, as the verse states: <b>“And slaughter it for a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:33). This verse indicates that <b>it,</b> i.e., a sin offering, when slaughtered <b>for its own sake</b> is <b>valid,</b> and when slaughtered <b>not for its own sake</b> is <b>disqualified. But all</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> animals, <b>whether</b> sacrificed <b>for their sake or not for their sake, are valid.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the Merciful One revealed that one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of other offerings that were sacrificed not for their sake from a sin offering, then <b>from where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> <b>that the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy are disqualified</b> when a handful is removed from them <b>not for their sake?</b>
The Gemara explains: With regard to <b>a sin offering, what is the reason</b> that it is disqualified when sacrificed not for its own sake? It is <b>because it is written with regard to</b> this offering: <b>“It,”</b> in a verse discussing the sin offering of the <i>Nasi</i>: “It is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). This indicates that a sin offering is valid only when it is sacrificed for its own sake. <b>So too, it is written with regard to them,</b> i.e., the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy: <b>“It.”</b> In the case of the meal offering of a sinner the verse states: “It is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:11), and with regard to the meal offering of jealousy it is written: “It is a meal offering of jealousy” (Numbers 5:15).
The Gemara challenges: But if so, concerning <b>a guilt offering as well, it is written about</b> this offering: <b>“It,”</b> as the verse states: “It is a guilt offering” (Leviticus 7:5). Accordingly, a guilt offering should likewise be disqualified if it is slaughtered not for its own sake. The Gemara responds: <b>That</b> term <b>“it” is written with regard to</b> the stage <b>after the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions [<i>eimurin</i>]</b> of a guilt offering, which are intended for burning upon the altar.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One derives from the word “it” that if the offering was slaughtered not for its own sake it is disqualified only in the case of a sin offering. <b>But</b> concerning <b>a guilt offering, it is stated about</b> this offering: <b>“It</b> is a guilt offering,” <b>only</b> with regard to the stage <b>after the burning of</b> the <b>sacrificial portions.</b> The <i>baraita</i> adds: One cannot derive that if these portions were burned not for the sake of a guilt offering then the offering is disqualified, since the guilt offering <b>itself</b> is <b>valid</b> if <b>its sacrificial portions were not burned</b> upon the altar at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>why do I</b> need the word <b>“it”</b> stated with regard to a guilt offering? The Gemara answers: It is necessary <b>for that which Rav Huna</b> says that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>a guilt offering</b> whose owner died or whose transgression was otherwise atoned for, and <b>that was</b> therefore <b>consigned</b> by the court <b>to grazing</b> until it develops a blemish so that it can be sold and the proceeds used to purchase a burnt offering, if, before it developed a blemish, someone <b>slaughtered it without specification</b> of its purpose, it is <b>fit</b> if it was sacrificed <b>as a burnt offering.</b>
The Gemara infers: If <b>it was consigned</b> to grazing, <b>yes,</b> it is fit if it was sacrificed as a burnt offering if slaughtered. By inference, if <b>it was not consigned</b> to grazing, it is <b>not</b> fit. What is the reason for this? <b>The verse states: “It</b> is a guilt offering,” indicating that <b>it shall</b> remain <b>as it is,</b> i.e., as a guilt offering, unless it is consigned by the court to another purpose.
§ The mishna teaches that all the meal offerings from which a handful was removed not for their sake are fit for sacrifice but they do not fulfill the owner’s obligation. Concerning this, <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering,</b> i.e., the measure of barley brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan (see Leviticus 23:9–14), if the priest <b>removed a handful</b> from it <b>not for its own sake</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b> It is disqualified <b>since</b> an <i>omer</i> meal offering <b>came</b> for a specific purpose, namely, <b>to permit</b> the consumption of the new crop, <b>and</b> this meal offering <b>did not permit</b> the consumption of the new crop because its rites were performed not for its own sake. <b>And so you say with regard to the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> who became ritually impure, whose proper sacrifice enables the nazirite to restart his naziriteship afresh in purity,

Daf 4b

<b>and</b> so you say with regard to <b>the guilt offering of a leper,</b> whose proper sacrifice enables the leper to enter the Israelite camp and to partake of offerings of sanctity, <b>that</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> these offerings <b>not for their sake, they are disqualified.</b> They are disqualified <b>since</b> their sacrifice <b>came to render</b> the nazirite and leper <b>fit, and</b> these guilt offerings <b>did not render</b> them <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna that <b>all the meal offerings</b> from <b>which a handful was removed not for their sake are fit</b> for sacrifice <b>but they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner, except for the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy. And if it is so</b> that an <i>omer</i> meal offering from which a handful was removed not for its own sake is disqualified, then <b>let</b> the mishna <b>also teach: Except for the <i>omer</i> meal offering.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>When</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i>, it teaches it only with regard to meal offerings that <b>come</b> on behalf of <b>an individual.</b> The mishna <b>does not teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to those meal offerings that <b>come</b> on behalf of the <b>community.</b> Additionally, <b>when</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i>, it is only with regard to a meal offering that <b>comes on account of itself,</b> i.e., as an independent offering. The mishna <b>does not teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering that <b>comes on account of,</b> i.e., together with, <b>a slaughtered offering,</b> e.g., the <i>omer</i> meal offering, which is brought along with two sheep.
The Gemara adds: Furthermore, <b>when</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> this <i>halakha</i>, it is only with regard to <b>those</b> meal offerings <b>whose time is not set,</b> i.e., they may be sacrificed on any date. The mishna <b>does not teach</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> <i>omer</i> meal offering, <b>whose time</b> for offering <b>is set</b> on the sixteenth of Nisan.
§ The Gemara analyzes the statement of Rav. <b>The Master said: And so you say with regard to the guilt offering of a nazirite</b> who became ritually impure, <b>and</b> so you say with regard to <b>the guilt offering of a leper, that</b> if one <b>slaughtered</b> these offerings <b>not for their sake, they are disqualified.</b> They are disqualified <b>since</b> their proper sacrifice <b>came to render</b> the nazirite and leper <b>fit, and they did not render</b> them <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 2a): <b>All slaughtered offerings that one slaughtered not for their sake are fit, but they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b> This is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all offerings <b>except for the Paschal offering and the sin offering,</b> which are disqualified when slaughtered not for their sake. <b>And if it is so</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with the statement of Rav, <b>let</b> the mishna <b>also teach: Except for the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper, since they came to render</b> one <b>fit and they did not render</b> one <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Since there</b> are other guilt offerings, i.e., <b>the guilt offering for robbery,</b> which one brings for taking a false oath denying an accusation of robbery, <b>and the guilt offering</b> brought <b>for misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>that come for atonement,</b> which do not render one fit and are fit for sacrifice if they were slaughtered not for their sake, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna could <b>not</b> state the <i>halakha</i> with regard to guilt offerings in <b>an absolute</b> manner, and therefore he refrains from mentioning guilt offerings at all.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> about <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper?</b> Why are they disqualified when slaughtered not for their sake <b>since they came to render fit and they did not render fit? These,</b> i.e., the guilt offerings for robbery and for misuse of consecrated property, should <b>likewise</b> be disqualified when slaughtered not for their sake, since they <b>came for atonement and they did not atone.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said</b> in response: <b>We find that the Torah differentiates between</b> those guilt offerings that <b>atone and</b> those that <b>render fit,</b> and the <i>halakha</i> is more stringent with regard to those that render fit. Rabbi Yirmeya elaborates: With regard to those guilt offerings that <b>atone, there are among them</b> offerings <b>that come after death,</b> i.e., they are sacrificed after the death of their owners, whereas with regard to those that <b>render fit, there are none among them that come after death. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kinnim</i> 2:5): With regard to <b>a woman</b> after childbirth <b>who brought her sin offering</b> for her ritual purification <b>and died, the heirs shall bring her burnt offering,</b>which comes to atone. If she set aside <b>her burnt offering and died, the heirs shall not bring her sin offering,</b> as it comes to render her fit to partake of offerings.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, objects to this:</b> With regard to offerings that <b>render fit as well, are there not among them</b> offerings <b>that come after death? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 11a): In the case of <b>one who separates funds for</b> the offerings of <b>his naziriteship,</b> i.e., his sin offering, burnt offering, and peace offering, a person <b>may not derive benefit</b> from them <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one benefited from them after the fact, he is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, i.e., he is not required to bring a guilt offering and is not obligated to repay the principal and an additional fifth. This is <b>because</b> the coins <b>are all fit for bringing peace offerings,</b>and there is no misuse of consecrated property with regard to funds fit for a peace offering.
The mishna continues: If the nazirite <b>died and he had undesignated funds</b> that he set aside to pay for his nazirite offerings without specifying how much money should be allocated toward each offering, <b>they will be allocated for</b> communal <b>gift</b> offerings. If he left behind <b>allocated</b> funds, then with regard to <b>the money for a sin offering,</b> one must <b>take</b> it and cast it <b>into the Dead Sea; one may not benefit</b> from it <i>ab initio</i>, <b>but</b> if one benefited from it after the fact, he is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. With regard to <b>the money for a burnt offering, one brings with it a burnt offering, and</b> one is liable for <b>misusing them.</b>
The mishna concludes: With <b>the money for a peace offering, one brings a peace offering with it, and</b> these offerings <b>are eaten for one day,</b> like the peace offering brought by a nazirite, <b>and do not require</b> the <b>loaves</b> that are normally bought with the peace offering of a nazirite. Rabbi Yehuda explains his question: <b>But</b> the <b>burnt offering and peace offering of a nazirite are</b> offerings <b>that render</b> the nazirite <b>fit</b> to drink wine, <b>and</b> yet <b>they come after death.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in response that <b>this is what Rabbi Yirmeya is saying: We do not find</b> an instance of <b>a fixed</b> manner of <b>rendering fit that comes after death,</b> i.e., there is no instance where the only offering that will render one fit to act in a manner previously prohibited to him may be sacrificed after death. <b>And</b> the offerings <b>of a nazirite</b> are examples of a means of <b>rendering fit that is not fixed,</b>

Daf 5a

<b>as the Master said</b> about the nazirite (<i>Nazir</i> 45a): And if he <b>shaved after</b> the sacrifice of any <b>one of the three of them,</b> i.e., after sacrificing his sin offering, burnt offering, or peace offering, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation after the fact, i.e., he has successfully completed his term of naziriteship. Accordingly, there is no specific offering that renders him fit.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>the guilt offering of a leper that was slaughtered not for its own sake, or</b> if <b>none of its blood was placed on</b> the leper’s right <b>thumb and big toe, this</b> guilt offering <b>is offered up upon the altar and it requires libations,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> of the guilt offering of a leper. <b>But</b> the leper <b>must</b> nevertheless bring <b>another guilt offering to render him fit</b> to partake of offerings. This <i>baraita</i> is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the statement <b>of Rav,</b> who said that the guilt offering of a leper that was slaughtered not for its own sake is entirely disqualified because it did not render the leper fit.
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion concerning the <i>omer</i> meal offering. <b>And Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says,</b> with regard to <b>an <i>omer</i> meal offering</b> from <b>which</b> a priest <b>removed a handful not for its own sake,</b> that it is <b>valid</b> and the handful is burned on the altar. <b>But its remainder may not be consumed</b> by the priests <b>until</b> a priest <b>brings another <i>omer</i> meal offering</b> on the same day <b>and</b> thereby <b>permits</b> the first offering for consumption, as the prohibition against consuming the new crop remains in effect.
The Gemara asks: But if <b>its remainder may not</b> be <b>consumed</b> by the priests <b>until</b> they <b>bring another <i>omer</i> meal offering, how can</b> the handful removed from this <i>omer</i> meal offering <b>be sacrificed</b> upon the altar? Before the <i>omer</i> meal offering is sacrificed, the new crop is forbidden for consumption, and the verse states: <b>“From the well-watered pastures of Israel;</b> for a meal offering, and for a burnt offering, and for peace offerings” (Ezekiel 45:15), from which it is derived that one may sacrifice only <b>from</b> that <b>which is permitted to the Jewish people.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava said</b> in response: <b>Reish Lakish holds</b> that an offering is <b>not</b> considered one <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived if it is to be brought <b>on that day.</b> Accordingly, since the new crop will be permitted for consumption on the same day that this handful was removed from the <i>omer</i> meal offering, it is already considered fit to be sacrificed upon the altar.
<b>Rav Adda, son of Rav Yitzḥak, raises an objection</b> to Rav Adda bar Ahava’s explanation from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to birds that</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to meal offerings,</b> and <b>there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to meal offerings that</b> does <b>not</b> apply <b>to birds.</b> The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>There is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to birds</b> that does not apply to meal offerings, <b>as birds</b> may be <b>brought as a gift</b> offering on behalf <b>of two</b> people, i.e., two people may take a vow to bring a single bird offering jointly. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>meal offerings</b> it <b>is written:</b> “And when <b>one</b> brings a meal offering” (Leviticus 2:1), indicating that only individuals may vow to bring a meal offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And</b> another <i>halakha</i> that applies to birds but not meal offerings involves one who <b>has not yet</b> brought his <b>atonement</b> offering, i.e., <b>a man who experienced a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>], or woman who experienced a discharge of uterine blood after her menstrual period [<i>zava</i>], or a woman after childbirth, or a leper,</b> all of whom must bring an offering to complete their atonement process. They bring a bird offering, not a meal offering.
<b>And</b> furthermore, with regard to birds, <b>their general prohibition was permitted when</b> they are <b>consecrated,</b> i.e., killing a non-sacred bird by pinching the nape of its neck renders it a carcass, whose consumption is prohibited, and yet pinching the nape of a bird offering enables it to be sacrificed upon the altar and permits it for consumption, <b>which is not so with regard to meal offerings,</b> i.e., there is no prohibition that applies to the non-consecrated ingredients of a meal offering that does not apply to actual meal offerings as well.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to meal offerings</b> that does not apply to birds. <b>As meal offerings require</b> placement in a service <b>vessel, and</b> they require <b>waving and bringing,</b> i.e., they must be brought to the corner of the altar prior to removal of the handful. <b>And</b> lastly, <b>there are</b> meal offerings <b>of the community just as</b> there are meal offerings <b>of individuals,</b> e.g., the <i>omer</i> meal offering is a communal meal offering, <b>which is not so with regard to birds.</b> Bird offerings do not require the use of service vessels, they do not require waving or bringing, and there are no communal bird offerings.
Rav Adda, son of Rav Yitzḥak, explains his objection: <b>And if it is so</b> that a handful that was removed from an <i>omer</i> meal offering not for its own sake is fit for burning upon the altar, then <b>with regard to meal offerings as well, you find that their general prohibition was permitted when</b> they are <b>consecrated. And what is this</b> meal offering that was permitted? It is <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering</b> from which a handful was removed not for its own sake, as although the new crop remains prohibited to the Jewish people until another <i>omer</i> meal offering is brought, the handful of this meal offering may be sacrificed upon the altar.
The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> an offering is <b>not</b> considered one <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived if it is to be brought <b>on that day,</b> the sacrificing of that handful <b>is not a prohibition</b> that was permitted. Instead, it was initially fit for sacrifice upon the altar, as though another <i>omer</i> meal offering had already been brought to permit it.
<b>Rav Sheshet raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> that discusses the ritual purification of a leper: If the priest <b>performed the placement of oil</b> on the leper’s right thumb and big toe <b>before the placement of blood</b> from the leper’s guilt offering on the leper’s right thumb and big toe, i.e., his actions were in the opposite order from those prescribed in the Torah (see Leviticus 14:14–17), <b>he fills</b> the vessel that holds a <i>log</i> of <b>oil and he</b> then <b>puts oil</b> on the leper’s right thumb and big toe <b>again after the placement of blood.</b> If the priest <b>performed the placement of</b> oil on the leper’s right <b>thumb and big toe before the placement of seven</b> sprinklings of oil before the Lord, <b>he fills</b> the vessel that holds a <i>log</i> of <b>oil and he again puts</b> oil on the leper’s right <b>thumb and big toe after the placement of seven</b> sprinklings.
Rav Sheshet explains his objection: <b>And if you say</b> that an offering is <b>not</b> considered as one <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived if it is to be brought <b>on that day,</b> then <b>why should</b> the priest <b>place</b> the oil on the leper’s right thumb and big toe <b>again? What he performed, he</b> already <b>performed,</b> i.e., since the oil was going to be placed on the leper’s right thumb and big toe on that day, the placement should be valid even when done out of order.
<b>Rav Pappa said</b> in response: <b>The <i>halakhot</i> of a leper are different, as</b> it <b>is written concerning them</b> an expression of <b>being, as the verse states: “This shall be the law of the leper”</b> (Leviticus 14:2). The term <b>“shall be”</b> indicates that <b>it shall be as it is,</b> i.e., the purification process of a leper must be performed in accordance with the precise order prescribed in the Torah.
<b>Rav Pappa raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If the priest <b>performed</b> the slaughter of a leper’s <b>sin offering before</b> the slaughter of <b>his guilt offering,</b> i.e., the priest’s actions were in the opposite order from those prescribed in the Torah (see Leviticus 14:13–19), <b>there</b> should <b>not be another</b> priest <b>stirring the blood of</b> the leper’s sin offering to prevent it from congealing in order that his guilt offering may be slaughtered and its blood sprinkled before the blood of his sin offering. <b>Rather,</b> the sin offering is left until <b>its form decays,</b> i.e., until the next morning, at which point it is definitively disqualified due to remaining in the Temple overnight <b>and</b> can be <b>taken out to the place</b> designated <b>for burning.</b> The objection is as follows: If an offering that is to be brought on that day is not considered one whose time has not yet arrived, why must this sin offering be left to decay? It should be considered as though it was slaughtered after the guilt offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why does Rav Pappa raise</b> this <b>objection? But isn’t it Rav Pappa</b> himself <b>who said: The <i>halakhot</i> of a leper are different, as</b> it <b>is written concerning them</b> an expression of <b>being,</b> which indicates that the order of slaughter of a leper’s offerings must be preserved? <b>Rather, this is what is difficult to Rav Pappa</b> from the <i>baraita</i>: You can <b>say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the order is indispensable to the purification process of a leper, applies only to a sacrificial <b>rite,</b> whereas the act of <b>slaughter is not</b> considered <b>a rite. And if</b> an offering is <b>not</b> considered one <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived if it is to be brought <b>on that day,</b> then <b>another</b> priest <b>should be stirring the blood of</b> the leper’s sin offering to prevent it from congealing, <b>and</b> a priest <b>should sacrifice</b> the <b>guilt offering</b> and present its blood in the meantime, <b>and afterward he should sacrifice</b> the <b>sin offering.</b>
<b>Rather, Rav Pappa said: This is the reason of Reish Lakish,</b> who said <b>that</b> the handful of an <i>omer</i> meal offering that was removed not for its own sake is valid and may be burned upon the altar: It is that <b>he holds</b> that <b>the illumination of</b> the <b>eastern</b> horizon on the morning of the sixteenth of Nisan <b>permits</b> the new crop to the Jewish people even before the <i>omer</i> meal offering is sacrificed, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish both say: Even when the Temple is standing,</b>

Daf 5b

<b>the illumination of</b> the <b>eastern</b> horizon <b>permits</b> the new crop.
The Gemara notes: <b>And this</b> statement <b>of Reish Lakish was not stated explicitly; rather, it was stated by inference,</b> i.e., it is evident from a different statement of Reish Lakish that this is his opinion. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (68b): <b>One may not bring a meal offering, the first fruits, or the meal offering</b> brought with the libations accompanying <b>an animal</b> offering, from the new crop, <b>prior to</b> the sacrifice of <b>the <i>omer</i>.</b> The Gemara interrupts its citation of the mishna to add that the reason is <b>that we require</b> that an offering be <b>“from the well-watered pastures of Israel,”</b> i.e., it must be brought from that which is permitted to the Jewish people, and the new crop has not yet been permitted to them. The mishna concludes: <b>And if he brought</b> these offerings from the new crop they are <b>unfit.</b>
The mishna continues: After the <i>omer</i> but <b>prior to the two loaves one may not bring</b> those offerings from the new crop. The Gemara explains that this is <b>because</b> the two loaves <b>are called first fruits,</b> and therefore they should precede all other offerings from the new crop. The mishna adds: <b>But if he brought</b> those offerings from the new crop, they are <b>fit.</b>
<b>And Rav Yitzḥak says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that a meal offering that was brought from the new crop before the <i>omer</i> meal offering is disqualified <b>only</b> if it was brought <b>on the fourteenth or on the fifteenth</b> of Nisan. <b>But</b> if it was <b>on the sixteenth,</b> then even <b>if he brought</b> it prior to the <i>omer</i> meal offering, it is <b>valid.</b> He continues: <b>And</b> this statement poses <b>a difficulty for me:</b> Why should meal offerings be valid when sacrificed on the sixteenth if they were sacrificed before the <i>omer</i> meal offering? <b>Let them be</b> considered <b>like</b> offerings <b>whose time has not yet</b> arrived. The Gemara comments: <b>Apparently,</b> Reish Lakish <b>holds</b> that <b>the illumination of the eastern</b> horizon <b>permits</b> the new crop.
§ The Gemara previously cited the opinion of Rav that an <i>omer</i> meal offering from which a handful was removed not for its own sake is disqualified. The Gemara also cited the opinion of Reish Lakish that this meal offering is valid but another <i>omer</i> meal offering is necessary to permit the new crop for consumption. <b>And Rava says:</b> With regard to <b>an <i>omer</i> meal offering</b> from <b>which</b> the priest <b>removed a handful not for its own sake,</b> it is <b>valid and its remainder is consumed, and it does not require another <i>omer</i> meal offering to permit it</b> for consumption. The reason is <b>that</b> improper <b>intent is effective [<i>mo’elet</i>]</b> to disqualify an offering <b>only</b> when it is expressed <b>by one who is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service, and with regard to an item that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service, and in a place that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service.</b>
Rava elaborates: The condition that improper intent disqualifies only when expressed <b>by one who is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> the intent of <b>a blemished priest,</b> who is disqualified from performing the Temple service. The condition that it disqualifies only when expressed <b>with regard to an item that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service</b> serves <b>to exclude the <i>omer</i> meal offering, which</b> is generally <b>unfit</b> for the Temple service, <b>as it is a novelty,</b> in that it is brought from barley whereas most meal offerings are brought from wheat. <b>And</b> finally, the condition that it disqualifies only when expressed <b>in a place that is fit for the</b> Temple <b>service</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> sacrificial rites that were performed with improper intent while <b>the altar was damaged.</b> At such a time improper intent does not disqualify an offering, and therefore if the altar is repaired on the same day, the offering may be sacrificed upon the altar.
