§ The Gemara discusses the prohibition against sacrificing an item that is prohibited to the Jewish people. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is derived from a passage in the Torah that discusses burnt offerings: “You shall bring your offering from the cattle, even from the herd or from the flock” (Leviticus 1:2), that certain animals are prohibited for sacrifice upon the altar (see <i>Temura</i> 28a). <b>When it states later,</b> in the next verse: “If his offering is a burnt offering <b>of the herd”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), this is difficult, <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this, as it was already written earlier. <b>Rather,</b> this serves <b>to exclude an animal with a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>]</b> from being brought as an offering.
The <i>baraita</i> questions the need for this derivation: <b>But could this not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference? And if a blemished</b> animal, <b>which is permitted to an ordinary person [<i>lehedyot</i>]</b> for consumption, is nevertheless <b>prohibited</b> as an offering <b>for the Most High</b> (see Leviticus 22:19), then certainly with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, which is forbidden to an ordinary person</b> for consumption (see Exodus 22:30), <b>is it not logical that it is prohibited for the Most High?</b> The <i>baraita</i> responds: <b>Fat [<i>ḥelev</i>] and blood prove</b> that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference is not valid, <b>as they are forbidden to an ordinary person and</b> yet <b>they are permitted for the Most High.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> rejects this suggestion: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about fat and blood?</b> They are notable <b>in that they come from</b> an item that is <b>generally permitted,</b> i.e., the animal from which they come is itself permitted for consumption. Will <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, which is entirely forbidden</b> for eating, <b>and</b> therefore <b>should not be permitted for the Most High?</b>
The <i>baraita</i> responds: The <b>pinching</b> of bird offerings <b>will prove</b> that one cannot derive by means of an <i>a fortiori</i> inference that a <i>tereifa</i> is disqualified. <b>As</b> a bird killed by the pinching of its nape is also <b>entirely forbidden, and</b> yet although it is <b>forbidden</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person,</b> as it is rendered a carcass, it is nevertheless <b>permitted for the Most High,</b> as bird offerings are killed by the pinching of their napes. The verse is therefore necessary to disqualify a <i>tereifa</i>.
The <i>baraita</i> rejects this suggestion as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about pinching?</b> It is notable <b>in that its sanctity prohibits it,</b> i.e., only <b>at the time</b> when <b>it</b> becomes <b>sanctified for the altar</b> does <b>it</b> become <b>prohibited</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person, which is</b> at the time of <b>its pinching. But before this</b> time it is <b>not</b> yet <b>prohibited to an ordinary person</b> for consumption. This <b>is not the case with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, as its sanctity does not prohibit it</b> for consumption, since it is always prohibited to eat it. Accordingly, by logical inference alone one can arrive at the conclusion that a <i>tereifa</i> should not be permitted for the Most High.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes with a statement that will soon be explained: <b>And if you have responded,</b> i.e., if you succeeded in rejecting the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, then <b>when</b> the verse <b>states later: “Of the herd”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> this phrase, it serves <b>to exclude a <i>tereifa</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> response is alluded to by the statement: <b>If you have responded?</b> The conclusion of the <i>baraita</i> had indicated that the <i>a fortiori</i> inference must be accepted. The Gemara cites several suggestions, for which it provides the following <b>mnemonic: <i>Rekiaḥ</i>, <i>Mar</i>, <i>Adda</i>, <i>Leshisheih</i>.</b> These terms allude to the names of some of the Sages mentioned in the following discussion: Rav; Rabbi Akiva; Rav Aḥa; Mar, son of Ravina; Rav Adda; and Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi.
<b>Rav said</b> that this is the response: The <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice must be derived from a verse <b>because it may be said</b> that <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering proves</b> that the <i>halakha</i> concerning a <i>tereifa</i> cannot be derived by the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as</b> the <i>omer</i> is <b>prohibited</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person,</b> since it comes from the new crop, <b>and</b> yet it is <b>permitted</b> as an offering <b>for the Most High.</b> The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about the <i>omer</i> meal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>renders</b> the <b>new</b> crop <b>permitted</b> for consumption, whereas a <i>tereifa</i> does not render anything permitted.
The Gemara responds: Although the <i>omer</i> meal offering generally renders the new crop permitted, the <i>omer</i> brought <b>during a Sabbatical Year</b> does not render the crop permitted, as it is prohibited to plant during the Sabbatical Year, and consequently there is no new crop for the <i>omer</i> offering to permit. The Gemara counters this suggestion: The <i>omer</i> meal offering brought during <b>a Sabbatical Year also</b> renders something permitted, <b>as it permits produce that grew without being purposely planted [<i>sefiḥin</i>] during the Sabbatical Year.</b> The Gemara responds: Nevertheless, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that <b><i>sefiḥin</i> are prohibited during the Sabbatical Year,</b> the <i>omer</i> meal offering brought during a Sabbatical Year does not render the new crop permitted for consumption, and yet it is permitted for the Most High. A verse is therefore necessary to derive that a <i>tereifa</i> may not be sacrificed.
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Abba said to Rav Ashi: According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva as well, let us refute</b> the statement of Rav, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about the <i>omer</i> meal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>permits</b> the <b>new</b> crop for consumption <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, where the prohibitions of the Sabbatical Year do not apply.
<b>And even according to the one who says</b> that the consumption of produce from the <b>new</b> crop grown <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael is <b>not</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law,</b> Rav’s statement can be refuted in another manner: What is notable about the <i>omer</i> meal offering? It is notable <b>in that</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>comes to permit a prohibition</b> that applies to a substance <b>that</b> was previously <b>within it,</b> i.e., the burning upon the altar of a handful from the <i>omer</i> meal offering renders the remainder of the meal offering permitted to the priests, whereas a <i>tereifa</i> is entirely forbidden.
<b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina:</b> This is not a refutation, as, <b>if that is so,</b> then with regard to <b>a <i>tereifa</i> as well, you should sacrifice</b> it <b>and you will</b> thereby <b>permit a prohibition</b> that applies to a substance <b>that</b> was previously <b>within it,</b> and its meat will become permitted to the priests for consumption. Therefore, a verse is needed to exclude a <i>tereifa</i>. <b>Rather,</b> one can <b>refute</b> the statement of Rav <b>like this: What</b> is notable <b>about the <i>omer</i> meal offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that its mitzva is in this</b> manner, i.e., the Torah requires the <i>omer</i> meal offering to be brought from the new crop in order to permit the new crop for consumption. By contrast, there is no mitzva to sacrifice specifically a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Reish Lakish said</b> that this is the response alluded to at the end of the <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice must be derived from a verse <b>because it can be said</b> that <b>the one who prepares the incense proves</b> that the <i>halakha</i> concerning a <i>tereifa</i> may not be derived by the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as</b> this is <b>prohibited to an ordinary person, and</b> is nevertheless <b>permitted for the Most High.</b> The Gemara questions the terminology of Reish Lakish: But <b>the one who prepares</b> the incense <b>is a person.</b> How can it be said that a person is prohibited to an ordinary person?
<b>Rather,</b> Reish Lakish meant that <b>the preparation of the incense proves</b> it, <b>as</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to prepare the incense mixture for use <b>by an ordinary person</b> (see Exodus 30:37), <b>and</b> yet it is <b>permitted</b> to do so <b>for the Most High.</b> The Gemara refutes this claim: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about preparation of the incense?</b> It is notable <b>in that its mitzva is in this</b> manner. By contrast, there is no mitzva to sacrifice specifically a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Mar, son of Ravina, said</b> that this is the response of the <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice must be derived from a verse <b>because it can be said</b> that <b>Shabbat proves</b> that the <i>halakha</i> concerning a <i>tereifa</i> cannot be derived by the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as it is prohibited for an ordinary person</b> to perform labor on Shabbat, <b>and</b> yet the labor involved in the Temple service is <b>permitted</b> on Shabbat <b>for the Most High.</b> Without the verse, one might similarly conclude that a <i>tereifa</i> is permitted for the Most High despite the fact that it is prohibited for consumption.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about Shabbat?</b> It is notable <b>in that the general prohibition</b> against labor on Shabbat <b>was permitted with regard to an ordinary person in</b> the case of <b>circumcision,</b> as the mitzva of circumcision must be performed in its proper time, even on Shabbat, despite the fact that the act of circumcision is generally prohibited on Shabbat.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>circumcision is</b> considered <b>a requirement of an ordinary person,</b> whose performance was exempted from the general prohibition against labor on Shabbat for one’s private needs? <b>Circumcision is a mitzva. Rather,</b> the statement of Mar, son of Ravina, can be refuted like this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about Shabbat?</b> It is notable <b>in that its mitzva is in this</b> manner, i.e., the Torah requires that offerings be brought on Shabbat. By contrast, there is no mitzva to sacrifice specifically a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Adda bar Abba said</b> that this is the response mentioned in the <i>baraita</i>: The <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice must be derived from a verse <b>because it can be said</b> that the prohibition against <b>diverse kinds proves</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of a <i>tereifa</i> cannot be derived from the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, <b>as it is prohibited for an ordinary person</b> to wear garments sewn from a mixture of diverse kinds (Deuteronomy 22:11), <b>and</b> yet such garments are <b>permitted for the Most High,</b> as the belt of the priestly vestments was fashioned from a mixture of diverse kinds.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> the prohibition against <b>diverse kinds?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the <b>general prohibition</b> against wearing a garment sewn from diverse kinds <b>was permitted in</b> the case of <b>an ordinary person with regard to ritual fringes,</b> as a string of sky-blue wool must be placed on a four-cornered garment even if that garment is made from linen. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>ritual fringes</b> are considered <b>a requirement of an ordinary person,</b> whose performance was exempted from the general prohibition concerning diverse kinds with regard to one’s private needs? Placing ritual fringes on a garment <b>is a mitzva. Rather,</b> the claim of Rav Adda bar Abba can be refuted like this:

Daf 6a

<b>What</b> is notable <b>about diverse kinds?</b> It is notable <b>in that its mitzva is in this</b> manner, since the belt of the priestly vestments must be sewn from diverse kinds. By contrast, there is no mitzva to sacrifice specifically a <i>tereifa</i>.
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice must be derived from the verse, <b>because it can be said: Let</b> this claim <b>be derived by</b> analogy from <b>the common element</b> of two sources, as follows: With regard to the question of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about pinching?</b> It is notable <b>in that its sanctity prohibits it,</b> one can respond: <b>Fat and blood prove</b> that this consideration is not enough to reject the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as these are prohibited before they are sanctified and are nevertheless permitted for the Most High.
Similarly, with regard to the question: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about fat and blood?</b> They are notable <b>in that they come from</b> an item that is <b>generally permitted,</b> i.e., the animal from which they come is itself permitted for consumption, one can reply: <b>Pinching proves</b> that this consideration is insufficient for a rejection of the <i>a fortiori</i> inference, as a bird that was killed by pinching is entirely prohibited for eating, and yet a pinched bird is permitted to the altar.
Rav Sheisha concludes: <b>And</b> accordingly, <b>the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case; <b>their common element</b> is <b>that they are prohibited</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person and are</b> nevertheless <b>permitted for the Most High.</b> Therefore, <b>I will also bring</b> the case of <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> and say: <b>Even though is it prohibited</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person, it should be permitted for the Most High.</b> It is therefore necessary to derive from a verse that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice. The Gemara rejects this: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable in <b>that</b> with regard to fat and blood, and pinching, in both cases <b>its mitzva</b> is performed <b>in this</b> manner.
<b>Rather, Rav Ashi said:</b> It is necessary to derive the <i>halakha</i> of a <i>tereifa</i> from a verse <b>because one can say</b> that the <b>refutation of the</b> <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference</b> is present <b>from the outset.</b> Rav Ashi elaborates: <b>From where do you</b> wish to <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice? You wish to derive it from an <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>from</b> the case of <b>a blemished</b> animal, as a blemished animal is permitted for consumption and prohibited for sacrifice. This is problematic.
Rav Ashi explains: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a blemished</b> animal? It is notable <b>in that with regard to</b> blemishes the Torah <b>rendered those who sacrifice like that which is sacrificed,</b> i.e., a blemished priest may not sacrifice an offering just as a blemished animal is unfit for sacrifice (see Leviticus, chapter 22). This cannot be said with regard to a <i>tereifa</i>, as a priest with a wound that will cause him to die within twelve months may perform the Temple service. It is therefore necessary to derive from the verse the fact that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice.
<b>Rav Aḥa Sava said to Rav Ashi:</b> But an animal <b>born by caesarean section proves</b> that this <i>a fortiori</i> inference cannot be rejected based on that consideration, <b>as with regard to it</b> the Torah <b>did not render those who sacrifice like that which is sacrificed,</b> since an animal born by caesarean section is unfit for sacrifice whereas a priest born in such a manner may perform the Temple service. <b>And</b> yet an animal born by caesarean section is <b>permitted</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person and prohibited for the Most High.</b> If so, one cannot reject the <i>a fortiori</i> inference because with regard to blemishes the Torah rendered those who sacrifice like that which is sacrificed. Why then is a verse necessary in order to derive that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit?
Rav Ashi responds: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about</b> an animal <b>born by caesarean section?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> such an animal <b>is not sanctified with firstborn</b> status, whereas a firstborn animal that was born as a <i>tereifa</i> is sanctified. Accordingly, without the verse one might have concluded that a <i>tereifa</i> may be sacrificed.
Rav Aḥa Sava answers: <b>A blemished</b> animal <b>proves</b> that this is not the decisive consideration, as it does become sanctified with the sanctity of a firstborn, and it too is permitted for consumption and prohibited for the Most High. And if you say: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a blemished</b> animal? It is notable <b>in that with regard to it</b> the Torah <b>rendered those who sacrifice like that which is sacrificed,</b> one can respond: An animal <b>born by caesarean section proves</b> that this consideration is not decisive, as a priest born by caesarean section may perform the Temple service.
Rav Aḥa Sava concludes: <b>And</b> therefore, <b>the inference has reverted</b> to its starting point. <b>The aspect of this</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of that</b> case <b>and the aspect of that</b> case <b>is not like the aspect of this</b> case; <b>their common element</b> is <b>that they are permitted</b> for consumption <b>to an ordinary person and prohibited for the Most High. And all the more so a <i>tereifa</i>, which is prohibited to an ordinary person, should be prohibited for the Most High.</b> If so, the derivation from a verse is unnecessary.
Rav Ashi refutes the proof of Rav Aḥa Sava: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that their general prohibition was not permitted,</b> since blemished animals and those born by caesarean section are never permitted for sacrifice. <b>Will you say</b> that the same applies <b>to a <i>tereifa</i>, whose general prohibition was permitted,</b> as will be explained? Accordingly, it is necessary to derive from the verse that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> This <b><i>tereifa</i> whose general prohibition was permitted, what is it,</b> i.e., to what case is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to the <b>pinching of a bird burnt offering for the Most High,</b> whereby the bird is initially rendered a <i>tereifa</i> at the start of the pinching process, and nevertheless it is sacrificed upon the altar, then the same may be said of <b>a blemished</b> animal <b>as well.</b> As <b>with regard to birds</b> it is <b>permitted</b> to sacrifice a blemished bird. This is in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> that the requirement that an offering must be <b>unblemished and male</b> applies <b>to animal</b> offerings, <b>but there is no</b> requirement that an offering must be <b>unblemished and male in</b> the case of <b>bird</b> offerings.
<b>Rather,</b> this permitting the general prohibition found in the context of a <i>tereifa</i> is referring to the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>pinching of a bird sin offering</b> renders it permitted <b>to the priests</b> for consumption despite the fact that it was not slaughtered by cutting its neck with a knife. This claim can be refuted as well, as the <b>priests receive</b> their portion <b>from the table of the Most High,</b> i.e., they may partake of the sin offering only because it was permitted for sacrifice upon the altar. Accordingly, there is no difference between a <i>tereifa</i> due to pinching and a blemished bird, as both were released from their general prohibition in this regard, since both are permitted for sacrifice upon the altar and both are therefore permitted for consumption by the priests. Consequently, the <i>a fortiori</i> inference remains valid, and the verse is unnecessary.
<b>Rather, refute</b> the <i>a fortiori</i> inference <b>like this: What</b> is notable <b>about their common element?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> with regard to both a blemished animal and one born by caesarean section <b>their blemish is noticeable,</b> as a blemished animal is visibly blemished and it is well known when an animal is born by caesarean section. <b>Will you say</b> that they can serve as the source of the <i>halakha</i> <b>of a <i>tereifa</i>, whose blemish is not</b> necessarily <b>noticeable? Due to that</b> reason, <b>the verse:</b> “Of the herd” (Leviticus 1:3), <b>was necessary,</b> to teach that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for sacrifice.
§ After trying to prove why a derivation from a verse is necessary, the Gemara questions the very source provided by the <i>baraita</i> on 5b for the disqualification of a <i>tereifa</i>, i.e., the verse: “Of the herd” (Leviticus 1:3). <b>But</b> is the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a <i>tereifa</i></b> is unfit for sacrifice <b>derived from here? It is derived from there,</b> i.e., from the verse: <b>“From the well-watered pastures of Israel”</b> (Ezekiel 45:15), from which it is derived that an offering may be brought only <b>from</b> that <b>which is permitted to the Jewish people.</b>
Alternatively, this <i>halakha</i> can be <b>derived from</b> a verse discussing animal tithe offerings: <b>“Whatever passes under the rod,</b> the tenth shall be holy for the Lord” (Leviticus 27:32). This teaches that all animals may be sacrificed as the animal tithe, <b>excluding a <i>tereifa</i>, as it does not pass</b> under the rod on account of its weakness, and the Sages derived from this the <i>halakha</i> that a <i>tereifa</i> is unfit for any type of offering.
The Gemara responds: All of these verses <b>are necessary, because if</b> the disqualification of a <i>tereifa</i> was derived <b>from</b> the verse <b>“the well-watered pastures of Israel,” I would say</b> that this verse serves <b>to exclude</b> a <i>tereifa</i> only in a case <b>where it did not have a period of fitness,</b> e.g., if it was born a <i>tereifa</i> and was therefore never fit for sacrifice. This is <b>similar to</b> the case of <b>the fruit of a tree during the first three years after its planting [<i>orla</i>] and diverse kinds</b> planted <b>in a vineyard,</b> whose disqualification is derived from this verse. <b>But</b> with regard to a <i>tereifa</i> that <b>had a period of fitness,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>it should be fit.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Whatever passes</b> under the rod,” to teach that all animals that do not pass under the rod are unfit for sacrifice, even if they were once fit.
The Gemara continues: <b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“Whatever passes</b> under the rod,” <b>I would say</b> that this verse serves <b>to exclude</b> a <i>tereifa</i> only <b>where it was rendered a <i>tereifa</i> and</b> its owner <b>subsequently sanctified it.</b> This is <b>similar to</b> the case of animal <b>tithes,</b> as this verse is teaching that a <i>tereifa</i> cannot be subsequently sanctified as a tithe. <b>But</b> if the owner <b>sanctified it and it was subsequently rendered a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> which means <b>that at the time when it was sanctified it was fit,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>it should be fit.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One wrote: “Of the herd,”</b> to teach that even an animal that became a <i>tereifa</i> after it was already sanctified is unfit for sacrifice. Accordingly, all three verses <b>are necessary.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>Both the meal offering of a sinner and all</b> other <b>meal offerings</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the one who <b>removed their handful</b> was <b>a non-priest,</b> or a priest who was <b>an acute mourner,</b> i.e., whose relative died and was not yet buried, or a priest who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and was waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed, or a priest <b>lacking</b> the requisite priestly <b>vestments,</b> or a priest <b>who had not yet</b> brought <b>an atonement</b> offering to complete the purification process, or a priest <b>who did not wash his hands and feet</b> from the water in the Basin prior to performing the Temple service, or <b>an uncircumcised</b> priest, or <b>a ritually impure</b> priest, or a priest who removed the handful while <b>sitting,</b> or while <b>standing</b> not on the floor of the Temple but <b>upon vessels,</b> or <b>upon an animal,</b> or <b>upon the feet of another</b> person; in all these cases the meal offerings are <b>unfit</b> for sacrifice.
If the priest <b>removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand the meal offering is <b>unfit. Ben Beteira says: He must return</b> the handful to the vessel that contains the meal offering <b>and again remove the handful,</b> this time <b>with</b> his <b>right</b> hand.
If a priest <b>removed the handful</b> of flour, <b>and a stone, a grain of salt, or a pinch [<i>koret</i>] of frankincense emerged in his hand,</b> the meal offering is <b>unfit due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Sages <b>said: The handful that is outsized or that is lacking</b> is <b>unfit.</b> The existence of one of these foreign items in the handful means that the requisite measure of flour is lacking. <b>And which is the outsized</b> handful? It is one <b>where he removed the handful overflowing [<i>mevoratz</i>]</b> in a manner in which his fingers do not hold the flour. <b>And</b> which is the <b>lacking</b> handful? It is one <b>where he removed the handful with the tips of his fingers.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach: Both the meal offering of a sinner and all</b> other <b>meal offerings? Let it teach: All the meal offerings</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the one who <b>removed their handful</b> was <b>a non-priest or an acute mourner.</b> Why does the mishna single out the case of the meal offering of a sinner?
The Gemara responds: <b>It was necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this <i>halakha</i> in this manner <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: By right the meal offering of a sinner should require oil and frankincense</b> like other meal offerings, <b>so that</b> the <b>sinner will not profit. And for what</b> reason does <b>it not require</b> oil and frankincense? So <b>that his offering will not be of superior quality. And</b> likewise, <b>by right</b> the <b>sin offering of</b> forbidden <b>fat,</b> i.e., the offering brought by one who unwittingly ate the forbidden fat of a domesticated animal, <b>should require libations</b>

Daf 6b

<b>so that</b> the <b>sinner will not profit. And for what</b> reason <b>does</b> his offering <b>not require</b> libations? So <b>that his offering will not be of superior quality.</b> Accordingly, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In order <b>that his offering will not be of superior quality, when the handful is removed</b> by one of those <b>unfit</b> for performing the Temple service, the offering <b>should also be valid,</b> as it too is of inferior quality. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> the <i>halakha</i> in a manner that emphasizes that even according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon the meal offering of a sinner is disqualified when the handful is removed by one who is unfit.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then <b>there as well,</b> i.e., with regard to slaughtered offerings, <b>let</b> the mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 15b) <b>teach: Both the sin offering of</b> forbidden <b>fat and all the slaughtered offerings</b> with regard to <b>which</b> the one who <b>collected their blood</b> was <b>a non-priest or</b> a priest who is <b>an acute mourner,</b> are disqualified. <b>And let us say</b> that <b>it was necessary</b> to teach the mishna in this manner <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> to emphasize that although the sin offering is not of superior quality, in that it does not require that libations be brought with it, nevertheless it is disqualified if its blood was collected by one unfit for Temple service. Why then does that mishna teach simply: All the slaughtered offerings with regard to which the one who collected their blood was a non-priest are disqualified?
The Gemara concludes its question: <b>Apparently, since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> that mishna with the term: <b>All, and he does not teach: Except, all</b> offerings <b>are indicated</b> by the general disqualification, and there is no need to emphasize the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a sin offering, even in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to meal offerings, <b>since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches</b> the mishna with the term: <b>All, and he does not teach: Except,</b> this means that <b>all of them are indicated,</b> even the meal offering of a sinner. Why then does the mishna specifically mention the meal offering of a sinner?
The Gemara explains: <b>It was necessary</b> to teach the mishna in this manner as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since I have established that the first clause,</b> i.e., the mishna on 2a, is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon,</b> with regard to <b>the last clause as well,</b> i.e., the mishna here, it may be concluded <b>that</b> it is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon.</b> Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this manner, to emphasize that it is in accordance with his opinion.
§ <b>Rav says:</b> In the case of <b>a non-priest who removed a handful, he should return</b> the handful to the meal offering. The Gemara challenges: <b>But we learned</b> in the mishna that a non-priest <b>disqualified</b> the meal offering by removing a handful from it. The Gemara responds: <b>What</b> does the mishna mean when it says: <b>Disqualified?</b> It means that the non-priest has <b>disqualified</b> the meal offering <b>until</b> such time as <b>he returns</b> the handful to the meal offering, whereupon a priest fit for the Temple service should again remove a handful from the meal offering and sacrifice it.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> then <b>this is</b> identical to the opinion of <b>ben Beteira</b> in the mishna, who says that if a priest removed a handful with his left hand it is returned to the meal offering whereupon the priest removes a handful from the offering with his right hand. What difference is there between the two opinions in the mishna? The Gemara explains: <b>If the handful</b> that was removed by one unfit for Temple service <b>is in its unadulterated form,</b> then <b>the Rabbis do not disagree with</b> the opinion of <b>ben Beteira,</b> and the handful is returned to the meal offering. <b>They disagree when</b> the <b>handful is lacking. The Rabbis hold: One does not bring</b> flour <b>from within his house and refill</b> the vessel containing the handful, whereas <b>ben Beteira holds</b> that <b>one brings</b> flour <b>from within his house and refills it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if the mishna is referring to a handful that is lacking, then the statement of the mishna: <b>Ben Beteira says he must return</b> the handful to the vessel with the meal offering <b>and again remove a handful with</b> his <b>right</b> hand, is imprecise, as the mishna <b>should have</b> taught: <b>Ben Beteira says he must return</b> the handful to the vessel with the meal offering <b>and bring</b> flour <b>from within his house and refill</b> the missing amount, <b>and again remove a handful with</b> his <b>right</b> hand.
The Gemara therefore suggests a different answer: <b>When Rav said</b> that the handful is returned to the meal offering, he said this only <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Beteira.</b> The Gemara asks: But isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that this is the opinion of ben Beteira? The Gemara responds: Rav’s statement is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>ben Beteira deems</b> the meal offering <b>fit only</b> when the handful was removed <b>with</b> one’s <b>left</b> hand, <b>but with regard to other disqualifications,</b> he does <b>not</b> deem it fit. Therefore, Rav <b>teaches us</b> that with regard to all of the disqualifications cited in the mishna, ben Beteira holds that the handful is returned to the meal offering whereupon a new handful is removed from it and sacrificed upon the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is different</b> in the case of a handful removed with a priest’s <b>left</b> hand that one might have thought that ben Beteira’s opinion applies only in this case? Perhaps the reason is <b>that we find</b> that the Temple service performed with the priest’s left hand is <b>fit on Yom Kippur,</b> i.e., when the High Priest would enter the Holy of Holies holding the vessel containing the incense in his left hand. But with regard to <b>a non-priest as well, we find</b> that the Temple service is <b>fit with regard to slaughter,</b> as an offering may be slaughtered by a non-priest. Why then is it necessary for Rav to teach that the opinion of ben Beteira applies to the case of a non-priest as well?
The Gemara responds: <b>Slaughter is not</b> considered a sacrificial <b>rite,</b> and it is for that reason that a non-priest may slaughter an offering. Accordingly, without the statement of Rav one would not have concluded that ben Beteira holds that a handful removed by a non-priest may be returned, as the Temple service is never fit when performed by a non-priest.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is slaughter really <b>not</b> considered a sacrificial rite? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say</b> that <b>Rav says: The slaughter of</b> a red <b>heifer by a non-priest</b> is <b>not valid? And Rav said with regard to this</b> <i>halakha</i>: This is because both the term: <b>“Elazar</b> the priest” (Numbers 19:3), <b>and</b> the term: <b>“Statute”</b> (Numbers 19:2), <b>are written in</b> the Torah’s description of the slaughter of the red heifer. The term “statute” indicates that if one deviates from any of the details of the service as delineated in the verses, the service is not valid. The Gemara answers: The <i>halakhot</i> of the red <b>heifer are different, as</b> the heifer <b>is</b> considered <b>sanctified for</b> the purpose of <b>Temple maintenance,</b> not for sacrifice upon the altar. Accordingly, one cannot derive from the case of the red heifer that the slaughter of an offering is considered a sacrificial rite.
The Gemara asks: <b>But is it not all the more so?</b> If items <b>sanctified for</b> the purpose of <b>Temple maintenance require</b> that the performance of rites relevant to them be performed by a member of the <b>priesthood,</b> then with regard to items <b>sanctified for</b> sacrifice upon the <b>altar, shouldn’t they</b> certainly <b>require</b> that their rites be performed by a member of the <b>priesthood? Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said</b> in response: The requirement that the red heifer be slaughtered by a priest is not proof that its slaughter is a sacrificial rite. Rather, that requirement is <b>just as it is in</b> the case of examination of the <b>shades of</b> leprous <b>marks, which is</b> obviously <b>not</b> considered a sacrificial <b>rite, and</b> yet the Torah <b>requires</b> that these marks be examined by a member of the <b>priesthood.</b>
The Gemara asks: Nevertheless, why was it necessary for Rav to teach that the removal of a handful by a non-priest does not disqualify the meal offering according to ben Beteira? <b>Let us derive</b> it <b>from</b> the fact that there was a period of fitness for rites performed by a non-priest, as before the construction of the Temple it was permitted for non-priests to sacrifice offerings upon a private <b>altar.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>we do not derive</b> <i>halakhot</i> of the rites performed in the Temple <b>from</b> those performed on a private <b>altar,</b> one can respond: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived with regard to an item, e.g., the limbs of an offering, <b>that emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard and was thereby rendered unfit for sacrifice upon the altar, <b>that if</b> it nevertheless <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall not descend?</b> It is derived from the fact <b>that</b> an item that <b>emerged is valid</b> for sacrifice <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> This indicates that one can learn the <i>halakhot</i> of offerings in the Temple from the <i>halakhot</i> of a private altar.
The Gemara rejects this: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>relies on</b> the verse: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:2), from which it is derived that any item that ascends upon the altar shall not descend from it, even if it was disqualified. In other words, the verse is the source for the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, whereas the case of a private altar is cited merely as a support for this ruling.
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, the reason</b> it is known that ben Beteira permits the return to the meal offering of a handful removed by a non-priest is <b>that Rav taught us</b> so. Were it <b>not</b> for <b>this, I would say</b> that <b>with regard to other disqualifications,</b> i.e., other than a handful removed with the left hand, <b>ben Beteira invalidates</b> the meal offering. <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> both <b>say: Ben Beteira would deem fit in</b> the case of <b>all the</b> other <b>disqualifications</b> listed in the mishna?
The Gemara continues: <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons the priests; <b>and he shall remove from there</b> his handful” (Leviticus 2:2), that this verse indicates that the removal of a handful from a meal offering may be performed <b>from the place where the feet of the non-priest stand,</b> i.e., anywhere within the Temple courtyard.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Ben Beteira says</b> that the verse should be interpreted as follows: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> one <b>removed a handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>that he must return</b> the handful to the vessel with the meal offering <b>and again remove the handful with</b> his <b>right</b> hand? It is derived from that which <b>the verse states: “And he shall remove from there,”</b> indicating that the handful is removed <b>from the place where he already removed</b> it, i.e., the handful is returned to the meal offering and thereupon removed from the same meal offering with the right hand. This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains the difficulty from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And since the verse is written</b> in an <b>unspecified</b> manner, i.e., it does not mention which handfuls are returned, <b>what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the handful was removed with the <b>left</b> hand, <b>and what</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if it was removed by means of one of <b>the other disqualifications?</b>
The Gemara therefore suggests an alternative explanation: <b>Rather, this</b> is what <b>Rav teaches us:</b> Ben Beteira holds that if one unfit for Temple service <b>removed a handful</b> it may be returned to the meal offering <b>even</b> if <b>he sanctified</b> the handful by placing it in a service vessel. <b>And</b> the statement of Rav serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of these <i>tanna’im</i>: As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei ben Yosei ben Yasiyyan and Rabbi Yehuda the baker said: In what</b> case <b>is this statement</b> of ben Beteira <b>said,</b> i.e., in which case does he rule that the handful may be returned to the meal offering? It is in a case <b>where</b> the unfit individual <b>removed a handful and did not sanctify</b> it by placing it inside a service vessel. <b>But</b> if <b>he sanctified</b> it then <b>he</b> has <b>disqualified</b> it, even according to ben Beteira, and it may not be returned to the meal offering.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Rav teaches the opposite, that if an unfit person merely <b>removed a handful, yes,</b> ben Beteira permits such a handful to be returned to the meal offering from which it was removed, but if he already <b>sanctified</b> the handful by placing it inside a service vessel, it may <b>not</b> be returned. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this explanation? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>these <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei ben Yosei ben Yasiyyan and Rabbi Yehuda the baker, <b>and</b> it is <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of the first <i>tanna</i></b> in that <i>baraita</i>, who disagrees with the ruling of Rabbi Yosei ben Yosei ben Yasiyyan and Rabbi Yehuda the baker and maintains that a handful may be returned even after it was sanctified by a service vessel.
<b>Rav Naḥman objects to this: What do these <i>tanna’im</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>hold? If</b> they hold that <b>the removal of a handful by</b> one <b>unfit</b> for Temple service <b>is</b> considered the performance of a sacrificial <b>rite</b> to the extent that it disqualifies the offering, then the meal offering should be disqualified <b>even though he did not perform</b> the stage of the <b>placement</b> of the handful <b>in a vessel.</b> And <b>if</b> they hold that <b>the removal of a handful by an unfit</b> individual <b>is not</b> considered the performance of a <b>rite,</b> then <b>when he performed</b> the stage of <b>its placement in a vessel, what</b> significance <b>was</b> there to this action? He can still return the handful to the meal offering.
<b>Rav Naḥman</b> reconsidered and <b>then said: Actually,</b> those <i>tanna’im</i> hold that the removal of a handful by one unfit for Temple service <b>is</b> considered the performance of a sacrificial <b>rite, but the rite of</b> the handful <b>is not complete until he performs</b> the stage of <b>its placement in a vessel.</b> Consequently, the meal offering is disqualified only after a person unfit for Temple service places the handful inside a service vessel.
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so,</b> i.e., if the placement of the handful inside a service vessel completes the rite that begins with the handful’s removal, then <b>even</b> if the handful was removed by an unfit individual who has <b>not</b> yet <b>sanctified</b> it in the service vessel designated for the handful,

Daf 7a

<b>when he returns the handful to its</b> former <b>place</b> in the service vessel that contains the meal offering <b>it should become sanctified,</b> as it is now placed inside a service vessel, <b>and it should</b> therefore <b>become disqualified.</b> It should not matter whether the handful was placed in the vessel designated for it, or back in the same vessel it was taken from.
Concerning this challenge, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said: That is to say</b> that <b>service vessels sanctify</b> items placed in them <b>only</b> when they are placed there <b>with</b> specific <b>intent</b> that they be sanctified by that vessel. Since the priest does not return the handful to the vessel containing the meal offering with such intent, the handful is not disqualified, because the rite was not completed.
The Gemara asks: It may be inferred from this statement that if items are placed into service vessels <b>with intent,</b> the service vessels <b>sanctify</b> them. <b>But</b> didn’t <b>Reish Lakish raise a dilemma before Rabbi Yoḥanan: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>service vessels,</b> i.e., do they <b>sanctify disqualified</b> items to the extent that they may be <b>sacrificed</b> upon the altar <b><i>ab initio</i>? And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him</b> that <b>they do not sanctify</b> the items. The Gemara responds: This is what Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: They do not sanctify</b> the disqualified items that are placed inside them <b>to</b> the extent that they may be <b>sacrificed, but they</b> do <b>sanctify</b> them <b>to</b> the extent <b>that</b> they <b>are disqualified.</b>
<b>Rav Amram says:</b> Even if service vessels sanctify items without specific intent, it is possible to return the handful to the meal offering without the vessel sanctifying the handful, <b>such as</b> in a case <b>where he returned it to a heaped bowl [<i>levisa</i>],</b> i.e., he placed the handful upon the heap of flour in such a manner that the handful did not enter the airspace of the vessel containing the meal offering. Consequently, the handful is not sanctified by the vessel.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if the meal offering was heaped, <b>how</b> was he initially able to <b>remove a handful</b> from it? The handful must initially be removed from within a vessel. <b>Rather,</b> it is possible to return the handful without sanctifying it in a case <b>where he returned it to a full [<i>tefufa</i>] bowl,</b> i.e., it was full to the brim but not heaped. When the priest initially removes a handful from such a vessel, he removes it from inside the vessel, but when it is returned, it does not enter the airspace of the vessel.
The Gemara asks: <b>But once he removed a handful, he formed a furrow</b> in the surface of the meal offering, and therefore <b>when he returns</b> the handful to its previous place inside the vessel, <b>he is</b> in fact <b>returning it to</b> a spot <b>within the vessel,</b> i.e., the furrow. If so, the handful should be sanctified to the extent that the vessel disqualifies it. The Gemara responds: <b>When he returns it</b> to the vessel containing the meal offering, he does not place it directly in the furrow. Rather, he <b>lays it on the wall of the vessel and moves</b> the vessel, <b>and</b> the handful <b>falls by itself</b> into the furrow. In this manner, <b>it is as though a monkey</b> rather than a person <b>returned</b> the handful to the furrow, and the handful is therefore not sanctified.
§ The Gemara returns to its discussion of the opinion of ben Beteira. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira: And let</b> one <b>interpret</b> ben Beteira’s ruling as speaking of a case in which the handful is not sanctified by the vessel containing the meal offering, <b>such as where he returned it to a vessel that is resting upon</b> the <b>ground. Rather,</b> the fact that this was not suggested indicates that service vessels sanctify items placed inside them even while resting on the ground. Is it correct to <b>conclude from</b> here that <b>one may remove a handful</b> of a meal offering <b>from</b> a service <b>vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground?</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: You have touched upon a dilemma that was</b> already <b>raised before us, when Rabbi Avimi</b> was <b>learning</b> tractate <b><i>Menaḥot</i></b> in the <b>study hall of Rav Ḥisda.</b>
The Gemara interrupts this statement with a question: <b>And</b> did Rabbi <b>Avimi</b> really <b>learn</b> in the <b>study hall of Rav Ḥisda? But didn’t Rav Ḥisda say: I absorbed many blows [<i>kulfei</i>] from Avimi</b> as a result <b>of that <i>halakha</i>,</b> i.e., Avimi would mock me when I questioned his statements with regard to the sale of orphans’ property by the courts, which were contradictory to the ruling of a particular <i>baraita</i>. Avimi explained to me that if the court <b>comes to announce</b> such a sale on <b>consecutive</b> days, then it is announced for <b>thirty days,</b> in accordance with that <i>baraita</i>. But if it will be announced only on <b>Monday, Thursday, and Monday,</b> then it is announced over the course of <b>sixty days.</b> If so, Rav Ḥisda was in fact the pupil while Rabbi Avimi was his teacher.
The Gemara answers: <b>Avimi</b> was in fact the teacher, but <b>tractate</b> <i>Menaḥot</i> <b>was uprooted for him,</b> i.e., he forgot it, <b>and</b> Avimi <b>came before</b> his student <b>Rav Ḥisda to</b> help him <b>recall his learning.</b> The Gemara asks: If Rav Ḥisda was in fact Avimi’s student, <b>let</b> Avimi <b>send for him and</b> Rav Ḥisda <b>come to</b> Avimi. The Gemara responds: Avimi <b>thought</b> that <b>this</b> would be <b>more helpful</b> in this <b>matter,</b> i.e., that by exerting the effort to travel to his pupil in order to learn from him, he would better retain his studies.
The Gemara returns to the statement of Rabbi Zeira: <b>Rav Naḥman encountered</b> Avimi upon his return from the study hall of Rav Ḥisda. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: How</b> does one properly <b>remove a handful</b> from a meal offering? Avimi pointed to a vessel that was resting on the ground and <b>said to him: From this vessel</b> one may properly remove a handful. Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: But may one remove a handful from a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground?</b> Avimi <b>said to him:</b> When I said that such a vessel may be used, I meant <b>that</b> one <b>priest</b> would first <b>raise it</b> from the ground and then another priest would remove a handful from it.
Rav Naḥman proceeded to ask Avimi another question: <b>How</b> does one properly <b>sanctify the meal offerings?</b> Avimi pointed to a vessel that was resting on the ground and <b>said to him:</b> The priest <b>places it into this vessel.</b> Rav Naḥman again said to him: <b>But can one sanctify</b> a meal offering <b>in a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground?</b> Avimi <b>said to him:</b> When I said that such a vessel may be used, I meant <b>that</b> another <b>priest</b> would initially <b>raise it</b> from the ground, and only then would the meal offering be placed inside it.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Avimi: <b>If so,</b> then <b>you require</b> the involvement of <b>three priests,</b> i.e., one to raise the vessel, one to sanctify the meal offering, and one to remove the handful from the meal offering. Avimi <b>said to him: And let it require</b> even <b>thirteen</b> priests, <b>just as</b> the service of the <b>daily</b> burnt <b>offering</b> required the involvement of thirteen priests. The need for several priests presents no difficulty.
Rav Naḥman <b>raised</b> another <b>objection</b> to the statement of Avimi from a mishna (12a) that discusses the <i>halakha</i> that improper intentions during the service of a meal offering disqualify it. <b>This is the principle:</b> In the case of <b>anyone who removes the handful, or places</b> the handful <b>in the vessel,</b> or <b>who conveys</b> the vessel with the handful to the altar, <b>or who burns</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, or to burn an item whose typical manner is such that one burns it on the altar, e.g., the handful or the frankincense, outside its designated area, the meal offering is unfit but there is no liability for excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>].
Rav Naḥman explained his objection: All the rites of a meal offering are taught in the mishna, <b>and yet raising</b> the vessel from the ground <b>is not taught.</b> This indicates that there is no requirement to raise a vessel from the ground in order to use it for the service of a meal offering. Avimi responded: The <b><i>tanna</i> cited the order of</b> sacrificial <b>rites,</b> i.e., those rites concerning which improper intentions disqualify a meal offering, <b>but</b> he did <b>not</b> cite <b>the order of the priests,</b> i.e., he did not cite the total number of priests involved in the service.
On the same topic, the Sages <b>raised a dilemma before Rav Sheshet: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the permissibility of <b>removing a handful from a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground?</b> Is this removal valid? Rav Sheshet <b>said to</b> one of the Sages who raised the dilemma: <b>Go out</b> and <b>see what they do within</b> the Sanctuary when they remove the bowls containing the frankincense that were placed upon the Table of the shewbread in order to burn the frankincense upon the altar. The mishna (99b) states: When the priests would replace the shewbread every Shabbat, <b>four priests</b> would <b>enter</b> the Sanctuary, <b>two</b> with the <b>two arrangements</b> of the new shewbread <b>in their hands and two</b> with the <b>two bowls</b> of frankincense <b>in their hands. And four</b> priests would <b>precede</b> them and enter the Sanctuary <b>before them, two to remove</b> the <b>two arrangements</b> of the old shewbread <b>and two to remove</b> the <b>two bowls</b> of frankincense.

Daf 7b

Rav Sheshet notes: The entire process of the replacement of the shewbread is taught in the mishna, <b>and yet</b> the statement: A priest <b>raises the Table</b> above the ground so that the bowls of frankincense can be properly removed from them, <b>is not taught.</b> One can therefore conclude from the mishna that just as the bowls of frankincense are removed from a vessel that is resting upon the ground, i.e., the Table, so too, one may remove a handful of a meal offering from a vessel that is resting upon the ground.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Didn’t you</b> already <b>say there,</b> with regard to the mishna that discusses improper intentions expressed during the service of a meal offering (12a), that the <i>tanna</i> <b>cited</b> only <b>the order of</b> sacrificial <b>rites? Here too,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>cited</b> only <b>the order of</b> sacrificial <b>rites.</b> Therefore, one cannot prove from here that there is no requirement to raise the Table.
The Gemara asks: <b>Are</b> these <i>mishnayot</i> <b>comparable? There,</b> on 12a, the <i>tanna</i> <b>did not delve into the number of priests</b> involved in the service of a meal offering. <b>Here,</b> on 99b, the <i>tanna</i> <b>does</b> in fact <b>delve into the number of priests</b> involved in the service of the shewbread. Therefore, <b>if it is so,</b> i.e., if the Table must be raised before the bowls of frankincense are removed, <b>let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>teach</b> that another priest <b>raises</b> the Table. <b>Rather, conclude from</b> the mishna that <b>one may remove a handful</b> of a meal offering <b>from a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground.</b> The Gemara affirms: <b>Conclude from</b> here that this is so.
§ <b>Rava said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that a priest may <b>remove a handful from a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground, as we find</b> such an instance <b>in</b> the case of <b>the removal of</b> the <b>bowls</b> of frankincense from the Table of the shewbread, since the Table is resting upon the ground of the Sanctuary when they are removed. Similarly, <b>one can sanctify a meal offering in a vessel that</b> is resting <b>upon</b> the <b>ground, as we find</b> such an instance <b>in</b> the case of <b>the arrangement of</b> the <b>bowls</b> of frankincense upon the Table of the shewbread.
<b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to the <b>sanctification of a handful</b> by placing it in a vessel that is resting upon the ground, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the sanctification of <b>a meal offering,</b> in which case one can sanctify a handful in this manner, just as he can do so with a meal offering? <b>Or</b> do <b>we derive it from</b> the collection of the <b>blood</b> of an offering, in which case one cannot do so, just as the blood of an offering may not be collected in a vessel that is resting upon the ground? Rava <b>then resolves</b> the dilemma: <b>We derive it from</b> the collection of the <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rava</b> really <b>say this,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the sanctification of a handful is derived from the collection of the blood? <b>But it was stated:</b> With regard to a full measure of <b>a handful that</b> a priest <b>divided</b> and placed <b>in two vessels, Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>it is not sanctified, and Rava says</b> that it is <b>sanctified. And if it is so</b> that the <i>halakha</i> of the handful is derived from the collection of the blood, then <b>let</b> Rava <b>derive from blood</b> that the handful is not sanctified in this manner, just as the blood is not sanctified when divided into two. The Gemara responds: <b>Rava retracted that</b> statement and ruled that a handful is not sanctified when divided and placed into two vessels.
The Gemara further discusses the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the collection of the blood. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>blood, from where do we</b> derive <b>that it is not sanctified in halves,</b> i.e., when collected in two vessels? It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>Rav Taḥlifa ben Shaul teaches</b> with regard to the water of purification: If the priest <b>sanctified</b> the water in two vessels in such a manner that he sanctified <b>less than the amount of sprinkling in this vessel,</b> i.e., there was not enough water into which he could dip a bundle of hyssop and sprinkle the water with it, <b>and</b> he sanctified <b>less than the amount of sprinkling in that vessel,</b> then <b>he has not sanctified</b> the water. Even if he subsequently combines the contents of both vessels into a single vessel, the water is not sanctified.
The Gemara continues: <b>And a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>With regard to</b> the collection of <b>blood</b> of a sin offering for the purpose of sprinkling it upon the altar, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Is</b> the ruling with regard to the water of purification <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai, in which case the <i>halakha</i> with regard to blood may not be derived from it, as <b>we do not derive</b> other cases <b>from a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted to Moses from Sinai?
The Gemara explains the other side of the dilemma: <b>Or perhaps, there,</b> in the case of the water of purification, <b>what is the reason</b> that it is not sanctified? It is possible that the reason is <b>that it is written</b> in a verse that is referring to the water initially placed in the vessel: <b>“And dip it in the water”</b> (Numbers 19:18). If this verse is the source of the <i>halakha</i> that the hyssop may be dipped in the water of purification only when there was initially enough water in the vessel for sprinkling, then <b>here too,</b> in the case of the blood of a sin offering, <b>isn’t it written: “And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger <b>in the blood”</b> (Leviticus 4:6)?
The Gemara continues: <b>And it was stated</b> with regard to this dilemma: <b>Rabbi Zerika says</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Even in</b> the case of the <b>blood, one has not sanctified</b> it if he collected less than a full measure of blood in a single vessel. <b>Rava said</b> that <b>this is also taught in</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to</b> the bull of <b>the anointed priest.</b> The verse states: “And the priest shall dip his finger in the blood, and sprinkle of the blood” (Leviticus 4:6). From the term <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip”</b> it is derived that there must be enough blood inside the vessel in which to dip his finger, <b>and</b> there should <b>not</b> be so little blood that he must resort to <b>wiping</b> his finger along the walls of the vessel.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Additionally, from the term <b>“in the blood”</b> it is derived <b>that there should initially be in</b> the vessel containing <b>the blood a measure</b> fit for <b>dipping</b> his finger. Furthermore, it is derived from the term <b>“of the blood”</b> that he must sprinkle <b>from the blood of the matter,</b> as will be explained.
<b>And it was necessary</b> for the Merciful One <b>to write: “And</b> the priest <b>shall dip,” and it was necessary</b> for the Merciful One <b>to write: “In the blood,”</b> despite the fact that both terms are referring to the amount of blood that must be in the vessel. <b>Because if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip,” I would say</b> that it is enough if the vessel contains enough blood for even one sprinkling, <b>even though</b> the priest <b>did not initially collect a measure</b> fit for all of the <b>sprinklings, that is,</b> enough with which to <b>sprinkle seven times.</b> Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “In the blood.”</b>
<b>And if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“In the blood,” I would say</b> that if there was initially a full measure collected in the vessel then the sprinkling is valid <b>even</b> if now the priest must resort to <b>wiping</b> his finger. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “And</b> the priest <b>shall dip,”</b> indicating that the priest must be able to dip his finger into the blood and not have to wipe it on the walls of the vessel.
The Gemara returns to the last statement of the <i>baraita</i>, that the priest must sprinkle <b>from the blood of the matter.</b> This statement serves <b>to exclude what? Rava said:</b> It serves <b>to exclude</b> the <b>remainder</b> of blood <b>on</b> his <b>finger</b> from the previous sprinkling, i.e., the priest must dip his finger into the blood before each sprinkling; he may not sprinkle with the blood that remains on his finger from the previous sprinkling. The Gemara notes: This <b>supports</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar, who says</b> that the <b>remainder</b> of blood <b>that</b> remained <b>on</b> the priest’s <b>finger is unfit</b> for sprinkling.
<b>Ravin bar Rav Adda said to Rava: Your students say</b> that <b>Rav Amram says</b> that <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where a priest <b>was sprinkling</b> from the blood of a sin offering <b>and</b> the blood of the <b>sprinkling sprayed from his hand</b> onto a garment, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: <b>If</b> the blood sprayed onto the garment <b>before he sprinkled,</b> the garment <b>requires laundering,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> when the blood of a sin offering that is fit for sprinkling fell on a garment. But if the blood sprayed onto the garment <b>after he</b> had already <b>sprinkled,</b> it <b>does not require laundering.</b>
Ravin bar Rav Adda asks: <b>What, is it not</b> correct to say that this means if the blood sprayed onto the garment <b>before he completed</b> all of <b>his sprinkling,</b> then the garment requires laundering, <b>and</b> if the blood sprayed onto the garment <b>after he completed his sprinkling,</b> then the garment does not require laundering? If so, one can <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>that</b> the <b>remainder</b> of blood <b>that</b> remained <b>on</b> his <b>finger</b> between each sprinkling is <b>fit</b> for sprinkling, as otherwise, it would not result in a requirement to launder a garment upon which it sprayed.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is saying that if the blood sprayed from his hand onto the garment <b>before</b> any particular <b>sprinkling left his hand,</b> the garment <b>requires laundering. But</b> if the blood was sprayed <b>after a sprinkling left his hand,</b> in which case the blood <b>sprayed from that which remained</b> on his finger following that sprinkling, then the garment <b>does not require laundering,</b> as the blood left on his finger was already rendered unfit for sprinkling.
<b>Abaye raised an objection to</b> Rava from a mishna discussing the red heifer (<i>Para</i> 3:9): When the priest has <b>completed sprinkling</b> the blood of the red heifer toward the entrance to the Sanctuary, <b>he wipes his hand</b> from the blood <b>on the body of the heifer.</b> Abaye explains his objection: The mishna states that when the priest <b>completed</b> all the sprinklings, then <b>yes,</b> he wipes his hand. It may be inferred that if he <b>did not complete</b> the sprinklings, he does <b>not</b> wipe his hand, even though blood remains on his finger from each preceding sprinkling. This proves that the blood that remains on his finger is fit for sprinkling.
Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: The mishna means that when the priest <b>completed</b> all of the sprinklings, <b>he wipes his hand.</b> If he has <b>not</b> yet <b>completed</b> all of them, then he does not wipe his hand but he must <b>wipe his finger</b> to remove the blood after each sprinkling, as that blood is no longer fit for subsequent sprinklings.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Granted,</b> after <b>he completed</b> all the sprinklings <b>he wipes his hand on the body of the heifer, as it is written: “And the heifer shall be burned in his sight;</b> her skin, and her flesh, and her blood” (Numbers 19:5), which indicates that the blood of the red heifer must be burned together with its flesh. <b>But</b> if when the priest had <b>not</b> yet <b>completed</b> the sprinklings <b>he wipes his finger,</b> then <b>with what</b> does he <b>wipe? Because if you say</b> that he wipes his finger <b>on the body of the heifer,</b> the mishna <b>should have taught:</b> He <b>wipes his hand and his finger on the body of the heifer.</b> Rather, <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the mishna <b>does not teach this,</b> that he wipes his finger on the body of the heifer, one can <b>conclude from</b> this mishna <b>that</b> his finger <b>does not require wiping</b> between sprinklings.
<b>Abaye said:</b> He wipes his finger <b>on the edge of</b> the <b>bowl</b> containing the blood, <b>as it is written: “Atoning bowls [<i>keforei</i>] of gold”</b> (Ezra 1:10), which is referring to the bowls containing the blood. The root <i>kafar</i> can also mean to wipe.
§ The Gemara returns to the issue of the sanctification of blood collected in two vessels: <b>And did Rabbi Elazar</b> really <b>say this,</b> that blood is sanctified only when a full measure is initially collected in a single vessel? <b>But it was stated</b> with regard to the <b>High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>it is not sanctified in halves,</b> i.e., if half of a tenth of an ephah was placed in one vessel, and a second half in another vessel, neither is sanctified. <b>Rabbi Elazar says: Since it is sacrificed in halves,</b> as half of the meal offering is sacrificed in the morning and half in the afternoon, it may be <b>sanctified in halves.</b>

Daf 8a

<b>And if it is so</b> that Rabbi Elazar holds that blood may not be sanctified in halves, <b>let him derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the High Priest’s griddle-cake offering <b>from</b> that of <b>blood. And if you would say</b> that in this case <b>Rabbi Elazar does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>matter</b> of a meal offering <b>from</b> that of another <b>matter,</b> that is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Elazar say: A meal offering</b> from <b>which</b> the priest <b>removed a handful</b> while <b>inside the Sanctuary</b> is <b>valid,</b> despite the fact that the handful should be removed in the Temple courtyard; the reason is <b>that we find</b> a similar case in the Sanctuary, <b>with regard to the removal of</b> the <b>bowls</b> of frankincense from the Table of the shewbread? Just as the bowls permit the shewbread for consumption when removed in the Sanctuary, so too, the handful permits the remainder of the meal offering for consumption. This indicates that Rabbi Elazar does derive the <i>halakha</i> of a meal offering from that of another matter.
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Elazar does <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a meal offering from</b> that of another <b>meal offering;</b> the shewbread is considered a meal offering. But <b>he does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a meal offering from</b> that of <b>blood.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does</b> Rabbi Elazar <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one <b>meal offering from</b> that of another <b>meal offering? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>before</b> the priest <b>detached</b> the arrangement of shewbread and the bowls of frankincense from upon the Table, the <b>bread broke</b> into pieces, <b>the bread</b> is <b>unfit</b> for consumption <b>and</b> the priest <b>does not burn the</b> frankincense contained in the <b>bowls on</b> account of <b>it.</b> If the <b>bread broke after</b> the priest <b>detached it, the bread is unfit but</b> the priest <b>burns the</b> frankincense contained in the <b>bowls on</b> account of <b>it.</b>
The Gemara continues: <b>And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> When the <i>baraita</i> refers to the detachment of the shewbread, it does <b>not</b> mean that the priest <b>actually detached it. Rather,</b> it means that <b>once</b> the <b>time to detach it has arrived, even though he has not</b> yet <b>detached it</b> and has not removed the bowls, <b>it is considered as though he has detached it.</b> Accordingly, if the shewbread broke after that time, the frankincense is burned.
The Gemara explains its question: <b>And</b> if Rabbi Elazar derives the <i>halakha</i> of one meal offering from another, <b>why</b> does he say that frankincense contained in the bowls are burned in a case where the shewbread broke when the time to detach the bread had arrived? <b>It should be like</b> the case of <b>a meal offering that became lacking</b> in its measure <b>before the removal of the handful.</b> Such a handful is not removed and is not sacrificed upon the altar. Likewise, the frankincense was still on the Table when the shewbread broke and should therefore be disqualified.
The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as there is a difference between these meal offerings. In the case of <b>a meal offering</b> that became lacking before the removal of a handful, <b>its handful was not clearly designated.</b> Consequently, if the meal offering became lacking before a handful was removed, one may no longer remove a handful from it. <b>But</b> in the case of the shewbread and the bowls of frankincense, <b>its handful,</b> i.e., the frankincense, <b>was clearly designated</b> at the time when the frankincense was placed in the bowls, since the frankincense is in a separate container from the bread. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>once</b> the <b>time to detach</b> the bread <b>has arrived, it is considered as though he has detached it.</b>
The Gemara asks: But <b>if that is so,</b> then even if the time to detach the shewbread arrived, why is the frankincense burned? <b>It should be like</b> a case where the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>became lacking between</b> the <b>removal of the handful and</b> the <b>burning</b> upon the altar; the <i>halakha</i> in this case is <b>that</b> one <b>does not burn the handful on</b> account of such a meal offering. The Gemara responds: <b>Isn’t it a dispute</b> among the <i>amora’im</i> (9a) whether or not the handful is burned in such a case? One can say that <b>Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that if the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering became <b>lacking between</b> the <b>removal of the handful and</b> the <b>burning,</b> the priest <b>burns the handful on</b> account of such a meal offering.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself:</b> With regard to the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of</b> the <b>High Priest, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>it is not sanctified in halves, and Rabbi Elazar says: Since it is sacrificed in halves,</b> as half of the meal offering is sacrificed in the morning and half in the afternoon, it may likewise be <b>sanctified in halves. Rav Aḥa said: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Yoḥanan? The verse states: “A meal offering</b> perpetually, <b>half of it</b> in the morning, and half of it in the evening” (Leviticus 6:13). This means: First <b>bring</b> a whole <b>meal offering, and</b> only <b>afterward divide it</b> into halves.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar. The mishna teaches (50b): The <b>griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of</b> the <b>High Priest did not come in halves. Rather,</b> the High Priest <b>brings a full tenth</b> of an ephah <b>and</b> then <b>divides it</b> into two. <b>And it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to this mishna: <b>If it were stated: A meal offering, half</b> in the morning, and half in the evening, <b>I would say: He brings half of a tenth from his home</b> in the <b>morning and sacrifices</b> it, and another <b>half of a tenth from his home</b> in the <b>evening and sacrifices</b> it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Half of it in the morning,”</b> indicating that <b>he brings a half from a whole,</b> and he does not bring a half by itself.
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Elazar maintains that the verse requires that a whole meal offering be brought in the morning only <b>for a mitzva,</b> i.e., <i>ab initio</i>. Nevertheless, if half of a tenth was brought in the morning it is valid after the fact. <b>Rav Geviha from Bei Katil said to Rav Ashi: But</b> the term <b>“statute” is written with regard to</b> the griddle-cake offering, as the verse states: “A statute forever” (Leviticus 6:15), and there is a principle that whenever the Torah calls a mitzva a statute, the details of its performance are indispensable. Rav Ashi <b>said to him: It was necessary</b> for the Torah to define this mitzva as a statute <b>only with regard to</b> the requirement that the High Priest <b>bring a full</b> tenth <b>from his home.</b> With regard to its sanctification in a service vessel, it can be sanctified in halves.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> really <b>say this? But it was stated:</b> If one <b>set aside half a tenth</b> of an ephah for any meal offering, <b>and his intention</b> was <b>to add</b> to the half in order to reach a full tenth, <b>Rav says</b> that <b>it is not sanctified,</b> as he did not bring a full tenth, <b>and Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it is <b>sanctified. And if it is so</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that the griddle-cake offering cannot be sanctified in halves, <b>let him derive from</b> the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering that no meal offering may be sanctified in halves.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one <b>matter</b> with regard to consecrated items <b>from</b> that of another <b>matter,</b> that is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan say: Peace offerings that</b> were <b>slaughtered in the Sanctuary are valid, as it is written: “And slaughter it at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), i.e., in the courtyard. Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: It is logical <b>that</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>minor</b> area, i.e., the courtyard, <b>should not be more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>major</b> area, the Tent of Meeting. Evidently, Rabbi Yoḥanan derives a <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Sanctuary from the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Yoḥanan does in fact derive the <i>halakha</i> of one matter from another, and therefore he learns the <i>halakha</i> with regard to all meal offerings from the griddle-cake offering, that in general they are not sanctified in halves. But a case where one expresses <b>his intention to add</b> to the half measure <b>is different, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “Both of them <b>full</b> of fine flour” (Numbers 7:13). <b>“Full”</b> is a reference <b>only</b> to <b>full</b> measurements; <b>that is to say,</b> the flour <b>is not sanctified until there is a full tenth</b> inside the vessel. <b>And Rabbi Yosei said: When</b> is it the <i>halakha</i> that the flour is sanctified only if a full tenth is inside the vessel? It is <b>at a time when his intention</b> was <b>not</b> initially <b>to add</b> to that which he placed inside the vessel. <b>But at a time when his intention</b> was initially <b>to add, each initial</b> bit of flour is <b>sanctified</b> by the vessel.
The Gemara asks: <b>And Rav,</b> who holds that standard meal offerings are not sanctified in halves even if one’s initial intention was to add to the half measure, <b>with regard to a griddle-cake</b> offering, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>does he hold? If</b> he holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> who says that a griddle-cake offering can be sanctified in halves, then <b>let him derive from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>griddle-cake</b> offerings that all meal offerings may be sanctified in halves.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>Rav does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one <b>matter from</b> that of another <b>matter,</b> that is difficult: <b>But doesn’t Rav say:</b> A standard <b>meal offering,</b> which is brought with oil and frankincense, <b>is sanctified</b> by a service vessel even <b>without</b> its <b>oil</b> and without its frankincense. It is sanctified without its oil, <b>as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the shewbread,</b> which is sacrificed without oil and is nevertheless sanctified by a service vessel. Similarly, it is sanctified even <b>without</b> its <b>frankincense, as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the meal offering</b> accompanying the <b>libations</b> of an offering, which is sacrificed without frankincense and is nevertheless sanctified by a service vessel.
Finally, a standard meal offering is sanctified by a service vessel even <b>without</b> its <b>oil and without</b> its <b>frankincense, as we find with regard to the meal offering of a sinner,</b> which includes neither of these. This indicates that Rav does derive the <i>halakha</i> of a meal offering from other meal offerings. Rather, <b>perforce,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering, <b>Rav holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> that this offering is not sanctified in halves, and it is derived from there that no meal offerings are sanctified in halves.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav says</b> that <b>a meal offering is sanctified without</b> its <b>oil, and its <i>halakha</i> is not</b> the same <b>as</b> when <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour is <b>lacking, as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the shewbread,</b> which is sacrificed without oil and is nevertheless sanctified by a service vessel. Similarly, it is sanctified even <b>without</b> its <b>frankincense, as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the meal offering</b> accompanying the <b>libations</b> of an offering, which is sacrificed without frankincense and is nevertheless sanctified. Additionally, a meal offering is sanctified even <b>without</b> its <b>oil and without</b> its <b>frankincense, as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the meal offering of a sinner,</b> which lacks both oil and frankincense and is nevertheless sanctified by a service vessel.
