Rav continues: <b>And oil and frankincense are</b> each <b>sanctified</b> by service vessels, <b>this</b> substance <b>without that</b> one, <b>and that</b> substance <b>without this</b> one. <b>Oil</b> is sanctified on its own, <b>as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the <i>log</i> of oil of a leper,</b> which is sanctified on its own. <b>Frankincense</b> is sanctified on its own, <b>as we find</b> such a <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the frankincense that comes in the bowls</b> that are brought with the shewbread; there is no oil in that case and yet the frankincense is sanctified in the bowls. <b>And Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b>

Daf 8b

<b>Neither</b> is <b>this</b> substance <b>sanctified without that, nor is that sanctified without this.</b> Rather, any meal offering that requires oil and frankincense is sanctified by a service vessel only when the flour, oil, and frankincense are all placed in the same vessel at the same time.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina, for what</b> purpose was the vessel that measured <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>anointed,</b> making it possible for it to sanctify items placed inside it? This vessel <b>was fashioned only for measuring flour, and</b> according to Rabbi Ḥanina <b>the flour is not sanctified without oil.</b> What then does this vessel sanctify? The Gemara answers: The vessel was anointed <b>for</b> the purpose of sanctifying the <b>meal offering of a sinner,</b> which contains neither oil nor frankincense.
The Gemara further asks: <b>And for what</b> purpose was the vessel that measured one <b><i>log</i></b> of oil <b>anointed?</b> After all, according to Rabbi Ḥanina oil for a meal offering cannot be sanctified by itself. The Gemara explains: It was anointed <b>for</b> the purpose of sanctifying the <b><i>log</i></b> of oil <b>of a leper,</b> which is not brought as part of a meal offering. This oil is sanctified without flour or frankincense.
The Gemara notes: <b>And Shmuel also holds in accordance with this</b> statement <b>of Rav,</b> that a service vessel sanctifies the flour of a meal offering even without its oil, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 88a): <b>The vessels</b> used for <b>liquids sanctify</b> only <b>the liquids, and the</b> vessels that serve as <b>dry measures sanctify</b> only <b>the dry</b> goods. <b>But the vessels</b> used for <b>liquids do not sanctify the dry</b> goods, <b>and the</b> vessels that serve as <b>dry measures do not sanctify the liquids.</b>
<b>And Shmuel says</b> with regard to this mishna: <b>They taught</b> that vessels used for liquids do not sanctify dry goods <b>only</b> with regard to vessels used as <b>measures. But bowls</b> that are used for collecting and tossing the <b>blood</b> of offerings <b>sanctify the dry goods</b> as well, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to the offerings of the princes brought during the inauguration of the Tabernacle: <b>“Both of them full of fine flour mixed with oil for a meal offering”</b> (Numbers 7:13), which indicates that the bowl sanctifies meal offerings, which are dry.
The Gemara continues its proof: And <b>Rav Aḥa of Difti said to Ravina,</b> with regard to this derivation of Shmuel: But the <b>meal offering</b> of the verse <b>is</b> also considered <b>a liquid,</b> as it is mingled with oil. How then can one derive from it the <i>halakha</i> with regard to items that are entirely dry? Ravina <b>said to him:</b> The verse cited by Shmuel <b>is necessary only to</b> teach that <b>the dry</b> part <b>of</b> a meal offering, <b>that is,</b> the <b>frankincense,</b> which invariably does not come into contact with the oil, is sanctified by the bowls as well.
The Gemara concludes its proof with regard to Shmuel’s opinion: <b>And if it enters your mind</b> that <b>Shmuel holds</b> that <b>a meal offering is not sanctified</b> by a service vessel <b>until all</b> of its components <b>are</b> together in the vessel, then <b>how can you find</b> a case where the <b>dry</b> parts <b>of</b> a meal offering are by themselves? <b>Is it not</b> correct that when meal offerings are sanctified, <b>all of them are liquids, due to the oil</b> that is mixed with them? <b>Rather, conclude from</b> here that <b>Shmuel holds</b> that <b>this</b> substance may be sanctified <b>without that</b> one.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead in answer to Rav Aḥa of Difti’s question: <b>A meal offering,</b> even when it is mixed with oil, is, <b>relative to blood, considered as a dry</b> item. Accordingly, one may derive from the verse that the bowls sanctify dry items, and just as a bowl sanctifies a meal offering that contains oil, as it is considered dry in comparison to blood, so too, it sanctifies a meal offering that is entirely dry, i.e., that contains no oil, as claimed by Rav.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Elazar says: A meal offering</b> from <b>which</b> the priest <b>removed a handful</b> while <b>inside the Sanctuary</b> is <b>valid,</b> despite the fact that the handful should be removed in the Temple courtyard; the reason is <b>that we find</b> a similar case in the Sanctuary, <b>with regard to the removal of</b> the <b>bowls</b> of frankincense from the Table of the shewbread. Just as the bowls permit the shewbread for consumption, so too, the handful permits the remainder of the meal offering for consumption.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises an objection</b> to this opinion from a <i>baraita</i> discussing the verse: “And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons the priests; <b>and he shall remove from there</b> his handful” (Leviticus 2:2). The verse indicates that the removal of a handful from a meal offering may be performed <b>from the place where the feet of the non-priest</b> may <b>stand,</b> i.e., anywhere within the Temple courtyard.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Ben Beteira,</b> who holds that a handful is not disqualified when removed with the left hand, <b>says</b> that the verse should be interpreted as follows: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> one <b>removed a handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>that he must return</b> the handful to the vessel that contains the meal offering <b>and</b> again <b>remove the handful with</b> his <b>right</b> hand? <b>The verse states: “And he shall remove from there.”</b> This indicates that the handful is removed <b>from the place where he already removed</b> it, i.e., the handful is returned to the meal offering and thereupon removed from the same meal offering, this time with his right hand. It is clear from the statement of the first <i>tanna</i> that the handful of a meal offering may be removed only in the place where the feet of a non-priest may stand, but not in the Sanctuary.
<b>Some say</b> that Rabbi Yirmeya <b>raises the objection and he resolves it</b> as well. And <b>some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ya’akov said to Rabbi Yirmeya bar Taḥlifa: I will explain to you</b> the resolution of this objection: The verse <b>is necessary only to permit the entire</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> for removing the handful there, not to prohibit the removal of a handful inside the Sanctuary. The reason is <b>that you should not say: Since a burnt offering</b> is <b>an offering of the most sacred order, and a meal offering</b> is likewise <b>an offering of the most sacred order,</b> then <b>just as a burnt offering requires</b> that its slaughter be performed in the <b>northern</b> part of the Temple courtyard, <b>so too, a meal offering requires</b> that the removal of its handful be in the <b>northern</b> part.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this comparison: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it is more sacred, as it is <b>consumed</b> in its entirety upon the altar. The Gemara responds: The same comparison may be drawn <b>from a sin offering,</b> which is also an offering of the most sacred order and is not sacrificed in its entirety upon the altar, and yet it must be slaughtered in the northern part of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this comparison as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of a sin offering are more stringent, as its sacrifice <b>atones for</b> those sins whose transgression causes one to be <b>liable to</b> receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> The Gemara responds: The comparison may be drawn <b>from a guilt offering,</b> as it too is an offering of the most sacred order, it is not sacrificed in its entirety upon the altar, it does not atone for such sins, and yet it must be slaughtered in the northern part of the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion as well: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> a guilt offering has a loftier status, as it is one of <b>the types of</b> offerings whose atonement is achieved through their <b>blood,</b> i.e., it is an animal offering. The Gemara adds: Once this claim has been accepted, <b>from all of them as well,</b> i.e., from a burnt offering and sin offering, one cannot draw a comparison to a meal offering either, <b>as</b> they are all of <b>the types of</b> offerings whose atonement is achieved through their <b>blood.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the verse <b>was necessary</b> in order to permit the removal of a handful anywhere in the Temple courtyard because it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since it is written: “And it shall be presented to the priest, and he shall bring it to the altar”</b> (Leviticus 2:8), and it states: <b>“And he shall remove</b> from there his handful” (Leviticus 2:2), one could claim: <b>Just as</b> the <b>bringing</b> of the meal offering is <b>in the southwestern corner</b> of the altar, <b>so too,</b> the <b>removal of the handful</b> must <b>also</b> be performed <b>in the southwestern corner.</b> Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that the removal of the handful may be performed anywhere in the Temple courtyard, but this does not serve to exclude the Sanctuary.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Peace offerings that</b> were <b>slaughtered in the Sanctuary are valid, as it is stated: “And slaughter it at the entrance of the Tent of Meeting”</b> (Leviticus 3:2), i.e., in the courtyard. <b>And</b> it is logical that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>minor</b> area, i.e., the courtyard, <b>should not be more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the major</b> one, the Tent of Meeting or the Sanctuary.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan from a <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda ben Beteira says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that if gentiles surrounded the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> and were firing projectiles inside to the point that it became impossible to remain in the courtyard on account of the threat, <b>that the priests enter the Sanctuary and partake of the offerings of the most sacred order and the remainders of</b> the <b>meal offerings</b> while inside the Sanctuary? <b>The verse states:</b>

Daf 9a

“Every meal offering of theirs, and every sin offering of theirs, and every guilt offering of theirs, which they may render unto Me, shall be most holy for you and for your sons. <b>In the Sanctuary you shall eat them”</b> (Numbers 18:9–10). This indicates that although the mitzva is to consume offerings of the most sacred order in the courtyard, in certain instances the priests may consume these offerings inside the Sanctuary, the most holy place.
The Gemara explains its objection: <b>But</b> according to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>why do I</b> need this <b>verse? Let him say</b> here as well that as the verse states: <b>“In the court of the Tent of Meeting they shall eat it”</b> (Leviticus 6:9), i.e., in the Temple courtyard, it is logical that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>minor</b> area <b>should not be more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the major</b> one, i.e., if one may consume a peace offering in the Temple courtyard then all the more so may he consume it in the Sanctuary.
The Gemara explains: Consuming an offering is not the same as slaughtering it. The slaughter of an offering is part of the sacrificial <b>service,</b> and it is not considered disrespectful <b>for a person</b> to <b>serve</b> his master <b>in the place of his master,</b> i.e., within the Sanctuary as well as in the courtyard. Therefore, <b>we say that</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>minor</b> area <b>should not be more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the major</b> one. By contrast, with regard to the <b>consumption</b> of an offering, <b>since a person may not eat in the place of his master, the</b> only <b>reason</b> that it is permitted to consume an offering inside the Sanctuary is <b>that</b> it is <b>written</b> in <b>the verse:</b> “In a most holy place you shall eat them.” <b>Had</b> this <b>not</b> been <b>written</b> in <b>the verse</b> explicitly, <b>we</b> would <b>not say</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <b>minor</b> area <b>should not be more stringent than</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>the major</b> one.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> If one <b>mixed</b> the oil of a meal offering into <b>it outside the wall of</b> the Temple <b>courtyard, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it is <b>disqualified,</b> and <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that it is <b>valid. Reish Lakish says:</b> It is <b>valid, as it is written: “And he shall pour oil upon it, and put frankincense upon it”</b> (Leviticus 2:1), <b>and then</b> it is written: <b>“And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons the priests; and he shall remove”</b> (Leviticus 2:2).
Reish Lakish explains: The Sages derived from here that <b>from the removal of the handful onward</b> the rites performed with the meal offering are solely <b>a mitzva of</b> the <b>priesthood.</b> Accordingly, the verse <b>taught about pouring and mixing that they are valid</b> when performed <b>by a non-priest. And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> the <b>priesthood is not required</b> for the mixing, it may be derived that it <b>is also not required</b> that its performance be <b>inside</b> the walls of the Temple courtyard.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> This meal offering is <b>disqualified, since</b> a meal offering’s <b>performance is in</b> a service <b>vessel.</b> Therefore, <b>granted that</b> the <b>priesthood is not required,</b> yet <b>in any event</b> its performance <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>is required.</b> The Gemara notes that <b>it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If a meal offering was <b>mixed</b> by a <b>non-priest</b> it is <b>valid.</b> But if it was mixed <b>outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b>
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to a <b>meal offering that became lacking</b> in its full measure <b>before the removal of the handful, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the owner <b>shall bring</b> additional flour <b>from within his home and shall fill</b> the missing part of the measure of the meal offering. <b>Reish Lakish says: He shall not bring</b> flour <b>from within his home and fill it.</b> Instead, he must bring a new meal offering.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>he brings</b> flour <b>from within his home and he fills it,</b> as the <b>removal of the handful establishes it</b> as a meal offering to the extent that it may become disqualified. Before the removal, one may always add flour to the meal offering. <b>Reish Lakish says: He shall not bring</b> flour <b>from within his home and fill it,</b> as <b>the sanctity of</b> the service <b>vessel establishes it</b> as a meal offering. Therefore, once the meal offering was placed in a service vessel and sanctified, it is disqualified if it becomes lacking.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish,</b> Reish Lakish, from a mishna (<i>Nega’im</i> 14:10) discussing the <i>log</i> of oil brought by a leper: In a case where <b>the <i>log</i> lacked</b> a full measure, <b>if</b> it became lacking <b>before</b> the priest <b>poured</b> from it into his palm in order to place it on the right thumb and big toe of the leper, <b>he shall fill it.</b> Clearly the service vessel containing the <i>log</i> does not sanctify the oil to the extent that it can become disqualified. The Gemara notes: Indeed, this is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion of Reish Lakish.
§ <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>that became lacking between</b> the <b>removal of the handful and</b> its <b>burning</b> upon the altar, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that one <b>burns the handful on</b> account of such a remainder, and that the remainder is then permitted for consumption. <b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that one does <b>not burn the handful on</b> account of the remainder. The Gemara notes: <b>According to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer, everyone agrees</b> that the handful is burned on account of the remainder. In other words, both <i>amora’im</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish, concur that this is the <i>halakha</i> according to the <i>tanna</i> Rabbi Eliezer. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is concerning the <i>halakha</i> <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua.</b>
The Gemara cites the dispute in question. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (26a): If, after the handful was removed, <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>became ritually impure,</b> or if <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>was burned,</b> or if <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>was lost, according to the principle of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says that with regard to an animal offering the blood is fit for sprinkling even if there is no meat that can be eaten, the meal offering is <b>fit,</b> and the priest burns the handful. <b>But according to the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who says that with regard to an animal offering the blood is fit for sprinkling only if there is meat that can be eaten, it is <b>unfit</b> and the priest does not burn the handful, as the handful serves to render the remainder permitted.
<b>The one who disqualifies</b> the remainder of a meal offering that became lacking between the removal of the handful and its burning upon the altar, i.e., Reish Lakish, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the plain meaning of the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua. And the one who deems</b> that remainder <b>fit,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan, maintains that when <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says</b> that the remainder is unfit, he says so <b>only there,</b> in a case <b>where nothing remained</b> from the meal offering other than the remainder. Since the handful is intended to render permitted for consumption the remainder of the meal offering, if there is no remainder at all then the handful is not burned. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where there remained</b> a portion of the remainder, Rabbi Yoḥanan maintains that <b>even Rabbi Yehoshua concedes to</b> Rabbi Eliezer that the handful is fit to be burned.
The Gemara cites a proof for Rabbi Yoḥanan: It is clear that this is Rabbi Yehoshua’s opinion, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>any of the offerings that</b> are mentioned <b>in the Torah from which there remains</b> either <b>an olive-bulk of meat or an olive-bulk of fat,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the priest <b>sprinkles the blood</b> of that offering and thereby permits either the remaining meat for consumption or the remaining fat for sacrifice upon the altar. But if there remains only <b>half an olive-bulk of meat</b> and <b>half an olive-bulk of fat, he does not sprinkle the blood,</b> as the consumption or burning of anything less than an olive-bulk is not significant enough to warrant the sprinkling of the blood. The volumes of the meat and the fat do not combine to form a whole olive-bulk.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And in</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering, even</b> if there remains only <b>half an olive-bulk of flesh and half an olive-bulk of fat, he sprinkles the blood, because in</b> the case of <b>a burnt offering it is entirely consumed,</b> i.e., as the flesh and fat are both burned upon the altar, there is in fact an olive-bulk of the offering that is designated for burning upon the altar. <b>And with regard to a meal offering, even though it</b> remains <b>entirely intact, he shall not sprinkle.</b>

Daf 9b

Parenthetically, the Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the mention of <b>a meal offering doing</b> here, in a <i>baraita</i> that discusses slaughtered offerings? There is no sprinkling in the case of a meal offering. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>a meal offering</b> that accompanies the <b>libations</b> brought with a slaughtered offering.
Rav Pappa elaborates: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> such a meal offering <b>comes with a</b> slaughtered <b>offering, it is considered like</b> the <b>offering itself.</b> Accordingly, if the only part remaining from an offering is the meal offering that is brought with it, perhaps it is considered as though part of the offering itself remains, and therefore the priest may sprinkle the offering’s blood on account of it. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the <i>halakha</i>. In any event, Rabbi Yehoshua states in this <i>baraita</i> that the blood of an offering is sprinkled if a minimum amount remains from it. The same should apply to the remainder of a regular meal offering.
Rabbi Yoḥanan cited this <i>baraita</i> as proof that even according to Rabbi Yehoshua, if a portion of the remainder of a meal offering remains intact then the handful may be burned on account of it. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning <b>the one who disqualifies</b> the handful when the remainder is lacking, i.e., Reish Lakish, how does he explain the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua? The Gemara responds: Reish Lakish would claim that it <b>is different here,</b> in the case of a meal offering, <b>as the verse states: “And the priest shall remove from the meal offering its memorial part, and shall make it smoke upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 2:9). Since it is clear that the verse is discussing a meal offering, the apparently superfluous mention of <b>“the meal offering”</b> teaches that <b>unless the entire meal offering is</b> intact, the priest <b>shall not burn</b> the handful.
The Gemara continues: <b>And the other</b> <i>amora</i>, Rabbi Yoḥanan, how does he interpret that verse? Rabbi Yoḥanan claims that the phrase <b>“from the meal offering”</b> is referring to <b>a meal offering that was already whole at the time of the removal of</b> its <b>handful,</b> and the verse teaches that <b>he shall burn</b> its handful <b>even though it is currently not whole.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>before</b> the priest <b>detached</b> the arrangement of shewbread and the bowls of frankincense from upon the Table, the <b>bread broke</b> into pieces, the bread is <b>unfit</b> for consumption <b>and</b> the priest <b>does not burn</b> the frankincense contained in <b>the bowls on</b> account of <b>it. And if</b> the <b>bread broke after</b> the priest <b>detached it, the bread is unfit but</b> the priest <b>burns the</b> frankincense contained in the <b>bowls on</b> account of <b>it. And Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <i>baraita</i> does <b>not</b> mean that the priest <b>actually detached</b> the shewbread. <b>Rather,</b> it means that <b>once</b> the <b>time to detach it has arrived</b> the frankincense contained in the bowls may be burned, <b>even though he has not</b> yet <b>detached it.</b> Just as the frankincense contained in the bowls is burned despite the broken shewbread, likewise, the handful of a meal offering should be burned even when the remainder is lacking.
Reish Lakish <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan in response: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who permits the burning of a handful even when the remainder has been entirely destroyed. And I hold in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua. Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to him: I am stating a complete <i>halakha</i> to you,</b> i.e., a <i>baraita</i> of an unspecified opinion, <b>and you say to me</b> that this <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> alone?
Rabbi Yoḥanan added: And furthermore, <b>if</b> the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of only <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> then <b>why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mention <b>specifically</b> an instance where the bread <b>broke?</b> According to Rabbi Eliezer, <b>even</b> if the bread was <b>burned or lost</b> entirely, <b>he deems</b> the frankincense contained in the bowls <b>fit</b> for burning <b>as well.</b> The Gemara notes: Reish Lakish <b>was silent</b> and did not respond to the objections of Rabbi Yoḥanan.
The Gemara asks: <b>But why was</b> Reish Lakish <b>silent? Let him say to</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan that one cannot cite a proof from a <i>baraita</i> that discusses the shewbread, a communal offering, because offerings of the <b>community are different, since ritual impurity was permitted for them,</b> i.e., communal offerings may be sacrificed even in a state of ritual impurity. Therefore, it <b>was also permitted</b> to sacrifice them when they <b>are lacking. Rav Adda bar Ahava said:</b> The fact <b>that</b> Reish Lakish did not respond in <b>this</b> manner <b>is to say</b> that a meal offering that is <b>lacking</b> in measure <b>is considered like a blemished</b> animal, not merely like an impure offering, <b>and there is no</b> instance of <b>a blemished</b> animal being permitted for use as an offering, even <b>in</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Pappa</b> was once <b>sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i>,</b> and he noted that Reish Lakish was silent and did not respond to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s objections by differentiating between a communal offering and that of an individual, and that Rav Adda bar Ahava derived from Reish Lakish’s silence that a lack in the measure of a meal offering is tantamount to a blemish. <b>Rav Yosef bar Shemaya said to Rav Pappa: Are we not dealing</b> with a disagreement <b>that</b> exists between <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish</b> even <b>in</b> the case of <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering, which is a communal</b> offering? <b>And</b> even so, they <b>disagree.</b> Accordingly, Reish Lakish could not have responded to the objections of Rabbi Yoḥanan by distinguishing between a communal and an individual offering, and therefore one cannot derive from his silence that a meal offering lacking in its measure is like a blemished animal.
The Gemara further discusses the disagreement between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish. <b>Rav Malkiyu says</b> that <b>one</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>taught:</b> The verse states: “And he shall remove…<b>of its fine flour”</b> (Leviticus 2:2). This indicates <b>that if</b> the meal offering <b>lacks any amount</b> of its flour, it is <b>disqualified</b> and the priest may not remove a handful from it. Similarly, the term: <b>“Of its oil”</b> (Leviticus 2:2), teaches <b>that if</b> the meal offering <b>lacks any amount</b> of its oil, it is <b>disqualified.</b>
<b>And it is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that the verse that states: <b>“But that which is left of the meal offering</b> shall be Aaron’s and his sons’” (Leviticus 2:3), teaches that the remainder of the meal offering is given to the priests only if there was initially a whole meal offering, <b>to the exclusion of a meal offering that was lacking, or whose handful was lacking, or from which</b> the priest <b>did not burn any frankincense.</b> In such cases, the meal offering is disqualified and its remainder may not be consumed by the priests.
Rav Malkiyu asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>two verses to</b> disqualify meal offerings that are <b>lacking?</b> Is it <b>not</b> correct to say that <b>one</b> verse is referring <b>to a meal offering that became lacking before the removal of the handful,</b> i.e., that one may not refill it, <b>and one</b> verse is referring <b>to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>that became lacking between the removal of the handful and</b> its <b>burning</b> upon the altar, and it teaches that one may not burn a handful on account of such a remainder?
Rav Malkiyu concludes: <b>And</b> if so, then this is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan in both</b> instances where he disagrees with Reish Lakish, i.e., in the case of a meal offering that became lacking before the removal of the handful, as Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that one may refill it, and in the case of the remainder that became lacking between the removal of the handful and its burning, as he holds that the handful may be burned.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No; one</b> verse is indeed referring <b>to a meal offering that became lacking before the removal of the handful,</b> but it is not teaching that this meal offering is disqualified. Rather, this verse indicates <b>that if he brings</b> flour <b>from his home and fills it</b> so that the meal offering is no longer lacking, then <b>yes,</b> it is fit, <b>but if</b> he does <b>not</b> bring more flour, it is <b>not</b> fit. <b>And one</b> verse is indeed referring <b>to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>that became lacking between the removal of the handful and</b> its <b>burning</b> upon the altar; nevertheless, it does not indicate that the handful may not be burned. Rather, it teaches <b>that even though</b> the priest <b>burns</b> the <b>handful on</b> account of such a remainder, <b>that remainder is prohibited for consumption.</b>
The Gemara continues: This is indeed the appropriate explanation of the verses, <b>as a dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: According <b>to the statement of</b> the one <b>who says that</b> in a case where the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>became lacking between the removal of the handful and</b> its <b>burning</b> upon the altar, the priest <b>burns</b> the <b>handful on</b> account of this remainder, concerning the <b>remainder itself, what</b> is its status <b>with regard to consumption,</b> i.e., may the remainder be eaten?
<b>Ze’eiri said</b> that <b>the verse states: “But that which is left</b> of the meal offering shall be Aaron’s and his sons’,” which teaches that the priests may consume the remainder of a meal offering, <b>but not the remainder of the remainder,</b> i.e., if the remainder became lacking before the handful was burned, the remaining part of the remainder may not be consumed. Alternatively, <b>Rabbi Yannai says</b> that <b>“of the meal offering</b> shall be Aaron’s and his sons’” indicates that the priests may consume only the remainder of <b>a meal offering that was previously</b> whole when the handful was burned, not the remainder of the remainder.
§ The mishna teaches: If the priest <b>removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand the meal offering is unfit. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Zeira said</b> that it is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>the verse states: “And the meal offering was presented; and he filled his hand from it”</b> (Leviticus 9:17). Rabbi Zeira explains: <b>This hand, I do not know what it is,</b> i.e., the left hand or the right. <b>When</b> the verse <b>states</b> with regard to the atonement of a leper: <b>“And the priest shall take of the <i>log</i> of oil, and pour it into the palm of his own left hand”</b> (Leviticus 14:15), it mentions the left hand. One can therefore derive that <b>here,</b> where the verse specifies, the priest must use his <b>left</b> hand, whereas in <b>any place where it is stated</b> in a verse <b>“hand”</b> without specification, it is referring <b>only</b> to the <b>right</b> hand.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can this conclusion be derived from the verse discussing the atonement of a leper? This verse <b>is necessary for itself,</b> i.e., to teach that the oil must be poured on the priest’s left hand, not his right. The Gemara answers that <b>another</b> mention of the <b>left</b> hand <b>is written</b> in the same passage (see Leviticus 14:16). From this additional mention of the left hand it may be derived that any unspecified reference to a hand is referring to the right hand.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But say</b> that according to the hermeneutical principle that one <b>restriction after</b> another <b>restriction</b> serves <b>only to amplify,</b> it should be inferred from the additional specification of the left hand that the oil may be poured onto the priest’s right hand. The Gemara responds: Yet <b>another</b> specification of the <b>left</b> hand <b>is written</b> in that passage (see Leviticus 14:26). Accordingly, the hermeneutical principle that one restriction after another serves only to amplify does not apply. Instead, the verse indicates that <b>here</b> the <b>left</b> hand is required, <b>and there is no other</b> instance where the Torah requires the <b>left</b> hand.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <b>on the contrary, just as here</b> the <b>left</b> hand is required, <b>so too generally,</b> the <b>left</b> hand is required <b>as well.</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Four</b> mentions of the <b>left</b> hand <b>are written</b> in the passage, <b>two with regard to a poor</b> leper (Leviticus 14:26–27), <b>and two with regard to a wealthy</b> one (Leviticus 14:15–16). Accordingly, three of the specifications serve to indicate that the oil may be poured only onto the left hand, while the additional mention serves to restrict the use of the left hand to the case of a leper alone.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said to Rabbi Zeira:</b> According to your opinion, one interprets homiletically the additional specifications in the passage discussing the purification of a leper. If so, there is another apparently superfluous verse: <b>“Upon the thumb of his right hand, and upon the big toe of his right foot”</b> (Leviticus 14:17), <b>which is written with regard to</b> the placement of the <b>oil</b> upon the right thumb and big toe <b>of a wealthy leper. Why do I</b> need the verse to specify that the oil is placed on the leper’s right thumb and big toe?

Daf 10a

After all, a verse already indicates that the oil must be placed on the right thumb and big toe, <b>as</b> it is <b>written: “Upon the blood of the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:17). Since the Torah has already specified that the blood is placed upon the right thumb and big toe (Leviticus 14:14), it is clear that the oil is placed there as well. Similarly, why must the verse specify with regard to a poor leper that the oil is placed on the right thumb and big toe? Isn’t already clear from the verse where the oil must be placed, as it states: “Upon the place of the blood of the guilt offering” (Leviticus 14:28)? The Gemara responds: <b>One</b> specification, stated with regard to a wealthy leper, serves <b>to permit</b> the placement of the oil on the <b>sides</b> of the thumb and sides of the big toe in addition to the nail side of the thumb and big toe, <b>and one,</b> stated with regard to a poor leper, serves <b>to disqualify the sides of sides,</b> i.e., their undersides.
The Gemara inquires with regard to the verse: <b>“Upon the blood of the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:17), stated with regard to the purification of a wealthy leper, and the verse: <b>“Upon the place of the blood of the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 14:28), stated with regard to the purification of a poor leper. <b>For what</b> purpose <b>do they come,</b> i.e., why are both verses necessary?
The Gemara responds: <b>These</b> verses <b>are necessary, because if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“Upon the blood of the guilt offering,” I would say:</b> If the blood <b>is</b> still on the right thumb and big toe of the leper, <b>yes,</b> the priest places the oil upon the blood. But if it <b>was wiped</b> from there, he does <b>not</b> place the oil. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One writes: “Upon the place</b> of the blood of the guilt offering,” indicating that the oil is placed upon the location of the blood, not necessarily upon the blood itself.
<b>And</b> conversely, <b>if the Merciful One had written</b> only: <b>“Upon the place</b> of the blood of the guilt offering,” <b>I would say:</b> The oil is placed on his right thumb and big toe <b>specifically</b> when the blood <b>was wiped</b> from there. <b>But</b> if the blood <b>is</b> still there, I will <b>say</b> that the blood <b>is an interposition</b> between the oil and the thumb or toe. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that the oil is placed <b>“upon the blood of the guilt offering,”</b> and the blood is not considered an interposition.
<b>Rava said: Since it is written</b> that the priest places the oil <b>“upon the blood of the guilt offering,” and: “Upon the place of</b> the blood of <b>the guilt offering,” and it is</b> also <b>written</b> with regard to a wealthy leper (see Leviticus 14:14) and a poor one (see Leviticus 14:25) that the <b>right</b> hand and foot are required <b>for</b> the placement of <b>the blood,</b> as the verses state: <b>“Upon the thumb of his right hand, and upon the big toe of his right foot,” and</b> this <b>is</b> also <b>written with regard to</b> the <b>oil of a wealthy leper</b> (see Leviticus 14:17) <b>and a poor</b> one (see Leviticus 14:28), one can ask: <b>Why do I</b> need all of these verses?
<b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The verses that specify that the oil must be placed on the right thumb and big toe do not teach a <i>halakha</i> with regard to a leper, as it is clear that the oil must be placed on the right thumb and big toe, as it states: “Upon the place of the blood of the guilt offering.” Rather, these verses are the source of verbal analogies for other <i>halakhot</i>. When the verse states with regard to a wealthy leper: “Of his right hand” (Leviticus 14:17), this teaches a verbal analogy between the term <b>“hand”</b> written here and <b>“hand”</b> written <b>with regard to the removal of a handful,</b> as the verse states about the removal of a handful: “And he filled his hand from it” (Leviticus 9:17). The verbal analogy teaches that the removal of the handful must also be performed with the right hand.
Similarly, when the verse states: “Of his right foot” (Leviticus 14:17), with regard to a wealthy leper, this teaches a verbal analogy between the term <b>“foot”</b> written here and <b>“foot”</b> written <b>with regard to the ritual through which the <i>yavam</i>, a man whose married brother died childless, frees his brother’s widow, the <i>yevama</i>, of her levirate bonds [<i>ḥalitza</i>],</b> as the verse states with regard to <i>ḥalitza</i>: “And remove his shoe from upon his foot” (Deuteronomy 25:9). The verbal analogy teaches that the shoe is removed from his right foot.
Additionally, when the verse states: “Upon the tip of the right ear of him that is to be cleansed” (Leviticus 14:17), with regard to a wealthy leper, this teaches a verbal analogy between the term <b>“ear”</b> written here and <b>“ear”</b> written <b>with regard to</b> the <b>piercing</b> of a Hebrew slave’s ear with an awl, as the verse states: “And his master shall bore his ear through with an awl” (Exodus 21:6). The verbal analogy teaches that the slave’s right ear is pierced.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the additional mention of the <b>left</b> hand in the verse dealing <b>with the poor</b> leper, <b>for what</b> purpose <b>does</b> it <b>come? Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said:</b> It comes <b>to disqualify</b> the <b>right</b> hand <b>of a priest for</b> the purification of <b>a leper.</b> This teaches <b>that you should not say: And if in a place where</b> the <b>left</b> side <b>is not included,</b> as sacrificial rites in general are disqualified when performed with the left hand, the <b>right</b> hand <b>is included,</b> i.e., those rites must be performed with the right hand, then <b>in a place where</b> the <b>left</b> hand <b>is included,</b> in the case of a leper, <b>isn’t it logical that</b> the <b>right</b> hand should also be <b>included?</b> Therefore, the verse repeats that the oil is poured into the priest’s left hand, in order to disqualify the right hand.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning <b>the other</b> verses that specify the <b>left</b> hand of a poor leper (Leviticus 14:26–27) as well as the <b>right hand and foot of a poor</b> leper (Leviticus 14:25–28), <b>for what</b> purpose do they <b>come?</b> The Gemara responds: These verses come <b>for that which the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Any passage that was stated</b> in the Torah <b>and was</b> then <b>repeated, was repeated only for</b> the sake of <b>a matter that was introduced</b> for the first time <b>in</b> the repeated passage. That is, sometimes the Torah repeats an entire passage just to teach a single new detail. In this case, the verses that discuss the purification of a poor leper were repeated only for the sake of the differences in the offerings between a wealthy leper and a poor one. No additional <i>halakha</i> should be derived from them.
§ <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Lakish says: Any place</b> in the Torah <b>in which</b> it <b>is stated</b> that an action is performed with <b>a finger or</b> by the <b>priesthood,</b> i.e., that one uses his finger to perform the action or that a priest performs it, this teaches that it is performed <b>only</b> with the <b>right</b> hand.
The Gemara comments: It might <b>enter our mind</b> to say that this means that <b>we require both a finger and</b> the <b>priesthood</b> to be stated together in the verse in order to mandate use of the right hand, e.g., <b>as it is written: “And the priest shall take of the blood of the sin offering with his finger”</b> (Leviticus 4:25). <b>And</b> the fact that this verse is referring to a finger from his right hand <b>is derived from a leper, as it is written: “And the priest shall dip his right finger”</b> (Leviticus 14:16). This cannot be correct, <b>as</b> there is the verse that addresses <b>the removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>in which only</b> the <b>priesthood is written, and</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (6a): If the priest <b>removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand the meal offering is <b>unfit.</b>
Therefore, <b>Rava said:</b> This statement means that if the verse mentions <b>either a finger or</b> the <b>priesthood,</b> only the right hand may be used.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: But this is contradicted by the verse discussing <b>the conveyance of</b> the <b>limbs</b> of the daily burnt offering <b>to the ramp</b> of the altar, <b>as priesthood is written with regard to it, as it is written: “And the priest shall sacrifice the whole</b> and make it smoke <b>upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:13), <b>and the Master said</b> that <b>this</b> verse is referring to <b>the conveyance of</b> the <b>limbs to the ramp. And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 31b): When the priest conveys the limbs to the ramp, <b>the foot of</b> the <b>right</b> side of the offering is carried <b>in</b> the <b>left</b> hand of the priest, <b>and the place of its skin,</b> i.e., the side of the limb covered in skin, is held facing <b>outward.</b> Clearly, use of the left hand does not disqualify the conveyance of the limbs.
The Gemara responds: <b>When we say</b> that if the verse states <b>either finger or priesthood</b> then the left hand is disqualified, this is only <b>with regard to a matter that precludes atonement,</b> i.e., a rite whose performance is indispensable to the atonement, similar to the sprinkling of the oil on the leper (see Leviticus 14:16). The conveyance of the limbs, by contrast, is not indispensable to atonement.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there the <b>collection</b> of the blood in a service vessel, <b>which is a matter indispensable to atonement, and about which priesthood is written? As it is written: “And Aaron’s sons, the priests, shall present the blood”</b> (Leviticus 1:5), and <b>this</b> is referring to <b>the collection of the blood. And</b> yet <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 15b): If <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the blood is <b>disqualified</b> for offering, <b>and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit,</b> despite the fact that priesthood is mentioned in the verse.
The Gemara responds: <b>You are saying</b> that there is a difficulty <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon? Rabbi Shimon requires</b> that <b>both</b> matters appear in the verse, i.e., both finger and priesthood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Shimon</b> really <b>require both? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In <b>any place</b> in the Torah in <b>which</b> the word <b>hand is stated,</b> the verse <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to the <b>right</b> hand, and whenever a verse mentions the word <b>finger,</b> it <b>is</b> referring <b>only</b> to a finger of the <b>right</b> hand? The Gemara responds: According to Rabbi Shimon, if the verse mentions only the word <b>finger,</b> it <b>does not require</b> a mention of the <b>priesthood</b> as well for the limitation to apply. But if the verse mentions only the <b>priesthood,</b> it <b>requires</b> mention of the term <b>finger</b> for the limitation to apply.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to Rabbi Shimon, if the mention of the priesthood alone does not suffice to disqualify the right hand, then <b>why do I</b> need the superfluous reference to <b>a priest</b> with regard to the collection of the blood? After all, the verse already states that the collection must be performed by the sons of Aaron. The Gemara responds: The additional mention of the priesthood indicates that a priest must perform the collection of the blood <b>in his priestly state,</b> i.e., while wearing the priestly vestments.

Daf 10b

The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t there the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>concerning which only</b> the <b>priesthood is written</b> in the verse, <b>and we learned:</b> If <b>one sprinkled</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand it is <b>disqualified; and Rabbi Shimon does not disagree</b> with this ruling, indicating that Rabbi Shimon holds that a mention of the priesthood does not require a mention of the word finger? <b>Abaye says: He disagrees</b> with this ruling <b>in a <i>baraita</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one collected</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand it is <b>disqualified, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b> Additionally, if <b>one sprinkled</b> the blood <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand it is <b>disqualified, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But that which Rava says</b> with regard to the superfluous terms in the passage discussing a leper: One derives a verbal analogy between the word <b>“hand”</b> written in that passage and the word <b>“hand”</b> written <b>with regard to the removal of a handful</b> from a meal offering, to indicate that the latter must also be performed with the right hand, <b>why do I</b> need this verbal analogy? One can <b>derive</b> that the handful must be removed with the right hand <b>from</b> the verse’s mention of the <b>priesthood,</b> as it is stated: “And the priest shall remove his handful” (Leviticus 5:12).
The Gemara responds: Both derivations are necessary, <b>one for</b> the removal of the <b>handful</b> from a meal offering, <b>and one for the sanctification of</b> the <b>handful,</b> i.e., placing it into a second service vessel. Both must be performed with the right hand.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Rabbi Shimon, who does not require sanctification of</b> the <b>handful, or according to the one who says that Rabbi Shimon also requires the sanctification of</b> the <b>handful but</b> that <b>he deems</b> the sanctification <b>fit</b> when performed <b>with</b> the <b>left</b> hand (see 26a), <b>why do I</b> need the verbal analogy <b>of Rava</b> between <b>“hand”</b> and <b>“hand”?</b>
<b>If</b> one suggests that it is necessary <b>to</b> indicate that the <b>removal of the handful itself</b> must be performed with the right hand, this cannot be, since this is <b>derived from</b> the verse cited by <b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya. As Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: What is the reason that Rabbi Shimon</b> does not require that the handful be sanctified in a service vessel? <b>As the verse states</b> with regard to the meal offering: <b>“It is most holy, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:10).
Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, elaborates: The verse compares the meal offering to a sin offering and a guilt offering. Therefore, if the priest <b>comes to perform</b> the burning of the handful <b>with</b> his <b>hand, he performs it with</b> his <b>right</b> hand, <b>like</b> in the case of <b>a sin offering,</b> whose blood is sprinkled with the hand. And if he <b>comes to perform it with a vessel,</b> i.e., if he first sanctifies the handful in a service vessel, then <b>he</b> may <b>perform it with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>like</b> in the case of <b>a guilt offering,</b> whose blood is sprinkled from a vessel. Since the removal of the handful is performed with the hand, the verse indicates that it must be performed with the right hand, and the verbal analogy is unnecessary.
The Gemara responds: The verbal analogy <b>is necessary only for the handful of the meal offering of a sinner,</b> to teach that it must be removed with the right hand. It might <b>enter your mind to say: Since Rabbi Shimon says</b> that this offering does not require oil and frankincense <b>so that</b> a sinner’s <b>offering will not be of superior quality,</b> perhaps <b>when</b> the priest <b>removed the handful with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, which is a manner of inferior quality, <b>it should be fit as well.</b> The verbal analogy therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the handful must always be removed with the right hand, even in the case of the meal offering of a sinner.
§ The mishna teaches: If a priest <b>removed the handful</b> of flour, <b>and a stone or a grain of salt emerged in his hand,</b>

Daf 11a

<b>or a pinch of frankincense</b> emerged in his hand, the meal offering is <b>unfit,</b> as the handful lacks a full measure on account of these items. The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need <b>all these</b> examples? Any one of them would convey the fact that the handful must contain a full measure.
The Gemara explains: All of the cases are <b>necessary. Because if</b> the mishna had <b>taught</b> only the example of <b>a stone,</b> it might have been thought that only a stone diminishes the measure of the handful, <b>because it is not fit for sacrifice. But</b> with regard to <b>salt, which is fit for sacrifice,</b> as the priest places salt on the handful before burning it upon the altar, one might <b>say</b> that the handful <b>should be fit,</b> as the salt should not subtract from the handful’s measure.
<b>And if</b> the mishna had <b>taught</b> only the example of <b>salt,</b> it might have been thought that the salt diminishes the handful’s measure <b>as it was not initially fixed</b> together <b>with</b> the entire <b>meal offering.</b> The reason is <b>that</b> the priest <b>salts the handful alone. But</b> with regard to the <b>frankincense, which was initially fixed</b> together <b>with</b> the entire <b>meal offering,</b> i.e., it is placed upon the meal offering before the priest removes a handful from it, one might <b>say</b> that the handful <b>should be fit</b> and the frankincense should not diminish from the handful’s measure. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that in any of these instances the meal offering is unfit.
§ The mishna teaches that if a stone, or a grain of salt, or a pinch of frankincense emerged in the priest’s hand together with the handful, the meal offering is unfit <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the Sages <b>said: The handful that is lacking or that is outsized</b> is <b>unfit.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why</b> does the <i>tanna</i> explain that the offering is not valid <b>specifically because</b> it is <b>lacking or outsized? But let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>derive</b> that such a handful is not valid <b>due to</b> the fact that there is <b>an interposition</b> between the priest’s hand and the handful. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says:</b> Since there are certain instances where these items do not interpose between one’s hand and the handful, e.g., when they are located <b>on the side</b> of the handful, the mishna teaches that they disqualify the handful due to the fact that they reduce its measure.
§ <b>Abaye said to Rava: How do</b> the priests properly <b>remove the handful</b> from a meal offering? Rava <b>said to him:</b> They remove it <b>as people</b> normally <b>remove handfuls,</b> by folding all of their fingers over the palm of the hand. Abaye <b>raised an objection to</b> Rava from a <i>baraita</i> discussing the mitzva function of each of the fingers: <b>This</b> small finger is for measuring <b>a span</b> (see Exodus 28:16), i.e., the distance between the thumb and the little finger. <b>This</b> fourth finger is used for <b>removal of a handful</b> from the meal offering, i.e., the measurement of a handful begins from this finger, as the priest removes a handful by folding the middle three fingers over his palm.
Furthermore, <b>this</b> middle finger is used for measuring <b>a cubit,</b> the distance from the elbow to the tip of the middle finger. <b>This</b> forefinger, next to the thumb, is the <b>finger</b> used to sprinkle the blood of offerings on the altar. And finally, <b>this thumb</b> is the one on which the blood and oil is placed during the purification ritual of a leper (see Leviticus 14:17). Evidently, the little finger is not used in the removal of a handful.
The Gemara responds: The little finger is used <b>only for</b> the purposes of <b>leveling</b> the handful, <b>that is to say,</b> the priest first <b>removes a handful</b> with <b>a full hand,</b> i.e., all of his fingers, <b>so that it should not be lacking</b> in measure, <b>and then he wipes</b> away the protruding flour <b>with</b> his <b>little finger from the bottom,</b> and with his thumb from the top.
The Gemara asks: <b>How</b> is the removal of the handful <b>performed? Rav Zutra bar Toviyya says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> When the priest places his hand in the meal offering, <b>he bends his</b> middle <b>three fingers until</b> the tips of his fingers <b>reach over the palm of his hand, and</b> he then <b>removes the handful.</b>
The Gemara notes <b>that</b> this <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. From the verse that states: “And he shall remove from there <b>his handful”</b> (Leviticus 2:2), one <b>might</b> have thought that the handful should be <b>overflowing.</b> Therefore, another <b>verse states:</b> “And he shall take up from it <b>with his handful [<i>bekumtzo</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:8). The prefix that means “with” can also mean: In, indicating that the proper measure of a handful is that which is contained within one’s fingers alone.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> the measurement of a handful is determined by the term <b>“with his handful,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the priest removes a handful <b>with his fingertips,</b> i.e., that a handful consists of that which the priest removes by folding his fingers onto themselves. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “His handful,”</b> indicating that the handful must be full and not merely that which is contained within his fingers. <b>How so? He scoops</b> by closing <b>his three fingers over the palm of his hand, and</b> in this way <b>takes a handful</b> from the flour of the meal offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>In</b> the case of <b>a pan</b> meal offering <b>and</b> that <b>of a deep-pan</b> meal offering, when the flour was fried before being scooped and was therefore hard, the priest <b>wipes</b> away <b>with his thumb</b> any flour that was overflowing <b>above</b> his handful, <b>and with his little finger</b> he wipes away the flour that was pushing out <b>below. And this</b> precise taking of the handful of a meal offering <b>is</b> the most <b>difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rite in the Temple,</b> as the priest must wipe away any protruding elements without removing any flour from the handful itself.
The Gemara asks: <b>This one</b> is the hardest sacrificial rite, <b>and no other? But isn’t there pinching</b> the nape of the neck of a bird offering, which is also considered extremely difficult to perform, <b>and isn’t there</b> the <b>scooping</b> of the handful of incense by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, another rite that is extremely difficult to perform? <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that <b>this</b> taking of the handful of a meal offering <b>is one of</b> the most <b>difficult</b> sacrificial <b>rites in the Temple.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that the term <b>“his handful”</b> means that the removal of the handful from a meal offering should be performed <i>ab initio</i> <b>in the manner that people</b> usually <b>remove a handful,</b> with their fingertips angled to the side. <b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: What</b> is the <i>halakha</i> if the priest <b>removed a handful with his fingertips,</b> i.e., if he placed his hand horizontally over the meal offering and filled his palm with flour by closing his fingers to his palm? Does this disqualify the taking of the handful or not?
Similarly, if the priest took a handful <b>from the sides,</b> by passing the back of his hand back and forth over the flour in the vessel so that the flour collected in his palm by way of the side of his palm, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Furthermore, if he took the handful with the back of his hand placed <b>downward</b> in the vessel, and with his fingers he collected the flour <b>upward</b> into his palm, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Are the handfuls removed in this manner fit for sacrifice? The Gemara states: These dilemmas <b>shall stand</b>unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is <b>obvious to me</b> that when the Torah states: <b>“His handful”</b> (Leviticus 16:12), in the context of the scooping of handfuls of incense by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, it means <b>in the manner that people</b> usually <b>scoop a handful,</b> by placing the backs of their hands into the vessel and bringing their hands together. <b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if the High Priest <b>scooped a handful with his fingertips? What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if he took a handful <b>from the sides? What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> if <b>he scooped a handful with this</b> hand <b>and with that</b> hand separately <b>and</b> then <b>brought them together?</b> The Gemara states: These dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Pappa raises</b> yet another <b>dilemma:</b> If the priest took the handful from the vessel containing the meal offering and <b>stuck the handful onto the side of</b> the second <b>vessel</b> in order to sanctify it, i.e., the handful was not placed directly into the vessel, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we require</b> that the handful be <b>inside</b> the <b>vessel, and</b> that <b>is</b> the case here? <b>Or perhaps we require</b> that the handful be <b>placed</b> properly <b>inside</b> the vessel, <b>and</b> that <b>is not</b> the case in this instance. No answer is found, and the Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Mar bar Rav Ashi raises</b> a similar <b>dilemma:</b> If the priest <b>overturned the vessel and stuck</b> the <b>handful to the underside of the vessel,</b> in a case where there was an indentation on the underside, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Do <b>we require</b> that the handful be <b>placed inside</b> the vessel, <b>and that</b> requirement <b>is</b> fulfilled here, as the handful is within the indentation? <b>Or perhaps we require</b> that it be placed <b>properly</b> in the vessel, <b>and that is not</b> the case here. The Gemara states: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>How does</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the removal of a handful? <b>He extends his fingers onto the palm of his hand.</b> If <b>one increased its oil, decreased its oil,</b> or <b>decreased its frankincense,</b> beyond the appropriate measures, the meal offering is <b>unfit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>What are the circumstances</b> of a case where the meal offering is disqualified due to the fact that one <b>increased its oil? Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The circumstances are a case <b>where he separated two <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>for</b> the meal offering instead of one <i>log</i>, and mixed them into a tenth of an ephah of flour. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>And let</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>interpret</b> the mishna as referring to a case <b>where he mixed non-sacred oil or the oil of another</b> meal offering <b>into</b> the meal offering.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>non-sacred oil and the oil of another</b> meal offering <b>do not disqualify</b> a meal offering, <b>Rav Zutra bar Toviyya objects to this</b> claim: <b>If that is so,</b> then with regard to the <b>meal offering of a sinner,</b> of which it is stated (59b) <b>that oil disqualifies it, how can you find</b> the circumstances where it is in fact disqualified?
Rav Zutra bar Toviyya elaborates: <b>If</b> you suggest that he mixed <b>its own</b> oil into the flour, such a case does not exist, as the meal offering of a sinner <b>does not have</b> any oil. <b>If</b> he mixed <b>non-sacred</b> oil <b>or</b> that <b>of another</b> meal offering into the flour, the meal offering should not be disqualified, as <b>you said</b> that such oil <b>does not disqualify</b> a meal offering. <b>And if you would say that he designated oil for</b> his meal offering and mixed it into the flour despite the Torah prohibition against mixing oil into it, I say that <b>since</b> the meal offering of a sinner <b>does not have oil at all,</b> any oil that he separates and mixes into it <b>is</b> considered <b>non-sacred,</b> and you have already said that non-sacred oil does not disqualify a meal offering.
The Gemara responds: In fact, non-sacred oil and the oil of another meal offering do disqualify a meal offering, <b>and Rabbi Eliezer is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary,</b> as follows: <b>It is not necessary</b> to say <b>that non-sacred</b> oil <b>and</b> the oil <b>of another</b> meal offering <b>disqualify</b> a meal offering. <b>But</b> in a case where one <b>separated two <i>log</i> for</b> his meal offering, <b>since this</b> first <i>log</i> <b>is fit for</b> the meal offering, <b>and that</b> second <i>log</i> <b>is</b> also <b>fit for it,</b> one might <b>say</b> that even when he mixes both <i>log</i> into the meal offering, <b>it should not disqualify</b> the meal offering. Therefore, Rabbi Eliezer <b>teaches us</b> that the meal offering is disqualified in this case as well.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does Rabbi Eliezer</b> derive <b>this</b> conclusion? <b>Rava said:</b> The terminology of <b>the mishna posed a difficulty for him,</b> as one can ask: <b>Why does</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>specifically teach</b> that the meal offering is disqualified if <b>he increased its oil,</b> which indicates that he increased it with oil belonging to the offering itself? <b>Let</b> the mishna <b>teach</b> simply: <b>He increased the oil. Rather, this</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us: That even though he</b> initially <b>separated two <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>for</b> the meal offering, its own oil disqualifies the offering when there is too much.
§ The mishna teaches that if one <b>decreased its frankincense</b> beyond its appropriate measure, the meal offering is unfit. Concerning this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>decreased</b> its frankincense to the point that the amount <b>stood at</b> only <b>one pinch,</b> it is <b>disqualified,</b> but if the decreased amount stood <b>at two pinches,</b> it is <b>fit;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> If the decreased amount stood <b>at one pinch,</b> it is <b>fit; less than that,</b> it is <b>disqualified.</b>

Daf 11b

The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: A handful</b> of flour <b>or frankincense that</b> was <b>decreased</b> by <b>any amount</b> from its full measure is <b>disqualified?</b> The Gemara answers that one should <b>teach</b> the <i>baraita</i> as follows: <b>A pinch of frankincense that</b> was <b>decreased</b> by <b>any amount</b> is <b>disqualified. And if you wish, say</b> instead that <b>here,</b> the first cited statement of Rabbi Shimon, is referring to the case <b>of frankincense that comes with a meal offering,</b> and this frankincense is disqualified only when there is less than a pinch, whereas <b>there,</b> the second statement of Rabbi Shimon, is referring to the case <b>of frankincense that comes by itself.</b> Such frankincense is disqualified if it comprises any less than its full measure.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> There are <b>three disputes</b> of <i>tanna’im</i> <b>with regard to the matter. Rabbi Meir holds</b> that the priest must remove <b>a handful at the beginning, and ultimately</b> the entire <b>handful</b> must be burned upon the altar. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that the priest must remove <b>a handful at the beginning, and ultimately</b> at least <b>two pinches</b> from it must be burned upon the altar. <b>And Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that the priest must remove <b>a handful at the beginning and ultimately</b> at least <b>one pinch</b> from it must be burned upon the altar.
<b>And</b> all <b>three of them interpret a single verse</b> differently. The verse states: “And he shall take up from there his handful, of the fine flour of the meal offering, and of the oil of it, <b>and [<i>ve’et</i>] all the frankincense that is upon the meal offering,</b> and shall make it smoke upon the altar” (Leviticus 6:8). <b>Rabbi Meir holds</b> that one may not make the offering smoke upon the altar <b>unless there</b> remains <b>the</b> entire measure of <b>frankincense that was initially fixed together with the meal offering. And Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that when the verse states: <b>“All [<i>kol</i>],”</b> it is referring to any part of the frankincense, <b>even a single pinch,</b> as <i>kol</i> can mean any amount (see II Kings 2:4). And when the verse states: <b>“<i>Et</i>,”</b> this serves <b>to includ-e another pinch.</b> Accordingly, at least two pinches must remain to be burned upon the altar. <b>And Rabbi Shimon</b> interprets the word “all” in the same manner as does Rabbi Yehuda, but he <b>does not interpret</b> and derive a <i>halakha</i> from the term <b>“<i>et</i>,”</b> and he therefore holds that only one pinch must remain to be burned.
<b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef</b> further <b>says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between these <i>tanna’im</i> is <b>with regard to frankincense that comes with a meal offering. But with regard to frankincense that comes by itself, everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, <b>agrees</b> that the priest must bring <b>a handful at the beginning, and ultimately</b> the entire <b>handful</b> must be burned upon the altar. <b>For this</b> reason it <b>was necessary</b> for the verse to state: <b>“That is upon the meal offering,”</b> as this indicates <b>that together with a meal offering, yes,</b> one may burn the frankincense even if there remains only a pinch or two, but with regard to frankincense that comes <b>by itself,</b> one may <b>not</b> burn it if it is in that state.
<b>And Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between these <i>tanna’im</i> is <b>with regard to frankincense that comes with a meal offering. But with regard to frankincense that comes in bowls</b> together with the shewbread, <b>everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon, <b>agrees</b> that there must be <b>two handfuls in the beginning,</b> one handful for each bowl, <b>and ultimately</b> there must also be <b>two handfuls.</b>
The Gemara asks: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that this is the case, as with regard to this <i>halakha</i> the verse does not state the term: All, from which one might derive that it is referring to any part of the frankincense? The Gemara explains: This ruling is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since</b> the frankincense in the bowls <b>comes together with bread,</b> i.e., the shewbread, it should be <b>considered as:</b> “Frankincense <b>that is upon the meal offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:8), and therefore Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon claim that one may sacrifice it even if less than two handfuls remain. Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Yosef <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the case.
The Gemara notes: <b>Rabbi Ami and Rabbi Yitzḥak Nappaḥa disagree with regard to</b> the case of frankincense that comes by itself. <b>One says</b> that the <b>dispute</b> between the <i>tanna’im</i> with regard to whether or not a handful of frankincense that became lacking may be sacrificed upon the altar applies only <b>with regard to frankincense that comes with a meal offering, but with regard to frankincense that comes by itself, everyone agrees</b> that the priest must remove <b>a handful at the beginning and ultimately</b> the entire <b>handful</b> must be burned upon the altar. <b>And one says: Just as</b> there is <b>a dispute in this</b> case, <b>so too,</b> there is <b>a dispute in that</b> case.
§ The mishna teaches that if the priest <b>decreased its frankincense</b> beyond its appropriate measure, the meal offering is unfit. The Gemara infers from this statement that if <b>he increased</b> its frankincense, it is <b>fit.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that if he <b>increased</b> its frankincense the meal offering is <b>disqualified? Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> rules that the meal offering is disqualified in a case <b>where he separated two handfuls</b> of frankincense <b>for</b> the meal offering and placed both of them onto the meal offering.
<b>And Rami bar Ḥama says:</b> In a case where <b>one separated two handfuls</b> of frankincense <b>for</b> the meal offering <b>and</b> subsequently <b>lost one of them,</b> if it was lost <b>before the removal of the handful</b> of the meal offering, the additional frankincense <b>was not fixed</b> with the meal offering, and therefore it does not disqualify the meal offering. But if this occurred <b>after the removal of the handful</b> of the meal offering, since both handfuls <b>were</b> already <b>fixed</b> with the meal offering, it is disqualified, as he increased its frankincense by a large amount.
<b>And Rami bar Ḥama says:</b> In a case where <b>one separated four handfuls</b> of frankincense <b>for</b> placement in the <b>two bowls</b> that accompany the shewbread, <b>and two of them</b> were subsequently <b>lost,</b> the <i>halakha</i> depends on when they were lost. If they were lost <b>before the removal of</b> the <b>bowls</b> from the Table of the shewbread, then the additional frankincense <b>was not</b> yet <b>fixed</b> with the shewbread, and the frankincense remains fit for sacrifice. But if they were lost <b>after the removal of</b> the <b>bowls,</b> then all four handfuls <b>were</b> already <b>fixed</b> with the shewbread, and therefore the frankincense is disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I also</b> need <b>this? This</b> statement of Rami bar Ḥama is identical to <b>that</b> previous statement, as the burning of the frankincense permits the shewbread for consumption just as the frankincense permits the meal offering for consumption. Consequently, the removal of the bowls of frankincense is comparable to the removal of the handful from a meal offering.
The Gemara explains: The last statement of Rami bar Ḥama is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>since</b> the <b>handful of</b> frankincense of the shewbread <b>is</b> already considered <b>designated</b> for burning, as it is placed in a separate bowl and burned in its entirety, then <b>once the time arrives for removing</b> the bowls from upon the Table of the shewbread, <b>it is considered as though</b> the bowls were already <b>removed,</b> and the shewbread should therefore be disqualified on account of the additional frankincense. Therefore, Rami bar Ḥama <b>teaches us</b> that the additional handfuls disqualify the shewbread only if they were inside the bowls at the time of their actual removal from the Table.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent <b>to partake</b> of <b>its remainder outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or</b> to partake of <b>an olive-bulk of its remainder outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>to burn its handful outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or</b> to burn <b>an olive-bulk</b> of <b>its handful outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>or to burn its frankincense outside</b> the Temple courtyard, in all these cases the offering is <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i></b> for one who partakes of <b>it.</b> If one had the intent <b>to partake</b> of <b>its remainder on the next day or</b> to partake of <b>an olive-bulk of its remainder on the next day, to burn its handful on the next day or</b> to burn <b>an olive-bulk of its handful on the next day, or to burn</b> its <b>frankincense on the next day,</b>

Daf 12a

the offering is <b><i>piggul</i>, and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of the remainder of that meal offering.
<b>This is the principle:</b> In the case of <b>anyone who removes the handful, or places</b> the handful <b>in the vessel,</b> or <b>who conveys</b> the vessel with the handful to the altar, or <b>who burns</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, e.g., the remainder, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>burns</b> it on the altar, e.g., the handful or the frankincense, <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the meal offering is <b>unfit but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>.</b> If his intent was to do so <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> on account of it, provided that the permitting</b> factor, i.e., the handful, <b>was sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b> If the permitting factor was not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva, although the meal offering is unfit, the prohibition of <i>piggul</i> does not apply to it.
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor</b> considered to have been <b>sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If one <b>removed the handful in silence,</b> i.e., with no specific intent, and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> if one <b>removed the handful</b> with the intent to partake of the or burn the handful or frankincense <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, and conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar <b>in silence,</b> with no specific intent; <b>or</b> if one <b>removed the handful</b> and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, that is</b> the case of an offering <b>whose permitting factor was sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva,</b> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for partaking of it due to <i>piggul</i>.
<b>How</b> is <b>the permitting factor not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva?</b> If one <b>removed the handful</b> with the intent to partake of the remainder or burn the handful or frankincense <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> or <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or</b> if one <b>removed the handful</b> with the intent to partake of the remainder or burn the handful or frankincense <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area; or</b> if one <b>removed the handful</b> and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, and conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, that is</b> the case of an offering <b>whose permitting factor was not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
<b>The meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy</b> brought by a <i>sota</i> <b>that one removed their handful not for their sake</b> and <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of the remainder or burn the handful <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time; or that one removed the handful</b> with the intent to partake of the remainder or burn the handful <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time</b> or <b>placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, <b>not for their sake; or that one removed the handful, and placed</b> it <b>in the vessel, and conveyed</b> it, <b>and burned</b> the handful on the altar, <b>not for their sake, that is</b> the case of an offering <b>whose permitting factor was not sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.</b>
If one performed one of these rites with the intent <b>to partake of an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, or <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area and <b>half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>half an olive-bulk the next day</b> and <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, the offering is <b>unfit but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>this is the principle: If the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area,</b> the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> on account of it. If the intent</b> with regard to <b>the area preceded the intent</b> with regard to <b>the time,</b> the offering is <b>unfit but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>.
