And the Rabbis say:</b> In both <b>this</b> case, where the intent with regard to time was first, <b>and that</b> case, where the intent with regard to area came first, the offering is <b>unfit but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>According to the statement of the one who says</b> that if the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering became <b>lacking between the removal of the handful and the burning</b> of the handful on the altar the priest nevertheless <b>burns the handful on</b> account of such a meal offering, <b>and</b> as <b>we maintain that</b> despite the fact that the handful is burned on account of it <b>that remainder is prohibited for consumption, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <i>piggul</i>? <b>Should</b> the <b>burning</b> of the handful <b>be effective in establishing</b> such a remainder <b>as <i>piggul</i></b> when the handful was burned with the intent to partake of the remainder the next day?
<b>And</b> similarly, is the burning of the handful effective <b>in removing</b> such a remainder <b>from</b> being subject to <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, just as a complete remainder is removed being subject to this prohibition after the burning of the handful, when it becomes permitted to the priests for consumption?
<b>Rav Huna said: Even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood of an offering, which renders its meat permitted for consumption and removes it from being subject to misuse of consecrated property, <b>is effective in</b> removing the meat of an offering that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard from being subject to misuse of consecrated property despite the fact that such meat is prohibited for consumption, <b>that statement</b> applies only when the meat was disqualified by means of <b>leaving.</b>
Rav Huna explains: The reason is <b>that</b> the meat remains <b>as is, and</b> the <b>disqualification</b> of the meat by means of leaving is <b>on account of something else,</b> i.e., a factor external to the meat itself. <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a lack</b> in the measure of the remainder of a meal offering, <b>which is a disqualification</b> on account <b>of itself,</b> the <b>burning</b> of the handful <b>is not effective in</b> removing the remainder from being subject to misuse of consecrated property, nor to establish it as <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rava said to</b> Rav Huna: <b>On the contrary; even according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says</b> that <b>sprinkling is not effective in</b> removing the meat that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard from being subject to misuse of consecrated property, <b>that statement</b> applies only when the meat was disqualified by means of <b>leaving, as</b> the meat <b>is not inside</b> the Temple courtyard where the sprinkling could be effective for it. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a lack</b> in the measure of the remainder of a meal offering <b>that is inside</b> the Temple courtyard, the <b>burning</b> of the handful <b>is effective</b> in removing the remainder from being subject to misuse of consecrated property as well as in establishing it as <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Rava said: From where do I say</b> that even remainders that lack a full measure can be rendered <i>piggul</i>? This can be inferred from that <b>which we learned</b> in the mishna: With regard to <b>one who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent <b>to partake</b> of <b>its remainder outside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>or</b> to partake of <b>an olive-bulk of its remainder outside</b> the Temple courtyard, the meal offering is unfit but there is no liability for <i>karet</i>, and if he removes a handful from the meal offering with the intent to partake of its remainder beyond the designated time or to partake of an olive-bulk of its remainder beyond the designated time the offering is <i>piggul</i> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for partaking of the remainder of that meal offering. <b>And Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches</b> in his version of the mishna: <b>One who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent to partake of its remainder, <b>and he does not teach: Or an olive-bulk</b> of its remainder.
Rava continues: <b>What is the reason</b> that Rabbi Ḥiyya diverged from the standard text of the mishna and <b>did not teach: Or an olive-bulk?</b> Is it <b>not</b> because his mishna is discussing a case <b>where</b> the <b>remainder</b> later <b>became lacking and</b> its measure <b>stood at an olive-bulk? And</b> therefore Rabbi Ḥiyya did not include the clause: Or an olive-bulk, <b>since</b> later in the mishna, <b>with regard to</b> the <b>placement</b> of the handful <b>in a vessel,</b> and <b>with regard to</b> the <b>conveyance</b> of the vessel to the altar, <b>and with regard to</b> the <b>burning</b> of the handful, <b>he</b> could <b>not teach</b> the phrase:

Daf 12b

<b>Or an olive-bulk, in</b> the case of one’s intent with regard to the consumption of the <b>remainder,</b> because the remainder is already the size of an olive-bulk. Therefore, <b>in</b> the case of the <b>removal of the handful as well,</b> i.e., when he teaches: One who removes a handful <b>to partake</b> of <b>its remainder,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>did not teach: Or</b> to consume <b>an olive-bulk</b> of its remainder, despite the fact that he could have done so in that clause. Rava concludes his proof: <b>And</b> yet <b>the latter clause teaches</b> that if one burned the handful with the intent to consume the remainder after its designated time, the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> on</b> account of <b>it. Evidently, burning is effective in</b> rendering a lacking remainder as <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>No,</b> one cannot prove from here that the mishna is discussing the case of a remainder that became lacking. The reason for this is: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna of Rabbi Ḥiyya? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 109b): With regard to <b>the handful</b> of flour, <b>and the frankincense, and the incense, and the meal offering of priests</b> (see Leviticus 6:16), <b>and the meal offering of the anointed priest</b> (see Leviticus 6:12–15), <b>and the meal offering</b> that accompanies the <b>libations</b> brought with animal offerings (see Numbers 15:1–16), <b>where one sacrificed an olive-bulk from one of them outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>liable</b> for sacrificing outside the courtyard. <b>And Rabbi Elazar exempts</b> one from liability <b>until he sacrifices</b> them in their <b>entirety</b> rather than just an olive-bulk from them.
Abaye concludes: <b>Since with regard to the burning of the handful he</b> could <b>not teach: Or</b> burn <b>an olive-bulk of its handful outside</b> the Temple, as according to Rabbi Elazar one is not liable for burning anything less than the full handful and therefore intent to burn only an olive-bulk does not render the offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>with regard to</b> the <b>remainder as well, he did not teach: Or an olive-bulk.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna of Rabbi Ḥiyya is really in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar,</b> then <b>this</b> statement: <b>To burn its handful</b> outside the Temple courtyard, <b>should have</b> been phrased: <b>To burn its handful and its frankincense</b> outside the Temple courtyard, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 110a): With regard to <b>the handful and the frankincense,</b> in a case <b>where one sacrificed</b> only <b>one of them outside</b> the Temple courtyard, he is <b>liable. Rabbi Eliezer exempts</b> from liability one who burns only one of them <b>until he sacrifices both of them</b> together.
The Gemara responds: The mishna of Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>is necessary only for the handful of the meal offering of a sinner,</b> which has no frankincense. Since only the burning of the handful permits the remainder of the sinner’s meal offering for consumption, one’s intent to burn it the next day renders the offering <i>piggul</i>. With regard to this meal offering, one is not liable for burning anything less than the full handful, according to Rabbi Elazar, and therefore it does not teach: Or an olive-bulk.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did the <i>tanna</i> go to all that trouble [<i>ve’ikhpal</i>]</b> just <b>to teach us</b> a <i>halakha</i> that is applicable only in the case of <b>the handful of the meal offering of a sinner?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Yes,</b> he did. <b>And similarly, when Rav Dimi came</b> to Babylonia from Eretz Yisrael, he said that <b>Rabbi Elazar</b> ben Pedat <b>said:</b> When the mishna discusses an instance where one has intent to sacrifice the handful of a meal offering outside, <b>it is</b> referring to the <b>handful of the meal offering of a sinner, and it is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar.</b>
<b>Rava then said: That</b> which <b>I said,</b> that the burning of the handful with the intent to consume the remainder the next day is effective in rendering even a remainder that became lacking in measure as <i>piggul</i> and to remove it from being subject to misuse of consecrated property <b>is nothing, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the shewbread: <b>“It is most holy”</b> (Leviticus 24:9). The restrictive term “it” teaches that the shewbread must remain whole, so <b>that if one of</b> the loaves of the shewbread <b>broke</b> and consequently became lacking in measure, then <b>all of its loaves are disqualified,</b> and the burning of the bowls of frankincense do not render them permitted for consumption.
Rava continues: It can be inferred from the <i>baraita</i> that if the loaves remained whole <b>but</b> one of them <b>left</b> the Temple, <b>those that are inside</b> the Temple are still <b>fit.</b> And <b>whom have you heard who says:</b> The <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>is effective in</b> rendering <i>piggul</i> an item that <b>left</b> the Temple? <b>It is Rabbi Akiva. And</b> yet <b>he says</b> in this <i>baraita</i> that if one of the loaves <b>broke,</b> the burning of the frankincense is <b>not</b> effective for them. Similarly, with regard to the remainder of a meal offering that became lacking in measure, even Rabbi Akiva agrees that the burning of the handful is ineffective in rendering it <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: How can you cite a proof from this <i>baraita</i>? <b>Is</b> it <b>taught</b> in this <i>baraita</i>: But if a loaf of shewbread <b>left,</b> those loaves that remain inside are fit? <b>Perhaps</b> all of the loaves are disqualified if even one of them left, and one should infer a different <i>halakha</i> from the <i>baraita</i>, that <b>if</b> one of the loaves <b>became ritually impure, these</b> that remain pure <b>are fit.</b>
Abaye explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for such a distinction? The reason is <b>that the frontplate</b> of the High Priest <b>effects acceptance</b> for ritually impure offerings. <b>But</b> in a case where a loaf of shewbread <b>left,</b> the frontplate does <b>not</b> effect acceptance, and therefore all of the loaves are disqualified, as in a case where one loaf breaks. <b>And</b> if so, the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says</b> that <b>sprinkling is not effective</b> with regard <b>to</b> an item <b>that left</b> the Temple courtyard.
Abaye continues: <b>And by right</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have also taught</b> that if one of the loaves of shewbread <b>left,</b> all the loaves are disqualified. <b>And</b> as for the fact <b>that it teaches</b> the <i>halakha</i> specifically with regard to a loaf that <b>broke, this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us: That even</b> if the loaf <b>broke,</b> in <b>which</b> case the loaf <b>is</b> still <b>inside</b> the Temple, <b>burning is not effective</b> with regard <b>to it. But according to Rabbi Akiva, who says</b> that <b>sprinkling is effective</b> with regard <b>to</b> an item that <b>left</b> the Temple, <b>even</b> in the case of <b>a lacking</b> measure, <b>burning is effective</b> with regard <b>to it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one’s intent was <b>to partake of half an olive-bulk</b> of the remainder <b>and to burn half an olive-bulk</b> of it not at the appropriate time or not in the appropriate area, the offering is <b>fit, because eating and burning do not join together.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara infers from the mishna: <b>The reason that</b> the two halves of an olive-bulk do not join together is because his intent was <b>to partake of</b> half an olive-bulk <b>and to burn</b> half an olive-bulk, which indicates that if his intent was <b>to partake</b> of half an olive-bulk of the remainder <b>and to partake of</b> half an olive-bulk of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one does <b>not consume</b> it, i.e., the handful, then the halves do <b>join together</b> to the amount of an olive-bulk and disqualify the offering.
The Gemara notes an apparent contradiction: <b>But the first clause teaches,</b> in the earlier mishna: If one’s intent was <b>to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, <b>or to burn an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>burns</b> it on the altar, beyond its designated time, the offering is <i>piggul</i>. One can infer from this mishna that if his intent was to partake of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, <b>yes,</b> such intent disqualifies an offering. But if his intent was to partake of an item <b>whose</b> typical <b>manner is</b> such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, this intent does <b>not</b> disqualify the offering, and likewise such intent does not join together with another to this end. If so, <b>who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> the latter clause?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer, who says</b> that <b>one can</b> have improper <b>intent from the consumption</b> performed by <b>a person to</b> the consumption performed by <b>the altar, and from the consumption</b> performed by the <b>altar to</b> the consumption performed by <b>a person.</b> In other words, if one’s intent was to burn the remainder the next day or to consume the handful the next day, such intent disqualifies an offering even though the remainder is intended for consumption by the priests and the handful is intended for burning upon the altar.
The Gemara cites the relevant ruling of Rabbi Eliezer. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (17a): In the case of <b>one who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent <b>to consume</b> after its designated time <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner is</b> such that one does <b>not consume</b> it, i.e., the handful, <b>or to burn</b> beyond its designated time <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner is</b> such that one does <b>not burn</b> it on the altar, i.e., the remainder of the meal offering, the meal offering is <b>fit. And Rabbi Eliezer deems</b> it <b>unfit,</b> although it is not <i>piggul</i> and consuming it is not punishable by <i>karet</i>.
<b>Abaye said: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna here is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> And <b>do not say that</b> one should infer from the mishna that if his intent was <b>to partake</b> of half an olive-bulk of an item whose typical manner is such that one consumes it <b>and to partake of</b> half an olive-bulk of <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner is</b> such that one does <b>not partake</b> of it, the offering is disqualified. <b>Rather, say</b> that if his intent was <b>to partake</b> of half an olive-bulk on the next day <b>and to partake</b> of half an olive-bulk outside the Temple, and each of these halves is from <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, then the halves are joined together and disqualify the offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is</b> this <b>teaching us?</b> The previous mishna already <b>teaches</b> that principle <b>explicitly:</b> If one performed one of these rites with the intent <b>to partake of an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area <b>and an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk the next day and an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, or <b>half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area <b>and half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> or <b>half an olive-bulk the next day and half an olive-bulk outside</b> its designated area, the offering is <b>unfit but there is no</b> liability for <b><i>karet</i>.</b>

Daf 13a

According to Abaye, <b>why do I also</b> need <b>this</b> mishna here? <b>If</b> you will suggest that this mishna is necessary, as one can infer from it that if one intended <b>to partake</b> of half an olive-bulk the next day <b>and</b> then intended <b>to partake of</b> another half an olive-bulk the next day, both from <b>an item whose</b> typical <b>manner</b> is such that one <b>partakes</b> of it, the mishna <b>teaches us that</b> they <b>join together</b> in order to render the offering <i>piggul</i>, this suggestion can be rejected: But <b>you</b> already <b>learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case <b>from the first clause of the latter clause</b> of the previous mishna, <b>as it teaches: Half an olive-bulk outside and half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> the offering is <b>unfit.</b> One can infer from this <b>that</b> if his intent was to consume <b>half an olive-bulk the next day and half an olive-bulk the next day,</b> it is <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>If</b> you suggest that the mishna is necessary for a case where one intended <b>to consume and to burn,</b> i.e., <b>that</b> the mishna <b>teaches us the</b> matter <b>itself,</b> that intent to consume does not join together with intent to burn, this too cannot be. The reason is that <b>from the inference of the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>you</b> can already <b>learn</b> the <i>halakha</i> in this case, as it teaches: If one intended to partake of an item whose typical manner is such that one partakes of it, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>. This indicates that if his intent was to consume an item whose typical manner is such that one does not consume it, the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara explains how the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> intent to consume and burn do not combine can be inferred from the mishna: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>if</b> when one intended <b>to partake</b> of an item whose typical manner is such that one partakes of it <b>and to partake of an item whose</b> typical <b>manner is</b> such that one does <b>not partake of</b> it, <b>you say</b> that his intentions <b>do not join together,</b> despite the fact that both of his intentions referred to consumption, <b>is it necessary</b> for the mishna to teach that intentions <b>to consume and to burn</b> do not join together?
The Gemara responds: <b>Yes;</b> although the mishna teaches the <i>halakha</i> of a case where one intended to consume an item typically consumed and to consume an item typically not consumed, <b>it was necessary for</b> the mishna to teach the <i>halakha</i> of a case where one intended <b>to eat and to burn.</b> As it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>there,</b> where one’s intentions referred solely to consumption, the <i>halakha</i> <b>is</b> that his intentions do not join together, <b>as he intended</b> to act <b>not in accordance with its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> since he intended to consume that which is not meant to be consumed.
The Gemara continues: <b>But here,</b> where his intent was to consume half an olive-bulk and to burn half an olive-bulk, <b>where with regard to this</b> half <b>he intends</b> in <b>accordance with its</b> typical <b>manner, and with regard to this</b> half <b>he intends in accordance with its</b> typical <b>manner,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>they should join together,</b> despite the fact that each intention concerns only half an olive-bulk. Therefore, the mishna <b>teaches us</b> that such intentions do not join together, and the mishna can be explained even in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of a priest <b>who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent <b>to partake of its remainder or to burn its handful</b> on <b>the next day, Rabbi Yosei concedes in this</b> instance <b>that it is</b> a case of <b><i>piggul</i> and he is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of <b>it.</b> But if the priest’s intent was <b>to burn its frankincense the next day, Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The meal offering is <b>unfit but</b> partaking of it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And the Rabbis say:</b> It is a case of <b><i>piggul</i> and he is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of the meal offering.
The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei: In <b>what</b> manner does <b>this differ from</b> an animal <b>offering,</b> where if one slaughtered it with the intent to sacrifice the portions consumed on the altar the next day, it is <i>piggul</i>? Rabbi Yosei <b>said to</b> the Rabbis: There is a difference, <b>as</b> in <b>the</b> case of an animal <b>offering, its blood, and its flesh, and its portions</b> consumed on the altar are all <b>one</b> entity. Consequently, intent with regard to any one of them renders the entire offering <i>piggul</i>. <b>But</b> the <b>frankincense is not</b> part <b>of the meal offering.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara questions the terminology of the mishna: <b>Why do I</b> need the <i>tanna</i> <b>to teach</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei concedes in this</b> instance? Let the <i>tanna</i> simply state: If one removes the handful from a meal offering with the intent to partake of its remainder or to burn the handful on the next day, Rabbi Yosei says that the offering is <i>piggul</i> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> for partaking of the remainder.
The Gemara responds: It was necessary for the <i>tanna</i> to teach that Rabbi Yosei concedes, <b>because he wants to teach the latter clause</b> of the mishna, that if his intent was <b>to burn its frankincense the next day, Rabbi Yosei says</b> that the meal offering is <b>unfit, but</b> partaking of it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: The reason the <i>tanna</i> links the two cases of the mishna is <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the reason that Rabbi Yosei</b> does not render the meal offering <i>piggul</i> is <b>because he holds</b> that one <b>cannot render</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i> with</b> intent that concerns only <b>half of</b> its <b>permitting factors. And</b> consequently, since the burning of the handful and the frankincense render the remainder of a meal offering permitted for consumption, then <b>even</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, where one intends to burn the handful the next day, Rabbi Yosei should hold that the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>, as the intent does not refer to the frankincense as well.

Daf 13b

Therefore, the <i>tanna</i> <b>teaches us that in this</b> case Rabbi Yosei <b>concedes</b> that if the handful is removed with the intent to burn only the handful on the next day, the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i>. Accordingly, Rabbi Yosei holds that one renders an offering <i>piggul</i> with intent that concerns only half of its permitting factors, and the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i> in the case of the latter clause for a different reason, as the Gemara will discuss later.
§ The mishna teaches that if one removed the handful from a meal offering with the intent <b>to burn its frankincense</b> on <b>the next day, Rabbi Yosei says</b> that the meal offering is <b>unfit but</b> partaking of it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> Concerning this, <b>Reish Lakish says: Rabbi Yosei would say,</b> i.e., this is Rabbi Yosei’s reasoning: <b>A permitting factor does not render</b> another <b>permitting factor <i>piggul</i>.</b> In other words, if, while performing the rites of a permitting factor, one had intent to perform the rites of a different permitting factor outside its designated time, the offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i> on account of this intent.
Reish Lakish adds: <b>And you</b> would <b>say the same with regard to</b> the <b>two bowls of frankincense of the shewbread, that a permitting factor does not render</b> another <b>permitting factor <i>piggul</i>,</b> and therefore if the priest burned one of the bowls with the intent to burn the other bowl the next day, the shewbread is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the purpose of the apparently superfluous statement: <b>And you</b> would <b>say the same</b> with regard to the two bowls of frankincense? Is there reason to assume that Rabbi Yosei would hold that the shewbread is rendered <i>piggul</i> in such a case? The Gemara responds that it is necessary, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>the reason that Rabbi Yosei</b> holds that there is no <i>piggul</i> <b>in</b> the case of the <b>frankincense</b> is <b>because it is not</b> of the same <b>type as a meal offering. But with regard to</b> the <b>two bowls of frankincense, which are of the same type as each other,</b> one might <b>say</b> that <b>they do render one another <i>piggul</i>.</b> Therefore, Reish Lakish <b>teaches us</b> that in both instances one permitting factor does not render another permitting factor <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And can you say</b> that <b>the reason</b> for the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei in</b> the case of the <b>frankincense</b> in the mishna <b>is not due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> the frankincense <b>is not</b> of the same <b>type as a meal offering? But isn’t it taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna that the Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei: In <b>what</b> manner does the frankincense <b>differ from</b> an animal <b>offering,</b> where if one slaughtered it with the intent to sacrifice the portions consumed on the altar the next day it is <i>piggul</i>; and Rabbi Yosei <b>said to</b> the Rabbis: There is a difference, as in <b>the</b> case of an animal <b>offering, its blood, and its flesh, and its portions</b> consumed on the altar are all <b>one</b> entity, <b>but</b> the <b>frankincense is not</b> part <b>of the meal offering?</b> The mishna indicates that according to Rabbi Yosei the reason the meal offering is not <i>piggul</i> is because the frankincense is not of the same type as the meal offering.
The Gemara explains: <b>What</b> does Rabbi Yosei mean when he says that the frankincense <b>is not</b> part <b>of the meal offering?</b> He means that <b>it is not</b> part <b>of</b> the <b>preclusion</b> of the <b>meal offering.</b> The Gemara elaborates: This means <b>that</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>not</b> that <b>just as</b> the <b>handful precludes</b> the <b>remainder,</b> i.e., <b>that as long as</b> the <b>handful is not burned</b> the <b>remainder may not be consumed, so too</b> the handful <b>precludes the frankincense</b> from being burned upon the altar. <b>Rather, if</b> the priest <b>wants, he burns this first, and if he wants, he burns that first,</b> i.e., he may burn the frankincense before or after the burning of the handful. Accordingly, the frankincense is an independent permitting factor. For this reason, intent with regard to the frankincense that occurred during the removal of the handful does not render a meal offering <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis,</b> who say that the meal offering is rendered <i>piggul</i> in such a case, what is their opinion? The Gemara responds: They hold that <b>when we say</b> that <b>a permitting factor does not render</b> another <b>permitting factor <i>piggul</i>,</b> this is <b>with regard to</b> the case taught in a mishna (16a) concerning one who <b>slaughtered one of the lambs</b> whose sacrifice permits the consumption of the two loaves meal offering brought on <i>Shavuot</i>, with the intent <b>to partake of the other</b> lamb <b>the next day.</b> The Gemara elaborates: <b>When you said</b> in the mishna that <b>both</b> permitting factors <b>are fit, this statement</b> applies only <b>where they were not fixed in one vessel. But</b> in a situation <b>where they were fixed in one vessel,</b> as is the case with regard to the handful and the frankincense, they are <b>considered like one</b> unit, and therefore they render one another <i>piggul</i>.
§ With regard to the frankincense, <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> The <b>collection</b> of the <b>frankincense</b> from a meal offering, when performed <b>by a non-priest,</b> is <b>not valid</b> and disqualifies the meal offering. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason? Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> It is <b>because</b> the rite of <b>conveying has touched it,</b> i.e., the collection of the frankincense is considered part of the rite of the conveying of the frankincense to the altar for the purpose of burning. Even if the non-priest simply collected the frankincense and thereafter transferred it to a priest, Rabbi Yannai <b>holds</b> that <b>conveying</b> even <b>without</b> moving one’s <b>leg is called conveying, and</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the performance of the rite of <b>conveying by a non-priest</b> is <b>not valid.</b>
<b>Rav Mari said: We learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna on 12a, which discusses those sacrificial rites of a meal offering during which improper intent renders an offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>as well.</b> The mishna teaches: <b>This is the principle:</b> In the case of <b>anyone who removes the handful, or places</b> the handful <b>in the vessel,</b> or <b>who conveys</b> the vessel with the handful to the altar, or <b>who burns</b> the handful on the altar, with the intent to partake of an item whose typical manner is such that one partakes of it, or to burn an item whose typical manner is such that one burns it on the altar, outside its designated area, the meal offering is unfit but there is no liability for <i>karet</i>. If his intent was to perform any of these actions beyond their designated time, the offering is <i>piggul</i> and one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> on account of it, provided that the permitting factor, i.e., the handful, was sacrificed in accordance with its mitzva.
Rav Mari analyzes the first part of this mishna: <b>Granted,</b> the <b>removal of the handful</b> from a meal offering <b>is</b> the same as, i.e., equivalent to, the <b>slaughter</b> of animal offerings. The <b>conveying</b> of the handful to the altar in order to burn it <b>is also</b> the same as the <b>conveying</b> of the blood of a slaughtered offering to the altar in order to sprinkle it. Similarly, the <b>burning</b> of the handful and frankincense of a meal offering <b>is</b> comparable to the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood of a slaughtered offering upon the altar. <b>But</b> as for <b>placing</b> the handful <b>in the</b> service <b>vessel, what</b> rite <b>is he performing</b> that is comparable to a rite of slaughtered offerings?
<b>If we say</b> that the meal offering is <i>piggul</i> <b>because</b> the placing of the handful into a vessel <b>is comparable to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood of a slaughtered offering into a service vessel, one can ask: <b>Are</b> these rites in fact <b>comparable? There,</b> in the case of animal offerings, the blood enters the vessel <b>by itself,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> the priest <b>takes</b> the handful from the meal offering <b>and casts</b> it into the vessel.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be <b>due to</b> the following reason: <b>Since it is not possible</b> to sacrifice the handful <b>without</b> first <b>performing</b> the act of placing it in a vessel, the placement of the handful in a vessel <b>is</b> considered <b>a significant rite,</b> and <b>perforce</b> this factor causes it to be <b>considered like</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood. <b>Here too,</b> with regard to the collection of the frankincense, <b>since it is not possible</b> to sacrifice the frankincense <b>without</b> first <b>performing</b> the act of collecting it from the vessel, the collection of the frankincense <b>is a significant rite</b> that <b>perforce</b> causes it to be <b>considered like</b> the rite of <b>conveying.</b>
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>No,</b> this is not the reason, and one cannot prove from the mishna that the collection of the frankincense from a meal offering performed by a non-priest is not valid. <b>Actually,</b> the reason why intent during the placement of the handful renders the offering <i>piggul</i> is in fact <b>because it is comparable to</b> the <b>collection</b> of the blood of a slaughtered offering. <b>And as for</b> the <b>difficulty you</b> raised, that <b>there</b> the blood enters the vessel <b>by itself,</b> whereas <b>here he takes</b> the handful from the meal offering <b>and casts</b> it into the vessel, this is not a true difficulty.
The Gemara explains: <b>Now</b> consider, <b>both of them,</b> i.e., the collection of the blood and the placing of the handful, involve the <b>sanctity of a vessel,</b> in which a service vessel sanctifies a permitting factor to the altar, either the handful or the blood. <b>What</b> difference is it <b>to me</b> if the permitting factor enters the vessel <b>by itself or</b> whether one <b>takes</b> the item <b>and casts</b> it into the vessel?
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one slaughtered</b> the <b>two lambs</b> that accompany the two meal offering loaves sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i> with the intent <b>to partake of one of the</b> two <b>loaves the next day,</b> or if <b>one burned</b> the <b>two bowls</b> of frankincense accompanying the shewbread with the intent <b>to partake of one of the arrangements</b> of the shewbread <b>the next day, Rabbi Yosei says: That loaf and that arrangement of which he intended</b> to partake the next day are <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> their consumption, <b>and the second</b> loaf and arrangement are <b>unfit, but there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> their consumption. <b>And the Rabbis say: This</b> loaf and arrangement <b>and that</b> loaf and arrangement are both <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> their consumption.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Huna says: Rabbi Yosei would say,</b> in accordance with his opinion that intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to one loaf or one arrangement does not render the second loaf or arrangement <i>piggul</i>, that if one <b>had intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to the right thigh,</b> i.e., he slaughtered an offering with the intent to partake of the right thigh the next day, then <b>the left thigh has not become <i>piggul</i></b> and one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for its consumption. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument, and if you wish, cite a verse.</b>
Rav Huna elaborates: <b>If you wish, propose a logical argument:</b> Disqualifying <b>intent is no stronger than an incident of ritual impurity,</b> and <b>if one limb</b> of an offering <b>became impure, did the entire</b> offering then <b>become impure?</b> Accordingly, one limb can be rendered <i>piggul</i> without the other. <b>And if you wish, cite a verse</b> that addresses <i>piggul</i>: <b>“And the soul that eats of it shall bear his iniquity”</b> (Leviticus 7:18). The verse indicates that one who eats specifically <b>“of it,”</b> i.e., from one part, shall bear his iniquity, <b>and not</b> one who eats <b>from the other</b> part of the offering.
<b>Rav Naḥman raised an objection to</b> Rav <b>Huna</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>And the Rabbis say</b> that <b>there is never</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> for partaking of the two loaves <b>unless one has intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to an olive-bulk of both of them,</b> i.e., one’s intent renders both loaves <i>piggul</i> only if he slaughters the lambs with the intent to consume an amount equal to an olive-bulk from both loaves combined outside their proper time. One can infer from this that if he had intent <b>with regard to both of them, yes,</b> both loaves are <i>piggul</i>. But if his intent was <b>with regard to</b> only <b>one of them, no,</b> the other loaf is not <i>piggul</i>.
Rav Naḥman continues: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> of the mishna, then <b>even</b> if his intent was <b>with regard to</b> only <b>one of them,</b> both loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i>. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei.</b> Now, <b>granted, if you say</b> that according to Rabbi Yosei the left and right thighs of an offering are considered <b>one body,</b> and consequently <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to one thigh renders the other thigh <i>piggul</i> as well, then <b>due to that</b> reason it is understandable that if the <i>piggul</i> intent was for an amount equal to one total olive-bulk from both of the loaves, then the intent with regard to each loaf is <b>combined</b> with the other.

Daf 14a

<b>But if you say</b> that Rabbi Yosei holds that the right and left thighs of an offering <b>are</b> considered <b>two</b> distinct <b>bodies,</b> and therefore <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to one does not render the other <i>piggul</i>, then in the case of the two loaves, <b>would</b> the intentions concerning both loaves <b>combine</b> to render them both <i>piggul</i>?
Rav Huna responds: One cannot infer anything from this <i>baraita</i> with regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei, as in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> one of <b>the lambs</b> brought as peace offerings on <i>Shavuot</i> with the intent <b>to consume half an olive-bulk from this loaf</b>  the next day, <b>and similarly,</b> he slaughtered <b>the other</b> lamb with the intent <b>to consume half an olive-bulk from that</b> second <b>loaf</b> the next day, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say that this</b> offering is <b>valid,</b> as his intentions do not combine.
Rav Huna continues: It may be inferred that <b>the reason</b> why the priest’s intentions do not combine is <b>that</b> his intent was <b>said</b> with regard to <b>a half</b> and <b>a half,</b> i.e., he slaughtered each lamb with the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from one loaf the next day. <b>But</b> if he <b>said</b> during the slaughter of each of the lambs that he is slaughtering it with the intent to consume <b>an olive-bulk from both of them,</b> then the halves <b>combine</b> to render the offering <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who says that the two loaves are <i>piggul</i> only if he has intent with regard to an amount equal to an olive-bulk from both of them combined, <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion is his statement? <b>If</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis</b> of the mishna, who hold that <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to one loaf renders both loaves <i>piggul</i>, then <b>even</b> if his intent was <b>with regard to</b> only <b>one of them,</b> both loaves should be <i>piggul</i>. And <b>if</b> it is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yosei,</b> who holds that <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to one loaf does not render the second loaf <i>piggul</i>, then <b>our difficulty returns to its place:</b> If Rabbi Yosei holds that the right and left thighs are considered two distinct bodies, how can intentions with regard to two halves of an olive-bulk combine to render both loaves <i>piggul</i>?
The Gemara responds: <b>Actually,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis. And do not say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> states: It is not <i>piggul</i> <b>unless one has</b> the <b>intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to both of them [<i>bishteihen</i>],</b> in the feminine form, whereby the <i>baraita</i> would be referring to the loaves. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> states: <b>With regard to both of them [<i>bishneihen</i>],</b> in the masculine form, i.e., unless he slaughters both lambs with <i>piggul</i> intent, <b>and</b> in such a case, <b>even</b> if his intent was with regard to only <b>one of the</b> loaves, the offering is <i>piggul</i>.
The Gemara adds: <b>And</b> this <i>baraita</i> serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir, who says</b> in the mishna on 16a: <b>One renders</b> an offering <b><i>piggul</i></b> by means of intent during the sacrifice <b>of half a permitting factor,</b> e.g., if one slaughtered one of the lambs with the intent to consume the two loaves the next day, the loaves are <i>piggul</i>. This <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us that</b> this is <b>not</b> the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> then <b>what</b> is the meaning of the emphasis in the <i>baraita</i>: There is <b>never</b> liability? <b>Granted,</b> this phrase is understandable <b>if you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means that the loaves are not <i>piggul</i> unless he has intent <b>with regard to both of the</b> loaves <b>and both of the</b> lambs, i.e., they are <i>piggul</i> only if he slaughters both lambs with the intention to partake of both loaves the next day. In that case the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei, and it comes to exclude</b> the statements <b>of</b> both <b>Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis,</b> and <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>states:</b> There is <b>never</b> liability, to emphasize that Rabbi Yosei disagrees with both of these opinions.
<b>But if you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis and</b> that it serves <b>to exclude</b> only the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir,</b> for <b>what</b> reason does the <i>baraita</i> stress: There is <b>never</b> liability? The <i>tanna</i> would not use such a word to exclude merely one opinion. Rather, it must be that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yosei. If so, then the difficulty raised against Rav Huna, who says that <i>piggul</i> intent concerning the right thigh does not render the left one <i>piggul</i>, remains unresolved.
<b>And furthermore, didn’t Rav Ashi say: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a refutation of the opinion of Rav Huna from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says in the name of Rabbi Yosei</b> that if, while performing the sacrificial rites for the bulls or goats which are burned as an offering, the priest had an intention that can <b>render</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> with regard to a matter that is performed outside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., in the Temple courtyard, <b>he has rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> If his intention was <b>with regard to a matter that is performed inside</b> the Sanctuary or the Holy of Holies, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> elaborates: <b>How so?</b> If <b>he was standing outside</b> when slaughtering the animal <b>and said: I hereby slaughter</b> the animal <b>with the intention of sprinkling its blood tomorrow</b> inside the Sanctuary, <b>he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>.</b> The reason is <b>that</b> when one has <b>an intention outside with regard to a matter that is performed inside,</b> he has not rendered the offering <i>piggul</i>. Likewise, if he <b>was standing inside</b> when sprinkling, <b>and said: I hereby sprinkle</b> the blood of the sin offering <b>in order to burn</b> its <b>sacrificial portions</b> on the external altar <b>tomorrow and to pour out</b> its <b>remainder</b> on the base of the altar <b>tomorrow, he has not rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> he had <b>an intention inside with regard to a matter that is performed outside.</b>
<b>But</b> if <b>he was standing outside and said: I hereby slaughter</b> the animal <b>with the intention to pour out</b> the <b>remainder</b> of its blood <b>tomorrow, or to burn</b> its <b>sacrificial portions tomorrow, he has rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> he had <b>an intention outside with regard to a matter that is performed outside.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the case where one slaughtered the offering with the intent <b>to pour the remaining</b> blood the next day, <b>what could be rendered <i>piggul</i>? If we say</b> the <b>blood could be rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> one can ask: <b>Does blood become <i>piggul</i>? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 42b): <b>These are</b> the <b>items for which one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>: The handful; the frankincense; the incense; the meal offering of priests; the meal offering</b> accompanying the <b>libations</b> brought with an animal offering; <b>the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest; and the blood?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> means that it is the <b>meat</b> of the offering that <b>could be rendered <i>piggul</i>. Now</b> consider: <b>And if there,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>where he did not have intent with regard to the meat itself,</b> as his intention was not to partake of the meat the next day but to pour the remaining blood the next day, and yet <b>Rabbi Yosei said</b> that the meat <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i>;</b> then <b>here, where he has intent</b> to partake of the right thigh the next day, which is part <b>of the offering itself,</b> is it <b>not all the more so that</b> if <b>he had intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to the right thigh, he has rendered the left thigh <i>piggul</i></b> as well?
<b>And furthermore, doesn’t Ravina say: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a refutation of the statement of Rav Huna from the mishna (13a): In the case of <b>one who removes a handful from the meal offering</b> with the intent <b>to partake of its remainder or to burn its handful</b> on <b>the next day, Rabbi Yosei concedes in this</b> instance <b>that he has rendered</b> the offering <b><i>piggul</i> and he is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of <b>it.</b>
Ravina continues: When one removes the handful with the intent <b>to burn its handful, what could be rendered <i>piggul</i>? If we say</b> that <b>the handful could be rendered <i>piggul</i>, does the handful become <i>piggul</i>? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 42b): <b>These are</b> the <b>items for which one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>: The handful, etc. Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <b>remainder could be rendered <i>piggul</i>. Now</b> consider: <b>And if there,</b> in the mishna, <b>where he did not have intent with regard to</b> the <b>remainder itself,</b> i.e., to partake of the remainder the next day,

Daf 14b

and yet Rabbi Yosei said that the remainder <b>is rendered <i>piggul</i>;</b> then <b>here, where he has intent</b> to partake of the right thigh the next day, which is part <b>of</b> the <b>offering itself,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> that both thighs should become <i>piggul</i>?
<b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> Rabbi Yosei holds that intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to one thigh renders the other thigh <i>piggul</i> as well, as they are of one body. Similarly, with regard to two loaves, Rabbi Yosei is of the opinion that if one intends to consume an amount equal to an olive-bulk from both loaves, both loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i>. And as for his statement that intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to one loaf does not render the other loaf <i>piggul</i>, <b>this is the reasoning of Rabbi Yosei: The verse renders</b> the two loaves <b>one body, and the verse</b> also <b>renders them two bodies.</b> The verse renders them <b>one body</b> in the sense <b>that they preclude one another,</b> i.e., neither loaf is valid without the other. The verse also renders them <b>two bodies, as the Merciful One states: This</b> loaf <b>is prepared alone and that is prepared alone,</b> i.e., the kneading and arrangement of each loaf must be performed separately.
Therefore, if the priest <b>mixed them</b> together by intending to consume an olive-bulk from both of them, then <b>they are mixed</b> and they are both <i>piggul</i>, <b>as the verse renders them one body.</b> But if <b>he separated them</b> by having intent with regard to only one loaf, in that case <b>they are separated</b> and only that loaf is <i>piggul</i>, <b>as the verse renders them two bodies.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>had intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to</b> one type of loaf from the <b>loaves of a thanks offering, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the remaining types of loaves, i.e., are they rendered <i>piggul</i> as well? Similarly, if one had intent of <i>piggul</i> <b>with regard to</b> either the loaves or the wafers of <b>baked meal offerings, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the remaining type? <b>Rav Taḥlifa from the West,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael, <b>taught him</b> a <i>baraita</i> that states: <b>And likewise you say with regard to the bread of a thanks offering, and likewise you say with regard to a baked meal offering,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is a matter of dispute between Rabbi Yosei and the Rabbis.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>at the time of</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of an offering one <b>had intent to consume half an olive-bulk</b> of its meat the next day, <b>and at the time of</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>he had intent to consume half</b> of another <b>olive-bulk</b> of meat the next day, the offering is <b><i>piggul</i>, as</b> intentions that occur during the <b>slaughter and sprinkling combine</b> to render an offering <i>piggul</i>.
There is a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to the <i>halakha</i> of this <i>baraita</i>: <b>Some say</b> that in the case of intentions that occur specifically during the <b>slaughter and sprinkling, as both of them are permitting factors</b> of the offering, <b>yes,</b> the intentions combine. But intentions that occur during the <b>collection</b> of the blood in a service vessel <b>and</b> the <b>conveying</b> of the blood to the altar do <b>not</b> combine, as neither rite is a permitting factor. <b>And some say</b> that if intentions during <b>those</b> rites <b>that are distant</b> from one another, i.e., the slaughter and sprinkling, combine, <b>all the more so</b> intentions during <b>these</b> rites <b>that are close</b> to one another, i.e., collection and conveying, certainly combine.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so,</b> i.e., that intentions during the slaughter and sprinkling combine? <b>But Levi teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Intentions that occur during the <b>four</b> sacrificial <b>rites do not combine to</b> render an offering <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> and those rites are: <b>Slaughter and sprinkling, collection and conveying. Rava said:</b> It is <b>not difficult; this</b> statement of Levi is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the two loaves and two lambs sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i>: With regard to <b>one who slaughters</b> one of <b>the lambs</b> brought as peace offerings on <i>Shavuot</i> with the intent <b>to consume half an olive-bulk from this loaf</b> the next day, <b>and similarly,</b> he slaughtered <b>the other</b> lamb with the intent <b>to consume half an olive-bulk from that</b> second <b>loaf</b> the next day, <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: I say that this</b> offering is <b>valid.</b> Clearly, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that intentions that occur during the performance of two permitting factors do not combine to render an offering <i>piggul</i>.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: You can <b>say that you have heard that Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi holds that intentions do not combine to render an offering <i>piggul</i> when each intention is concerning <b>half a permitting factor and half</b> a measure of <b>consumption,</b> i.e., one lamb and half an olive-bulk. But in a case where one had intentions during the performance of <b>an entire permitting factor,</b> i.e., during the slaughter and sprinkling, <b>and</b> concerning <b>half</b> a measure of <b>consumption, did you hear him</b> say that such intentions do not combine?
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥanan said to Abaye: But if Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>is of</b> the opinion that intentions during the performance of <b>an entire permitting factor and</b> concerning <b>half</b> a measure of <b>consumption</b> combine to render an offering <i>piggul</i>, why does he rule that when one slaughters each lamb with the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from one loaf the next day the offering is entirely valid? <b>Let him decree</b> that intentions during <b>half a permitting factor and</b> concerning <b>half</b> a measure of <b>consumption</b> disqualify an offering, <b>due to</b> the fact that intentions during <b>an entire permitting factor and</b> concerning <b>half</b> a measure of <b>consumption</b> render the offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>as</b> one finds in similar instances that <b>Rabbi Yosei decreed and the Rabbis decreed</b> in this manner.
Rava bar Rav Ḥanan elaborates: <b>Rabbi Yosei decreed</b> in such a case, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (13a): With regard to one who removes a handful from the meal offering with the intent to burn its handful on the next day, everyone agrees that the meal offering is <i>piggul</i>. But if his intent was <b>to burn its frankincense</b> on <b>the next day, Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The meal offering is <b>unfit, but</b> partaking of it <b>does not include</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i>. And the Rabbis say:</b> It is a case of <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> partaking of the meal offering. Since one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i>, Rabbi Yosei evidently disqualifies the meal offering as a rabbinic decree due to concern over a case where his intention was to burn the handful the next day.
<b>And the Rabbis decreed as well, as we learned</b> in a mishna (16a): If one had <b>intent of <i>piggul</i> during</b> the burning of <b>the handful but not during</b> the burning of <b>the frankincense,</b> or if he had such intent <b>during</b> the burning of <b>the frankincense but not during</b> the burning of <b>the handful, Rabbi Meir says:</b> The meal offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> its consumption, <b>and the Rabbis say: There is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> its consumption <b>unless he has intent of <i>piggul</i> during</b> the burning of <b>the entire permitting factor,</b> i.e., both the handful and the frankincense. Since the Rabbis state that there is no liability to receive <i>karet</i>, but they do not rule that the offering is valid, evidently they maintain that the offering is disqualified by rabbinic law, due to concern over a case of <i>piggul</i> intent during the burning of the entire permitting factor.
Abaye <b>said to</b> Rava bar Rav Ḥanan: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? Granted there, Rabbi Yosei decreed</b> that the offering is disqualified in a case of intent involving <b>the handful of frankincense due to</b> the concern of intent involving <b>the handful of the meal offering,</b> as the two cases are similar.
Similarly, <b>the Rabbis decreed</b> that the offering is disqualified in a case of intent involving the <b>handful due to</b> a similar case of intent concerning <b>the handful of the meal offering of a sinner.</b> There is no frankincense in the case of a meal offering of a sinner, and consequently the priest’s intent with regard to the handful alone renders the offering <i>piggul</i>, as it is the sole permitting factor. <b>And</b> the Rabbis also decreed in a case of intent with regard to the <b>frankincense due to</b> a similar case of intent concerning the <b>frankincense that comes in</b> the <b>bowls</b> that accompany the shewbread. Here there is no handful, and consequently intent with regard to the frankincense alone renders the shewbread <i>piggul</i>.
In the case of the two <b>lambs</b> that accompany the two loaves brought on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>as well</b> (16a), the Rabbis rule that if one slaughters one of the lambs with the intent to consume both loaves the next day the offering is disqualified, but one is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for partaking of it. This is a rabbinic decree in a case of intent during the slaughter of one <b>lamb due to the other lamb,</b> as were one to slaughter both lambs with intent of <i>piggul</i>, the loaves would be rendered <i>piggul</i>, since his intent occurred during the slaughter of the entire permitting factor.
Similarly, when one burns a single <b>bowl</b> of frankincense from those that accompany the shewbread with the intent to consume both arrangements of shewbread the next day, the Rabbis disqualify the shewbread by rabbinic decree <b>due to the other bowl,</b> i.e., due to the concern over <i>piggul</i> intent during the burning of both bowls, as this intent involves the burning of the entire permitting factor.
Abaye concludes: <b>But here,</b> in the case of the <i>baraita</i> where one slaughtered each of the two lambs with the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from a different loaf, <b>is there</b> another instance <b>in general</b> where intent during the performance of a rite concerning <b>half a permitting factor and</b> with regard to <b>half</b> a measure <b>of consumption</b> renders an offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>that</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>will arise and decree</b> that the lambs in this instance are disqualified?
The Gemara notes: <b>So too, it is reasonable that the reasoning of the Rabbis is due to that</b> explanation, i.e., they disqualified the offerings in the aforementioned cases due to the fact that in similar instances the offering is <i>piggul</i>. This is evident from the fact <b>that</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna (16a): <b>The Rabbis concede to Rabbi Meir in</b> the case of <b>the meal offering of a sinner and the meal offering of jealousy that if one had intent of <i>piggul</i> during</b> the burning of <b>the handful,</b> the meal offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and one is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i> for</b> its consumption, <b>as the handful is the</b> sole <b>permitting factor.</b>
The Gemara explains this proof: <b>Why do I</b> need the mishna <b>to teach</b> this last statement <b>at all?</b> Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that these meal offerings are <i>piggul</i>, as <b>is there another permitting factor</b> aside from the handful? <b>Rather, is it not</b> correct to say that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>teaches us, that the reason that</b> the Rabbis disqualified a standard meal offering when only the <b>handful</b> was removed with the intent of <i>piggul</i> is <b>because there is</b> the case of <b>the handful of the meal offering of a sinner, which is similar to it</b> and is rendered <i>piggul</i> due to intent involving the handful alone?
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>one of the</b> two <b>loaves</b> of <i>Shavuot</i> <b>or one of the</b> two <b>arrangements</b> of the shewbread <b>became ritually impure, Rabbi Yehuda says: Both must be taken to the place of burning</b> like any other disqualified offering, <b>as no communal offering is divided.</b> That is, it is either fit in its entirety or unfit in its entirety. <b>And the Rabbis say: The impure one</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>impurity and the pure one shall be eaten.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The <b>dispute</b> between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis applies only to a case where one loaf became ritually impure <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood of the lambs, as this is the act that renders the loaves permitted for consumption. Accordingly, they disagree whether the sprinkling is effective in permitting the remaining pure loaf for consumption. <b>But</b> in a case where one loaf was rendered impure <b>after the sprinkling,</b> meaning that both loaves were initially permitted for consumption, <b>everyone agrees</b> that <b>the impure one</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>impurity and the pure one shall be eaten.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> in the case where the loaves become impure <b>before</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>with regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree? Rav Pappa said: They disagree with regard to</b> the <b>frontplate</b> of the High Priest, i.e., whether it <b>effects acceptance</b> only for the impurity of items sacrificed on the altar, or even <b>for</b> the impurity of items that would normally be <b>consumed</b> by the priests.

Daf 15a

<b>The Rabbis hold</b> that <b>the frontplate effects acceptance for</b> items that are normally <b>consumed</b> by the priests but have become ritually impure. Consequently, the sprinkling of the blood in this case is an entirely valid act that is capable of rendering the remaining pure loaf permitted for consumption. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that <b>the frontplate does not effect acceptance for</b> items that are <b>consumed</b> by the priests and have become impure. Accordingly, the sprinkling of the blood is ineffective in rendering the remaining pure loaf permitted for consumption.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa:</b> Can this be the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis? <b>But</b> what about items that normally <b>ascend</b> upon the altar? Even Rabbi Yehuda concedes <b>that the frontplate effects acceptance for</b> impure items <b>that</b> normally <b>ascend</b> the altar, <b>and</b> Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis nevertheless <b>disagree</b> with regard to the remaining item in a case of this kind.
The Gemara provides the source for this claim. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If <b>one of the bowls</b> of frankincense accompanying the shewbread, which are meant to be burned upon the altar, <b>became impure, Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that the rites of <b>both of them may be performed in impurity,</b> i.e., the priest may even render the second bowl impure and burn both of them together, <b>as no communal offering is divided,</b> and the mitzva to sacrifice communal offerings overrides the prohibition against rendering them impure. <b>And the Rabbis say: The impure one</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>impurity and the pure one</b> remains <b>in its</b> state of <b>purity.</b> Evidently, their dispute does not depend on whether the frontplate effects acceptance.
<b>And furthermore, Rav Ashi said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an additional proof that the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis does not concern the frontplate, as we learn in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 80a) with regard to the consumption of the Paschal offering in a state of impurity, that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if <b>one tribe is ritually impure and all</b> the rest of <b>the tribes are pure,</b> all the tribes <b>may perform</b> the rite of the Paschal offering <b>in</b> a state of <b>impurity, as no communal offerings are divided.</b> Rav Ashi explains: <b>But here, what</b> relevance <b>is there</b> to the question of whether <b>the frontplate effects acceptance?</b> The frontplate effects acceptance for offerings that have become impure; but it does not render it permitted for one who is ritually impure to sacrifice an offering.
<b>And furthermore, doesn’t Ravina say: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof that the matter of the frontplate cannot be the subject of the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda and the Rabbis, as the mishna teaches: If <b>one of the</b> two <b>loaves</b> brought on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>or one of the</b> two <b>arrangements</b> of shewbread <b>became ritually impure, Rabbi Yehuda says: Both must be taken to the place of burning, as no communal offering is divided. And the Rabbis say: The impure one</b> remains <b>in its impurity and the pure one may be eaten.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>And if it is so,</b> i.e., that the dispute between them concerns the frontplate, then Rabbi Yehuda <b>should have</b> said: They are both burned, <b>because the frontplate does not effect acceptance for</b> impure items that are <b>consumed</b> by the priests. <b>Rather, Rabbi Yoḥanan says: It is a settled tradition in the mouth of Rabbi Yehuda that no communal offering is divided,</b> and if one part of an offering becomes impure, the entire offering is disqualified.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The thanks offering renders the</b> accompanying <b>loaves <i>piggul</i> but the loaves do not render the thanks offering <i>piggul</i>. How so?</b> If <b>one slaughtered the thanks offering,</b> which may be consumed only during the day it is slaughtered and the night thereafter, with the intent <b>to partake of it the next day,</b> the offering <b>and the</b> accompanying <b>loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> If he slaughtered it with the intent <b>to partake of the loaves the next day, the loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i> and the thanks offering is not <i>piggul</i>.</b>
Likewise, <b>the lambs</b> sacrificed with the two loaves meal offering on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>render the</b> accompanying <b>loaves <i>piggul</i>, but the loaves do not render the lambs <i>piggul</i>. How so?</b> If <b>one slaughtered the lambs,</b> which may be consumed only during the day they are slaughtered and the night thereafter, with the intent <b>to partake of them the next day,</b> the lambs <b>and the</b> accompanying <b>loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> If he did so with the intent <b>to partake of the loaves the next day, the loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i> and the lambs are not <i>piggul</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that a thanks offering renders its accompanying loaves <i>piggul</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is <b>due to that</b> which <b>Rav Kahana</b> says, this is problematic. <b>As Rav Kahana says: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the loaves of a thanks offering are</b> themselves <b>called a thanks offering?</b> It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“Then he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanks offering loaves”</b> (Leviticus 7:12). The juxtaposition of the words “thanks offering” and “loaves” indicates that the loaves are themselves called a thanks offering.
The Gemara explains why the <i>halakha</i> of the mishna cannot be derived from Rav Kahana’s exposition. <b>If so,</b> then <b>the opposite</b> should be the <i>halakha</i> <b>as well,</b> that intent of <i>piggul</i> with regard to the loaves should likewise render the thanks offering <i>piggul</i>. The Gemara rejects this suggestion: <b>This</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> as the <b>loaves are called a thanks offering,</b> but <b>a thanks offering is not called loaves.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to <b>that which</b> the mishna <b>teaches: The lambs</b> sacrificed with the two loaves meal offering on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>render the</b> accompanying <b>loaves <i>piggul</i> but the loaves do not render the lambs <i>piggul</i>, where do we find that</b> the two <b>loaves are called lambs? Rather, is it not</b> correct that <b>this is the reason</b> why the thanks offering renders the loaves <i>piggul</i> but not vice versa: The <b>bread</b> is brought <b>on account of [<i>gelal</i>]</b> the <b>thanks offering, but</b> the <b>thanks offering is not</b> brought <b>on account of</b> the <b>bread,</b> i.e., the thanks offering is the primary element of the sacrifice. Similarly, the two loaves of <b>bread are</b> brought <b>on account of</b> the <b>lambs, and</b> the <b>lambs are not</b> brought <b>on account of</b> the <b>bread.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> both of these <i>halakhot</i> <b>are necessary, as, had</b> the mishna <b>taught us</b> the <i>halakha</i> only in the case of <b>a thanks offering,</b> then one might say: <b>It is</b> only <b>there,</b> with regard to a thanks offering, <b>that when one renders the loaves <i>piggul</i> the thanks offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>, because they were not bound to one another by waving,</b> i.e., the mitzva of waving the thanks offering may be fulfilled without the bread. <b>But</b> with regard to the <b>lambs,</b> in <b>which</b> the two items <b>were bound to one another by waving,</b> as the two loaves are waved together with the lambs, one might <b>say</b> that <b>when he renders the bread <i>piggul</i>,</b> the <b>lambs should be rendered <i>piggul</i> as well.</b> Therefore, it was <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach this <i>halakha</i> also with regard to the case of the lambs.
§ <b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> If <b>one slaughters the thanks offering</b> with the intent <b>to consume an olive-bulk from it and from its loaves the next day, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Elazar elaborates: <b>I do not raise the dilemma with regard to rendering</b> the <b>thanks offering <i>piggul</i>,</b> for the following reason: <b>Now</b> that in a case where his intent was to consume <b>the entire</b> olive-bulk <b>from its loaves</b> alone, the thanks offering <b>is not rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> in accordance with the mishna’s ruling that <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to the loaves does not render the thanks offering <i>piggul</i>, then in a case where his intent is to consume half an olive-bulk <b>from</b> the thanks offering <b>and</b> half an olive-bulk <b>from its loaves,</b> in which case the offering is rendered <i>piggul</i> only if the two intentions of less than a full measure are combined, is it <b>necessary</b> to teach that the thanks offering is not <i>piggul</i>?
Rather, <b>when I raise the dilemma,</b> it is with regard <b>to rendering the loaves <i>piggul</i>,</b> which can be rendered <i>piggul</i> via intent concerning the loaves alone. In this case, <b>does</b> the intention of the priest with regard to the <b>thanks offering combine</b> with his intention concerning the loaves <b>to render the loaves <i>piggul</i>, or not?</b>
Rav <b>said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: <b>Even in this</b> case, <b>the loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i> and the thanks offering is not rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> should the loaves be rendered <i>piggul</i>? <b>Let us say</b> the following <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if</b> the <b>thanks offering, which</b> in this case serves to <b>render</b> the loaves <b><i>piggul</i>, is</b> itself <b>not rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> then the loaves, <b>which come to render</b> the thanks offering <b><i>piggul</i>, but do not render</b> it <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> as the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from the loaves does not combine with the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from the thanks offering to render the thanks offering <i>piggul</i>, <b>is it not logical that the</b> loaves themselves <b>should not be rendered <i>piggul</i>?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>in this way? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: There was <b>an incident involving one</b>

Daf 15b

<b>who planted</b> seeds in <b>the vineyard of an another</b> when the grapes on the vines were <b>budding, and</b> the <b>incident came before the Sages and they deemed the seeds prohibited</b> due to the prohibition against planting diverse kinds in a vineyard, <b>but they deemed the vines permitted.</b> The Gemara continues: <b>But why</b> did they deem the seeds prohibited? <b>Let</b> the Sages <b>say</b> through an analogous <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that the seeds should be permitted: <b>And if that which renders</b> an item <b>prohibited,</b> i.e., the vine, which causes the seeds to be prohibited, <b>is</b> itself <b>not prohibited,</b> then with regard to the seeds, <b>which come to render</b> the vines <b>prohibited but did not render</b> the vines <b>prohibited, is it not logical that they should not be rendered prohibited?</b>
The Gemara rejects the comparison: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, only <b>hemp and arum</b> are <b>prohibited</b> by <b>Torah</b> law to be sown in a vineyard, <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kilayim</i> 2:5): If <b>one’s field was sown</b> with <b>hemp and arum, he should not sow above them, as they produce</b> a yield only once every <b>three years. Other seeds are prohibited by rabbinic</b> law. Therefore, with regard to <b>this</b> person <b>who committed a transgression</b> by planting the seeds in the vineyard of another, <b>the Sages penalized him</b> and deemed his seeds prohibited, but as for <b>that</b> person <b>who did not commit a transgression,</b> i.e., the owner of the vineyard, <b>the Sages did not penalize him. But here,</b> in the case of <i>piggul</i>, which is a biblical prohibition, <b>let us say</b> such <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
<b>And there are those who teach</b> the dilemma of Rabbi Elazar <b>with regard to the lambs</b> brought with the two loaves, and not with regard to a thanks offering. <b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> In a case where <b>one slaughters the lambs</b> with the intent <b>to consume an olive-bulk from them and from their loaves</b> the next day, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
Rabbi Elazar elaborated: <b>I do not raise the dilemma with regard to rendering</b> the <b>lambs <i>piggul</i></b> for the following reason: <b>Now</b> that in a case where his intent was to consume <b>an entire</b> olive-bulk <b>from the loaves</b> alone, the lambs <b>are not rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> as the mishna teaches that <i>piggul</i> intent with regard to the loaves does not render the lambs <i>piggul</i>, then in a case where his intent is to consume half an olive-bulk <b>from them and</b> half an olive-bulk <b>from their loaves, is</b> it <b>necessary</b> to teach that the lambs are not <i>piggul</i>? Rather, <b>when I raised the dilemma,</b> it was <b>with regard to rendering the loaves <i>piggul</i>. Does</b> his intention with regard to the <b>lambs combine</b> with his intention with regard to the loaves <b>to render the loaves <i>piggul</i> or not?</b>
Rav <b>said to</b> Rabbi Elazar: <b>Even in this</b> case, <b>the loaves are rendered <i>piggul</i> and the lambs are not rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But why</b> should the loaves be rendered <i>piggul</i>? <b>Let us say</b> the following <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference: <b>And if that which renders</b> an item <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., the lambs, since it is maintained that intent to consume half an olive-bulk from the lambs assists to render the loaves <i>piggul</i>, <b>is</b> itself <b>not rendered <i>piggul</i>,</b> then with regard to the loaves, <b>which come to render</b> the lambs <b><i>piggul</i>, but do not render</b> them <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> as the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from the loaves does not combine with the intent to consume half an olive-bulk from the lambs to render them <i>piggul</i>, <b>is it not logical that</b> the loaves themselves <b>should not be rendered <i>piggul</i>?</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we say an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>of this kind? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that there was <b>an incident involving one who planted</b> seeds in <b>the vineyard of his friend</b> when the grapes on the vines were <b>budding,</b> and the incident came before the Sages and they deemed the seeds prohibited due to the prohibition against planting diverse kinds in a vineyard, but they deemed the vines permitted. The Gemara continues: <b>But why</b> did they deem the seeds prohibited? <b>Let</b> the Sages <b>say</b> through an analogous <b><i>a fortiori</i></b> inference that the seeds should be permitted: <b>And</b> if <b>that which renders</b> an item <b>prohibited,</b> i.e., the vine, which causes the seeds to be prohibited, <b>is</b> itself <b>not prohibited,</b> then with regard to the seeds, <b>which come to render</b> the vines <b>prohibited but did not render</b> the vines <b>prohibited, is it not logical that</b> they <b>should not be rendered prohibited?</b>
The Gemara rejects the comparison: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, only <b>hemp and arum</b> are <b>prohibited</b> by <b>Torah</b> law to be sown in a vineyard. <b>Other seeds are prohibited by rabbinic</b> law. Therefore, with regard to <b>this</b> person <b>who committed a transgression</b> by planting the seeds in the vineyard of another, <b>the Sages penalized him</b> and deemed his seeds prohibited, but as for <b>this</b> person <b>who did not commit a transgression,</b> i.e., the owner of the vineyard, <b>the Sages did not penalize him. But here,</b> in the case of <i>piggul</i>, which is a biblical prohibition, <b>let us say</b> such <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference.
The Gemara notes: <b>The one who teaches</b> that the dilemma of Rabbi Elazar was raised <b>with regard to the thanks offering</b> and the accompanying loaves, <b>all the more so</b> will hold that the dilemma may be raised <b>with regard to</b> the case of <b>the lambs</b> brought with the two loaves on <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>But the one who teaches</b> that Rabbi Elazar’s dilemma was raised <b>with regard to the lambs</b> and the two loaves, it is possible that he holds that the dilemma <b>was</b> raised only with regard to the <b>lambs</b> and the two loaves, <b>as they were bound to one another by waving,</b> since the priest waves the lambs and loaves together (see Leviticus 23:20). <b>But</b> with regard to <b>a thanks offering</b> and its loaves, <b>as they were not bound to one another by waving,</b> the dilemma was <b>not</b> raised, since it is obvious in this case that his intentions do not combine.
<b>Rabbi Abba the small</b> taught that Rabbi Elazar <b>raises the dilemma</b> in <b>this</b> manner: <b>Rabbi Elazar raised a dilemma before Rav:</b> If <b>one slaughters</b> one of <b>the lambs</b> brought on <i>Shavuot</i> with the two loaves intending <b>to consume an olive-bulk from the other the next day, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
