Therefore, <b>just as the placing of the hands</b> on the offering is performed <b>by non-priests, so too,</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the offering is performed <b>by non-priests.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> there is a juxtaposition of the placing of the hands and the slaughter of the animals, why not also say that <b>just as the placing of the hands</b> on the offering is performed only <b>by the owner</b> of the animal, <b>so too,</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the offering may be performed only <b>by the owner</b> of the animal? The Gemara answers: <b>You cannot say that,</b> due to <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference from the <i>halakha</i> of the sprinkling of the blood: <b>And just as the sprinkling</b> of the blood, <b>which is the essential</b> rite that enables the one who brings the offering to achieve <b>atonement, does not require</b> the <b>owner</b> to perform it, as the priests perform this rite on his behalf, with regard to the <b>slaughter</b> of the offering, <b>which is not the essential</b> rite that enables the one who brings the offering to achieve <b>atonement,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> clear that it does not need to be performed by the owner?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>one cannot derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> and the owner may not sprinkle the blood as he is not a priest, but he may still be obligated to slaughter the animal, as this rite may be performed by a non-priest, <b>the Merciful One revealed</b> in the Torah <b>in</b> the context of the <b>Yom Kippur</b> service with regard to the High Priest: <b>“And he shall slaughter the bull of the sin offering which is for himself”</b> (Leviticus 16:11). <b>By inference,</b> from the fact that the verse specifies that here the High Priest, who is the owner of the offering, must perform the slaughter, it is clear <b>that usually</b> the <b>slaughter does not require</b> the participation of the <b>owner.</b>
§ Apropos the mishna’s list of rites that are not indispensable for the meal offering, the Gemara explains that <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>any</b> sacrificial rite <b>where</b> the term <b>law and statute are stated,</b> they are stated <b>only to</b> teach that the absence of the performance of that rite <b>invalidates</b> the offering. The Gemara comments: <b>It enters our mind</b> to say that the <b>two</b> terms are both <b>required</b> for this principle to be in effect, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to a red heifer: <b>“This is the statute of the law”</b> (Numbers 19:2).
Before continuing its discussion of this principle, the Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for the questions that follow: <b><i>Nun</i>, <i>tav</i>, <i>tzadi</i>; <i>yod</i>, <i>kuf</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>lamed</i>.</b> They represent: Nazirite; thanks offering [<i>toda</i>]; leper [<i>metzora</i>]; Yom Kippur; offerings [<i>korbanot</i>]; meal offering [<i>minḥa</i>]; shewbread [<i>leḥem hapanim</i>].
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of the offering of <b>a nazirite, about which it is written only “law,”</b> as the verse states: “This is the law of the nazirite who vows, and of his offering to the Lord for his naziriteship, beside that for which his means suffice; according to his vow which he vows, so he must do after the law of his naziriteship” (Numbers 6:21), <b>and</b> yet <b>Rav says</b> that the lack of <b>waving of</b> the offering by <b>a nazirite invalidates</b> the offering? The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, since it is written</b> in the continuation of the verse: <b>“So he must do,”</b> and therefore <b>it is considered as if</b> the term <b>statute were written with regard to it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of the <b>thanks offering, about which it is written only “law,”</b> as the verse states: “This is the law of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:11), <b>and we learn</b> in a mishna (27a) that with regard to the <b>four</b> types of loaves <b>that</b> accompany <b>the thanks offering,</b> failure to bring <b>each</b> of them <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the others?</b> The Gemara answers: The <b>thanks offering is different, since it is juxtaposed</b> in the Torah <b>to</b> the offering of <b>a nazirite; as it is written</b> in a verse describing the thanks offering: <b>“With the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving”</b> (Leviticus 7:13), instead of simply stating: The sacrifice of his thanks offering. <b>And the Master says:</b> The term <b>“his peace offerings”</b> serves <b>to include</b> the loaves of <b>the peace offering of</b> the <b>nazirite,</b> to teach that the same <i>halakhot</i> apply to both.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of the offering of <b>a leper, about which it is written only “law,”</b> as the verse states: “This shall be the law of the leper” (Leviticus 14:2), <b>and we learn</b> in a mishna (27a) that with regard to the <b>four species that</b> are used <b>in</b> the purification process of <b>the leper,</b> i.e., cedar, hyssop, scarlet wool, and birds, failure to bring <b>each</b> of them <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the others?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, since it is written: “This shall be the law of the leper.”</b> Due to the added emphasis of the term “shall be,” it is <b>considered as if</b> the term <b>statute were written with regard to it.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of <b>Yom Kippur, about which it is written only “statute,”</b> as the verse states: “And it shall be a statute for you forever” (Leviticus 16:29), <b>and we learn</b> in a mishna (27a) that with regard to <b>the two goats of Yom Kippur,</b> the absence of <b>each</b> goat <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the other? Rather,</b> it must be that Rav meant that wherever <b>either</b> the term <b>law or</b> the term <b>statute</b> is employed, this signifies that the rite is an indispensable requirement.
The Gemara questions this understanding of Rav’s statement: <b>But</b> what of <b>the rest of the offerings, as</b> the term <b>“law” is written with regard to them, and</b> yet failure to perform all of their different rites <b>does not invalidate</b> those offerings? The verse states: “This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the consecration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:37). The Gemara answers: When the term <b>law</b> appears, it is still <b>necessary</b> for the term <b>statute</b> to appear, in order to teach that failure to perform the rites invalidates the offering. <b>But</b> when the term <b>statute</b> appears, it is <b>not necessary</b> for the term <b>law</b> to appear as well. The term statute is sufficient.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>But doesn’t</b> Rav <b>say:</b> Wherever the terms <b>law and statute</b> appear? Apparently, both are necessary for his principle to apply. The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> is what Rav <b>is saying: Even</b> in a context <b>where</b> the term <b>law is written, if</b> the term <b>statute is written</b> as well, then <b>yes,</b> failure to perform the rites invalidates the offering; <b>but if</b> the term statute does <b>not</b> accompany the term law, then failure to perform the rites does <b>not</b> invalidate the offering.
The Gemara questions this explanation: <b>But</b> what of the <b>meal offering, as</b> the term <b>“statute” is written with regard to it,</b> as the verse states: “Every male among the children of Aaron may eat of it, as a statute forever” (Leviticus 6:11), <b>and</b> yet <b>Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>every</b> sacrificial rite of <b>the law of the meal offering that the verse repeats,</b> as the details of the meal offering are discussed in Leviticus, chapter 2, and again in Leviticus, chapter 6, it is repeated <b>only to</b> teach that the failure to perform that rite <b>invalidates</b> the offering? Doesn’t this demonstrate that where the verse <b>repeated</b> the command, then <b>yes,</b> failure to perform the rite invalidates the offering; but if the verse <b>did not repeat</b> it, then failure to perform the rite does <b>not</b> invalidate the offering, whether or not the term statute appears?
The Gemara answers: <b>There it is different, as when</b> the term <b>statute is written, it is written with regard to the eating</b> of the meal offering rather than with regard to the sacrificial rites.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> what of <b>the shewbread, where when</b> the term <b>statute is written, it is written with regard to the eating</b> of the shewbread, as the verse states: “And they shall eat it in a holy place, for it is most holy to him of the offerings of the Lord made by fire, a perpetual statute” (Leviticus 24:9), <b>and we learn</b> in the mishna (27a): With regard to <b>the two arrangements</b> of the shewbread, failure to place <b>each</b> of the arrangements <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the other.</b> With regard to the <b>two bowls</b> of frankincense that accompany the shewbread, failure to place <b>each</b> of the arrangements <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the other.</b> With regard to <b>the arrangements</b> of the shewbread <b>and the bowls</b> of frankincense, failure to bring <b>each</b> of them <b>prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the other.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> it must be that <b>anywhere that</b> the term statute <b>is written with regard to eating, it is written with regard to the entire matter,</b> i.e., all the <i>halakhot</i> of the offering, and teaches that failure to perform the rites invalidates the offering.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to the meal offering, it <b>is different,</b> and it is only the rites that are repeated that are indispensable, <b>as the verse states: “Of its groats, and of its oil”</b> (Leviticus 2:16), rather than simply: Of the groats and oil,

Daf 19b

teaching that the <b>groats and oil are indispensable, and nothing else is indispensable,</b> despite the fact that the term statute appears.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Rav says:</b> With regard to <b>every</b> sacrificial <b>rite of the meal offering that the verse in the Torah repeats,</b> it is repeated <b>only to</b> teach that the failure to perform that rite <b>invalidates</b> the offering. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> Only the <b>groats and oil are indispensable, and nothing else is indispensable.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And according to Shmuel,</b> is it true that <b>even though</b> a rite of the meal offering is <b>repeated</b> in another <b>verse he does not deem it indispensable?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Shmuel must agree that <b>wherever the verse repeats</b> a rite it is <b>certainly</b> understood to be <b>indispensable; and here,</b> Rav and Shmuel <b>disagree with regard to</b> the expressions <b>“his handful”</b> (Leviticus 2:2) and <b>“with his hand”</b> (Leviticus 6:8). <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And he shall remove <b>his handful,”</b> and elsewhere it states: “And he shall take up from it <b>with his hand.”</b> The change in terminology between the two verses teaches <b>that</b> the priest <b>should not</b> use a utensil to <b>measure an amount for the handful</b> of a meal offering, but should use his hand.
<b>Rav holds</b> that <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> of using one’s hand and not a utensil is <b>also repeated</b> in another <b>verse, as it is written</b> in the context of Aaron’s service on the eighth day of the consecration of the Tabernacle: <b>“And he presented the meal offering; and he filled his hand from it”</b> (Leviticus 9:17), demonstrating that the handful is removed by hand and not with a utensil. <b>And Shmuel</b> holds that <b>we do not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> for all <b>generations from a temporary</b> situation. Therefore, using one’s hand is not indispensable, as the general requirements of the rites of the meal offering cannot be derived from a verse referring to the meal offering that was sacrificed during the consecration of the Tabernacle.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Shmuel not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> for all <b>generations from a temporary</b> situation? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 88a): Service <b>vessels</b> used for <b>the liquids sanctify</b> only <b>the liquids</b> placed in them, <b>and</b> service vessels used to <b>measure dry</b> substances <b>sanctify</b> only <b>the dry</b> substances that are placed in them. <b>But</b> service <b>vessels</b> used for <b>the liquids do not sanctify the dry</b> substances placed in them, <b>and</b> service vessels used to <b>measure dry</b> substances <b>do not sanctify the liquids</b> placed in them.
<b>And Shmuel says</b> concerning this mishna: <b>They taught</b> that <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> with regard to service vessels used to <b>measure</b> liquids, e.g., wine or oil. <b>But cups,</b> which are used for collecting the blood of offerings, <b>sanctify</b> dry substances placed in them as well, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the offerings of the princes during the inauguration of the Tabernacle: “One silver cup of seventy shekels, after the shekel of the Sanctuary; <b>both of them full of fine flour</b> mingled with oil for a meal offering” (Numbers 7:13), indicating that the cups were also fashioned for use with flour, a dry substance. In this case, Shmuel does derive the general <i>halakha</i> from a temporary situation, in this case the offerings of the princes.
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> with regard to the offering of the princes, it <b>is different, as the verse is repeated twelve times,</b> once with regard to each and every prince. Therefore, Shmuel derives a <i>halakha</i> for all generations from it. Nevertheless, generally speaking, the <i>halakha</i> for all generations cannot be derived from a temporary situation.
The Gemara returns to discussing Rav’s statement that a rite is deemed indispensable if it is repeated in the verses. <b>Rav Kahana and Rav Asi said to Rav: But</b> what of <b>bringing</b> the meal offering to the corner of the altar, <b>which</b> is <b>repeated</b> in <b>the verse,</b> as it is stated: “And he shall bring it to the altar” (Leviticus 2:8); <b>and</b> it is <b>not indispensable,</b> as stated in the mishna (18a)? The Gemara elaborates: <b>Where is it repeated? As it is written: “And this is the law of the meal offering: The sons of Aaron shall sacrifice it before the Lord,</b> in front of the altar” (Leviticus 6:7).
The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse is not a repetition of the mitzva for the priest to bring the meal offering to the corner of the altar; rather, it <b>comes</b> only <b>to establish the place for</b> the meal offering and describe where it should be brought. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And this is the law of the meal offering. The sons of Aaron shall sacrifice it before the Lord, in front of the altar” (Leviticus 6:7). From the phrase: <b>“Before the Lord,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the meal offering must be brought <b>on the western</b> side of the altar, which faces the Sanctuary and is therefore “before the Lord.” Therefore, <b>the verse states: “In front of the altar,”</b> which is its southern side, where the priests ascend the ramp.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> the verse had merely stated: <b>In front of the altar,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the meal offering is brought only <b>on the southern</b> side of the altar, as just mentioned. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Before the Lord,”</b> which indicates the western side. <b>How</b> can <b>these</b> texts be reconciled? The <i>baraita</i> answers: The priest <b>brings it</b> near <b>on the southwest corner</b> of the altar, <b>opposite the edge of the corner</b> of the altar, <b>and</b> that will <b>suffice for him.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that the verse presents the priest with the option that <b>he may bring it on the western side of</b> the <b>corner or on the southern side of</b> the <b>corner. You say</b> the following principle: <b>Any</b> time <b>you find two verses, one</b> of which <b>fulfills itself and fulfills the other, and one</b> of which <b>fulfills itself and negates the other, we set aside</b> the verse <b>that fulfills itself and negates the other, and we seize</b> the verse <b>that fulfills itself and fulfills the other.</b>
He explains: <b>As, when you say</b> to bring the meal offering <b>“before the Lord,”</b> which indicates that it shall be brought <b>on the western</b> side, <b>you have nullified</b> the other part of the verse, which states to bring it <b>“in front of the altar,”</b> which is <b>on the southern</b> side. <b>But when you say</b> to bring the meal offering <b>“in front of the altar”</b> and offer it <b>on the southern</b> side, <b>you have</b> also <b>fulfilled</b> the other part of the verse, which states to bring it <b>“before the Lord.”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if one brought the meal offering on the southern side, <b>where have you fulfilled:</b> “Before the Lord”? <b>Rav Ashi said: This <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., Rabbi Eliezer, <b>holds</b> that <b>the entire altar stood in the northern</b> part of the Temple courtyard. The southern side of the altar was aligned with the midpoint of the Temple courtyard, opposite the Holy of Holies, directly before the Lord. In any event, it can be seen in this <i>baraita</i> that the purpose of the verse: “The sons of Aaron shall offer it before the Lord, in front of the altar” is to establish the precise location where the meal offering is brought, and it does not serve as a repetition.
The Gemara cites another objection to Rav’s statement that a rite of the meal offering is deemed indispensable if it is repeated in the verses. <b>Rav Huna objects to this: But</b> what of the placement of the <b>salt</b> on the handful of the meal offering before it is burned, <b>which</b> is <b>not repeated</b> in <b>the verse, and</b> yet it is still <b>indispensable in its</b> sacrifice? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“It is an everlasting covenant of salt”</b> (Numbers 18:19), teaching <b>that there will be</b>

Daf 20a

<b>a covenant stated with regard to salt,</b> ensuring that the offerings should always be salted; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says: It is stated here: “It is an everlasting covenant of salt”</b> (Numbers 18:19), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the reward given to Pinehas: <b>“The covenant of an everlasting priesthood”</b> (Numbers 25:13). This teaches that <b>just as it is impossible for the offerings</b> to be sacrificed <b>without</b> the involvement of the <b>priesthood, so too, it is impossible for the offerings</b> to be sacrificed <b>without salt.</b> The <i>baraita</i> demonstrates that the rite of salting is an indispensable requirement, despite the fact that the rite is not repeated in the verses.
<b>Rav Yosef said: Rav,</b> who holds that the only sacrificial rites that are indispensable are the ones repeated in the verses, <b>holds in accordance with the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna, <b>who says:</b> If one <b>did not</b> add <b>salt,</b> the meal offering is still <b>fit.</b> According to this <i>tanna</i>, adding salt is not indispensable. <b>Abaye said to him: If that is so</b> and you understand the mishna to be referring to a case where no salt is added at all, then you should <b>also</b> understand the mishna’s statement: If one <b>did not pour</b> the oil, as referring to a case where he <b>did not pour</b> oil <b>at all.</b> This cannot be, as the rite of pouring oil is repeated in the verses and is clearly indispensable. <b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be referring to a case where <b>a priest did not pour</b> oil onto the meal offering, <b>but a non-priest</b> did pour the oil. <b>Here too,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna means only that <b>a priest did not</b> add <b>salt, but a non-priest</b> did add salt. If no salt is added, even this <i>tanna</i> holds that the meal offering is unfit.
Rav Yosef <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>But could it enter your mind that a non-priest would approach</b> the <b>altar</b> to salt the handful of the meal offering? A non-priest may not enter the area near the altar. Since it is not conceivable that this would take place, it must be that when ruling that the meal offering is fit, the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna is referring to a case where the salt was never added.
<b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that Rav holds that <b>since</b> with regard to the application of salt, the term <b>“covenant” is written about it, it is considered as though it were repeated in</b> another <b>verse,</b> as the term “covenant” teaches that it is an indispensable rite.
With regard to the question that was raised to challenge the statement of Rav, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it correct that the application of salt <b>is not repeated in the verse? But isn’t it written: “And every meal offering of yours you shall season with salt”</b> (Leviticus 2:13)? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse does not function as a repetition, since it is <b>necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Had</b> the verse <b>stated</b> only: And every <b>offering</b> you shall season <b>with salt, I</b> would <b>derive</b> that this applies to even the <b>wood and</b> the <b>blood, which are</b> also <b>termed: An offering.</b>
To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “And every <b>meal offering</b> of yours,” to teach that <b>just as</b> the <b>meal offering is unique</b> in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it,</b> as the wood is required for the burning of the handful of the meal offering, <b>so too any</b> item that is unique in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it</b> requires the application of salt. By contrast, the wood and the blood do not require salting, as the wood itself requires no wood, and the blood is presented on the altar and does not require wood.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>If</b> that logic is employed, one could say: <b>Just as</b> the handful of the <b>meal offering</b> that is burned <b>is unique</b> in <b>that it permits</b> the remainder of the meal offering to be eaten by the priests, and it requires salting, <b>so too, any</b> item that is unique in <b>that it permits</b> other items requires the application of salt. Accordingly, <b>I will include blood</b> in the obligation to be salted, <b>as</b> its presentation <b>permits</b> the offering to be sacrificed and eaten. To counter this, the continuation of <b>the verse states:</b> “Neither shall you suffer the salt of the covenant of your God to be lacking <b>from your meal offering,”</b> demonstrating that it cannot be lacking from the meal offering, <b>but not from your blood.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>the entire meal offering requires salting,</b> including the remainder of the offering that is eaten by the priests. To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b> “And every meal <b>offering [<i>korban</i>]</b> of yours you shall season with salt” (Leviticus 2:13), teaching that the handful, which is burned as <b>an offering [<i>korban</i>]</b> on the altar, <b>requires salting, but the entire meal offering [<i>minḥa</i>] does not require salting.</b>
<b>And I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>the handful of a meal offering</b> requires salting. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the frankincense,</b> which is also burned on the altar, in the requirement to be salted? <b>I include the frankincense due to</b> the fact <b>that it comes along with</b> the handful <b>in one vessel</b> and is therefore included in the expression “offering.”
<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include</b> in the requirement to be salted <b>the frankincense that comes by itself</b> as a separate offering? One may accept the obligation to bring an offering of frankincense to be burned on the altar. From where is it derived that this frankincense requires salting? Moreover, from where is it derived to include in the requirement to be salted the <b>frankincense that comes in bowls</b> together with the shewbread, <b>and the incense?</b>
Moreover, from where is it derived in the requirement of salting in the case of the meal offerings from which a handful is not removed, i.e., <b>the meal offering of priests, and the meal offering of the anointed priest</b> that is brought every day by the High Priest, <b>and the meal offering</b> that accompanies the <b>libations</b> brought with burnt offerings and peace offerings? From where is it derived in the requirement of salting with regard to <b>the sacrificial portions of the sin offering</b> consumed on the altar, <b>and the sacrificial portions of the guilt offering, and the sacrificial portions of the offerings of the most sacred order, and the sacrificial portions of the offerings of lesser sanctity, and the limbs of the burnt offering, and the bird burnt offering? From where</b> is it derived that all these require salting?
The <i>baraita</i> continues: Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall sacrifice salt with all your offerings”</b> (Leviticus 2:13), demonstrating that everything burned on the altar requires salting. From this <i>baraita</i>, it is apparent that the mitzva to apply salt is necessary in order to teach about the circumstances where salt is added, and therefore it cannot be used as an instance where the mitzva is repeated in order to teach that the rite is indispensable.
§ The Gemara discusses the <i>baraita</i> cited above: <b>The Master said: I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>the handful of a meal offering</b> requires salting. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to include the frankincense,</b> which is also burned on the altar, in the requirement to be salted? <b>I include the frankincense, due to</b> the fact <b>that it comes along with</b> the handful <b>in one vessel</b> and therefore is included in the expression “offering.” The Gemara asks: Why is this verse needed? <b>But didn’t you state</b> earlier that <b>just as a meal offering is unique</b> in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it,</b> as the wood is required for the burning of the handful of the meal offering, so too, anything that is unique in that other items come as a requirement requires the application of salt? Therefore, it is already known that the frankincense and all the other items require salting, since wood is required for their burning.
The Gemara answers: When the <i>tanna</i> says: I have derived only that the handful of the meal offering requires salting, <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying:</b> One might understand the verse “And every meal offering of yours you shall season with salt” (Leviticus 2:13) differently and <b>say</b> the following exposition: The term <b>“offering”</b> that appears here is <b>a generalization,</b> while <b>“meal offering”</b> is <b>a detail.</b> According to the hermeneutical principles, in the case of <b>a generalization and a detail, there is nothing in the generalization other than what is in the detail.</b> Therefore, in the case of <b>a meal offering, yes,</b> it requires salting, but <b>anything else</b> does <b>not</b> require salting. From where, then, is the <i>halakha</i> of salting in all other cases derived?
Therefore, the verse <b>then states:</b> “You shall sacrifice salt <b>with all your offerings”</b> (Leviticus 2:13), and <b>it then generalized</b> again, so that the verse includes <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization,</b> in which case according to the hermeneutical principles <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail. Just as the specified detail,</b> i.e., the meal offering, is unique in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it, so too, anything</b> that is unique in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it</b> requires the application of salt. That is why the latter part of the verse is needed.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>What are</b> the <b>other</b> items <b>that come as a requirement for</b> the meal offering? This is referring to the <b>wood,</b> as the wood is required for the burning of the handful of the meal offering. <b>So too,</b> the expression: <b>Anything</b> that is unique in that other items come as a requirement for it, is referring to anything that requires <b>wood</b> so that it may be burned on the altar.
The Gemara asks: Why not <b>say</b> that the <b>other</b> items <b>that come as a requirement for</b> the meal offering <b>is</b> referring to the <b>frankincense,</b> which accompanies the meal offering, <b>and</b> therefore by means of the hermeneutical principle applying to a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization, <b>include blood, which is</b> accompanied by <b>libations?</b> The Gemara answers: The <b>libations</b> are not considered to accompany the sprinkling of the blood; rather, <b>they accompany the sacrificial portions</b> that are burned on the altar. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is because the burning of the sacrificial parts and the pouring of the libations are the <b>eating and drinking</b> of the altar. The Gemara counters: <b>On the contrary,</b> the libations are considered to accompany the blood, since the <b>atonement</b> that is effected by the presentation of the blood is followed by the <b>joy</b> that is displayed in the libation of wine.
<b>Rather,</b> one must say that since the <b>frankincense comes</b> together <b>with</b> the meal offering <b>in one vessel,</b> while the blood is not brought together with the libations in one vessel, the blood is not comparable to the meal offering. <b>But</b> when it is explained that the expression: The other items that come as a requirement for the meal offering, is referring to the <b>wood,</b> this means that <b>just as</b> the <b>meal offering is rendered fit by</b> means of the wood, <b>so too, all offerings are rendered fit by</b> means of the wood.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why not <b>say: Just as</b> the item mentioned in <b>the detail,</b> i.e., the handful of the meal offering, is clearly <b>defined as</b> an item <b>for which other</b> items <b>come as a requirement, and</b> in addition it <b>renders</b> other items <b>permitted, so too, anything</b> that is unique in <b>that other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it and renders</b> other items <b>permitted</b> requires the application of salt. <b>And what is</b> included due to this derivation? <b>Frankincense that comes in</b> the <b>bowls</b> that are placed upon the shewbread, <b>as it renders</b> the bread <b>permitted</b> to be eaten. <b>But</b> every <b>other item</b> should <b>not</b> be included.
The Gemara answers: It is apparent that all other items require only the factor of having other items come as a requirement for them to be considered similar to the meal offering. This is clear <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> in the case of blood, which is similar to the meal offering only in that it renders the offering permitted, it <b>was necessary</b> to teach that salt is not placed on blood, by means of the phrase: “Neither shall you suffer the salt of the covenant of your God to be lacking <b>from your meal offering,”</b> from which it is derived: <b>But not from your blood.</b> Had it been necessary for all items to have both aspects in common with the meal offering, there would be no need for a derivation to exclude blood. <b>By inference, these</b> other items <b>derived</b> from a meal offering are similar to it <b>in one respect.</b>
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said</b> above: The verse states: “Neither shall you suffer the salt of the covenant of your God to be lacking <b>from your meal offering,”</b> demonstrating that salt cannot be lacking from the meal offering, <b>but not from your blood.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> since the verse does not allude to blood explicitly, why not <b>say</b> that the verse teaches that salt cannot be lacking <b>from your meal offering, but not from your limbs</b> of the burnt offering that are sacrificed on the altar?
The Gemara answers: <b>It stands to reason</b> that the <b>limbs</b> of a burnt offering <b>should be included</b> in the requirement to have salt applied, <b>since</b> they share many characteristics with a meal offering that blood does not. The Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for the characteristics that they share: <b><i>Alef</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>nun</i>; <i>tet</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>alef</i>.</b> These are a reference to others [<i>aḥerim</i>], fire [<i>ishim</i>], external [<i>baḥutz</i>], <i>notar</i>; ritual impurity [<i>tuma</i>], and misuse of consecrated property [<i>me’ila</i>].
In the case of the limbs of a burnt offering, <b>other</b> items <b>come as a requirement for it, as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering. The burnt offering requires wood in order to be burned on the altar, which is not the case with regard to the blood. The limbs of the burnt offering are burned in the <b>fire</b> of the altar, <b>as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering, whereas the blood is presented on the corners of the altar. The burnt offering is sacrificed <b>on the external</b> altar, <b>as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering, as opposed to the blood, which is presented inside the Sanctuary in the cases of the bull and goat of Yom Kippur. It is prohibited to partake of its <b>leftover [<i>notar</i>]</b> parts, <b>as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering, which is not relevant to blood.
It is prohibited to partake of a burnt offering while in a state of <b>ritual impurity, as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering, which is not relevant to blood. It is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering, which is not so with regard to the blood.

Daf 20b

The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>On the contrary, blood should be included</b> in the requirement to have salt applied, <b>since</b> it <b>renders</b> the offering <b>permitted</b> to be sacrificed and eaten, <b>as</b> is so with regard to the handful, which renders the remainder of the meal offering permitted to be eaten. In addition, blood <b>becomes invalid at sunset</b> and can no longer be sprinkled on the altar, <b>as</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the handful of a meal offering, whereas the limbs of the burnt offering may be sacrificed at any point during the night. The Gemara responds: <b>These</b> characteristics shared by the meal offering and the limbs of the burnt offering are <b>more</b> than those shared by the blood and the meal offering.
§ The Gemara continues discussing the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said</b> above: Had the verse stated only: And every offering you shall season with salt, <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> that this applies to <b>even</b> the <b>wood and</b> the <b>blood, which are</b> also <b>termed: An offering.</b> Therefore, the verse states “and every meal offering of yours” (Leviticus 2:13), to teach that just as the meal offering is unique in that other items come as a requirement for it, so too, anything that is unique in that other items come as a requirement for it requires the application of salt. Therefore, the wood and the blood do not require salting, as in their case no other item is needed. The Gemara asks: <b>Whom did you hear who says</b> that the <b>wood is termed an offering?</b> It is <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. But <b>according to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, doesn’t the wood in fact <b>require salting?</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And when one brings <b>a meal offering [<i>korban minḥa</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 2:1). The superfluous word <i>korban</i> <b>teaches that one can voluntarily give wood</b> as an offering for the altar. <b>And how much</b> wood must one bring if he does not specify an amount? <b>Two logs. And</b> the support for the fact that wood can be brought as a voluntary offering is from a verse, <b>as</b> the verse <b>states: “And we cast lots for the wood offering”</b> (Nehemiah 10:35). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> This voluntary donation of <b>wood is</b> an offering like <b>a meal offering, and</b> therefore it <b>requires salt and requires bringing</b> to the corner of the altar, like a meal offering.
<b>And Rava says: According to the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>wood</b> donated in this manner <b>requires</b> the <b>removal of a handful,</b> just as in the case of a meal offering, a portion of the wood must be removed and sacrificed separately. <b>And Rav Pappa says</b> that <b>according to the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, since it is an offering for the altar, the <b>wood</b> that is brought as an offering <b>needs</b> to be placed on other <b>wood</b> to burn, like any other offering that is burned on wood on the altar. Apparently, this means that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the wood is termed an offering, also holds that it requires the application of salt, in contrast to the ruling in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>Remove wood from</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>here,</b> as it is not excluded by the term “and every meal offering of yours.” The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> then, the phrase in <b>the verse</b> “and every meal offering of yours” is <b>to exclude what? If</b> it serves <b>to exclude blood,</b> this is <b>derived from</b> the continuation of the verse, which states: <b>“From your meal offering,”</b> as explained in the continuation of the <i>baraita</i>.

Daf 21a

The Gemara responds: <b>Wood</b> is <b>removed</b> from the <i>baraita</i>, <b>and insert</b> in its place wine <b>libations,</b> teaching that they do not require the addition of salt. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>But the wine</b> libations <b>and the blood, and the wood and the incense, do not require salt.</b>
The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If</b> you say it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> concerning <b>wood</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> rules that wood does not require salt, whereas Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that wood does require salt. <b>If</b> you say it is the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> concerning <b>incense</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as they taught in the <i>baraita</i> on 20a that any item for which another item is necessary requires salt, and this includes the incense, which is burned with wood.
The Gemara suggests: The <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with <b>this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>,</b> who explains the verse that was interpreted in the <i>baraita</i> in a different manner. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> The verse states: “And every meal offering of yours you shall season with salt” (Leviticus 2:13). <b>Just as the specified detail,</b> i.e., the meal offering, is <b>an item that is susceptible to ritual impurity, and is brought on the fire</b> of the altar, <b>and is</b> sacrificed <b>on the external altar, so too, any item that is susceptible to ritual impurity, and is brought on the fire</b> of the altar, <b>and is</b> sacrificed <b>on the external altar</b> requires salting.
Therefore, <b>wood is excluded, as</b> it is <b>not susceptible to ritual impurity. Wine and blood are excluded, as they are not brought on the fire</b> of the altar but rather are sprinkled on the corner of the altar. The <b>incense</b> is <b>excluded, as it is</b> sacrificed <b>not on the external altar</b> but rather on the inner altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> how can it be that according to all opinions, <b>the reason that</b> blood does not require salting is that <b>the verse excluded blood,</b> indicating <b>that</b> if <b>not</b> for <b>that, I would say</b> that <b>blood requires salt? Once one salts</b> the blood, <b>it exits the category of blood, as Ze’eiri says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> With regard to <b>blood that one cooked, one does not transgress</b> the prohibition against consuming blood <b>by</b> drinking <b>it,</b> since it no longer has the status of blood that is fit to be presented on the altar. <b>And Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Ze’eiri</b> says: With regard to <b>blood that one salted, one does not transgress</b> a prohibition <b>by</b> drinking <b>it,</b> since salted blood has the status of cooked blood.
<b>And</b> similarly, <b>Rav Yehuda himself says:</b> With regard to the <b>limbs</b> of a burnt offering <b>that</b> one first <b>roasted and</b> afterward <b>brought them up</b> to the altar, <b>they do not constitute</b> fulfillment of the requirement of the verse that an offering be <b>“an aroma pleasing</b> to the Lord” (Exodus 29:25).
The Gemara answers: It is still necessary to derive that blood does not require salt, <b>lest you say</b> that the priest should <b>sprinkle any amount</b> of salt, even a minute quantity, <b>on</b> the blood, <b>merely for</b> the fulfillment of the <b>mitzva,</b> as such an amount would not render the blood as cooked. To counter this, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that blood requires no application of salt.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself: Ze’eiri says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> With regard to <b>blood that one cooked, one does not transgress</b> a prohibition <b>by</b> drinking <b>it. Rava was sitting and saying this <i>halakha</i>. Abaye raised an objection to</b> him from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Karetot</i> 2:19): If <b>one curdled blood and consumed it, or</b> in a case <b>where one melted</b> forbidden <b>fat and swallowed it,</b> even though he changed its form, he is <b>liable.</b> This demonstrates that even after its form is changed, the blood’s status remains unchanged.
Rava responded: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>here,</b> Ze’eiri’s statement relates to a case <b>where he curdled</b> the blood <b>by</b> means of <b>the fire,</b> whereas <b>there,</b> in the case of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>he curdled</b> the blood <b>by</b> means of <b>the sun.</b> Blood curdled <b>by</b> means of <b>a fire cannot return</b> to its former state, so one is not liable, whereas blood curdled <b>by</b> means of <b>the sun can return</b> to its former state, so one is liable.
Abaye objected: But <b>even</b> when blood is curdled <b>by</b> means of <b>the sun, let us say</b> that <b>since it was disqualified</b> from being presented on the altar, <b>it was disqualified,</b> i.e., excluded, from the prohibition against consuming blood; <b>as Rabbi Mani inquired of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> With regard to <b>blood that was congealed and one ate it, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Rabbi Yoḥanan responded: He is not liable; <b>since it was disqualified</b> from being presented on the altar, <b>it shall be disqualified</b> from the prohibition against consuming blood. Rava <b>was silent</b> and had no answer.
Abaye <b>said to him: Perhaps here</b> the <i>baraita</i> is <b>certainly</b> referring <b>to</b> the blood of <b>the external sin offerings,</b> which is sprinkled on the external altar in the Temple courtyard, whereas <b>there</b> Ze’eiri is referring <b>to</b> the blood of <b>the inner sin offerings,</b> which is sprinkled inside the Sanctuary.
Rava <b>said</b> to him: <b>You have reminded me of a matter, as Rabbi Ḥisda says:</b> With regard to <b>blood that became congealed,</b> if it is blood <b>of the</b> external <b>sin offerings and one ate it,</b> he is <b>liable,</b> as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take</b> of the blood of the sin offering with his finger, <b>and place it</b> upon the corners of the altar of burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:25), and congealed blood <b>is suitable for taking and placing,</b> as one can take the congealed blood and place it upon the altar. By contrast, if it is blood <b>of the inner sin offerings and one ate it,</b> he is <b>exempt,</b> as <b>the Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall dip</b> his finger in the blood, <b>and sprinkle</b> of the blood” (Leviticus 4:6), <b>and this</b> congealed blood <b>is not suitable for dipping and sprinkling.</b>
<b>And Rava himself says: Even</b> if there was blood <b>of the inner sin offerings and one ate it,</b> he is <b>liable, since</b> blood <b>corresponding to</b> this blood is <b>suitable</b> to be placed on the altar <b>in</b> the case of <b>the external sin offerings. Rav Pappa says: Therefore,</b> according to the same reasoning, in the case of <b>the blood of a donkey that became congealed and one ate it,</b> he is <b>liable,</b> despite the fact that a donkey’s blood is not fit to be brought as an offering, <b>since</b> blood <b>corresponding to</b> this blood <b>is suitable</b> to be placed on the altar <b>in</b> the case of <b>the external sin offerings.</b>
In the context of the <i>halakhot</i> of blood, <b>Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Ze’eiri says: Blood, whether moist or dry, interposes</b> during ritual immersion. The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Mikvaot</i> 6:9): With regard to <b>blood, ink, honey, or milk</b> on a person’s skin, when <b>they are dry, they interpose</b> during immersion; but when <b>they are moist, they do not interpose.</b> The Gemara explains: This is <b>not difficult; this</b> statement of Rav Giddel is referring to a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>adheres</b> to the skin, as it has begun to congeal and therefore interposes. <b>That</b> <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where</b> the blood <b>did not adhere</b> and therefore does not interpose.
§ The Gemara returns to its interpretation of the verse: “And every meal offering of yours you shall season with salt” (Leviticus 2:13), and asks: <b>For what</b> purpose does the expression <b>“you shall season” come?</b> The Gemara answers: It is written <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Had the verse stated only: And every meal offering of yours shall be <b>with salt,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the <i>halakha</i> is <b><i>tevonehu</i>,</b> a term that will be explained in the Gemara. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “You shall season.”</b> Conversely, <b>had</b> the verse stated only: <b>“You shall season,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that this obligation can be fulfilled <b>by</b> means of adding <b>salt water.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states “with salt.”</b>
The continuation of the verse: <b>“And you shall not omit [<i>tashbit</i>] salt</b> from your meal offering,” teaches that <b>one should bring salt that never rests [<i>shovetet</i>],</b> i.e., it is found continuously. <b>And what</b> type of salt <b>is this? This</b> is referring to <b>salt of Sodom. And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if one did not find salt of Sodom that he should bring salt of <i>istrokanit</i>,</b> which is quarried from rock? <b>The verse states</b> immediately afterward: “With all your offerings <b>you shall sacrifice</b> salt” (Leviticus 2:13), in order to emphasize that <b>you should sacrifice any</b> type of salt; <b>you should sacrifice</b> salt <b>from any place,</b> even from a location outside of Eretz Yisrael; <b>you should sacrifice</b> salt <b>even on Shabbat;</b> and <b>you should sacrifice</b> salt <b>even in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b><i>tevonehu</i>? Rabba bar Ulla said: This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one should mix into it [<i>yitabonenu</i>]</b> large quantities of salt, <b>just as</b> one mixes <b>straw [<i>teven</i>] into clay. Abaye said to him: If so,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have said: <i>Yitabonenu</i>,</b> and not <i>tevonehu</i>. <b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> is saying that one <b>might</b> have thought <b>one should form</b> the addition of salt <b>just as</b> one builds <b>a building [<i>binyan</i>],</b> by adding layer upon layer. <b>Rava said to him: If so,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have said: He should build it [<i>yivnenu</i>]</b> and not <i>tevonehu</i>. <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> states: One <b>might</b> have thought <b><i>tevonehu</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by <b><i>tevonehu</i>? Rav Ashi said:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one should infuse</b> the entire offering with the <b>taste</b> of salt, <b>just as understanding [<i>bina</i>]</b> infuses a person with wisdom. To counter this, <b>the verse states: “You shall season.” How does he act? He brings the limb</b> that is to be sacrificed on the altar <b>and applies salt, and then turns it over and again applies salt, and brings it up</b> to the altar.
<b>Abaye says: And</b> one acts <b>similarly</b> before placing meat <b>into a pot.</b> If one wishes to cook meat and needs to salt it in order to extract its blood, it is sufficient to apply salt to both sides and let it sit until the blood drains. Then, after it is washed, the meat is ready to be cooked and eaten.

Daf 21b

<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:4): With regard to <b>salt that is on the limb</b> of an offering, one who derives benefit <b>from it</b> is liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, but in the case of salt <b>that is on the ramp or that is on top of the altar,</b> one who derives benefit <b>from it</b> is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property. <b>And Rav Mattana said: What is the verse</b> from which it is derived that the salt found upon a sacrificial limb is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property? The verse states: <b>“And you shall sacrifice them before the Lord, and the priests shall cast salt upon them, and they shall offer them up for a burnt offering to the Lord”</b> (Ezekiel 43:24). In this verse, the limbs, together with the salt, are termed a burnt offering, and therefore the salt on the limb is also subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property.
With regard to the <i>halakha</i> that salt is not subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of misuse of consecrated property, <b>we learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 7:7): The court instituted an ordinance <b>about the salt and about the wood</b> in the Temple to the effect <b>that the priests may derive benefit from them. Shmuel says: They taught only</b> that the priests may derive benefit from the salt <b>for</b> use on <b>their offerings, but not for eating</b> it.
The Gemara comments: <b>It enters our mind</b> to say: <b>What</b> did Shmuel mean by the expression: <b>For</b> use on <b>their offerings?</b> He meant that the priests were permitted <b>to salt their</b> personal <b>offerings.</b> And when Shmuel states that <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>eating</b> it is not permitted for the priests to derive benefit from the salt, he is referring to adding salt when <b>eating</b> the meat <b>of sacrificial</b> animals, e.g., the portions of the sin offering and guilt offering that are given to the priests. The Gemara challenges this explanation: <b>Now,</b> if <b>we give</b> the priests salt in order <b>to salt the hides of sacrificial</b> animals that are given to the priests to keep, so that they can process them, is it reasonable to rule that <b>we do not give them</b> salt in order <b>to</b> add it when they <b>eat</b> the meat of <b>sacrificial</b> animals?
The Gemara explains its challenge: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 6:2): <b>You are found</b> to be <b>saying</b> that <b>the salt is placed in three locations</b> in the Temple: <b>In the Chamber of the Salt, and on the ramp, and on top of</b> the <b>altar.</b> It is placed <b>in the Chamber of the Salt, since</b> the priests <b>salted there the hides of sacrificial</b> animals that are given to them. It is placed <b>on the ramp, since</b> the priests <b>salted there the</b> sacrificial <b>limbs.</b> It is placed <b>on top of</b> the <b>altar, since</b> the priests <b>salted there the handful</b> of the meal offering, <b>the frankincense, the incense, the meal offering of priests, the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, the meal offering</b> that accompanies the <b>libations, and the bird burnt offering.</b> Evidently, it was permitted for the priests to add salt to their portions of sacrificial meat.
The Gemara suggests a different explanation of Shmuel’s statement: <b>Rather, what</b> did Shmuel mean by the expression: <b>For</b> use on <b>their offerings?</b> He meant that it is permitted for the priests <b>to</b> add salt when they <b>eat</b> the meat of <b>their offerings,</b> e.g., the portions of the guilt offerings and sin offerings that are given to the priests, as well as when they eat the remainder of the meal offering. <b>And what</b> is meant when Shmuel states that <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>eating</b> it is not permitted for the priests to derive benefit from the salt? He is referring to using the salt for the purpose of <b>eating non-sacred</b> food.
The Gemara objects: Isn’t it <b>obvious</b> that the salt is not to be eaten with <b>non-sacred</b> food? <b>What</b> would non-sacred food be <b>doing there</b> in the Temple courtyard? The Gemara answers: <b>Even though the Master says</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that the verse stated with regard to the meal offering: “And that which is left of it Aaron and his sons <b>shall eat”</b> (Leviticus 6:9), teaching <b>that</b> the priests <b>shall eat non-sacred</b> food <b>and <i>teruma</i> along with</b> the remainder of the meal offering <b>so that</b> the remainder of the meal offering <b>will be eaten in</b> a manner that the priest will be <b>satiated</b> when he finishes eating it, demonstrating that non-sacred food may be brought to the Temple courtyard, <b>even so we do not give them consecrated salt.</b>
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: So too, it is reasonable</b> to explain that Shmuel’s explanation of the mishna in <i>Shekalim</i> is that the ordinance of the court permitted the priests to eat the salt with sacrificial foods. <b>As, if it enters your mind</b> to say: <b>What</b> did Shmuel mean by the expression: <b>For</b> use on <b>their offerings?</b> He meant that the priests were permitted <b>to salt</b> their personal offerings; then one must extrapolate from the mishna that <b>the reason</b> this is permitted is <b>that the court stipulated</b> that it should be, <b>but had the court not stipulated</b> this, it would <b>not</b> be permitted. That cannot be, as <b>now</b> that <b>we give</b> salt <b>to Israelites</b> to salt their offerings, will <b>we not give</b> salt <b>to priests</b> for the same purpose?
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that we provide salt for the offerings of Israelites: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a meal offering, must bring salt from his home,</b> i.e., his own salt, to salt the handful that is burned on the altar, <b>just as he brings frankincense from his home</b> for his meal offering. <b>And</b> this would seem to be <b>a logical inference:</b> It <b>is stated</b> in the Torah that one shall <b>bring a meal offering, and</b> it is stated that one shall <b>bring salt,</b> as it is written: “And every meal offering of yours you shall season with salt” (Leviticus 2:13); <b>and</b> it <b>is stated</b> that one shall <b>bring a meal offering, and</b> it is stated that one shall <b>bring frankincense.</b> Therefore, <b>just as</b> one brings <b>frankincense from his home,</b> as it is written: “And put frankincense on it. And he shall bring it to Aaron’s sons the priests” (Leviticus 2:1–2), <b>so too,</b> one must bring <b>salt from his home.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way:</b> It <b>is stated</b> in the Torah that one shall <b>bring a meal offering and</b> that one shall <b>bring salt, and</b> it <b>is stated</b> that one shall <b>bring a meal offering and</b> that one shall <b>bring wood,</b> as the meal offering cannot be burned on the altar without the wood. Therefore, <b>just as</b> the <b>wood</b> comes <b>from communal</b> supplies, <b>so too,</b> the <b>salt</b> shall come <b>from communal</b> supplies.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Let us see to which</b> salt <b>is</b> more <b>similar,</b> i.e., which comparison seems more reasonable: <b>We derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of salt, which is <b>a matter that applies to all offerings, from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of wood, which is also <b>a matter that applies to all offerings. And</b> do <b>not</b> let the <i>halakha</i> of <b>frankincense prove</b> otherwise, <b>as it does not apply to all offerings,</b> only to the meal offerings.
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way: We derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of salt, which is <b>a matter that accompanies</b> the meal offering <b>in one vessel, from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of frankincense, which is also <b>a matter that accompanies</b> the meal offering <b>in one vessel. And</b> do <b>not</b> let the <i>halakha</i> of <b>wood prove</b> otherwise, <b>as it does not accompany</b> the meal offering <b>in one vessel.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>The verse states: “It is an everlasting covenant of salt”</b> (Numbers 18:19), <b>and there,</b> with regard to the shewbread, <b>it states: “It is from the children of Israel, an everlasting covenant”</b> (Leviticus 24:8); Therefore, <b>just as</b> the phrase written <b>there:</b> “From the children of Israel, an everlasting covenant,” means that it is brought <b>from communal</b> supplies, as the shewbread is a communal offering, <b>so too here,</b> the verse that speaks of the everlasting covenant of salt means that the salt is brought <b>from communal</b> supplies. Evidently, salt is provided for offerings of Israelites, and should likewise be provided for the offerings of priests. Accordingly, there would have been no need for the court to permit the priests to salt their offerings, and it must be that the ordinance of the court permitted the priests to use salt when eating sacrificial foods.
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: This</b> is what <b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, says:</b> The initial understanding of Shmuel’s interpretation of the mishna is correct, i.e., that the ordinance of the court permitted the priests to salt their offerings; and the ruling of the mishna <b>is necessary only according to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Bukhri,</b> who holds that priests are not obligated to contribute a yearly half-shekel to purchase the communal supplies.
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 1:4): <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>ben Bukhri testified in Yavne: Any priest who contributes his shekel is not</b> considered <b>a sinner,</b> despite the fact that he is not obligated to do so. Rabbi Yehuda added that <b>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to</b> ben Bukhri: <b>That is not</b> the case; <b>rather, any priest who does not contribute his shekel</b> is considered <b>a sinner,</b> as they are obligated in this mitzva like all other Jews. <b>But the priests</b> who do not contribute the shekel <b>interpret this</b> following <b>verse to their own</b> advantage in order to excuse themselves from the mitzva.
The verse states: <b>“And every meal offering of the priest shall be wholly made to smoke; it shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:16). Those priests claim as follows: <b>Since</b> the <b><i>omer</i></b> offering <b>and the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering of two loaves from the new wheat, brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>and the shewbread</b> placed on the Table in the Sanctuary each Shabbat, which are all meal offerings, are <b>ours,</b> then if we contribute shekels we will have partial ownership of these communal offerings, as they are purchased with the shekels. <b>How,</b> then, <b>can they be eaten?</b> They would then be regarded as priests’ meal offerings, which must be wholly burned.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>ben Bukhri,</b> why is a priest who contributes a half-shekel not considered a sinner? <b>Since he is not obligated to bring</b> it <b><i>ab initio</i>, when he brings</b> the half-shekel <b>he is also a sinner, since he is</b> causing the <b>bringing</b> of <b>a non-sacred</b> item <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> He is not contributing the half-shekel as part of the communal offering, as he is exempt from this obligation. Therefore, his donation is the donation of an individual, and a communal offering cannot be brought on behalf of an individual. His donation should disqualify all offerings brought from the communal funds. The Gemara answers: The priest <b>brings and transfers</b> the half-shekel <b>to the community,</b> so it is considered part of the communal funds.
The Gemara states the relevance of the opinion of ben Bukhri to the statement of Shmuel: According to the opinion of ben Bukhri it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that

Daf 22a

<b>when the Merciful One granted</b> the Jewish people the right to use the salt when eating their offerings, he granted this <b>to Israelites, who have</b> an obligation to donate their half-shekels to the <b>chamber,</b> as this fund supplies the salt that is applied to the offerings. With regard <b>to the priests, who do not have</b> an obligation to donate their half-shekels to the <b>chamber, the Merciful One did not grant them</b> the right to make use of the salt. To counter this, the mishna in tractate <i>Shekalim</i> <b>teaches us</b> that the court granted to the priests the right to use the salt when eating their offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to the <b>wood,</b> concerning <b>which</b> it is <b>obvious to the <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>that</b> it is brought <b>from communal</b> supplies, <b>from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering, must bring wood from his home</b> on which the burnt offering will be sacrificed, <b>just as he brings libations from his home</b> along with a burnt offering (see Numbers, chapter 15). Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the burnt offering: <b>“On the wood that is on the fire which is upon the altar”</b> (Leviticus 1:12); the Torah juxtaposes the wood to the altar, teaching that <b>just as</b> the <b>altar</b> was built <b>from communal</b> funds, <b>so too,</b> the <b>wood and fire</b> are brought <b>from communal</b> supplies. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua says: Just as</b> the <b>altar was not used by an ordinary</b> person, as it was built for the purpose of serving as an altar for God, <b>so too,</b> the <b>wood and fire</b> should <b>not have been used</b> previously <b>by an ordinary</b> person, so one does not bring the wood from his home. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> the two opinions? The Gemara answers: The difference <b>between</b> the two <b>is whether</b> there is a requirement that the wood be <b>new,</b> i.e., that it had never been used. According to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar bar Rabbi Shimon, the wood is fit provided that it comes from communal supplies, even if it is not new wood, whereas according to Rabbi Elazar ben Shammua it must be new wood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it in fact the <i>halakha</i> that <b>old,</b> i.e., previously used, wood is <b>not</b> fit to be burned on the altar? <b>But isn’t it written: “And Araunah said to David: Let my lord the king take and offer up what seems good to him; behold the oxen for the burnt offering, and the threshing instruments [<i>morigim</i>] and the equipment of the oxen for the wood”</b> (II Samuel 24:22)? Despite the fact that the threshing instruments and equipment of the oxen have been used previously, apparently they are fit to be used when offering a burnt offering. The Gemara answers: <b>Here too,</b> the verse is speaking <b>of new</b> instruments and equipment that had not been previously used.
Tangentially, the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the term <b><i>morigim</i></b> mentioned in this verse? <b>Ulla said:</b> It is <b>a <i>turbal</i> bed.</b> This was not a known expression in Babylonia, so the Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is <b>a <i>turbal</i> bed? Rav Yehuda said:</b> It is referring to <b>a serrated [<i>dekurkesa</i>] board that the threshers use for threshing,</b> which is dragged over the grain by an animal in order to separate the kernels from the stalks. <b>Rav Yosef said: What is the verse</b> from which the meaning of <i>morigim</i> is derived? It is the verse that states: <b>“Behold, I have made you a new threshing sledge [<i>morag</i>] having sharp teeth; you shall thresh the mountains”</b> (Isaiah 41:15).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>a handful</b> of one meal offering, which is to be burned on the altar, <b>was intermingled with a handful of another</b> meal offering, or <b>with the meal offering of priests,</b> or <b>with the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest,</b> i.e., the High Priest, or <b>with the meal offering of libations</b> accompanying burnt offerings and peace offerings, all of which are burned in their entirety on the altar, it is <b>fit</b> for sacrifice, and the mixture is burned on the altar.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the handful was intermingled <b>with the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest,</b> or <b>with the meal offering of libations,</b> the mixture is <b>unfit because</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> the handful from the standard meal offering, <b>its mixture is thick,</b> one <i>log</i> of oil mixed with a tenth of an ephah of flour, <b>and</b> with regard to <b>that,</b> the meal offering of the anointed priest and the meal offering of libations, <b>its mixture is loose,</b> three <i>log</i> of oil mixed with a tenth of an ephah of flour. <b>And</b> the mixtures, which are not identical, <b>absorb from each other,</b> increasing the amount of oil in the handful and decreasing the amount of oil in the meal offering of the anointed priest or the meal offering of libations, thereby invalidating both.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 77b): In the case of <b>blood</b> of an offering fit for sacrifice <b>that was mixed with water, if</b> the mixture <b>has the appearance of blood,</b> it is <b>fit</b> for presenting on the altar, even though the majority of the mixture is water. If the blood <b>was mixed with</b> red <b>wine, one views</b> the wine <b>as though it were water.</b> If that amount of water would leave the mixture with the appearance of blood, it is fit for presentation. Likewise, if the blood <b>was mixed with the blood of</b> a non-sacred <b>domesticated animal or the blood of</b> a non-sacred <b>undomesticated animal, one considers</b> the blood <b>as though it were water. Rabbi Yehuda says: Blood does not nullify blood.</b> Therefore, the priest presents the blood of the mixture on the altar regardless of the ratio of sacred to non-sacred blood.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And both</b> the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yehuda <b>derived</b> their opinions <b>from one verse.</b> With regard to the sacrificial rites performed by the High Priest on Yom Kippur, the Torah teaches that after sprinkling of the blood of the bull and of the goat separately between the staves of the Ark and on the Curtain, the blood of the two animals is mixed together and presented on the golden altar inside the Sanctuary. The verse states: <b>“And he shall take of the blood of the bull and of the blood of the goat</b> and put it on the corners of the altar” (Leviticus 16:18). <b>It is a known matter that the blood of the bull is more than the blood of a goat.</b> Why then is the blood of the goat not nullified? Rabbi Yoḥanan explains: <b>The Rabbis,</b> i.e, the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>hold:</b>

Daf 22b

<b>From here</b> it is learned <b>that</b> with regard to a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, e.g., the blood of the bull and the goat, the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another. And Rabbi Yehuda holds: From here</b> it is learned <b>that</b> any <b>substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance is not nullified.</b>
The Gemara examines Rabbi Yoḥanan’s explanation of the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda. With regard to the first part of his explanation, that <b>the Rabbis hold: From here</b> it is learned <b>that</b> with regard to a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another,</b> the Gemara suggests: <b>But perhaps</b> the blood of the goat is not nullified when mixed with the blood of the bull <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> by using an example of <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance, and not taught us</b> a case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, the verse would be interpreted <b>as you said.</b> But <b>now that</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> through a case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, it is understood that the reason it is not nullified is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that</b> it is part of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, not because the substances are of the same type.
The Gemara suggests: <b>But perhaps</b> it is not nullified <b>until</b> both criteria <b>are</b> met, and unless the mixture is both <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance and</b> a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, one nullifies the other. The Gemara concedes: This is <b>difficult.</b>
With regard to the second part of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s explanation: <b>And Rabbi Yehuda holds: From here</b> it is learned <b>that</b> any <b>substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance is not nullified,</b> the Gemara suggests: <b>But perhaps</b> the blood of the goat is not nullified when mixed with the blood of the bull <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is</b> a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar.
The Gemara answers: <b>Had</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> by using an example of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar where the <b>substance</b> is in contact <b>with a different</b> type of <b>substance,</b> the verse would be interpreted <b>as you say.</b> But <b>now that</b> the verse <b>taught us</b> this <i>halakha</i> in a case of <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance,</b> it is understood that the reason it is not nullified is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that it is a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>But perhaps</b> it is not nullified <b>until</b> both criteria <b>are</b> met, and unless the mixture is both <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance and</b> a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar, one nullifies the other. The Gemara concedes: This is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara raises another objection to the explanation of Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna here that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> If the handful was intermingled <b>with the meal offering of priests, with the meal offering of</b> the <b>anointed priest, or with the meal offering of libations,</b> the mixture is <b>unfit because</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> the handful from the standard meal offering, <b>its mixture is thick, and</b> with regard to <b>that,</b> the meal offering of the anointed priest and the meal offering of libations, <b>its mixture is loose. And</b> the mixtures, which are not identical, <b>absorb from each other,</b> invalidating both. The Gemara asks: <b>But when</b> the mixtures <b>absorb from each other, what of it?</b> This <b>is</b> a case of <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance,</b> and therefore neither oil nullifies the other and both should be sacrificed on the altar.

Daf 23a

<b>Rava said: Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that in the case of <b>any</b> mixture <b>that consists of a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance as well as another</b> type of <b>substance,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is to <b>disregard</b> the <b>same substance,</b> considering it <b>as though it were not</b> there, <b>and</b> in the event that the <b>different</b> type of <b>substance is more than</b> the first substance, the different substance <b>nullifies</b> the first substance. In the case of the mishna here, the handful of the meal offering is mixed with other types of meal offerings that comprise greater quantities of oil. The oil of the handful is disregarded, and the flour of the handful, which is present in greater quantities than the oil of the other meal offering that is absorbed in it, nullifies this oil of the other meal offering. That oil is now considered to be one with the oil of the handful, and therefore the oil of the handful is increased, and the handful is unfit.
§ <b>It was stated</b> that the <i>amora’im</i> disagreed with regard to the <i>halakha</i> <b>where one added oil to the handful</b> that is removed from <b>the meal offering of a sinner,</b> which does not include oil. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>unfit, and Reish Lakish says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of the meal offering <b>itself</b> is to <b>wipe it,</b> <i>ab initio</i>, <b>in the remainder of the <i>log</i></b> of oil that remains in the vessels that were used previously for other meal offerings, <b>and</b> the priest then <b>brings it up</b> and burns it on the altar. This is done so that the meal offering will not be completely dry.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it written</b> with regard to the meal offering of a sinner: <b>“He shall put no oil upon it, neither shall he put any frankincense on it”</b> (Leviticus 5:11)? How, then, can any oil be added? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse teaches <b>that one should not designate oil for it as</b> one designates oil for the <b>other</b> meal offerings, but the meal offering of a sinner is not rendered unfit by the addition of a small amount of oil.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raised an objection to Reish Lakish</b> from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 4:4): In the case of <b>a dry</b> meal offering <b>that was intermingled with</b> a meal offering that was <b>mixed</b> with oil, the priest <b>shall sacrifice</b> it. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The priest <b>shall not sacrifice</b> it. <b>What, is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>not</b> referring to <b>a handful of the meal offering of a sinner that was intermingled with a handful of a voluntary meal offering,</b> demonstrating that the oil invalidates the handful of a meal offering of a sinner?
Reish Lakish responded: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>the meal offering</b> that accompanies the libations brought with the offerings <b>of bulls or rams,</b> for which two <i>log</i> of oil is mixed with a tenth of an ephah of flour, that became intermingled <b>with the meal offering</b> that accompanies the libations brought with the offering <b>of sheep,</b> for which three <i>log</i> of oil is mixed with a tenth of an ephah of flour, as the former is considered dry relative to the latter.
Rabbi Yoḥanan objected: <b>But</b> another <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches this explicitly</b> as a separate <i>halakha</i>: With regard to <b>the meal offering</b> that accompanies the offerings <b>of bulls or rams</b> that became intermingled <b>with the meal offering</b> that accompanies the offering <b>of sheep, and a dry</b> meal offering <b>that was intermingled with</b> a meal offering that was <b>mixed</b> with oil, the meal offering <b>shall be sacrificed. Rabbi Yehuda says: It shall not be sacrificed.</b> Therefore, the latter case must be referring to other meal offerings. Reish Lakish responded: The latter clause <b>is explaining</b> the first clause of the <i>baraita</i>, teaching that the reason one may not offer a meal offering that accompanies bulls and rams that was intermingled with the meal offering that accompanies sheep is because one may not offer a dry offering that was intermingled with one that is mixed with oil.
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>a handful whose oil</b> the priest <b>squeezed onto the wood</b> and only afterward he placed the handful on the wood to be burned, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are substances that are <b>contiguous to</b> items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar <b>considered</b> to be <b>as</b> part of the items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar, in which case the oil that was absorbed into the wood and is contiguous to the handful of the meal offering is considered part of the handful? <b>Or</b> are they <b>not considered</b> to be <b>as</b> part of the items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar, and the oil is not viewed as part of the handful, and therefore the handful is missing oil? <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: Is this not</b> the same disagreement <b>as</b> the dispute between <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish?</b>
<b>As it was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who offers up,</b> outside the Temple courtyard, <b>a limb that contains less than an olive-bulk</b> of meat, <b>but</b> the offering’s <b>bone completes</b> the measure of the offering <b>to an olive-bulk, Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> He is <b>liable,</b> and <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> He is <b>exempt.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that one is <b>liable</b> because he holds that substances that are <b>contiguous to</b> items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar are <b>considered</b> to be <b>as</b> part of the items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar. Therefore, the measure of the bone is added to the measure of the meat, resulting in a total measure of an olive-bulk, which is the measure that determines liability. <b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that one is <b>exempt</b> because he holds that substances that are <b>contiguous to</b> items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar <b>are not considered</b> to be <b>as</b> part of the items that <b>ascend</b> upon the altar. Since less than an olive-bulk of meat was sacrificed, he is not liable.
Rav Ashi responded: Rava’s <b>dilemma can be raised according to Rabbi Yoḥanan, and</b> Rava’s <b>dilemma can be raised according to Reish Lakish.</b> The circumstances in their dispute are not the same as in Rava’s dilemma, so their opinions in that case may not be applicable to this one. Rav Ashi elaborates: The <b>dilemma can be raised according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> even though he holds that the bone is considered to be part of the meat to complete the measure of an olive-bulk.
