Perhaps <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> his opinion <b>only there, in</b> the case of <b>a bone, because</b> the bone <b>is</b> the same <b>type as</b> the <b>meat,</b> i.e., it is from the same animal, and is therefore considered to be part of the sacrificial meat. <b>But</b> in <b>this</b> case of oil, <b>which is not</b> the same <b>type as</b> the <b>handful,</b> it is <b>not</b> considered to be a part of the handful even if it is contiguous to it.
<b>Or perhaps, even according to Reish Lakish, he says</b> his ruling <b>only in</b> the case of the <b>bone,</b> teaching that it does not add to the quantity of the meat. The reason is <b>that</b> the bone <b>is able to be separated</b> from the meat, <b>and if it separated,</b> there is <b>no mitzva to return it</b> to the fire. Therefore, he views it as distinct from the meat. <b>But</b> in this case of <b>oil, which is not able to be separated</b> from the handful of the meal offering, as it must be burned together with the handful, he will <b>not</b> hold that the oil is viewed as separate from the handful. <b>Or perhaps there is no difference</b> between the case of the bone and the case of the oil, and Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish would have the same opinions, respectively, in both cases. The Gemara comments: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>two meal offerings from which a handful was not removed and</b> that <b>were intermingled with each other, if</b> the priest <b>can remove a handful from this</b> meal offering <b>by itself and from that</b> meal offering <b>by itself, they are fit</b> meal offerings, <b>but if not, they are unfit,</b> as the handful of each meal offering must be taken from its original source.
In the case of <b>a handful that was intermingled with a meal offering from which a handful was not removed,</b> the priest <b>should not burn</b> the mixture on the altar. <b>And if he burned</b> it, <b>this</b> meal offering <b>from which the handful was taken satisfies the obligation of the owner and that</b> meal offering <b>from which the handful was not taken does not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b>
If, after it was removed, <b>its handful was intermingled with its remainder or with the remainder of another</b> meal offering, the priest <b>should not burn</b> the mixture on the altar, <b>but if he burned</b> it, <b>it satisfies the obligation of the owner.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> The meat of an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass</b> is <b>nullified in</b> a larger quantity of meat of <b>a slaughtered</b> animal. Although meat from a carcass generally imparts impurity, if one touches the mixture of the two meats he does not become ritually impure, as the carcass meat is considered a different type of substance from the slaughtered animal and is therefore nullified. This is not considered a mixture that comprises a substance in contact with the same type of substance, <b>because</b> meat from <b>a slaughtered</b> animal <b>cannot attain the status of a carcass,</b> and it is therefore viewed as a different type of substance.
By contrast, if meat of a slaughtered animal became intermingled with a larger quantity of meat of animal carcass, the meat of the <b>slaughtered</b> animal <b>is not nullified in</b> the larger quantity of meat of the <b>carcass, as it is possible for a carcass to attain the status of a slaughtered</b> animal with regard to the <i>halakhot</i> of ritual impurity, as it can lose its ability to transmit ritual impurity. This is <b>because when</b> a carcass <b>rots</b> to the extent that it is no longer edible, <b>it loses its impure</b> status. The <i>halakha</i> that the carcass meat has the ability to attain the ritually pure status of meat of a slaughtered animal renders the two meats as the same type of substance, and the mixture retains its status of intermingled carcass meat and meat of a slaughtered animal.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> the opposite: <b>Any</b> small quantity of an item <b>that can possibly become like</b> the item that is present in larger quantities is <b>not nullified</b> when the two are intermingled, <b>but any</b> small quantity of an item <b>that cannot possibly become like</b> the item that is present in larger quantities is <b>nullified</b> in the larger quantity. Accordingly, a small quantity of meat of a slaughtered animal is nullified in a larger quantity of unslaughtered animal carcass meat, since the meat of a slaughtered animal cannot become like the animal carcass meat; but a small quantity of animal carcass meat is not nullified in a larger quantity of meat of a slaughtered animal, since it can lose its impure status and become akin to the meat of a slaughtered animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion do Rabbi Ḥanina and Rav Ḥisda state their opinions? <b>If</b> their opinions are <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> this is difficult: <b>Didn’t</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>it is</b> in the case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar <b>that</b> the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another, but</b> otherwise, <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>nullified?</b> Therefore, in any case where meat of a slaughtered animal becomes intermingled with unslaughtered animal carcass meat, the smaller quantity is nullified in the larger quantity.
<b>If</b> their opinions are <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the blood of an offering is not nullified in the blood of a non-sacred animal because the two are the same type of substance, this is difficult: <b>But</b>

Daf 23b

<b>Rabbi Yehuda follows the appearance</b> of the item in determining whether the two items are the same type of substance. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>this</b> meat of a slaughtered animal <b>and that</b> meat of an unslaughtered carcass are viewed as <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance,</b> since their appearances are identical, and neither one nullifies the other.
<b>Rather,</b> it must be explained that the opinions of Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Ḥanina are <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥiyya. As Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> The meat of an unslaughtered <b>animal carcass and</b> the meat of <b>a slaughtered</b> animal <b>are nullified one in the other.</b> Rav Ḥisda understands this statement to mean that the meat of an animal carcass is nullified in a larger quantity of meat of a slaughtered animal, whereas Rabbi Ḥanina understands the statement to be referring to meat of a slaughtered animal that is nullified in a larger quantity of meat of an unslaughtered animal carcass.
The Gemara asks: But then <b>in accordance with whose</b> opinion did <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> himself state his opinion? <b>If</b> his opinion is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis,</b> that is difficult: <b>Didn’t</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>it is</b> in the case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar <b>that</b> the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another, but</b> in general, <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>nullified? And if</b> his statement is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda,</b> that is difficult: <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda any substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>not nullified.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> the statement of Rabbi Ḥiyya is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, and</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya holds that <b>when Rabbi Yehuda says</b> that <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>not nullified, this statement</b> applies only <b>where it is possible for one to become like</b> the other. <b>But where it is not possible for one to become like</b> the other, it is <b>nullified,</b> since the two are not considered the same substance.
<b>And</b> Rav Ḥisda and Rabbi Ḥanina <b>disagree with regard to this, as Rav Ḥisda holds</b> that <b>we follow the</b> potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, i.e., the larger quantity, and if it can attain the status of the smaller quantity, the two are considered identical substances and the smaller quantity is not nullified in the larger quantity. Therefore, if meat of a slaughtered animal became mingled with a larger quantity of meat of an animal carcass, the meat of the slaughtered animal is not nullified, as it is possible for a carcass to attain the status of a slaughtered animal with regard to ritual impurity, as when a carcass rots it loses its impure status.
<b>And Rabbi Ḥanina holds</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, i.e., the smaller quantity, and only if it can attain the status of the larger quantity, e.g., in the case of meat of an animal carcass that was intermingled with a larger quantity of meat of a slaughtered animal, the two are considered identical substances and the smaller quantity is not nullified in the larger quantity.
The Gemara offers support for the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina: <b>We learned</b> in the mishna: In the case of <b>two meal offerings from which a handful was not removed and</b> which <b>were intermingled with each other, if</b> the priest <b>can remove a handful from this</b> meal offering <b>by itself and from that</b> meal offering <b>by itself, they are fit</b> meal offerings, <b>but if not, they are unfit,</b> as the handful of each meal offering must be taken from its original source. <b>And here, once he removes a handful from one, the rest</b> of it <b>becomes</b> the <b>remainder,</b> which is designated for the priests, <b>and</b> this <b>remainder does not nullify</b> the other <b>meal offering from which a handful has not yet been removed.</b>
In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the mishna? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that is difficult: <b>Didn’t</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>it is</b> in the case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar <b>that</b> the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another, but</b> in general, <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>nullified?</b> Therefore, the remainder of the first meal offering should nullify the second meal offering, as both consist of the same substances, flour and oil. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that the meal offering is not nullified in the remainder, as any substance in contact with the same type of substance is not nullified.
Now, <b>granted, according to</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, in the mishna’s case the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance can <b>become like</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, <b>as when</b> the priest <b>removes the handful from the other</b> meal offering, the intermingled offering <b>will become a remainder</b> that is designated for the priests, just <b>like that</b> of the first meal offering. Therefore, the intermingled second meal offering is not nullified in the remainder of the first meal offering.
<b>But according to</b> Rav Ḥisda, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, <b>can</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the first meal offering <b>become a meal offering from which a handful has not yet been removed?</b> Therefore, <b>shall we say</b> that <b>according to Rav Ḥisda</b> the mishna here <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion?
The Gemara answers: <b>There,</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the mishna is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Zeira, as Rabbi Zeira says</b> that the verse teaches that nullification does not take place when remainders are intermingled with handfuls. He explains: The term <b>burning is stated with regard to</b> the <b>handful</b> removed from the meal offering (see Leviticus 2:2), as it is a mitzva to burn the handful, <b>and</b> the term <b>burning is stated with regard to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering (see Leviticus 2:11), as it is taught that it is prohibited to burn the remainder.
This verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as</b> in the case of the <b>burning that is stated with regard to</b> the <b>handful,</b> if two handfuls are mixed together <b>one handful does not nullify the other</b> and all agree that the two are burned on the altar, <b>so too,</b> in the case of the <b>burning that is stated with regard to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering, if the remainder of one offering is intermingled with another meal offering, the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering <b>does not nullify</b> the <b>handful</b> or the remainder of the second meal offering.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna here: In the case of <b>the handful that was intermingled with a meal offering from which a handful was not removed,</b> the priest <b>should not burn</b> the mixture on the altar, <b>and if he burned</b> it, <b>this</b> meal offering <b>from which the handful was taken satisfied the obligation of the owner and that</b> meal offering <b>from which the handful was not taken did not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b> This is a case of a mixture of identical substances, <b>and the meal offering from which a handful has not yet been removed does not nullify</b> the <b>handful,</b> since after the fact if the mixture is burned on the altar the meal offering from which the handful was taken satisfies the obligation of the owner.
The Gemara explains the proof: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the mishna? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that is difficult: <b>Didn’t</b> the Rabbis <b>say</b> that <b>it is</b> in the case of a mixture of items that <b>ascend</b> to the altar <b>that</b> the different components of the mixture <b>do not nullify one another, but</b> in general, <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>nullified? Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that any substance in contact with the same type of substance is not nullified.
Now, <b>granted, according to</b> Rav Ḥisda, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, in the mishna’s case the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance can <b>become like</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, <b>since every bit</b> of the meal offering <b>is fit to have the handful taken from it. And</b> therefore, the mixture <b>is</b> considered to be one that consists of <b>a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance, and a substance</b> in contact <b>with</b> the <b>same</b> type of <b>substance</b> is <b>not nullified.</b>
<b>But according to</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, <b>can</b> the <b>handful become a meal offering from which a handful has not yet been removed,</b> so that it would not be nullified by the other meal offering whose handful was not removed? Therefore, <b>shall we say that</b> according to Rabbi Ḥanina the mishna here is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> with regard to Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion? The Gemara answers: <b>This</b> mishna <b>as well</b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Zeira,</b> who explains that a Torah edict establishes that the remainder does not nullify the handful, and similarly, a meal offering from which a handful has not yet been removed does not nullify the handful.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from the mishna here: If, after it was removed, <b>its handful was intermingled with the remainder of another</b> meal offering, the priest <b>should not burn</b> the mixture on the altar, <b>and if he burned</b> it, <b>it satisfied the obligation of the owner.</b> The Gemara explains the proof: <b>But here,</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance <b>cannot become like</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, since the remainder of the meal offering cannot become like the handful, and the potentially nullified substance cannot become like the potentially nullifying substance, since the handful cannot become like the remainder of the meal offering; <b>and</b> the mishna teaches that the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering <b>does not nullify</b> the <b>handful.</b>
In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the mishna? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that is difficult: Didn’t the Rabbis say that it is in the case of a mixture of items that ascend to the altar that the different components of the mixture do not nullify one another, but in general, a substance in contact with the same type of substance is nullified? Rather, it is obvious that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, who holds that any substance in contact with the same type of substance is not nullified. But in contrast to Rabbi Ḥiyya’s statement, Rabbi Yehuda apparently holds that nullification takes place even if the nullifying substance cannot become like the nullified substance, or if the nullified substance cannot become like the nullifying substance.
<b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> This mishna is an independent <i>halakha</i>, based on a Torah edict that nullification does not take place when remainders are intermingled with handfuls. He explains: The term <b>burning is stated with regard to</b> the <b>handful</b> removed from the meal offering, <b>and</b> the term <b>burning is stated with regard to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering. This verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as</b> in the case of the <b>burning that is stated with regard to</b> the <b>handful,</b> if two handfuls are mixed together <b>one handful does not nullify the other</b> and all agree that the two are burned on the altar, <b>so too,</b> in the case of the <b>burning that is stated with regard to</b> the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering, if the remainder of one offering is intermingled with another meal offering, the <b>remainder</b> of the meal offering <b>does not nullify the handful</b> or the remainder of the second meal offering.
The Gemara suggests another proof from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Pesaḥim</i> 2:21): <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> In the case of <i>matza</i> that one <b>seasoned with black cumin, with sesame, or with any type of spice,</b> it is <b>fit</b> to be eaten during the festival of Passover, as <b>it is</b> considered <b><i>matza</i>, but it is called seasoned <i>matza</i>.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>It enters your mind</b> to explain that this is a case <b>where</b> there were <b>more spices than</b> the <b><i>matza</i></b> itself.
Now, <b>granted, according to</b> Rabbi Ḥanina, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance, in the case here the potentially <b>nullified</b> substance can <b>become like</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, <b>as when</b> the <i>matza</i> <b>becomes moldy it becomes like</b> the <b>spices,</b> as it is no longer fit to be used to fulfill the mitzva of eating <i>matza</i>. Therefore, the smaller quantity of <i>matza</i> is not nullified by the larger quantity of spices. <b>But according to</b> Rav Ḥisda, who is <b>the one who says</b> that <b>we follow</b> the potentially <b>nullifying</b> substance, <b>can</b> the <b>spices become</b> like the <b><i>matza</i>?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>What are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> there are <b>not more spices</b> than <i>matza</i>, but rather <b>the majority is <i>matza</i> and</b> therefore the <i>matza</i> is <b>not nullified.</b> The Gemara notes: According to this explanation, the language of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is also precise, as it teaches: It is</b> considered <b><i>matza</i>, but it is called seasoned <i>matza</i>. Learn from</b> here that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to an entity whose majority is <i>matza</i>, and therefore it is referred to as seasoned <i>matza</i>.
§ The Gemara relates: <b>When Rav Kahana ascended</b> from Babylonia to Eretz Yisrael, <b>he found the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya, who were sitting and saying</b> the following: In the case of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of a meal offering <b>that one divided</b>

Daf 24a

<b>and placed in a receptacle</b> such that the flour of the measure was in two places, not in contact with each other, <b>and one</b> who was ritually impure <b>who immersed that day</b> and is waiting for nightfall for the purification process to be completed <b>touched one of</b> the portions of the meal offering, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does he disqualify only the part of the meal offering that he touched, or the other part as well? <b>When we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 20b) that <b>a vessel joins</b> all the food <b>that is in it with regard to sacrificial</b> food, meaning that if some of the contents become impure all the contents become impure as well, does <b>this matter</b> apply only <b>where</b> the contents <b>are touching each other, but where</b> the contents <b>are not touching each other</b> the ritual impurity is <b>not</b> imparted to the other contents? <b>Or perhaps</b> there is <b>no difference.</b>
Rav Kahana <b>said to</b> the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya: <b>Did we learn</b> in the mishna that <b>a vessel connects</b> the contents within it? <b>We learned</b> that <b>a vessel joins</b> the contents within it, indicating that it does so in <b>any</b> case, whether or not the contents are in contact with one another. The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya then asked Rav Kahana: If one <b>inserted</b> another <b>one</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>between them,</b> and one who was ritually impure who immersed that day touched it, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are the first two half-tenths rendered impure?
Rav Kahana <b>said to them:</b> Only when an item <b>requires a vessel</b> in order for it to be sanctified, e.g., in the case of the two half-tenths of an ephah of a meal offering, does the <b>vessel join it</b> together. In the case of an item that <b>does not require a vessel,</b> such as this half-tenth that was placed between them, the <b>vessel does not join it.</b>
The sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya then asked: If <b>one who immersed that day inserted his finger between</b> the two half-tenths of the ephah that were placed in the receptacle, without touching either one, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Are the two half-tenths rendered impure? Rav Kahana <b>said to them</b> in response: The <b>only item you have that transmits impurity through its airspace</b> is <b>an earthenware vessel alone.</b>
Rav Kahana <b>himself then asked</b> the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya: If two half-tenths of an ephah of a meal offering are placed in one vessel but are not in contact with each other, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Can one <b>remove a handful from this</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>on</b> behalf of <b>that</b> half-tenth of an ephah? Is the <b>joining</b> of the contents of the vessel effective <b>by Torah law or by rabbinic law?</b> If it is effective by Torah law, then the removal of the handful is valid. If it is effective by rabbinic law, then the removal of the handful was not performed correctly, since it was not taken from the entire tenth of an ephah of the meal offering.
<b>They said to</b> Rav Kahana: <b>We did not hear</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>this</b> case explicitly, but <b>we heard</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a case <b>similar to this. As we learned</b> in the mishna: In the case of <b>two meal offerings from which a handful was not removed and</b> which <b>were intermingled with each other, if</b> the priest <b>can remove a handful from this</b> meal offering <b>by itself and from that</b> meal offering <b>by itself, they are fit</b> meal offerings, <b>but if not, they are unfit,</b> as the handful of each meal offering must be taken from its original source.
They explain: <b>In any event,</b> the mishna teaches that in a case <b>when he can remove a handful</b> from each meal offering, the meal offerings <b>are fit. Why</b> is this considered a valid removal of the handful? <b>But this</b> part of the meal offering <b>that is intermingled</b> with the other meal offering <b>does not touch</b> the part of the meal offering from which the handful is removed. Evidently, the vessel joins the different parts of the meal offering together, and one can remove the handful from any part of its contents, even if they are not touching.
<b>Rava said:</b> This cannot be inferred from the mishna, as <b>perhaps</b> the ruling of the mishna is stated <b>with regard to</b> a case where the <b>clumps</b> of the meal offering <b>are divided like</b> the teeth of <b>a comb,</b> so that although the handful is removed from a clump of the meal offering that is separate from the clump that is intermingled with the other offering, all parts of the meal offering are still in contact with one another. It may still be that in the case presented by Rav Kahana, where the parts are truly separated from one another, it is possible that one cannot remove the handful from one part on behalf of the other.
The Gemara asks: Since this question was not resolved, <b>what</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter? <b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And he shall take up from it</b> his handful” (Leviticus 6:8), meaning that he shall take the handful <b>from</b> the meal offering <b>that is connected.</b> This teaches <b>that one shall not bring a tenth</b> of an ephah divided <b>in two vessels and remove the handful</b> from one on behalf of the other. It can therefore be inferred that <b>in</b> the case of <b>one vessel</b> that is <b>similar to two vessels,</b> as the entirety of the meal offering is brought in one vessel although the different parts are not touching, one may <b>remove the handful</b> from one part on behalf of the other part.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: <b>Perhaps</b> one could say: <b>What are the circumstances</b> when the <i>baraita</i> states that one may not bring a tenth of an ephah in <b>two vessels?</b> The circumstances are, <b>for example,</b> if one hollowed out the area of a smaller <b><i>kefiza</i></b> measure <b>within</b> the area of a larger <b><i>kav</i></b> measure, so that within the one receptacle there were two cavities divided by a partition that did not reach the top of the receptacle. In this case, <b>even though</b> the two <b>are intermingled on top,</b> above the partition, <b>since the partition of the <i>kefiza</i></b> measure <b>divides</b> them <b>below,</b> they are still separated and not joined together.
Abaye continues: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>one vessel</b> that is <b>similar to two vessels,</b> with regard to which you inferred that one may remove the handful from one part on behalf of the other part? The circumstances are, <b>for example, a hen trough</b> that is filled with water or fodder, <b>and even though a partition divides</b> the top of the trough, the contents are <b>touching</b> below. <b>But here,</b> in the case of two half-tenths of an ephah that are placed in a receptacle <b>that are not touching</b> each other <b>at all, you should raise the dilemma</b> as to whether the handful may be removed from one part on behalf of the other.
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma:</b> In a scenario where <b>a vessel joins</b> the two half-tenths of an ephah that are inside the vessel but not touching, <b>and</b> there is <b>a connection</b> by means of <b>water</b> between one of the half-tenths of the ephah inside the vessel and another half-tenth of an ephah that is outside the vessel, and one who immersed that day touched the other half-tenth of an ephah that is inside the vessel, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Does he also disqualify the half-tenth of an ephah that is outside the vessel?
<b>When we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 20b) that <b>a vessel joins</b> all the food <b>that is in it with regard to sacrificial</b> food, meaning that if some of the contents become impure all the contents become impure as well, does <b>this matter</b> apply only to <b>that</b> which is <b>inside</b> the vessel, <b>but not</b> to <b>that</b> which is <b>outside</b> of it, despite the fact that the outer item is connected to an item inside the vessel? <b>Or perhaps, since</b> the half-tenth of an ephah found outside the vessel <b>is connected</b> to an impure item, it <b>is connected</b> and becomes impure.
Rabbi Yirmeya continues: <b>And if you say</b> that <b>since</b> the half-tenth of an ephah found outside the vessel <b>is connected</b> to an impure item, it <b>is connected</b> and becomes impure, one can raise another dilemma. In a case where there is <b>a connection</b> by means of <b>water</b> between a half-tenth of an ephah outside a vessel and another half-tenth of an ephah that is inside the vessel, <b>and</b> the <b>vessel joins</b> two half-tenths of an ephah that are inside the vessel, <b>and one who immersed that day touched</b> the half-tenth of an ephah <b>that is outside</b> the vessel, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>?
<b>When we learned</b> in a mishna that <b>a vessel joins</b> all the food that is in it with regard to sacrificial food, meaning that if some of the contents become impure all the contents become impure as well, does <b>this matter</b> apply only in a case <b>where</b> the one who immersed that day <b>touched</b> that <b>which is inside</b> the vessel, thereby transmitting impurity to all of the contents of the vessel, and due to the connection by means of water the impurity is then transmitted to that which is outside the vessel, <b>but</b> it does <b>not</b> apply in a case <b>where</b> the one who immersed that day touched that <b>which is outside</b> of the vessel, and only the half-tenth of an ephah that is connected to the outer item becomes impure? <b>Or perhaps</b> this case <b>is no different,</b> and the vessel joins all of its contents with regard to ritual impurity. The Gemara comments: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ It has been demonstrated that a vessel joins the contents that are found in it, even if they are not touching one another, with regard to ritual impurity, such that if some of the contents become impure, all of the contents are rendered impure. <b>Rava raised a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of a meal offering <b>that one divided</b> and then placed the two halves in different vessels, <b>and one of them became impure and</b> afterward <b>he placed it in a receptacle</b> along with the second half-tenth of an ephah, <b>and then one who immersed that day touched that one</b> that was already rendered <b>impure, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Do we say</b> that the item is already <b>saturated with impurity</b> and cannot be rendered impure a second time, and therefore the second half-tenth of the ephah is not rendered impure even though it is joined in the same receptacle, <b>or not?</b>
<b>Abaye said to him: And do we say</b> that an item that is already <b>saturated with impurity</b> cannot be rendered impure a second time? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 27:9): With regard to <b>a sheet</b> that is impure due to <b>ritual impurity</b>

Daf 24b

imparted by <b>treading,</b> e.g., if a man who experiences a gonorrhea-like discharge [<i>zav</i>] lay down on it and transferred to it this severe impurity, <b>and</b> afterward <b>one made a curtain [<i>villon</i>] of it,</b> it is <b>pure</b> with regard to ritual impurity <b>imparted by treading,</b> as it is no longer fit for sitting or lying down. <b>But</b> it is <b>impure</b> due to having been in <b>contact</b> with an item that became ritually impure with impurity imparted by <b>treading,</b> as it is viewed as having been in contact with itself, and therefore it can impart impurity to food and drink.
The mishna continues: <b>Rabbi Yosei said: What</b> source of impurity imparted by <b>treading did this</b> curtain <b>touch? Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is <b>that if a <i>zav</i> touched</b> the sheet itself before it was made into a curtain, and did not only lie on it without touching it directly, then although the curtain is pure with regard to ritual impurity imparted by treading, it is nevertheless <b>impure</b> due to <b>contact</b> with <b>a <i>zav</i>.</b> This is because the impurity transmitted by contact with a <i>zav</i> applies in the case of a curtain, which is not the <i>halakha</i> with regard to impurity imparted by treading.
Abaye comments: <b>When a <i>zav</i> touched</b> the sheet, <b>in any event</b> it was rendered <b>impure, even</b> if he touched it <b>after</b> he lay on the sheet, thereby rendering it impure with impurity imparted by treading. In this manner, it was rendered impure with the <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading, and afterward</b> it was again rendered impure due to <b>contact</b> with <b>a <i>zav</i>.</b> According to the statement of Rava, <b>why</b> would this be the <i>halakha</i>? <b>Let us say</b> that the item is already <b>saturated with impurity</b> and cannot be rendered impure a second time.
Rava <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>And from where</b> do you know <b>that this</b> statement of Rabbi Yosei: <b>That if a <i>zav</i> touched</b> the sheet it is nevertheless impure due to contact with a <i>zav</i>, is referring <b>to</b> a case where a <i>zav</i> touched the sheet <b>after</b> it was rendered impure with the ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading? Perhaps</b> he was referring to a case where a <i>zav</i> touched the sheet, rendering it impure due to contact with a <i>zav</i>, <b>before</b> he lay on it and rendered it impure with the ritual impurity imparted by <b>treading.</b> In that case, the <b>severe</b> form of ritual <b>impurity</b> imparted by the treading of the <i>zav</i>, which is a primary source of ritual impurity that imparts impurity to all people and items, <b>takes effect in addition to</b> the <b>lesser</b> form of <b>impurity</b> imparted by contact with a <i>zav</i>, which imparts impurity only to food and drink.
<b>But here,</b> in the case of part of a meal offering that was touched by one who immersed that day after having already become impure due to the touch of one who immersed that day, <b>where</b> both <b>this and that</b> are <b>lesser</b> forms of <b>impurity,</b> perhaps the impurity does <b>not</b> take effect a second time, as it is already impure.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Rather,</b> the proof against the existence of a principle that an item can be saturated with impurity and not susceptible to becoming impure a second time is <b>from the last clause</b> of a <i>baraita</i> that corresponds to the mishna: <b>Rabbi Yosei concedes that in</b> a case of <b>two sheets that are folded and placed on</b> top of <b>one another, and a <i>zav</i> sat upon them, the top</b> sheet is rendered impure with the <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading, and the bottom</b> sheet is rendered impure with the <b>ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b>treading and</b> due to <b>contact</b> with the top sheet that has become ritually impure with impurity imparted by <b>treading.</b> The Gemara explains: <b>But</b> according to the opinion advanced in Rava’s dilemma, <b>why</b> would this be the case? <b>Let us say</b> that the bottom sheet is already <b>saturated with impurity</b> and cannot be rendered impure a second time.
The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>There,</b> with regard to the bottom sheet, the two types of impurity take effect <b>simultaneously,</b> whereas <b>here,</b> with regard to the impure meal offering, the two forms of impurity take effect <b>one after the other.</b> It is only in the latter case that Rava suggests that the second type of impurity does not take effect. Therefore, there is no conclusive proof, and the question raised by Rava remains unresolved.
§ <b>Rava says:</b> In a case where one <b>divided a tenth</b> of an ephah of a meal offering into two halves, <b>and one</b> half was <b>lost and he separated another</b> half <b>in its stead, and</b> afterward <b>the first</b> lost half <b>was found, and all three are placed in a receptacle</b> together, if the one that had been <b>lost became impure, the</b> previously <b>lost</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>and</b> the <b>first</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>join together</b> and become impure, in accordance with the mishna cited earlier (<i>Ḥagiga</i> 20b) that a vessel joins the two together with regard to ritual impurity. But the half-tenth of an ephah that was <b>separated</b> to replace the lost half-tenth <b>does not join together</b> with the other half-tenths, and it remains pure.
If the one that had been <b>separated</b> to replace the lost half-tenth <b>became impure,</b> then the <b>separated</b> half-tenth <b>and</b> the <b>first</b> half-tenth <b>join together</b> and become impure, since the former was separated in order to complete the tenth together with the first half-tenth, while the previously <b>lost</b> half-tenth <b>does not join together</b> with them. If the <b>first</b> half-tenth <b>became impure,</b> then <b>both</b> the previously lost half-tenth as well as the half-tenth that was separated as its replacement <b>join together</b> and become ritually impure, as each of them had at one point been part of the same tenth as the first half-tenth.
<b>Abaye says: Even if</b> any <b>one of</b> the half-tenths <b>became impure, both</b> remaining half-tenths <b>join together</b> and become impure as well. <b>What is the reason? They are all residents of one cabin,</b> i.e., they were meant to be part of the same meal offering.
<b>And similarly,</b> according to Rava, <b>with regard to the removal of the handful,</b> if one <b>removed the handful from</b> the previously <b>lost</b> half-tenth, <b>its remainder and</b> the remainder of the <b>first</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>are eaten</b> by the priests, while the half-tenth of an ephah that was <b>separated</b> in its stead <b>is not eaten.</b> Since it was not meant to join together with this other half-tenth, the removal of the handful does not permit its consumption. If one <b>removed the handful from</b> the one that had been <b>separated</b> in place of the lost half-tenth, then <b>its remainder and</b> the <b>first</b> half-tenth of an ephah <b>are eaten,</b> while the previously <b>lost</b> half-tenth <b>is not eaten.</b>
If one <b>removed the handful from</b> the <b>first</b> half-tenth, then <b>both</b> the previously lost half-tenth as well as the half-tenth that had been separated in its stead <b>are not eaten.</b> This is because the removal of the handful allows the remainder of only one tenth to be eaten, and it is not known whether the consumption of the previously lost half-tenth or the replacement half-tenth has now been permitted.
<b>Abaye says: Even if</b> one <b>removed the handful from</b> any <b>one of them, both</b> remaining half-tenths <b>are not eaten. What is the reason? They are all residents of one cabin,</b> and it is not possible to know whether the consumption of one or of the other has been permitted.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this</b> ruling of Abaye: <b>And</b> is that to say that <b>in any event</b> the <b>remainder of</b> the half-tenth itself from which the handful was taken <b>is eaten? But one-sixth [<i>danka</i>] of</b> the <b>handful</b> that was removed <b>was not sacrificed</b> to permit this remainder. The handful was removed to permit the consumption of the remainders of all three half-tenths of an ephah in the receptacle. Since the handful included one-third that was removed to account for the half-tenth that is not needed, it turns out that each of the two actual half-tenths should have had an additional one-sixth removed to render them permitted.
<b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Mesharshiyya,</b> also <b>objects to this</b> ruling of Abaye: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the handful itself, how can it be sacrificed? But one-third</b> of it, i.e., the portion separated to permit the extraneous half-tenth of an ephah, <b>is non-sacred.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> These questions present no difficulty, since with regard to the removal of the <b>handful, the matter is dependent on the intention of</b> the <b>priest. And when</b> the <b>priest removes the handful, he removes it to</b> permit the remainder of <b>the tenth</b> of an ephah, and not the remainder of the extraneous half-tenth. Still, the other two halves may not be eaten because it is not possible to know whether the consumption of one or of the other has been permitted.

Daf 25a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>the handful became ritually impure and</b> despite this the priest <b>sacrificed it, the frontplate</b> worn by the High Priest <b>effects acceptance</b> of the meal offering, and the remainder is eaten by the priests. If the handful <b>left</b> its designated area <b>and</b> despite this the priest then <b>sacrificed it, the frontplate does not effect acceptance.</b> The reason is <b>that the frontplate effects acceptance for</b> offerings sacrificed when <b>ritually impure and does not effect acceptance for</b> offerings <b>that leave</b> their designated areas.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is written with regard to the frontplate: “And it shall be upon Aaron’s forehead, <b>and Aaron shall bear the sin committed with the sacred items,</b> which the children of Israel shall hallow, even all their sacred gifts; and it shall be always upon his forehead, that they may be accepted before the Lord” (Exodus 28:38). The Sages expounded: <b>But which sin does he bear? If you say</b> he atones for <b>the sin of <i>piggul</i>,</b> it <b>is already stated: “It shall not be credited</b> to him” (Leviticus 7:18). <b>If you say</b> he atones for <b>the sin of <i>notar</i>,</b> it <b>is already stated</b> in the same verse: <b>“It shall not be accepted.”</b>
Evidently, the High Priest wearing the frontplate <b>bears only the sin of impurity</b> in the offering of an individual. The frontplate is understood to atone for the sin of sacrificing an impure offering, <b>as its general prohibition was permitted</b> in certain circumstances, specifically <b>in</b> the case of the <b>community,</b> since in a situation where the entire community is impure it is permitted to sacrifice impure communal offerings <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>Rabbi Zeira objects to this:</b> Why not <b>say</b> that the frontplate atones for the <b>sin</b> of sacrificing offerings that <b>leave</b> the courtyard and are thereby disqualified, <b>as its general prohibition was permitted</b> in certain circumstances, specifically <b>in</b> the case of an offering sacrificed on a private <b>altar</b> during the period after the Jewish people had entered Eretz Yisrael and before there was an established location for the Tabernacle?
<b>Abaye said to him: The verse states</b> with regard to the frontplate: “And it shall be always upon his forehead, <b>that they may be accepted before the Lord”</b> (Exodus 28:38), teaching that in the case of <b>a sin</b> whose general prohibition is permitted <b>before the Lord,</b> i.e., in the Temple, <b>yes,</b> the frontplate atones for it. But in the case of the <b>sin</b> of offerings <b>that leave</b> the courtyard, whose general prohibition is not permitted before the Lord, the frontplate does <b>not</b> atone for it.
<b>Rabbi Ile’a objects to this:</b> Why not <b>say</b> that the frontplate atones for the <b>sin</b> of performing the service using one’s <b>left</b> hand instead of one’s right, <b>as its general prohibition was permitted</b> in certain circumstances, specifically <b>in</b> the case of <b>Yom Kippur,</b> when the High Priest carries the spoon bearing the incense into the Holy of Holies with his left hand?
<b>Abaye said to him: The verse states:</b> “And Aaron shall bear <b>the sin</b> committed with the sacred items” (Exodus 28:38), to say that the frontplate atones for <b>a sin that was</b> committed <b>with</b> the offering <b>and I deferred it.</b> This serves <b>to exclude</b> the spoon bearing the incense of <b>Yom Kippur,</b> where there is no sin that was deferred, <b>since its proper</b> performance <b>is</b> for the High Priest to hold it <b>with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, as he must hold both the coal pan and the spoon of incense.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The frontplate does not atone for the sin of sacrificing an offering with the left hand for a different reason: The verse states: “And Aaron shall bear <b>the sin committed with the sacred items [<i>hakodashim</i>],”</b> demonstrating that the frontplate atones for a sin inherent in the offering itself, <b>and not</b> for <b>a sin</b> committed by <b>those who bring the offering [<i>hamakdishin</i>].</b>
<b>Rav Sima, son of Rav Idi, said to Rav Ashi; and some say</b> that it was <b>Rav Sima, son of Rav Ashi,</b> who said <b>to Rav Ashi: But</b> why not <b>say</b> that the frontplate atones for <b>the sin of a blemished animal</b> that is sacrificed, <b>as its general prohibition was permitted</b> in certain circumstances, specifically <b>in</b> the case of <b>birds? As the Master says:</b> The <i>halakha</i> that an offering must be <b>unblemished and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a burnt offering must be <b>male</b> are taught <b>with regard to animal</b> offerings, <b>but</b> there is <b>no</b> requirement that an offering must be <b>unblemished and male with regard to birds.</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to him: With regard to your</b> claim, <b>the verse states</b> about blemished animals: <b>“It shall not be accepted”</b> (Leviticus 22:23), and: “But whatsoever has a blemish that you shall not bring; <b>for it shall not be acceptable for you”</b> (Leviticus 22:20), teaching that in no case are blemished animals accepted as offerings, even due to the frontplate.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>blood</b> of an offering <b>that became impure and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it</b> on the altar, if he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the offering is <b>accepted</b> and effects atonement for the owner of the offering. If he sprinkled the blood <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>not accepted. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said? In</b> the case of the offering of <b>an individual. But in</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering, <b>whether</b> he sprinkled the blood <b>unwittingly</b> or <b>whether</b> he did so <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>accepted. And in</b> the case of an offering of <b>a gentile</b> where the blood of the offering became impure, <b>whether</b> the priest sprinkled the blood <b>unwittingly</b> or <b>whether</b> he did so <b>intentionally, whether</b> he did so <b>due to circumstances beyond his control</b> or <b>whether</b> he did so <b>willingly,</b>

Daf 25b

the offering is <b>not accepted,</b> as the verse states with regard to the frontplate: “That it may be accepted for them before the Lord” (Exodus 28:38), with the term “for them” teaching that this applies only for Jews, not for gentiles.
<b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>For what does the frontplate</b> worn by the High Priest <b>effect acceptance?</b> It effects acceptance <b>for the blood, for the flesh, and for the fat</b> of an offering <b>that became impure</b> in the Temple, <b>whether</b> they were rendered impure <b>unwittingly or intentionally, whether due to circumstances beyond one’s control or willfully, whether in</b> the case of the offering of <b>an individual or in</b> the case of <b>a communal</b> offering. In contrast to the statement of the previous <i>baraita</i>, this <i>baraita</i> teaches that the frontplate does effect acceptance in the case of an individual offering for blood that became impure and was sprinkled intentionally.
<b>Rav Yosef said:</b> This is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that the frontplate effects acceptance for impure blood of an individual offering that was sprinkled intentionally, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei,</b> whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that the frontplate does not effect acceptance, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not separate <i>teruma</i> from ritually impure</b> produce <b>for ritually pure</b> produce. <b>And if he separated <i>teruma</i></b> from impure produce <b>unwittingly, his <i>teruma</i> is</b> considered <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> but if he did so <b>intentionally,</b> the Sages penalize him and <b>his <i>teruma</i> is not <i>teruma</i>. Rabbi Yosei says: Whether</b> he did so <b>unwittingly or intentionally, his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>.</b> Like the ruling found in the second <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Yosei does not distinguish between a case where one acted unwittingly and where one acted intentionally.
The Gemara objects to the comparison: You can <b>say that you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> holds <b>that</b> the Sages <b>do not penalize</b> him. <b>Did you hear him</b> say, as the <i>baraita</i> teaches, <b>that</b> the <b>frontplate effects acceptance for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The frontplate effects acceptance for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yosei says: The frontplate does not effect acceptance for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Reverse</b> the opinions, so that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The frontplate does not effect acceptance for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yosei says: The frontplate does effect acceptance for</b> the impurity of portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet objects to this: And are you able to reverse</b> the opinions and say that according to Rabbi Eliezer the frontplate does not effect acceptance for the impurity of portions that are to be eaten? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that</b> one who partakes of <b>impure sacrificial meat,</b> i.e., one who partakes of the meat while in a state of ritual impurity, <b>before the sprinkling of the blood</b> takes place, is <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b>
To counter this, <b>the verse states: “Every one that is ritually pure may eat of it”</b> (Leviticus 7:19), and immediately afterward the verse states: <b>“But the soul that eats of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings, that belong to the Lord, having his impurity upon him,</b> that soul <b>shall be cut off</b> from his people” (Leviticus 7:20). The juxtaposition of these verses teaches that if one who is impure partakes of <b>that which has become permitted to those who are ritually pure,</b> he is <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>But</b> if one who is impure partakes of <b>that which is not permitted to those who are pure,</b> he is <b>not liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure.</b> Since it is not permitted to eat the sacrificial meat before the sprinkling of the blood, one who partakes of it at that point is not liable to receive <i>karet</i> for eating it while ritually impure.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>is</b> the verse teaching <b>only</b> that if one who is impure partakes of that which <b>is eaten by those who are ritually pure,</b> he is <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure; but</b> in a case <b>where</b> he partakes of <b>that which is not eaten by those who are ritually pure,</b> he is <b>not liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure</b> despite the fact that its blood has already been sprinkled? <b>I would</b> then <b>exclude</b> sacrificial meat <b>that</b> was <b>left overnight and</b> meat <b>that leaves</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>which are not</b> permitted to be <b>eaten by those who are ritually pure,</b> and I would derive that one who is impure who partakes of them is not liable for eating them.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “That belong to the Lord,”</b> which teaches that the verse <b>included</b> leftover meat and meat that leaves the Temple courtyard in the prohibition, and one who partakes of them while impure is liable for partaking of them.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I include</b> in the prohibition <b>the</b> meat that was rendered <b><i>piggul</i></b> through one’s intention of consuming it after its designated time <b>and the</b> meat that was rendered <b><i>notar</i>.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> interjects: <b>Isn’t <i>notar</i></b> identical to meat that was <b>left overnight,</b> and it has already been established that one is liable for partaking of leftover meat while in an impure state? <b>Rather,</b> what is meant is as follows: One might have thought to include in the prohibition <b>even the</b> meats that were rendered <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> just <b>as <i>notar</i></b> is included. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Of the meat of the sacrifice of peace offerings,”</b> and the term “of the meat” <b>excluded</b> one who is impure who partakes of <i>piggul</i>.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>And what did you see to include these,</b> i.e., leftover meat and meat that leaves the courtyard, <b>and to exclude those,</b> i.e., <i>piggul</i>? It answers: <b>After the verse included</b> some offerings <b>and excluded</b> others, <b>you</b> should <b>say</b> the following: <b>I include these,</b> the leftover meat and the meat that leaves the Temple courtyard, <b>as they had a period of fitness</b> after their blood was sprinkled, before they were rendered unfit by being left over or by leaving the Temple courtyard. <b>And I exclude those,</b> <i>piggul</i>, <b>as they never had a period of fitness,</b> as they were already unfit when the blood was sprinkled.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>And if you say</b> that if that is the case, then with regard to sacrificial <b>meat that became impure before the sprinkling of the blood, and</b> one who was impure <b>ate it after the sprinkling of the blood, for what</b> reason is he <b>liable for</b> eating <b>it due to</b> violation of the prohibition against partaking of the meat while <b>ritually impure</b> if it never had a period of fitness? The answer is that he is liable <b>because the frontplate effects acceptance</b> and the sprinkling is valid.
It arises from this <i>baraita</i> that if the offering <b>became impure,</b> then <b>yes,</b> the frontplate effects acceptance; but in the case of sacrificial meat that <b>leaves</b> the Temple courtyard, the frontplate <b>does not</b> effect acceptance, and therefore it was never considered to have a period of fitness.
Rav Sheshet now states his question: <b>Who did you hear who says</b> that the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood is <b>not effective</b> in the case of sacrificial meat that <b>leaves</b> the Temple courtyard? This is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> as seen in tractate <i>Me’ila</i> (6b), <b>and</b> yet although this <i>baraita</i> is then clearly in accordance with his opinion, it <b>teaches that</b> the <b>frontplate effects acceptance for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten.</b> Therefore, this too is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer, and the opinions in the <i>baraita</i> cited above should not be reversed.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is <b>not difficult. This</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that the frontplate effects acceptance for the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be eaten, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> whereas <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i>, which teaches that the frontplate does not effect acceptance, is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b>
The Gemara asks: You can <b>say that you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> holds <b>that</b> the <b>frontplate effects acceptance for</b> the impurity of the portions of offerings that are to be <b>eaten,</b> but <b>did you hear him</b> say <b>that</b> the Sages <b>did not penalize</b> one who acted willfully? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes. Just as you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei</b> holds with regard to <i>teruma</i> that one who separated impure produce on behalf of pure produce is not penalized, <b>you heard</b> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> holds the same. This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: Whether</b> one acted <b>unwittingly or intentionally, his <i>teruma</i> is <i>teruma</i>.</b>
The Gemara objects: You can <b>say that you heard Rabbi Eliezer</b> state this <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to <i>teruma</i>, which</b> is <b>lenient,</b> but <b>did you hear him</b> say this <b>with regard to consecrated</b> items, <b>which</b> are more <b>severe?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it is <b>so</b> that Rabbi Eliezer does not hold the same opinion with regard to consecrated items, <b>to whom will you attribute this</b> <i>baraita</i> that rules that the Sages did not penalize one who acted willfully? Rather, it must be that this is the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer.
<b>Ravina said</b> that the contradiction between the two <i>baraitot</i> should be resolved as follows: With regard to the circumstances of the contraction of <b>its ritual impurity,</b> regardless of whether the blood was rendered impure <b>unwittingly or intentionally,</b> the frontplate effects acceptance for the impurity and the offering is <b>accepted,</b> as the second <i>baraita</i> teaches. By contrast, with regard to <b>the sprinkling of</b> the blood, if it was <b>unwittingly</b> sprinkled after becoming ritually impure, meaning that the priest was unaware that it was impure, then the offering is <b>accepted,</b> but if it was <b>intentionally</b> sprinkled after becoming impure, it is <b>not accepted,</b> as the first <i>baraita</i> teaches.
<b>And Rabbi Sheila said</b> the opposite resolution: With regard to <b>the sprinkling of</b> the blood, <b>whether</b> it was performed <b>unwittingly or intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>accepted.</b> By contrast, with regard to the circumstances of the contraction of <b>its ritual impurity,</b> if it was rendered impure <b>unwittingly</b> the offering is <b>accepted,</b> and if it was rendered impure <b>intentionally</b> it is <b>not accepted.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>And according to Rav Sheila,</b> concerning that <b>which is taught</b> in the second <i>baraita</i>, that the frontplate effects acceptance for blood <b>that was rendered impure</b> regardless of <b>whether</b> it happened <b>unwittingly or intentionally, this</b> is what <b>it is saying:</b> If the blood <b>was rendered impure unwittingly and one sprinkled</b> its blood, <b>whether</b> it was sprinkled <b>unwittingly or intentionally,</b> it is accepted.

Daf 26a

The Gemara suggests a refutation of Rav Sheila’s opinion based on the first <i>baraita</i>: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> In the case of <b>blood</b> of an offering <b>that became impure and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it</b> on the altar, if he did so <b>unwittingly,</b> the offering is <b>accepted</b> and achieves atonement for the owner of the offering. If he sprinkled the blood <b>intentionally,</b> the offering is <b>not accepted.</b> This contradicts Rav Sheila’s statement that even if the priest sprinkled the blood intentionally, it is accepted. The Gemara rejects this proof: According to Rav Sheila, <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> In the case of <b>blood that became impure and</b> a priest <b>sprinkled it, whether</b> it was sprinkled <b>unwittingly or intentionally,</b> if it was <b>rendered impure unwittingly</b> it is <b>accepted,</b> but if it was rendered impure <b>intentionally</b> then it is <b>not accepted.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If after the handful was removed <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>became ritually impure,</b> or if <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>was burned,</b> or if <b>the remainder of</b> the meal offering <b>was lost, according to the principle of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who says that with regard to an animal offering the blood is fit for sprinkling even if there is no meat that can be eaten, the meal offering is <b>fit,</b> and the priest burns the handful. <b>But according to the principle of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who says that with regard to an animal offering the blood is fit for sprinkling only if there is meat that can be eaten, it is <b>unfit</b> and the priest does not burn the handful, as the handful serves to render permitted the remainder.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the mishna’s statement that according to Rabbi Yehoshua the meal offering is unfit if its remainder is rendered impure, <b>Rav says: And this</b> is the <i>halakha</i> only <b>when all of its remainder became impure. But</b> if only <b>a part of its remainder</b> became impure, the meal offering is <b>not</b> unfit.
The Gemara comments: It <b>enters your mind</b> that Rav holds that only if a part of the remainder <b>became impure,</b> then <b>yes,</b> the meal offering is fit; but if part of the remainder <b>was lost or burned,</b> then the meal offering is <b>not</b> fit. The Gemara asks: <b>What does</b> Rav <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>what remains is significant,</b> so that even if a portion of the remainder cannot be eaten the handful is still sacrificed to render the rest permitted, then why would this not also be the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if part of the remainder <b>was lost or burned?</b> Alternatively, <b>if he holds</b> that <b>what remains is not significant,</b> and the Gemara interjects: <b>And</b> accordingly, <b>what is the reason</b> that the handful is sacrificed if a part of the remainder <b>became impure?</b> It is <b>because</b> the <b>frontplate effects acceptance</b> for the impurity; <b>if that is so,</b> then <b>even</b> if <b>all of the remainder</b> became impure, the handful should still be sacrificed.
The Gemara explains: <b>Actually, he holds</b> that <b>what remains is significant, and</b> just as when a part of the remainder <b>became impure</b> but the offering is still fit, the rest of the remainder is sacrificed, <b>the same is true</b> with regard <b>to</b> a case where a part of the remainder <b>was lost or burned. And</b> the reason <b>that he stated</b> this <i>halakha</i> specifically in a case where it <b>became impure</b> is that <b>he employed</b> the terminology of <b>the beginning of</b> the mishna, which discusses a case where the remainder became impure.
Rava’s statement accords with the opinion of Rabbi Yehoshua, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> With regard to <b>all the offerings in the Torah from which there remains an olive-bulk of meat</b> that is fit to be eaten <b>or an olive-bulk of fat</b> that is fit to be sacrificed on the altar, the priest <b>sprinkles the blood.</b> Similarly, if a part of the remainder can be eaten the handful is still sacrificed, as the status of the remainder relative to the handful corresponds to the status of the meat relative to the blood.
The Gemara cites the continuation of the <i>baraita</i>: If all that remains is <b>half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of fat,</b> the priest <b>does not sprinkle the blood.</b> This is because the half olive-bulk of meat and the half olive-bulk of fat do not combine to form one olive-bulk, since the former is eaten and the latter is sacrificed on the altar. <b>And with regard to a burnt offering, even</b> if all that was left was <b>half an olive-bulk of meat and half an olive-bulk of fat,</b> the priest <b>sprinkles the blood, because it is consumed</b> on the altar <b>in its entirety.</b> Since both the meat and the fat are sacrificed on the altar, they combine to form one olive-bulk. <b>And with regard to a meal offering, although all of it remains</b> pure, the priest <b>shall not sprinkle</b> the blood.
The Gemara questions the last ruling of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is</b> the mention of <b>a meal offering doing</b> here? The discussion is about sprinkling blood, which is not relevant in the case of a meal offering. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The meal offering mentioned is <b>the meal offering</b> that accompanies the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings. It could <b>enter your mind</b> to say: <b>Since</b> this meal offering <b>accompanies</b> the animal <b>offering,</b> it is <b>comparable to the offering itself,</b> and therefore if the offering became impure but the meal offering remained pure, the blood of the offering is sprinkled due to the remaining meal offering. To counter this, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this is not the <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara returns to its discussion of the <i>halakha</i> that if only an olive-bulk of the fat remains, the priest sprinkles the blood of the offering. <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says in the name of Rabbi Yishmael, and</b> there are those who <b>determined</b> that <b>it</b> was stated <b>in the name of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Ḥananya: The verse states:</b> “And the priest shall sprinkle the blood against the altar of the Lord at the door of the Tent of Meeting, <b>and he shall make the fat smoke for a pleasing aroma to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 17:6). This verse never mentions the meat, but only the <b>fat,</b> indicating that the blood is sprinkled <b>even if there is no</b> ritually pure <b>meat,</b> but only fat.
The Gemara asks: <b>And we found</b> a source for the <i>halakha</i> that the priest sprinkles the blood if only <b>fat</b> remains. <b>From where do we</b> derive that the priest sprinkles the blood if all that is left is the <b>lobe</b> of the liver <b>or</b> the <b>two kidneys,</b> which are also sacrificed on the altar? The Gemara answers: The <i>halakha</i> that the priest sprinkles the blood in that case is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is taught</b> at the end of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And with regard to a meal offering, although all of it remains</b> pure, the priest <b>shall not sprinkle</b> the blood. This teaches that <b>it is</b> in the case of <b>a meal offering that</b> the priest <b>shall not sprinkle</b> the blood, as the meal offering is not part of the animal; <b>but</b> if the <b>lobe</b> of the liver <b>or</b> the <b>two kidneys</b> remain, the priest <b>sprinkles</b> the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan himself says:</b> The verse states: <b>“For a pleasing aroma</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 17:6). This teaches that the blood is sprinkled whenever <b>anything that you offer up</b> on the altar <b>for a pleasing aroma</b> remains. This includes anything burned on the altar.
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> it <b>was necessary to write “fat”</b> in that verse, <b>and</b> it <b>was necessary to write “for a pleasing aroma.” As, if</b> the Merciful One <b>had written</b> only <b>“fat,” I would say</b> that if <b>fat</b> remains, <b>yes,</b> the priest sprinkles the blood, but if only the <b>lobe</b> of the liver <b>or</b> the <b>two kidneys</b> remain, since they are not as significant as the fat, the blood is <b>not</b> sprinkled. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One wrote “for a pleasing aroma.” And if the Merciful One had written</b> only <b>“for a pleasing aroma,” I would say</b> that it includes <b>even a meal offering</b> brought with the libations that accompany animal offerings. Therefore, <b>the Merciful One wrote “fat,”</b> to teach that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to sacrificial parts of the animal, but not to accompanying libations and meal offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> A handful of a meal offering <b>that was not</b> sanctified <b>in a service vessel</b> is <b>unfit, and Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>fit.</b> If the priest <b>burned the handful of</b> a meal offering <b>twice,</b> i.e., in two increments, it is <b>fit.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, says: What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon? The verse states</b> with regard to a meal offering: <b>“It is most holy, as the sin offering, and as the guilt offering”</b> (Leviticus 6:10). Rabbi Shimon derives from here that the handful of the meal offering may be placed on the altar in the manner of the blood of either a sin offering or a guilt offering. If a priest <b>comes to perform the</b> sacrificial <b>rites of</b> a meal offering <b>with</b> his <b>hand, as</b> one performs the sprinkling of the blood of <b>a sin offering,</b> which is performed with the priest’s right index finger, <b>he must perform its rites with</b> his <b>right</b> hand, <b>like the sin offering.</b> If he performs the sacrificial rites <b>with a vessel,</b> as one performs the sprinkling of the blood of a guilt offering, whose blood is sprinkled from a vessel on the altar and whose sprinkling may be performed with the priest’s left hand, <b>he may perform its rites with</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>like the guilt offering.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Yannai says:</b> According to Rabbi Shimon there are no restrictions on the manner in which the handful is sacrificed, as <b>once</b> the priest has <b>removed the handful from a service vessel, he may bring it up and burn it even</b> if he placed it <b>in his belt, or even in an earthenware vessel. Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says: All concede that</b> the <b>handful requires sanctification</b> in a service vessel before it is sacrificed.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya, from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Zevaḥim</i> 1:11): With regard to <b>the burning of</b> the <b>fats, and</b> the <b>limbs, and</b> the <b>wood</b> that were brought up to the altar, <b>that</b> the priest <b>brought them up</b> to the altar, <b>whether by hand or with a vessel, whether with</b> the <b>right</b> hand <b>or with</b> the <b>left</b> hand, <b>they are fit.</b> With regard to <b>the handful, and the incense, and the frankincense, that</b> the priest <b>brought them up</b> to the altar, <b>whether by hand or with a vessel, whether with</b> the <b>right</b> hand <b>or with</b> the <b>left</b> hand, <b>they are fit.</b> The Gemara suggests: This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> who stated that if the handful is sacrificed by hand, it must be sacrificed only with the right hand.
The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> could <b>say to you</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> it <b>disjunctively,</b> and the statement should be understood as follows: If these items are brought up <b>by hand, with</b> the <b>right</b> hand, or <b>with a vessel, whether with</b> the <b>right</b> hand <b>or with</b> the <b>left,</b> they are fit.
The Gemara attempts to refute the opinion of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak that all concede that the handful requires sanctification in a service vessel before it is sacrificed. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If the priest <b>removed the handful,</b> but <b>not from a service vessel, and sanctified it,</b> but <b>not in a service vessel, and brought it up and burned it,</b> but <b>not in a service vessel,</b> then it is <b>unfit. Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon deem</b> it <b>fit in</b> a case where the handful had been <b>placed</b> in any type of <b>vessel.</b> This contradicts Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s claim that all concede that the handful must be sanctified in a service vessel.
The Gemara responds: <b>Say</b> that according to Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon, <b>from</b> the point when the handful has been <b>placed</b> in a service <b>vessel</b> and sanctified <b>and onward,</b> it is no longer necessary to take it in a service vessel to the altar to sacrifice it. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> does not contradict Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s statement.
The Gemara suggests another refutation of Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i> 4:15). <b>Come</b> and <b>hear: And the Rabbis say:</b> The <b>handful requires</b> sanctification in <b>a service vessel. How</b> is this sanctification performed? The priest <b>removes the handful from a service vessel, and sanctifies it in a service vessel, and brings it up and burns it in a service vessel. Rabbi Shimon says: Once the handful is removed from a service vessel,</b> the priest may <b>bring it up and burn it</b> even if it is <b>not in a service vessel, and</b> this <b>is sufficient for it.</b> This <i>baraita</i> demonstrates that, in contrast to Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak’s statement, Rabbi Shimon does not hold that the handful must be sanctified in a service vessel.
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that according to Rabbi Shimon, <b>once</b> the priest <b>removes the handful and sanctifies it in a service vessel,</b> he may <b>bring it up and burn it, and</b> this <b>is sufficient for it.</b>
The Gemara suggests another proof. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> If the priest <b>removed the handful with his right</b> hand <b>and put</b> it <b>in his left</b> hand, <b>he shall return it to his right</b> hand. If the handful was <b>in his left</b> hand

Daf 26b

<b>and he intended</b> to partake <b>of</b> the meal offering in an improper manner, <b>whether outside its</b> designated <b>area or beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> the offering is <b>not valid, but there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> if one partakes <b>of it.</b>
The Gemara presents an alternative version of this <i>baraita</i>: If, while the handful was in his right hand, <b>he intended</b> to partake <b>of</b> the meal offering <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> the offering is <b>not valid, but there is no</b> liability to receive <b><i>karet</i></b> if one partakes <b>of it.</b> If he intended to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> then the offering is <b><i>piggul</i> and</b> one who partakes of it <b>is liable</b> to receive <b><i>karet</i>.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: Once he put</b> the handful <b>in</b> his <b>left</b> hand, the <b>placing</b> of it in his left hand <b>renders it unfit</b> and it cannot be rendered fit by returning it to his right hand. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is <b>because it requires sanctification in</b> a service <b>vessel, and once he put it in</b> his <b>left</b> hand, <b>it is considered like blood that spilled from an animal’s neck onto the floor</b> before being collected in a service vessel <b>and one</b> then <b>gathered it, which</b> is <b>unfit</b> and cannot be rendered fit by then being placed in a service vessel.
The Gemara notes: <b>By inference,</b> one can conclude <b>that Rabbi Elazar and Rabbi Shimon do not require</b> sanctification of the handful by <b>placing</b> it in a service <b>vessel.</b> Accordingly, this serves as <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rav Naḥman</b> bar Yitzḥak, who stated that even Rabbi Shimon requires sanctification in a service vessel. The Gemara affirms: This is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of his opinion.
The <i>baraita</i> teaches that according to Rabbi Shimon, if the priest transferred the handful to his left hand he should return the handful to his right hand. The Gemara comments: This <b>supports</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya,</b> as he said that according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon the rites of the meal offering must be performed with the priest’s right hand. The Gemara asks: <b>Shall we say</b> that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yannai,</b> as it teaches that the handful must be transferred back to his right hand, whereas he states that once the handful has been removed from a service vessel it may be sacrificed in any manner?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi Yannai</b> could <b>say to you: I stated</b> my ruling <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the <i>tanna</i></b> who taught <b>that</b> the <b>burning</b> of the fats and the limbs and the sacrifice of the meal offering can all take place with either the right or left hand. <b>And</b> I hold that he <b>does not teach</b> it <b>disjunctively,</b> as it was explained in order to reconcile the <i>baraita</i> with the statement of Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Ḥiyya. Rather, it is to be understood according to its straightforward meaning.
§ The mishna teaches: If the priest <b>burned the handful of</b> a meal offering <b>twice,</b> i.e., in two increments, it is <b>fit.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says:</b> The handful is fit if it is burned <b>twice,</b> where half of the handful is burned each time, <b>but not</b> if it is burned <b>several times,</b> in smaller increments. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is fit if it is burned <b>twice, and</b> it is fit <b>even</b> if it is burned <b>several times.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the basis for the dispute <b>between</b> the two opinions? <b>Rabbi Zeira said:</b> The dispute <b>between</b> the two <b>is</b> with regard to whether <b>there is</b> significance to <b>a handful</b> that is <b>less than</b> the size of <b>two olives and whether there is</b> significance to the <b>burning</b> of <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> on the altar.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi holds</b> that <b>there is no</b> significance to <b>a handful</b> that is <b>less than</b> the size of <b>two olives and there is no</b> significance to the <b>burning</b> of <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> on the altar. Therefore, the mishna’s statement that the handful may be burned in two increments is meant literally, and the handful may be divided into only two equal portions, where each one contains exactly one olive-bulk. It may not be divided further, since doing so would result in the burning of less than an olive-bulk on the altar. <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan holds</b> that <b>there is</b> significance to <b>a handful</b> that is <b>less than</b> the size of <b>two olives and there is</b> significance to the <b>burning</b> of <b>less than an olive-bulk</b> on the altar. Therefore, if the handful was divided into several small portions and each portion was burned separately, it is fit.
