The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> isn’t <b>this also obvious,</b> since the letter is not formed properly? <b>Rather, it is necessary only according to another</b> statement <b>that Rav Yehuda</b> says. <b>As Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: Any letter that is not encircled with</b> blank <b>parchment on</b> all <b>four of its sides,</b> as its ink connects to the letter above it, below it, preceding it, or succeeding it, is <b>unfit.</b>

Daf 34b

§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the number of compartments in the phylacteries of the head, the verse states: “It shall be for a sign upon your hand, and <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (Exodus 13:16), with the word <i>totafot</i> spelled deficient, without a <i>vav</i> before the final letter, in a way that can be read as singular; and again: “They shall be <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 6:8), spelled as a singular word; and again: “They shall be <b>for <i>totafot</i></b> between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 11:18), this time spelled plene, with a <i>vav</i> before the final letter, in a manner that must be plural. <b>There are four</b> mentions of <i>totafot</i> <b>here,</b> as the third one is written in the plural and therefore counts as two. Consequently, it is derived that the phylacteries of the head must have four compartments. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says: There is no need</b> for this proof, as the requirement of four compartments can be derived from the word <i>totafot</i> itself: The word <b><i>tot</i> in</b> the language of <b>Katfei</b> means <b>two,</b> and the word <b><i>pat</i> in</b> the language of <b>Afriki</b> also means <b>two,</b> and therefore <i>totafot</i> can be understood as a compound word meaning four.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that a scribe <b>should write</b> the passages of the phylacteries of the head <b>on four</b> separate <b>hides,</b> i.e., parchments, <b>and place them in four compartments of four hides,</b> one passage in each compartment. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And for a memorial between your eyes”</b> (Exodus 13:9). This teaches: <b>I said to you</b> that the phylacteries are <b>one memorial, but not</b> that they are <b>two or three memorials,</b> i.e., the phylacteries themselves must be one unit. <b>How so?</b> One <b>writes</b> the passages <b>on four hides and places them in four compartments</b> fashioned <b>of one hide.</b>
<b>And if</b> a scribe <b>wrote</b> all four of <b>them on one hide and placed them in four compartments</b> by slitting the parchment between each of the passages, one who dons these phylacteries has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>And</b> in such a case it is <b>necessary for there to be a space between</b> each of the passages, so that each can be placed in a separate compartment; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: It is not necessary</b> for there to be a space between them. <b>And</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis <b>agree that one places a string or</b> a thicker <b>band between each and every one</b> of the four compartments. The <i>baraita</i> adds: <b>And if their furrows,</b> i.e., the lines marking the separation between the compartments, <b>are not noticeable</b> from the outside, the phylacteries <b>are unfit.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does</b> a scribe <b>write them?</b> With regard to <b>the phylacteries of the arm, he writes it on one hide. But if he wrote it on four</b> separate <b>hides and placed it in one compartment,</b> one who wears it has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>And</b> in such a case <b>it is necessary to attach</b> the four parchments, <b>as it is stated: “And it shall be for a sign for you upon your arm”</b> (Exodus 13:9). This teaches that <b>just as</b> the phylacteries of the arm are <b>one sign on the outside,</b> as the compartment is fashioned from a single hide, <b>so too,</b> they must be <b>one sign on the inside,</b> i.e., the four passages must be on a single parchment. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Yosei says: It is not necessary</b> to attach the passages.
<b>Rabbi Yosei says: And Rabbi Yehuda the Distinguished [<i>Beribbi</i>] concedes to me that if one does not have phylacteries of the arm but has two phylacteries of the head, that he covers one of them with patches of hide,</b> to render it like one compartment, <b>and places it</b> on his arm. The Gemara asks: How can Rabbi Yosei say that Rabbi Yehuda <b>concedes</b> to him in this case? <b>This is</b> the very situation in which <b>their dispute</b> applies, as they disagree over whether or not the passages of the phylacteries of the arm may be written on separate parchments. <b>Rava said: From Rabbi Yosei’s statement</b> one can infer that <b>Rabbi Yehuda retracted</b> his opinion and accepted Rabbi Yosei’s ruling.
Rabbi Yosei said that all agree that one can convert phylacteries of the head into phylacteries of the arm. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But Rav Ḥananya sent</b> the following ruling <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If one has <b>phylacteries of the arm,</b> he <b>can convert it to</b> phylacteries <b>of the head, but</b> if one has phylacteries <b>of the head,</b> he <b>cannot convert it to</b> phylacteries <b>of the arm, because one does not reduce</b> the sanctity of an item <b>from</b> a level of <b>greater sanctity</b> of phylacteries of the head <b>to</b> a level of <b>lesser sanctity</b> of phylacteries of the arm.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> ruling is stated <b>with regard to old</b> phylacteries, which have already been worn on one’s head and therefore have a greater level of sanctity, whereas <b>that</b> ruling is stated <b>with regard to new</b> phylacteries, which have not yet been used. The Gemara adds: <b>And according to the one who says</b> that <b>designation is significant,</b> i.e., once one designates an item for use in fulfilling a particular mitzva, it assumes the sanctity of an item used for mitzvot, this ruling is stated with regard to a case <b>where he stipulated with regard to them from the outset</b> that he may convert it from phylacteries of the head to phylacteries of the arm, and only in this circumstance it is permitted to convert them.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How does one arrange</b> the four passages inside the phylacteries? The passage of: <b>“Sanctify unto Me”</b> (Exodus 13:1–10), and the passage of: <b>“And it shall be when He shall bring you”</b> (Exodus 13:11–16), are placed <b>on the right;</b> the passage of: <b>“Listen,</b> O Israel” (Deuteronomy 6:4–9), and the passage of: <b>“And it shall come to pass, if you shall hearken diligently”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:13–21), are placed <b>on the left.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that one places them in the <b>opposite</b> manner, with the first two passages on the left and the latter two on the right? <b>Abaye said</b> that it is <b>not difficult: Here</b> it means <b>to the right of</b> the <b>reader,</b> i.e., one who is standing opposite the one donning the phylacteries, whereas <b>there</b> it means <b>to the right of</b> the <b>one who is donning</b> the phylacteries. <b>And</b> in this manner <b>the reader reads</b> the passages <b>in their order,</b> as they appear in the Torah, starting with Exodus 13:1–10 to his right.
<b>Rav Ḥananel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>one exchanged its passages,</b> i.e., placed them in a different order within the compartment, the phylacteries <b>are unfit. Abaye said: We did not say</b> this

Daf 35a

<b>unless</b> it is a case where one exchanges <b>an inner</b> passage <b>for an outer</b> one, e.g., he placed the passage of Exodus 13:11–16 to the right of Exodus 13:1–10, <b>or an outer</b> passage <b>for an inner one,</b> e.g., he placed the passage of Deuteronomy 11:13–21 to the right of Deuteronomy 6:4–9. <b>But</b> if one exchanges <b>an inner</b> passage <b>for</b> the other <b>inner</b> one, i.e., he exchanges Exodus 13:11–16 with Deuteronomy 6:4–9, <b>or an outer</b> passage <b>for</b> the other <b>outer</b> one, i.e., he exchanges Exodus 13:1–10 with Deuteronomy 11:13–21, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it.</b>
<b>Rava said to</b> Abaye: <b>What is different</b> about the cases of exchanging <b>an inner</b> passage <b>for an outer</b> one, <b>and an outer</b> passage <b>for an inner</b> one, such <b>that</b> the phylacteries are <b>not</b> fit? The reason is <b>that this</b> passage, <b>which needs to see the air,</b> i.e., to be placed on the outer side, <b>does not see</b> it, <b>and that</b> passage, <b>which does not need to see the air, does see it.</b> But in a case where one exchanges <b>an outer</b> passage <b>for</b> the other <b>outer</b> one <b>or an inner</b> passage <b>for</b> the other <b>inner</b> one, it should be unfit <b>as well,</b> as <b>this</b> passage, <b>which needs to see the air of</b> the <b>right</b> side, <b>sees the air of</b> the <b>left</b> side, <b>and</b> that passage, which requires to see the air <b>of</b> the <b>left</b> side, <b>sees the air of</b> the <b>right</b> side. <b>Rather,</b> there <b>is no difference</b> between any of these cases, and any change in the order renders the phylacteries unfit.
§ <b>And Rav Ḥananel says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The requirement to have <b>the <i>titora</i> of phylacteries,</b> i.e., the base of phylacteries upon which the compartments rest, is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. Abaye said:</b> The requirement to have <b>the <i>ma’ebarta</i> of phylacteries,</b> i.e., the passageway through which the straps are inserted, is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. And Abaye says:</b> The requirement to have a letter <b><i>shin</i></b> protruding <b>on</b> the <b>phylacteries</b> of one’s head, which is achieved by pressing the hide into the shape of that letter, is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b>
Abaye further says: <b>And there is a requirement that</b> the <b>furrow</b> between each of the compartments of phylacteries of the head <b>reach the place of the stitches,</b> i.e., the <i>titora</i>, to which the compartments are sewn. <b>Rav Dimi of Neharde’a says: Once it is noticeable</b> that there is a furrow between each of the compartments, <b>it is not necessary</b> for them to reach all the way to the <i>titora</i>.
<b>And Abaye says:</b> With regard to <b>this parchment</b> upon which one writes the passages <b>of phylacteries,</b> the scribe <b>must examine it</b> before writing, <b>as perhaps it has a flaw,</b> i.e., a perforation, <b>and complete writing is required, and</b> that requirement would <b>not</b> be fulfilled if a letter were perforated. <b>Rav Dimi of Neharde’a says: No</b> prior examination is <b>required;</b> rather, <b>the quill examines it</b> as one writes, as any perforation which the ink covers is disregarded.
<b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> The requirement that the <b>straps</b> of the phylacteries be <b>black</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai.</b> The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may tie phylacteries only</b> with straps <b>of their</b> same <b>type,</b> i.e., the straps must be made from hide, and it does not matter <b>whether</b> they are <b>green, or black, or white.</b> Nevertheless, <b>one should not make red</b> straps, <b>because</b> this is <b>deprecatory</b> to him, as it looks like he has wounds on his head, <b>and</b> also due to <b>something else,</b> i.e., lest people suspect him of engaging in sexual intercourse with a menstruating woman and getting blood on the straps.
The Gemara cites the continuation of that <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rabbi Yehuda said:</b> There was <b>an incident involving Rabbi Akiva’s student, who would tie his phylacteries with strips of sky</b>-<b>blue wool</b> rather than hide, <b>and</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>did not say anything to him.</b> Is it <b>possible</b> that <b>that righteous man saw his student</b> doing something improper <b>and he did not object to his</b> conduct? Another Sage <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>Yes,</b> it is possible that the student acted improperly, as Rabbi Akiva <b>did not see him, and if he had seen him, he would not have allowed him</b> to do so.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: There was <b>an incident involving Hyrcanus, the son of Rabbi Eliezer ben Hyrcanus, who would tie his phylacteries with strips of purple wool, and</b> his father <b>did not say anything to him.</b> Is it <b>possible</b> that <b>that righteous man saw his son</b> doing something improper <b>and he did not object to his</b> conduct? The Sages <b>said to him: Yes,</b> it is possible that his son acted improperly, as Rabbi Eliezer <b>did not see him, and if he had seen him, he would not have allowed him</b> to do so. This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains the objection from the <i>baraita</i>: <b>In any event,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> that it does not matter <b>whether</b> the straps are <b>green, or black, or white,</b> whereas Rabbi Yitzḥak maintains that it is a <i>halakha</i> transmitted to Moses from Sinai that the straps of the phylacteries must be black. The Gemara answers that it is <b>not difficult. Here,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>the inside</b> of the straps, which touch the body. These may be any color other than red. Conversely, <b>there,</b> when Rabbi Yitzḥak says that the straps of the phylacteries must be black, he is speaking of <b>the outside</b> of the straps.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>If</b> the <i>baraita</i> is discussing <b>the inside</b> of the straps, <b>what deprecatory</b> matter <b>or</b> problem of <b>something else is there</b> with straps that are red on the inside? After all, this side is not seen. The Gemara answers: <b>Sometimes his</b> straps <b>become reversed,</b> and therefore these concerns are applicable.
It is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The requirement that <b>phylacteries</b> be <b>square</b> is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. Rav Pappa says</b> about this <i>halakha</i>: Square means <b>along their seams and their diagonals,</b> i.e., they must be perfectly square where the compartments are sewn to the <i>titora</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that a mishna <b>supports</b> this opinion (<i>Megilla</i> 24b): <b>One who fashions his phylacteries</b> in <b>a round</b> shape exposes himself to <b>danger, and it</b> does <b>not</b> enable him to fulfill the <b>mitzva</b> of phylacteries. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is no support, as one can say that <b>the mishna</b> is referring to phylacteries <b>that are fashioned like a nut,</b> i.e., their underside is rounded, and therefore there is a danger that if he strikes his head on a wall the underside will press into his head and injure him. By contrast, if the underside is flat one might have thought that it is fit despite the fact that it is not square. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that phylacteries must be square.
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> With regard to <b>phylacteries</b> of the head, <b>as long as the surface of outer hide is intact,</b> i.e., it is not torn, <b>they are fit,</b> even if the hide between the compartments has torn. <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If <b>two</b> of the walls between the compartments <b>tore,</b> such phylacteries <b>are fit,</b> but if <b>three</b> of these inner walls tore, <b>they are unfit.</b>
<b>Rava said:</b> Concerning <b>that which you said,</b> that if <b>two</b> of the walls between the compartments tore <b>they are fit, we said</b> this <b>only</b> if the inner walls that tore are <b>not aligned with each other,</b> i.e., they are not adjacent to one another. <b>But</b> if the torn walls are <b>aligned with each other,</b> the phylacteries <b>are unfit. And</b> furthermore, <b>even</b> in a case where the torn walls are <b>aligned with each other, we said</b> that they are unfit <b>only with regard to new</b> phylacteries, as the hide is certainly defective. <b>But with regard to old</b> phylacteries, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> as they tore due to aging.
<b>Abaye said to Rav Yosef: What are the circumstances</b> of <b>new</b> phylacteries, <b>and what are the circumstances</b> of <b>old</b> phylacteries? Rav Yosef <b>said to him:</b> In <b>any</b> case <b>where if one holds the hide and pulls it, it returns to its place [<i>ḥaleim</i>],</b> these phylacteries are considered <b>old; and</b> in <b>the other</b> case, where hide that was pulled does not return to its place, they are considered <b>new.</b>

Daf 35b

<b>Alternatively,</b> in <b>any</b> case <b>where if</b> the phylacteries are <b>hanging by the strap</b> the compartment <b>follows</b> the strap, i.e., it remains attached, these phylacteries are considered <b>new; and</b> in <b>the other</b> case, where the phylacteries would fall off, they are considered <b>old.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Abaye was sitting before Rav Yosef</b> when the <b>strap of his phylacteries tore.</b> Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as <b>to</b> whether one may <b>tie</b> the strap? Rav Yosef <b>said to him: It is written</b> with regard to phylacteries: <b>“And you shall bind them [<i>ukshartam</i>]</b> for a sign upon your arm” (Deuteronomy 6:8), which teaches <b>that</b> the <b>binding must be complete [<i>keshira tamma</i>],</b> whole and beautiful, and that would not be the case with a makeshift knot.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Yosef, said to Rav Ashi: What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> as <b>to</b> whether one may <b>sew</b> a strap that tore <b>and insert</b> the <b>stitching inside,</b> so that it is not visible from the outside? Rav Ashi <b>said</b> to him: <b>Go out and see what the people are doing.</b> If the common custom is to do this, it is permitted.
<b>Rav Pappa says: The remnants of straps,</b> i.e., what remains when part of the strap has been cut off, <b>are fit.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And it is not so,</b> as can be derived <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya say: The remnants of</b> the <b>sky</b>-<b>blue wool</b> of ritual fringes, when only a small thread remains, <b>and</b> likewise <b>the remnants of</b> the <b>hyssop,</b> used for the sprinkling of the purification water of the red heifer, <b>are fit.</b> They did not include the remnants of straps of phylacteries in this <i>halakha</i>. The reason for this difference is that <b>it is there</b> that the remnants are fit, <b>as they are</b> mere <b>articles</b> used in the performance <b>of a mitzva; but here,</b> phylacteries <b>are articles of sanctity,</b> which are of greater sanctity, and therefore their remnants are <b>not</b> fit.
The Gemara states: From this line of inquiry one can conclude <b>by inference that</b> the straps of phylacteries <b>have</b> a minimum requisite <b>measure. And how much is their measure? Rami bar Ḥama says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> It is <b>until the index finger.</b> In explanation of this size, <b>Rav Kahana</b> would <b>demonstrate a bowed</b> measure, i.e., from the tip of the middle finger until the tip of the index finger, with the fingers spread. <b>Rav Ashi</b> would <b>demonstrate a straight</b> measure, from the tip of the thumb until the tip of the index finger, with the fingers spread.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabba</b> would <b>tie</b> the straps <b>and release</b> them <b>and let them fall</b> behind him. <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov</b> would <b>tie them and plait them</b> together like a braid. <b>Mar, son of Rabbana,</b> would <b>act like we</b> do, i.e., he would let the straps fall and hang over the front of his body.
<b>Rav Yehuda, son of Rav Shmuel bar Sheilat, says in the name of Rav:</b> The form of the <b>knot of phylacteries,</b> i.e., that there must be the form of a letter <i>dalet</i> in the knot of the phylacteries of the head and the letter <i>yod</i> in the knot of the phylacteries of the arm, is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai. Rav Naḥman says: And their decorative</b> side, the black side of the knot where the shape of the letter is visible, must face <b>outward.</b> The Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ashi was sitting before Mar Zutra</b> when the <b>strap of</b> his <b>phylacteries became reversed.</b> Mar Zutra <b>said to him: Doesn’t the Master hold</b> in accordance with the ruling that <b>their decorative</b> side must face <b>outward?</b> Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> It did <b>not</b> enter <b>my mind,</b> i.e., I did not notice.
With regard to the verse: <b>“And all the nations of the land shall see that the name of the Lord is called upon you, and they shall be afraid of you”</b> (Deuteronomy 28:10), it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer the Great says: This</b> is a reference to <b>the phylacteries of the head,</b> upon which the name of God is written, as they demonstrate to all that the name of God is called upon the Jewish people. With regard to the statement of God to Moses: <b>“And I will remove My hand, and you will see My back”</b> (Exodus 33:23), <b>Rav Ḥana bar Bizna says</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon Ḥasida says:</b> This <b>teaches that the Holy One, Blessed be He, showed Moses the knot of</b> the <b>phylacteries</b> of the head.
<b>Rav Yehuda says: The knot of phylacteries must be above,</b> i.e., it must rest on the head rather than on the neck, <b>in order that the Jewish people should be above and not below. And</b> likewise <b>it must be placed toward the front [<i>panim</i>],</b> i.e., not on the sides of the head, <b>in order that the Jewish people should be in front [<i>lefanim</i>] and not behind.</b>
§ <b>Rav Shmuel bar Bideri says</b> that <b>Rav says, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Aḥa Arikha,</b> i.e., Rabbi Aḥa the Tall, <b>says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says, and some say</b> that <b>Rav Menashya says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>phylacteries, from when does one recite a blessing over them? From the time when one dons them</b> on the arm and onward. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>Is that so? But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> With regard to <b>all the mitzvot, one recites a blessing over them prior to their performance?</b> How, then, can one recite a blessing over phylacteries after donning them? <b>Abaye and Rava both say:</b> One recites the blessing <b>from the time of donning</b> the phylacteries <b>until the time of binding</b> them, as the binding constitutes the performance of the mitzva.

Daf 36a

§ <b>Rav Ḥisda says:</b> If one <b>spoke between</b> donning the <b>phylacteries</b> of the arm <b>and</b> the <b>phylacteries</b> of the head, he must <b>recite the blessing again</b> when donning the phylacteries of the head.
The Gemara notes: One can infer that if he <b>spoke, yes,</b> he must recite a blessing when donning the phylacteries of the head, but if he <b>did not speak,</b> he does <b>not</b> recite a blessing. The Gemara challenges this: <b>But Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, sent</b> a ruling <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: On the phylacteries of the arm</b> one <b>says</b> the blessing: <b>Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the Universe, <b>Who has sanctified us through His mitzvot and commanded us to don phylacteries. On the phylacteries of the head</b> one <b>says</b> the blessing: <b>Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the Universe, <b>Who has sanctified us through His mitzvot and commanded us concerning the mitzva of phylacteries.</b> This indicates that one always recites a blessing when donning the phylacteries of the head.
<b>Abaye and Rava both say,</b> to resolve this apparent contradiction: Rabbi Yoḥanan meant that if one <b>did not speak,</b> he <b>recites one</b> blessing; if he <b>spoke,</b> he <b>recites two</b> blessings, when donning the phylacteries of the head as well as when donning the phylacteries of the arm.
Concerning this, it is <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>spoke between</b> donning the <b>phylacteries</b> of the arm <b>and</b> the <b>phylacteries</b> of the head, <b>he has a sin, and due to</b> that sin <b>he returns from the ranks of</b> soldiers waging <b>war.</b> This is referring to the preparation for war, when the officers announce: “What man is there who is fearful and fainthearted? Let him go and return to his house” (Deuteronomy 20:8). The Sages explained that this is referring to one who is fearful due to his transgressions.
It is further <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>When one dons</b> phylacteries, he first <b>dons</b> the phylacteries <b>of the arm and afterward dons</b> the phylacteries <b>of the head. And when he removes</b> his phylacteries, he first <b>removes</b> the phylacteries <b>of the head and afterward removes</b> the phylacteries <b>of the arm.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Granted,</b> the ruling that <b>when one dons</b> phylacteries he first <b>dons</b> the phylacteries <b>of the arm and afterward dons</b> the phylacteries <b>of the head</b> is understood, <b>as it is</b> first <b>written: “And you shall bind them for a sign upon your arm,” and then</b> it is written: <b>“And they shall be for frontlets between your eyes”</b> (Deuteronomy 6:8).
<b>But from where do we</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that <b>when he removes</b> his phylacteries, he first <b>removes</b> the phylacteries <b>of the head and afterward he removes</b> the phylacteries <b>of the arm? Rabba said</b> in explanation: <b>Rav Huna explained to me</b> the source of this <i>halakha</i>. <b>The verse states:</b> “And you shall bind them for a sign upon your arm <b>and they shall be for frontlets between your eyes,”</b> and it is derived from here: <b>As long as</b> the phylacteries of the head are <b>between your eyes,</b> the number of phylacteries you are wearing <b>shall be two.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>phylacteries, from when does one recite a blessing over them? From</b> when <b>the time</b> arrives to <b>don them. How so? If one is rising early to leave</b> his home <b>to</b> travel on <b>the road and is afraid lest</b> his phylacteries <b>become lost</b> during the journey, he <b>dons them</b> even at night, despite the fact that this is not the proper time for the mitzva of phylacteries. <b>And when</b> the <b>time</b> for <b>their</b> mitzva <b>arrives,</b> in the morning, <b>he touches them and recites a blessing over them.</b>
<b>And until when does one wear them? Until the sun sets. Rabbi Ya’akov says: Until traffic in the marketplace ceases. And the Rabbis say: Until the time of sleep. And the Rabbis concede to Rabbi Ya’akov that if one removed them to go out to the bathroom or to enter the bathhouse and the sun set, one does not don them again.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov.</b> The Gemara likewise relates that <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna would pray in the evening,</b> i.e., the evening service, <b>with</b> phylacteries. <b>Some say</b> that Rav Naḥman ruled that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ya’akov</b> but in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> that the mitzva of phylacteries ends at sunset.

Daf 36b

The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But Rav Ḥisda and Rabba bar Rav Huna would pray in the evening with</b> phylacteries. The Gemara explains: <b>That</b> opinion represented in this incident <b>disagrees</b> with the ruling of Rav Naḥman.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabba bar Rav Huna</b> actually <b>say this,</b> that the mitzva of phylacteries applies at night? <b>But doesn’t Rabba bar Rav Huna say:</b> If it is <b>uncertain</b> whether it is <b>nightfall</b> or whether it is <b>not nightfall,</b> one <b>neither removes</b> his phylacteries, as it is not yet definitely night, <b>nor dons</b> them <i>ab initio</i>. <b>This</b> indicates that if it is <b>definitely nightfall,</b> one <b>removes</b> his phylacteries. The Gemara answers: Rabba bar Rav Huna’s ruling <b>there was stated with regard to Shabbat eve,</b> as one may not don phylacteries on Shabbat, when the mitzva does not apply.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with regard to this answer: <b>What does</b> Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>hold? If he holds</b> that <b>night</b> is <b>a time</b> when one performs the mitzva of wearing <b>phylacteries,</b> then <b>Shabbat</b> is <b>also a time</b> when one performs the mitzva of wearing <b>phylacteries. If he holds</b> that <b>Shabbat</b> is <b>not a time</b> when one performs the mitzva of wearing <b>phylacteries,</b> then <b>night</b> is <b>also not a time</b> when one performs the mitzva of wearing <b>phylacteries.</b> The reason for this statement is <b>that from</b> the source <b>where Shabbat is excluded</b> from the mitzva of phylacteries, <b>nights are excluded from there</b> as well.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the end of the passage of the Torah that discusses both the mitzvot of the Paschal offering and phylacteries: <b>“And you shall observe this ordinance in its season from year [<i>miyamim</i>] to year”</b> (Exodus 13:10). This indicates that these mitzvot apply during the <b>days [<i>yamim</i>] but not</b> during the <b>nights.</b> Furthermore, the letter <i>mem</i>, meaning from, in the term: <b>“From year [<i>miyamim</i>],”</b> teaches: These mitzvot apply on some days, <b>but not</b> on <b>all days.</b> This <b>excludes <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals,</b> on which phylacteries are not worn. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says: This</b> verse, mentioning <b>an ordinance, is stated only with regard to the Paschal</b> offering, and it is not referring to phylacteries at all. Evidently, Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who says that at night one is exempt from the obligation of donning phylacteries, says that on Shabbat one is exempt as well.
The Gemara answers: Rabba bar Rav Huna <b>derives</b> the exemption from the obligation to don phylacteries on Shabbat <b>from</b> a different source, the source <b>where Rabbi Akiva derives it from, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a person should don phylacteries on <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “And it shall be for a sign for you on your arm, and for a remembrance between your eyes,</b> so that God’s law shall be in your mouth; for with a strong arm God brought you out of Egypt” (Exodus 13:9). This teaches that the obligation to don phylacteries applies when the Jewish people <b>require a sign</b> to assert their status as God’s nation, i.e., during the week. This serves to <b>exclude <i>Shabbatot</i> and Festivals, as they themselves are signs</b> of the Jewish people’s status as God’s nation and a remembrance of the exodus from Egypt. Consequently, no further sign is required on these days.
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: Anyone who dons phylacteries after sunset violates a positive mitzva. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: He violates a prohibition.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that these Sages <b>disagree with regard to</b> the principle that <b>Rabbi Avin says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ile’a says. As Rabbi Avin says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ile’a says: Any place where it is stated</b> in the Torah any of the terms: <b>Observe,</b> or: <b>Lest, or: Do not,</b> this means <b>nothing other than a prohibition,</b> as these are negative terms.
The Gemara explains this suggestion: <b>As</b> this <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avin,</b> and therefore the verse: “And you shall observe this ordinance in its season from year to year,” from which the exclusion of nights is derived, is a prohibition, as it employs the term “observe.” <b>And</b> that <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is <b>not</b> in accordance with the opinion <b>of Rabbi Avin,</b> and therefore the term: “And you shall observe,” is a positive mitzva.
The Gemara counters: <b>No, everyone is of</b> the opinion that the ruling is in accordance with the opinion <b>that Rabbi Avin</b> says that <b>Rabbi Ile’a says, and here they disagree with regard to this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Elazar, <b>holds</b> that the term <b>“observe”</b> written <b>with regard to a prohibition</b> has the status of <b>a prohibition,</b> whereas that same term <b>“observe”</b> written <b>with regard to a positive</b> mitzva has the status of <b>a positive</b> mitzva, as the Torah is issuing a warning to take special care in the observance of a mitzva. Accordingly, the command with regard to the positive mitzva of phylacteries is a positive mitzva. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the term <b>“observe”</b> written <b>with regard to a positive</b> mitzva is <b>also a prohibition.</b>
<b>And Rabbi Elazar says: And</b> although it is prohibited to don phylacteries at night, <b>if</b> one does so in order <b>to safeguard them</b> from theft and the like, it is <b>permitted.And Ravina said: I was sitting before Rav Ashi and</b> it <b>grew dark, and he donned phylacteries. And I said to him: Does the Master need to safeguard them? And he said to me: Yes. But I saw that his intention</b> in donning them was <b>not</b> that he <b>needed to safeguard them;</b> rather, Rav Ashi <b>holds:</b> This is the <b><i>halakha</i>,</b> that night is an appropriate time for phylacteries, <b>but</b> a public <b>ruling is not issued to that effect.</b>
<b>Rabba bar Rav Huna says: A person is obligated to touch</b> his <b>phylacteries</b> regularly for <b>the entire time</b> that he is wearing them. This is derived from <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <b>frontplate</b> of the High Priest, as follows: <b>And if</b> with regard to the <b>frontplate, which has only one mention</b> of God’s name, <b>the Torah states: “And it should be always upon his forehead”</b> (Exodus 28:38), which means that the High Priest must always be aware that the frontplate is placed on his head and <b>that he should not be distracted from it,</b> then with regard to <b>phylacteries, which have numerous mentions</b> of God’s name, <b>all the more so</b> one must always be aware of them.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> with regard to the verse: “And it shall be for a sign for you on <b>your arm [<i>yadkha</i>]”</b> (Exodus 13:9), that <b>this</b> is referring to the <b>left</b> arm. <b>Do you say</b> it means the <b>left</b> arm, <b>or is it only</b> the <b>right</b> arm? <b>The verse states: “Even My hand [<i>yadi</i>] has laid the foundation of the earth, and My right hand [<i>vimini</i>] has spread out the heavens”</b> (Isaiah 48:13). <b>And</b> another verse <b>states: “Her hand [<i>yadah</i>] she put to the tent pin, and her right hand [<i>viminah</i>] to the workmen’s hammer”</b> (Judges 5:26), <b>and</b> another verse <b>states: “Why do You withdraw Your hand [<i>yadkha</i>], even Your right hand [<i>viminekha</i>]? Draw it out of Your bosom and consume them”</b> (Psalms 74:11). All these verses employ the term <i>yad</i> with regard to the left hand, and use the term <i>yamin</i>, literally, right, without the term <i>yad</i>, to indicate the right hand.

Daf 37a

<b>Rabbi Yosei HaḤorem says:</b> This is no proof, as <b>we have found that</b> the <b>right</b> hand is also <b>called <i>yad</i>, as it is stated: “And when Joseph saw that his father was laying his right hand [<i>yad yemino</i>]”</b> (Genesis 48:17). The Gemara asks: <b>And the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, who maintains that the right hand is not called <i>yad</i>, how does he respond to this proof? He maintains that the right hand <b>is called “his right hand [<i>yad yemino</i>],”</b> but it <b>is not called a <i>yad</i> without</b> further <b>specification.</b>
<b>Rabbi Natan says:</b> This proof is <b>not necessary,</b> as <b>it says: “And you shall bind them</b> for a sign upon your arm” (Deuteronomy 6:8), and then it states: <b>“And you shall write them</b> upon the doorposts of your house” (Deuteronomy 6:9). This teaches that <b>just as writing is with</b> the <b>right</b> hand, as most people write with their right hands, <b>so too,</b> the <b>binding</b> of phylacteries must be performed <b>with</b> the <b>right</b> hand. <b>And since binding is with</b> the <b>right</b> hand, this means that <b>donning is on</b> the <b>left</b> arm, as one cannot bind the phylacteries with the same hand upon which he is donning them. The Gemara asks: <b>And from where does Rabbi Yosei HaḤorem,</b> who holds that the right hand is also called <i>yad</i> in the Torah, <b>derive that donning</b> phylacteries is <b>on</b> the <b>left</b> arm? The Gemara answers: <b>He derives it from where Rabbi Natan derives it.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The requirement that phylacteries be donned on the left arm is derived <b>from</b> the verse: “It shall be for a sign upon <b>your arm [<i>yadkha</i>]”</b> (Exodus 13:16), which <b>is written with</b> a letter <b><i>heh</i></b> at the end. This is expounded as though it stated: Your <b>weak [<i>keha</i>]</b> arm. <b>Rabbi Abba said to Rav Ashi: But</b> one can <b>say</b> that <i>yadkha</i> should be interpreted as <i>yadko’aḥ</i>, with a letter <i>ḥet</i> at the end instead of a <i>heh</i>. If so, this would mean: <b>Your arm that is of strength [<i>shebeko’aḥ</i>],</b> which is the right arm. Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Rabbi Abba: <b>Is</b> this word <b>written with a <i>ḥet</i>?</b>
The Gemara notes that Rav Ashi’s opinion, that the <i>halakha</i> that phylacteries are donned on the left arm is derived from the term <i>yadkha</i>, is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b><i>Yadkha</i></b> is written <b>with a <i>heh</i>,</b> indicating weakness, and <b>this</b> is referring to the <b>left</b> arm. <b>Others say: “Your arm,”</b> i.e., <i>yadkha</i>, serves <b>to include one without</b> a complete <b>arm,</b> i.e., one whose arm ends at the elbow, in the obligation to don phylacteries, as the remaining part is also categorized as a weak arm. It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>does not have</b> a left <b>arm,</b> i.e., not even above the elbow, he is <b>exempt from the</b> mitzva of <b>phylacteries. Others say: <i>Yadkha</i></b> serves <b>to include one without</b> a left <b>arm</b> even above the elbow, teaching that he must don phylacteries on his right arm.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A left-handed person dons phylacteries on his right</b> arm, <b>which is</b> equivalent to <b>his left</b> arm, i.e., his weaker arm. The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that a left-handed person <b>dons</b> phylacteries <b>on his left</b> arm, <b>which is the left</b> arm <b>of every</b> other <b>person? Abaye said: When that</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught,</b> it is referring <b>to one who has</b> equal <b>control with both his hands,</b> i.e., an ambidextrous person. Since such an individual also uses his right hand, he dons phylacteries on his left arm.
<b>The school of Menashe taught</b> with regard to the verse: “And you shall bind them for a sign on your arm, and they shall be as frontlets between your eyes” (Deuteronomy 6:8): <b>“On your arm”; this</b> is the <b>bicep. “Between your eyes”; this</b> is the <b>crown</b> of the head. The Gemara asks: <b>Where</b> exactly on the crown of the head are the phylacteries placed? <b>The school of Rabbi Yannai say:</b> Phylacteries are placed on the <b>place where</b> the bone above <b>the baby’s brain is soft</b> after birth.
§ The Sage <b>Peleimu raised a dilemma before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: In the case of <b>one who has two heads, on which of them does he don phylacteries?</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: Either get up</b> and <b>exile</b> yourself from here <b>or accept upon yourself excommunication</b> for asking such a ridiculous question. <b>In the meantime, a certain man arrived</b> and <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: A firstborn <b>child has been born to me who has two heads. How much</b> money <b>must I give to the priest</b> for the redemption of the firstborn? <b>A certain elder came</b> and <b>taught him: You are obligated to give him ten <i>sela</i>,</b> the requisite five for each head.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But Rami bar Ḥama teaches: Since it is stated</b> with regard to the redemption of the firstborn: <b>“The firstborn of man you shall redeem”</b> (Numbers 18:15), <b>I</b> would <b>derive</b> that <b>even</b> if <b>he was ravaged,</b> e.g., by an animal, <b>within thirty</b> days of his birth, one should redeem him. To counter this, <b>the verse states:</b>

Daf 37b

<b>“Yet</b> the firstborn of man you shall redeem”; the addition of the word “yet” serves to <b>differentiate</b> and teach that there is a firstborn who is not redeemed, namely, one that was ravaged. A child with two heads is like one that was ravaged, as he will certainly not live. The Gemara answers: <b>Here it is different, as the Merciful One makes</b> the redemption of the firstborn <b>dependent on</b> his <b>skull,</b> as it is stated: “You shall take five shekels apiece, by the skull” (Numbers 3:47), which indicates that there is a case in which a firstborn with more than one skull must be redeemed.
The Gemara returns to its discussion of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master says: “On your arm”; this</b> is the <b>bicep.</b> The term <i>yad</i> can mean either hand or arm. Therefore, the Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>As the Sages taught: “On your arm [<i>yadkha</i>]”; this</b> is the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the arm. Do you say</b> that <b>this</b> is the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the arm, or</b> is it <b>only literally on your</b> actual <b>hand,</b> i.e., on the palm of the hand? <b>The Torah says: Don phylacteries on the <i>yad</i> and don phylacteries on the head; just as there,</b> with regard to the head, it means <b>on</b> the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head,</b> as will be explained, <b>so too here,</b> it means <b>on</b> the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the arm.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> This proof is <b>not necessary, as</b> the verse <b>states: “And it shall be for a sign for you</b> upon your arm” (Exodus 13:9), which teaches: It shall be <b>a sign for you, but not a sign for others,</b> i.e., one must don the phylacteries of the arm in a place where they are not seen by others. This is the arm, which is usually covered, whereas the hand is usually visible. <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says:</b> This proof is <b>not necessary, as</b> the verse <b>states: “Therefore you shall place these words in your heart</b> and in your soul, <b>and you shall bind them”</b> (Deuteronomy 11:18). This teaches <b>that placing</b> the words, i.e., donning the phylacteries, <b>shall be opposite the heart,</b> on the bicep.
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya and Rav Aḥa, son of Rav Avya,</b> would <b>direct</b> the placement of his phylacteries of the arm <b>and don</b> them <b>opposite his heart. Rav Ashi was sitting before Ameimar,</b> and <b>there was a cut in</b> the sleeve covering Ameimar’s <b>arm, and</b> as a result his <b>phylacteries were visible,</b> as they were not covered by a garment. Rav Ashi <b>said to</b> Ameimar: <b>Doesn’t the Master hold</b> that the phylacteries shall be <b>a sign for you but not a sign for others?</b> Ameimar <b>said to him:</b> This does not mean that phylacteries must be hidden; rather, this <b>was stated</b> in order to teach that they must be donned <b>in a place</b> that is <b>a sign for you,</b> i.e., the bicep, which is generally not seen, but it does not matter if in practice the phylacteries are visible.
With regard to the statement of the <i>baraita</i> that the phylacteries of the head are donned on the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head,</b> the Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? <b>As the Sages taught: “Between your eyes”</b> (Exodus 13:9); <b>this</b> is the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head. Do you say</b> that <b>this</b> is the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head, or is it only literally between your eyes? It is stated here: “Between your eyes,” and it is stated there:</b> “You shall not cut yourselves, <b>nor make any baldness between your eyes for the dead”</b> (Deuteronomy 14:1), <b>Just as there,</b> the phrase “between your eyes” is referring to a place <b>on</b> the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head,</b> as that is <b>a place where</b> one can <b>render</b> himself <b>bald</b> by removing his hair, <b>so too,</b> the place where phylacteries are donned is <b>on</b> the <b>upper</b> part <b>of the head, a place where</b> one can <b>render</b> himself <b>bald.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> This proof is <b>not necessary,</b> as <b>the Torah says: Don phylacteries on the arm</b> and <b>don phylacteries on the head. Just as there,</b> with regard to the phylacteries of the arm, it is referring <b>to a place which is fit to become ritually impure with</b> only <b>one</b> type of leprous <b>mark,</b> that of the skin, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the phylacteries of the head, it is referring <b>to a place which is fit to become ritually impure with</b> only <b>one</b> type of leprous <b>mark,</b> that of a place of hair (see Leviticus 13:29–37).
Rabbi Yehuda continues: This serves <b>to exclude</b> the area which is literally <b>“between your eyes,” as there is flesh and</b> the <b>hair</b> of the eyebrows present there, and therefore <b>there is</b> a possibility of leprosy through the growth of <b>a white hair,</b> which is impure according to the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy of the skin (see Leviticus 13:3), <b>and there is also</b> a possibility of leprosy through the growth of <b>a yellow hair,</b> which is impure according to the <i>halakhot</i> of leprosy of the head or the beard (see Leviticus 13:30).
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to the <b>four ritual fringes</b> on a garment, the absence of <b>each prevents fulfillment of the mitzva with the others, as the four of them</b> constitute <b>one mitzva.</b> Rabbi Yishmael says: The four of them are four discrete mitzvot, and the absence of one does not prevent fulfillment of the rest. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of the first <i>tanna</i> and Rabbi Yishmael? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> The difference <b>between</b> their opinions <b>is</b> with regard to a linen <b>sheet with</b> woolen <b>ritual fringes</b> that has fewer than four ritual fringes. The first <i>tanna</i> maintains that since one is not performing a mitzva, he may not wrap himself in the sheet, due to the prohibition of diverse kinds, i.e., the prohibition against wearing clothing made from a mixture of wool and linen threads. Conversely, Rabbi Yishmael permits one to wrap himself in it, as each ritual fringe is a separate mitzva, and the mitzva of ritual fringes overrides the prohibition against wearing diverse kinds.
<b>Rava bar Ahina said:</b> The difference <b>between</b> their opinions <b>is</b> with regard to <b>a cloak with five</b> corners. It is derived that a cloak of this kind requires ritual fringes (see 43b), but it is unclear whether ritual fringes must be placed on each corner. If each fringe is a discrete mitzva, then the obligation applies to the fifth corner as well, but if it is one mitzva then it applies only to four of the corners of this garment.
<b>Ravina said:</b> The difference <b>between</b> their opinions <b>is</b> with regard to the opinion <b>of Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says: One who goes out</b> unwittingly to the public domain <b>on Shabbat with</b> a four-cornered <b>cloak that does not have</b> all of <b>the requisite ritual fringes</b> attached to its corners is <b>liable</b> to bring <b>a sin offering,</b> because the remaining fringes are not an integral part of the garment. Since they do not enable the wearer to fulfill the mitzva, they are considered a burden, which may not be carried into the public domain on Shabbat. The first <i>tanna</i> agrees with this ruling, whereas Rabbi Yishmael maintains that since each corner with ritual fringes is the fulfillment of a mitzva, one is not liable to bring a sin offering due to carrying on Shabbat for wearing it into the public domain.
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, said: One who cuts</b> the corner of <b>his garmenthas not done anything</b> of consequence with regard to exempting the garment from the obligation of ritual fringes, as <b>he has rendered it a cloak with five</b> corners, to which the obligation of ritual fringes applies.
<b>Rav Mesharshiyya</b> similarly <b>says: One who ties his garment has not done anything</b> of consequence with regard to exempting the garment from the obligation of ritual fringes. <b>What is the reason? It is considered as though</b> the garment is <b>untied,</b> since the knot can be loosened at any time. <b>And we learned likewise</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 26:4): <b>All bound</b> leather <b>jugs,</b> i.e., those whose bottoms are not sewn but tied, <b>are ritually pure,</b> i.e., they are not susceptible to ritual impurity. This is because they are not considered receptacles, as these knots will be untied, <b>except for</b> leather <b>jugs of Arabs,</b> who would tie them with a permanent knot.
<b>Rav Dimi of Neharde’a</b> similarly <b>says: One who sews his garment,</b> i.e., he folded over a long garment and sewed the edges together, <b>has not done anything</b> of consequence with regard to the obligation of ritual fringes, and he must place ritual fringes on the original corners. The reason is that <b>if it is so that he does not need</b> the folded part, which is why he is sewing it, <b>let him cut</b> it <b>and throw it</b> away.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yishmael says: The four of them are four</b> discrete <b>mitzvot,</b> and the absence of one does not prevent fulfillment of the rest. <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael.</b> The Gemara states: <b>But the <i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with his</b> opinion.
The Gemara relates: <b>Ravina was walking behind Mar bar Rav Ashi on the Shabbat of the Festival</b> when <b>the corner</b> of Mar bar Rav Ashi’s garment <b>on</b> which <b>his ritual fringes</b> were hanging <b>tore, and</b> yet Ravina <b>did not say anything to him. When he arrived at</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi’s <b>house,</b> Ravina <b>said to him: Back there,</b> along the way, the corner <b>tore.</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi <b>said to him: If you would have told me</b> then, <b>I would have thrown off</b> the garment <b>there,</b> as once one of the ritual fringes is torn no mitzva is performed with the rest, and it is prohibited to walk in the public domain on Shabbat wearing such a garment. This is in accordance with the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i>, who disagrees with the ruling of Rabbi Yishmael.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But didn’t the Master say: Great is human dignity, as it overrides a prohibition in the Torah?</b> This includes the prohibition against carrying on Shabbat in the public domain. That being the case, why would he remove his garment in public?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rav bar Shabba interpreted</b> that statement <b>before Rav Kahana:</b>

Daf 38a

He stated this <b>with regard to the prohibition of: “You shall not deviate</b> to the left or the right of that which they tell you” (Deuteronomy 17:11). A prohibition by rabbinic law is overridden by human dignity, but not a prohibition by Torah law. Therefore, Mar bar Rav Ashi would have removed his garment had he known about the tear.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> there is a different version of this discussion: It was <b>when</b> they were <b>there,</b> in the place where the corner of Mar bar Rav Ashi’s garment tore, that Ravina <b>said to him</b> that it had torn, <b>and</b> Mar bar Rav Ashi <b>said to him</b> in response: <b>What is your opinion?</b> Do you think <b>that I should throw</b> the garment off? <b>But doesn’t the Master say: Great is human dignity, as it overrides a prohibition in the Torah?</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But Rav bar Shabba interpreted</b> that statement <b>before Rav Kahana:</b> He stated this <b>with regard to the prohibition of: “You shall not deviate,”</b> not the prohibition against carrying in the public domain, which applies by Torah law. The Gemara answers that <b>here too,</b> it is not a prohibition by Torah law, as the place where they were walking was not a full-fledged public domain but <b>a <i>karmelit</i>,</b> in which carrying <b>is</b> prohibited <b>by rabbinic law.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The absence of <b>the sky-blue [<i>tekhelet</i>]</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva of ritual fringes with <b>the white</b> strings, <b>and the</b> absence of <b>white</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the sky-blue</b> strings. If one has only one, he wears it without the other. Absence of the <b>phylacteries of</b> the <b>arm does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva of the phylacteries <b>of</b> the <b>head, and</b> absence of the phylacteries <b>of</b> the <b>head does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva of the phylacteries <b>of</b> the <b>arm.</b> If one has only one, he dons it without the other.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that <b>the mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When the verse requires one to place white and sky-blue strings upon the corners of his garments and then states: <b>“That you may look upon it”</b> (Numbers 15:39), it <b>teaches</b> that the lack of either <b>one prevents</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the other;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>But the Rabbis say:</b> The lack of one <b>does not prevent the</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with the other.
The Gemara inquires: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, i.e., how does he derive his ruling from this verse? The Gemara explains: <b>As it is written:</b> “And they shall put on the fringe of the corner a sky-blue thread” (Numbers 15:38). “The fringe of <b>the corner”</b> is a reference to strings that are of the same <b>type</b> as the <b>corner</b> of the garment. Since garments are usually white, this phrase is referring to white strings. <b>And it is written</b> in this same verse: <b>“A sky-blue thread.” And the Merciful One states</b> in the following verse, referring to both types of strings: “And it shall be to you for a fringe <b>that you may look upon it”</b> (Numbers 15:39), in the singular. This teaches that one does not fulfill his obligation <b>until both</b> types <b>are present together.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how do <b>the Rabbis,</b> who hold that the one can fulfill one obligation without the other, understand this verse? The Gemara answers: They hold that the phrase <b>“that you may look upon it” indicates</b> that one fulfills a mitzva with <b>each one individually.</b>
The Gemara concludes its initial suggestion: <b>Shall we say that</b> the mishna, which states that one can fulfill the mitzva with either white or sky-blue strings even in the absence of the other, is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? The Gemara responds: <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and the ruling of the mishna <b>is necessary only with regard to granting precedence.</b> The white strings should precede the blue strings, but if the order is reversed, one still fulfills the mitzva.
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: It is <b>a mitzva to</b> insert the <b>white</b> strings into the garment <b>before</b> inserting <b>the sky-blue</b> strings, <b>but if</b> one inserted the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>before the white</b> strings, he <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation <b>but omitted</b> the <b>mitzva.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean by the phrase: <b>Omitted</b> the <b>mitzva?</b>

Daf 38b

<b>If we say</b> that the individual <b>omitted</b> the <b>mitzva of white</b> strings <b>and fulfilled</b> only the <b>mitzva of sky-blue</b> strings, how is this possible? <b>According to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, the absence of either one <b>prevents</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the other,</b> and therefore in this case one would not fulfill any mitzva at all.
The Gemara answers that <b>Rav Yehuda said</b> that <b>Rav said:</b> It means <b>that he omitted a mitzva but</b> nevertheless <b>performed a mitzva. And what</b> does it mean that he <b>omitted a mitzva?</b> It means <b>that he did not perform</b> the <b>mitzva in the optimal manner</b> because he did not insert the white strings first, but he did fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well</b> with regard to the mishna’s statement that absence of the <b>white</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the sky-blue</b> strings, which has been interpreted to mean that failing to insert the white strings before the sky-blue strings does not invalidate the ritual fringes. But <b>what is</b> the meaning of the mishna’s statement <b>that</b> the absence of <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the white</b> strings?
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said:</b> That statement of the mishna <b>is necessary only</b> in the case of <b>a garment that</b> consists <b>entirely</b> of <b>sky-blue wool.</b> In such a case, one is supposed to insert the sky-blue strings before the white strings.
The Gemara notes that this <b>was also stated</b> by <i>amora’im</i>: <b>Levi said to Shmuel: Aryokh, do not sit on your feet until you explain to me this matter:</b> When the mishna states that the absence of <b>the sky-blue</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva of ritual fringes <b>with the white</b> strings, <b>and the</b> absence of <b>white</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the sky-blue</b> strings, <b>what</b> does <b>it</b> mean? Shmuel <b>said to</b> Levi: That statement <b>is necessary only</b> in the case of a linen <b>cloak</b> on which one places <b>ritual fringes, where</b> there is <b>a mitzva to</b> insert the <b>white</b> strings <b>first.</b>
<b>What is the reason</b> for this? The verse states: “And they shall put on the fringe of the corner a sky-blue thread” (Numbers 15:38). “The fringe of <b>the corner”</b> is a reference to the string that is the same <b>type</b> as the <b>corner</b> of the garment. In the case of a linen cloak, which is generally white, this is a reference to the white strings, and since the verse mentions “the fringe of the corner” before the sky-blue thread, the white strings must be inserted before the sky-blue strings. The mishna therefore teaches that <b>if</b> one inserted the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>before the white</b> strings, <b>we have no</b> problem <b>with it</b> after the fact, and the ritual fringes are valid.
The Gemara asks: This <b>works out well</b> with regard to the mishna’s statement <b>that</b> absence of the <b>white</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the sky-blue</b> strings. But <b>what is</b> the meaning of the mishna’s statement <b>that</b> the absence of <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the white</b> strings?
<b>Rami bar Ḥama said to him:</b> That statement of the mishna <b>is necessary only</b> in the case of <b>a garment that</b> consists <b>entirely</b> of <b>sky-blue wool, where</b> it is <b>a mitzva to</b> insert the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>first, as</b> the phrase: “The fringe of <b>the corner”</b> indicates that the first strings one inserts into the garment are those that are the same <b>type</b> as the <b>corner</b> of the garment. The mishna therefore teaches that <b>if</b> one inserted the <b>white</b> strings <b>first, we have no</b> problem <b>with it</b> after the fact, and the ritual fringes are fit.
<b>Rava said: Is it</b> actually the <b>color</b> of the garment that <b>determines</b> the proper order in which one should insert the strings? <b>Rather, Rava said:</b> The ruling of the mishna <b>is necessary only for</b> a case of <b>severed</b> strings. The mishna teaches <b>that if</b> the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>were severed and</b> the <b>white</b> ones <b>remain, or if</b> the <b>white</b> strings <b>were severed and</b> the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>remain, we have no</b> problem <b>with it,</b> and the ritual fringes are fit.
<b>As the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya say: Severed</b> white or <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>are fit, and</b> similarly, <b>severed hyssop</b> branches <b>are fit</b> for sprinkling the water of purification mixed with the ashes of a red heifer. The Gemara asks: <b>What measure</b> do <b>severed</b> strings need to be in order to remain fit? <b>Bar Hamduri says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> The strings must remain long <b>enough to tie them in a slipknot.</b>
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: When Shmuel says that severed strings must still be long <b>enough to tie them in a slipknot,</b> does that mean <b>to tie all of the</b> strings <b>together in a slipknot? Or perhaps</b> the strings may be even shorter, provided that they are long enough to tie <b>each one individually.</b> The Gemara concludes: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Ashi asks:</b> If the strings are <b>thick</b> and <b>cannot be tied in a slipknot, but if they were</b> the same length but <b>thin</b> they <b>could be tied in a slipknot, what</b> is their status? <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi:</b> If the strings are long enough to be fit if they are thin, <b>all the more so</b> they are fit if they are thick, <b>as the mitzva</b> one fulfills <b>with them is</b> more <b>recognizable</b> with thicker strings.
The Gemara cited the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that one cannot fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes without both white and sky-blue strings, and the Gemara explained that the mishna can be interpreted in accordance with his opinion. The Gemara now asks: <b>Who is the <i>tanna</i> who disagrees with Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and holds that the sky-blue strings and the white strings are not interdependent? The Gemara answers: <b>It is this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says in the name of Rabbi Natan, who said in the name of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, who said in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Nuri:</b> If <b>one does not have sky-blue</b> strings, he nevertheless <b>affixes white</b> strings.
<b>Rava said: Learn from</b> the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya that one is <b>required to tie</b> a knot <b>after each and every set</b> of windings, and one cannot suffice with only one knot at the end of all the windings. <b>As, if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> to say that one is <b>not required</b> to tie a knot after each set of windings, then <b>that which the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya say: Severed</b> white or <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>are fit, and</b> similarly, <b>severed hyssop</b> branches <b>are fit,</b> is difficult: <b>Once the uppermost</b> knot <b>is undone,</b> all of the windings on <b>the entire</b> corner will <b>come undone,</b> as there are no other knots holding the windings in place, and in that case the garment will not have valid ritual fringes.

Daf 39a

The Gemara rejects this proof: <b>Perhaps</b> the sons of Rabbi Ḥiyya were referring to a case <b>where</b> one <b>tied knots</b> between the sets of windings even though there is no obligation to do so.
<b>And Rabba says: Learn from it</b> that <b>the uppermost knot</b> in the ritual fringes is required <b>by Torah</b> law. <b>As, if</b> it <b>enters your mind</b> to say that it is <b>by rabbinic</b> law, whereas by Torah law it is sufficient to merely insert the strings into the hole without tying any knots, for <b>what</b> reason <b>was</b> it <b>necessary</b> for the Torah <b>to permit</b> placing wool <b>ritual fringes</b> on a linen <b>cloak?</b> It is <b>obvious</b> that it is permitted, since if <b>one attaches</b> a swatch of wool and a swatch of linen <b>with a single connection, it is not</b> considered <b>a connection</b> with regard to the prohibition against wearing a garment that includes both wool and linen. <b>Rather, learn from</b> it that the uppermost knot is required <b>by Torah law.</b>
§ <b>Rabba bar Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rav Adda says</b> that <b>Rav says: If a string was severed at its base,</b> i.e., where it is connected to the garment, the ritual fringes are <b>unfit. Rav Naḥman sat</b> in the study hall <b>and stated this <i>halakha</i>. Rava raised an objection to Rav Naḥman</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said,</b> i.e., that there is a minimum length required for the strings? That is only when the strings are <b>initially</b> affixed to the garment. <b>But</b> in the <b>end,</b> i.e., after the strings are affixed in an acceptable manner, <b>its remainder and its severed</b> strings are fit at <b>any</b> length.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is <b>its remainder and what</b> are <b>its severed</b> strings? <b>What, is it not</b> that when the <i>baraita</i> mentions <b>its remainder</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> parts <b>of the</b> strings <b>were severed and</b> parts <b>of them remain, and</b> when the <i>baraita</i> mentions <b>its severed</b> strings it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the strings <b>were completely severed,</b> and nevertheless the strings are fit for the mitzva?
The Gemara responds to Rava’s objection: <b>No,</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is teaching one</b> <i>halakha</i>, and the <i>baraita</i> should be understood as follows: <b>The remainder of its severed</b> strings are fit at <b>any length.</b> The Gemara asks: If so, <b>let</b> the <i>baraita</i> simply <b>say: Its severed</b> strings are fit at any length; <b>why do I</b> need the mention of <b>its remainder? This teaches us that we require a remainder of its severed</b> strings long <b>enough to</b> wrap them around the other strings and <b>tie them in a slipknot.</b>
§ <b>Rabba sat</b> in the study hall <b>and said in the name of Rav:</b> The <b>string</b> used <b>for winding</b> around the other strings <b>is counted in the quota</b> of ritual fringes, i.e., it is one of the eight strings on each corner, and there is no need to have an additional string for winding. <b>Rav Yosef said to</b> Rabba: <b>Shmuel said it, and not Rav.</b> This <b>was also stated</b> by another <i>amora</i>: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana says: Rabbi Yoshiya of Usha told me</b> that the <b>string</b> used <b>for winding</b> around the other strings <b>is counted in the quota</b> of ritual fringes.
<b>Rava sat</b> in the study hall <b>and said in the name of Shmuel:</b> If one <b>wound the majority of</b> the white and the <b>sky-blue</b> strings instead of leaving the larger portion of the strings hanging loose beyond the windings, the ritual fringes are nevertheless <b>fit. Rav Yosef said to</b> Rava: <b>Rav said it, and not Shmuel.</b> The Gemara supports Rav Yosef’s version from that which <b>was also stated: Rav Huna bar Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet says</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If one <b>wound the majority of</b> the white and the <b>sky-blue</b> strings, the ritual fringes are nevertheless <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Natan, teaches</b> this discussion <b>like this: Rav Huna says</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet says</b> that <b>Rav Yirmeya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If one <b>wound the majority of</b> the white and the <b>sky-blue</b> strings, the ritual fringes are nevertheless <b>fit. And even</b> if <b>he wound only one set of</b> windings, the ritual fringes are <b>fit. But</b> the <b>finest</b> way to affix the white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings is to ensure that <b>one-third</b> of the length of the strings is <b>windings and two-thirds</b> are <b>loose</b> hanging strings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is the <b>measure</b> of <b>a set</b> of windings? It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It is <b>such that one winds</b> once <b>and</b> winds <b>a second and third</b> time, i.e., each set must contain at least three windings. It was <b>taught: One who minimizes</b> the sets of windings <b>may not</b> have <b>fewer than seven</b> sets, <b>and one who adds</b> to this number of sets <b>may not</b> have <b>more than thirteen</b> sets of windings.
The Gemara provides explanations for these guidelines: <b>One who minimizes</b> the sets of windings <b>may not</b> wind <b>fewer than seven</b> sets, <b>corresponding to</b> the <b>seven firmaments. And one who adds</b> to this number of sets <b>may not</b> wind <b>more than thirteen</b> sets of windings, <b>corresponding to</b> the <b>seven firmaments and</b> the <b>six air</b> spaces <b>between them.</b>
It was <b>taught: When one begins</b> to form the windings, he <b>begins</b> winding <b>with a white</b> string. This is because the verse indicates that one first inserts “the fringe of <b>the corner”</b> (Numbers 15:38), i.e., the white strings, which are of the same <b>type</b> as the <b>corner</b> of the garment. <b>And when he concludes</b> the windings, <b>he concludes with a white</b> string, in accordance with the principle: <b>One elevates</b> to a higher level <b>in</b> matters of <b>sanctity and does not downgrade.</b>
§ The Gemara relates: <b>Rav and Rabba bar bar Ḥana were sitting</b> together. <b>A certain man was passing by wearing a cloak that</b> was made <b>entirely of sky-blue</b> wool, <b>on which he had affixed</b> white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings,

Daf 39b

<b>and</b> the ritual fringes were composed <b>entirely</b> of <b>windings,</b> without any portion of the strings hanging loose. <b>Rav said: The cloak is beautiful, but the</b> white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings are <b>not beautiful. Rabba bar bar Ḥana said: The cloak is beautiful, and the</b> white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings are also <b>beautiful.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do they disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana holds</b> that since <b>it is written</b> in one verse: “You shall prepare yourself <b>twisted cords”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12), <b>and</b> in another <b>it is written:</b> “And they shall put on the fringe of the corner a sky-blue <b>thread”</b> (Numbers 15:38), it teaches that the ritual fringes may be composed entirely of <b>either twisted cords,</b> i.e., the windings, <b>or</b> loose threads or <b>strings.</b>
<b>And Rav holds</b> that <b>actually, we</b> also <b>require</b> loose <b>strings</b> in addition to the windings, <b>and</b> when <b>that</b> term <b>“twisted cords”</b> appears in the verse, <b>it comes for</b> the purpose of teaching the <b>number</b> of strings that are required. If the verse would have employed the singular term <b>twisted cord,</b> it would still indicate that <b>two</b> strings are required, as twisted means that two strings are wound around each other. Once the verse uses the plural term <b>“twisted cords,”</b> it thereby indicates that <b>four</b> strings are required. By using the terms “twisted cords” and “thread,” the verses indicates: <b>Form twisted cords</b> with the four strings that one attaches to each corner, <b>and let</b> the strings <b>hang loose from them.</b>
§ <b>Shmuel says in the name of Levi: Wool strings exempt</b> a garment made <b>of linen,</b> i.e., one fulfills the mitzva by affixing wool strings to a linen garment.
<b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: <b>What is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether strings made <b>of linen exempt</b> a garment made <b>of wool?</b> One can say that <b>it is</b> only <b>wool</b> strings <b>that exempt</b> a garment <b>of linen, as since the sky-blue</b> string, which must be wool, <b>exempts</b> a linen garment, <b>white</b> strings of wool <b>also exempt</b> the garment. <b>But</b> if one affixes <b>linen</b> strings <b>to a wool</b> garment, he does <b>not</b> fulfill his obligation.
<b>Or perhaps, since it is written: “You shall not wear diverse kinds, wool and linen together. You shall prepare yourself twisted cords</b> upon the four corners of your covering” (Deuteronomy 22:11–12), which indicates that one may wear wool and linen together in order to fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes, there <b>is no difference</b> whether one affixes <b>wool</b> strings <b>to</b> a garment of <b>linen, and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> whether one affixes <b>linen</b> strings <b>to</b> a garment of <b>wool.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to this dilemma, <b>as Raḥava says</b> that <b>Rav Yehuda says: Wool strings exempt</b> a garment made <b>of linen,</b> strings <b>of linen exempt</b> a garment made <b>of wool,</b> and <b>strings of wool and linen exempt</b> a garment <b>in any case,</b> i.e., all garments, <b>and even</b> garments made <b>from silks [<i>beshira’in</i>].</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>And</b> this last point <b>disagrees</b> with a ruling <b>of Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says: <i>Shira’in</i> are</b> entirely <b>exempt from</b> the obligation of <b>ritual fringes. Rava raised an objection to</b> the opinion of <b>Rav Naḥman</b> from the following <i>baraita</i>: Garments made from types of silks known as <b><i>shira’in</i>, <i>kalakh</i>, and <i>serikin</i> all require ritual fringes.</b> The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> means that there is an obligation <b>by rabbinic law,</b> whereas Rav Naḥman meant they are exempt by Torah law.
The Gemara challenges this suggestion: <b>If that is so,</b> then <b>say the latter clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>all of these</b> garments, strings of <b>wool and linen exempt them.</b> This indicates that one may affix wool sky-blue strings and white linen strings. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the obligation of ritual fringes for silk garments is <b>by Torah law, that is</b> why <b>diverse kinds are permitted for them. But if you say</b> that the obligation is <b>by rabbinic law, how could diverse kinds be permitted for them?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> instead: <b>Either wool or linen</b> strings exempt silk garments, but one may not affix both wool and linen strings to the same silk garment.
The Gemara comments: <b>So too, it is reasonable</b> to assume that this is the correct interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>, <b>as</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause:</b> Strings made from <b>these</b> silk fabrics <b>exempt</b> a garment <b>of their type</b> but <b>do not exempt</b> a garment <b>that is not of their type. Granted, if you say</b> that the obligation to attach ritual fringes to these garments is <b>by rabbinic law, that is</b> why <b>they are exempted</b> if one affixes strings <b>of their type. But if you say</b> that the obligation is <b>by Torah law,</b> then <b>it</b> should be only <b>wool or linen that exempt</b> these garments.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>If</b> it is <b>due to that</b> reason, <b>there is no</b> conclusive <b>argument,</b> because one can maintain that other fabrics also fulfill the obligation of ritual fringes by Torah law, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava. As Rava raises a contradiction: It is written</b> in one verse: “And they shall put on the fringe of the corner a sky-blue thread” (Numbers 15:38). The term <b>“the corner”</b> indicates that the fringe must be from the same <b>type</b> of fabric as the <b>corner. And</b> yet <b>it is written: “Wool and linen”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:11), immediately before the verse states: “You shall prepare yourself twisted cords upon the four corners of your covering” (Deuteronomy 22:12), indicating that ritual fringes must be from either wool or linen.
<b>How so?</b> Strings made of <b>wool or linen exempt</b> any garment, <b>whether</b> the garment is made <b>of their type</b> of fabric, or <b>whether</b> it is <b>not of their type</b> of fabric. Strings made of all <b>other types</b> of fabric <b>exempt</b> garments made <b>of their type</b> of fabric, e.g., silk strings exempt a silk garment, but <b>they do not exempt</b> a garment made from a fabric <b>that is not their type,</b> i.e., a garment made from a different fabric.
The Gemara notes: <b>And Rav Naḥman,</b> who holds that silk garments do not require ritual fringes by Torah law, holds <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling stated by <b>a <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>As</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: Since</b> the word <b>garments is</b> usually <b>stated in the Torah without specification</b> as to the material from which the garments are made, <b>and the verse specified in one of</b> its references to garments that it is referring to garments made from <b>wool or linen,</b> as it states: “And the garment in which there will be the mark of leprosy, whether it be a woolen garment or a linen garment” (Leviticus 13:47), it may be derived that <b>so too, all</b> garments mentioned in the Torah are those made from <b>wool or linen.</b> Other fabrics are not classified as garments by Torah law. Consequently, when the Torah requires strings on the corners of garments (see Numbers 15:38), it is referring specifically to garments made of wool or linen.
<b>Abaye said: This</b> statement by <b>a <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael diverges from another</b> statement by <b>a <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael,</b> who holds that all fabrics are considered garments. <b>As</b> a <i>tanna</i> <b>of the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> From the fact that the verse states: “A woolen <b>garment”</b> (Leviticus 13:47), <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that <b>a garment of wool</b> can become ritually impure. <b>From where</b> is it derived that garments made of <b>camels’ hair, rabbits’ wool, goats’ hair, or</b> the types of silk <b><i>kalakh</i>, <i>serikin</i>, and <i>shirayin</i>,</b> are also <b>included</b> in this <i>halakha</i>? <b>The</b> same <b>verse states: “Or</b> a linen <b>garment.”</b> The word “or” serves as an amplification to include all types of fabric.

Daf 40a

<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>ritual fringes</b> on a linen <b>cloak, Beit Shammai deem</b> the cloak <b>exempt</b> from ritual fringes due to the fact that the sky-blue strings must be made from wool, and there is a Torah prohibition against wearing a mixture of wool and linen. <b>And Beit Hillel deem</b> a linen cloak <b>obligated</b> in the mitzva of ritual fringes. <b>And</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with the statement of Beit Hillel.</b>
