<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Rabbi Tzadok says: But is it not</b> the case that <b>anyone who affixes sky-blue</b> strings to a linen cloak <b>in Jerusalem is</b> considered <b>nothing other than one of those who causes</b> others <b>to be astonished</b> at their behavior, as it appears that he is violating the prohibition against wearing a garment containing wool and linen?
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: If so,</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is in accordance with Beit Hillel and a linen cloak is required to have ritual fringes, <b>why did</b> the Sages <b>prohibit</b> attaching ritual fringes to linen garments in Jerusalem? It is <b>because</b> people <b>are not well versed</b> in the <i>halakha</i> and might ultimately wear garments of wool and linen even when it is not necessary for the mitzva of ritual fringes.
<b>Rava bar Rav Ḥana said to Rava:</b> If that is the concern, then <b>let ten</b> people <b>take</b> linen cloaks with ritual fringes <b>and go out to the marketplace and</b> thereby <b>publicize the matter,</b> i.e., that it is permitted to affix wool strings to a linen garment due to the mitzva. Rava answered: <b>All the more so</b> people <b>would be astonished at us</b> for acting in such an unconventional manner.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let</b> the Rabbis <b>teach during</b> their public <b>lecture</b> that affixing wool strings to a linen garment is permitted for the mitzva of ritual fringes. The Gemara answers: Wearing strings on a linen garment is prohibited because of a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the concern that people might use strings that were dyed blue with <b>indigo [<i>kala ilan</i>],</b> instead of with <i>tekhelet</i>, the sky-blue dye produced from the <i>ḥilazon</i> (see 44b), in which case they would not fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes and would violate the prohibition against wearing garments containing wool and linen.
The Gemara suggests: Even if one’s blue strings are not dyed with <i>tekhelet</i> as required for the mitzva, <b>let</b> them <b>be</b> considered <b>merely</b> as <b>white</b> strings. In the absence of <i>tekhelet</i> one fulfills the mitzva with white strings, and therefore it should be permitted to affix white woolen strings to a linen garment. The Gemara explains: <b>Since it is possible</b> to affix white strings that are <b>the same type</b> of material as the garment, i.e., linen, and thereby fulfill the mitzva without overriding the prohibition against wearing a garment made from wool and linen, one may <b>not</b> affix white wool strings to a linen garment.
The Gemara notes: This is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Reish Lakish. As Reish Lakish says: Any place where you find a positive mitzva and a prohibition</b> that clash with one another, <b>if you are able to fulfill both of them,</b> that is <b>preferable; and if</b> that is <b>not</b> possible, <b>the positive mitzva shall come and override the prohibition.</b> In this case, the clash is between the mitzva of ritual fringes and the prohibition against wearing a garment that contains wool and linen. One can fulfill both of them by using white strings that are linen instead of wool if the garment is made from linen.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And let them test</b> the strings to ascertain whether they are dyed with indigo or with <i>tekhelet</i>, as explained by the Gemara (42b). The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> the prohibition against affixing ritual fringes to a linen garment is a rabbinic <b>decree due to</b> the concern that perhaps the sky-blue strings were colored with <i>tekhelet</i> dye that had been used for <b>testing</b> the color of the dye in the vat and therefore became unfit (see 42b). In such a case, there would be no fulfillment of the mitzva of sky-blue ritual fringes to override the prohibition against wearing a garment of wool and linen.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let</b> the Sages <b>write letters</b> informing dye producers that <i>tekhelet</i> that was used for testing the color of the dye in the vat is unfit for ritual fringes. The Gemara explains: <b>Shall we go and rely on letters,</b> assuming that dye producers will follow the instructions they contain? <b>Rava</b> responded to this and <b>said: Now,</b>

Daf 40b

with regard to the prohibitions against eating <b>leavened bread on Passover and</b> eating on <b>Yom Kippur, which</b> are punishable by <b><i>karet</i>, we rely on letters</b> sent from the rabbinical court in Eretz Yisrael publicizing whether the year was declared a leap year and when they have declared the New Moon; <b>here,</b> with regard to the mitzva of ritual fringes, <b>which</b> is <b>merely a positive mitzva,</b> is it <b>not all the more so</b> correct that letters can be relied on?
<b>Rather, Rava said: This is a statement</b> that <b>I said, and it was stated in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of Rabbi Zeira in accordance with my</b> opinion: The reason for the rabbinic decree is <b>lest</b> one’s <b>cloak rip within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the corner of the garment, which is where the ritual fringes are placed, <b>and he sew it</b> with linen string and then use the excess string for ritual fringes.
<b>And</b> in such a case the ritual fringes would be unfit because <b>the Torah states:</b> “You shall prepare yourself twisted cords” (Deuteronomy 22:12), which teaches: <b>Prepare</b> it, <b>and not from what has already been prepared.</b> Consequently, the strings must be attached to the garment for the sake of the mitzva of ritual fringes. When the individual places the linen string there in order to stitch the garment and then decides to use it for the mitzva of ritual fringes and adds sky-blue wool strings, he does not fulfill the mitzva of ritual fringes and violates the prohibition against wearing a garment of wool and linen.
Because of this rabbinic decree, <b>Rabbi Zeira untied</b> the ritual fringes and removed them from <b>his</b> linen <b>cloak. Rav Zeira said:</b> The rabbinic <b>decree</b> prohibiting ritual fringes on a linen garment is <b>also due to</b> the concern that one might affix ritual fringes to <b>a nighttime garment.</b> Since the mitzva of ritual fringes does not apply in that case, if one wears the garment he would not fulfill the mitzva and would violate the prohibition against wearing a garment with wool and linen.
<b>And Rava said: This is a statement</b> that <b>I said, and it was stated in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>in the name of Rabbi Zeira in accordance with my</b> opinion: If a garment is made <b>from cloth and its corners</b> are made <b>from leather,</b> it is <b>required</b> to have ritual fringes. Conversely, if a cloak is made <b>from leather and its corners</b> are made <b>from cloth,</b> it is <b>exempt</b> from the mitzva of ritual fringes. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>We require</b> that <b>the main</b> part of the <b>garment</b> be obligated, and a leather garment is not required to have ritual fringes.
The Gemara notes: <b>Rav Aḥai</b> would <b>follow the corner</b> in determining whether the garment is required to have ritual fringes or not, because the Torah states: “On the corners of their garments” (Numbers 15:38).
§ <b>Rava says</b> that <b>Rav Seḥora says</b> that <b>Rav Huna says:</b> In a case where one <b>affixed</b> ritual fringes <b>to</b> a garment <b>possessing</b> only <b>three</b> corners, which is not required to have ritual fringes, <b>and</b> then <b>completed</b> its <b>fourth</b> corner by sewing on additional material or cutting away some of the material, the ritual fringes he attached to the original three corners are <b>unfit.</b> This is due to the principle: <b>Prepare</b> it, <b>and not from what has already been prepared.</b> Once the garment is required to have ritual fringes one may attach the ritual fringes; the strings that were attached before the garment was required to have them are not fit.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: It is told of <b>the early</b> generations of <b>pious</b> men that <b>once they weaved three</b> fingerbreadths of the length of the garment, <b>they would affix</b> the white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>to</b> the first two corners, even though the garment was not yet long enough to be obligated to have ritual fringes. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should read as follows: <b>Once they completed [<i>shepatzu</i>]</b> the garment until there were only <b>three</b> fingerbreadths left to weave, <b>they would affix</b> the white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>to</b> the first two corners.
The Gemara asks: <b>And do we say: Prepare</b> it, <b>and not from what has already been prepared? Is that so</b> that this principle disqualifies ritual fringes that one affixed to a garment before he was required to do so? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Zeira say:</b> If one <b>affixed</b> ritual fringes <b>to</b> a garment that already had ritual fringes <b>affixed</b> to it and then removed the original strings, it is <b>fit,</b> despite the fact that when he attached the second set they were superfluous? This indicates that even if one attaches ritual fringes to a garment when there is no obligation to attach them, the ritual fringes are fit.
<b>Rava said:</b> This does not present a difficulty, because <b>now</b> that he adds a second, unnecessary set of ritual fringes and <b>is</b> liable <b>for</b> violating the <b>prohibition of adding</b> to a mitzva (see Deuteronomy 13:1), <b>is</b> it <b>not</b> considered <b>an action?</b>
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this: From where</b> is it known <b>that</b> Rabbi Zeira is discussing a case where the <b>person intended to add</b> to the original set of ritual fringes? <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Zeira is discussing a case where <b>he intended to nullify</b> the original strings, <b>and</b> therefore <b>there is no prohibition of adding</b> to a mitzva, and <b>there is an action.</b>
With regard to the issue of affixing ritual fringes to a garment that already has ritual fringes, the Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Zeira says</b> that <b>Rav Mattana says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> White and <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>are not subject to</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds, and</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if they are affixed <b>to a cloak</b> that is <b>exempt</b> from ritual fringes.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by: <b>A cloak</b> that is <b>exempt</b> from ritual fringes? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to a cloak <b>that is not of the size</b> necessary to require the affixing of ritual fringes, that is difficult: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a cloak that</b> is large enough for <b>a minor</b> to <b>cover his head and most of his</b> body <b>with</b> it,

Daf 41a

<b>and an adult goes out</b> in public <b>on occasion</b> while wearing <b>it,</b> it is <b>required</b> to have <b>ritual fringes.</b> But if it is <b>not</b> large enough for <b>a minor</b> to <b>cover his head and most of his</b> body <b>with</b> it, then <b>even if an adult goes out</b> in public <b>on occasion</b> while wearing <b>it,</b> it is <b>exempt</b> from ritual fringes. <b>And so too with regard to diverse kinds,</b> i.e., the prohibition against wearing wool and linen together.
<b>And we discussed it: What</b> is meant by: <b>And so too with regard to diverse kinds? If we say</b> that it means: <b>And so too with regard to the prohibition of diverse kinds,</b> that if a minor could not cover the majority of his head and body with it, the prohibition of diverse kinds does not apply, that is difficult: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Kilayim</i> 9:2): <b>There is no</b> exemption <b>with regard to</b> the prohibition of <b>diverse kinds</b> for clothing that an adult would not wear even <b>occasionally</b> in public?
<b>And Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak says</b> in explanation: Rather, the <i>baraita</i> means: <b>And so too with regard to</b> whether a linen <b>cloak</b> is required <b>to</b> have <b>ritual fringes.</b> If the cloak is large enough for a minor to cover his head and most of his body with it, then it requires ritual fringes, and wearing the garment with the ritual fringes is not a violation of the prohibition of diverse kinds. But if the garment is smaller than that, it is prohibited to place ritual fringes on it, due to the prohibition of diverse kinds. Therefore, one cannot explain Shmuel’s statement to mean that a cloak that is exempt from ritual fringes because it is too small is not subject to the prohibition of diverse kinds.
<b>Rather, what</b> is meant by the statement that a cloak that is <b>exempt</b> from ritual fringes is not subject to the prohibition of diverse kinds? It is referring to where one <b>affixed</b> ritual fringes <b>to</b> a garment that already had ritual fringes <b>affixed</b> to it. Even though the second set of ritual fringes is superfluous, nevertheless there is no violation of the prohibition of diverse kinds.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rabbi Zeira</b> already <b>say this one time</b> when he stated that if one attached ritual fringes to a garment that already had ritual fringes attached to it and he then removed the first set of strings, the garment is fit? The Gemara answers: <b>One was stated from the other by inference,</b> and Rabbi Zeira did not state both statements.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A very long <b>cloak that is folded</b> in half is <b>required</b> to have <b>ritual fringes</b> at the fold. <b>And Rabbi Shimon deems</b> it <b>exempt</b> it from ritual fringes at the fold because that is not where the corners of the garment are located. <b>And</b> Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis <b>agree that if he folded it and sewed it,</b> it is <b>required</b> to have ritual fringes at the fold.
The Gemara challenges: If one <b>sewed it,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that it is required to have ritual fringes at the fold. The Gemara explains: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> because it is referring to a case <b>where he fastened it with pins</b> rather than sewing it in the conventional manner.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabba bar Huna arrived at the house of Rava bar Rav Naḥman,</b> and <b>he saw that</b> Rava bar Rav Naḥman <b>was wearing a cloak that was folded and</b> that he had <b>affixed strings to it on</b> the corners of <b>the fold.</b> The cloak <b>unfolded, and the string</b> that had been on the corner of the fold now <b>came and settled near his head,</b> i.e., in the middle of the cloak, as the two sides of the cloak were in the front and back of Rava bar Rav Naḥman.
Rabba bar Huna <b>said to</b> Rava bar Rav Naḥman: <b>This is not</b> the <b>corner</b> of the garment <b>that the Merciful One writes</b> about <b>in the Torah.</b> Rava bar Rav Naḥman <b>went</b> and <b>threw it off,</b> and <b>he covered himself</b> with <b>a different cloak.</b>
Rabba bar Huna <b>said to</b> Rava bar Rav Naḥman: <b>Do you hold</b> that ritual fringes are <b>an obligation</b> incumbent upon <b>the man?</b> That is not so. Rather, <b>it is an obligation</b> that pertains to every <b>cloak</b> that one owns. Therefore, <b>go</b> and <b>affix</b> ritual fringes <b>to it</b> properly.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that a <i>baraita</i> <b>supports</b> the opinion of Rabba bar Huna: It is told of <b>the early</b> generations of <b>pious</b> men that <b>once they weaved three</b> fingerbreadths <b>of</b> the length of the garment, <b>they would affix</b> the white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>to</b> the first two corners, even though the garment was not yet ready to be worn. This seems to prove that there is an obligation to affix ritual fringes to all the cloaks in one’s possession, even if he is not currently wearing them. The Gemara rejects this proof: The <b>pious</b> men were <b>different, as they would act stringently with themselves.</b> Therefore, one cannot adduce the actual requirement from their behavior.
The Gemara notes that this <b>disagrees with</b> what <b>an angel</b> said. <b>As an angel found Rav Ketina when he was wearing</b> a linen <b>cloak,</b> which is exempt from ritual fringes. The angel <b>said to him: Ketina, Ketina,</b> if you wear a linen <b>cloak in the summer and a coat [<i>sarbela</i>],</b> which has only two corners and is therefore also exempt from ritual fringes, <b>in the winter, what will become of</b> the <b>ritual fringes of sky-blue wool?</b> As a result, you will never fulfill the mitzva.
Rav Ketina <b>said to him: Do you punish</b> us even <b>for</b> failing to fulfill <b>a positive mitzva?</b> The angel <b>said to him: At a time when there is</b> divine <b>anger</b> and judgment, <b>we punish</b> even for the failure to fulfill a positive mitzva.
The Gemara attempts to draw conclusions from the statement of the angel: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the mitzva of ritual fringes <b>is an obligation</b> incumbent upon the <b>man, that is</b> why Rav Ketina would be <b>deemed liable</b> at a time of divine anger, <b>as he did not affix</b> ritual fringes to his cloak and thereby neglected the obligation incumbent upon him. <b>But if you say</b> that it <b>is an obligation</b> to attach them to every <b>cloak</b> that one owns, since Rav Ketina’s cloaks were not required to have ritual fringes, <b>he was not obligated</b> to attach ritual fringes to them. Why should he be punished in a time of divine anger?
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather, what</b> should one assume, that <b>it is an obligation</b> incumbent upon the <b>man?</b> Even so, <b>granted that the Merciful One rendered him obligated when he is wearing a cloak that</b> has four corners and is therefore <b>subject to the obligation</b> of ritual fringes, but <b>when he is wearing a cloak that is not subject to the obligation</b> of ritual fringes, <b>did the Merciful One deem him obligated?</b>
<b>Rather, this</b> is what the angel <b>is saying to</b> Rav Ketina: Are you seeking <b>ploys [<i>tatzdeki</i>] to exempt yourself from</b> performing the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes?</b>
<b>Rav Tovi bar Kisna says</b> that <b>Shmuel says: Garments</b> that are not being worn but are stored in <b>a box are required</b> to have <b>ritual fringes,</b> because the mitzva pertains to the garment, not the man. <b>But Shmuel concedes in</b> the case of <b>an old man, where</b> the garment <b>was made</b> as a shroud <b>in his honor, that</b> the shroud is <b>exempt. What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah that one must place ritual fringes on the corners of garments <b>“with which you cover yourself”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12). <b>This</b> shroud <b>is not made for</b> the purpose of <b>covering</b> oneself.
The Gemara comments: <b>At that time,</b> i.e., a person’s burial, <b>we certainly affix</b> ritual fringes <b>to</b> the shroud, <b>because</b> otherwise it would be a violation of: <b>“Whoever mocks the poor blasphemes his Maker”</b> (Proverbs 17:5). If we did not place them, it would be mocking the deceased, as if to taunt him that now he is no longer obligated in mitzvot.
§ <b>Raḥava says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> In the case of <b>a cloak that became torn</b> at one of its corners, if it was torn <b>beyond three</b> fingerbreadths from the edge of the garment, one <b>may sew</b> it. But if it was torn <b>within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, then one <b>may not sew</b> it. There is a concern that he might use the thread with which he sewed the garment for the ritual fringes, in which case the strings would be unfit due to the principle: Prepare it, and not from what has already been prepared.
The Gemara comments: <b>This</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a cloak that became torn</b> at one of its corners, if it was torn <b>beyond three</b> fingerbreadths from the edge of the garment, one <b>may sew</b> it. But if it was torn <b>within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> One <b>may not sew</b> it. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One <b>may sew</b> it.
<b>And</b> Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis <b>agree that one may not bring</b> a piece of cloth, <b>even</b> if it is <b>a square cubit</b> in size, <b>from elsewhere, containing</b> white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings, <b>and attach</b> it <b>to</b> a cloak. This is because one must attach the ritual fringes directly to the corner of the garment, rather than attaching them to a piece of cloth and then attaching that cloth to the garment. <b>And</b> Rabbi Meir and the Rabbis also <b>agree that one may bring</b> white or <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>from elsewhere and attach</b> them <b>to</b> the garment, i.e., one may remove strings from one garment in order to attach them to another garment.

Daf 41b

This is permitted <b>provided that</b> the strings <b>are not broken.</b> The Gemara asks: Should one <b>conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that it is always permitted to <b>untie</b> ritual fringes <b>from</b> one <b>garment</b> in order to affix them <b>to</b> another <b>garment?</b> The Gemara rejects this inference: <b>Perhaps</b> the ruling of this <i>baraita</i> applies only <b>if</b> the first garment was <b>worn out</b> and no longer wearable.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>a cloak that</b> is made <b>entirely</b> of <b>sky-blue wool,</b> strings of <b>every type of color exempt it,</b> i.e., the ritual fringes that are not <i>tekhelet</i> may be any color <b>except for indigo,</b> a color that is indistinguishable from <i>tekhelet</i>. This indicates that if one attached strings dyed with indigo alongside the strings dyed with <i>tekhelet</i>, the ritual fringes are unfit.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>A cloak</b> is <b>exempted only by</b> strings of <b>its own type.</b> In the case of <b>a cloak that</b> is made <b>entirely</b> of <b>sky-blue wool,</b> one <b>brings sky-blue [<i>tekhelet</i>]</b> strings <b>and something else,</b> i.e., strings of a different color, <b>and attaches</b> them <b>to</b> the cloak. <b>And he may not bring</b> strings dyed with <b>indigo</b> along with the strings dyed with <i>tekhelet</i>. <b>But if he brought</b> strings dyed with indigo together with the strings dyed with <i>tekhelet</i>, the ritual fringes are <b>fit.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said:</b> This is <b>not difficult,</b> because <b>here,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that holds that the ritual fringes are fit after the fact, it is referring <b>to a cloak that has</b> only <b>four strings,</b> two of <i>tekhelet</i> and two of indigo. <b>There,</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that holds that the ritual fringes are unfit after the fact, it is referring <b>to a cloak that has eight strings,</b> four of <i>tekhelet</i> and four of indigo. In this case, the Sages were concerned that one would take the four indigo strings from this garment and use them in another garment, thinking that they were <i>tekhelet</i>.
The Gemara asks: Should <b>you conclude from</b> the fact that the Sages were concerned lest one take the indigo strings from this garment for use in another garment that in general <b>one may untie</b> ritual fringes <b>from</b> one <b>garment</b> in order <b>to</b> affix them to another <b>garment?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>Perhaps</b> their concern was <b>that if</b> one <b>did</b> transfer the strings, he might mistake indigo for <i>tekhelet</i>, but it is not permitted to transfer the strings <i>ab initio</i>.
<b>It was stated</b> that there is a dispute between <i>amora’im</i> with regard to this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Rav says: One may not untie</b> ritual fringes <b>from</b> one <b>garment</b> in order <b>to</b> affix them to another <b>garment. And Shmuel says: One may untie</b> them <b>from</b> one <b>garment</b> and affix them <b>to</b> another <b>garment.</b>
The Gemara cites additional disputes between Rav and Shmuel: <b>Rav says: One may not light from</b> one Hanukkah <b>lamp to</b> another Hanukkah <b>lamp. And Shmuel says: One may light from</b> one Hanukkah <b>lamp to</b> another Hanukkah <b>lamp.</b>
Rabbi Shimon rules that it is permitted to drag items on Shabbat despite the possibility that one might thereby create a furrow in the ground. Creating a furrow is a labor prohibited on Shabbat, but since he does not intend to create the furrow, and it is not certain that a furrow will be created, dragging the item is permitted. <b>Rav says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to dragging</b> items on Shabbat. <b>And Shmuel says</b> that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to dragging</b> items on Shabbat.
<b>Abaye said:</b> In <b>all</b> halakhic <b>matters of the Master,</b> Rabba, <b>he conducted himself in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rav, except these three where he conducted himself in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel.</b> He ruled that <b>one may untie</b> ritual fringes <b>from</b> one <b>garment</b> in order to affix them <b>to</b> another <b>garment, and one may light from</b> one Hanukkah <b>lamp to</b> another Hanukkah <b>lamp, and</b> the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon with regard to dragging</b> items on Shabbat.
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: A person may drag a bed, chair, or bench</b> on the ground on Shabbat, <b>provided that he does not intend to make a furrow</b> in the ground. Even if a furrow is formed inadvertently, one does not need to be concerned.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Yehuda</b> would <b>give</b> his garments containing ritual fringes <b>to a laundryman</b> and was not concerned that the strings dyed with <i>tekhelet</i> might become detached and that the laundryman would replace them with strings dyed with indigo. <b>Rav Ḥanina</b> would <b>form a bundle</b> with his ritual fringes so that they would not become detached while they were being laundered. <b>Ravina</b> would tuck <b>them</b> into a pocket he formed on the garment and <b>sew</b> the cover of the pocket in order to protect the ritual fringes.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How many strings does one place</b> on a garment? <b>Beit Shammai say: Four</b> strings are inserted into the hole in the garment, so that there are eight strings hanging down altogether, <b>and Beit Hillel say: Three</b> strings are inserted into the garment.
<b>And how much should be hanging [<i>meshulleshet</i>]</b> beyond the knots and windings? <b>Beit Shammai say: Four</b> fingerbreadths, <b>and Beit Hillel say: Three</b> fingerbreadths. <b>And</b> the <b>three</b> fingerbreadths <b>that Beit Hillel say</b> should be hanging are each <b>one-fourth of a handbreadth [<i>tefaḥ</i>] of any</b> average <b>person.</b> The Gemara notes that <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The <b>handbreadth of the Torah</b> is <b>four</b> fingerbreadths if measured <b>by</b> the <b>thumb; six</b> fingerbreadths if measured <b>by</b> the <b>smallest</b> finger; and <b>five</b> if measured <b>by</b> the <b>third,</b> i.e., the middle, finger.
<b>Rav Huna says</b> that the <i>halakha</i> is: One must attach <b>four</b> strings <b>within four</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, <b>and</b> they should <b>hang</b> down <b>four</b> fingerbreadths beyond the knots and windings. <b>And Rav Yehuda says:</b> One must attach <b>three</b> strings <b>within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, and they should <b>hang</b> down <b>three</b> fingerbreadths beyond the knots and windings.
<b>Rav Pappa says</b> that <b>the <i>halakha</i></b> is that one must attach <b>four</b> strings <b>within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, and they should <b>hang</b> down <b>four</b> fingerbreadths beyond the knots and windings.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is this to say that</b> ritual fringes <b>have</b> a required <b>measure? And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “That they prepare for themselves <b>strings”</b> (Numbers 15:38). <b>Strings</b> are <b>nothing other than</b> what <b>emerges</b> from the corner of the garment, <b>and</b> the term <b>strings</b> indicates <b>only</b> that there must be strings of <b>any length. And</b> it <b>already</b> occurred that <b>the elders of Beit Shammai and the elders of Beit Hillel ascended to the attic of Yoḥanan ben Beteira, and</b> they discussed the matter and <b>said: Ritual fringes have no measure. Similarly, a <i>lulav</i> has no measure.</b>
<b>What,</b> does this <b>not</b> mean that ritual fringes <b>have no</b> required <b>measure at all?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b>

Daf 42a

the <i>baraita</i> means that ritual fringes <b>do not have a maximum measure,</b> i.e., the strings can be as long as one wants; <b>however, they do have a minimum measure,</b> and if the strings are shorter than this measure they are not fit. <b>As, if you do not say so,</b> in a case <b>similar to it,</b> where it is taught that <b>a <i>lulav</i> has no measure,</b> is it possible <b>that it also has no measure whatsoever?</b>
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Sukka</i> 29b): <b>A <i>lulav</i> that has three handbreadths</b> in length, <b>sufficient</b> to enable one <b>to wave with it,</b> is <b>fit</b> for use in fulfilling the mitzva? This indicates that if the <i>lulav</i> is less than the measure, it is not fit. <b>Rather,</b> it must be that a <i>lulav</i> <b>has no maximum measure, but it does have a minimum measure. So too,</b> ritual fringes <b>have no maximum measure, but they have a minimum measure.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “That they prepare for themselves <b>strings”</b> (Numbers 15:38). The term <b>strings [<i>tzitzit</i>]</b> means <b>nothing other than strings that hang down [<i>anaf</i>], and so it states</b> in the verse: <b>“I was taken by a lock [<i>betzitzit</i>] of my head”</b> (Ezekiel 8:3). <b>And Abaye says: And</b> one is <b>required to separate</b> the ritual fringes <b>like a gentile’s lock</b> of hair, part of which is braided and the rest of which is allowed to hang loose.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>affixed</b> the ritual fringes <b>to</b> the tip of <b>the corner or to the border [<i>gadil</i>],</b> they are <b>fit. Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov disqualifies</b> them <b>in both</b> cases.
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rav Giddel says</b> that <b>Rav says: Ritual fringes must</b> be inserted into a hole above the corner and <b>hang down onto the corner</b> of the garment, <b>as it is stated: “On the corners of their garments”</b> (Numbers 15:38)? <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this? The Gemara answers: It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov.</b>
<b>Rabbi Ya’akov says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And</b> one <b>must distance</b> the hole through which the ritual fringes are inserted into the garment the length of <b>a full thumb joint</b> from the edge of the garment.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it was necessary</b> to state the ruling <b>of Rav Pappa</b> (41b) that the ritual fringes must be inserted into a hole within three fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment, <b>and it was</b> also <b>necessary</b> to state the ruling <b>of Rabbi Ya’akov.</b> This is <b>because if</b> the location of the hole was taught only <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rav Pappa, I would say</b> that his ruling that the hole must be <b>within three</b> fingerbreadths of the edge of the garment was to teach <b>that one may not distance</b> the hole from the edge of the garment by <b>more</b> than this amount, <b>but the closer</b> the hole is to the edge of the garment, <b>the better.</b> Consequently, <b>it was necessary</b> to include the statement <b>of Rabbi Ya’akov.</b>
<b>And if</b> the location of the hole was taught only <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Ya’akov, I would say</b> that his ruling that it must be <b>a full thumb joint</b> away from the edge of the garment was to teach <b>that one may not</b> situate the hole <b>closer</b> than that to the edge of the garment, <b>but the further</b> he places it, <b>the better.</b> Therefore, both statements were <b>necessary.</b>
The Gemara relates that <b>Ravina and Rav Samma were sitting before Rav Ashi. Rav Samma saw that the corner of Ravina’s cloak was torn and</b> therefore the hole through which the ritual fringes were inserted was <b>less than</b> the <b>full</b> length of <b>a thumb joint</b> from the edge of the garment. Rav Samma <b>said to</b> Ravina: <b>Doesn’t the Master hold in accordance with that</b> statement <b>of Rabbi Ya’akov</b> that the hole must be at least the length of a thumb joint from the edge of the garment? Ravina <b>said to</b> Rav Samma: It <b>was stated</b> that this distance is required <b>at the time</b> when the ritual fringes are <b>made.</b> If the corner tears later, causing the hole to be closer to the edge of the garment, the ritual fringes remain fit.
Rav Samma <b>became embarrassed</b> because he had asked his question based on a mistaken assumption. <b>Rav Ashi said to</b> Rav Samma: <b>Do not be upset</b> that Ravina is a greater scholar than you are; <b>one of them,</b> i.e., the Sages of Eretz Yisrael, <b>is like two of us,</b> i.e., the Sages of Babylonia.
§ With regard to attaching ritual fringes to a garment, the Gemara relates that <b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov would affix four</b> strings to the garment, <b>and he would</b> first <b>fold them</b> in half <b>and</b> then <b>insert them</b> at the point of the folds <b>into</b> the hole of <b>the garment,</b> so that on one side there were eight strings and on the other side there were four loops. He would then take the eight strings <b>and loop them</b> through the four loops and pull them tight, thereby attaching them to the garment. The Gemara explains that <b>he held</b> that <b>we require eight</b> strings when they are initially placed <b>in the garment, in order that there be twisted cord</b> and <b>“twisted cords”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12), i.e., four doubled strings, <b>at the place,</b> i.e., the time, when he creates the <b>loose hanging string.</b>
<b>Rav Yirmeya of Difti would affix eight</b> strings <b>that are sixteen</b> strings after they are placed in the hole of the garment and half of each string hangs down on each side, <b>and he would not loop them</b> as Rav Aha bar Ya’akov did. <b>Mar, son of Ravina, would prepare</b> ritual fringes <b>like ours,</b> placing four strings through the hole and allowing both ends of each string to hang down, thereby forming eight.
§ The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Naḥman found Rav Adda bar Ahava affixing strings</b> to a garment <b>and reciting the blessing</b> that concludes: <b>To prepare ritual fringes [<i>tzitzit</i>].</b> Rav Naḥman <b>said to</b> Rav Adda bar Ahava: <b>What</b> is this <b><i>tzitzi</i></b> sound that <b>I hear? This is what Rav says: Ritual fringes do not require a blessing</b> when one attaches them to the garment.
With regard to this statement of Rav, the Gemara relates that <b>when Rav Huna died, Rav Ḥisda went into</b> the study hall <b>to raise a contradiction</b> from one statement <b>of Rav to</b> another statement <b>of Rav,</b> as follows: <b>Did Rav</b> actually <b>say</b> that <b>ritual fringes do not require a blessing</b> when one attaches them to the garment? <b>But doesn’t Rav Yehuda say</b> that <b>Rav says: From where</b> is it derived that <b>ritual fringes</b> attached <b>by a gentile</b> are <b>unfit?</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is stated: “Speak unto the children of Israel</b> and command them <b>that they prepare for themselves strings”</b> (Numbers 15:38). The Sages derive from here that <b>the children of Israel shall prepare</b> ritual fringes, <b>but the gentiles shall not prepare</b> ritual fringes.
The Gemara asks: <b>But what</b> is the <b>contradiction</b> between these two statements of Rav? <b>Rav Yosef said: Rav Ḥisda held</b> that in the case of <b>any mitzva</b> for <b>which</b> the necessary item is <b>fit</b> when produced <b>by a gentile,</b> if it is produced <b>by a Jew, he does not need to recite a blessing.</b> Conversely, <b>any mitzva</b> for <b>which</b> the necessary item is <b>unfit</b> when produced <b>by a gentile,</b> if it is produced <b>by a Jew, he needs to recite a blessing</b> when he produces the item.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is</b> this an established <b>principle? But</b> what about <b>circumcision, which is valid</b> if performed <b>by a gentile, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In <b>a city in which there is no Jewish physician, and in which there is an Aramean,</b> i.e., a gentile, <b>physician and a Samaritan physician,</b> it is preferable that the <b>Aramean circumcise</b> the Jewish boys of the city <b>and</b> the <b>Samaritan not circumcise</b> them; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is preferable that the <b>Samaritan</b> circumcise the boys <b>and</b> the <b>Aramean not</b> circumcise them. Nevertheless, all agree that a circumcision performed by a gentile is valid.
<b>And</b> despite the fact that circumcision performed by a gentile is valid, when it is performed <b>by a Jew, he must recite a blessing, as the Master said: The one who circumcises</b> a child <b>says: Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, <b>Who has sanctified us through His mitzvot and has commanded us concerning circumcision.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Is there reason</b> to resolve the contradiction <b>according to</b> anyone <b>but Rav? Rav</b> himself <b>invalidates</b> circumcision performed by a gentile, <b>as it was stated: From where</b> is it derived <b>that circumcision</b> performed <b>by a gentile</b> is <b>not valid? Daru bar Pappa says in the name of Rav:</b> This is derived from the verse: “And God said unto Abraham: <b>And as for you, you shall keep My covenant,</b> you, and your seed after you throughout their generations” (Genesis 17:9). The verse indicates that only the descendants of Abraham may perform circumcision.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that this <i>halakha</i> is derived from the doubled verb in the verse: <b>“Must be circumcised [<i>himmol yimmol</i>]”</b> (Genesis 17:13), which he interprets to mean: Only <b>one who is circumcised [<i>hammal</i>] may circumcise [<i>yamul</i>]</b> others.
The Gemara notes that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a <i>sukka</i> supports</b> the opinion of Rav Ḥisda, who holds that when an item used for a mitzva can be created by a gentile, a Jew who creates it does not recite a blessing. And the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>phylacteries is a conclusive refutation of his</b> opinion.
The Gemara explains: <b>A <i>sukka</i> is fit</b> even if it was built <b>by a gentile, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>a booth</b> built by <b>gentiles, a booth</b> built by <b>women, a booth for domesticated animals, a booth</b> built by <b>Samaritans, a booth of any sort,</b> each is <b>fit</b> for use as a <i>sukka</i>, <b>provided that it is roofed in accordance with the <i>halakha</i>.</b>
<b>And</b> if a <i>sukka</i> was built <b>by a Jew, he is not required to recite a blessing</b> upon its construction, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One who constructs a <i>sukka</i> for himself recites: Blessed are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, Who has given us life, sustained us, and brought us to this time.</b> When <b>he comes to sit in</b> the <i>sukka</i>, <b>he recites: Blessed are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, Who has sanctified us through His mitzvot and commanded us to reside in the <i>sukka</i>.</b> The Gemara notes that the <i>baraita</i> indicates that he recites a blessing at the time of construction, <b>whereas he does not recite a blessing</b> including the words: <b>To construct a <i>sukka</i>,</b> which confirms the opinion of Rav Ḥisda.
By contrast, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>phylacteries</b> is <b>a conclusive refutation of</b> Rav Ḥisda’s opinion. <b>Phylacteries are unfit</b> when written <b>by a gentile, as it is taught</b> by <b>Rav Ḥinnana, son of Rava,</b>

Daf 42b

<b>of Pashronya: A Torah scroll, phylacteries, or <i>mezuzot</i> that were written by a heretic, a Samaritan, a gentile,</b> a Canaanite <b>slave, a woman, a minor, or a Jewish apostate [<i>meshummad</i>] are unfit, as it is stated: “And you shall bind them</b> for a sign on your arm…<b>and you shall write them</b> on the doorposts of your house” (Deuteronomy 6:8–9). From this juxtaposition, one can derive the following: <b>Anyone who is</b> included <b>in</b> the mitzva of <b>binding</b> the phylacteries, i.e., one who is both obligated and performs the mitzva, <b>is</b> included <b>in</b> the class of people who may <b>write</b> Torah scrolls, phylacteries, and <i>mezuzot</i>; and <b>anyone who is not</b> included <b>in</b> the mitzva of <b>binding is not</b> included <b>in</b> the class of people who may <b>write</b> sacred texts.
<b>And</b> despite the fact that phylacteries written by a gentile are unfit, <b>a Jew</b> who writes them <b>does not have to recite a blessing. As Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Huna, sent</b> a ruling <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: On phylacteries of the arm</b> one <b>says</b> the blessing: <b>Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, W<b>ho has sanctified us through His mitzvot and commanded us to don phylacteries. On phylacteries of the head</b> one <b>says</b> the blessing: <b>Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, <b>Who has sanctified us through His mitzvot and commanded us concerning the mitzva of phylacteries.</b> The implication of this is that one recites blessings only when he dons the phylacteries, <b>whereas</b> when he writes the phylacteries he <b>does not recite a blessing: To prepare phylacteries.</b>
<b>Rather, isn’t this the reason</b> for the distinction between different mitzvot: For <b>any mitzva whose performance is the completion of</b> the <b>mitzva, such as circumcision, even though it is valid</b> when performed <b>by a gentile,</b> when it is performed <b>by a Jew he must recite a blessing. But</b> for <b>any mitzva where the performance of</b> a particular act <b>is not the completion of</b> the <b>mitzva, such as</b> writing <b>phylacteries,</b> where one does not complete the mitzva until he dons them, <b>even though it is not valid</b> when performed <b>by a gentile,</b> when it is performed <b>by a Jew he does not need to recite a blessing.</b>
<b>And with regard to</b> reciting a blessing when one attaches <b>ritual fringes</b> to a garment, the Sages <b>disagree about this:</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Rav Adda bar Ahava, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is an obligation</b> pertaining to the <b>cloak.</b> Therefore, when one attaches the ritual fringes he is completing the mitzva, and he should recite a blessing: To prepare ritual fringes. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Naḥman, citing Rav, <b>holds</b> that <b>it is an obligation</b> incumbent upon <b>the man.</b> Consequently, the mitzva is not complete until he wears the garment, and he should not recite a blessing when he attaches the ritual fringes to the garment.
<b>Rav Mordekhai said to Rav Ashi: You teach this</b> <i>halakha</i> about gentiles attaching ritual fringes to a garment <b>in this manner,</b> citing Rav Yehuda in the name of Rav that the ritual fringes are invalid. Consequently, Rav Ḥisda raises a contradiction between this ruling and another ruling of Rav.
<b>We teach it in this way,</b> according to which there is no contradiction: <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: From where</b> is it derived that if <b>ritual fringes</b> are attached to a garment <b>by a gentile</b> they are <b>valid?</b> It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: “Speak unto the children of Israel</b> and command them <b>that they prepare for themselves [<i>lahem</i>] strings”</b> (Numbers 15:38). From the fact that the verse does not merely state: That they prepare [<i>ve’asu</i>], but rather states “<i>ve’asu lahem</i>,” which can be translated as: That they prepare for them, the indication is that even <b>others,</b> i.e., gentiles, <b>shall prepare</b> ritual fringes <b>for them.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> If <b>one prepared</b> ritual fringes <b>from</b> threads that protrude from the fabric like <b>thorns [<i>kotzim</i>], or</b> if he prepared them <b>from threads [<i>nimin</i>]</b> that were used to sew the garment and remain attached to it, <b>or from the strings [<i>geradin</i>]</b> that hang from the bottom of a garment, the ritual fringes are <b>unfit,</b> as one must attach ritual fringes to a garment for the sake of the mitzva. But if he prepared ritual fringes <b>from swatches</b> of wool that were not spun for the sake of the mitzva, they are <b>fit.</b>
Rav Yehuda continues: <b>When I stated this</b> <i>halakha</i> in the name of Rav <b>before Shmuel,</b> he <b>said</b> to me: <b>Even</b> ritual fringes tied <b>from swatches</b> of wool that were not spun for the sake of the mitzva are <b>unfit,</b> as <b>we require the spinning</b> of the string to be <b>for the sake of</b> the mitzva.
The Gemara notes that this dispute <b>is like</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If one took phylacteries and <b>coated them</b> with <b>gold or patched them</b> with the <b>skin of a non-kosher animal,</b> then <b>they are unfit.</b> But if one patched them with the <b>skin of a kosher animal,</b> then <b>they are fit, and</b> this is so <b>even though he did not prepare</b> the skin <b>for their sake,</b> i.e., for the sake of its use in a mitzva. <b>Rabban Shimon ben Gamliel says: Even</b> if he patched them with the <b>skin of a kosher animal they are unfit, until he prepares them for their sake.</b>
§ <b>Abaye said to Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda: How do you dye this sky-blue wool</b> to be used for ritual fringes? Rav Shmuel bar Rav Yehuda <b>said to</b> Abaye: <b>We bring blood of a <i>ḥilazon</i> and</b> various <b>herbs and put them in a pot</b> and boil them. <b>And</b> then <b>we take a bit</b> of the resulting dye <b>in an egg</b> shell <b>and test it by</b> using it to dye <b>a wad</b> of wool to see if it has attained the desired hue. <b>And</b> then <b>we throw</b> away <b>that egg</b> shell and its contents <b>and burn the wad</b> of wool.
The Gemara comments: <b>Learn from</b> this statement <b>three</b> <i>halakhot</i>: <b>Learn from it</b> that wool that was dyed for the purpose of <b>testing</b> the dye and not for use as ritual fringes is <b>unfit</b> for ritual fringes. Consequently, one burns the wad of wool so that no one will use it for ritual fringes. <b>And learn from it that we require dyeing for the sake of</b> the mitzva. <b>And learn from it</b> that using dye for <b>testing renders</b> all the dye in that vessel <b>unfit.</b> Therefore, some of the dye is removed from the pot before it is tested.
The Gemara challenges: The <i>halakha</i> that wool dyed for the purpose of <b>testing</b> the dye is <b>unfit is</b> the same as the requirement of <b>dyeing for the sake of</b> the mitzva. It is only because the sky-blue strings must be dyed for the sake of the mitzva that wool dyed as a test is unfit for use as ritual fringes, so why are these stated as two <i>halakhot</i>? <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The statement about learning three <i>halakhot</i> <b>employs</b> the style known as: <b>What is the reason,</b> and it means: <b>What is the reason</b> that wool that was dyed for the purpose of <b>testing</b> is <b>unfit?</b> It is <b>because we require dyeing for the sake of</b> the mitzva.
The Gemara notes that the <i>halakha</i> that using the dye for testing renders all the dye in the pot unfit is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <i>Tekhelet</i> dye that was used for <b>testing</b> is <b>unfit, as it is stated</b> concerning the priestly vestments: “And you shall make the robe of the ephod <b>entirely of blue [<i>kelil tekhelet</i>]”</b> (Exodus 28:31), which indicates that the dye must be used exclusively for this purpose, i.e., this must be the first item it is being used to dye. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Dahavai says: Even a second appearance</b> caused by the dye <b>is fit,</b> meaning even if it is the second time that the dye is being used, it is still fit. <b>As it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“And scarlet wool [<i>ushni tola’at</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 14:4), which is interpreted to mean that this may be the second [<i>sheni</i>] usage of the dye.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There is no</b> reliable method of <b>testing sky-blue wool, and</b> therefore <b>it may be purchased only from an expert. There is</b> a method of <b>testing phylacteries</b> to ensure they were written properly, <b>but</b> nevertheless <b>they may be purchased only from an expert. There is</b> a method of <b>testing Torah scrolls and <i>mezuzot</i>, and they may be purchased from anyone.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there no</b> method for <b>testing sky-blue wool? But didn’t Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda, test it</b> to ensure it was dyed with <i>tekhelet</i>? The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for the test, which was carried out <b>with</b> items whose names contain the letters <b><i>gimmel</i>, <i>shin</i>,</b> or <b><i>mem</i>.</b> He would <b>bring alum clay [<i>megavya gila</i>], and water of fenugreek [<i>shavlilta</i>], and urine [<i>meimei raglayim</i>]</b>

Daf 43a

that was <b>forty days old.</b> He would <b>soak</b> the sky-blue wool <b>in</b> this solution <b>from night until morning.</b> If <b>its color would fade [<i>ipparad ḥazutei</i>],</b> the sky-blue wool was determined to be <b>unfit,</b> as it was not dyed with <i>tekhelet</i> derived from a <i>ḥilazon</i>. If <b>its color would not fade,</b> the sky-blue wool was determined to be <b>fit.</b>
<b>And Rav Adda said before Rava in the name of Rav Avira: One brings hard [<i>arkesa</i>] leavened barley</b> dough <b>and bakes</b> the sky-blue wool <b>in it.</b> If the color of the sky-blue wool <b>changes for the better,</b> meaning that the process intensifies the color of the sky-blue wool, then it is <b>fit.</b> If the color of the sky-blue wool changes for the <b>worse,</b> i.e., it fades, then it is <b>unfit. And your mnemonic</b> is: <b>Change</b> reveals <b>falsehood</b> and <b>change</b> reveals <b>truth.</b> All of this indicates that it is possible to test whether sky-blue wool has been dyed with real <i>tekhelet</i>, contrary to the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara explains the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What</b> does it mean <b>when it says: There is no</b> reliable method of <b>testing</b> sky-blue wool? It means that there is no way to test whether it was dyed for the sake of the mitzva or <b>for</b> the purpose of <b>testing</b> the dye.
The Gemara relates that <b>Mar,</b> a Sage <b>from Mashkhei, brought sky-blue</b> wool <b>in the years</b> when <b>Rav Aḥai</b> was a preeminent Sage. <b>They tested it in</b> the manner described by <b>Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda, and its color faded.</b> They then tested it <b>in</b> the manner described by <b>Rav Adda and</b> the color <b>changed for the better.</b>
The Sages <b>thought</b> that the sky-blue wool should be <b>deemed unfit</b> because it did not pass the first test. <b>Rav Aḥai said to them: But</b> how could it be that <b>this</b> wool <b>is not <i>tekhelet</i>,</b> as it failed one of the tests, <b>and is</b> also <b>not indigo,</b> as it passed the other? This is impossible, because it must be one or the other. <b>Rather, conclude from it</b> that these <b><i>halakhot</i> were stated together.</b>
He explains: In a case <b>where we tested</b> the wool <b>in</b> the manner described <b>by Rav Yitzḥak, son of Rav Yehuda,</b> and <b>its color did not fade,</b> it is <b>fit</b> and requires no further testing. If <b>its color faded,</b> then <b>we test it in</b> the manner described <b>by Rav Adda, with hard leavened</b> barley dough. If the color <b>changed for the better</b> it is <b>fit;</b> if the color changed <b>for the worse</b> it is <b>unfit.</b> The Gemara adds: <b>They sent</b> a message <b>from there,</b> i.e., Eretz Yisrael: These <b><i>halakhot</i> were</b> in fact <b>stated together,</b> as explained by Rav Aḥai.
The Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Mani was exacting and purchased</b> sky-blue wool <b>in accordance with the stringencies of the <i>baraita</i></b> cited earlier, i.e., that wool dyed as a test is unfit for ritual fringes, and that therefore one should purchase sky-blue wool for ritual fringes only from an expert. <b>A certain elder said to him: This is what your early predecessors did, and their businesses were successful.</b>
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who purchases a cloak with ritual fringes from the marketplace,</b> if he purchased it <b>from a Jew it retains its presumptive status</b> that it is fit for the mitzva. If he purchased it <b>from a gentile,</b> then if he purchased it <b>from a merchant</b> it is presumed to be <b>fit,</b> as the merchant would want to maintain his credibility and would therefore purchase the sky-blue strings only from a reliable source. But if he purchased it <b>from</b> a gentile who is <b>an ordinary</b> person rather than a professional merchant, the sky-blue strings are <b>unfit,</b> as the seller presumably dyed them himself.
<b>And even though</b> the Sages <b>said: A person is not permitted to sell a cloak with ritual fringes to a gentile until he unties</b> and removes <b>its ritual fringes,</b> it is permitted to purchase such a cloak from a gentile merchant, as it is assumed that the merchant acquired the cloak from a Jew who ignored this <i>halakha</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> for the prohibition against selling a cloak with ritual fringes to a gentile? The Gemara answers: <b>Here they interpreted</b> that it is prohibited <b>because</b> of the concern that the gentile will visit <b>a prostitute</b> and observers will think that he is a Jew. Alternatively, <b>Rav Yehuda said:</b> It is prohibited <b>lest</b> a Jew mistake the gentile for a Jew and <b>accompany him on a journey</b> thinking that he is also Jewish, due to his ritual fringes, <b>and</b> the gentile might then <b>kill him.</b>
§ <b>Rav Yehuda would affix</b> white and <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>to the garment [<i>pirzuma</i>] of his wife. And every morning</b> he would <b>recite the blessing: To wrap ourselves in</b> garments with <b>ritual fringes.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that</b> he would <b>affix</b> ritual fringes to his wife’s garments, it is apparent that <b>he holds</b> that the obligation of ritual fringes is <b>a positive mitzva that is not time-bound,</b> and therefore women are also obligated in it. But if that is his opinion, <b>why</b> did <b>he recite the blessing</b> on ritual fringes <b>each and every morning?</b> In order for the mitzva to not be time-bound, it must apply at night, in which case a new blessing should not be recited in the morning.
The Gemara answers: Rav Yehuda was acting <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>phylacteries, every time one dons them he recites the blessing over them,</b> even several times in one day; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> he should have <b>also</b> recited a blessing <b>every time</b> that he took the cloak off and put it back on, and not merely once a day in the morning. The Gemara answers: <b>Rav Yehuda was a modest man and he did not remove his cloak the entire day.</b> The Gemara asks: In <b>what</b> way is it <b>different from the morning,</b> i.e., why did he recite a blessing in the morning? The Gemara answers: He recited the blessing in the morning <b>when he changed from a nighttime garment to a daytime garment.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Everyone is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes,</b> including <b>priests, Levites, Israelites, converts, women, and</b> Canaanite <b>slaves. Rabbi Shimon deems women exempt, because</b> the mitzva of ritual fringes <b>is a positive, time-bound mitzva, and women are exempt</b> from <b>every positive, time-bound mitzva.</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Everyone is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes,</b> including <b>priests, Levites, and Israelites.</b> The Gemara asks: Isn’t that <b>obvious? As, if priests, Levites, and Israelites were exempt</b> from the mitzva, <b>who</b> then <b>is to be obligated?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>It was necessary for</b> the <i>baraita</i> to mention that <b>priests</b> are obligated to fulfill the mitzva, as <b>it may enter your mind to say</b> as follows: <b>Since it is written: “You shall not wear diverse kinds, wool and linen together. You shall prepare yourself twisted cords</b> upon the four corners of your covering” (Deuteronomy 22:11–12), only <b>one who is not permitted to wear diverse kinds is obligated in</b> the mitzva of <b>ritual fringes.</b> With regard to <b>these priests, since diverse kinds are permitted for them</b> when they perform the Temple service, as the belt of the priestly vestments contains diverse kinds, <b>they should not be obligated</b> in the mitzva of ritual fringes.
Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that <b>although</b> the prohibition of diverse kinds is <b>permitted</b> for them <b>at the time</b> when they perform the Temple <b>service, when</b> it is <b>not the time of</b> the Temple <b>service</b> it is <b>not permitted,</b> and therefore priests are obligated in the mitzva of ritual fringes.
The <i>baraita</i> states that <b>Rabbi Shimon deems women exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Shimon?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that with regard to ritual fringes it is stated: “And it shall be unto you for a fringe, <b>that you may look upon it</b> and remember all the commandments of the Lord” (Numbers 15:39). The term “that you may look” <b>excludes a nighttime garment,</b> as it is dark at night and it is therefore difficult to see.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One may ask: <b>Do you say</b> that the verse serves to <b>exclude a nighttime garment? Or is it</b> to <b>exclude only the garment of a blind person,</b> who is also unable to see his ritual fringes? The <i>tanna</i> explains: <b>When</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “Of your covering, <b>with which you cover yourself”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12), the <b>garment of a blind person is mentioned</b> as being included, as the verse already stated: “Of your covering,” and did not need to state: “With which you cover yourself.” If so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the exclusion: <b>“That you may look upon it”?</b> It must <b>exclude a nighttime garment.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What did you see</b> that led you <b>to include the garment of a blind person</b> from the phrase: “With which you cover yourself,” <b>and to exclude a nighttime garment</b> from the phrase: “That you may look upon it,” rather than including a nighttime garment in the obligation and excluding the garment of a blind person? The Gemara answers: <b>I include the garment of a blind person, which is visible to others,</b> even though the blind person himself cannot see it, <b>and I exclude a nighttime garment, which is not visible</b> even <b>to others.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabbi Shimon,

Daf 43b

<b>what do they do with,</b> i.e., how do they interpret, <b>this</b> verse: <b>“With which you cover yourself”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12)? The Gemara answers that the Rabbis <b>require</b> it <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>“on the four corners of your garment”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:12) indicates that one is required to attach ritual fringes to a garment that has <b>four</b> corners, <b>but not</b> to one that has <b>three</b> corners.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Do you say</b> that a garment with <b>four</b> corners is obligated <b>but not</b> a garment with <b>three</b> corners? <b>Or is it</b> teaching <b>only</b> that a garment with <b>four</b> corners is obligated <b>but not</b> a garment that has <b>five</b> corners? <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “With which you cover yourself,”</b> a garment <b>with five</b> corners <b>is thereby mentioned</b> in the verse as being obligated. Then <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of: <b>“On the four</b> corners of your garment”? It teaches that this obligation is limited to a garment that has <b>four</b> corners, <b>but not</b> to one that has <b>three</b> corners.
The Gemara asks: <b>But what did you see</b> that led you <b>to include</b> a garment <b>with five</b> corners <b>and to exclude</b> a garment <b>with three</b> corners, rather than including a garment with three corners and excluding a garment with five corners? The Gemara answers: <b>I include</b> a garment <b>with five</b> corners, <b>as five includes four, and I exclude</b> a garment <b>with three</b> corners, <b>as three does not include four.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how does <b>Rabbi Shimon</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> that a five-cornered garment is required to have ritual fringes? The Gemara answers: He <b>derives</b> it <b>from</b> the seemingly extraneous word: “With <b>which [<i>asher</i>]</b> you cover yourself” (Deuteronomy 22:12). The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what do <b>the Rabbis</b> derive from this word? The Gemara answers: <b>They do not learn</b> any new <i>halakhot</i> from the word <b>“which [<i>asher</i>].”</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis, what do they do with this</b> phrase: <b>“That you may look upon it”</b> (Numbers 15:39), from which Rabbi Shimon derives that a nighttime garment is exempt? The Gemara answers: <b>They require it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse: <b>“That you may look upon it and remember”</b> (Numbers 15:39), teaches that one should <b>see this mitzva</b> of ritual fringes <b>and remember another mitzva that is contingent on it. And which</b> mitzva <b>is that? It is</b> the mitzva of <b>the recitation of <i>Shema</i>. As we learned</b> in a mishna (Berakhot 9b): <b>From when may one recite <i>Shema</i> in the morning? From when</b> one can <b>distinguish between</b> the <b>sky-blue</b> strings <b>and</b> the <b>white</b> strings of his ritual fringes.
<b>And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>“that you may look upon it and remember”</b> teaches that one should <b>see this mitzva</b> of ritual fringes <b>and remember another mitzva that is adjacent to it</b> in the Torah. <b>And which</b> mitzva <b>is that? It is the mitzva of diverse kinds</b> of wool and linen, <b>as it is written: “You shall not wear diverse kinds, wool and linen together. You shall prepare yourself twisted cords”</b> (Deuteronomy 22:11–12).
It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“That you may look upon it and remember all the commandments of the Lord”</b> (Numbers 15:39). This indicates that <b>once a person is obligated in this mitzva</b> of ritual fringes, <b>he is obligated in all of the mitzvot.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>And this is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who says</b> that ritual fringes are <b>a positive, time-bound mitzva,</b> and women are exempt from it. Only men are obligated in all mitzvot, including positive, time-bound mitzvot, just as they are obligated in the mitzva of ritual fringes.
It <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“That you may look upon it and remember all the commandments of the Lord”;</b> this teaches that <b>this mitzva</b> of ritual fringes <b>is equivalent to all the mitzvot</b> of the Torah.
<b>And</b> it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“That you may look upon it and remember</b> all the commandments of the Lord <b>and do</b> them.” This teaches that <b>looking</b> at the ritual fringes <b>leads to remembering</b> the mitzvot, and <b>remembering</b> them <b>leads to doing</b> them. <b>And Rabbi Shimon bar Yoḥai says: Anyone who is diligent in this mitzva</b> of ritual fringes <b>merits receiving the Divine Presence.</b> It is <b>written here: “That you may look upon it [<i>oto</i>]”</b> (Numbers 15:39), <b>and it is written there: “You shall fear the Lord your God; and Him [<i>oto</i>] shall you serve”</b> (Deuteronomy 6:13). Just as <i>oto</i> in that verse is referring to the Divine Presence, so too in this verse it is referring to the Divine Presence.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Jewish people are beloved, as the Holy One, Blessed be He, surrounded them with mitzvot:</b> They have <b>phylacteries on their heads, and phylacteries on their arms, and ritual fringes on their garments, and a <i>mezuza</i> for their doorways. Concerning them David said: “Seven times a day I praise You, because of Your righteous ordinances”</b> (Psalms 119:164). This alludes to the two phylacteries, the four ritual fringes, and the <i>mezuza</i>, which total seven.
<b>And when David entered the bathhouse and saw himself standing naked, he said: Woe to me that that I stand naked without</b> any <b>mitzva. But once he remembered the</b> mitzva of <b>circumcision that was in his flesh his mind was put at ease,</b> as he realized he was still accompanied by this mitzva. <b>After he left</b> the bathhouse, <b>he recited a song about</b> the mitzva of circumcision, <b>as it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“For the leader, on the <i>Sheminith</i>: A Psalm of David”</b> (Psalms 12:1). This is interpreted as a psalm <b>about circumcision, which was given</b> to be performed <b>on the eighth [<i>bashemini</i>]</b> day of the baby’s life.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: Anyone who has phylacteries on his head, phylacteries on his arm, ritual fringes on his garment, and a <i>mezuza</i> on his doorway is strengthened</b> from <b>all</b> sides <b>so that he will not sin, as it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“And a threefold cord is not quickly broken”</b> (Ecclesiastes 4:12). This is interpreted as an allusion to the three mitzvot of phylacteries, ritual fringes, and <i>mezuza</i>. <b>And</b> the verse <b>states: “The angel of the Lord encamps round about them that fear Him, and delivers them”</b> (Psalms 34:8). This is interpreted to mean that the angel of the Lord surrounds those who fulfill the mitzvot and saves them from sin.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: What is different about <i>tekhelet</i> from all</b> other <b>types of colors</b> such that it was chosen for the mitzva of ritual fringes? It is <b>because <i>tekhelet</i> is similar</b> in its color <b>to</b> the <b>sea, and</b> the <b>sea is similar to</b> the <b>sky, and</b> the <b>sky is similar to the Throne of Glory, as it is stated:</b> “And they saw the God of Israel; <b>and there was under His feet the like of a paved work of sapphire stone, and the like of the very heaven for clearness”</b> (Exodus 24:10), indicating that the sky is like a sapphire brickwork. <b>And it is written: “The likeness of a throne, as the appearance of a sapphire stone”</b> (Ezekiel 1:26).
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say:</b> The <b>punishment for</b> not attaching <b>white</b> strings is <b>greater than the punishment for</b> not attaching <b>sky-blue</b> strings, despite the fact that the sky-blue strings are more important. Rabbi Meir illustrates this with <b>a parable: To what is this matter comparable?</b> It is comparable <b>to a king of flesh and blood who said to his two subjects</b> that they must bring him a seal. The king <b>said to one</b> of them: <b>Bring me a seal of clay, and he said to</b> the other <b>one: Bring me a seal of gold. And both of them were negligent and did not bring</b> the seals. <b>Which of them</b> will have <b>a greater punishment? You must say</b> that it is <b>this</b> one <b>to whom he said: Bring me a seal of clay, and</b> despite its availability and low cost, he <b>did not bring</b> it.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: A person is obligated to recite one hundred blessings every day, as it is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“And now, Israel, what [<i>ma</i>] does the Lord your God require of you”</b> (Deuteronomy 10:12). Rabbi Meir interprets the verse as though it said one hundred [<i>me’a</i>], rather than <i>ma</i>.
The Gemara relates that <b>on Shabbat and Festivals,</b> when the prayers contain fewer blessings, <b>Rav Ḥiyya, son of Rav Avya, made an effort to fill</b> this quota of blessings <b>with</b> blessings on <b>spices [<i>be’isparmakei</i>] and sweet fruit,</b> of which he would partake in order to recite extra blessings.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Meir would say: A man is obligated to recite three blessings every day</b> praising God for His kindnesses, and <b>these</b> blessings <b>are: Who did not make me a gentile; Who did not make me a woman;</b> and <b>Who did not make me an ignoramus.</b>
<b>Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov heard his son reciting the blessing: Who did not make me an ignoramus.</b> Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov <b>said to him:</b> Is it <b>in fact</b> proper to go <b>this far</b> in reciting blessings? Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov’s son <b>said to him: Rather, what blessing</b> should one <b>recite?</b> If you will say that one should recite: <b>Who did not make me a slave, that is</b> the same as <b>a woman;</b> why should one recite two blessings about the same matter? Rav Aḥa bar Ya’akov answered: Nevertheless, <b>a slave</b>

Daf 44a

is <b>more lowly</b> than a woman, and therefore it is appropriate to recite an additional blessing on not having been born a slave.
§ <b>The Sages taught: This <i>ḥilazon</i>,</b> which <b>is</b> the source of the sky-blue dye used in ritual fringes, has the following characteristics: <b>Its body resembles the sea, its form resembles</b> that of <b>a fish, it emerges once in seventy years, and with its blood one dyes</b> wool <b>sky-blue</b> for ritual fringes. It is scarce, and <b>therefore it is expensive.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Natan says: There is no mitzva,</b> however <b>minor, that is written in the Torah, for which there is no reward given in this world; and in the World-to-Come I do not know how much</b> reward is given. <b>Go and learn from</b> the following incident concerning <b>the mitzva of ritual fringes.</b>
There was <b>an incident involving a certain man who was diligent about the mitzva of ritual fringes.</b> This man <b>heard that there was a prostitute in</b> one of <b>the cities overseas who took four hundred gold coins as her payment. He sent her four hundred gold coins and fixed a time to</b> meet with <b>her. When his time came, he came and sat at the entrance</b> to her house.
<b>The maidservant of</b> that prostitute <b>entered and said to her: That man who sent you four hundred gold coins came and sat at the entrance. She said: Let him enter. He entered. She arranged seven beds for him, six of silver and one of gold. Between each and every one</b> of them there was <b>a ladder</b> made <b>of silver, and the top</b> bed was the one that was made <b>of gold.</b>
<b>She went up and sat naked on the top</b> bed, <b>and he too went up</b> in order <b>to sit naked facing her.</b> In the meantime, <b>his four ritual fringes came and slapped him on his face. He dropped down and sat himself on the ground, and she also dropped down and sat on the ground. She said to him:</b> I take an oath by the <b><i>gappa</i> of Rome that I will not allow you</b> to go <b>until you tell me what defect you saw in me.</b>
<b>He said to her:</b> I take an oath by <b>the Temple</b> service <b>that I never saw a woman as beautiful as you. But</b> there is <b>one mitzva</b> that <b>the Lord, our God, commanded us, and its name is ritual fringes, and in</b> the passage where <b>it</b> is commanded, <b>it is written twice: “I am the Lord your God”</b> (Numbers 15:41). The doubling of this phrase indicates: <b>I am the one who will punish</b> those who transgress My mitzvot, <b>and I am the one who will reward</b> those who fulfill them. <b>Now,</b> said the man, the four sets of ritual fringes <b>appeared to me as</b> if they were <b>four witnesses</b> who will testify against me.
<b>She said to him: I will not allow you</b> to go <b>until you tell me: What is your name, and what is the name of your city, and what is the name of your teacher, and what is the name of the study hall in which you studied Torah? He wrote</b> the information <b>and placed</b> it <b>in her hand.</b>
<b>She arose and divided all of her property,</b> giving <b>one-third</b> as a bribe <b>to the government, one-third to the poor, and she took one-third</b> with her <b>in her possession, in addition to those beds</b> of gold and silver.
<b>She came to the study hall of Rabbi Ḥiyya</b> and <b>said to him: My teacher, instruct</b> your students <b>concerning me and</b> have them <b>make me a convert.</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya <b>said to her: My daughter, perhaps you set your sights on one of the students</b> and that is why you want to convert? <b>She took</b> the <b>note</b> the student had given her <b>from her hand and gave it to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya. <b>He said to her: Go take possession of your purchase.</b>
<b>Those beds that she had arranged for him in a prohibited</b> fashion, <b>she</b> now <b>arranged for him in a permitted</b> fashion. The Gemara completes its point about the reward of mitzvot and points out how this story illustrates the concept: <b>This is the reward given to him in this world, and</b> with regard <b>to the World-to-Come, I do not know how much</b> reward he will be given.
§ <b>Rav Yehuda says:</b> In the case of <b>a borrowed cloak, for</b> the first <b>thirty days it is exempt from ritual fringes; from then on</b> it is <b>obligated.</b>
The Gemara notes: <b>That</b> distinction <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of <b>one who resides in a guesthouse [<i>pundaki</i>] in Eretz Yisrael, or one who rents a house outside of Eretz Yisrael, for</b> the first <b>thirty days</b> he is <b>exempt from the</b> mitzva of <b><i>mezuza</i>; from then on</b> he is <b>obligated. But one who rents a house in Eretz Yisrael</b> must <b>affix a <i>mezuza</i> immediately, due to</b> the <b>settlement of Eretz Yisrael.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: Absence of the <b>phylacteries of</b> the <b>arm does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva of the phylacteries of the head, and absence of the phylacteries of the head does not prevent fulfillment of the mitzva of the phylacteries of the arm. <b>Rav Ḥisda said: They taught</b> this <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one has</b> the other phylacteries, but they are not with him or he is unable to wear them for some reason. <b>But</b> if <b>he does not have</b> the other phylacteries at all, then their absence <b>does prevent</b> the fulfillment of the mitzva to don the phylacteries that he has.
Later on, the students <b>said to him:</b> Do <b>you</b> still <b>say</b> that? Rav Ḥisda <b>said to them: No, rather</b> I would say the opposite: Concerning <b>one who does not have</b> the ability to fulfill <b>two mitzvot, should he also not perform</b> the <b>one mitzva</b> that he does have the ability to fulfill? The Gemara asks: <b>And what did he hold initially</b> when he said not to don one of the phylacteries in the absence of the other? The Gemara answers: He held that it was due to a rabbinic <b>decree, lest he be negligent</b> and not try to acquire the phylacteries that he lacks.
<b>Rav Sheshet says: Anyone who does not don phylacteries violates eight positive mitzvot.</b> This is referring to the mitzva to don phylacteries of the arm and head, each of which is mentioned in four different passages (Exodus 13:9; Exodus 13:16; Deuteronomy 6:8; Deuteronomy 11:18).
<b>And anyone who does not have ritual fringes on his garments violates five positive mitzvot.</b> This is because the mitzva of ritual fringes is stated four times in the primary passage concerning ritual fringes in Numbers: “That they prepare for themselves strings…and they shall put on the fringe of the corner a sky-blue thread. And it shall be to you for a fringe that you may look upon it and remember all the commandments of the Lord” (Numbers 15:38–39). An additional command appears in the verse: “You shall prepare yourself twisted cords” (Deuteronomy 22:12).
<b>And any priest who does not ascend the platform</b> to recite the Priestly Benediction <b>violates three positive mitzvot</b> expressed in the verses: “So you shall bless the children of Israel; you shall say to them” (Numbers 6:23), and: “And they shall put My name upon the children of Israel” (Numbers 6:27).
<b>Anyone who does not have a <i>mezuza</i> in his doorway violates two positive mitzvot,</b> stated in the verses: <b>“And you shall write them</b> on the doorposts of your house” (Deuteronomy 6:9), and: <b>“And you shall write them</b> on the doorposts of your house” (Deuteronomy 11:20).
<b>And Reish Lakish says: Anyone who dons phylacteries lives</b> a <b>long life, as it is stated:</b>

Daf 44b

<b>“The Lord is upon them, they will live, and altogether therein is the life of my spirit; and have me recover, and make me to live”</b> (Isaiah 38:16). This is interpreted as referring to those who don phylacteries, which contain the name of the Lord, on their heads; as a result, they will live, be healed and merit long life.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The mishna returns to discussing the <i>halakhot</i> of meal offerings, which are the central theme of this tractate. The absence of <b>the fine flour and the oil</b> for the meal offering accompanying burnt offerings and peace offerings <b>does not prevent</b> libation of <b>the wine, and</b> the absence of <b>the wine</b> for libation <b>does not prevent</b> sacrifice of the flour and the oil. Failure to perform some of <b>the placements</b> of blood <b>on the external altar does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the other</b> placements, as even if the priest performed only one placement of blood, the offering effects atonement after the fact.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse concerning the additional offerings sacrificed on <i>Sukkot</i> and the Eighth Day of Assembly states: <b>“And their meal offering and their libations</b> for the bulls, for the rams and for the lambs” (Numbers 29:18). This indicates that after the animal is sacrificed, one must <b>bring</b> the <b>meal offering and then bring</b> the <b>libations.
