Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that since the verse states: “To bring an offering made by fire to the Lord, a burnt offering, and a meal offering, <b>an animal offering, and libations,</b> each on its own day” (Leviticus 23:37), one must <b>bring</b> the <b>animal offering and then bring</b> the <b>libations,</b> and only then bring the meal offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>also, isn’t it written: “And their meal offering and their libations,”</b> indicating that the meal offering precedes the libations? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary</b> in order <b>to</b> teach that once the animals have been sacrificed during the day, <b>their meal offering and their libations</b> may be offered even <b>at night, and</b> similarly, <b>their meal offering and their libations</b> may be offered even <b>the next day.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>the Rabbis also, isn’t it written: “An animal offering, and libations,”</b> indicating that the libations immediately follow the animal offering and precede the meal offering? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary to</b> teach that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Ze’eiri, as Ze’eiri says:</b> The <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings <b>are consecrated only through the slaughter of the animal offering.</b> This means that once the animal is slaughtered, the libations that were set aside to be brought with that animal offering cannot be diverted to accompany a different animal offering.
The Gemara points out that both opinions remain difficult: <b>But Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi should <b>also require</b> the phrase “an animal offering, and libations” <b>to</b> teach that the <i>halakha</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Ze’eiri. And the Rabbis</b> should <b>also require</b> the phrase “and their meal offering and their libations” <b>to</b> indicate that <b>their meal offering and their libations</b> may be offered even <b>at night, and their meal offering and their libations</b> may be offered even <b>the next day.</b>
The Gemara offers a different explanation of the dispute in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rather, this is the reasoning of the Rabbis, as it is written</b> in the verse: “To bring an offering made by fire to the Lord, <b>a burnt offering, and a meal offering,</b> an animal offering, and libations, each on its own day.” The Rabbis derive from this that the meal offering should be offered immediately following the animal burnt offering. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> according to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>also, isn’t it written: “A burnt offering, and a meal offering”?</b>
<b>Rather, with regard to</b> libations that <b>accompany an animal offering, everyone agrees that</b> the <b>meal offering</b> should be brought <b>and afterward</b> the <b>libations</b> should be brought, <b>as it is written: “A burnt offering, and a meal offering.” When they disagree</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> meal offerings and libations that are <b>brought by themselves. The Rabbis hold</b> that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that</b> when meal offerings and libations <b>accompany offerings,</b> the <b>meal offerings</b> are brought <b>and then</b> the <b>libations</b> are brought, it can be derived that when they are brought <b>by themselves also,</b> first the <b>meal offering</b> is brought <b>and then</b> the <b>libations</b> are brought.
<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi holds that <b>it is</b> specifically <b>there,</b> in the case of meal offerings and libations that accompany an animal offering, that the meal offering is burned on the altar before the wine libation is poured on the altar. This is <b>because since</b> the altar <b>has started</b> to <b>eat,</b> i.e., consume, the animal offering, one must first <b>complete the entire matter of</b> the altar’s <b>eating,</b> including the meal offering. The pouring of the wine on the altar is likened more to drinking than to eating. <b>But</b> when the meal offering and the libations are brought <b>by themselves,</b> the <b>libations are</b> considered <b>preferable, because</b> the <b>song</b> of the Levites <b>is recited over them.</b> Consequently, the pouring of the libations precedes the burning of the meal offering on the altar.
§ The mishna teaches: Failure to perform some of <b>the placements</b> of blood <b>on the external altar does not prevent</b> fulfillment of the mitzva <b>with the other</b> placements, as even if the priest performed only one placement, the offering effects atonement after the fact.
Apropos this statement, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived with regard <b>to all</b> offerings <b>whose</b> blood is to be <b>placed on the external altar that</b> if <b>one placed their</b> blood <b>with one</b> act of <b>placement,</b> as opposed to the two or four that are required depending upon the offering, <b>that</b> the offering has nevertheless <b>effected atonement</b> after the fact, i.e., one has fulfilled his obligation to bring the offering? <b>As it is stated: “And the blood of your offerings shall be poured out against the altar of the Lord your God”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:27).
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Failure to sacrifice one of <b>the bulls, the rams, the sheep, or the goats</b> of the additional offerings brought on Festivals <b>does not prevent</b> the sacrifice of <b>the others. Rabbi Shimon says: If</b> the Temple treasurers <b>had</b> sufficient funds for the <b>numerous bulls</b> that are required to be sacrificed on that day <b>but they did not</b> also <b>have</b> sufficient funds for the accompanying <b>libations,</b> they should rather <b>bring one bull and</b> its <b>libations, and they should not sacrifice all of them without libations.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>these bulls,</b> rams, <b>and sheep</b> mentioned in the mishna, <b>on which</b> festival are they offered? <b>If we say</b> that these are the offerings <b>of the festival</b> of <i>Sukkot</i>, this is difficult: <b>It is written with regard to those</b> days that their offerings must be brought: <b>“According to the ordinance”</b> (see, e.g., Numbers 29:18), and: <b>“According to their ordinance”</b> (Numbers 29:33). This indicates that no deviation from the Torah’s prescription is possible.
<b>Rather,</b> the mishna must be referring to the two bulls, one ram, and seven sheep <b>of the New Moon and <i>Shavuot</i>,</b> as mentioned in <b>the book of Numbers</b> (28:11, 27).

Daf 45a

The Gemara asks: The mishna mentioned <b>rams,</b> in plural; <b>on which</b> festival are multiple rams offered? <b>If</b> the mishna is referring to the additional offerings sacrificed <b>on those</b> days of the new moon and <i>Shavuot</i> as prescribed in the book of Numbers, these offerings include only one <b>ram</b> and not two. And <b>if</b> it is referring to the two rams <b>of <i>Shavuot</i></b> that accompany the two loaves, as prescribed <b>in Leviticus,</b> a term of <b>being is written about them</b> in the verse: “They shall be a burnt offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 23:18). This term indicates that the offerings must be sacrificed exactly as prescribed in order to be valid. Consequently, one may not sacrifice fewer than two rams.
The Gemara answers: <b>Actually,</b> it is referring to the two rams <b>of <i>Shavuot</i></b> that are prescribed <b>in Leviticus, and this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> Failure to sacrifice the <b>rams</b> that accompany the two loaves, as prescribed <b>in Leviticus, does not prevent</b> the sacrifice of the <b>ram</b> of the additional offering prescribed <b>in the book of Numbers.</b> Similarly, failure to sacrifice the <b>ram</b> of the additional offering, prescribed <b>in the book of Numbers, does not prevent</b> the sacrifice of the <b>rams</b> that accompany the two loaves, as prescribed <b>in Leviticus.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if that is the explanation, then when the mishna mentions <b>bulls</b> and sheep it means <b>that even</b> the bulls or sheep of the additional offering prescribed in the book of Numbers <b>do not prevent each other</b> from being sacrificed, i.e., the inability to sacrifice one of the bulls or sheep does not prevent one from sacrificing the rest. <b>But</b> when the mishna mentions <b>rams, it is the</b> rams mentioned <b>here</b> in Leviticus <b>that do not prevent</b> sacrifice of the rams mentioned <b>there,</b> in Numbers, and vice versa; but the failure to sacrifice one of <b>those</b> rams in Leviticus <b>does prevent</b> sacrifice of the other. Consequently, although the mishna mentions bulls, rams, and sheep together, the <i>halakha</i> is not the same with regard to these different animals.
The Gemara responds: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of the mishna <b>teaches each statement</b> individually, i.e., the <i>halakha</i> applies to each of the animals listed in a different manner.
§ The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the offerings sacrificed on the New Moon: The verse states: <b>“And on the day of the new moon, a young bull without blemish; and six lambs, and a ram; they shall be without blemish”</b> (Ezekiel 46:6) The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Why</b> does <b>the verse state “a bull”</b> when the verse in the Torah requires two bulls, as it is stated: “And on your New Moons you shall present a burnt offering to the Lord: Two young bulls, and one ram, seven lambs of the first year without blemish” (Numbers 28:11)?
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Since</b> it <b>is stated in the Torah</b> with regard to the offering of the New Moon: “Two young <b>bulls,”</b> one might think that it is not acceptable to bring fewer than two bulls under any circumstances. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> one <b>did not find two</b> bulls, <b>he brings one?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “A young <b>bull,”</b> in the singular, to teach that even if one has only one bull it should be sacrificed.
The <i>baraita</i> discusses the continuation of the verse in Ezekiel, which mentions <b>“six lambs.” Why</b> does <b>the verse state</b> only six lambs when the verse in the Torah requires seven? The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>Since it is stated in the Torah</b> with regard to the offering of the New Moon: <b>“Seven</b> lambs,” one might think that it is not acceptable to bring fewer than seven lambs under any circumstances. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that if</b> one <b>did not find seven</b> lambs, <b>he should bring six? Therefore, the verse</b> in Ezekiel <b>states: “Six</b> lambs,” to teach that in the absence of all seven lambs one should sacrifice six.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if he did not find six</b> lambs, <b>he should bring five;</b> and that if he did not find <b>five</b> lambs, <b>he should bring four;</b> and that if he did not find <b>four</b> lambs, <b>he should bring three;</b> and that if he did not find <b>three</b> lambs, <b>he should bring two; and</b> that if he could not find even two lambs, he should bring <b>even one</b> lamb? Therefore, <b>the</b> next <b>verse</b> in Ezekiel <b>states: “And for the lambs as his means suffice”</b> (Ezekiel 46:7), indicating that one should bring however many lambs one is able to bring.
The Gemara asks: <b>But once this is written, why do I</b> need the previous verse to state <b>“six lambs,”</b> indicating that if one does not have seven lambs he should bring six? The Gemara answers: It teaches <b>that</b> although the minimal obligation is satisfied with even one lamb, nevertheless, <b>to the degree that it is possible to seek</b> more lambs, <b>we seek</b> them.
The Gemara presents another <i>halakha</i> derived from these verses: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> failure to slaughter some of the required two bulls and seven sheep of the additional offering on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>prevents</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the others?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>the verse states: “They shall be”</b> (Numbers 28:31); the term “they shall be” indicates that the offerings must be brought precisely as prescribed.
§ The Gemara discusses the meaning of another difficult verse in Ezekiel: <b>“So says the Lord God: In the first month, on the first day of the month, you shall take a young bull without blemish; and you shall purify [<i>veḥitteita</i>] the Sanctuary”</b> (Ezekiel 45:18). The Gemara asks: Since this verse speaks of the first of Nisan, which is a New Moon, why does it state <b>“you shall purify [<i>ḥitteita</i>],”</b> which indicates the sacrifice of a sin offering [<i>ḥatat</i>], when in fact each of the two the bulls sacrificed on the New Moon <b>is a burnt offering</b> (see Numbers 28:11)? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This passage</b> is indeed difficult, and in the <b>future Elijah</b> the prophet <b>will interpret it.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi says:</b> It is possible to explain that this verse is not referring to the additional offerings sacrificed on the New Moon but rather to the offerings of the <b>inauguration</b> that <b>they sacrificed</b> later <b>in the days of Ezra, similar to</b> the offerings <b>that were sacrificed</b> during the period of inauguration of the Tabernacle <b>in the days of Moses.</b> When the Temple service was restored in the Second Temple, the Jewish people observed eight days of inauguration, initiating the priests in the Temple service, from the twenty-third of Adar through the New Moon of Nisan. During these eight days, they offered a bull for a sin offering in addition to the offerings of the inauguration, just as had been done at the inauguration of the Tabernacle (see Leviticus 9:2).
The Gemara comments that <b>this</b> discussion with regard to the interpretation of the verse in Ezekiel <b>is also taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: This passage</b> is indeed difficult, but in the <b>future Elijah</b> the prophet <b>will interpret it. Rabbi Yosei said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: This verse is referring to the offerings of the <b>inauguration</b> that <b>they sacrificed</b> later <b>in the days of Ezra, similar to</b> the offerings <b>that were sacrificed</b> during the period of inauguration <b>in the days of Moses.</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei: <b>May your mind be at ease, as you have put my mind at ease</b> with this interpretation of the verse.
§ The Gemara discusses the meaning of another difficult verse in Ezekiel: <b>“The priests shall not eat of anything that dies of itself, or is torn, whether it be fowl or beast”</b> (Ezekiel 44:31). The Gemara asks: <b>Is it</b> only the <b>priests who may not eat</b> an unslaughtered animal carcass or an animal that was torn and now has a wound that will cause it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], <b>but</b> an ordinary <b>Jew may eat</b> them? In fact, these items are prohibited for consumption by all. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: This passage</b> is indeed difficult, but in the <b>future Elijah</b> the prophet <b>will interpret it.</b>
<b>Ravina said</b> that it <b>was necessary for</b> the verse to emphasize that these prohibitions apply to <b>priests</b> for the following reason: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since pinching is permitted with regard to</b> priests, therefore an animal <b>carcass or a <i>tereifa</i> should also be permitted</b> for them. A bird sin offering is killed by a priest pinching the nape of its neck. This is not a valid method of slaughter and would generally render a bird or animal an unslaughtered carcass, yet the priests are permitted to partake of the bird sin offering. Consequently, one might think that the prohibitions against eating an animal carcass or a <i>tereifa</i> in general do not apply to priests. Therefore, the verse <b>teaches us</b> that these prohibitions apply to priests as well.
§ The Gemara discusses the meaning of another difficult verse in Ezekiel: <b>“And so shall you do on the seventh of the month for every one that errs, and for him that is simple; so shall you make atonement for the house”</b> (Ezekiel 45:20). The Gemara asks: What is the meaning of the expression “on the <b>seventh</b> of the month”? There are no special offerings that are sacrificed on the seventh day of any month.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The verse must be reinterpreted as referring to the bull for an unwitting communal sin, which is brought when the majority of the Jewish people have sinned as a result of following a mistaken ruling of the Sanhedrin. <b>These</b> seven alluded to in the verse are <b>seven tribes who sinned.</b> In such a case, a bull for an unwitting communal sin is brought <b>even though</b> the number of individuals who sinned <b>are not the majority of the congregation.</b> Because the majority of the individuals in the majority of the tribes have sinned, it is considered a sin of the congregation and not sins of many individuals.
Similarly, the word <b>“month [<i>ḥodesh</i>]”</b> is to be interpreted as meaning that a bull for an unwitting communal sin is brought <b>if</b> the court <b>innovated [<i>ḥiddeshu</i>]</b> a new <i>halakha</i> contradicting the Torah, e.g., if <b>they said</b> that eating forbidden <b>fat</b> is <b>permitted.</b> The continuation of the verse: <b>“For every one that errs, and for him that is simple,” teaches that</b> the Sanhedrin is <b>liable</b> to sacrifice the bull for unwitting communal sin <b>only for a matter</b> that was <b>hidden</b> from the Sanhedrin, i.e., about which the Sanhedrin issued a mistaken ruling, and <b>accompanied by unwitting action</b> by the majority of the community, who relied on the mistaken ruling.
The Gemara concludes the discussion of specific difficult verses in Ezekiel with the following general statement: <b>Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Rav says: That man is remembered for good, and Ḥanina ben Ḥizkiyya is his name. As were it not for him, the book of Ezekiel would have been suppressed</b> and not included in the biblical canon, <b>because</b> various details of <b>its contents</b> appear to <b>contradict statements of the Torah. What did</b> Ḥanina ben Ḥizkiyya <b>do? He brought up</b> to his upper story <b>three hundred jugs [<i>garbei</i>] of oil</b> for light so that he could study even at night, <b>and he sat</b> isolated <b>in the upper story and</b> did not move from there until <b>he homiletically interpreted</b> all of those verses in the book of Ezekiel that seemed to contradict verses in the Torah.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: If</b> the Temple treasurers <b>had</b> sufficient funds for the <b>numerous bulls</b> that are required to be sacrificed on that day but they did not also have sufficient funds for the accompanying libations, they should rather bring one bull and its libations, and they should not sacrifice all of them without libations.
Concerning this, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And he shall prepare a meal offering, an ephah for the bull, and an ephah for the ram, and for the lambs as his means suffice, and a <i>hin</i> of oil to an ephah”</b> (Ezekiel 46:7). <b>Rabbi Shimon says: Is the measure of</b> the meal offering accompanying <b>bulls and rams the same,</b> as stated in this verse that it is an ephah for each? In fact, this is not the <i>halakha</i>, as the meal offering accompanying a bull is three-tenths of an ephah of fine flour (see Numbers 15:9), whereas the meal offering accompanying a ram is only two-tenths of an ephah (see Numbers 15:6).
<b>Rather,</b> the verse teaches <b>that if</b> the Temple treasurers <b>had</b> sufficient funds for the <b>numerous bulls</b> that are required to be sacrificed on that day <b>but they did not</b> also <b>have</b> sufficient funds for the accompanying <b>libations, they should bring one bull and its libations, and they should not sacrifice all of them without libations. And</b> similarly, <b>if</b> the Temple treasurers <b>had</b> sufficient funds for

Daf 45b

the <b>numerous rams</b> t hat are required to be sacrificed on that day <b>and they did not</b> also <b>have</b> sufficient funds for the <b>ephah,</b> i.e., the prescribed measure, of flour <b>for</b> all of the rams, <b>they should bring one ram and its ephah</b> of flour, <b>and they should not sacrifice all of them without their ephahs</b> of flour.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> On <i>Shavuot</i> there is an obligation to sacrifice burnt offerings, a sin offering, and peace offerings together with the offering of the two loaves. The burnt offerings consists of a bull, two rams, and seven sheep. A goat is brought for the sin offering. Two sheep are brought as peace offerings and waved together with the two loaves. Failure to sacrifice <b>the bull, the rams, and the sheep,</b> which are all brought as burnt offerings, <b>and the goat</b> that is brought as a sin offering, <b>does not prevent</b> the bringing of <b>the</b> two <b>loaves,</b> and they are sacrificed nevertheless. Failure to bring <b>the</b> two <b>loaves does not prevent</b> sacrifice of the accompanying animal offerings.
Failure to bring <b>the</b> two <b>loaves prevents</b> sacrifice of <b>the</b> accompanying peace offering of two <b>sheep, but</b> failure to sacrifice <b>the</b> two <b>sheep does not prevent</b> the bringing of <b>the</b> two <b>loaves;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas says: No, rather</b> the opposite is true. Failure to sacrifice <b>the</b> peace offering of two <b>sheep prevents</b> the bringing of <b>the</b> two <b>loaves, but</b> failure to bring <b>the</b> two <b>loaves does not prevent</b> sacrifice of <b>the</b> accompanying peace offering of two <b>sheep. As we found that when the Jewish people were in the wilderness</b> for <b>forty years</b> after the exodus from Egypt, <b>they sacrificed</b> the two <b>sheep</b> as a peace offering on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>without</b> the two <b>loaves,</b> as the two loaves may be brought only from wheat grown in Eretz Yisrael after the Jewish people entered the land. <b>Here too,</b> whenever wheat is unavailable, <b>they</b> should <b>sacrifice</b> the two <b>sheep</b> without the two <b>loaves.</b> However, the two loaves are not sacrificed without the peace offering of two sheep.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with the statement of</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas</b> that failure to sacrifice the two sheep prevents the bringing of the two loaves but failure to bring the two loaves does not prevent sacrifice of the accompanying peace offering of two sheep, <b>but the reason</b> for that ruling <b>is not in accordance with his statement.</b>
<b>As all</b> the offerings that must be sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i> <b>that</b> are <b>stated in the book of Numbers</b> (see 28:27), i.e., two bulls, one ram, and seven sheep as additional offerings and a goat as a sin offering, were <b>sacrificed</b> when the Jewish people were <b>in the wilderness. But all</b> the offerings <b>stated in Leviticus</b> (see 23:18–20), i.e., the offerings accompanying the two loaves, were <b>not sacrificed</b> when the Jewish people were <b>in the wilderness.</b> Not only were the two loaves not sacrificed, but the accompanying offerings, including the peace offering of the two sheep, were also not sacrificed, because it was only <b>when they arrived in Eretz</b> Yisrael that <b>these</b> additional offerings <b>and those</b> offerings accompanying the two loaves <b>were sacrificed.</b> Neither the additional offerings of <i>Shavuot</i> nor the two loaves, and the offerings that accompany them, were sacrificed in the wilderness, contrary to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas.
Rather, <b>for what</b> reason <b>do I</b> nevertheless <b>say that the sheep should be sacrificed without</b> the <b>loaves,</b> in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas? It is <b>due to</b> the fact <b>that the sheep permit themselves,</b> as the sprinkling of their blood and the burning of the portions consumed on the altar renders it permitted to partake of their meat. <b>And</b> why are <b>the loaves not</b> sacrificed <b>without the sheep?</b> It is <b>because there is no</b> item <b>to permit</b> the loaves, as the loaves are permitted only after the sheep are sacrificed.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches the <i>halakhot</i> of the sacrifices that generally accompany the two loaves on <i>Shavuot</i> in a case when the two loaves are not available. The Gemara cites a relevant <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Sages taught:</b> The verse that mandates these offerings states: “And you shall sacrifice with the bread seven lambs without blemish of the first year, and one young bull, and two rams” (Leviticus 23:18). The phrase <b>“and you shall sacrifice with the bread”</b> indicates that it is <b>obligatory</b> to sacrifice these burnt offerings <b>with the loaves</b> of bread, and if the loaves are not available, then these offerings are not sacrificed. The continuation of the verse: <b>“Seven lambs without blemish,”</b> teaches that the lambs are sacrificed <b>even if there are no loaves</b> available.
<b>If so,</b> that the animal offerings may be sacrificed even without loaves, <b>what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states “with the bread”?</b> It <b>teaches that they were not obligated to</b> sacrifice <b>the sheep before they were obligated to</b> sacrifice <b>loaves,</b> i.e., they became obligated to sacrifice all of these offerings only when they entered Eretz Yisrael. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Tarfon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that the <b>sheep mentioned here</b> in Leviticus, which accompany the two loaves, <b>are the very same ones mentioned in the book of Numbers</b> (see 28:27), in the passage prescribing the additional offerings. You must <b>say when you reach</b> the <b>bulls and rams</b> that are enumerated in the two passages that the offerings mentioned in one <b>are not those</b> mentioned in the other, as the number of bulls and rams are not equal. Whereas in Leviticus the verse requires the sacrifice of one bull and two rams, in Numbers the verse requires the sacrifice of two bulls and one ram. <b>Rather,</b> the two passages are referring to different offerings. <b>These</b> mentioned in Numbers <b>come</b> upon the altar <b>for their own sake, and those</b> mentioned in Leviticus <b>come</b> upon the altar <b>for the sake of</b> the two <b>loaves.</b>
It is therefore <b>found</b> that the offerings <b>that are mentioned in the book of Numbers were sacrificed</b> even when the Jewish people were <b>in the wilderness</b> and could not bring the offering of the two loaves, <b>but</b> the offerings <b>that are mentioned in Leviticus were not sacrificed in the wilderness,</b> due to the fact that the two loaves could not be sacrificed in the wilderness.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps the bulls and rams</b> mentioned in Numbers <b>are not those</b> mentioned in Leviticus, <b>but the sheep</b> mentioned in Numbers <b>are</b> the same as <b>those</b> mentioned in Leviticus. The Gemara explains: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that these</b> bulls and rams <b>are different,</b> it is apparent that <b>those</b> sheep <b>are also different</b> offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>But from where</b> is it proven <b>that</b> the <b>bulls and rams</b> in Numbers <b>are different</b> offerings than the bulls and rams mentioned in Leviticus? <b>Perhaps</b> they are actually the same offerings, and <b>this</b> is what <b>the Merciful One is saying: If</b> you <b>want, sacrifice a bull and two rams,</b> as the verse states in Leviticus; and <b>if</b> you <b>want, sacrifice two bulls and one ram,</b> as the verse states in Numbers. The Gemara answers: <b>From</b> the fact <b>that the order of</b> the offerings <b>is different</b> in the two passages, as the verse in Leviticus mentions the sheep, then the bull, and then the rams, whereas the verse in Numbers mentions the bulls, then the ram, and then the sheep, one may <b>conclude from it</b> that <b>they are different</b> offerings.
§ The mishna teaches: Failure to bring <b>the</b> two <b>loaves prevents</b> sacrifice of <b>the</b> accompanying peace offering of two <b>sheep,</b> but failure to sacrifice the two sheep does not prevent the bringing of the two loaves; this is the statement of Rabbi Akiva. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi Akiva?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>He derived</b> the <i>halakha</i> based upon a verbal analogy between two verses. One verse states: “And the priest shall wave them with the bread of the first fruits for a wave offering before the Lord, with the two lambs; <b>they shall be [<i>yihyu</i>]</b> holy to the Lord for the priest” (Leviticus 23:20). The term “they shall be” indicates that it is essential that the offering be brought precisely as commanded, but it is unclear whether this is referring to the loaves or to the sheep brought as peace offerings. This is clarified by means of a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the verse: “You shall bring out of your dwellings two loaves of waving of two tenth parts of an ephah; <b>they shall be [<i>tihyena</i>]</b> of fine flour” (Leviticus 23:17).
The verbal analogy teaches that <b>just as there</b> the requirement that it be done as prescribed is referring to the <b>loaves</b> rather than the sheep, <b>so too here</b> it is referring to the <b>loaves</b> rather than the sheep. Consequently, failure to bring the loaves prevents sacrifice of the sheep, but failure to sacrifice the sheep does not prevent the bringing of the loaves.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how did Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas,</b> who holds that failure to sacrifice the sheep prevents the bringing of the loaves but failure to bring the loaves does not prevent sacrifice of the sheep, derive his ruling? <b>He derived</b> the <i>halakha</i> through a verbal analogy between the verse: <b>“They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>]</b> holy to the Lord for the priest,” and the verse that states, concerning the seven sheep brought as burnt offerings: <b>“They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>]</b> a burnt offering to the Lord” (Leviticus 23:18). <b>Just as there</b> the requirement that it be done as prescribed is referring to the <b>sheep, so too here</b> it is referring to <b>sheep</b> rather than loaves.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas also, we should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> based upon a verbal analogy <b>from</b> the word <b><i>tihyena</i></b> as Rabbi Akiva does, and conclude that <b>just as there</b> it is referring to the <b>loaves, so too here</b> it is referring to the <b>loaves.</b> The Gemara responds: It is preferable to <b>derive</b> the meaning of the term <b><i>yihyu</i> from</b> a verbal analogy using the identical form <b><i>yihyu</i>, and</b> one should <b>not derive</b> the meaning of the term <b><i>yihyu</i> from</b> a verbal analogy using the term <b><i>tihyena</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What difference is</b> there whether or not the words are identical? <b>Didn’t the school of Rabbi Yishmael teach</b> a verbal analogy with regard to leprosy of houses? The verse states: <b>“And the priest shall return [<i>veshav</i>]</b> on the seventh day” (Leviticus 14:39), and another verse with regard to the priest’s visit seven days later states: <b>“And the priest shall come [<i>uva</i>]</b> and look” (Leviticus 14:44). <b>This returning</b> and <b>this coming</b> have the same meaning, and one can therefore derive by verbal analogy that the <i>halakha</i> which applies if the leprosy had spread at the conclusion of the first week likewise applies if it had spread again by the end of the following week. Certainly, if the <i>halakha</i> can be derived via a verbal analogy with the words <i>veshav</i> and <i>uva</i>, the even slighter difference in form between <i>yihyu</i> and <i>tihyena</i> should not prevent the application of a verbal analogy.
The Gemara answers: <b>This matter</b> applies only <b>when there are no</b> terms that are <b>identical to it. But where there are</b> terms that are <b>identical to it, we derive</b> the verbal analogy <b>from</b> terms <b>identical to it</b> rather than from the terms that are not precisely identical. Consequently, it is preferable to derive the meaning of the term <i>yihyu</i> from the identical term rather than from <i>tihyena</i>.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let Rabbi Akiva also derive</b> the meaning of the term <b><i>yihyu</i> from</b> a verbal analogy to the identical term <b><i>yihyu</i>,</b> as Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas does. The Gemara responds: Rabbi Akiva holds that it is preferable to <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>an item that</b> is given as <b>a gift to the priest,</b> such as the loaves or the sheep brought as peace offerings, which are the subject of Leviticus 23:20, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>an item that</b> is also <b>a gift to the priest,</b> i.e., the two loaves, which are the subject of Leviticus 23:17. This is <b>to the exclusion of these</b> seven sheep that are mentioned in Leviticus 23:18, <b>which are burnt offerings</b> and wholly consumed by the altar, and are not a gift to the priest. Consequently, it is preferable to derive the meaning of the term <i>yihyu</i> in verse 20 from the term <i>tihyena</i> in verse 17, rather than from the term <i>yihyu</i> in verse 18.
The Gemara presents an alternative explanation for the basis of their divergent opinions: <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that they <b>disagree about the</b> interpretation of the <b>verse itself: “They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>] holy to the Lord for the priest”</b> (Leviticus 23:20). <b>Rabbi Akiva holds: Which item is entirely</b> given <b>to the priest? You must say</b> that <b>it is</b> the loaves of <b>bread.</b> Therefore he concludes that the word <i>yihyu</i> is referring to the loaves of bread, and if they are not sacrificed, the two sheep cannot be sacrificed as peace offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas</b> respond to this? He would say: <b>Is it</b> in fact <b>written: They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>] holy for the priest,</b> in which case one should interpret it as Rabbi Akiva does? <b>It is written</b> in the verse: <b>“They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>] holy to the Lord for the priest.”</b> Therefore, it should be understood in the following manner: <b>Which item is partially</b> given <b>to the Lord and partially</b> given <b>to the priest? You must say</b> that <b>it is</b> the <b>sheep,</b> which are sacrificed as a peace offering, part of which is burned on the altar and part of which is consumed by the priests. Consequently, the word <i>yihyu</i> should be understood as referring to the sheep, and if they are not sacrificed, the two loaves cannot be sacrificed either.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> how would <b>Rabbi Akiva</b> respond to this? He would say: <b>Is it</b> in fact <b>written: They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>] holy for the Lord and for the priest? It is written</b> in the verse: “They shall be [<i>yihyu</i>] holy <b>to the Lord for the priest.”</b> Therefore, it should be understood to mean that it is given to the Lord, and it is then given by Him entirely to the priests, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rav Huna, as Rav Huna says: The Lord acquired it</b> initially <b>and</b> then <b>gave it to the priest.</b>
§ With regard to the dispute in the mishna about whether failure to sacrifice the two sheep as peace offerings prevents the bringing of the two loaves or vice versa, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Everyone concedes</b>

Daf 46a

<b>that if</b> they <b>became bound to each other</b> and then one of them became lost, <b>that</b> the lost item <b>prevents</b> fulfillment of the mitzva with <b>the other,</b> i.e., the remaining item is unfit and must be burned. Rabbi Yoḥanan clarifies: <b>And what is</b> it that establishes <b>their bond?</b> It is the <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep. If the loaves existed at the time of the slaughter, then the loaves and sheep are sanctified as one unit. Consequently, if one of them is lost, the other is unfit and must be burned.
With regard to the establishment of the bond between the loaves and the sheep, <b>Ulla said</b> that the Sages <b>in the West,</b> Eretz Yisrael, <b>raise a dilemma:</b> Does <b>waving</b> of the sheep and loaves before the sheep are slaughtered <b>establish a bond</b> between the sheep and the loaves, such that if one is lost the other becomes unfit, <b>or does it not establish a bond</b> between them?
The Gemara asks: Why is there a dilemma about this issue? <b>Resolve it from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, as Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>establishes a bond</b> between sheep and the loaves. On can conclude <b>by inference</b> that <b>waving,</b> which precedes the slaughter, <b>does not establish a bond</b> between them.
The Gemara answers: It is with regard to the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan itself</b> that Ulla <b>raises the dilemma:</b> Is it <b>obvious to Rabbi Yoḥanan that slaughter establishes a bond</b> between them <b>but waving does not establish a bond</b> between them? <b>Or perhaps it is obvious to him</b> that <b>slaughter</b> establishes a bond between them, <b>but he is uncertain</b> as to whether or not <b>waving</b> establishes a bond between them. According to the second possibility, the reason that he mentioned slaughter is that he was certain about it. The Gemara notes that the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda bar Ḥanina said to Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua: But when it is written: “They shall be holy to the Lord for the priest”</b> (Leviticus 23:20), it is <b>written</b> immediately <b>after</b> the verse mentions <b>waving, and</b> nevertheless Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva disagree,</b> based on this phrase, about whether the loaves can be brought without the sheep or the sheep can be sacrificed without the loaves. This indicates that the waving does not establish a bond between these two items.
Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, replied to Rabbi Yehuda bar Ḥanina: <b>And according to your reasoning</b> that one can infer the <i>halakha</i> based upon the placement of the phrase: “They shall be holy to the Lord for the priest,” is this phrase referring to the time <b>after waving but not after</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep? After all, the verse speaks of giving them to the priest, which is done after the sheep have been slaughtered. How then did Rabbi Shimon ben Nannas and Rabbi Akiva disagree concerning this verse?
<b>Rather, what do you have to say</b> concerning this verse? It must be <b>referring</b> to a time <b>before</b> the slaughter, <b>and what</b> is meant by: <b>“They shall be holy to the Lord for the priest”?</b> It means <b>an item that is ultimately</b> given <b>to the priest. Here too,</b> one can explain that the verse is referring to a time before the waving, and it means <b>an item that is ultimately</b> given <b>to the priest.</b> The issue of whether or not waving establishes a bond between the sheep and loaves therefore remains an open question.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> is it so that <b>slaughter establishes a bond</b> between them? <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i> concerning a thanks offering, which consists of an animal offering accompanied by forty loaves. The <i>baraita</i> states: If one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves broke before he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, <b>he should bring another loaf and slaughter</b> the thanks offering.
But if one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves broke once he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, it is not possible to bring another loaf because the loaves of a thanks offering are sanctified through the slaughter of the animal, which has already taken place. Consequently, <b>the blood</b> should <b>be sprinkled</b> on the altar <b>and the meat</b> should <b>be eaten, but he has not fulfilled his vow</b> to bring a thanks offering, <b>and the loaves are</b> all <b>unfit.</b>
If one of its accompanying loaves broke after <b>the blood was sprinkled</b> on the altar, the loaves are not deemed unfit and the individual has fulfilled his vow to bring a thanks offering. <b>He separates</b> the four loaves for the priest <b>from the whole</b> loaves <b>for the broken</b> loaf. The priest receives whole loaves and not the broken one.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves left</b> the confines of the walls of Jerusalem <b>before he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, it is not unfit because the loaves were not yet sanctified by the slaughter. Therefore, <b>he brings it</b> back <b>into</b> the city <b>and slaughters</b> the thanks offering.
If one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves left</b> the confines of the walls of Jerusalem <b>once he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, the loaves are rendered unfit. Consequently, <b>the blood</b> should <b>be sprinkled</b> on the altar <b>and the meat</b> should <b>be eaten, but he has not fulfilled his vow</b> to bring a thanks offering <b>and the loaves are</b> all <b>unfit.</b> If one of the loaves left the confines of the walls of Jerusalem after <b>the blood was sprinkled</b> on the altar, the remainder of the offering is fit, and <b>he separates</b> the four loaves for the priest <b>from the</b> ones <b>that</b> remained <b>inside</b> the city <b>for the loaf that</b> went <b>outside</b> the walls of the city.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves became impure before he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, <b>he brings another loaf and slaughters</b> the thanks offering. But if one of <b>its</b> accompanying <b>loaves became impure once he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering, then <b>the blood</b> should <b>be sprinkled</b> on the altar <b>and the meat</b> should <b>be eaten, and he has fulfilled his vow</b> to bring a thanks offering. This is due to the fact <b>that the frontplate effects acceptance of</b> offerings that are <b>impure.</b> Nevertheless, <b>the loaf</b> that became impure <b>is unfit,</b> as the frontplate effects acceptance of the offering but does not render impure items pure.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: If one of its accompanying loaves became impure after <b>the blood was sprinkled</b> on the altar, <b>he separates</b> the four loaves that are given to the priest <b>from the</b> loaves that remained <b>pure for the impure</b> loaf.
The Gemara comes to its question: <b>If it enters your mind</b> to say that <b>slaughter establishes a bond</b> between the sheep and the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>, and similarly between the animal offering and the loaves of a thanks offering, then in the cases where a loaf became unfit after the animal was slaughtered but before the blood was sprinkled, <b>since</b> the animal and the loaves <b>bonded with each other through the slaughtering,</b> once the <b>loaf became unfit, the thanks offering should also become unfit.</b> Consequently, the blood of the offering should not be sprinkled on the altar and the meat should not be eaten, contrary to what is stated in the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara answers: The <b>thanks offering is different, as the Merciful One called it a peace offering,</b> as the verse states: “The sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving” (Leviticus 7:13). Consequently, <b>just as a peace offering is sacrificed without loaves, so too a thanks offering</b> can be <b>sacrificed without loaves.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yirmeya says: If you say</b> that <b>waving establishes a bond</b> between the loaves and the sheep, then in a case where <b>the loaves were lost</b> after the waving,

Daf 46b

the <b>sheep are lost</b> as well, i.e., they cannot be sacrificed, and one must bring different loaves and sheep. Similarly, if the <b>sheep are lost</b> after the waving, <b>the loaves are</b> thereby <b>lost</b> as well, since a bond was established between them by means of the waving.
<b>And if you say</b> that <b>waving does not establish a bond</b> between the loaves and the sheep, then one can raise the following dilemma: If one <b>brought loaves and sheep and they were waved, and</b> then <b>the loaves were lost and</b> he <b>brought other loaves</b> to replace the original loaves, does <b>that</b> second set of <b>loaves require waving</b> with the sheep, as it has not yet been waved? <b>Or does it not require waving,</b> as the accompanying sheep have already been waved with the original loaves, and the sheep are the subject in the verse that serves as the source of the requirement of waving (see Leviticus 23:20)?
Rabbi Yirmeya clarifies the dilemma: In a case where the <b>sheep were lost</b> after the waving, <b>do not raise the dilemma, as</b> in this case <b>they certainly require waving,</b> because the primary obligation of waving is mentioned with respect to the sheep, and these sheep have not yet been waved. <b>When should you raise the dilemma?</b> You should raise it in a case where <b>the loaves were lost</b> after the waving.
<b>And according to</b> the opinion <b>of</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>ben Nannas,</b> who holds that failure to sacrifice the sheep prevents one from sacrificing the loaves, <b>do not raise the dilemma, as he says</b> that the <b>sheep are primary.</b> Consequently, since the sheep have been waved, there is no need to repeat the waving. <b>When should you raise the dilemma?</b> Raise it <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva,</b> who holds that failure to bring the loaves prevents one from sacrificing the sheep, <b>as he says</b> that the <b>loaves are primary.</b> According to his opinion, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> concerning the loaves that are brought as replacements?
On the one hand, one might say that <b>since the loaves are primary</b> and this set of loaves has not yet been waved, <b>it requires waving. Or</b> on the other hand, <b>perhaps</b> one should say that <b>since its permitting factors are</b> the <b>sheep,</b> and they were already waved, the new set of loaves <b>does not require waving.</b> The Gemara concludes that the question <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>Abaye said to Rava: What is different</b> about the <b>two sheep</b> brought as peace offerings together with the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>, such <b>that their</b> slaughter <b>sanctifies the loaves</b> (see 47a), <b>and</b> according to Rabbi Yoḥanan failure to sacrifice them once they have been slaughtered <b>prevents</b> the bringing of the loaves; <b>and what is different</b> about the <b>seven sheep, the bull, and</b> the two <b>rams</b> brought on <i>Shavuot</i> as an additional offering, such <b>that their</b> slaughter <b>does not sanctify</b> the <b>loaves, and</b> failure to sacrifice them <b>does not prevent</b> the bringing of the loaves?
Rava <b>said to</b> Abaye: The reason for the distinction is <b>because</b> the two sheep and the loaves brought as peace offerings <b>are bound to each other through the waving.</b> This is not so with regard to the additional offerings, which are not waved with the loaves. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> in the case of <b>a thanks offering</b> and its loaves, which are not waved together, <b>they are not bound to each other through waving, and</b> nevertheless the slaughter of the animal offering <b>sanctifies</b> the loaves <b>and</b> failure to sacrifice the animal offering <b>prevents</b> the bringing of the loaves. This indicates that the waving is not the critical factor.
<b>Rather,</b> the reason for the distinction is that the two sheep brought as peace offerings are <b>comparable to a thanks offering. Just as a thanks offering is a peace offering, so too</b> the two sheep are <b>also a peace offering.</b> Consequently, just as the slaughter of the thanks offering sanctifies the accompanying loaves, and failure to sacrifice the animal prevents one from bringing the loaves, the same applies with regard to the sheep peace offerings and loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>Are</b> the two sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> and the thanks offering really <b>comparable? There,</b> in the case of the thanks offering, <b>there are no other animal offerings</b> brought <b>with it.</b> But <b>here,</b> in the case of the offerings brought on <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>where there are other animal offerings</b> brought <b>with it, let these</b> peace offerings <b>and those</b> additional offerings <b>sanctify</b> the loaves. Why is it only the sheep brought as peace offerings that sanctify the loaves?
<b>Rather,</b> the reason for the distinction is that the two sheep brought as peace offerings are <b>comparable to a nazirite’s ram,</b> which is sacrificed as a peace offering when he completes his term of naziriteship, in addition to a lamb that he sacrifices as a burnt offering, a female lamb that he brings then as a sin offering, and the nazirite loaves (see Numbers 6:14–15). <b>Just as</b> in the case of a <b>nazirite’s ram, even though there are other offerings</b> brought with it, nevertheless <b>it is</b> the slaughter of the <b>peace offering that sanctifies</b> the nazirite loaves and <b>not</b> the slaughter of <b>anything else, here too,</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>is no different,</b> and it is specifically the slaughter of the peace offerings that sanctifies the loaves.
The Gemara asks: <b>And there,</b> in the case of the offerings of the nazirite, <b>from where do we</b> derive that it is specifically the slaughter of the peace offering that sanctifies the loaves? The Gemara answers: This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning a verse stated with regard to the offerings of the nazirite: <b>“And he shall offer the ram for a sacrifice of peace offerings to the Lord, with the basket of unleavened bread”</b> (Numbers 6:17). This verse, which connects the ram and the loaves, <b>teaches that the basket</b> of the nazirite loaves <b>comes</b> as <b>an obligation for the ram,</b> which is a peace offering, <b>and the slaughter of the ram sanctifies</b> the loaves. <b>Therefore,</b> if the slaughter was unfit, e.g., in a case where <b>he slaughtered</b> the ram <b>not for the sake of</b> a peace offering, <b>the loaves were not sanctified.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that according to Rabbi Akiva failure to sacrifice the two sheep brought as peace offerings does not prevent sacrifice of the loaves. Consequently, if there are no sheep, the loaves are sacrificed by themselves. Concerning this <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>the two loaves</b> are <b>brought by themselves, they should be waved.</b> They should then be left overnight so that <b>their form decays,</b> i.e., they become disqualified, <b>and they are</b> then <b>brought out to the place of burning,</b> like any disqualified offering.
The Gemara challenges: <b>Whichever way you</b> look at it, this is difficult: <b>If</b> the loaves are <b>brought</b> and waved in order <b>to be eaten, let</b> the priests <b>eat them</b> rather than burn them. <b>If</b> they are <b>brought</b> only <b>to be burned, let</b> the priests <b>burn them immediately. Why are they</b> left overnight so that they undergo <b>a decay of form,</b> i.e., become disqualified?
<b>Rabba said: Actually,</b> the loaves are <b>brought</b> and waved in order <b>to be eaten.</b> Nevertheless, the Sages instituted a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that they not be eaten out of concern <b>lest sheep become available to</b> the nation <b>the following year, and they</b> might <b>say: Didn’t we eat the loaves without</b> any accompanying <b>sheep last year [<i>eshtakad</i>]? Now too, we will eat</b> the loaves without sacrificing sheep.
<b>And they will not know that</b> the reason they were permitted to eat the loaves without sacrificing sheep <b>last year</b> is that <b>there were no sheep,</b> and therefore the two loaves <b>permitted themselves</b> to be eaten, i.e., they could be eaten without the sacrifice of the sheep. But <b>now that there are sheep, it is</b> the sacrifice of <b>the sheep that permits</b> the loaves to be eaten. Since loaves brought without sheep are fit by Torah law and may not be eaten due to rabbinic decree, they may not be burned until they become disqualified by remaining overnight.
<b>Rabba said: From where do I say</b> this, i.e., what is the source for my statement? It is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 1:4): <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that <b>ben Bukhri testified</b> before the Sages <b>in Yavne: Any priest who contributes his</b> half-<b>shekel is not</b> considered <b>a sinner,</b> despite the fact that he is not obligated to do so.
Rabbi Yehuda added that <b>Rabban Yoḥanan ben Zakkai said to</b> ben Bukhri: <b>That is not</b> the case, <b>rather, any priest who does not contribute his</b> half-<b>shekel</b> is considered <b>a sinner,</b> as they are obligated in this mitzva like all other Jews. <b>But the priests</b> who do not contribute the half-shekel <b>interpret this</b> following <b>verse to their own</b> advantage in order to excuse themselves from the mitzva.
The verse states: <b>“And every meal offering of the priest shall be wholly made to smoke; it shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:16). Those priests claim as follows: <b>Since the <i>omer</i></b> offering <b>and the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering of two loaves from the new wheat, brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>and the shewbread</b> placed on the Table in the Sanctuary each Shabbat, which are all meal offerings, <b>are ours,</b> then if we contribute half-shekels we will have partial ownership of these communal offerings, as they are purchased with the half-shekels. <b>How,</b> then, <b>can they be eaten?</b> They would then be regarded as priests’ meal offerings, which must be wholly burned.
Rabba discusses this mishna: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of <b>these two loaves? If we say</b> that the mishna is referring <b>to</b> a case <b>where</b> they are <b>brought with the animal offering,</b> i.e., the two sheep brought as peace offerings, why shouldn’t the loaves be eaten? <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>priests cannot volunteer</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering and its loaves and eat them?</b> Just as the loaves that accompany a thanks offering may be eaten, even if brought by a priest, the same <i>halakha</i> should apply to the two loaves when they accompany sheep brought as peace offerings.
<b>Rather,</b> is it <b>not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the two loaves are <b>brought by themselves,</b> and the mishna <b>teaches</b> that the priests claimed: <b>How</b> can <b>they be eaten? Apparently,</b> in principle the loaves <b>come to be eaten,</b> but due to rabbinic decree they are not eaten and are left overnight until their form decays.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabba in response: <b>Actually,</b> the mishna can be interpreted as referring <b>to</b> loaves <b>brought with the animal offering,</b> and therefore it does not prove that when the two loaves are brought by themselves they may be eaten. <b>And as for that which</b> is <b>difficult for you</b> based <b>on</b> the case of <b>a thanks offering and its loaves,</b> the resolution is that the <b>loaves of a thanks offering are not called a meal offering,</b> and therefore even when a priest brings a thanks offering, the loaves may be eaten. By contrast, <b>the two loaves</b> of <i>Shavuot</i> <b>are called a meal offering, as it is stated</b> with regard to the two loaves: “Also in the day of the first fruits, <b>when you bring a new meal offering to the Lord”</b> (Numbers 28:26). Therefore, the priests held that if they would donate half-shekels, the two loaves would not be permitted to be eaten.
<b>Rav Yosef said</b> a different response to Rabba’s proof: <b>Actually,</b> when the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i> are brought by themselves <b>they come to be burned,</b> i.e., they may not be eaten. <b>And this is the reason that we do not burn them</b> until the following day: It is <b>because one may not burn consecrated</b> items <b>on a Festival.</b>
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>Is</b> the burning of the two loaves <b>comparable</b> to the burning of other consecrated items, such that the loaves may not be burned right away for this reason? <b>There,</b> in the case of other consecrated items, <b>this is not their mitzva,</b> i.e., they are supposed to be eaten, but if they become disqualified they must be burned. Conversely, <b>here,</b> in the case of the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i> that are brought by themselves, <b>where this is their mitzva,</b> i.e., they are supposed to be burned, <b>let</b> the priests <b>burn them</b> on the Festival, <b>just as is</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case <b>of the bull and the goat of Yom Kippur,</b> which are burned on Yom Kippur despite the fact that it is a Festival.
<b>Rather, Rav Yosef said:</b> The reason the loaves are left overnight is due to a rabbinic <b>decree</b> not to burn them immediately, <b>lest sheep become available to</b> the nation <b>afterward,</b> i.e., later in the day, in which case the loaves could be waved with them and then eaten. <b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: That <b>works out well</b> for the <b>entire time</b> period when <b>they</b> may be <b>sacrificed,</b> i.e., until the afternoon daily offering is sacrificed. But <b>after that, let them burn</b> the loaves immediately and not wait until the next day. Rav Yosef replied: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase in the <i>baraita</i> <b>that teaches</b> that the loaves must be left until <b>their form decays?</b> It means that they must be left until <b>the form of their sacrifice</b> has passed, i.e., until after the time when the sheep could be sacrificed.
<b>Rava said</b> that there is a different response to Rabba’s proof: When the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i> are brought by themselves, by Torah law <b>they come to be eaten, but</b> due to rabbinic <b>decree</b> they are not eaten and are left overnight until they are disqualified. The reason for the decree is <b>due to</b> that <b>which Rabba</b> said, i.e., due to the concern that the following year sheep will be available and nevertheless the nation will bring the two loaves without sheep. <b>But</b> the proof that by Torah law the loaves may be eaten is <b>not from</b> Rabba’s line of <b>reasoning,</b> i.e., from the mishna in <i>Shekalim</i>; <b>rather,</b> it is <b>from a verse.</b>
<b>And Rava said</b> by way of explanation: <b>From where do I state</b> this <i>halakha</i>? From the fact <b>that it is written</b> with regard to the two loaves: <b>“You shall bring out of your dwellings</b> two <b>loaves of waving</b> of two tenth parts of an ephah; they shall be of fine flour, they shall be baked with leaven, <b>for first fruits to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 23:17). <b>Just as first fruits</b> are brought <b>by themselves,</b> without an accompanying animal offering, <b>so too the two loaves</b> are brought <b>by themselves</b> when there are no sheep available. <b>And</b> learn <b>from this</b> comparison to first fruits that <b>just as first fruits</b> are brought <b>to be eaten, so too the two loaves</b> are <b>also</b> brought <b>to be eaten,</b> even in the absence of the sheep brought as peace offerings.

Daf 47a

§ The Gemara cites further discussion of the two sheep and the two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>: <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The</b> two <b>sheep</b> of <b><i>Shavuot</i> consecrate the</b> two <b>loaves</b> that accompany them <b>only by</b> means of their <b>slaughter.</b>
<b>How so?</b> If <b>one slaughtered</b> the sheep <b>for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> as the peace offerings that are supposed to be sacrificed on <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>and</b> then the priest <b>sprinkled their blood</b> on the altar <b>for their</b> own <b>sake,</b> then <b>the loaves are consecrated.</b> But if <b>one slaughtered them not for their</b> own <b>sake, and</b> the priest <b>sprinkled their blood not for their</b> own <b>sake, the loaves are not consecrated.</b> If <b>one slaughtered them for their</b> own <b>sake and he sprinkled their blood not for their</b> own <b>sake, the loaves are</b> partially <b>consecrated, but they are not</b> fully <b>consecrated.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says:</b> The loaves are <b>never consecrated</b> at all <b>until one slaughters</b> the offerings <b>for their</b> own <b>sake and sprinkles their blood for their</b> own <b>sake.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reasoning of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the slaughtering of the sheep partially consecrates the loaves even without the sprinkling of the blood?
The Gemara answers: It is based on the fact <b>that it is written</b> concerning the ram brought by the nazirite when he completes his naziriteship: <b>“And he shall offer the ram for a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] of peace offerings to the Lord, with the basket of unleavened bread”</b> (Numbers 6:17). Since the verse uses the word <i>zevaḥ</i>, which also means slaughter, and the verse then makes reference to the loaves, <b>that is to say that</b> it is specifically the <b>slaughter</b> that <b>consecrates</b> the loaves that accompany the offering. Similarly, the slaughter of the sheep brought as peace offerings on <i>Shavuot</i> consecrates the accompanying two loaves, as the <i>halakha</i> of the loaves of <i>Shavuot</i> is derived from that of the loaves of the nazirite.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> what is the reasoning of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that the slaughtering and sprinkling of the blood together consecrate the loaves? The Gemara answers: He derives it from the term: <b>“He shall offer,”</b> which he understands to mean that the loaves are not consecrated <b>until</b> the priest <b>performs all of the actions</b> included in the sacrificial rites of that offering, including the sprinkling of the blood.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>also, isn’t it written: “He shall offer,”</b> which indicates that the loaves are consecrated only once the blood has been sprinkled on the altar? The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> it were <b>written: A sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>] he shall offer,</b> it would be <b>as you are saying</b> that he should slaughter it and then perform a further action, i.e., sprinkling the blood, in order to consecrate the loaves. <b>Now that it is written: “He shall offer</b> the ram for <b>a sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>],”</b> it should be understood as: <b>By what</b> means <b>should he offer</b> the ram in order to consecrate the loaves? <b>By</b> means of <b>slaughtering [<i>zeviḥa</i>].</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, isn’t it written: “A sacrifice [<i>zevaḥ</i>],”</b> indicating that slaughtering alone consecrates the loaves? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires that</b> expression <b>for</b> that <b>which Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> says, <b>as Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>everyone,</b> including Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>concedes that the loaves must be</b> in existence <b>at the time of the slaughter.</b>
§ The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is meant by Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi’s statement in the <i>baraita</i> that if one slaughtered the sheep for their own sake and sprinkled their blood not for their own sake, then the loaves are partially <b>consecrated, but they are not</b> fully <b>consecrated? Abaye says:</b> The loaves are <b>consecrated</b> by means of the slaughtering, <b>but</b> their consecration is <b>not complete. Rava says:</b> The loaves are fully <b>consecrated</b> by means of the slaughtering, <b>but</b> they are <b>not</b> thereby <b>permitted</b> to be eaten.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the practical difference <b>between them?</b> Everyone concedes that the loaves may not be eaten as a result of this slaughtering. The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> is the ability <b>to transfer</b> sanctity to <b>their redemption</b> money. <b>According to Abaye,</b> who holds that the loaves are not completely consecrated, they <b>do not transfer</b> sanctity to <b>their redemption</b> money if one tries to redeem them for money. <b>According to Rava,</b> who holds that the loaves are completely consecrated, they <b>transfer</b> sanctity to <b>their redemption</b> money.
The Gemara asks: <b>Granted, according to Rava,</b> who holds that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the loaves are completely sanctified, <b>that is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon.</b> But <b>according to Abaye, what</b> difference <b>is there between</b> the opinions of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi and <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon?</b>
The Gemara answers: The practical difference <b>between them</b> is <b>with regard to</b> whether the loaves are <b>rendered unfit by</b> means of <b>leaving</b> the Temple courtyard after the slaughtering of the offering. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, the loaves are rendered unfit if they leave the courtyard. According to Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who holds that the loaves are not consecrated, they are not rendered unfit if they leave the courtyard.
§ The Gemara continues the discussion of the dispute between Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, concerning the consecration of the two loaves by means of the slaughter and sprinkling of the blood of the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba:</b> In the case of a communal peace offering of two <b>sheep</b> that accompany the two loaves on <b><i>Shavuot</i> that one slaughtered for their sake but</b> the priest <b>sprinkled their blood not for their sake,</b> concerning <b>those</b> accompanying <b>loaves, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to eating</b> them?
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion was this dilemma raised? <b>If</b> it was raised <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, doesn’t he say</b> that <b>it is</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of the blood <b>that consecrates the loaves?</b> Consequently, if the blood was not properly sprinkled, it is clear that the loves are unfit and may not be eaten. And <b>if</b> it was raised <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>both according to</b> the opinion <b>of Abaye and according to</b> that of <b>Rava,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that the loaves <b>are consecrated but are not permitted</b> to be eaten.
The Gemara responds: <b>Rather,</b> one must say that the question was asked <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>. As the father of Rabbi Yirmeya bar Abba teaches</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where <b>the two loaves left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>between</b> the <b>slaughtering</b> of the offering <b>and</b> the <b>sprinkling</b> of its blood, <b>and</b> then the priest <b>sprinkled the blood of</b> the <b>sheep</b> with the intent that their meat would be eaten <b>beyond their</b> designated <b>time,</b> the sheep are rendered <i>piggul</i>. With regard to the loaves, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: The loaves do not</b> become prohibited <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>. Rabbi Akiva says: The loaves do</b> become prohibited <b>due to</b> the prohibition of <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said: These <i>tanna’im</i>,</b> Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Akiva, both <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> The <b>slaughtering consecrates</b> the loaves by itself. Consequently, if the loaves are taken out of the Temple courtyard after the sheep are slaughtered, the loaves become disqualified.
<b>But</b> they disagree as to the following: <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as</b> Rabbi Eliezer <b>says</b> that <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>is not effective with regard to</b> offerings that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard. Since the loaves left the courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood, the intent of the priest while sprinkling the blood that the offering be eaten outside of its designated time does not render the loaves <i>piggul</i>. <b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rabbi Akiva says</b> that <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>is effective with regard to</b> offerings that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard. Therefore, the intent of the priest while sprinkling the blood that the offering be eaten outside of its designated time renders the loaves <i>piggul</i>, even though they left the courtyard.

Daf 47b

<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Me’ila</i> 6b): In the case of <b>sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity that left</b> the Temple courtyard <b>before the sprinkling of the blood, Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The sprinkling of the blood is completely ineffective with regard to these portions, and therefore one is <b>not</b> liable for <b>misusing them. And</b> if <b>one</b> eats <b>them, he is not liable due to</b> the prohibitions of <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, or</b> of partaking of sacrificial meat while one is <b>ritually impure.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says:</b> The sprinkling is effective and therefore, one is liable for <b>misusing them. And</b> if <b>one</b> eats <b>them he is liable due to</b> the prohibitions of <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, or</b> of partaking of sacrificial meat while one is <b>ritually impure.</b>
The Gemara now concludes the dilemma that Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak raised before Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: According to the opinion of Rabbi Akiva, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to eating the loaves when the sheep were slaughtered for their own sake, but their blood was sprinkled not for their sake?
The Gemara clarifies the two sides of the dilemma: Should one say that <b>from</b> the fact <b>that sprinkling</b> the blood of the sheep in a manner that renders it <b><i>piggul</i> renders</b> the loaves <b><i>piggul</i>, like the meat</b> of the offering, despite the fact that the loaves were disqualified <b>by leaving</b> the courtyard of the Temple, it can be derived that <b>sprinkling</b> the blood <b>not for its own sake also permits the loaves</b> to be eaten, just as it permits the meat of the sheep to be eaten? <b>Or perhaps</b> it is only <b>to</b> be <b>stringent</b> that <b>we say</b> that sprinkling the blood is effective with regard to loaves that have left the Temple courtyard, but <b>we do not say</b> this in order <b>to</b> be <b>lenient,</b> e.g., to render the loaves permitted to be eaten.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this</b> understanding of the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Eliezer. <b>From where</b> do we know that <b>they disagree</b> in a case <b>where</b> the loaves <b>are outside</b> the courtyard at the time of the sprinkling?
<b>Perhaps in</b> a case <b>where</b> the loaves <b>are</b> still <b>outside</b> the courtyard <b>everyone agrees that sprinkling</b> the blood <b>is not effective with regard to</b> offerings that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and they disagree in</b> a case <b>where</b> the loaves left the courtyard and <b>one then brought them</b> back into the courtyard before the sprinkling. <b>As Rabbi Eliezer holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> The <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>consecrates</b> the loaves, <b>and</b> therefore the loaves <b>became disqualified by leaving</b> the courtyard after the sheep were slaughtered. Consequently, even if they were brought back into the courtyard before the sprinkling of the blood they cannot become <i>piggul</i> because they have already been disqualified for a different reason.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> The <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>does not consecrate</b> the loaves at all before the sprinkling of the blood. Since the loaves were not yet consecrated, <b>they do not become disqualified by leaving</b> the Temple courtyard.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is this</b> interpretation of the dispute between Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Eliezer? It does not fit what they say. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>Rabbi Akiva holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> The <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>consecrates</b> the loaves, <b>that is what Rabbi Akiva</b> means when he <b>says that</b> the loaves <b>are consecrated by</b> the <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>and</b> then the <b>sprinkling</b> that was done with the intent to consume the offering after its appointed time <b>comes and renders</b> the loaves <b><i>piggul</i>.</b>
<b>But if you say</b> that Rabbi Akiva holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> The <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>does not consecrate</b> the loaves without the sprinkling of the blood, <b>does sprinkling</b> with an intent that renders the sheep <b><i>piggul</i></b> actually <b>consecrate</b> the loaves?
<b>But doesn’t Rav Giddel say</b> that <b>Rav says: Sprinkling</b> with an intent that renders an offering <b><i>piggul</i> does not cause</b> items <b>to</b> become subject to the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property, <b>and it does not remove</b> items <b>from</b> being subject to the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property?
Rav explains: The <i>halakha</i> that it <b>does not cause</b> items <b>to</b> become subject to the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property applies <b>with regard to sacrificial portions of offerings of lesser sanctity.</b> The prohibition against misusing consecrated property applies to: “The sacred items of the Lord” (Leviticus 5:15). Consequently, it does not apply to offerings of lesser sanctity, as the meat is the property of those who brought the offering, and the sacrificial portions are disqualified by the sprinkling performed with improper intent.
<b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>it does not remove</b> items <b>from</b> being subject to the prohibition against <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property applies <b>with regard to meat of offerings of the most sacred order,</b> such as a sin offering, a guilt offering, or a communal peace offering. Since the sprinkling of the blood was not valid, the meat, which would have become permitted for the priests to eat, retains the status of “the sacred items of the Lord,” and the prohibition against misuse of consecrated property still applies.
The Gemara rejects this explanation: <b>Wasn’t that which Rav Giddel</b> says that <b>Rav says conclusively refuted?</b> Consequently, one cannot ask a question based on this statement.
§ The Gemara cites another dilemma concerning the sheep and loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raised a dilemma before Rabbi Zeira:</b> In a case of the two <b>sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> that one slaughtered for their own sake,</b> thereby establishing a bond between the sheep and the loaves, <b>and the loaves were</b> then <b>lost,</b> if the blood of the sheep would be sprinkled for their sake, the meat would not be permitted to be eaten because the loaves were lost. That said, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to whether the priest may <b>sprinkle their blood not for their own sake</b> but rather for the sake of a peace offering in order <b>to permit</b> the <b>meat</b> of the sheep <b>to be eaten?</b>
Rabbi Zeira <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>Do you have anything that is not fit</b> if the sacrificial rites are performed <b>for its own sake, and</b> yet it is <b>fit</b> if the sacrificial rites are performed <b>not for its own sake?</b> This is certainly not a logical option. Rabbi Yirmeya responded: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> precedent for this? <b>But there is</b> the <b>Paschal offering before midday</b> on the fourteenth of Nisan, <b>which is not fit</b> if it is slaughtered <b>for its own sake,</b> as it is before the proper time for the Paschal offering, <b>and</b> yet it is <b>fit</b> if it is slaughtered <b>not for its own sake</b> but rather for the sake of a peace offering.
Rabbi Zeira replied: <b>This is what I</b> was <b>saying: Do you have anything that was fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>for its own sake,</b> like these sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> that were slaughtered before the loaves were lost, <b>and was</b> then <b>rejected from</b> being sacrificed <b>for its own sake,</b> like these sheep when the loaves were lost, <b>and is not fit</b> if it is sacrificed <b>for its own sake, and</b> yet it is <b>fit</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its own sake?</b>
Rabbi Yirmeya responded: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> precedent for this? <b>But there is</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> which was fit to be sacrificed for its own sake during its designated time, and <b>after its</b> designated <b>time, during</b> the <b>rest of the days of the year before midday,</b> it is not fit to be sacrificed as a Paschal offering but it is fit to be sacrificed as a peace offering.
Rabbi Zeira replied: <b>This is what I</b> was <b>saying: Do you have anything that was fit</b> to be sacrificed <b>for its own sake,</b> like the two sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> that were slaughtered before the loaves were lost, <b>and it was slaughtered for its own sake, and was</b> then <b>rejected from</b> being sacrificed <b>for its own sake,</b> like the two sheep when the loaves were lost, <b>and it is not fit</b> if it is sacrificed <b>for its own sake, and</b> yet it is <b>fit</b> if it is sacrificed <b>not for its own sake?</b>
Rabbi Yirmeya responded: <b>And</b> is there <b>no</b> precedent for this? <b>But there is</b> the <b>thanks offering,</b> as the Gemara (46a) states that if the thanks offering was slaughtered and then its accompanying loaves broke into pieces and thereby became disqualified, the blood should be sprinkled for the sake of a peace offering rather than a thanks offering, and then the meat may be eaten. Yet, if the blood was sprinkled for the sake of a thanks offering, the meat would not be permitted to be eaten.
Rabbi Zeira answered: The <b>thanks offering is different, as the Merciful One called it a peace offering</b> (see Leviticus 7:13). Just as a peace offering is sacrificed without loaves, so too a thanks offering may sometimes be sacrificed without loaves. Therefore, the loss of the loaves does not render the thanks offering disqualified, and this case is not comparable to the case of the two sheep and two loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>.
§ The Gemara cites another discussion concerning the sheep and loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one <b>slaughtered</b> the <b>two sheep</b> as required but they were accompanied <b>by four loaves</b> rather than the requisite two loaves, <b>he draws two of</b> the loaves from the four <b>and waves them</b> together with the sheep,

Daf 48a

<b>and the rest</b> of the loaves <b>are</b> permitted to be <b>eaten through redemption. The Sages said</b> the following <b>before Rav Ḥisda: This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, who holds that the slaughter of the sheep grants the loaves inherent sanctity, and in this case two of the loaves have inherent sanctity but it is not known which ones.
