<b>As, if</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>since he says</b> that the <b>slaughter</b> of the sheep <b>consecrates</b> the loaves with inherent sanctity, when the <i>baraita</i> states <b>that he redeems</b> the loaves, <b>where</b> does he redeem them?
The process of redemption would be to place all four loaves in front of him and state that whichever two of the loaves do not have inherent sanctity are redeemed for money. <b>If he redeems them outside</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>since it is written:</b> “And the priest shall wave them with the bread of the first fruits for a wave offering <b>before the Lord,</b> with the two lambs” (Leviticus 23:20), <b>he disqualifies</b> the two loaves that possess inherent sanctity <b>by</b> causing them to <b>leave</b> the courtyard, at which point they are no longer “before the Lord.” Conversely, <b>if</b> he redeems them <b>inside</b> the courtyard, once the two loaves that do not possess inherent sanctity are redeemed, he violates the prohibition against <b>bringing non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said to</b> them: <b>Actually</b> the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and</b> one <b>redeems</b> the loaves <b>inside</b> the courtyard. Nevertheless, it is not considered to be a violation of the prohibition against bringing non-sacred items into the courtyard because the <b>non-sacred</b> loaves <b>came</b> into the courtyard <b>by themselves,</b> i.e., they were already there when they became non-sacred and were not actively brought into the courtyard in their non-sacred state.
<b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to this very case: <b>When he redeems</b> the loaves, <b>he</b> may <b>redeem them only outside</b> of the courtyard? This contradicts Rav Ḥisda’s claim that according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi one redeems the loaves inside the courtyard.
Rav Ashi answered: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is certainly</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, because if</b> it were in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, when he brings the loaves outside the courtyard <b>he thereby disqualifies them by</b> causing them to <b>leave</b> the courtyard.
§ <b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: Let us say</b> that the <i>baraita</i>, which states that if the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> are slaughtered with four loaves instead of two, two of the four are invested with inherent sanctity, <b>is a conclusive refutation</b> of the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan that was stated</b> with regard to <b>a thanks offering that one slaughtered</b> accompanied <b>by eighty loaves</b> rather than the required forty. In that case, <b>Ḥizkiyya says: Forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Not</b> even <b>forty of</b> the <b>eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Wasn’t it stated with regard to this</b> dispute that <b>Rabbi Zeira says: Everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>concedes</b> that in a case <b>where</b> the individual bringing the offering <b>said: Let forty of</b> the <b>eighty</b> loaves <b>be consecrated, that</b> forty <b>are consecrated? Here too,</b> one can say that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where one said: Let two of the four</b> loaves <b>be consecrated.</b>
§ The Gemara cites another discussion concerning the sheep and loaves of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>Rabbi Ḥanina Tirata taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> If <b>one slaughtered four sheep</b> for <i>Shavuot</i>, rather than the required two, accompanied <b>by two loaves,</b> he <b>draws two of</b> the sheep out of the four <b>and sprinkles their blood not for the sake</b> of the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>. He then sprinkles the blood of the other sheep for the sake of the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>.
<b>As, if you do not say</b> to do <b>this,</b> but rather require him to first sprinkle the blood of two of the sheep for their own sake, then <b>you have caused the loss</b> of <b>the latter</b> two sheep. Since they were previously fit to have their blood sprinkled on the altar for the sake of the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>, and were disqualified from this status when the blood of the other two sheep was sprinkled for that purpose, they are no longer fit to have their blood sprinkled even for the sake of a different offering.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said to</b> Rabbi Ḥanina Tirata: <b>And does</b> the court <b>say to a person: Arise and sin in order that you may gain?</b> Is it proper for the priest to sprinkle the blood of the first pair not for their own sake so that the second pair will remain fit?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Zevaḥim</i> 77a) that <i>tanna’im</i> disagree concerning this matter? The mishna teaches: In the case of <b>the limbs of a sin offering,</b> whose flesh is eaten by priests and may not be burned on the altar, <b>that were intermingled with the limbs of a burnt offering,</b> which are burned on the altar, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The priest <b>shall place</b> all the limbs <b>above,</b> on the altar, <b>and I view the flesh</b> of the limbs <b>of the sin offering above</b> on the altar <b>as though they are</b> pieces of <b>wood</b> burned on the altar, not an offering. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> One should wait until <b>the form of</b> all the intermingled limbs <b>decays and they will</b> all <b>go out to the place of burning</b> in the Temple courtyard, where all disqualified offerings of the most sacred order are burned.
Rabbi Yoḥanan continued: According to your opinion, <b>why</b> do the Rabbis say that the mixture is burned? <b>Let</b> the court <b>say</b> to the priest instead: <b>Arise and sin</b> by burning all the limbs on the altar, including the limbs of the sin offering, <b>in order that you may gain</b> by performing the mitzva of sacrificing the limbs of the burnt offering.
Rabbi Ḥanina Tirata answered Rabbi Yoḥanan: <b>We do say: Arise and sin with a sin offering in order that you may gain with regard to a sin offering,</b> since it is the same type of offering. Similarly, one may sin with regard to the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> in order to gain with regard to the other sheep brought for the same offering. <b>We do not say: Arise and sin with a sin offering in order that you may gain with regard to a burnt offering.</b> Therefore, the Rabbis prohibit burning the limbs of the sin offering on the altar in order to allow for the burning of the limbs of the burnt offering.
Rabbi Yoḥanan asked Rabbi Ḥanina Tirata: <b>And does</b> the court actually <b>say:</b> Arise and sin in order that you may gain in a case where the sin and the gain are <b>with regard to one matter? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> concerning a case of the two <b>sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> where one slaughtered them not for their</b> own <b>sake, or where he slaughtered them either before their time,</b> i.e., before <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>or after their time,</b> that <b>the blood shall be sprinkled,</b> although it shall be sprinkled for the sake of a peace offering, <b>and the meat shall be eaten.</b>
Rabbi Yoḥanan continued: <b>And if</b> the Festival <b>was</b> on <b>Shabbat, one may not sprinkle</b> the blood, the sacrificial portions may not be burned on the altar, and the meat may not be eaten. This is because the improper slaughter of the sheep disqualified them as communal offerings, whereas individual offerings may not be sacrificed on Shabbat. <b>But if</b> the priest nevertheless <b>sprinkled</b> the blood of these sheep on Shabbat, the offering <b>is accepted</b> in that it is permitted <b>to burn</b> its sacrificial <b>portions</b> on the altar <b>in the evening,</b> after the conclusion of Shabbat, and then the meat may be eaten.
Rabbi Yoḥanan concluded his proof: <b>But</b> according to your opinion, <b>why</b> is it not permitted to sprinkle the blood on Shabbat? <b>Let</b> the court <b>say: Arise</b> and <b>sin</b> by sprinkling the blood of these offerings <b>in order that you may gain</b> by being able to burn their sacrificial portions in the evening and then eat their meat.
Rabbi Ḥanina Tirata answered: <b>We do say: Arise and sin on Shabbat in order that you may gain on Shabbat. We do not say: Arise and sin on Shabbat in order that you may gain on a weekday.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it so that <b>with regard to two</b> separate <b>matters</b> the court does <b>not say</b> that one should sin with regard to one in order to gain with regard to other? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 8:9): In the case of <b>a barrel of</b> wine that is <b><i>teruma</i> that broke in the upper</b> section of a <b>winepress, and in the lower</b> section of the winepress there is <b>non-sacred, impure</b> wine, and the wine that is <i>teruma</i> will flow into the lower press and become impure, <b>Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua</b> both <b>concede that if one is able to rescue</b> even <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of</b> the wine that is <i>teruma</i> in a pure vessel so that it retains its <b>ritual purity, he</b> should <b>rescue</b> it, even if, in the process, the rest of the wine that is <i>teruma</i> will mix with the non-sacred wine. This will cause the owner a financial loss, because the wine that is <i>teruma</i> will become impure, causing the entire mixture to become prohibited for consumption.
<b>But if not,</b> i.e., one cannot save any of the wine that is <i>teruma</i>, e.g., if one does not have any pure vessels in which to collect it, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b>

Daf 48b

The <i>teruma</i> wine should be allowed to <b>descend and become impure</b> on its own, ruining the non-sacred wine in the lower press, <b>but one</b> should <b>not render it impure through</b> his direct <b>action</b> by catching it in an impure vessel, even though catching it would prevent the wine that is <i>teruma</i> from mixing with his impure, non-sacred wine. <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> Since the wine that is <i>teruma</i> will become impure in any event, <b>one</b> may <b>even render it impure through</b> his direct <b>action</b> in order to save his non-sacred wine. This indicates that according to Rabbi Yehoshua it is permitted to sin with regard to one matter, i.e., the wine that is <i>teruma</i>, in order to gain with regard to another matter, i.e., the non-sacred wine.
The Gemara responds: It <b>is different there,</b> in the case of the wine, <b>because</b> the wine that is <i>teruma</i> <b>is going to</b> become <b>impure</b> in any event. Consequently, his action is not considered a sin, and this is not a case of sinning with regard to one matter in order to gain in another.
§ The Gemara continues its discussion of the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>When Rav Yitzḥak came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia he reported traditions that he learned in Eretz Yisrael, and <b>he taught</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to a case of the two <b>sheep</b> of <b><i>Shavuot</i> where one slaughtered them not in accordance with their mitzva,</b> e.g., he slaughtered them for the sake of a different offering, they are <b>disqualified; and</b> they should be left overnight until <b>their form decays</b> and they attain the status of leftover sacrificial meat, <b>and</b> then <b>they are brought out to the place</b> designated <b>for burning.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said</b> to Rav Yitzḥak: The <b>Master,</b> i.e., Rav Yitzḥak, <b>who compares</b> the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> <b>to a sin offering</b> because they are juxtaposed in a verse (see Leviticus 23:19), <b>teaches:</b> The sheep are <b>disqualified,</b> like a sin offering that was slaughtered not for its own sake. By contrast, the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Levi, who derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an obligatory peace offering,</b> e.g., the two sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a voluntary peace offering, teaches</b> that the two sheep remain <b>valid</b> offerings, just as a voluntary peace offering remains valid even if it is slaughtered for the sake of a different offering.
<b>As Levi teaches: And</b> with regard to the <b>other peace offerings of a nazirite that one slaughtered not in accordance with their mitzva,</b> they are <b>valid</b> offerings like voluntary peace offerings, <b>but they do not satisfy the obligation of the owner</b> to bring the required nazirite peace offerings. <b>And</b> these offerings <b>are eaten for</b> only <b>one day and one night,</b> in accordance with the <i>halakha</i> concerning the peace offerings of nazirite, and not for two days and one night like voluntary peace offerings. They <b>require neither bread nor</b> the <b>foreleg,</b> unlike the required peace offering of a nazirite.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rav Yitzḥak from that which was taught in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where one is obligated to sacrifice as <b>a guilt offering</b> an animal <b>in its</b> first <b>year,</b> which the Torah calls a lamb, <b>and</b> instead he <b>brought</b> an animal <b>in its second</b> year, which is considered a ram; or if he is obligated to sacrifice as a guilt offering an animal <b>in its second</b> year <b>and he brought</b> an animal <b>in its</b> first <b>year;</b> the offerings are <b>disqualified.</b> They are to be left overnight until <b>their form decays, and are brought out to the place</b> designated for <b>burning.</b>
<b>But</b> in the case of <b>the burnt offering of a nazirite,</b> i.e., the lamb that is sacrificed when he completes his naziriteship; <b>or the burnt offering of a woman after childbirth,</b> i.e., the lamb she sacrifices on the forty-first day after giving birth to a son or on the eighty-first day after giving birth to a daughter; <b>or the burnt offering of a leper,</b> i.e., the lamb that is sacrificed after he is purified; in all of these cases if the animals <b>were in their second year</b> instead, <b>and one slaughtered them,</b> the offerings are <b>valid.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>The principle of the matter</b> is: <b>Any</b> animal <b>that is valid as a voluntary burnt offering is</b> also <b>valid as an obligatory burnt offering, and any</b> animal <b>that is disqualified as a sin offering is</b> also <b>disqualified as a guilt offering, except for</b> an offering that was sacrificed <b>not for its own sake,</b> which is disqualified in the case of a sin offering but not a guilt offering. This demonstrates that the <i>halakhot</i> of obligatory burnt offerings are derived from those of voluntary burnt offerings, despite the fact that the burnt offering of a nazirite is juxtaposed to the sin offering of a nazirite (see Numbers 6:14) and the burnt offering of a leper is juxtaposed to the sin offering of a leper (see Leviticus 14:19). Similarly, the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>, which are obligatory peace offerings, should be derived from the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to voluntary peace offerings, and not from the <i>halakha</i> pertaining to a sin offering as Rav Yitzḥak holds.
The Gemara answers: <b>This <i>tanna</i>,</b> who taught this <i>baraita</i>, <b>is</b> the <b><i>tanna</i> of the school of Levi</b> cited earlier, who holds that if one slaughters a sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> not for its own sake, it is nevertheless valid.
The Gemara discusses the opinion of Rav Naḥman, who maintains that the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Levi holds that a sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> slaughtered not for its own sake is valid because he derives its <i>halakha</i> from that of a voluntary peace offering. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> what Levi teaches to the contrary, <b>as Levi teaches: The guilt offering of a nazirite,</b> i.e., the lamb he brings on the eighth day after becoming impure through contact with a corpse, <b>and the guilt offering of a leper,</b> i.e., the lamb he brings at the completion of his purification, <b>that one slaughtered not for their sake are valid, but they did not satisfy the obligation of the owner.</b>
If <b>one slaughtered them</b> when the <b>time had not yet</b> arrived <b>for</b> their <b>owners</b> to sacrifice these offerings, <b>or they were in their second year</b> instead of their first year <b>and one slaughtered them,</b> they are <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>But if it is so</b> that Levi derives the <i>halakhot</i> of an obligatory offering from those of a voluntary one, <b>let him derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the guilt offering <b>from</b> that of the <b>peace offering,</b> in which case the guilt offerings should be valid even if they were in their second year. The Gemara answers: Levi <b>derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning an obligatory <b>peace offering from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning a voluntary <b>peace offering,</b> but <b>he does not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a guilt offering from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a peace offering.</b>
The Gemara further challenges the statement of Rav Naḥman: <b>But if</b> Levi <b>derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of an obligatory <b>peace offering from</b> that of a voluntary <b>peace offering, let him</b> similarly <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one <b>guilt offering from</b> that of another <b>guilt offering.</b> He should derive that <b>the guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper</b> are valid even if the animal is in its second year <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning <b>a guilt offering for robbery and a guilt offering for misuse</b> of consecrated property, which are supposed to be a ram in its second year. <b>Or,</b> if one brought a lamb in its first year as <b>a guilt offering for robbery or a guilt offering for misuse</b> of consecrated property, Levi should derive that it is valid <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>guilt offering of a nazirite and the guilt offering of a leper,</b> which are lambs in their first year.
<b>Rav Shimi bar Ashi said: One can derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> e.g., the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> that were slaughtered not for their own sake, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to another <b>item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> e.g., a voluntary peace offering slaughtered not for its own sake. <b>But one cannot derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>not in its valid manner,</b> e.g., the guilt offering of a nazirite or a leper that is sacrificed when it is in its second year, <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>an item that is</b> prepared <b>in its valid manner,</b> e.g., a guilt offering for robbery or for misuse of consecrated property that is sacrificed when it is in its second year.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> can one <b>not</b> derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to disqualified offerings from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to fit offerings? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to</b> an item that <b>left</b> the Temple courtyard and was thereby disqualified <b>that if</b> it nevertheless <b>ascended</b> upon the altar <b>it shall not descend?</b> It is derived from the fact <b>that</b> an item that <b>left is valid</b> for sacrifice <b>on</b> a private <b>altar.</b> Here, the <i>baraita</i> derives the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an disqualified offering from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a fit offering.

Daf 49a

The Gemara answers: The <b><i>tanna</i></b> of that <i>baraita</i> <b>relies on</b> the phrase: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering [<i>ha’ola</i>]:</b> It is that which goes up on its firewood upon the altar all night unto the morning” (Leviticus 6:2), a seemingly superfluous general phrase which is interpreted homiletically to <b>include</b> the <i>halakha</i> that any item that ascends [<i>ola</i>] upon the altar shall not descend from it, even if it was disqualified. The verse is the actual source for the <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i>, whereas the case of a private altar is cited merely in support of this ruling. Accordingly, the <i>baraita</i> does not contradict the opinion of Rav Shimi bar Ashi.
§ The Gemara cites another discussion concerning the sheep of <i>Shavuot</i>. <b>Rabba bar bar Ḥana taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav:</b> In a case of <b>the</b> two <b>sheep of <i>Shavuot</i> where one slaughtered them for the sake of rams</b> and not for their own sake, <b>they are valid</b> offerings, <b>but they do not satisfy the obligation of the owner,</b> i.e., the community, to sacrifice these offerings. <b>Rav said to</b> Rabba bar bar Ḥana: That is not so; rather, the sheep <b>certainly satisfy</b> the obligation of the community.
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: The statement of Rav is reasonable in</b> a case where <b>one thought</b> that they were <b>rams</b> when he slaughtered them, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>slaughtered them for the sake of lambs.</b> In such a case, it makes sense that they satisfy the community’s obligation <b>since</b> the <b>lambs were slaughtered for the sake of lambs.</b>
<b>But</b> in a case where <b>he thought</b> that they were <b>rams</b> when he slaughtered them, <b>and</b> therefore <b>slaughtered them for the sake of rams,</b> they do <b>not</b> satisfy the community’s obligation, even though they were actually lambs. This is due to the fact that the <b>erroneous uprooting</b> of the status of an offering <b>constitutes uprooting,</b> despite the fact that it was done in error. <b>But Rabba said:</b> The <b>erroneous uprooting</b> of the status of an offering <b>does not constitute uprooting.</b>
<b>Rava said: We raise an objection to our</b> own ruling concerning this <b><i>halakha</i></b> from that which was taught in a mishna (<i>Gittin</i> 54a): In a case of <b>priests who disqualified</b> an offering <b>through improper intention in the Temple,</b> by expressing, while sacrificing the offering, the intention to eat it after the appropriate time, if they did so <b>intentionally, they are liable</b> to pay the value of the offering to its owner, who must now bring another offering. It follows, <b>therefore,</b> that if the priests did so <b>unintentionally they are exempt. And</b> it <b>is taught concerning this</b> case in a <i>baraita</i>: Even though they slaughtered it with improper intent unintentionally, <b>their</b> act of <b>improper intention</b> renders the offering <b><i>piggul</i>,</b> despite the fact that they are exempt from paying damages.
<b>What are the circumstances</b> in which this is the <i>halakha</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to a case where the priest <b>knew that</b> the offering <b>was a sin offering,</b> which is eaten for only one day and one night, <b>and</b> nevertheless <b>he intended</b> the offering to be <b>for the sake of a peace offering,</b> which is eaten for two days and one night, and thereby his intention was that it be eaten after its appropriate time, is <b>this</b> considered <b>an unintentional</b> act by the priests? Certainly <b>they were</b> acting <b>intentionally.</b>
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case where the offering was a sin offering, which is eaten for only one day and one night, and the priest <b>thought that it was a peace offering and</b> therefore <b>he intended</b> the offering to be <b>for the sake of a peace offering,</b> which is eaten for two days and one night, and thereby his intention was that it be eaten after its appropriate time? <b>And</b> with regard to this case the <i>tanna</i> <b>taught: Their</b> act of <b>improper intention</b> renders the offering <b><i>piggul</i>. Apparently,</b> this proves that the <b>erroneous uprooting</b> of the status of an offering <b>constitutes uprooting,</b> contrary to the ruling of Rabba.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rava: There is no objection from this <i>baraita</i>, because <b>actually</b> it is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>knew that it</b> was <b>a sin offering and</b> nevertheless <b>he intended</b> the offering to be <b>for the sake of a peace offering,</b> and his uprooting was done intentionally. Nevertheless, the <i>baraita</i> refers to the priests as acting unintentionally because it is referring to circumstances <b>where</b> the priest <b>says,</b> i.e., he mistakenly thinks, that it is <b>permitted</b> to sacrifice the offering with this intent.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raises an objection</b> to Rabba’s opinion that erroneous uprooting of the status of an offering does not constitute uprooting. A <i>baraita</i> teaches that <b>Rabbi Shimon says: All meal offerings</b> from which <b>the handful was removed not for their sake are</b> entirely <b>valid, and have</b> even <b>satisfied the obligation of the owner,</b> unlike animal offerings slaughtered not for their sake, which do not satisfy the obligation of the owner.
This is <b>because meal offerings are not similar to animal offerings. As,</b> in the case of <b>one who removes a handful</b> from a meal offering prepared in a shallow <b>pan for the sake of</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan, its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is a shallow-<b>pan</b> meal offering and not a deep-pan meal offering. Since a meal offering prepared in a shallow pan is hard and one prepared in a deep pan is soft, his intention is plainly false. Similarly, if one removes a handful from <b>a dry</b> meal offering, the meal offering of a sinner, which has no oil, <b>for the sake of</b> a meal offering <b>mixed</b> with oil, his intention is plainly false, as <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is <b>a dry</b> meal offering.
<b>But with regard to animal offerings</b> this <b>is not so.</b> There is <b>one</b> mode of <b>slaughter for all of</b> the offerings, <b>one</b> mode of <b>collection</b> of the blood <b>for all of them,</b> and <b>one</b> mode of <b>sprinkling for all of them.</b> Since the only factor that distinguishes between one type of offering and another is the intention of the individuals involved in its sacrifice, their intention is significant. Consequently, if one of the sacrificial rites is performed for the sake of the wrong type of offering, the offering does not satisfy its owner’s obligation.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> to which Rabbi Shimon is referring? <b>If we say</b> that he is referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>knew that</b> the meal offering <b>was</b> prepared in a shallow <b>pan, and</b> nevertheless <b>he removed a handful</b> from it <b>for the sake of</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan,</b> then although <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> that it was prepared in a shallow pan, <b>what of it?</b> In any case <b>he is</b> consciously <b>uprooting</b> its status as a shallow-pan meal offering, changing it to a deep-pan meal offering by means of his intention when he removes the handful.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>thought it was</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan and</b> therefore <b>removed a handful for the sake of</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan, but he was mistaken,</b> as it was actually a meal offering prepared in a shallow pan? <b>It is</b> specifically <b>here,</b> in this case, that Rabbi Shimon rules that the offering remains valid, <b>since its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is a shallow-pan meal offering, which indicates <b>that in general, erroneous uprooting</b> of the status of an offering <b>constitutes uprooting,</b> contrary the ruling of Rabba.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rabbi Zeira, in response to his objection: This objection to Rabba’s opinion is inconclusive, because one can explain that the <i>baraita</i> is <b>actually</b> referring to a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>knew that</b> the meal offering <b>was</b> prepared in a shallow <b>pan, and</b> nevertheless <b>he removed a handful for the sake of</b> a meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which you said</b> in your question: Although <b>its mode of preparation proves</b> that <b>it</b> is prepared in a shallow pan, <b>what of it,</b> i.e., since he is consciously uprooting its identity, how can it satisfy its owner’s obligation? Abaye answers that <b>Rava</b> conforms <b>to his</b> line of <b>reasoning, as Rava says: The Merciful One disqualifies</b> an offering due to improper <b>intent that is not recognizably</b> false, i.e., when the physical properties of the offering itself do not prove that the intent is mistaken. <b>The Merciful One does not disqualify</b> an offering due to improper <b>intent that is recognizably</b> false. Consequently, if one removes a handful from a shallow-pan meal offering for the sake of a deep-pan meal offering, even if he did so consciously, the offering remains valid and satisfies the owner’s obligation.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Failure to sacrifice <b>the daily offerings does not prevent</b> sacrifice of <b>the additional offerings, and</b> likewise, failure to sacrifice <b>the additional offerings does not prevent</b> sacrifice of <b>the daily offerings. And</b> failure to sacrifice some of <b>the additional offerings</b> on a day when more than one is sacrificed, e.g., if it was both Shabbat and the New Moon, <b>does not prevent</b> sacrifice of the <b>other</b> additional offerings. If the priests <b>did not sacrifice a lamb in the morning</b> as the daily offering, nevertheless, <b>they should sacrifice</b> a lamb <b>in the afternoon</b> as the daily offering, as failure to sacrifice one daily offering does not prevent sacrifice of the other. In all of these cases, if they failed to sacrifice one offering, they should still sacrifice the other.
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: When</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply? It applies <b>at a time when</b> the failure to sacrifice the daily morning offering was because <b>they were</b> prevented from sacrificing it due to <b>circumstances beyond their control or</b> they failed to sacrifice it <b>unwittingly. But if</b> the priests acted <b>intentionally and did not sacrifice a lamb in the morning</b> as the daily offering, <b>they should not sacrifice</b> a lamb <b>in the afternoon</b> as the daily offering.
Incense was burned twice a day, half a measure in the morning and half a measure in the afternoon. If <b>they did not burn</b> the half-measure of <b>incense in the morning, they should burn</b> the half-measure <b>in the afternoon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: And</b> in such a case, <b>the entire</b> measure <b>was sacrificed in the afternoon.</b> The reason for the difference between the daily offerings and the incense is <b>that</b> the daily service on a new <b>golden altar is initiated only with</b> the burning of <b>the incense of the spices</b> in the afternoon, at which time they would burn a full measure. <b>And the</b> daily service on a new <b>altar of the burnt offering,</b> on which the daily offerings were sacrificed, is initiated <b>only with the daily morning offering. And</b> use of a new <b>Table</b> was initiated <b>only with</b> the arrangement of <b>the shewbread on Shabbat, and</b> use of a new <b>Candelabrum</b> was initiated <b>only with</b> the kindling <b>of its seven lamps in the afternoon.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the daily offerings and the additional offerings each do not prevent fulfillment of the mitzva with the other. Concerning this, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin raised a dilemma before Rav Ḥisda:</b> In the case of <b>a community that did not have</b> the resources to sacrifice both <b>the daily offerings and the additional offerings, which of them takes precedence</b> over the other?
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> to which Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin is referring? <b>If we say</b> that he is referring to a case where the choice is between <b>the daily offerings of that day and the additional offerings of that</b> same <b>day,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that <b>the daily offerings are given preference, as</b> the sacrifice of the daily offerings <b>is</b> more <b>frequent</b> than the sacrifice of the additional offerings, which are sacrificed only on special occasions, <b>and</b> the daily offerings are also <b>sanctified.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin must be referring to a case where they have enough animals for the daily offerings of today and also for either <b>the daily offerings for tomorrow or the additional offerings for today.</b> In such a case, are <b>the daily offerings given preference since</b> their sacrifice is more <b>frequent? Or perhaps the additional offerings are given preference because they are</b> considered more <b>sanctified</b> because they are sacrificed on a holy day.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin: The resolution to this dilemma can be derived from that which <b>you learned</b> in the mishna: Failure to sacrifice <b>the daily offerings does not prevent</b> sacrifice of <b>the additional offerings, and</b> likewise, failure to sacrifice <b>the additional offerings does not prevent</b> sacrifice of <b>the daily offerings. And</b> failure to sacrifice some of <b>the additional offerings does not prevent</b> sacrifice of the <b>other</b> additional offerings.
<b>What are the circumstances</b> to which the mishna is referring? <b>If we say</b> that it is referring to a case where the Temple treasury <b>has</b> all of the animals necessary for both offerings, <b>and</b> the only question is <b>in</b> terms of sacrificing one <b>before</b> the other, <b>isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that no</b> sacrifice <b>should precede</b> the sacrifice of the <b>daily offering of morning?</b> The <i>baraita</i> continues: It is derived from that which <b>the verse states:</b> “And the fire upon the altar shall be kept burning thereby, it shall not go out; and the priest shall kindle wood on it every morning; <b>and he shall lay the burnt offering in order on it,</b> and shall cause the fats of the peace offering to go up in smoke upon it” (Leviticus 6:5).
<b>And Rava says</b> in explanation of this derivation in the <i>baraita</i> that the term <b>“the burnt offering,”</b> with the definite article, is referring to <b>the first burnt offering</b> of the day, which is the daily offering. Consequently, one may not sacrifice the additional offerings before the daily offering.

Daf 49b

<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where he does not have</b> a sufficient number of animals for both offerings. <b>And if</b> it is referring to the offerings <b>of that day, why</b> does the mishna say that failure to sacrifice one does not prevent sacrifice of the other? Since the daily offering is more <b>frequent</b> and it is sanctified, <b>and</b> the additional offerings are <b>sanctified</b> but are less frequent than the daily offering, the <b>frequent</b> offering <b>are given preference.</b> Consequently, failure to sacrifice the daily offering should prevent the sacrifice of the additional offerings.
<b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to a case where the Temple treasury does not have enough animals for both the additional offerings of today and the daily offering <b>of tomorrow, and</b> yet the mishna <b>teaches</b> that failure to sacrifice one does <b>not prevent</b> one from sacrificing <b>the other? Evidently, they are equal</b> and he may sacrifice whichever offering he chooses. This would resolve Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin’s dilemma.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Ḥisda: That is not a valid resolution of the dilemma, as one can claim that <b>actually,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where they have</b> enough animals for all the offerings, <b>and</b> the mishna is referring to the issue of sacrificing one <b>before</b> the other. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>that which</b> poses <b>a difficulty for you</b> based upon the <i>baraita</i> that states that <b>no</b> sacrifice <b>should precede</b> the sacrifice of the daily offering of the morning, that <i>baraita</i> <b>is merely</b> stating <b>the mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Avin’s dilemma based upon a mishna (<i>Arakhin</i> 13a): One maintains <b>no fewer than six lambs that</b> have been <b>inspected</b> and found to be unblemished <b>in the Chamber of the Lambs, sufficient for Shabbat and for the two festival days of Rosh HaShana</b> that in some years occur adjacent to it.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say that</b> it is referring to a case where the Temple treasury <b>has</b> enough animals for all of the offerings that should be brought, six lambs are not enough, as <b>there are many</b> lambs sacrificed for <b>daily offerings and additional offerings</b> on those three days. In total, twenty-two lambs are required: Two each day for the daily offerings, two for the additional offering of Shabbat, seven for the additional offering of Rosh HaShana, and seven for the additional offering of the New Moon.
<b>Rather, is it not that</b> the mishna is referring to a case where the Temple treasury <b>does not have</b> enough animals for all of the offerings, and it is teaching that the animals that he does have are utilized for the daily offerings of all three days rather than for the additional offering of Shabbat on the first of the three days? Consequently, one may <b>conclude from it</b> that the <b>daily offerings</b> of tomorrow <b>are given preference</b> over the additional offerings of today.
The Gemara replies: <b>No,</b> this is not a valid proof, as one can claim that <b>actually,</b> the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the Temple treasury <b>has</b> enough animals for all of the offerings of the three days, <b>and this is what</b> the mishna <b>is saying</b> when it mentions six lambs: One maintains for use as daily offerings <b>no fewer than six lambs that</b> have been <b>inspected</b> and found to be unblemished <b>in the Chamber of the Lambs four days prior to</b> their <b>slaughter.</b> Lambs sacrificed as other offerings do not have to be inspected four days prior to being slaughtered. <b>And</b> in accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>ben Bag Bag.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>ben Bag Bag says: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the daily offering requires inspection four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter? The verse states</b> with regard to the daily offering: <b>“You shall observe [<i>tishmeru</i>] to sacrifice to Me in its due season”</b> (Numbers 28:2), <b>and elsewhere,</b> with regard to the Paschal offering, the verse <b>states:</b> “On the tenth day of this month they shall take for them every man a lamb…<b>and you shall keep it [<i>mishmeret</i>] until the fourteenth day</b> of this month” (Exodus 12:3–6).
Consequently, it is derived by means of a verbal analogy that <b>just as</b> in the verse <b>there,</b> the Paschal offering <b>requires inspection four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> from the tenth of the month to the fourteenth, <b>so too here,</b> the daily offering <b>requires inspection four days prior to</b> its <b>slaughter.</b> This is not a requirement that pertains to all offerings; it is stated specifically with regard to the Paschal offering and extended by means of a verbal analogy to the daily offering.
§ The Gemara cites a discussion pertaining to the mishna cited earlier. <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> With regard to <b>these six</b> inspected lambs that must always be kept in the Chamber of Lambs, there ought to <b>be seven, as there is</b> a need for another lamb for the daily offering <b>of the morning of the third</b> day <b>of the week,</b> since it cannot be inspected on Shabbat or the subsequent festival days of Rosh HaShana, and therefore should be inspected and kept beforehand.
Rav Ashi responded to Ravina: <b>According to your reasoning</b> the correct number is not seven, but rather <b>it is eight; as there is</b> also the daily offering <b>of the afternoon of Shabbat eve</b> that should also be counted.
Ravina replied: <b>That</b> is <b>not difficult,</b> because the mishna <b>is saying that after he sacrificed</b> the daily offering of the afternoon there must be six inspected lambs.

Daf 50a

The Gemara asks: <b>In any case,</b> the question stands: Why does the mishna say six lambs when, in fact the number required <b>is seven?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Rather, the <i>tanna</i> is</b> speaking <b>generally,</b> referring to how many inspected lambs are required throughout the year. <b>And what</b> did he mean by his statement: <b>Sufficient for Shabbat and for the two festival days of Rosh HaShana?</b> It is <b>merely</b> intended as <b>a mnemonic,</b> to help one remember that there must be enough lambs for the daily offering of three days.
According to this the language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as</b> it <b>teaches: Sufficient for Shabbat</b> and for the two festival days of Rosh HaShana, <b>and it does not teach</b> that there must be six lambs <b>for Shabbat and for the two festival days of Rosh HaShana,</b> which would have indicated that these lambs are meant to actually be sacrificed on those days. The Gemara concludes that in fact one can <b>learn from</b> the language of the mishna that this is the correct interpretation.
§ The mishna teaches: If the priests <b>did not sacrifice a lamb in the morning</b> as the daily offering, nevertheless, they should sacrifice a lamb in the afternoon as the daily offering. If they did not burn the half-measure of incense in the morning, they should burn the half-measure in the afternoon. <b>Rabbi Shimon said: And</b> in such a case, <b>the entire</b> measure <b>was sacrificed in the afternoon, as</b> the daily service on a new <b>golden altar is initiated only with</b> the burning of <b>the incense of the spices</b> in the afternoon, at which time they would burn a full measure. The Gemara asks: <b>Who mentioned anything about</b> the <b>initiation</b> of the Temple vessels, i.e., what is its relevance to the mishna?
The Gemara answers that the mishna <b>is incomplete, and this is</b> what <b>it is teaching:</b> If <b>they did not sacrifice a lamb</b> for the daily offering <b>in the morning, they should not sacrifice</b> a lamb in <b>the afternoon. In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> the service of a new <b>altar had not</b> yet <b>been initiated,</b> since it must first be initiated with the daily offering of the morning. <b>But</b> if the service of <b>the altar had</b> already <b>been initiated,</b> then <b>they should sacrifice</b> the lamb of the daily offering in <b>the afternoon</b> even though they did not sacrifice the lamb of the morning offering.
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: When</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply? It applies <b>at a time when</b> the failure to sacrifice the daily morning offering was because <b>they were</b> prevented from sacrificing it due to <b>circumstances beyond their control or</b> they failed to sacrifice it <b>unwittingly. But if</b> the priests acted <b>intentionally and did not sacrifice a lamb in the morning</b> as the daily offering, <b>they should not sacrifice</b> a lamb <b>in the afternoon</b> as the daily offering. By contrast, if <b>they did not burn</b> the half-measure of <b>incense in the morning, they should burn</b> the half-measure <b>in the afternoon</b> regardless of the circumstances.
The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived, that if the lamb of the daily offering of the morning was not sacrificed and the service of a new altar had not yet been initiated, then the lamb of the afternoon is also not sacrificed? The Gemara explains that it is derived <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: “The one lamb you shall offer in the morning; <b>and the second lamb you shall offer in the afternoon”</b> (Exodus 29:39). This verse teaches that <b>the second</b> lamb of the daily offering is sacrificed <b>in the afternoon, but</b> if it is <b>the first</b> one to be sacrificed, it may <b>not</b> be sacrificed <b>in the afternoon.</b>
<b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where</b> the service of a new <b>altar had not</b> yet <b>been initiated,</b> since it must first be initiated with the offering of the morning. When the verse refers to the first or second offering, it means the first or second offering ever sacrificed on the altar. <b>But</b> if the service of <b>the altar had</b> already <b>been initiated,</b> then <b>even</b> if it is <b>the first</b> to be sacrificed that day, it should be sacrificed <b>in the afternoon.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon said: When</b> does this <i>halakha</i> apply? It applies <b>at a time when</b> the failure to sacrifice the daily morning offering was because <b>they were</b> prevented from sacrificing it due to <b>circumstances beyond their control or</b> they failed to sacrifice it <b>unwittingly. But if</b> the priests acted <b>intentionally and did not sacrifice a lamb in the morning</b> as the daily offering, <b>they should not sacrifice</b> a lamb <b>in the afternoon</b> as the daily offering. By contrast, if <b>they did not burn</b> the half-measure of <b>incense in the morning, they should burn</b> the half-measure <b>in the afternoon</b> regardless of the circumstances.
The Gemara asks: Does it make sense that <b>because the priests sinned</b> by intentionally failing to sacrifice the morning daily offering, <b>the altar</b> should be entirely <b>idle? Rava said</b> that <b>this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying: They,</b> the priests who deliberately failed to sacrifice the morning daily offering, <b>should not sacrifice</b> the afternoon daily offering; <b>but other</b> priests <b>should sacrifice</b> it.
By contrast, if the priests acted intentionally and <b>did not burn</b> the <b>incense in the morning,</b> even those same priests <b>may burn</b> it in the <b>afternoon.</b> The reason for this is <b>that since</b> burning the incense <b>is uncommon and causes</b> those who do so to become <b>wealthy,</b> it is <b>dear to the</b> priests, <b>and they will not be negligent</b> in the performance of this rite.
§The mishna teaches that if they did not burn the half-measure of incense in the morning, they should burn the half-measure in the afternoon. <b>Rabbi Shimon said: And</b> in such a case, <b>the entire</b> measure <b>was sacrificed in the afternoon.</b> The reason for the difference between the daily offerings and the incense is <b>that</b> the daily service on a new <b>golden altar is initiated only with</b> the burning of <b>the incense of the spices of the afternoon,</b> at which time they would burn a full measure. The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The service of a new golden altar is initiated <b>with</b> the burning of <b>the incense of the spices of the morning?</b> The Gemara answers: The question of whether the incense of the morning or the afternoon initiates the service of a new golden altar <b>is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>.</b>
<b>Abaye said:</b> It <b>stands to reason</b> that the <i>halakha</i> should be <b>in accordance with the one who says</b> that it was initiated <b>with the incense of the spices of the afternoon, as it is written</b> with regard to the golden altar: “And Aaron shall burn thereon incense of sweet spices; <b>every morning, when he dresses the lamps, he shall burn it.</b> And when Aaron lights the lamps at dusk, he shall burn it, a perpetual incense before the Lord throughout your generations” (Exodus 30:7–8).
The fact that ashes are removed from the lamps of the Candelabrum in the morning indicates that the lamps had been lit previously, since <b>if</b> the priest had <b>not performed the lighting</b> of the lamps the previous <b>evening, from where</b> would the ashes be <b>removed in the morning?</b> This proves that the Candelabrum must have been lit for the first time in the evening. Since the verse states: “When Aaron lights the lamps at dusk, he shall burn it, a perpetual incense before the Lord,” it must be that the incense was burned for the first time in the evening.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according to the one who says</b> that the service of a new golden altar is initiated <b>with</b> the burning of <b>the incense of the spices of the morning,</b> from where is this <i>halakha</i> derived? The Gemara answers: He <b>derives</b> it <b>from</b> the initiation of <b>the altar of the burnt offering. Just as there,</b> the service of a new altar of the burnt offering is initiated <b>by</b> means of the <b>daily offering of the morning</b> rather than the afternoon, <b>so too here,</b> the service of a new golden altar is initiated <b>by</b> means of the burning of <b>the incense of the spices of the morning.</b>
§The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> use of a new <b>Table</b> was initiated <b>only with</b> the arrangement of <b>the shewbread on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> does the mishna mean to indicate that if the shewbread was placed on the Table <b>on a weekday it is</b> merely that the use of a new Table <b>is not initiated, but</b> the shewbread <b>is sanctified?</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that the shewbread is sanctified only when it is placed on the Table on Shabbat.
The Gemara answers: The mishna <b>teaches us this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>itself, that the initiation</b> of the use of a new Table <b>and the sanctification of</b> the shewbread when it is placed on <b>the Table</b> occur only <b>on Shabbat.</b> This is <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> with regard to the initiation of the use of a new Candelabrum: <b>And</b> use of a new <b>Candelabrum</b> was initiated <b>only with</b> the kindling <b>of its seven lamps in the afternoon.</b>
§The Gemara cites another <i>halakha</i> relating to the burning of incense. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is incense that was offered for an individual</b> rather than the community <b>on the external altar,</b> and not on the golden altar as usual; <b>and this was a provisional edict,</b> permitted temporarily for that time only. The Gemara clarifies: To <b>what</b> case is the <i>baraita</i> referring? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> It is referring to the incense brought <b>by the</b> tribal <b>princes</b> at the inauguration of the Tabernacle (see Numbers, chapter 7).
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> with regard to the incense of <b>an individual, is it</b> only <b>on the external altar that</b> it is <b>not</b> generally permitted to be burned, <b>but</b> an individual <b>may sacrifice</b> incense <b>on the inner altar,</b> as indicated by the <i>baraita</i>? <b>And furthermore, on the external altar, is it</b> only an <b>individual who may not</b> sacrifice incense, <b>but the community may sacrifice</b> incense on the external altar?
<b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> contrary to those two inferences: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>an individual may voluntarily donate and bring</b> incense <b>similar to</b> the incense brought by the tribal princes to the Temple as <b>a gift</b> offering, <b>and I</b> will <b>read with regard to</b> this incense, as in the case of other gift offerings: <b>“That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do”</b> (Deuteronomy 23:24). Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> concerning the inner altar: <b>“You shall bring no strange incense thereon”</b> (Exodus 30:9). This indicates that an individual may not sacrifice incense even on the inner altar.
One <b>might</b> have thought that only <b>an individual may not bring</b> a gift of incense on the inner altar, <b>as</b> an individual <b>does not bring his obligatory</b> offering <b>similar to this</b> gift of incense, i.e., since an individual is never obligated to sacrifice incense, he may not voluntarily sacrifice incense either;

Daf 50b

<b>but a community may bring</b> incense as a gift offering, <b>as</b> the community <b>does bring its obligatory</b> offering <b>similar to this,</b> i.e., since the community is obligated to sacrifice incense it can also voluntarily sacrifice incense. Therefore, <b>the verse states: You shall not bring [<i>lo ta’alu</i>]</b> strange incense thereon” (Exodus 30:9). The fact that the verse formulates the prohibition with the plural word <i>ta’alu</i> indicates that even the community may not sacrifice incense as a voluntary gift offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that the community <b>may not bring</b> a gift offering of incense <b>on the inner altar, but</b> it <b>may bring</b> incense <b>on the external altar.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And the anointing oil, and the incense of sweet spices for the sacred place; according to all that I have commanded you shall they do”</b> (Exodus 31:11). This teaches that one <b>has</b> the right to do <b>only that which is stated with regard to the matter,</b> without deviation. Consequently, incense may sacrificed only by the community, only when there is an obligation to sacrifice it, and it must be burned only on the inner altar. This contradicts the implication of the previously cited <i>baraita</i> that it is permitted to burn the incense of an individual on the golden altar or the incense of a community on the outer altar.
<b>Rav Pappa said:</b> This is not problematic. The <i>baraita</i> <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>It is not necessary,</b> as follows. <b>It is not necessary</b> to state that <b>the community</b> may not sacrifice incense <b>on the external altar, as we have not found</b> a precedent for it. <b>And</b> similarly, <b>it is not necessary</b> to state that <b>an individual</b> may not sacrifice incense <b>on the inner altar, as we have not found</b> a precedent for it. <b>But</b> it is necessary to state that it is <b>even</b> prohibited for <b>an individual</b> to sacrifice incense <b>on the external altar,</b> despite the fact <b>that we have</b> ostensibly <b>found</b> a precedent for it <b>in</b> the case of <b>the</b> tribal <b>princes;</b> as that <b>was a provisional edict</b> and therefore cannot serve as a precedent.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The twelve loaves of <i>matza</i> prepared from a tenth of an ephah of flour of the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of the High Priest did not come</b> from the house of the High Priest <b>in halves. Rather,</b> the High Priest <b>brings</b> from his house <b>a complete tenth</b> of an ephah of flour (see Leviticus 6:13) <b>and divides it</b> in half, and he <b>sacrifices half in the morning and half in the afternoon.</b>
In the case of a High <b>Priest who brings</b> and sacrifices <b>half in the morning and dies, and they appointed another</b> High <b>Priest in his stead,</b> the replacement High Priest <b>should neither bring half of a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>from his house nor</b> sacrifice the remaining <b>half of</b> the <b>tenth of an ephah of</b> his <b>predecessor. Rather, he brings</b> from his house <b>an entire tenth</b> of an ephah <b>and divides it</b> in half, <b>sacrifices half, and</b> the other <b>half</b> is not sacrificed and <b>is lost. Consequently, two halves</b> of a tenth of an ephah <b>are sacrificed,</b> one-half of what was brought by each priest, <b>and</b> the other <b>two halves are lost.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara cites that which <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>, commenting on the verse: “This is the offering of Aaron and of his sons, which they shall offer to the Lord on the day when he is anointed: The tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a meal offering perpetually, half of it in the morning, and half of it in the evening” (Leviticus 6:13). <b>If</b> the verse had <b>stated: A meal offering</b> perpetually, <b>half</b> in the morning and half in the evening; <b>I would have said</b> that the High Priest <b>brings half of a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>in the morning and sacrifices</b> it, and then he brings <b>half of a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>in the afternoon and sacrifices</b> it.
Since <b>the verse states: “Half of it in the morning, and half of it in the evening”</b> (Leviticus 6:13), it teaches that <b>he sacrifices half of a complete</b> tenth of an ephah. <b>How so?</b> The High Priest <b>brings</b> from his house <b>a complete tenth</b> of an ephah of fine flour, <b>and divides it</b> in half, <b>and sacrifices half in the morning and half in the afternoon.</b>
In a case where the <b>half of</b> a tenth of an ephah that was supposed to be offered in <b>the afternoon became impure or was lost</b> after the High Priest sacrificed the first half in the morning, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he should bring half of a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>from his house and sacrifice</b> it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Half of it in the morning, and half of it in the evening,”</b> which teaches that <b>he brings half of a complete</b> tenth of an ephah.
<b>How so?</b> The High Priest <b>brings a complete tenth</b> of an ephah of fine flour <b>from his house and divides it</b> in half, <b>and he sacrifices half, and</b> the other <b>half</b> is not sacrificed and <b>is lost. Consequently, two halves</b> of a tenth of an ephah <b>are sacrificed,</b> the half that was sacrificed in the morning from the original tenth of an ephah, and half of the replacement tenth of an ephah, <b>and</b> the other <b>two halves are lost.</b>
In the case of a High <b>Priest who sacrificed half in the morning and died, and they appointed another</b> High <b>Priest in his stead,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that the second High Priest <b>should bring half of a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>from his house</b> and sacrifice it, <b>or</b> that he should sacrifice the remaining <b>half of a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>of the first</b> High Priest. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And half of it in the evening,”</b> which teaches that he <b>brings and sacrifices half of a complete</b> tenth of an ephah.
<b>How so?</b> The replacement High Priest <b>brings a complete tenth</b> of an ephah of fine flour <b>from his house and divides it</b> in half, <b>and he sacrifices</b> half, <b>and half</b> is not sacrificed and <b>is lost. Consequently, two halves</b> of a tenth of an ephah <b>are lost,</b> half of the tenth of an ephah brought by each priest, <b>and</b> the other <b>two halves are sacrificed.</b>
§ With regard to the two halves of a tenth of an ephah that are lost, <b>a <i>tanna</i>,</b> i.e., a Sage who recited <i>baraitot</i>, <b>taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> <b>before Rav Naḥman:</b> With regard to <b>the half</b> that was not sacrificed by the <b>first</b> High Priest, who died, <b>and the half</b> brought but not sacrificed by the <b>second</b> High Priest who replaced him, <b>their form should decay,</b> i.e., they should be left overnight so they become disqualified, <b>and</b> then they should be <b>brought out to the place</b> designated <b>for burning.</b>
<b>Rav Naḥman said to</b> the <i>tanna</i>: <b>Granted,</b> the half that was not sacrificed by the <b>first</b> High Priest should be left overnight before it is burned, because it was initially <b>fit for sacrifice</b> before the first High Priest died. <b>But</b> with regard to the half that was not sacrificed by the <b>second</b> High Priest, <b>why</b> must <b>it</b> be left overnight so that its <b>form decays?</b> It was <b>brought to be lost from the outset,</b> i.e., when the full tenth of an ephah was brought it was known that only half would be sacrificed and half would be lost. Consequently, it is unnecessary to leave it overnight before burning it.
Rav Naḥman continued: <b>Who is</b> the one <b>who said</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>to you? It was the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabba bar Avuh, who says:</b> All disqualified offerings, <b>even <i>piggul</i>,</b> which is disqualified by Torah law, <b>require decay of form</b> before they are burned.
<b>Rav Ashi said:</b> The <i>baraita</i> can be understood <b>even</b> if <b>you say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> who disagree with Rabba bar Avuh and hold that <i>piggul</i> does not require decay of form. Nevertheless, <b>since at the time when</b> the second High Priest <b>divides the</b> two halves, <b>if he wants</b> he can <b>sacrifice this</b> half, <b>and if he wants</b> he can <b>sacrifice that</b> other half, both halves are considered <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed and may not be burned until they are left overnight.
§ The Gemara cites that which <b>was stated</b> further about the griddle-cake offering: <b>How are the griddle-cake</b> offerings of <b>the High Priest prepared?</b> The verse seems to prescribe a variety of methods of preparation: “On a griddle it shall be made with oil; when it is soaked, you shall bring it in; and baked pieces [<i>tufinei</i>] of the meal offering shall you sacrifice for a pleasing aroma to the Lord” (Leviticus 6:14). <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba</b> says that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it is prepared in the following manner: The individual preparing it <b>bakes it</b> in an oven <b>and afterward he fries it</b> in a pan. <b>Rabbi Asi</b> says that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> that it is prepared in the following manner: The individual preparing it <b>fries it</b> in a pan <b>and afterward he bakes</b> it in an oven.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said: It stands to reason in accordance with my</b> opinion because the verse states: “And baked pieces [<i>tufinei</i>] of the meal offering.” The word for <b>baked pieces [<i>tufinei</i>]</b> should be understood as meaning that <b>they shall be baked</b> when they are still <b>beautiful [<i>te’afena na’a</i>],</b> i.e., before being fried. <b>Rabbi Asi said: It stands to reason in accordance with my</b> opinion because the word <i>tufinei</i> should be understood as meaning that <b>they shall be baked</b> when they are already <b>partially cooked [<i>te’afena na</i>],</b> i.e., after being fried.
This dispute between the <i>amora’im</i> is <b>parallel to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i></b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The word for baked pieces [<i>tufinei</i>] should be understood as meaning that <b>they shall be baked</b> when they are already <b>partially cooked [<i>te’afena na</i>]. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It should be understood as meaning that <b>they shall be baked</b> when they are still <b>beautiful [<i>te’afena na’a</i>]. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The word <i>tufinei</i> is plural, indicating that the pieces <b>should be baked extensively,</b> i.e., more than once. Consequently, Rabbi Yosei <b>accepts</b> the opinion that the pieces should be baked when they are already <b>partially cooked, and he</b> also <b>accepts</b> the opinion that they should be baked when they are <b>beautiful.</b> Therefore the offering should first be baked, then fried, then baked again.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (96a): Concerning the twelve loaves of <b>the High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, of which six are sacrificed in the morning and six in the evening, <b>their kneading, and forming of their</b> loaves, <b>and their baking are</b> performed <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> all labors involved in those actions <b>override Shabbat.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter,</b> i.e., that these actions override Shabbat, derived? <b>Rav Huna said:</b> The verse says <b><i>tufinei</i>,</b> meaning that when it is already <b>baked it must</b> still <b>be beautiful [<i>te’afena na’a</i>]. And if</b> one would <b>bake it yesterday,</b> on the eve of Shabbat, <b>it</b> would become <b>swollen [<i>inshefa</i>]</b> and no longer beautiful. <b>Rav Yosef objects to this:</b> If the purpose of baking them on Shabbat is to ensure they remain fresh, <b>say that</b> the loaves should be baked before Shabbat and <b>covered with greens</b> to preserve them.
The Gemara cites another explanation of why the preparation of these loaves overrides Shabbat. A Sage from <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught:</b> The verse states: “On a griddle it <b>shall be made</b> with oil” (Leviticus 6:14), which teaches that it shall be made under all circumstances, <b>even on Shabbat.</b> Similarly, this phrase <b>“shall be made”</b> teaches that it should be made <b>even in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity.</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> that there is a different explanation: The <b>verse states: “Fine flour for a meal offering perpetually”</b> (Leviticus 6:13);

Daf 51a

this teaches that the <i>halakha</i> of the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest <b>is like</b> that of <b>the meal offering</b> that is a component <b>of the daily offerings.</b> The daily offerings override Shabbat, as the verse says: “This is the burnt offering of every Shabbat, beside the continual burnt offering, and the drink offering thereof” (Numbers 28:10). Therefore, preparing the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest likewise overrides Shabbat.
<b>Rava said</b> that the basis for it overriding Shabbat is the fact that the verse states: <b>“On a griddle”</b> (Leviticus 6:14), which <b>teaches that</b> the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest <b>requires a vessel.</b> Therefore, <b>if he had baked it the previous day</b> rather than on Shabbat, it would be <b>disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight,</b> since the loaves had already been consecrated in a service vessel. It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rava: “On a griddle” teaches that</b> the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest <b>requires a vessel.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The continuation of the verse states: “It shall be made <b>with the oil.”</b> The fact that the verse makes reference to “the oil” rather than just oil indicates that one is supposed <b>to add</b> extra <b>oil to it,</b> but <b>I do not know how much</b> oil to add.
Therefore <b>I</b> must <b>deduce</b> as follows: <b>It is stated here,</b> concerning the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“Oil,” and it is stated there, with regard to the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany animal offerings: “A tenth part of an ephah of fine flour mingled with the fourth part of a <i>hin</i> of beaten <b>oil”</b> (Exodus 29:40). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the meal offering brought with the libations, the amount of oil required is <b>three <i>log</i> per tenth</b> of an ephah of flour; <b>so too here,</b> in the case of the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, one brings <b>three <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>per tenth</b> of an ephah of flour.
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way: It is stated here,</b> concerning the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“Oil,” and it is stated with regard to</b> the <b>voluntary meal offering:</b> “And when anyone brings a meal offering to the Lord, his offering shall be of fine flour; and he shall pour <b>oil</b> upon it” (Leviticus 2:1). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the voluntary meal offering, one brings <b>one <i>log</i></b> of oil for each tenth of an ephah of flour (see 88a); <b>so too here,</b> one brings <b>one <i>log</i></b> of oil for each tenth of an ephah of flour.
The <i>baraita</i> analyzes these two possibilities: <b>Let us see to which</b> case <b>it is</b> more <b>similar,</b> i.e., which is a better comparison to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest. Perhaps <b>we</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which has characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>tav</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>tet</i>, from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering brought with libations, which also has the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>tav</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>tet</i>.</b> These characteristics are that they are <b>frequent [<i>tadir</i>],</b> as these offerings are sacrificed twice daily; they are <b>brought [<i>ba’ah</i>] as an obligation;</b> they <b>override Shabbat;</b> and they <b>override impurity [<i>tuma</i>].</b>
<b>And we should not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which has the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>tav</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>tet</i>, from</b> the voluntary meal offering, which <b>does not</b> have the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>tav</i>, <i>beit</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>tet</i>.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way: We</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which has the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>yod</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>lamed</i>, from</b> the voluntary meal offering, which also has the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>yod</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>lamed</i>,</b> which stand for the following <i>halakhot</i>: Each of these offerings may be brought by <b>an individual [<i>yaḥid</i>];</b> each is <b>brought for [<i>biglal</i>] its own sake,</b> rather than accompanying another offering; they are not accompanied by <b>wine [<i>yayin</i>]</b> for a libation; and they require <b>frankincense [<i>levona</i>].</b>
<b>And we should not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which has the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>yod</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>lamed</i>, from</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the meal offering brought with libations, <b>which does not</b> have the characteristics represented by the letters <b><i>yod</i>, <i>gimmel</i>, <i>yod</i>, <i>lamed</i>.</b> Consequently, the comparisons in both directions are equally compelling.
The <i>baraita</i> continues its determination of how much oil is brought with the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest. <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, says:</b> “This is the offering of Aaron…the tenth part of an ephah of <b>fine flour for a meal offering perpetually [<i>tamid</i>],</b> half of it in the morning, and half of it in the evening” (Leviticus 6:13). The fact that the verse makes reference to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest as <i>tamid</i> teaches that <b>it is in</b> the same category as <b>the meal offering</b> component <b>of the daily offerings [<i>temidin</i>]. Just as the meal offering</b> component <b>of the daily offerings</b> requires <b>three <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>so too this</b> griddle-cake offering of the High Priest requires <b>three <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour.
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The verse <b>adds</b> to the amount of <b>oil</b> that is required <b>here,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, <b>and</b> it similarly <b>adds</b> to the amount of <b>oil</b> that is required <b>there,</b> in the case of the <b>meal offering</b> that accompanies the sacrifice of <b>sheep. Just as there,</b> in the case of the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of sheep, <b>three <i>log</i></b> of oil are required <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, <b>three <i>log</i></b> of oil are required <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour.
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way:</b> The verse <b>adds</b> to the amount of <b>oil</b> that is required <b>here,</b> and it similarly <b>adds</b> to the amount of <b>oil</b> that is required in the case of <b>the meal offering</b> that accompanies the sacrifice of <b>bulls and rams. Just as there,</b> in the case of the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of bulls and rams, <b>two <i>log</i></b> of oil are required <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, <b>two <i>log</i></b> of oil are required <b>for</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour.
With regard to these two possibilities, <b>let us see to which</b> case <b>it is</b> more <b>similar,</b> i.e., which is a better comparison to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest. Perhaps <b>we</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which is <b>a meal offering that comes</b> in the amount of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>from</b> the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of sheep, which is also <b>a meal offering that comes</b> in the amount of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour. <b>And we should not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a meal offering that comes</b> in the amount of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> in the case of <b>a meal offering that comes</b> in the amount of <b>two or three tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, such as the meal offerings that accompany the sacrifice of bulls and rams.
The Gemara asks a question with regard to the beginning of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>itself</b> is <b>difficult,</b> as it contains an internal contradiction. First <b>you said</b> that the expression <b>“with the oil”</b> stated in the verse concerning the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest serves <b>to add</b> extra <b>oil,</b> which indicates that more than the basic amount of one <i>log</i> of oil is required. <b>And then it teaches: It is stated here,</b> concerning the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“Oil,” and it is stated with regard to</b> the <b>voluntary meal offering</b> that it must be brought with <b>“oil.”</b> The <i>baraita</i> suggests that just as one <i>log</i> of oil is brought with the voluntary meal offering, so too one <i>log</i> is brought with the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest.
In answer to this question, <b>Abaye said: Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught</b> that the term <b>“with the oil”</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest serves <b>to add</b> extra oil? <b>It is Rabbi Shimon,</b> who holds that three <i>log</i> of oil are required, as derived from the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of sheep. <b>And</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>If it were not stated.</b> If the verse had not indicated by the term “with the oil” that extra oil is required, it would have been possible to derive from the voluntary meal offering that only one <i>log</i> is required. <b>And who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>responds</b> to Rabbi Shimon’s <b>derivation</b> and suggests that in fact the amount of oil can be derived from the case of the voluntary meal offering? It is <b>Rabbi Yishmael.</b>
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehoshua, said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should be understood differently: The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka,</b> who derives that three <i>log</i> of oil are required in the griddle-cake offering based upon the amount required in the meal offering component of the daily offerings.
<b>And</b> with regard to the possibility of deriving that only one <i>log</i> is required, as in the voluntary meal offering, <b>this</b> is what <b>he is saying:</b> The term <b>“with the oil”</b> stated with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest comes <b>to add</b> more <b>oil to it</b> than the single <i>log</i> required for the voluntary meal offering. <b>As, if</b> the purpose of that term were merely <b>to establish</b> the basic fact that the offering must include <b>oil,</b> a verse is <b>not needed</b> to teach that. <b>Since it is written with</b> respect to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“On a griddle [<i>maḥavat</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:14), it is <b>comparable to a pan [<i>maḥavat</i>] meal offering,</b> which requires oil.
<b>Or</b> perhaps the purpose of the verse is <b>to establish only</b> that the offering must include <b>oil,</b> and it is necessary to teach that <b>because if the Merciful One had not stated: “With the oil,” I would say: Let it be like</b> the <b>meal offering of a sinner,</b> which does not include oil.
Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>then said: Let it even be</b> that the purpose of the verse is <b>to establish only</b> that <b>it</b> requires <b>oil,</b> and even so one can <b>arrive</b> at the conclusion that three <i>log</i> are required due to the <b>derivation</b> based upon the verbal analogy from the meal offering brought with the libations that accompany animal offerings. <b>But</b> although Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, attempts to <b>employ</b> this <b>derivation he is unsuccessful,</b> as there is a counter-indication from another verbal analogy to the voluntary meal offering. Therefore, Rabbi Yishmael, son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>needed</b> to derive the <i>halakha</i> from the <b>verse: “Fine flour for a meal offering perpetually [<i>tamid</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:13), <b>as Rabbi Yishmael,</b> son of Rabbi Yoḥanan ben Beroka, <b>concluded his statement</b> in the <i>baraita</i>.
<b>Rabba said</b> that the <i>baraita</i> should be understood differently: The <b>entire</b> <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, and</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>is speaking</b> utilizing the style of: <b>If it were not stated.</b>
<b>And this</b> is what Rabbi Shimon <b>is saying:</b> The term <b>“with the oil”</b> serves <b>to add</b> extra <b>oil to it. As, if</b> the purpose of that term were merely <b>to establish</b> that the offering must include <b>oil,</b> a verse is <b>not needed</b> to teach that. <b>Since it is written with</b> respect to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“On a griddle [<i>maḥavat</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 6:14), it is <b>comparable to a pan [<i>maḥavat</i>]</b> meal offering, which requires oil. <b>And</b> even <b>if</b> the verse <b>had not stated: “With the oil,” I have</b> a manner of <b>derivation</b> for the fact that more than one <i>log</i> of oil is required, based upon a verbal analogy.
<b>But</b> although Rabbi Shimon attempts to <b>employ</b> this <b>derivation he is unsuccessful,</b> as there is a counter-indication from another verbal analogy, <b>and</b> therefore the term <b>“with the oil” is needed</b> to teach that more than one <i>log</i> of oil is required. Nevertheless, this teaches only that more oil than usual is required, but the specific amount still must be clarified. Rabbi Shimon <b>then said: Let</b> the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest <b>be like the meal offering</b> that accompanies the sacrifice of <b>bulls and rams,</b> which require two <i>log</i> of oil per ephah of flour.
Rabbi Shimon <b>then said: We</b> should <b>derive</b> the <i>halakha</i>

Daf 51b

with regard to the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which is <b>a meal offering that comes</b> in the amount of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour, from the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of sheep, which is also a meal offering that comes in the amount of a tenth of an ephah of flour, and not from a meal offering that is brought in the amount of two or three tenths of an ephah of flour.
