<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If <b>they did not appoint another</b> High <b>Priest in his stead, from whose</b> property <b>was</b> the griddle-cake offering brought and <b>sacrificed? Rabbi Shimon says:</b> It is brought and sacrificed <b>from</b> the property <b>of the community. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> It is brought and sacrificed <b>from</b> the property <b>of the heirs</b> of the High Priest. <b>And</b> for the duration of the period until a new High Priest was appointed, the griddle-cake offering <b>was sacrificed</b> as <b>a complete</b> tenth of an ephah of fine flour.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In a case where the <b>High Priest died and they did not appoint another</b> High <b>Priest in his stead, from where</b> is it derived <b>that his</b> griddle-cake <b>meal offering should be sacrificed from</b> the property <b>of the heirs</b> of the High Priest? <b>The verse states</b> in reference to the griddle-cake offering: <b>“And the anointed priest that shall be in his stead from among his sons shall offer it”</b> (Leviticus 6:15).
One <b>might</b> have thought that the heirs should <b>sacrifice it in halves</b> as the High Priest does. Therefore <b>the verse states “it,”</b> teaching that they should sacrifice <b>all of</b> the tenth of an ephah <b>and not half of it;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The continuation of the verse: <b>“It is a statute forever [<i>olam</i>]</b> to the Lord,” teaches that in this case of a High Priest who has died and has not yet been replaced, the offering is brought <b>from</b> the property <b>of the world [<i>olam</i>],</b> i.e., the community. The end of the verse: <b>“It shall be wholly made to smoke</b> to the Lord,” teaches <b>that</b> although it is brought by the community and not by a priest, <b>the entire</b> tenth of an ephah <b>should be sacrificed</b> and not eaten.
The Gemara asks: <b>And did that</b> verse: <b>“And the anointed priest</b> that shall be in his stead from among his sons shall offer it,” <b>come to</b> teach <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> that Rabbi Yehuda derived from it?
<b>That</b> verse <b>is needed for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>“This is the offering of Aaron and of his sons, which they shall offer to the Lord in the day when he is anointed”</b> (Leviticus 6:13). One <b>might</b> have thought that since the verse speaks of the offering in the singular, it means that <b>Aaron and his sons should sacrifice one offering.</b> Therefore <b>the verse states: “Which they shall offer to the Lord,”</b> in plural, teaching that <b>Aaron</b> sacrifices an offering <b>by himself</b> as the High Priest, <b>and his sons</b> sacrifice offerings <b>by themselves</b> as ordinary priests. When the verse refers to <b>“his sons,” these are the ordinary priests.</b> Each priest must bring a griddle-cake offering as an offering of initiation when he begins his service.
<b>Do you say</b> that this is referring to the offering of initiation of <b>ordinary priests, or is it</b> referring <b>only</b> to the griddle-cake offering of the <b>High Priests? When</b> the verse <b>states</b> in the continuation of that passage: <b>“And the anointed priest that shall be in his stead from among his sons</b> shall offer it; it is a statute forever to the Lord; it shall be wholly made to smoke to the Lord” (Leviticus 6:15), the griddle-cake offering of the <b>High Priest is thereby mentioned. How do I realize</b> the meaning of the term <b>“his sons”</b> in Leviticus 6:13? <b>These are the ordinary priests,</b> and the verse is referring to their offering of initiation. Consequently, verse 15 is referring to the basic obligation of the High Priest to bring the griddle-cake offering, rather than referring to a case of a High Priest who died.
The Gemara answers: The verse teaches both the basic obligation of the High Priest to bring the griddle-cake offering daily and the fact that when he dies his heirs must bring the offering until a new High Priest is appointed. <b>If</b> it were <b>so</b> that the verse is teaching only that the heirs of a High Priest who died must bring the griddle-cake offering until a new High Priest is appointed, <b>let the verse</b> merely <b>write: The anointed priest that shall be in his stead, his sons shall offer. What</b> is the need to say: <b>“From among</b> his sons”? <b>Learn from</b> the fact that verse uses this term that <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i> are derived from the verse.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Shimon,</b> who derives the <i>halakha</i> that it should be entirely sacrificed from the phrase: “It shall be wholly made to smoke,” <b>do</b> with <b>that</b> word <b>“it,”</b> from which Rabbi Yehuda derives this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>He requires</b> it <b>to</b> teach that in the case of <b>a High Priest who died</b> after bringing the first half of his griddle-cake offering, <b>and</b> then <b>they appointed another</b> High Priest <b>in his stead,</b> the replacement High Priest <b>should neither bring half of a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>from his house nor</b> sacrifice the remaining <b>half of the tenth of an ephah of the first</b> High Priest, i.e., his predecessor.
The Gemara asks: <b>Let him derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the expression: <b>“And half of it”</b> (Leviticus 6:13), as discussed on 50b; the word “and,” which is added by the letter <i>vav</i> at the beginning of the word, is expounded to mean that the replacement High Priest must bring a complete tenth of an ephah of fine flour. The Gemara answers: He did not derive the <i>halakha</i> from there because <b>he does not expound</b> the extra letter <b><i>vav</i></b> in that word, as he holds that its addition is not significant.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that if the High Priest dies and a new one has not yet been appointed the griddle-cake offering is brought by the previous High Priest’s heirs, <b>do</b> with <b>that</b> phrase: <b>“It is a statute forever</b> to the Lord,” from which Rabbi Shimon derives that it is brought from communal resources? The Gemara answers: It teaches that the <b>statute</b> requiring the High Priest to sacrifice the griddle-cake offering <b>is to</b> apply <b>forever.</b>
The Gemara asks: According to Rabbi Yehuda, <b>why do I</b> need the phrase: <b>“It shall be wholly made to smoke”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the griddle-cake <b>meal offering of the High Priest</b> mentioned <b>above is</b> included <b>in</b> the mandate: <b>“It shall be wholly made to smoke”</b> (Leviticus 6:15), <b>and</b> that the voluntary <b>meal offering</b> of the <b>ordinary priest</b> mentioned <b>below is</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“It shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:16).
<b>From where</b> is it derived that one is mandated <b>to apply what is said about that</b> verse <b>to this</b> one, <b>and</b> what is said <b>about this</b> verse <b>to that</b> one? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering: <b>“Wholly,”</b> and the verse uses the word <b>“wholly”</b> with regard to the voluntary meal offering of a priest, in order <b>to</b> teach <b>a verbal analogy: It is stated here,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake meal offering of the High Priest: <b>“Wholly”</b> (Leviticus 6:15), <b>and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the voluntary meal offering of the ordinary priest: <b>“Wholly”</b> (Leviticus 6:16).
<b>Just as here,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake meal offering, it is included <b>in</b> the mandate: <b>“It shall be wholly made to smoke,” so too there,</b> the voluntary meal offering of the ordinary priest is included <b>in</b> the mandate: <b>It shall be wholly made to smoke. And just as there,</b> with regard to the voluntary meal offering of the ordinary priest, the verse comes <b>to place a prohibition on its consumption, so too here,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake meal offering of the High Priest, the verse comes <b>to place a prohibition on its consumption.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Shimon hold</b> that in a case where the High Priest died and a new one has not been appointed, the requirement that the griddle offering be brought <b>from</b> the property <b>of the community is by Torah law,</b> as indicated by the fact that he derives this <i>halakha</i> from a verse?
<b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 7:6) that <b>Rabbi Shimon said: The court instituted seven ordinances</b> with regard to the financial aspects of offerings and consecrations; <b>and this</b> ordinance, namely, that the cost of the libations accompanying the sacrifice of a found animal is borne by the public, <b>is one of them.</b> These are the other ordinances: In the case of <b>a gentile who sent his burnt offering from a country overseas,</b> and <b>he sent with it</b> money for the purchase of the <b>libations</b> that must accompany it, the libations <b>are sacrificed at his</b> expense. <b>And if</b> the gentile did <b>not</b> cover the cost of the libations, it is a condition of the court that the libations are <b>sacrificed at the public’s</b> expense, with funds taken from the Temple treasury.
<b>And similarly,</b> in the case of <b>a convert who died</b> without heirs <b>and left</b> animals that he had designated as <b>offerings, if he has the libations,</b> i.e., if he also had set aside libations or money for that purpose, the libations <b>are sacrificed from his</b> estate. <b>And if</b> he did <b>not</b> do so, the libations <b>are sacrificed from public</b> funds.
<b>And</b> another ordinance: <b>It is a stipulation of the court</b> with regard to <b>a High Priest who died, and they did not</b> yet <b>appoint another</b> High <b>Priest in his stead, that his</b> griddle-cake <b>meal offering</b> would be <b>sacrificed from public</b> funds. Rabbi Shimon then enumerates three additional ordinances. In any case, it is clear from this mishna that Rabbi Shimon holds that this <i>halakha</i> concerning the offering of a High Priest who died is a rabbinic ordinance, rather than Torah law.
<b>Rabbi Abbahu said</b> in response: In fact, Rabbi Shimon holds that this <i>halakha</i> is by Torah law. But in fact, there <b>were two ordinances</b> that were enacted concerning this matter.
Initially, they acted in accordance with that which is prescribed <b>by Torah law,</b> and if a High Priest died and a new High Priest had not yet been appointed in his stead, his griddle-cake meal offering would be sacrificed <b>from public</b> funds. <b>Once they saw that the</b> funds in the <b>chamber</b> of the Temple treasury were being <b>depleted,</b> the Sages <b>instituted</b> an ordinance <b>that</b> the payment for the offering <b>should be collected from the</b> previous High Priest’s <b>heirs. Once they saw that</b> the heirs <b>were negligent in</b> the matter and did not bring the offering, <b>they</b> revoked the previous ordinance and <b>established it in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> as it is <b>by Torah law,</b> that it is brought from public funds.
§ The Gemara cites the continuation of the mishna in <i>Shekalim</i> (7:7): <b>And</b> the court enacted an ordinance <b>with regard to the</b> red <b>heifer that one is not</b> liable to bring an offering <b>for misusing</b> consecrated property if he derives benefit <b>from its ashes.</b> The Gemara asks: Why does the <i>baraita</i> state that this is an ordinance of the court, when in fact <b>it is by Torah law? As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to a red heifer: <b>“It is a sin offering”</b> (Numbers 19:9), which <b>teaches</b> that a red heifer is treated like a sin offering in that <b>one</b> is liable for <b>misusing it.</b> The fact that it states: <b>“It</b> is a sin offering” indicates that if one derives benefit from <b>it,</b> the animal itself, he is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property,

Daf 52a

but if one derives benefit <b>from its ashes, one is not</b> liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property. It is clear from the <i>baraita</i> that by Torah law one is not liable for misuse of consecrated property if he derives benefit from the ashes of a red heifer.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> in response: In fact, this <i>halakha</i> is by Torah law, but <b>there were two ordinances</b> that were enacted concerning this matter. <b>By Torah law,</b> if one derives benefit from <b>it,</b> the animal itself, he is liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property, but if he derives benefit <b>from its ashes</b> he is not liable for <b>misusing</b> consecrated property. <b>Once</b> the Sages <b>saw that</b> people <b>were treating</b> the ashes of the heifer <b>disrespectfully, and making</b> salves <b>for their wounds from it, they decreed</b> that it is subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property and one may not derive benefit from it.
<b>Once they saw that</b> as a result of this decree people <b>were refraining from</b> sprinkling it in cases where there was <b>uncertainty</b> as to whether or not an individual was impure and required <b>sprinkling, they</b> revoked the decree and <b>established it in accordance with</b> the <i>halakha</i> as it is <b>by Torah law,</b> that one is not liable for misusing the ashes of a red heifer.
§ The Gemara cites a dispute between Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Yehuda that is similar to the one cited earlier. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If there is a need to sacrifice the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin,</b> brought if the Sanhedrin issues an erroneous halakhic ruling concerning a prohibition for which one is liable to receive <i>karet</i> and the majority of the community acts upon it, <b>or the goats</b> brought if the Sanhedrin issues an erroneous ruling permitting <b>idol worship</b> and the majority of the community acts on it, <b>a new collection</b> of funds is organized <b>for them.</b> The funds are not taken from the collection of the Temple treasury chamber, unlike other communal offerings. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> The funds for these sacrifices <b>come from the collection of the chamber.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>the opposite,</b> i.e., that the first opinion cited above is that of Rabbi Shimon and the second is that of Rabbi Yehuda? <b>Which of</b> the two <i>baraitot</i> is <b>the later</b> one and therefore the more accurate and authoritative version of their opinions?
<b>The Sages said</b> the following <b>before Rav Ashi: Let</b> us <b>say</b> that <b>the first</b> <i>baraita</i> cited above <b>is the later</b> one, <b>as we have heard that Rabbi Shimon is concerned about</b> the possibility of <b>negligence.</b> Just as Rabbi Shimon was concerned above that the heirs of the High Priest would not provide the funds for the griddle-cake offering, it is reasonable to assume that he would be concerned that people would not contribute to a new collection, and therefore the funds are taken from the collection of the chamber.
<b>Rav Ashi said to</b> the Sages: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that <b>the latter</b> <i>baraita</i> cited above <b>is the later</b> and more authoritative one. <b>When Rabbi Shimon</b> expressed that he <b>is concerned about</b> the possibility of people acting with <b>negligence,</b> that was only with regard to <b>a matter that does not provide them with atonement,</b> e.g., the griddle-cake offering of the deceased High Priest. But <b>Rabbi Shimon is not concerned about</b> the possibility of <b>negligence with regard to a matter that does provide them with atonement,</b> e.g., these sin offerings.
The Gemara asks, in light of the fact that the discussion above was inconclusive: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about it;</b> which <i>baraita</i> is later and more authoritative?
<b>Rabba Zuti said to Rav Ashi: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse concerning the daily sacrifice: “Command the children of Israel, and say to them: <b>My food that is presented to Me for offerings made by fire, of a pleasing aroma to Me, you shall observe to sacrifice to Me in its due season”</b> (Numbers 28:2), serves <b>to include</b> the <b>bull for an unwitting communal sin and the goats of idol worship.</b> This teaches <b>that</b> the funds for these offerings <b>come from the collection of the chamber;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Shimon.</b> This proves that it is Rabbi Shimon who holds that these sacrifices are brought from the collection of the chamber.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And</b> for the duration of the period until a new High Priest is appointed, the griddle-cake offering <b>was sacrificed</b> as <b>a complete</b> tenth of an ephah of fine flour. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a dilemma:</b> Does the mishna mean that <b>a complete</b> tenth of an ephah is offered in the <b>morning and</b> another <b>complete</b> tenth of an ephah is offered <b>in the afternoon,</b> because this offering is sacrificed twice a day and is not divided in half when it is not brought by the High Priest himself? <b>Or</b> does it <b>perhaps</b> mean that <b>a complete</b> tenth of an ephah is sacrificed in the <b>morning and</b> the offering is <b>canceled in the afternoon?</b>
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> the resolution to this dilemma from that which is taught in a mishna (<i>Tamid</i> 31b) describing the order of the nine priests who brought the limbs of the daily offering up to the ramp of the altar, both in the morning and in the afternoon: The <b>eighth</b> priest carries <b>the griddle-cake</b> offering of the High Priest. <b>And if it were so that</b> the offering is <b>canceled in the afternoon,</b> then <b>sometimes</b> one would <b>not find the eighth</b> priest carrying <b>the griddle-cake</b> offering. <b>What are the circumstances</b> when there would be no eighth priest? In a case <b>where the High Priest died</b> after he brought his griddle-cake offering in the morning <b>and they did not</b> yet <b>appoint another</b> High Priest <b>in his stead.</b> Therefore, it must be that a complete tenth of an ephah was also brought for the afternoon offering.
<b>The Sages stated</b> this proof <b>before Rabbi Yirmeya.</b> Rabbi Yirmeya rejected it and <b>said:</b> Those <b>foolish Babylonians, because they dwell in</b> a low-lying and therefore <b>dark land, they state <i>halakhot</i> that are dark,</b> i.e., erroneous.
<b>Rather,</b> with regard to <b>that</b> which the same mishna <b>teaches:</b> The <b>seventh</b> priest carries <b>the fine flour</b> for the meal offering component of the daily offering and <b>the ninth</b> priest carries <b>the wine</b> for the libations that accompany the daily offering, is it <b>also</b> the case <b>that they are never canceled?</b>
That is not correct, as it is derived from the verse <b>“Their meal offering and their libations”</b> (Numbers 29:18) that these items may be sacrificed even <b>at night,</b> despite the fact that the daily offering they accompany must be sacrificed during the day. Similarly, the phrase <b>“their meal offering and their libations”</b> indicates that these items may be sacrificed even <b>the next day</b> (see 44b). Under those circumstances there would not have been fine flour and wine brought by the seventh and nine priests at the time of the daily offering.
<b>Rather,</b> one must explain that the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> cases of <b>what if,</b> and is speaking only about the typical case. <b>So too</b> with regard to Rava’s proof from the mishna, it is not compelling because the <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> cases of <b>what if</b> the High Priest dies and a successor has not yet been appointed.
The Sages then <b>brought</b> Rabbi Yirmeya’s analysis <b>before Rava.</b> Rava initially <b>said</b> to them: <b>You state our inferior</b> statements, which can be refuted, <b>before</b> the Sages of Eretz Yisrael, but <b>you do not state our superior</b> statements <b>before them?</b>
<b>And Rava then said</b> to them: <b>This</b> statement, that the griddle-cake offering is sacrificed twice a day even if there is no High Priest, is <b>also</b> one of <b>our superior</b> statements, as <b>the verse states</b> concerning the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest: <b>“Fine flour for a meal offering perpetually [<i>tamid</i>],</b> half of it in the morning, and half of it in the evening” (Leviticus 6:13). This teaches that the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest <b>is like the meal offering</b> component of the <b>daily offerings [<i>temidin</i>]</b> and must be sacrificed in the morning and the afternoon, even if the High Priest died and was not yet replaced.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s dilemma, <b>as it is taught</b> explicitly in a <i>baraita</i>: If the High Priest died and was not yet replaced, <b>a complete</b> tenth of an ephah is sacrificed in the <b>morning and</b> another <b>complete</b> tenth of an ephah is sacrificed <b>in the afternoon.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Abba Yosei ben Dostai and the Rabbis disagree</b> as to the amount of frankincense brought with the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest.
<b>Abba Yosei ben Dostai says:</b> The High Priest <b>separates two handfuls of frankincense for</b> his griddle-cake offering each day; one <b>handful</b> for his <b>morning</b> offering <b>and</b> one <b>handful</b> for his <b>afternoon</b> offering. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> The High Priest <b>separates one handful</b> of frankincense each day <b>for</b> his griddle-cake offering. He divides it in half and brings <b>half a handful</b> for his <b>morning</b> offering <b>and half a handful</b> for his <b>afternoon</b> offering.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> they <b>disagree? Abba Yosei ben Dostai holds</b> that since <b>one does not find</b> a case where the Torah explicitly states that <b>half a handful is sacrificed,</b> he brings a complete handful for each offering. <b>And the Rabbis hold that</b> since <b>one does not find</b> a case where <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>requires two handfuls</b> of frankincense, he brings only one handful and divides it between the two offerings.
Having discussed the quantity of frankincense that is generally brought with the griddle-cake offering, the Gemara now addresses a case where the High Priest died. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan raises a dilemma:</b> In the case of <b>a High Priest who died and they did not</b> yet <b>appoint another in his stead,</b>

Daf 52b

<b>according to the Rabbis,</b> who hold that generally one handful of frankincense is divided between the morning and afternoon offerings, <b>is the</b> amount of <b>frankincense doubled or not? Do we say</b> that <b>since</b> in this case <b>its fine flour is doubled,</b> as a complete tenth of an ephah of fine flour is sacrificed in both the morning and evening, <b>its frankincense</b> is also <b>doubled? Or perhaps that which</b> the verse <b>reveals,</b> i.e., that a complete tenth of an ephah is sacrificed in the morning and afternoon, <b>it reveals,</b> and <b>that which</b> it <b>does not reveal,</b> it <b>does not reveal;</b> and therefore, since the verse does not indicate that the amount of frankincense is doubled, only one handful is brought.
<b>And</b> furthermore, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i> concerning the <b>oil</b> of the griddle-cake offering in a case where the High Priest died and was not yet replaced, <b>both</b> according <b>to Abba Yosei ben Dostai and</b> according <b>to the Rabbis?</b> Is the required amount three <i>log</i>, as it is when the High Priest brings the griddle-cake offering, or is the amount of oil doubled just as the amount of fine flour is doubled?
<b>Rava said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution to the dilemma concerning the quantity of frankincense that is brought in this case, based upon a mishna (106b): <b>There are five</b> <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to <b>a handful.</b> The <i>halakha</i> of the frankincense sacrificed with the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest is not included in this number, because only half a handful of frankincense is sacrificed at one time. <b>And if it is so</b> that when there is no High Priest a complete handful is brought in the morning and in the afternoon, then <b>sometimes you find</b> that there are <b>seven</b> <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to a handful.
The Gemara rejects this proof: The <i>tanna</i> <b>does not teach</b> cases of <b>what if</b> the High Priest died, and is speaking only about a typical case. The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Pappa was sitting and teaching this <i>halakha</i>. Rav Yosef bar Shemaya said to Rav Pappa: But</b> the mishna does list the case of <b>one who</b> intentionally <b>offers up</b> the <b>handful</b> from a meal offering <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, who is liable to receive <i>karet</i>. This <b>is</b> not a standard case but rather a case of <b>what if, and</b> nevertheless it <b>is taught</b> in the mishna. Accordingly, Rava’s proof is valid.
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about</b> this matter? <b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak said: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: In the case of a <b>High Priest who died and they did not</b> yet <b>appoint another in his stead, a complete</b> tenth of an ephah of fine flour is brought for the griddle-cake offering in the <b>morning and</b> another <b>complete</b> tenth of an ephah is brought <b>in the afternoon. And one separates two handfuls</b> of frankincense <b>for it,</b> and sacrifices one <b>handful</b> with the <b>morning</b> offering <b>and</b> one <b>handful</b> with the <b>afternoon</b> offering. <b>And</b> one <b>separates three <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>for it,</b> and brings <b>a <i>log</i> and a half</b> with the <b>morning</b> offering <b>and a <i>log</i> and a half</b> with the <b>afternoon</b> offering.
The Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is this <i>baraita</i>? <b>If we say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis, what is different</b> about <b>its frankincense</b> such <b>that it is doubled</b> in the case where the High Priest died, <b>and what is different</b> about <b>its oil</b> such <b>that it is not doubled?</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Yosei ben Dostai, who said:</b> The <b>griddle-cake</b> offering of the <b>High Priest generally requires two handfuls. And</b> therefore when the <i>baraita</i> requires two handfuls of frankincense in the case where the High Priest died and another has not yet been appointed, the <b>frankincense is not</b> being <b>doubled and the oil is</b> also <b>not doubled.</b> Therefore, three <i>log</i> of oil are required, as usual.
<b>And from</b> the fact <b>that</b> according <b>to Abba Yosei ben Dostai</b> the requisite <b>oil is not doubled,</b> one can conclude that <b>also</b> according <b>to the Rabbis its frankincense and its oil are not doubled.</b>
This discussion in the Gemara began with Rabbi Yoḥanan presenting the dispute between Abba Yosei ben Dostai and the Rabbis, and it concludes with his ruling concerning their dispute. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Abba Yosei ben Dostai.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And did Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> actually <b>say this? But doesn’t Rabbi Yoḥanan state</b> a principle that the <b><i>halakha</i></b> is <b>in accordance with</b> the ruling of <b>an unattributed mishna,</b> and <b>we learned</b> in the unattributed mishna cited earlier: <b>There are</b> only <b>five</b> <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to <b>a handful.</b> Since the mishna does not list the fact that a handful of frankincense is offered twice daily with the griddle-cake offering, how can Rabbi Yoḥanan accept that opinion?
The Gemara answers: <b>They are</b> different <b><i>amora’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b> One said that Rabbi Yoḥanan rules in accordance with Abba Yosei ben Dostai, and one said that according to Rabbi Yoḥanan the <i>halakha</i> is always in accordance with an unattributed mishna.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the meal offerings come</b> to be offered as <b><i>matza</i>,</b> with care taken to prevent leavening, <b>except for</b> ten loaves of <b>leavened bread</b> among the forty loaves <b>that</b> accompany <b>the thanks offering, and</b> the meal offering of <b>the two loaves</b> that are brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>as they come</b> to be offered as <b>leavened bread.</b>
The Sages disagree as to the manner in which those meal offerings are leavened. <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> With regard to <b>the leaven</b> added to the dough to facilitate leavening, <b>one separates [<i>bodeh</i>]</b> part of the flour <b>for</b> the meal offerings <b>from within</b> the flour of the meal offerings themselves, causes it to become leaven, <b>and leavens</b> the meal offerings with it.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says: That is also not the optimal</b> manner in which to fulfill the mitzva, as aged leaven is a more effective leavening agent. <b>Rather, one brings the leaven</b> from another, aged, dough <b>and places it into the measuring</b> vessel, <b>and</b> then he adds flour until he <b>fills the measuring</b> vessel, to ensure the appropriate measure of a tenth of an ephah of flour. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda: <b>That too</b> is inappropriate, as in that manner the meal offering <b>will</b> either be <b>lacking</b> the requisite measure <b>or</b> be <b>greater</b> than the required measure, as the Gemara will explain.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi Perida raised a dilemma before Rabbi Ami: From where</b> is it derived with regard <b>to all the meal offerings that they come</b> to be offered as <b><i>matza</i>?</b> Rabbi Ami was puzzled by this question, and replied: What do you mean when you say: <b>From where do we</b> derive this? Concerning every meal offering <b>with regard to which it is written</b> explicitly in the Torah that it comes as <i>matza</i>, <b>it is written with regard to it,</b> and therefore the dilemma does not arise. And concerning any meal offering where <b>it is not written</b> explicitly <b>with regard to it</b> that it must be <i>matza</i>, nevertheless <b>it is written with regard to it:</b>

Daf 53a

<b>“And this is the law of the meal offering: The sons of Aaron shall sacrifice it before the Lord in front of the altar…And that which is left of it Aaron and his sons shall eat; it shall be eaten as <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Leviticus 6:7–9). These verses demonstrate that there is a general requirement that meal offerings must be brought as <i>matza</i>. Rabbi Perida <b>said to</b> Rabbi Ami: <b>I do not raise the dilemma</b> with regard to the source of the <b>mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i>, as that is clearly derived from these verses. <b>Where I raise the dilemma,</b> it is <b>with regard to</b> the source that indicates this requirement is <b>indispensable,</b> i.e., that if one violated the mitzva and brought a meal offering not as <i>matza</i> the offering is not valid.
Rabbi Ami <b>said to</b> Rabbi Perida: <b>With regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the requirement that meal offerings must come as <i>matza</i> is <b>indispensable, it is also written: “It shall not be baked as leavened bread”</b> (Leviticus 6:10), <b>but</b> rather must come as <b><i>matza</i>.</b> This additional verse indicates that even after the fact, if a meal offering was not made as <i>matza</i> it is not valid.
Rav <b>Ḥisda objects to this: But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the verse should be interpreted as follows: <b>“It shall not be baked as leavened bread,”</b> i.e., fully leavened, <b>but</b> it can be brought even if it has been leavened slightly with <b>leavening [<i>siur</i>]</b> dough. Although it does not have the status of leavened bread and is therefore not prohibited by the verse, it also does not have the status of <i>matza</i>.
The Gemara analyzes Rav Ḥisda’s objection, as there is a dispute among the Sages with regard to the definition of <i>siur</i> (see <i>Pesaḥim</i> 48b). According to Rabbi Meir, <i>siur</i> is dough at the beginning of the leavening process, when its surface has become pale. Conversely, Rabbi Yehuda maintains that <i>siur</i> is dough that has been leavened to the point that it has cracks that look like the antennae of locusts. In this light, the Gemara inquires: This <b><i>siur</i>,</b> mentioned by Rav Ḥisda in his suggested interpretation of the verse, is in accordance <b>with whose</b> opinion? <b>If</b> he is referring to <i>siur</i> as defined <b>by Rabbi Meir,</b> then <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda</b> Rav Ḥisda’s objection does not arise, as Rabbi Yehuda maintains this <b>is full-fledged <i>matza</i>.</b> And <b>if</b> Rav Ḥisda is referring to <i>siur</i> as defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda,</b> then <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> Rav Ḥisda’s objection does not arise either, as Rabbi Meir holds that it <b>is full-fledged leavened bread.</b>
Furthermore, <b>if</b> Rav Ḥisda is referring to <i>siur</i> as defined <b>by Rabbi Meir,</b> then even <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> himself the objection does not arise. The reason is that <b>from</b> the fact that Rabbi Meir rules <b>that</b> one who eats this <i>siur</i> on Passover <b>is flogged for it,</b> this indicates that <b>it is</b> deemed <b>full-fledged leavened bread. Rather,</b> Rav Ḥisda’s objection arises with regard to leavening dough as defined <b>by Rabbi Yehuda, according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who maintains that this dough is not considered full-fledged leavened bread.
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Yitzḥak</b> also <b>objects to</b> Rabbi Ami’s explanation: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the verse can be interpreted as follows: <b>“It shall not be baked as leavened bread,” but</b> one may bring a meal offering that has been <b>boiled,</b> as this is not leavened bread; although it is also not <i>matza</i>. The Gemara asks: This <b>boiled</b> dough, <b>what is it?</b> It is <b>poached [<i>revikha</i>],</b> as described in the verse: “In a pan it shall be made of oil, when it is soaked [<i>murbekhet</i>]” (Leviticus 6:14). If so, there is no need to derive the <i>halakha</i> of boiled dough from the verse: “It shall not be baked as leavened bread.” <b>If</b> it is a meal offering that must be <b>poached, it is</b> explicitly <b>written with regard to it</b> that it must be <b>poached. And</b> if it is a meal offering that is not to be poached, <b>it is not written with regard to it</b> that it is <b>poached.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the verse: “It shall not be baked as leavened bread,” indicates that with regard to a meal offering <b>about which it is written</b> explicitly that it must be <b>poached,</b> it is a <b>mitzva that</b> it be <b>poached, and</b> with regard to a meal offering <b>about which it is not written</b> that it must be <b>poached,</b> the one who brings the offering can decide: <b>If he wants, let him bring</b> it <b>poached,</b> and <b>if he wants, let him bring</b> it as <b><i>matza</i>.</b> Accordingly, Rabbi Ami’s proof from the verse is inconclusive.
<b>Ravina</b> also <b>objects to</b> Rabbi Ami’s explanation: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the verse: <b>“It shall not be baked as leavened bread,”</b> serves <b>to determine</b> that this <b>man</b> who brings a meal offering as leavened bread <b>is</b> liable <b>for</b> violating <b>a mere prohibition, but</b> the meal offering itself is <b>not invalid.</b>
All these objections indicate that the verse: “It shall not be baked as leavened bread,” can be interpreted in ways other than that suggested by Rabbi Ami. Accordingly, the Gemara asks: <b>Rather, from where do we</b> derive that all meal offerings not brought as <i>matza</i> are not valid? The Gemara answers: We derive it <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> discussing a verse concerning meal offerings: “It shall be of <b><i>matza</i>”</b> (Leviticus 2:5): One <b>might</b> have thought that it is only <b>a mitzva</b> <i>ab initio</i> for a meal offering to be of <i>matza</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It shall be,”</b> which indicates that <b>the verse established it</b> as <b>an obligation,</b> i.e., if the meal offering was not brought as <i>matza</i> it is not valid.
§ <b>Rabbi Perida raised</b> another <b>dilemma before Rabbi Ami: From where</b> is it derived with regard <b>to all the meal offerings</b> that must be brought as <i>matza</i> <b>that they are kneaded with lukewarm</b> water so that the dough will be baked well, as only a small amount of oil is added, <b>and</b> that <b>one must watch over them</b> to ensure <b>that they do not</b> become <b>leavened</b> while kneading and shaping them? Shall <b>we derive this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the prohibition concerning leavened bread on the festival of <b>Passover, as it is written: “And you shall watch over the <i>matzot</i>”</b> (Exodus 12:17), which indicates that one must watch over any dough that is supposed to be made into <i>matza</i>, to ensure that it does not become leavened?
Rabbi Ami <b>said to</b> Rabbi Perida: The <i>halakha</i> of meal offerings is not derived from Passover, as <b>it is written in</b> the context of a meal offering <b>itself: “It shall be [<i>tehiye</i>] of <i>matza</i>”</b> (Leviticus 2:5), which can be read as meaning: <b>Preserve [<i>haḥaye</i>]</b> <i>matza</i>, i.e., preserve the <i>matza</i> as it is, and do not let it become leavened.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you</b> already <b>derive</b> from the term “it shall be” that the requirement that a meal offering must be made as <i>matza</i> <b>is indispensable?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>If so,</b> that this term serves to teach only one <i>halakha</i>, <b>let the verse write: It is <i>matza</i>. What</b> is the reason that it writes: <b>“It shall be</b> of <i>matza</i>”? <b>Learn from it two</b> conclusions, both that the requirement that it be made as <i>matza</i> is indispensable and that one must watch over the <i>matza</i> to ensure that it does not become leavened.
§ The Gemara relates an incident that involves the aforementioned Rabbi Perida. <b>The Sages said to Rabbi Perida:</b> The Sage <b>Rabbi Ezra,</b> who is of especially fine lineage, <b>a grandson of Rabbi Avtolus, who</b> in turn <b>is a</b> tenth-generation descendant <b>of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, who is a</b> tenth-generation descendant <b>of Ezra</b> the Scribe, <b>is standing</b> and waiting <b>at the gate</b> of the house and seeks entry. Rabbi Perida <b>said</b> to the Sages: <b>What is</b> the need for <b>all this</b> detail about Rabbi Ezra’s lineage?
Rabbi Perida elaborated: <b>If he is a man of Torah</b> study, he is <b>worthy</b> of entry on his own account, regardless of his ancestors. And <b>if he is</b> both <b>a man of Torah</b> study <b>and a man of lineage,</b> he is also <b>worthy</b> of entry. <b>But if</b> he is <b>a man of lineage and not a man of Torah,</b> better for <b>fire to devour him</b> than for him to enter my house. In this case, his lineage is to his detriment, as it highlights his failure to become a Sage like his ancestors. The Sages <b>said to</b> Rabbi Perida: Rabbi Ezra <b>is a man of Torah</b> study. Rabbi Perida <b>said to them:</b> If so, <b>let him enter and come.</b>
When Rabbi Ezra entered his house, Rabbi Perida <b>saw that</b> Rabbi Ezra’s <b>mind was troubled</b> with embarrassment at having to wait outside. Therefore, Rabbi Perida taught a homily to comfort Rabbi Ezra. <b>He began and said</b> an interpretation of the verse: <b>“I have said to the Lord: You are my Lord; I have no good but in You [<i>tovati bal alekha</i>]”</b> (Psalms 16:2). Rabbi Perida interpreted: <b>The congregation of Israel said before the Holy One, Blessed be He: Master of the Universe, give me credit, as I made Your</b> Name <b>known in the world,</b> as indicated by the phrase: “You are my Lord.”
God <b>said to</b> the congregation of Israel: <b>I give no credit to you [<i>tovati bal alekha</i>].</b> God explained: <b>I give credit only to</b> the three Patriarchs, <b>Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob, who</b> were the <b>first who made My</b> Name <b>known in the world, as it is stated: “As for the holy that are in the earth, they are the excellent [<i>ve’addirei</i>] in whom is all My delight”</b> (Psalms 16:3). The holy in the earth are the Patriarchs, in whom God delights. In this manner Rabbi Perida alluded to the importance of the ancestors of the Jewish people, including Ezra the Scribe, from whom Rabbi Ezra was descended.
<b>When</b> Rabbi Ezra <b>heard</b> Rabbi Perida <b>say</b> the word: <b>Excellent [<i>addir</i>],</b> he too <b>began</b> a homily, one that plays with different forms of this term, <b>and said: Let the <i>Addir</i> come and exact punishment for the <i>addirim</i> from the <i>addirim</i> in the <i>addirim</i>.</b>
Rabbi Ezra explained this statement: With regard to <i>Addir</i> in the phrase: <b>Let the <i>Addir</i> come, this is the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written: “The Lord on high is mighty [<i>addir</i>]”</b> (Psalms 93:4). In the phrase: <b>And exact punishment for the <i>addirim</i>, these</b> <i>addirim</i> <b>are the Jews, as it is stated: “The excellent [<i>ve’addirei</i>] in whom is all My delight”</b> (Psalms 16:3). In the phrase: <b>From the <i>addirim</i>, these</b> <i>addirim</i> <b>are the Egyptians, as it is written</b> with regard to the splitting of the Red Sea: <b>“The mighty [<i>addirim</i>] sank as lead in the waters”</b> (Exodus 15:10). In the phrase: <b>In the <i>addirim</i>, these</b> <i>addirim</i> <b>are the waters, as it is stated: “Above the voices of many waters, the mighty [<i>addirim</i>] breakers of the sea”</b> (Psalms 93:4).
Rabbi Ezra stated another, similar, homiletic interpretation: <b>Let <i>yadid</i>, son of <i>yadid</i>, come and build <i>yadid</i> for <i>yadid</i> in the portion of <i>yadid</i>, and let <i>yedidim</i> achieve atonement through it.</b>
Rabbi Ezra explained this statement: With regard to <i>yadid</i> in the phrase: <b>Let <i>yadid</i>, this is King Solomon, as it is written</b> after Solomon’s birth: <b>“And He sent by the hand of Nathan the prophet, and he called his name Yedidya, for the Lord’s sake”</b> (II Samuel 12:25).

Daf 53b

In the phrase: <b>Son of <i>yadid</i>, this</b> <i>yadid</i> <b>is Abraham, as it is written: “What has My beloved [<i>lididi</i>] to do in My house”</b> (Jeremiah 11:15). This verse is referring to Abraham, as will be explained. In the phrase: <b>And build <i>yadid</i>, this</b> <i>yadid</i> <b>is the Temple, as it is written: “How lovely [<i>yedidot</i>] are Your tabernacles”</b> (Psalms 84:2). And with regard to the term in the phrase: <b>For <i>Yadid</i>, this is the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written: “Let me sing of my Beloved [<i>lididi</i>]”</b> (Isaiah 5:1).
<b>In the portion of <i>yadid</i>; this</b> <i>yadid</i> <b>is</b> the tribe of <b>Benjamin,</b> in whose territory the Temple was built, <b>as it is stated</b> that Moses blessed Benjamin in the following terms: <b>“Of Benjamin he said: The beloved [<i>yedid</i>] of the Lord shall dwell in safety by Him”</b> (Deuteronomy 33:12). <b>And let <i>yedidim</i> achieve atonement through it; these</b> <i>yedidim</i> <b>are the Jewish people, as it is written</b> with regard to them: <b>“I have given the dearly beloved [<i>yedidut</i>] of My soul into the hand of her enemies”</b> (Jeremiah 12:7).
Rabbi Ezra stated another, similar homily: <b>Let the good one come and receive the good from the Good for the good ones.</b> He explained: <b>Let the good one come; this</b> good <b>is Moses, as it is written</b> about him: <b>“And when she saw him that he was a goodly child”</b> (Exodus 2:2). <b>And receive the good; this</b> good <b>is</b> the <b>Torah, as it is written</b> about the Torah: <b>“For I give you a good doctrine;</b> do not forsake my Torah” (Proverbs 4:2). <b>From the Good; this is</b> referring to <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written: “The Lord is good to all”</b> (Psalms 145:9). <b>For the good ones; these</b> good ones <b>are the Jews, as it is written</b> with regard to them: <b>“Do good, Lord, to the good ones”</b> (Psalms 125:4).
Rabbi Ezra stated yet another homily structured in a similar manner. <b>Let this one come and receive this from this One for this people.</b> He explained: <b>Let this one come; this is</b> referring to <b>Moses, as it is written</b> about him: <b>“For as for this Moses, the man</b> who brought us up out of the land of Egypt” (Exodus 32:1). <b>And receive this; this is</b> referring to the <b>Torah, as it is written: “And this is the Torah which Moses set</b> before the children of Israel” (Deuteronomy 4:44). <b>From this One; this is</b> referring to <b>the Holy One, Blessed be He, as it is written: “This is my God and I will glorify Him”</b> (Exodus 15:2). <b>For this people; these</b> people <b>are the Jews, as it is stated</b> about them: <b>“This people that You have gotten”</b> (Exodus 15:16).
§ It was stated above that the verse: “What has My beloved to do in My house,” is a reference to Abraham. The Gemara homiletically interprets the complete verse and the one after it: “What has My beloved to do in My house, seeing that she has performed lewdness with many, and the hallowed flesh is passed from you? When you do evil, then you rejoice. The Lord called your name a leafy olive tree, fair with goodly fruit; with the sound of a great tumult He has kindled fire upon it, and its branches are broken” (Jeremiah 11:15–16). <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak says: At the time when the</b> First <b>Temple was destroyed, the Holy One, Blessed be He, found Abraham standing in the Temple. He said to</b> Abraham: <b>“What has My beloved to do in My house?”</b>
Abraham <b>said to</b> God: <b>I have come over matters</b> concerning <b>my children,</b> to discover why God is destroying the Temple and exiling them from Eretz Yisrael. God <b>said to</b> Abraham: The reason is that <b>your children sinned, and</b> therefore they are being <b>exiled</b> from the land. Abraham <b>said to</b> God: <b>Perhaps they sinned unwittingly,</b> and they do not deserve such a terrible punishment. God <b>said to</b> him: <b>“Seeing that she has performed lewdness [<i>hamzimmata</i>],”</b> i.e., her evil actions were intentional. Abraham further <b>said to</b> God: <b>Perhaps</b> only <b>a minority</b> of Jews <b>sinned,</b> and the rest of the people should be spared punishment. God <b>said to</b> him: <b>“With many,”</b> i.e., the majority of the people are culpable.
Abraham continued to contend: Even so, <b>You should have remembered</b> the merit of the <b>covenant of circumcision,</b> which would have protected them from retribution. God <b>said to</b> him: <b>“And the hallowed flesh is passed from you,”</b> as they neglected the mitzva of circumcision. Abraham persisted and <b>said to</b> God: <b>Perhaps if You would have waited for them, they would have returned in repentance.</b> God <b>said to</b> him: <b>“When you do evil then you rejoice.”</b> That is, it is proper for them to be punished without delay, and they should not be given time to repent, since when they sin and are not punished they rejoice and live at ease, and rather than repent they are encouraged to do more evil.
Once all his arguments had been refuted, Abraham <b>immediately placed his hands on his head</b> in an act of mourning, <b>and was screaming and crying. And</b> he <b>said to</b> God: Is it <b>conceivable, Heaven forbid,</b> that the Jewish people <b>have no</b> further opportunity for <b>remedy? A Divine Voice emerged and said to him</b> the continuation of the verse: <b>“The Lord called your name a leafy olive tree, fair with goodly fruit.” Just as</b> with regard to <b>this olive tree, its final</b> purpose is fulfilled <b>at its end,</b> when its fruit is picked, <b>so too,</b> with regard to <b>the Jewish people, their final</b> purpose will be fulfilled <b>at their end,</b> i.e., they will ultimately repent and return to Me.
The Gemara analyzes the last part of the same verse: <b>“With the sound of a great tumult [<i>hamulla</i>] He has kindled fire upon it, and its branches [<i>daliyyotav</i>] are broken”</b> (Jeremiah 11:16). <b>Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa says: From the sound of the words [<i>milleihen</i>] of the spies</b> that Moses sent to Eretz Yisrael and who brought back an evil report, <b>the branches of the Jewish people were broken. As Rabbi Ḥinnana bar Pappa says: The spies said a serious statement at that moment: “They are stronger than us”</b> (Numbers 13:31). <b>Do not read</b> the phrase as: “Stronger <b>than us [<i>mimmenu</i>],”</b> but <b>rather</b> read it as: Stronger <b>than Him [<i>mimmennu</i>],</b> meaning <b>that even the Homeowner,</b> God, <b>is unable to remove His belongings from there, as it were.</b> The spies were speaking heresy and claiming that the Canaanites were stronger than God Himself.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya, son of Rabbi Ḥinnana, objects to this</b> interpretation. <b>This</b> phrase: <b>“With the sound of a great tumult [<i>hamulla</i>],”</b> is problematic according to your claim that it is a reference to the words of the spies. According to your interpretation, <b>it should have</b> stated: <b>With the sound of a word [<i>mila</i>]. Rather,</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya interprets this phrase in accordance with the earlier explanation that these verses are referring to Abraham’s discussion with God at the time of the destruction of the Temple. <b>The Holy One, Blessed be He, said to Abraham: I heard your voice, and I took pity [<i>ḥamalti</i>] on</b> the Jewish people and will punish them less harshly. <b>I</b> had previously <b>said</b> that the Jews <b>will be subjugated by four kingdoms:</b> Babylonia, Persia, Greece, and Rome, and <b>each and every one</b> of these kingdoms will subjugate them <b>for the measure</b> of time I had originally set for their subjugation to all <b>four kingdoms</b> put together.
But <b>now</b> that you have prayed for them, the Jewish people will be subjugated to <b>each one</b> of these four kingdoms only for the amount of time <b>stipulated for</b> each one separately. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that God said the following to Abraham: <b>I</b> initially <b>said</b> that these kingdoms will rule over the Jews <b>one after the other,</b> each of them for a separate period. <b>Now</b> I decree that their dominion shall occur <b>simultaneously</b> in different geographical regions, which will shorten the overall duration of the subjugation.
The verse in Jeremiah compares the Jewish people to an olive tree: “The Lord called your name a leafy olive tree.” <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi says: Why were the Jewish people likened to an olive tree?</b> It is <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as the leaves of an olive tree never fall off, neither in the summer nor in the rainy season, so too, the Jewish people will never be nullified, neither in this world nor in the World-to-Come. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Why were the Jewish people likened to an olive tree?</b> It is <b>to tell you</b> that <b>just as an olive tree brings forth its oil only by</b> means of <b>crushing</b> and breaking, <b>so too, the Jewish people,</b> if they sin, <b>return to good</b> ways <b>only by means of suffering.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> With regard to <b>the leaven</b> added to the dough to facilitate leavening, <b>one separates</b> part of the flour <b>for</b> the meal offerings <b>from within</b> the flour of the meal offerings themselves <b>and leavens</b> the meal offerings with it. Rabbi Yehuda maintains that one brings the leaven from another, aged, dough. The Rabbis subsequently questioned Rabbi Yehuda’s opinion, claiming that according to his ruling the measure of the meal offering would be lacking or would be greater than required. The Gemara inquires: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Lacking or greater?</b>
<b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> If the <b>leavening dough</b> that was brought from elsewhere is <b>stiff,</b> as its flour was mixed with a small amount of water, and it is relatively small in volume, when this stiff leaven is measured with the fine flour, the amount of fine flour for the meal offering <b>is found</b> to be <b>greater</b> than <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah when <b>the measuring</b> vessel is filled. This is because it will be necessary to add more flour to make up for the small volume of leavening dough. Conversely, if the leavening dough is <b>soft,</b> i.e., its flour was mixed with a larger amount of water, its volume will be larger than it should be, which will mean that the measuring vessel will be filled with less fine flour than normal, and the amount of flour <b>is found</b> to be <b>lacking.</b>
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the interpretation of Rav Ḥisda: Why does it matter if the leavening dough is stiff or soft? <b>Ultimately, when</b> the one preparing the meal offering <b>measures</b> the leaven brought from elsewhere together with the fine flour used for the meal offering, <b>he measures</b> and reaches the requisite amount <b>of a tenth</b> of an ephah, as the measure is full either way.
<b>Rabba and Rav Yosef both say:</b> In order to achieve the appropriate measure it is necessary to know how much flour the substance contained before water was added and it became dough. The reason is that <b>one measures</b> the tenth of an ephah <b>in accordance with</b> the amount there <b>was</b> of the flour of the leavening dough before it was mixed with water, together with the fine flour of the meal offering, and not in accordance with their present volume.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> even according to the opinion of Rabbis, who hold that Rabbi Yehuda’s method may not be used because the amount might be lacking or be greater than it should be, <b>let him take a little</b> fine flour <b>from</b> the tenth of an ephah after it has been measured and found to be the requisite amount, <b>and leaven it</b> thoroughly <b>outside</b> the rest of the dough, <b>and</b> afterward <b>bring it and knead it together with</b> the rest of the dough. In this way it is possible to bring leaven from the outside and to be certain that the meal offering contains exactly the correct measure. The Gemara answers: One cannot proceed in this manner, due to a rabbinic <b>decree.</b> The reason for this decree is that people who would see this practice might mistakenly think that the leavened portion was not part of the original fine flour, and <b>perhaps they will come to bring</b> leavening dough for their meal offerings <b>from elsewhere,</b> i.e., leavening dough that has not been consecrated for the meal offering.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may not leaven</b> the meal offerings that come as leavened bread

Daf 54a

<b>with</b> the juice of <b>apples,</b> as the dough will not leaven properly. It was <b>said in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel</b> that <b>one may leaven</b> these meal offerings with juice from apples, as this is considered proper leavening. The Gemara notes that <b>Rav Kahana would teach this</b> <i>halakha</i> in the name <b>of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Teradyon,</b> not in the name of Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel.
The Gemara analyzes this dispute. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 10:2): In the case of <b>an apple</b> of <i>teruma</i> <b>that one mashed and placed in</b> non-sacred <b>dough, and</b> the juice of the apple <b>leavened</b> the dough, <b>this</b> dough <b>is prohibited</b> to be consumed by anyone who may not partake of <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara reiterates the question: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this mishna? <b>Shall we say</b> that it <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Ḥanina ben Gamliel,</b> who maintains that the juice of apples causes the dough to leaven properly, <b>and not</b> in accordance with the ruling of <b>the Rabbis,</b> the majority opinion that disputes this ruling? The Gemara refutes this suggestion: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. Granted,</b> the Rabbis hold <b>that</b> dough leavened by the juice of apples does <b>not become full-fledged leavened bread,</b> but <b>in any event it becomes hardened [<i>nukshe</i>]</b> leaven. Consequently, dough leavened by the juice of <i>teruma</i> apples is prohibited to non-priests.
§ On the previous <i>amud</i> the Gemara cited the opinion of Rabba and Rav Yosef that measuring the flour in the leavening dough must be performed before water is added. The Gemara discusses this matter further. <b>Rabbi Ila says:</b> Of all the meal offerings, <b>you do not have</b> a meal offering <b>whose removal of</b> the <b>handful is more difficult than</b> that of <b>the meal offering of a sinner.</b> This particular meal offering is dry, as no oil is added to it. Therefore, it is very difficult to remove precisely a handful, as when the priest takes a handful with his thumb and little finger, a large amount of flour is apt to fall out. <b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi says:</b> The removal of the handful in the case of the meal offering of a sinner is no more difficult than its removal in other meal offerings. The reason is that although the Torah prohibited the addition of oil to <b>the meal offering of a sinner,</b> nevertheless the priest <b>may knead it in water, and</b> it is <b>fit</b> to be offered.
The Gemara analyzes this dispute. <b>Let us say</b> that these <i>amora’im</i> <b>disagree about this: As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi, <b>holds that one measures</b> meal offerings <b>as they are,</b> in their current state, after they have been mixed into a dough. Therefore it is permitted to perform the removal of the handful after water has been added, at which point it is not a particularly difficult rite to perform. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ila, <b>holds that one measures</b> meal offerings <b>as they were</b> before they were mixed with water, when they were still flour. Therefore, if one were to add water before measuring he might add too much, which would cause the dough to be too soft and the measure of the offering too large, or conversely, if he were to add too little water the dough would be stiff and too small in volume. Either way, the handful will not contain the correct amount of flour, and therefore no water may be added.
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> as <b>everyone</b> agrees that <b>one measures</b> meal offerings <b>as they</b> currently <b>are. And</b> it is <b>with regard to this</b> that <b>they disagree: As</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi, <b>holds: What</b> is the meaning of <b>“dry”</b> written in the verse discussing a meal offering: “And every meal offering, mixed with oil, or dry” (Leviticus 7:10)? It means <b>dry of oil,</b> but one may add water. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Ila, <b>holds</b> that the meal offering of a sinner must be <b>dry of all substances,</b> i.e., it may not contain even water.
§ The question concerning whether a meal offering is to be measured in its current, mixed state or as it was before it was mixed relates to a fundamental issue that also arises in other areas of <i>halakha</i>. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Okatzin</i> 2:8): <b>Meat of a calf that swelled</b> due to cooking, as the volume of calf flesh increases when it is cooked in water, <b>or meat of an old</b> animal <b>that shrank</b> due to cooking, which is what happens to meat of this type, are to be <b>measured as they are</b> in order to determine if they are the volume of an egg-bulk, in which case they can contract ritual impurity and transfer impurity of food to other items.
The Sages disagree as to the meaning of: Measured as they are. <b>Rav, Rabbi Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> all <b>say</b> that it means the items are to be <b>measured as they are</b> currently, after having been cooked. <b>Shmuel, Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and Reish Lakish</b> all <b>say</b> it means they are to be <b>measured according to</b> their volume <b>as they are,</b> before having been cooked. In other words, even if the meat of a calf is the volume of an egg-bulk after it was cooked, if it was less than this before cooking it cannot contract ritual impurity. Conversely, even if the meat of an old animal was less than an egg-bulk after cooking, if it was an egg-bulk before it was cooked it can contract ritual impurity.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Shmuel, Rabbi Shimon bar Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, and Reish Lakish from a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>meat of a calf that</b> came into contact with a source of ritual impurity but that <b>was not of</b> a volume equivalent <b>to</b> the minimum <b>measure</b> for contracting impurity, i.e., an egg-bulk, if it was then cooked, <b>and</b> as a result it <b>swelled</b> until <b>it stood at</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> for ritual impurity, this meat is <b>pure with regard to the past, but</b> can become <b>impure</b> and render other items impure <b>from here on.</b> In other words, the previous contact with a source of impurity did not render the meat impure, as it was of insufficient volume at the time. This indicates that the status of an item with regard to ritual impurity depends on its volume at the current moment.
The Gemara answers: It is possible that by Torah law this meat is in fact not susceptible to ritual impurity even from here on, as the <i>halakha</i> defines it by its volume prior to cooking. Nevertheless, the <i>baraita</i> teaches that it is impure <b>by rabbinic law.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If so, say the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>And similarly,</b> the same principle applies <b>to an offering that was sacrificed with the intent to consume it after its designated time [<i>piggul</i>], and similarly with regard to</b> food <b>left over from an offering after the time allotted for its consumption [<i>notar</i>].</b> The Gemara analyzes this statement: <b>Granted, if you say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is discussing <i>halakhot</i> that apply <b>by Torah law, this is</b> why the cases of <b><i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i> are</b> included in the <i>baraita</i>, as they also apply by Torah law. <b>But if you say</b> that the <i>halakhot</i> in the <i>baraita</i> apply <b>by rabbinic law, are there <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i> by rabbinic law?</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is not referring to the prohibitions of <i>piggul</i> and <i>notar</i>. Rather, it means the following: <b>And similarly,</b> the same principle applies <b>with regard to ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b><i>piggul</i>, and similarly with regard to ritual impurity</b> imparted by <b><i>notar</i>.</b> There is a rabbinic decree that meat which is <i>piggul</i> or <i>notar</i> imparts impurity to one’s hands even if the meat itself was not impure. The <i>baraita</i> teaches that if the meat is at least the volume of an egg-bulk after it was cooked, it renders the hands impure in this manner.
The Gemara explains that this statement is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since</b> the concepts of <b>impurity</b> imparted by <b><i>piggul</i> and impurity</b> imparted by <b><i>notar</i></b> apply <b>by rabbinic law, the Sages did not institute</b> a stringency to <b>such an extent,</b> making items that were less than the requisite volume until they were cooked contract and impart forms of impurity that apply <b>by rabbinic law.</b> Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that this <i>halakha</i> does apply to those forms of ritual impurity.
The Gemara continues to analyze this dispute. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>meat</b> of <b>an old</b> animal <b>that</b> initially <b>was</b> of a volume equivalent <b>to</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> for contracting ritual impurity and became impure, after which it was cooked <b>and</b> as a result <b>shrank</b> until it was <b>less than</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> for contracting impurity, it is considered <b>impure with regard to</b> items that touched it in <b>the past,</b> when it was large enough, <b>and</b> it is <b>pure</b> with regard to items that it may touch <b>from here on.</b> This <i>baraita</i> indicates that the current state of the item is decisive.
<b>Rabba said,</b> in explanation of the dispute between the <i>amora’im</i>: <b>Anywhere,</b> i.e., with regard to any item, <b>that was initially of</b> a volume equivalent to the requisite measure, <b>but now it is not of</b> such a volume, the <i>halakha</i> is determined according to the item’s current volume, and <b>it is not of</b> the requisite volume. Conversely, <b>anywhere,</b> i.e., with regard to any item, <b>that initially was not of</b> the requisite measure <b>but now it is of</b> sufficient volume, the item contracts impurity <b>by rabbinic law.</b>

Daf 54b

<b>When they disagree</b> is in a case <b>where</b> the food initially <b>had</b> the requisite <b>measure</b> for ritual impurity, <b>and it shrank</b> until it was less than this measure, <b>and</b> subsequently it <b>again swelled</b> to the requisite measure for contracting impurity. The dispute is <b>that</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., Shmuel, Rabbi Shimon, and Reish Lakish, <b>holds: There is disqualification with regard to a ritual matter,</b> including impurity. In other words, if at a certain point the food was less than the requisite measure it becomes entirely disqualified from contracting ritual impurity, even if it subsequently swells again. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> i.e., Rav, Rav Ḥiyya, and Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds: There is no disqualification with regard to a ritual matter.</b> Even if at a certain stage the food lost its ability to contract impurity, if it later swells it can once again become impure.
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there one who says</b> that <b>there is disqualification with regard to ritual matters? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Teharot</i> 3:6): In the case <b>of an egg-bulk</b> of a ritually impure <b>food that one placed in the sun and</b> that therefore <b>shrank</b> to less than an egg-bulk; <b>and similarly</b> in the case of <b>an olive-bulk</b> of flesh <b>of a corpse,</b> or <b>an olive-bulk of an animal carcass, or a lentil-bulk of a creeping animal,</b> all of which impart impurity; <b>or an olive-bulk</b> of <b><i>piggul</i>, or an olive-bulk</b> of <b><i>notar</i>, or an olive-bulk</b> of forbidden <b>fat,</b> if any of these were placed in the sun and shrank, they <b>are pure,</b> i.e., they do not impart impurity to other items, <b>and one is not liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for them due to</b> the prohibitions of <b><i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, or</b> forbidden <b>fat.</b>
The mishna continues: If, after they shrank in the sun, one took these foods and <b>placed them in the rain,</b> as a result of which <b>they</b> again <b>swelled</b> to the minimum volume for ritual impurity, <b>they are impure,</b> as was the case before they shrank. This applies to the impurity of a corpse, the impurity of an animal carcass, and the impurity of foods, <b>and one is</b> also <b>liable</b> to receive <i>karet</i> <b>for them due to <i>piggul</i>, <i>notar</i>, or</b> forbidden <b>fat.</b> This demonstrates that the food is not permanently disqualified. Therefore, <b>the refutation of</b> the opinion of <b>the one who says</b> that <b>there is disqualification with regard to ritual matters</b> is <b>a conclusive refutation.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to the dispute over whether food is to be measured in its current volume or according to its initial volume. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a <i>baraita</i>: (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Terumot</i> 4:2): <b>One may separate <i>teruma</i></b> and tithes from fresh <b>figs for dried figs,</b> which have shrunk and are now smaller than they were when they were fresh. In other words, one may designate fresh figs as <i>teruma</i> and tithe to exempt the dried figs, despite the difference between these two types of figs. This separation may be performed only <b>by number,</b> e.g., ten fresh figs for ninety dried figs. One may not set aside this <i>teruma</i> by volume, i.e., by separating fresh figs with a volume of one-tenth of the measure of dried figs. The reason is that the volume of the fresh figs is greater than that of the dried figs, so he would set aside fewer fresh figs than he would if he calculated by number.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that <b>one measures</b> food items <b>as they were</b> initially, then since when the obligation to separate <i>teruma</i> began, the volume of the dried figs was the same as the fresh ones, then it is <b>well;</b> the amount of figs to be separated as <i>teruma</i> should be calculated based on number, disregarding their current volume. <b>But if you say</b> that foods are to be measured <b>as they</b> currently <b>are,</b> then since the volume of the dried figs is smaller than that of the fresh figs, he will separate a larger amount than necessary, and <b>this</b> case is an example of one who <b>increases</b> his <b>tithes.</b>
<b>And we learned</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Demai</i> 8:10): In the case of <b>one who increases</b> his <b>tithes,</b> i.e., he designates more than one-tenth of the produce as tithe, the remainder of <b>his produce is rendered fit</b> for consumption, as it has been properly tithed. <b>But his tithes are ruined,</b> as the amount over one-tenth is not tithe, and it was not itself tithed, so it remains untithed produce. If so, how can the fresh figs be considered proper <i>teruma</i> and tithes in this case?
The Gemara asks: <b>Rather, what</b> will you claim; that one measures foods <b>as they were</b> initially? If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of that same <i>baraita</i>: One may separate tithes from <b>dried figs for</b> fresh <b>figs</b> only <b>by measure</b> of volume, i.e., dried figs that are one-tenth of the volume of the fresh figs. One may not separate by number, as this would result in fewer dried figs than separation by volume.
The Gemara analyzes this <i>halakha</i>. <b>Granted, if you say</b> that one measures foods <b>as they are</b> currently, it is <b>well. But if you say</b> that one measures foods <b>as they were</b> initially, when the dried figs were fresh, it should be enough to set aside a smaller number of dried figs corresponding to the fresh ones. Since the <i>baraita</i> instructs him to separate a larger number of dried figs than required, this too <b>is</b> an example of <b>one who increases</b> his <b>tithes.</b>
Therefore, this <i>baraita</i> cannot serve as proof for either opinion. Since the two statements of the <i>baraita</i> appear contradictory, it must be that this <i>baraita</i> is actually not discussing tithes, which must be separated according to a precise measure. <b>Rather, here we are dealing with standard <i>teruma</i>.</b> By Torah law there is no fixed measure for standard <i>teruma</i>; a single kernel of grain exempts the entire crop. The Sages established a range of measures: One-fortieth for a generous gift, one-fiftieth for an average gift, and one-sixtieth for a miserly gift. Accordingly, one who wishes to give generously should give slightly more than the exact measure. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> is speaking of one who wishes to separate <i>teruma</i> <b>generously, and</b> in <b>the latter clause,</b> where he also gives more than necessary, <b>it</b> is also referring to one who wishes to separate his <i>teruma</i> <b>generously.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>If so, say the last clause: Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: Father,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yosei, <b>would set aside ten dried figs that</b> were <b>in a vessel for ninety</b> fresh figs <b>that</b> were <b>in a basket. And if</b> this <i>baraita</i> is referring to <b>standard <i>teruma</i>,</b> then with regard to this mention of <b>ten</b> dried figs, <b>what is its purpose?</b> This proportion was greater by orders of magnitude than even the amount of a generous gift established by the Sages.
<b>Rather, here we are dealing with <i>teruma</i> of the tithe,</b> which the Levite separates from his tithe and gives to a priest. This <i>teruma</i> is one-tenth of the first tithe. <b>And</b> this ruling <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Abba Elazar ben Gomel. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Abba Elazar ben Gomel says</b> with regard to the verse: <b>“And your <i>teruma</i> [<i>terumatkhem</i>] shall be reckoned to you</b> as though it were the grain of the threshing floor” (Numbers 18:27), that in using a plural term of the word “your,” <b>the verse speaks about two <i>terumot</i>. One is standard <i>teruma</i>,</b> i.e., the grain of the threshing floor, <b>and</b> the other <b>one is <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.</b> The verse equates these two <i>terumot</i>.
Abba Elazar ben Gomel explains: <b>Just as standard <i>teruma</i> is taken by estimate,</b> as there is no requirement for the amount separated to be measured precisely; <b>and</b> it can be taken <b>by thought,</b> as one is not required to physically separate it before consuming the remaining produce, <b>so too, <i>teruma</i> of the tithe may be taken by estimate</b>

Daf 55a

<b>and by thought. And</b> this comparison also teaches that <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>standard <i>teruma</i></b> one should give <b>generously, so too,</b> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe</b> one should give <b>generously.</b> Therefore, one who separates <i>teruma</i> of the tithe from fresh figs for dried figs should do so generously, e.g., ten fresh figs for ninety dried ones, as though the volume of the dried figs was as large as that of fresh ones.
The Gemara suggests: <b>And from this</b> statement of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, one can cite a proof for the opinion that food is to be measured in accordance with its initial size. As <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Yosei, said: Father would set aside ten dried figs that</b> were <b>in a vessel for ninety</b> fresh figs <b>that</b> were <b>in a basket. Granted, if you say</b> that <b>we say</b> one measures food items <b>as they were</b> initially, it is <b>well,</b> as Rabbi Yosei apparently considers the dried figs set aside as tithes as though they were still fresh figs. <b>But if you say</b> that one measures foods <b>as they are</b> in their current state, then in a case where one separates ten dried figs for ninety fresh figs <b>they are less</b> than the requisite amount, as the volume of ten dried figs is less than the volume of ten fresh figs. This indicates that the measure of the food is determined according to its initial state.
The Gemara answers that one cannot extrapolate from the example of dried figs to other cases. <b>When Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, he said that <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> the following reason for that particular <i>halakha</i>: <b>Dried figs are different, since one can boil</b> dried figs in water <b>and return them to</b> their previous state; in other words, <b>as they were</b> when they were fresh. Consequently, one may separate them for fresh figs as though they too were fresh. One cannot extrapolate from here a principle with regard to other items.
§ The Gemara discusses the possibility of separating fresh figs as <i>teruma</i> for dried ones. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>One may separate <i>teruma</i></b> from fresh <b>figs for dried figs</b> by number, e.g., ten fresh figs for ninety dried ones, <b>in a place where they are accustomed to make</b> fresh <b>figs</b> into <b>dried figs,</b> and therefore the fresh figs can be preserved by processing them into dried figs. <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b> set aside <i>teruma</i> from <b>dried figs for</b> fresh <b>figs even in a place where they are accustomed to make</b> fresh <b>figs</b> into <b>dried figs.</b>
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said: One may separate <i>teruma</i></b> from fresh <b>figs for dried figs in a place where they are accustomed to make</b> fresh <b>figs</b> into <b>dried figs.</b> This indicates that <b>in a place where they are accustomed</b> to make dried figs, <b>yes,</b> one may set aside <i>teruma</i> in this manner. But <b>in a place where they are not accustomed</b> to make dried figs, one may <b>not</b> separate from fresh figs for dried ones, as the fresh figs are liable to spoil before they can be used.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If</b> it is referring to a situation <b>where there is a priest</b> present, and the owner of the produce can give him the <i>teruma</i> without delay, then even in <b>a place where he is not accustomed</b> to make dried figs, <b>why</b> may he <b>not</b> set aside fresh figs for dried ones? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 2:4): In <b>a place where there is a priest</b> present, the owner of the produce <b>separates <i>teruma</i> from the</b> best-quality produce? In this case, the fresh figs are superior in quality to the dried ones, despite the fact that dried figs last longer.
<b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is referring to a situation <b>where there is no priest</b> present, and by the time a priest is found the fresh figs might spoil. If so, <b>say the latter clause</b> of that <i>baraita</i>: <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b> set aside <i>teruma</i> from <b>dried figs for</b> fresh <b>figs even in a place where they are accustomed to make</b> fresh <b>figs</b> into <b>dried figs. And if</b> this is referring to a situation <b>where there is no priest</b> present, <b>why</b> may one <b>not</b> set aside dried figs, which can be preserved for a lengthy period, for fresh ones? <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the same mishna (<i>Terumot</i> 2:4): In <b>a place where there is no priest</b> present, the owner of the produce <b>separates <i>teruma</i> from that which will endure,</b> not from the best-quality produce? <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>obvious</b> that this clause is referring to a situation <b>where there is a priest</b> present.
The Gemara challenges: If so, <b>the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> addresses a case <b>where there is no priest</b> present, whereas <b>the latter clause</b> addresses a case <b>where there is a priest</b> present. The Gemara explains: <b>Yes, the first clause</b> of the <i>baraita</i> addresses a case <b>where there is no priest</b> present, and <b>the latter clause</b> addresses a case <b>where there is a priest</b> present.
