<b>Rav Pappa said: Learn from</b> this discussion that <b>we exert</b> ourselves <b>and interpret the mishna according to two reasons,</b> i.e., two different situations in accordance with the opinion of one <i>tanna</i>, <b>but we do not interpret</b> it as being in accordance with the opinions <b>of two <i>tanna’im</i>.</b> An interpretation that maintains a single authorship of a mishna is preferable even if it requires explaining the mishna as discussing two different situations.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the meal-offerings</b> that come as <i>matza</i> <b>are</b> to be <b>kneaded with lukewarm</b> water so that the dough will bake well, as only a small amount of oil is added. <b>And one must watch over them</b> to ensure <b>that they do not</b> become <b>leaven</b> while kneading and shaping them, <b>and if</b> a meal offering or even only <b>its remainder becomes leaven, one violates a prohibition, as it is stated: “No meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord shall be made with leaven;</b> as you shall burn no leaven nor any honey as an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11). <b>And one is liable</b> to be flogged <b>for kneading</b> the meal offering, <b>and for shaping</b> it, <b>and for baking</b> it, if the meal offering becomes leaven.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that one who allows the remainder of a meal offering to become leavened violates a prohibition. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived? <b>Reish Lakish said: The verse states: “It shall not be baked with leaven.</b> I have given it as <b>their portion</b> of My offerings made by fire” (Leviticus 6:10). This section of the verse can be read as a single sentence, to indicate: <b>Even their portion</b> of meal offerings, i.e., the remainder eaten by priests after the removal of the handful to be burned on the altar, <b>shall not be baked with leaven.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> does <b>this</b> verse <b>come for this</b> purpose? It cannot, as <b>it is necessary</b> as the source for a different <i>halakha</i>, <b>for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“It shall not</b>

Daf 55b

<b>be baked with leaven”</b> (Leviticus 6:10). <b>What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this? <b>Isn’t</b> this requirement <b>already stated</b> earlier: <b>“No</b> meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord <b>shall be made with leaven;</b> as you shall burn no leaven nor any honey as an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11)? Rather, the phrase “it shall not be baked with leaven” serves to teach a different <i>halakha</i>. <b>Since</b> the prohibition concerning leaven <b>is</b> first <b>stated</b> in general terms: <b>Shall not be made with leaven,</b> without specification, one <b>might</b> have thought that one who causes a meal offering to become leaven <b>will be liable</b> to receive <b>only one</b> set of lashes <b>for all of</b> his actions, i.e., kneading, shaping, and baking the dough. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It shall not be baked</b> with leaven,” which teaches that one who causes a meal offering to become leaven is liable separately for baking it, and for each stage of its preparation.
The <i>baraita</i> explains this derivation: <b>Baking</b> leaven <b>was</b> included <b>in the general</b> prohibition incorporating all of the stages involved in preparing the meal offering. <b>Why</b> did <b>it emerge</b> from the generalization to be mentioned explicitly? It emerged in order <b>to compare</b> the other stages <b>to it: Just as</b> the act of <b>baking is notable</b> in <b>that it is a single,</b> i.e., separately defined, <b>action, and one is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for it by itself</b> if the dough is leaven, <b>so too, I will include</b> the other stages of the preparation of a meal offering, i.e., <b>kneading it and shaping it,</b> and conclude that one is liable separately for each of these actions if the dough is leavened.
<b>And</b> the same applies to <b>any single action involved in</b> the preparation of a meal offering. This statement serves <b>to include</b> the act of <b>smoothing</b> the surface of the dough with water. The reason this act is included is that although it is not a significant stage in the preparation of the dough, <b>it is a single,</b> independent <b>action, and</b> therefore <b>one is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for it by itself.</b> This <i>baraita</i> demonstrates that one cannot derive the prohibition against allowing the remainder of a meal offering to become leavened from the verse: “It shall not be baked with leaven,” as this verse is the source of a different <i>halakha</i>. If so, from where is that prohibition derived?
The Gemara answers: The verse: “It shall not be baked with leaven,” is required for the principle stated earlier. <b>We say</b> that the prohibition against allowing the remainder of a meal offering to become leavened is derived <b>from</b> the subsequent phrase: “I have given it as <b>their portion</b> of My offerings made by fire” (Leviticus 6:10). The remainder is the portion of the meal offering eaten by the priests.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> once it has been determined that the term “their portion” teaches the prohibition against leavening the remainder of a meal offering, one can <b>say</b> this <b>entire</b> section of the verse <b>comes</b> only <b>for this</b> purpose, which would mean that there is no source for the <i>halakha</i> that one is liable separately for each stage of the preparation of a meal offering with leaven.
The Gemara answers: One cannot say that this teaches only the prohibition against leavening the remainder of a meal offering, as <b>if so, let</b> the verse <b>write: Their portion shall not be baked with leaven. What</b> is meant by the fact that the verse stated it in a different order: <b>“Shall not be baked with leaven.</b> I have given it as <b>their portion”?</b> This indicates that one should <b>learn from this two</b> <i>halakhot</i>, i.e., that there is a prohibition against leavening the remainder of a meal offering and that one is liable to receive a separate set of lashes for each stage of preparation performed with leavened dough.
The Gemara raises another difficulty: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the act of <b>baking</b> is different, <b>as the Merciful One specified it</b> in the Torah, and therefore <b>one should be liable</b> to receive <b>one</b> set of lashes for baking the dough. As for the <b>other</b> stages in the preparation of a meal offering, i.e., kneading, shaping, and smoothing, which are not explicitly stated in the verse, <b>let him be liable</b> to receive <b>one</b> set of lashes <b>for all of them.</b> The Gemara answers that this cannot be the <i>halakha</i>, <b>because</b> baking <b>is something that was included in a generalization but emerged from the generalization</b> in order <b>to teach</b> a <i>halakha</i>. According to a hermeneutic principle, a case of this kind <b>did not emerge to teach</b> a <i>halakha</i> only <b>about itself, but</b> rather it <b>emerged to teach</b> a <i>halakha</i> <b>about the entire generalization,</b> in this case, about all the other stages in the preparation of a meal offering.
The Gemara further challenges: <b>But</b> one can <b>say</b> that the phrase: <b>Shall not be made</b> with leaven, is <b>a generalization,</b> as it does not mention any specific acts, and the phrase: <b>“It shall not be baked</b> with leaven,” is <b>a detail,</b> as it specifies one particular stage of the preparation; and there is another standard hermeneutic principle: When there is <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization</b> is referring <b>only</b> to <b>that which</b> is specified <b>in the detail.</b> In this case, that would mean that <b>baking, yes,</b> is included in this prohibition, but <b>other matters,</b> e.g., kneading and shaping, are <b>not</b> included.
<b>Rabbi Aptoriki said:</b> That hermeneutic principle is not relevant here, <b>because</b> this <b>is</b> a case of <b>a generalization and a detail that</b> appear in the Torah <b>distanced from one another,</b> as the phrase: Shall not be made with leaven (Leviticus 2:11), is far from the expression: “It shall not be baked with leaven” (Leviticus 6:10). <b>And</b> for <b>any</b> instance of <b>a generalization and a detail that</b> appear in the Torah <b>distanced from one another, one cannot derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from <b>them by</b> analyzing them as <b>a generalization and a detail.</b>
<b>Rav Adda bar Ahava raises an objection, and some say</b> that this objection is <b>unattributed [<i>kedi</i>]: And</b> is it correct that in the case of <b>a generalization and a detail that</b> appear in the Torah <b>distanced from one another, one cannot derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from <b>them by</b> analyzing them as <b>a generalization and a detail? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a goat brought by a king as a sin offering: The verse states: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the goat, <b>and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before the Lord; it is a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:24). <b>Where is the burnt offering slaughtered? On the northern</b> side of the Temple courtyard, as it is stated: “And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar northward before the Lord” (Leviticus 1:11). <b>This</b> sin offering of a king must consequently <b>also</b> be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>And do you learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from here? But isn’t it already stated:</b> “Speak to Aaron and to his sons, saying: This is the law of the sin offering: <b>In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered shall the sin offering be slaughtered</b> before God; it is most holy” (Leviticus 6:18)? If so, <b>to what</b> purpose <b>was this singled out?</b> Why does the Torah state explicitly that the sin offering of the king requires slaughter in the north? The <i>baraita</i> answers: It is <b>to fix</b> a place <b>for it,</b> that this is the only place where a sin offering may be slaughtered, teaching <b>that if he did not slaughter it in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>he has disqualified it</b> even after the fact.
The <i>baraita</i> asks: <b>Do you say</b> that it is <b>singled out for this</b> purpose, to teach that even after the fact a sin offering slaughtered anywhere other than in the north is disqualified? <b>Or</b> perhaps <b>it is only</b> to teach <b>that this</b> goat sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north, but no other</b> goat sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north.</b> The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>The verse states</b> elsewhere: “And he shall place his hand upon the head of the sin offering, <b>and slaughter the sin offering in the place of burnt offering”</b> (Leviticus 4:29), and <b>this established a paradigm for all sin offerings, that they require</b> slaughter in the <b>north.</b> Therefore, the additional verse stated with regard to the sin offering of a king teaches that if he did not slaughter it in the north it is disqualified.
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. The <b>reason</b> that all sin offerings must be slaughtered in the north is <b>that the Merciful One wrote: “And slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering,”</b> from which it can be inferred that if <b>not for this</b> verse <b>I would say that</b> only <b>this</b> sin offering, the male goat brought by a king, <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north, but no other</b> type of sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north. What is the reason</b> for this? After all, the verse: “In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered shall the sin offering be slaughtered,” appears to be referring to all types of sin offerings.
<b>Isn’t</b> it <b>because</b> this verse <b>is a generalization and a detail,</b> as the verse first generalizes about all sin offerings, and then the verse concerning the sin offering of a king: “And slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering,” is a detail, as it is referring to a specific sin offering? <b>And even though</b> the verse concerning sin offerings and the verse concerning the sin offering of a king are <b>distanced from one another,</b> nevertheless <b>we</b> would <b>derive</b> a <i>halakha</i> from <b>them by</b> means of the principle of <b>a generalization and a detail.</b> This appears to disprove the explanation of Rabbi Aptoriki.
<b>Rav Ashi objects to this</b> claim raised by Rav Adda bar Ahava: Is <b>this a generalization and a detail? It is</b> in fact <b>a detail and a generalization,</b> as the verse: “And slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering” (Leviticus 4:24), appears in the Torah earlier than the verse: “In the place where the burnt offering is slaughtered the sin offering shall be slaughtered” (Leviticus 6:18). A hermeneutic principle states that in this case <b>the generalization adds to the detail, and includes all matters.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the reason that if not for the specific textual derivation we would have thought that only a sin offering brought by a king requires slaughter in the north is that the word <b>“it,”</b> which is an exclusion, is <b>difficult for the <i>tanna</i></b> of the <i>baraita</i>, as it is unclear what this term serves to exclude. <b>And this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: Or</b> perhaps the verse <b>is</b> teaching that <b>only this</b> sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north, but no other</b> type of sin offering <b>requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north, as the Merciful One writes “it,”</b> which is an exclusion. Therefore, the additional verse: “And slaughter the sin offering in the place of the burnt offering,” teaches that this <i>halakha</i> applies to all burnt offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>derives it from</b> the phrase: <b>“And slaughter the sin offering</b> in the place of the burnt offering,” <b>to exclude what</b> does the term <b>“it”</b> serve? The Gemara answers: It serves <b>to exclude</b> the case that emerges from the following discussion, summarized by the <b>mnemonic: Nahshon; and slaughter; bird; on Passover.</b>
The Gemara explains the first suggestion: <b>It,</b> the goat sin offering of a king, is slaughtered <b>in the north, but</b> the <b>goat</b> offered by <b>Nahshon,</b> prince of the tribe of Judah, was <b>not</b> slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Tabernacle. He, along with all the other princes of the tribes, brought offerings to inaugurate the altar and the Tabernacle, as recorded in the Torah (see Numbers, chapter 7). The sin offerings brought at this time were unique because they were not brought to atone for any sin. The term “it” teaches that even though they had some characteristics of a sin offering, the offerings of the princes did not require slaughter in the north.
The Gemara explains: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the sin offerings of the princes <b>are included in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands, they are also included in</b> the requirement to be slaughtered in the <b>north.</b> Therefore, the term “it” <b>teaches us</b> that there was no requirement of slaughter in the north for the goats brought as sin offerings by Nahshon and the other princes.
The Gemara asks: <b>And from where do we</b> derive that the requirement of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the animal <b>itself</b> applies to the goats offered by Nahshon and the other princes? The Gemara answers: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the sin offering of a king: <b>“And he shall place his hand upon the head of the goat,</b> and slaughter it in the place where they slaughter the burnt offering before the Lord; it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 4:24). The verse could have stated: Upon its head. The reason it adds “of the goat” is <b>to include</b> the <b>goat</b> brought as a sin offering by <b>Nahshon in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an offering. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Shimon says:</b>

Daf 56a

The term “of the goat” serves <b>to include</b> the <b>goats</b> brought as communal sin offerings for <b>idol worship in</b> the requirement of <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an offering.
<b>Ravina objects to this:</b> This <b>works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who says that the offering of Nahshon was included in the requirement of placing hands on the head of the animal. But <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, what is there to say?</b> Why should the Torah write the term “it,” since there is no reason to assume that it would require slaughter in the north?
<b>Mar Zutra, son of Rav Mari, said to Ravina:</b> And <b>according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda as well,</b> why not say that for <b>that which it was included,</b> i.e., placing hands on the head of an animal, <b>it was included; and</b> for <b>that which it was not included,</b> i.e., slaughter in the north, <b>it was not included.</b> Why would one think that the obligation to slaughter in the north applies to the offering of Nahshon merely because the requirement of placing hands applies to that offering?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>had the verse not excluded</b> the offerings of the princes <b>I would say</b> that one could <b>derive</b> the requirement for slaughter in the north <b>via a paradigm</b> from all other sin offerings, <b>if so,</b> one could also <b>derive</b> the requirement for <b>placing hands</b> on the head of an animal <b>itself via</b> the same <b>paradigm. Rather,</b> the reason that the requirement of placing hands cannot be derived via a paradigm is that <b>we do not learn</b> the requirements of the sin offering of Nahshon, which was for the <b>time</b> of the inauguration of the Tabernacle alone, <b>from</b> the requirements of sin offerings applicable to all <b>generations. So too,</b> the requirement of slaughter in the north cannot be derived via a paradigm because <b>we do not learn</b> the requirements of the sin offering of Nahshon, which was for the <b>time</b> of the inauguration of the Tabernacle alone, <b>from</b> the requirement of sin offerings applicable to all <b>generations.</b>
<b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard, <b>but the one who slaughters</b> it does <b>not</b> need to stand <b>in the north</b> when he slaughters. The offering would be valid even if he were to stand in the south of the courtyard and use a long knife to slaughter the animal that is positioned in the north.
The Gemara challenges this: The <i>halakha</i> of the one who slaughters has already been <b>derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Aḥiyya, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Aḥiyya says:</b> The verse states with regard to the burnt offering: <b>“And he shall slaughter it on the side of the altar northward</b> before God” (Leviticus 1:11). <b>Why</b> must <b>the verse state</b> the exclusionary term “it”?
He explains: <b>Since we have found</b> that the priest <b>stands in the north and collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal <b>in the north, and if he stood in the south and collected</b> the blood <b>in the north</b> the offering is <b>disqualified,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that this is <b>so also</b> with regard to <b>this</b> one who slaughters the offering. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And he shall slaughter <b>it,”</b> to teach that <b>it,</b> the animal, must be <b>in the north, but the one who slaughters</b> does <b>not</b> have to be standing <b>in the north</b> of the Temple courtyard when he slaughters the animal. The question returns: What is derived from the exclusionary term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king?
The Gemara answers: <b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it,</b> a goat brought as a sin offering, must be slaughtered <b>in the north, but a bird</b> brought as an offering does <b>not</b> need to be killed <b>in the north.</b> It might <b>enter your mind to say: Let it be derived</b> that a bird must be killed in the north by <b>an <i>a fortiori</i></b> inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sheep,</b> as follows: <b>Just as</b> is the case for <b>a sheep</b> brought as a burnt offering, <b>that</b> the Torah <b>did not fix</b> that <b>its</b> slaughter must be performed by <b>a priest,</b> yet nevertheless it <b>fixed</b> that <b>its</b> slaughter must be in the <b>north,</b> with regard to <b>a bird</b> brought as an offering, for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did fix</b> that <b>its</b> slaughter must be performed by <b>a priest, is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>should</b> also <b>fix its</b> slaughter in the <b>north?</b> Therefore, the verse states “it,” to exclude a bird from the requirement of being killed in the north.
The Gemara questions the logical inference. One cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of a bird offering from the <i>halakha</i> of a sheep offering, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a sheep offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah <b>fixed</b> the requirement that <b>it</b> be slaughtered with <b>a utensil,</b> i.e., a knife. By contrast, a bird is killed by the priest pinching the nape of its neck with his fingernail, without a utensil. Therefore, the term “it” cannot serve to counter this derivation. If so, there is no reason to think that a bird should also have to be killed in the north, and the term “it” is not necessary to exclude this possibility.
The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king serves to teach that <b>it,</b> the goat of the king, is slaughtered <b>in the north, but</b> the <b>Paschal offering</b> is <b>not</b> slaughtered <b>in the north.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: The <i>halakha</i> that the <b>Paschal offering</b> need not be slaughtered in the north is not derived from the term: “It,” but rather it is <b>derived as</b> stated by <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Yaakov says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>a Paschal offering requires</b> slaughter in the <b>north. And this</b> can be derived through <b>a logical inference: Just as</b> in the case of <b>a burnt offering,</b> for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>did not fix a time for its slaughter</b> yet <b>fixed</b> that <b>it</b> requires slaughter in the <b>north,</b> with regard to <b>a Paschal offering,</b> for <b>which</b> the Torah <b>fixed a time for its slaughter,</b> i.e., it must be slaughtered in the afternoon of the fourteenth day of Nisan, <b>is it not logical that</b> the Torah <b>would fix</b> that <b>it</b> must be slaughtered in the <b>north?</b> Therefore, the verse states “it,” to exclude the Paschal offering from the requirement of slaughter in the north.
The Gemara questions the logical inference. One cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> of a Paschal offering from the <i>halakha</i> of a burnt offering, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a burnt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> the Torah teaches that <b>it is entirely</b> burned on the altar. This is not so with regard to a Paschal offering.
The Gemara continues: If you would suggest learning a logical inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a sin offering,</b> which is not entirely burned upon the altar yet is slaughtered only in the north, this too can be refuted. As <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a sin offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that it</b> has the power to <b>atone for</b> those sins <b>liable for</b> punishment by <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>],</b> which is not so with regard to a Paschal offering.
The Gemara continues: If you would suggest learning a logical inference <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a guilt offering,</b> which is not entirely burned, does not atone for those sins liable for punishment by <i>karet</i>, and is slaughtered only in the north, this too can be refuted. As <b>what</b> is notable <b>about a guilt offering?</b> It is notable <b>in that</b> it is <b>an offering of the most sacred order,</b> which is not so with regard to a Paschal offering. The Gemara adds: Having noted this distinction between a guilt offering and a Paschal offering, one can say that for <b>all of</b> the three offerings the <i>halakha</i> of a Paschal offering cannot be derived <b>from</b> them <b>either, since</b> each of them is <b>an offering of the most sacred order.</b>
The Gemara returns to the earlier inference: <b>Rather,</b> the term “it” teaches <b>as we said initially: It,</b> i.e., the animal, must be standing <b>in the north, but</b> the <b>one who slaughters</b> the animal does <b>not</b> have to stand <b>in the north. And that</b> which is <b>difficult for you,</b> that <b>we derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Aḥiyya,</b> is in fact not difficult. The derivation <b>of Rabbi Aḥiyya</b> from the term “it” <b>does not come to exclude</b> one who <b>slaughters</b> from the requirement to slaughter <b>in the north,</b> since that is known already from the term “it” stated with regard to the sin offering of a king. <b>Rather, this is what</b> Rabbi Aḥiyya <b>is saying:</b> The <b>one who slaughters</b> the animal does <b>not</b> have to stand <b>in the north, but</b> by inference, the one who <b>collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal must stand <b>in the north.</b>
The Gemara questions this inference: The <i>halakha</i> that the one who <b>collects</b> the blood from the neck of the animal must stand in the north is derived <b>from</b> the fact that the Torah could have written: The priest <b>shall take,</b> and instead writes: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take”</b> (Leviticus 4:34). The Gemara explains: This <i>tanna</i> <b>does not learn</b> anything from this distinction between: The priest <b>shall take,</b> and: <b>“And</b> the priest <b>shall take.”</b> Since he does not agree with this derivation, he must therefore derive the requirement to collect the blood while standing in the north from a different verse.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And one is liable</b> to be flogged <b>for kneading</b> the meal offering, <b>and for shaping it, and for baking it,</b> if the meal offering becomes leaven. <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> If one <b>baked</b> a meal offering as leaven he <b>is flogged</b> with <b>two</b> sets of lashes, <b>one for shaping</b> the dough <b>and one for baking it.</b> The Gemara raises a difficulty: <b>But you said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Just as</b> the act of baking is <b>notable</b> in <b>that it is a single action and one is liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for it by itself;</b> this indicates that one receives one set of lashes for baking a meal offering as leavened bread, not two.
The Gemara answers: This is <b>not difficult,</b> as <b>this</b> statement of the <i>baraita</i>, i.e., that one receives a single set of lashes for baking, is referring to a case <b>where he shaped</b> the dough <b>and he,</b> the same person, also <b>baked</b> it. Since he already incurred liability to receive lashes for shaping the dough before he baked it, he is not liable again for shaping when he bakes it. <b>That</b> statement of Rav Pappa, that one who bakes the dough is liable to receive two sets of lashes, is referring to a situation <b>where another</b> person <b>shaped</b> the dough <b>and gave</b> the shaped dough <b>to him, and he baked</b> it. Although the one who shaped it is liable to receive lashes for the act of shaping, nevertheless, the one who bakes it is liable to receive two sets of lashes, as his act of baking also completed the shaping of the dough.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the leavening of a meal offering. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> (<i>Tosefta</i>, <i>Bekhorot</i> 3:6): In the case of an unblemished <b>firstborn</b> kosher <b>animal</b> whose <b>blood</b> circulation is <b>constricted,</b> a condition that can be healed only through bloodletting, <b>one may let</b> the animal’s <b>blood</b> by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>does not cause</b> a permanent <b>blemish. But one may not let</b> the animal’s <b>blood</b> by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>causes</b> a permanent <b>blemish,</b> as it is prohibited to intentionally cause a blemish in a firstborn animal; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>And the Rabbis say: One may even let</b> the animal’s blood by cutting it <b>in a place where</b> the incision <b>causes</b> a permanent <b>blemish, provided that he does not slaughter</b> the animal <b>on</b> the basis <b>of that blemish,</b> even though in general, a firstborn animal may be slaughtered once it develops a permanent blemish. The Rabbis maintain that in this case, since he caused the blemish himself, he may not slaughter it until it develops a different, unrelated blemish. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b>

Daf 56b

The animal <b>may even be slaughtered on</b> the basis <b>of that blemish. Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> if the firstborn would <b>die</b> if its blood is not let, <b>one may not let its blood</b> at all.
The Gemara discusses similar cases, including examples involving meal offerings. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: All</b> of the Sages who disagree as to whether one may let the blood of a firstborn animal whose blood circulation is constricted <b>concede that one who leavens</b> a meal offering <b>after</b> another had already <b>leavened</b> it is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes for the additional leavening, <b>as it is written:</b> “No meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord <b>shall be made with leaven”</b> (Leviticus 2:11), <b>and</b> it is also stated: <b>“It shall not be baked with leaven”</b> (Leviticus 6:10). This indicates that one is liable for every act of leavening performed on a meal offering.
Similarly, everyone agrees <b>that one who castrates</b> an animal <b>after one who castrates</b> it <b>is liable, as it is written: “Those whose testicles are bruised, or crushed, or detached, or cut,</b> shall not be offered to the Lord, and you shall not do this in your land” (Leviticus 22:24). <b>If one is liable</b> when the seminal vesicles <b>are cut,</b> then when the testicles <b>are detached</b> altogether is he <b>not all the more so</b> liable? <b>Rather,</b> this verse serves to <b>include</b> one who <b>detaches</b> the testicles <b>after</b> one who <b>cuts</b> the seminal vesicles, to indicate <b>that he is liable.</b> Apparently, one is liable for castrating an animal that is already sterilized.
These Sages <b>disagree only with regard to one who inflicts a blemish on</b> an already <b>blemished</b> animal, such as one whose blood circulation is constricted. <b>Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that as the verse states: “It shall be perfect to be accepted; <b>there shall be no blemish in it”</b> (Leviticus 22:21), this categorical statement includes even the infliction of a blemish on an offering that is already blemished. <b>And the Rabbis maintain</b> that the phrase <b>“it shall be perfect to be accepted”</b> indicates that the prohibition against inflicting a blemish applies only to an animal that is currently perfect, i.e., unblemished, and can therefore be accepted, meaning that it is suitable to be sacrificed upon the altar. If the animal is already blemished, there is no prohibition against inflicting an additional blemish upon it.
The Gemara analyzes this dispute. <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who derives the <i>halakha</i> from the phrase “there shall be no blemish in it,” <b>isn’t it written also: “It shall be perfect to be accepted”?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse serves <b>to exclude</b> only an animal that was <b>blemished from the outset,</b> i.e., an animal that was born with a blemish. In such a case, there is no prohibition to inflict an additional blemish on it. But if the animal was initially unblemished and later developed a blemish, it is prohibited to inflict another blemish upon it.
The Gemara rejects this suggestion: There is no need to exclude an animal that was <b>blemished from the outset,</b> as <b>it is merely like a palm tree,</b> i.e., it is an item that can never attain the status of an animal consecrated as an offering. Therefore, it is obvious that the prohibition against inflicting a blemish does not apply to this animal.
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Meir maintains that the phrase “it shall be perfect to be accepted” serves <b>to exclude disqualified consecrated animals,</b> to teach that <b>after their redemption,</b> when they become non-sacred, the prohibition against inflicting a blemish does not apply to them any longer. This exclusion is necessary, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> it is <b>prohibited</b> to <b>shear</b> disqualified consecrated animals <b>or</b> use them for <b>labor</b> even after they have been redeemed and are non-sacred, perhaps <b>let</b> it <b>also be prohibited</b> to inflict <b>a blemish upon them.</b> Consequently, this verse <b>teaches us</b> that there is no prohibition against inflicting a blemish upon these animals.
The Gemara analyzes the opinion of the Rabbis. <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>the Rabbis as well,</b> who base their opinion on the phrase: “It shall be perfect to be accepted,” <b>isn’t it written: “There shall not be any blemish in it,”</b> which indicates an expansion of the prohibition against inflicting a blemish? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse <b>is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“There shall not be any blemish in it”</b> (Leviticus 22:21). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only that it may not have a blemish</b> caused directly by human action. <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one may not cause</b> a blemish to be inflicted <b>upon it</b> indirectly <b>by means of other</b> agents, e.g., <b>that one may not place dough or</b> pressed <b>figs on its ear so that a dog will come and take it,</b> thereby biting off part of the animal’s ear and leaving it blemished? <b>The verse states: “Any blemish.” It says: “Blemish,” and it says “Any blemish”;</b> the word “no” serves to teach that one may not cause a blemish indirectly.
§ The Gemara returns to discuss the leavening of a meal offering. <b>Rabbi Ami says:</b> If one <b>placed leaven,</b> i.e., dough that has leavened to such an extent that it is no longer used as food but as a leavening agent for other dough, <b>on top of</b> the <b>dough</b> of a meal offering, <b>and he went and sat himself</b> down to wait, meaning that he performed no other action, <b>and</b> the dough then <b>leavened of its own</b> accord, he is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes <b>for it.</b> This is <b>similar to</b> performing a prohibited <b>action on Shabbat.</b> The Gemara questions this comparison: <b>And is one liable</b> for performing a prohibited <b>action on Shabbat</b> in <b>a case like this? But doesn’t Rabba bar bar Ḥana say</b>

Daf 57a

that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of one who <b>placed meat on top of coals</b> on Shabbat, if he subsequently <b>turned over</b> the meat to its other side, so that both sides were roasted, he is <b>liable</b> for cooking on Shabbat. But if he <b>did not turn over</b> the meat he is <b>exempt,</b> as the meat is considered cooked only if both sides were roasted. If so, the same should apply to one who places leaven on the dough of a meal offering: He should be liable only if he turns the dough over. This contradicts the ruling of Rabbi Ami.
<b>Rava said: What</b> does Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>as well,</b> mean <b>when he says:</b> He is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes for it, similar to performing a prohibited action on Shabbat? He means that one who places leaven on the dough of a meal offering, even if he does not turn it over, is similar <b>to</b> one who performs a prohibited <b>action of roasting on Shabbat,</b> meaning that he is similar to one who turned over the roasting food on the coals.
§ The Gemara discusses <b>the</b> matter <b>itself. Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of one who <b>placed meat on top of coals</b> on Shabbat, if he subsequently <b>turned over</b> the meat he is <b>liable</b> for cooking on Shabbat, and if he <b>did not turn over</b> the meat he is <b>exempt.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If we say</b> that this was a situation <b>where if</b> he does <b>not turn over</b> the meat it would <b>not cook,</b> then it is <b>obvious</b> that if he does not turn it over he is exempt. <b>Rather,</b> it must be referring to a case <b>where</b> even <b>if</b> he <b>does not turn over</b> the meat it would nevertheless <b>cook.</b> But if so, <b>why isn’t he liable</b> for merely placing the meat on the coals, despite the fact that he did not turn it over?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is <b>necessary</b> to state this <i>halakha</i> in a case <b>where if</b> he does <b>not turn over</b> the meat it would <b>cook on one side</b> only partially, roughly one-third of the ordinary process of cooking, <b>like the food of ben Derosai. And</b> now <b>that he turns it over,</b> it <b>cooks on both sides like the food of ben Derosai. And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>teaches us that any</b> meat roasted <b>on</b> only <b>one side like the food of ben Derosai is nothing,</b> i.e., this is not a violation of the prohibited labor of cooking on Shabbat. If it was roasted on both sides like the food of ben Derosai this is classified as cooking, and he is liable for cooking on Shabbat.
The Gemara continues to discuss the case of meat roasted on one side on Shabbat. <b>Rava says: And if</b> a quantity of that meat equivalent in volume <b>to a fig-bulk was</b> fully <b>roasted on one side</b> of the meat and the roasted area was <b>in one spot</b> on the piece of meat, while the rest of the meat remained raw, he is <b>liable</b> for cooking on Shabbat. <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi:</b> It can be inferred from Rava’s statement that if the fig-bulk of meat that was roasted was <b>in one spot, yes,</b> he is liable, whereas if the amount of the fig-bulk <b>was</b> distributed <b>over two or three</b> separate <b>spots</b> he is <b>not</b> liable. <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Shabbat</i> 102b): <b>One who drills</b> a hole of <b>any</b> size <b>is liable</b> for the labor of building or the labor of striking a blow with a hammer to complete the production process of a vessel?
The Gemara analyzes that mishna: <b>What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that the mishna is referring to one who drills a hole <b>in one spot</b> alone, why is he liable? <b>For what</b> purpose is a hole <b>of any size,</b> which includes a very small hole, <b>fit</b> to be used? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to one who drills holes <b>in two or three</b> different <b>spots,</b> and the reason he is liable is <b>that</b> these holes <b>are fit to</b> be <b>joined?</b> Builders who require a large hole will often start by drilling a few small holes which they later enlarge and join together. By the same logic, if the meat was roasted in a few spots he should be liable, as these can join together. The Gemara answers: <b>No; actually</b> the mishna is referring to one who drills <b>in</b> only <b>one spot,</b> as one can say <b>that</b> the hole <b>is fit as an entrance [<i>levava</i>] for</b> the placement of the tooth of <b>a key [<i>aklida</i>],</b> which is very small.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> there is a different version of this discussion: <b>Rava says: Even</b> if the fig-bulk of the meat that was fully roasted on only one side was distributed <b>over two or three</b> separate <b>spots,</b> he is liable for cooking on Shabbat. <b>Ravina said to Rav Ashi: We learn</b> this <i>halakha</i> in the mishna <b>as well: One who drills</b> a hole of <b>any</b> size is <b>liable. What are the circumstances? If we say</b> that the hole is <b>in one spot</b> alone, why is he liable? <b>For what</b> purpose is a hole <b>of any size fit</b> to be used? <b>Rather, is it not</b> referring to one who drills holes <b>in two or three</b> different <b>spots,</b> and the reason he is liable is <b>that</b> these holes <b>are fit to</b> be <b>joined?</b> Similarly, in the case discussed by Rava, one is liable for the cooking of the meat in a few different spots which can join together. The Gemara answers: <b>No; actually</b> the mishna is referring to one who drills <b>in</b> only <b>one spot,</b> as one can say <b>that it is fit as an entrance for</b> the placement of the tooth of <b>a key.</b>
§ The Gemara returns to discussing the prohibition against leavening a meal offering. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Concerning the deep-pan meal offering, the verse states: “No meal offering that you shall bring to the Lord shall be made with leaven; for any leaven, and any honey, you shall not burn any of it as an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11). The term “meal offering” is apparently superfluous, and therefore the <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>If</b> the verse <b>had stated</b> only: <b>Nothing that you shall bring to the Lord shall be made with leaven, I would say: I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the <b>handful</b> removed from the meal offering for burning on the altar <b>alone</b> is included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>“Shall not be made with leaven,”</b> as only the handful is burned on the altar.
<b>From where</b> is it derived that one is liable for the leavening of <b>a meal offering</b> whose handful has not yet been removed? <b>The verse states: “Meal offering,”</b> to teach that the prohibition includes a meal offering before the removal of its handful. The Gemara asks: Since this verse is stated in the context of the deep-pan meal offering, <b>from where</b> is it derived that one is liable for leavening the <b>other meal offerings,</b> which are not mentioned in this passage? Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> the inclusive phrase: <b>“No meal offering,”</b> to apply this <i>halakha</i> to other meal offerings.
The <i>baraita</i> continues to expound the verse. The phrase: <b>“That you shall bring to the Lord,”</b> indicates that this prohibition applies only to <b>a fit</b> meal offering, <b>but not</b> to a <b>disqualified</b> meal offering, e.g., a meal offering that was taken outside the Temple or that was rendered ritually impure. <b>From here</b> the Sages <b>stated</b> that <b>one who leavens a fit</b> meal offering is <b>liable</b> to receive lashes, <b>but</b> one who leavens <b>a disqualified meal offering</b> is <b>exempt.</b>
With regard to the ruling that the prohibition against leavening does not apply to a disqualified meal offering, <b>Rav Pappa raises a dilemma:</b> If one <b>leavened</b> a meal offering when it was fit, <b>and</b> subsequently someone removed the meal offering and it <b>emerged</b> from the Temple courtyard and was thereby disqualified, <b>and he again leavened it, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is he liable for the second leavening as well? The Gemara explains the possibilities: Does one say that <b>since</b> it <b>emerged it is disqualified in</b> accordance with the status of a sacred item that <b>emerges</b> from its permitted area, <b>and</b> therefore <b>when he again leavens it he is not liable for it due to</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening</b> a meal offering <b>after</b> one who already <b>leavened</b> it?
<b>Or perhaps, since</b> one already <b>leavened</b> the meal offering, from this point forward the <b>disqualification</b> of a sacred item that <b>emerges</b> from its permitted area <b>is ineffective with regard to</b> removing it from the prohibition against leavening, as the prohibition against emerging from the Temple itself applies only to a fit meal offering. <b>And</b> therefore, <b>when he again leavens it he is liable for it due to</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening</b> a meal offering <b>after one who</b> already <b>leavened</b> it. No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
<b>Rav Mari raises</b> another <b>dilemma</b> concerning the leavening of a meal offering. If a priest <b>leavened</b> a meal offering while standing <b>at the top of the altar, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara clarifies the possibilities: <b>The Merciful One states</b> in the Torah: “No meal offering <b>that you shall bring</b> to the Lord shall be made with leaven” (Leviticus 2:11), which indicates that this prohibition applies only to a meal offering that has not yet been brought to the Lord, i.e., to the altar. <b>And</b> therefore, as <b>this</b> meal offering <b>has</b> already been <b>brought</b> to the top of the altar, even though it has not yet been burned, perhaps it is not included in the prohibition.
<b>Or perhaps</b> any offering whose <b>burning has not yet</b> been performed <b>is considered like</b> one whose <b>action</b> of sacrifice <b>has not yet</b> been performed, despite the fact that it has already been brought to the top of the altar. If so, this meal offering is included in the prohibition against leavening. No answer was found, and the Gemara states that the dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> <b>derives from</b> the phrase: <b>“No meal offering,”</b> that the prohibition includes even a meal offering before the removal of its handful, <b>why do I</b> need the phrase: <b>“That you shall bring,”</b> in the same verse? The Gemara answers: <b>It is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“That you shall bring,”</b> in order <b>to include the meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany certain animal offerings such as burnt offerings, peace offerings, and the sin offerings and guilt offerings of a leper <b>in</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening.</b> Unlike the standard meal offerings, from which a handful is removed, these are entirely burned upon the altar, and the additional derivation is necessary to include them in the prohibition against <b>leavening.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> This phrase serves <b>to include the shewbread in</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening.</b>
The Gemara clarifies these opinions: With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, the Gemara asks: How is it possible to leaven <b>the meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations?</b> This type of meal offering is kneaded only with olive oil, which <b>is</b> a type of <b>fruit juice,</b>

Daf 57b

<b>and</b> there is a principle that <b>fruit juices do not leaven</b> dough. <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili would say:</b> Even though the oil of <b>the meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations</b> is plentiful, sometimes one might also <b>knead</b> a meal offering <b>with</b> some <b>water,</b> if he considers it necessary to add it, <b>and</b> it is <b>fit.</b> If so, it is possible for this meal offering to leaven due to the water, and therefore the verse: “That you shall bring,” teaches that the prohibition against leavening also applies to this type of meal offering.
The Gemara asks: With regard to Rabbi Akiva’s opinion, the vessel into which a tenth of an ephah of flour for baking the <b>shewbread is</b> placed in <b>is a measuring</b> vessel for <b>dry</b> items, <b>and we have heard that Rabbi Akiva said:</b> The <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items were <b>not consecrated</b> as service vessels. This means the shewbread becomes consecrated only when it is placed on the Table in the Sanctuary, after it has been baked. If so, at this stage, the prohibition against leavening is not relevant.
In answer to this question, the Gemara states that <b>Rabbi Reuven sent</b> a letter from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia, in which he cited a statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan: This is the</b> correct <b>version [<i>hetze’ah</i>] of</b> this <b><i>baraita</i>, and</b> one should <b>reverse</b> the names of the Sages in it: The phrase <b>“that you shall bring”</b> serves <b>to include the shewbread in</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yosei HaGelili. Rabbi Akiva says:</b> This phrase serves <b>to include the meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations in</b> the prohibition against <b>leavening.</b> Consequently, there is no contradiction between Rabbi Akiva’s statement here and his statement with regard to measuring vessels for dry items.
The Gemara comments: <b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who holds that Rabbi Yosei HaGelili is the one who maintains that the measuring vessels for dry items were consecrated, <b>follows [<i>ve’azda</i>] his</b> line of <b>reasoning</b> stated elsewhere. <b>As Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and one of the students of Rabbi Yishmael</b> both <b>said the same thing. And who is</b> that student of Rabbi Yishmael? It is <b>Rabbi Yoshiya.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the consecration of the Tabernacle and its vessels before their inauguration: “And it came to pass on the day that Moses had made an end of setting up the Tabernacle, and had anointed it and sanctified it, and all its vessels, and the altar and all its vessels, <b>and had anointed them and sanctified them”</b> (Numbers 7:1). <b>Rabbi Yoshiya says:</b> The <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>liquid</b> items, e.g., oil, and wine for libations, were <b>anointed</b> and thereby consecrated <b>both on</b> the <b>inside and on</b> the <b>outside.</b> The <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items, such as the flour for meal offerings, <b>were anointed</b> and consecrated only <b>on</b> the <b>inside, but were not anointed on</b> the <b>outside.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yonatan says:</b> The <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>liquid</b> items <b>were anointed on</b> the <b>inside and were not anointed on</b> the <b>outside,</b> whereas the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items <b>were not anointed at all.</b> Rabbi Yonatan cites a proof for his opinion: <b>You can know</b> that the measuring vessels for dry items were not consecrated at all, <b>because</b> it is taught that these vessels <b>do not consecrate</b> items placed inside them. <b>As it is written: “You shall bring out of your dwellings two wave-loaves of two tenth-parts of a ephah. They shall be of fine flour; they shall be baked with leaven, for first produce to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 23:17). <b>When</b> are <b>they</b> considered consecrated <b>to the Lord?</b> Only <b>after they are baked</b> with leaven. This demonstrates that when the flour is placed into the tenth of an ephah measuring vessel the meal offering is not yet consecrated.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> Rabbi Yoshiya and Rabbi Yonatan <b>disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the interpretation of the word “them” in the phrase: “And sanctified <b>them”</b> (Numbers 7:1). Both <i>tanna’im</i> agree that the term “them” serves to exclude something from the anointing and consecration, but they disagree over what is excluded. <b>Rabbi Yoshiya maintains</b> that <b>“them”</b> serves <b>to exclude</b> the consecration of the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items on the <b>outside,</b> i.e., only the inside of the vessels is consecrated. <b>And Rabbi Yonatan maintains</b> that the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items <b>are non-sacred,</b> i.e., not consecrated at all, <b>and</b> therefore <b>it is not necessary</b> for the <b>verse to exclude</b> them. <b>Where it was necessary</b> for the <b>verse to exclude</b> something, it was with regard to <b>measuring</b> vessels used for <b>liquid</b> items, to teach that they are consecrated only on the inside but not <b>on</b> the <b>outside.</b>
The Gemara asks: Since the dispute between Rabbi Yoshiya and Rabbi Yonatan concerns the <i>halakha</i> of measuring vessels for dry items, <b>let</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>say also,</b> as he did with regard to Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and Rabbi Yoshiya: <b>Rabbi Akiva and one of the students of Rabbi Yishmael</b> both <b>said the same thing, and who is</b> that student? <b>Rabbi Yonatan.</b> The Gemara explains: Rabbi Yoḥanan did not say this <b>due to</b> the fact that their opinions <b>are not the same with regard to measuring</b> vessels used for <b>liquid</b> items: Rabbi Akiva maintains that these vessels are consecrated both on the inside and on the outside, whereas Rabbi Yonatan rules that they are consecrated only on the inside.
<b>Rav Pappa said to Abaye:</b> How can it be suggested, according to the opinion that the measuring vessels for dry items were not consecrated, that the shewbread is consecrated only when it is placed on the Table? <b>But</b> before that <b>there is</b> the stage in which the dough is placed into the <b>receptacle [<i>bisa</i>]</b> in which it is kneaded. Since this vessel <b>is</b> used for <b>liquid</b> items, the dough should be consecrated at that point. Abaye <b>said to</b> Rav Pappa: This is referring to a case <b>where he kneaded</b> the dough <b>on top of</b> a flat <b>leather spread [<i>katavliyya</i>],</b> which does not sanctify the dough.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> with regard to <b>that which Rabbi Yonatan said to</b> Rabbi Yoshiya as proof of his opinion, that <b>you can know</b> that it is so, <b>as</b> it is taught that these vessels <b>do not consecrate</b> items placed inside them, <b>let</b> Rabbi Yoshiya <b>say to him</b> in refutation of his claim: This is referring to a case <b>where he measured</b> the flour for the two loaves <b>in</b> a vessel used for measuring <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah, but it was a vessel <b>that</b> was <b>non-sacred,</b> and it is for this reason that the loaves are not consecrated.
The Gemara responds: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? Granted,</b> one can say that the shewbread was kneaded on a leather spread rather than in <b>a receptacle,</b> as <b>the Merciful One does not write</b> in the Torah <b>that one should</b> specifically <b>use a receptacle to knead</b> the shewbread. Therefore, <b>when one kneads</b> the dough of a meal offering <b>on top of a leather spread, we have no</b> problem <b>with it. But</b> in the case of the two loaves whose flour was measured in a vessel used for measuring <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah, <b>since the Merciful One states</b> explicitly to <b>use</b> a vessel of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>and measure with it,</b> can it be suggested that the one preparing the meal offering should <b>leave aside</b> the <b>consecrated</b> vessel for <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>and measure with a non-sacred</b> vessel for <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah?
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that one who offers up</b> outside the Temple courtyard a portion <b>of the meat of a sin offering, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of a guilt offering, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of offerings of the most sacred order, or</b> a portion <b>of the meat of offerings of lesser sanctity, or</b> a portion <b>of the surplus of the <i>omer</i> offering, or</b> a portion <b>of the leftover of the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering on <i>Shavuot</i> of two loaves from the new wheat, <b>or the shewbread, or the remainder of meal offerings, that</b> in all these cases <b>he</b> violates <b>a prohibition,</b> although these items are not meant to be sacrificed on the altar?
The <i>baraita</i> answers: <b>The verse states: “For any leaven, and any honey, you shall not burn any of it as an offering made by fire to the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 2:11). The extra term “of it” teaches that <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> has already had some part <b>of it</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> on the altar <b>is</b> included <b>in</b> the prohibition: <b>Do not burn,</b> stated in that verse explicitly with regard to honey and leaven.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>the two loaves and the shewbread, is there</b> some part <b>of them</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire? But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: A portion of every offering is sacrificed on the altar, <b>except for the two loaves and the shewbread, as no</b> part <b>of them</b> is burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire?</b>
<b>Rav Sheshet said:</b> Although <b>no</b> part <b>of</b> the two loaves or the shewbread <b>themselves</b> is burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire,</b> nevertheless, they are included in the prohibition against offering them up to the altar, since they are not viewed as independent entities but rather as parts of larger offerings. The two loaves accompany the sheep sacrificed as burnt offerings on Shavuot, and are permitted for consumption only once those sheep have been burned on the altar. Similarly, the shewbread is permitted for consumption only after the bowls of frankincense that were on the Table with it have been burned on the altar.
§ The Gemara discusses the prohibition against offering up on the altar parts of offerings after their sacrificial portions have already been burned. <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who brings up</b> any part <b>of any of</b> the items listed in the <i>baraita</i> <b>onto the ramp</b> leading to the altar, but not to the altar itself, <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> he is <b>liable</b> and <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> he is <b>exempt.</b>
The Gemara elaborates. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> he is <b>liable, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: After the verse: “As any leaven and any honey, you shall not burn any of it as an offering made by fire to the Lord,” the next verse states: “As an offering of first fruits you may bring them to the Lord, but they shall not come up to <b>the altar</b> for a pleasing aroma” (Leviticus 2:12). <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this <i>halakha</i> applies to an item that is brought on the <b>altar. From where</b> is it derived that the same applies if it is brought to the <b>ramp</b> of the altar? <b>The verse states: “But they shall not come up to the altar</b> for a pleasing aroma,” to be accepted, and the ramp is the means to ascend to the altar.
<b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that one who brings up parts to the ramp is <b>exempt? As the verse states:</b> “For any <b>leaven, and</b> any <b>honey,</b> you shall not burn any of it as an offering made by fire to the Lord. <b>As an offering of first produce you may bring them</b> to the Lord, but they shall not come up to the altar for a pleasing aroma” (Leviticus 2:11–12).
The Gemara explains: The term <b>“them”</b> indicates that this <i>halakha</i> applies only to those offerings that come from leaven or honey and which are called: “An offering of first produce.” This category consists of first fruits, which are brought from dates and other sweet fruit and which are called: “The choicest first fruits of your land” (Exodus 23:19), and the two loaves, which are leaven and are the first meal offerings brought from the new crop each year. In other words, it is with regard to <b>this</b> category <b>that</b> the verse <b>amplifies for you</b> the <i>halakha</i> that the <b>ramp</b> of the altar is considered <b>like</b> the <b>altar</b> itself. <b>But</b> with regard to <b>other items,</b> e.g., the meat of sin offerings and guilt offerings, the ramp of the altar is <b>not</b> treated like the altar itself.

Daf 58a

The Gemara asks: <b>And what does Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who maintains that the prohibition against bringing leftover portions up to the ramp applies to all of the items listed in the <i>baraita</i>, <b>do with this</b> term: <b>“Them,”</b> in the verse: “As an offering of first produce you may bring them” (Leviticus 2:12), from which Rabbi Elazar learns that only first fruits and the two loaves are included in the prohibition?
The Gemara answers: <b>He requires it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>an individual may donate and bring</b> to the Temple <b>a gift</b> offering <b>similar to those</b> two loaves brought by the community, <b>and</b> in support <b>I</b> will <b>read with regard to</b> this offering the verse that deals with other gift offerings: <b>“That which has gone out of your lips you shall observe and do;</b> according to what you have vowed freely to the Lord your God, even that which you have promised with your mouth” (Deuteronomy 23:24), which would mean that the offering is consecrated and he must bring it as he declared.
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “As an offering of first produce you may bring.”</b> The phrase: “You may bring,” is written in the plural, meaning that it is addressed to the community. Therefore, it is interpreted to mean: <b>I said to you</b> that <b>a community</b> may consecrate and bring the two loaves, which are an offering of first produce, <b>but an individual</b> may <b>not</b> consecrate and bring two loaves of this nature.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that only <b>an individual may not bring</b> two loaves as a gift offering, <b>as</b> an individual <b>does not bring his obligatory</b> offering in a manner <b>similar to those</b> two loaves, i.e., perhaps specifically an individual, who never has an obligatory offering of two loaves, may not bring two loaves as a gift offering. <b>But</b> the <b>community shall bring</b> two loaves as a gift offering, <b>as</b> the community <b>does bring its obligatory</b> offering in a manner <b>similar to those</b> two loaves. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “You may bring <b>them,”</b> to exclude the possibility of a communal gift offering of two loaves. The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>And what is there</b> left <b>for you to bring</b> as offerings that come from leaven and honey? <b>The two loaves</b> that comes <b>from leaven, and</b> the <b>first fruits</b> that come <b>from honey,</b> i.e., sweet fruits.
The Gemara asks: <b>And may the two loaves not be sacrificed</b> as communal <b>gift</b> offerings? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “As any leaven, and any honey, you shall not burn any of it” (Leviticus 2:11): <b>If it is stated: “Any leaven,” why is it stated: “Any honey”? And if it is stated: “Any honey,” why is it stated: “Any leaven”?</b> In other words, why is it necessary for the verse to repeat the inclusive term “any,” from which it is derived that offering an insufficient quantity of honey or leaven is included in the prohibition? The <i>baraita</i> answers: Both of these terms had to be stated, <b>because there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to leaven that is not</b> applicable <b>to honey, and there is</b> another <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to honey that is not</b> applicable <b>to leaven.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> explains: In the case of <b>leaven,</b> although it may not be sacrificed on the altar, <b>its general</b> prohibition <b>was permitted</b> in certain circumstances <b>in the Temple,</b> as the two loaves and the bread of the thanks offering, i.e., the four loaves of the thanks offering that were eaten by the priests, are leavened bread. By contrast, with regard to <b>honey,</b> there are <b>no</b> circumstances in which <b>its general</b> prohibition <b>was permitted in the Temple.</b>
There is a <i>halakha</i> that applies to honey but not to leaven, as the prohibition concerning <b>honey is permitted</b> in the case <b>of the remainder of meal offerings,</b> meaning that the priests may eat their portion of meal offerings with honey, whereas the prohibition concerning <b>leaven is not permitted</b> in the case <b>of the remainder of meal offerings,</b> since one may not leaven this remainder. The <i>baraita</i> summarizes: <b>Due to</b> the fact <b>that there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to leaven that is not</b> applicable <b>to honey, and there is</b> a <i>halakha</i> that applies <b>to honey that is not</b> applicable <b>to leaven, it was necessary</b> for the verse <b>to state: “Any leaven,” and it was</b> also <b>necessary</b> for it <b>to state: “Any honey.”</b>
The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>. When the <i>baraita</i> states concerning <b>leaven that its general</b> prohibition <b>was permitted</b> in certain circumstances <b>in the Temple, what is this? Isn’t</b> this referring to the <i>halakha</i> <b>that</b> the meal offering of the <b>two loaves may be sacrificed</b> by the community as <b>a gift</b> offering on the altar, as the two loaves of the communal offering themselves were not sacrificed on the altar? This would mean that two loaves may be brought as a gift offering by the community, which contradicts this claim of the previous <i>baraita</i>. <b>Rav Amram said: No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> is referring to the fact that the two loaves, which were leaven, <b>are brought</b> as an offering <b>with</b> the two lambs, which are brought up onto the altar as communal peace offerings. Since they are brought together, the two loaves and the two lambs are considered a single offering, and the lambs are sacrificed on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> in the case of <b>first fruits also,</b> the fruits should be considered part of the offering that was brought with them. <b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Bikkurim</i> 3:5): As for <b>the fledglings that</b> were placed <b>on top of the baskets</b> that contained the first fruits brought to the Temple, <b>they would</b> sacrifice these as <b>burnt offerings, and the baskets</b> themselves <b>that were in the possession</b> of those bringing the first fruits would <b>be given to the priests.</b> Accordingly, with regard to honey as well, its general prohibition was permitted in certain circumstances, as these first fruits containing honey are included with the sacrifice of burnt offerings. The Gemara answers: <b>These</b> fledglings <b>came</b> only <b>to decorate</b> the <b>first fruits,</b> despite the fact that they were later sacrificed as burnt offerings. Bringing the fledglings is not obligatory, and therefore cannot be considered part of the same offering as first fruits.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the prohibition against bringing leftover parts of offerings up to the altar after the sacrificial parts have been burned. <b>Rami bar Ḥama asked Rav Ḥisda:</b> With regard to <b>one who offers up on the altar</b> some <b>of the meat of a bird</b> sacrificed as <b>a sin offering,</b> which is meant to be eaten by the priests, <b>what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? Is he liable to receive lashes for this action?
The Gemara clarifies the possibilities: <b>The Merciful One states</b> with regard to <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> has already had some portion <b>of it</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> on the altar that one who sacrifices any leftover part of it violates the prohibition. <b>And</b> as <b>no</b> part <b>of this</b> bird sacrificed as a sin offering is burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> on the altar, is he therefore exempt? <b>Or perhaps, any</b> item <b>that is called an offering</b> is included in the prohibition, <b>and</b> since <b>this</b> bird is <b>also called an offering,</b> one is liable. Rav Ḥisda <b>said to</b> Rami bar Ḥama: <b>Any</b> item <b>that is called an offering</b> is included in the prohibition, <b>and this</b> bird sacrificed as a sin offering is <b>also called an offering.</b>
The Gemara notes: Rami bar Ḥama’s dilemma is <b>subject to</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>,</b> as is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> Only <b>any</b> item <b>that</b> has already had some portion <b>of it</b> burned <b>in</b> the <b>fire</b> on the altar is included in the prohibition: Do not burn. <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Any</b> item <b>that is called an offering</b> is included in this prohibition.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> the difference <b>between</b> the opinions of Rabbi Akiva and Rabbi Eliezer? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> concerns the case discussed earlier, of one who brings some of <b>the meat of a bird sin offering</b> up to the altar. Rabbi Akiva maintains that he is liable, as it is called an offering, whereas Rabbi Eliezer holds that he is exempt, as no portion of it is burned on the altar.
<b>Rav said:</b> The difference <b>between them</b> concerns the <b><i>log</i> of oil</b> that accompanies the guilt offering <b>of</b> a recovered <b>leper, as Levi teaches:</b> Concerning the consecrated items given to priests as gifts, the verse states: <b>“Every offering of theirs</b>…shall be most holy for you and for your sons” (Numbers 18:9). The phrase “every offering” serves <b>to include the <i>log</i> of oil of a leper.</b> This oil is not burned on the altar. Nevertheless, Rabbi Akiva would deem one who brings some of this <i>log</i> up to the altar liable, as it is called an offering, whereas Rabbi Eliezer would deem him exempt, since no part of it is burned in the fire.
§ The Gemara returns to the discussion about the prohibition against sacrificing leaven. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: When the Torah states with regard to <b>leaven: Do not burn</b> it (see Leviticus 2:11), <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that one who burns <b>all of it</b> is liable, as will be explained. <b>From where</b> is it derived that one who burns only <b>part of it</b> is also included in the prohibition? <b>The verse states: “Any [<i>kol</i>]</b> leaven,” which serves to include such a case. The <i>baraita</i> adds: This <i>halakha</i> has been derived only with regard to leaven in a pure state; <b>from where</b> is it derived that the same applies to one who sacrifices it in <b>its mixed state,</b> i.e., mixed with another substance? <b>The verse states</b> the additional expression: <b>“As [<i>ki</i>] any</b> leaven.”
The Gemara analyzes this <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is it saying?</b> What is the meaning of the term: All of it, and the term: Part of it? <b>Abaye said: This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> When the verse states about <b>leaven: Do not burn</b> it, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this prohibition applies to <b>an olive-bulk</b> of leaven. <b>From where</b> is it derived that this prohibition applies if it is only <b>half an olive-bulk? The verse states: “Any</b> leaven.” Furthermore, <b>from where</b> is it derived that one is liable not only for leaven by itself, but also for leaven in <b>its mixed state? The verse states: “As any</b> leaven.”
<b>Rava said</b> that there is a different interpretation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>This</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying:</b> When the verse states about <b>leaven: Do not burn</b> it, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that this prohibition applies to the entire <b>handful</b> that is removed from the meal offering. <b>From where</b> is it derived that this prohibition applies to <b>half</b> of the <b>handful? The verse states: “Any</b> leaven.” Furthermore, <b>from where</b> is it derived that one is liable not only for leaven by itself, but also for <b>its mixed state? The verse states: “As any</b> leaven.”
The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>what</b> principle <b>do</b> Abaye and Rava <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Abaye holds: There is</b> such an entity as <b>a handful</b> that is <b>less than</b> the volume of <b>two olives.</b>

Daf 58b

<b>And</b> Abaye consequently maintains that <b>there is</b> such a matter as a halakhically significant <b>burning</b> of a handful even if it is <b>less than</b> the volume of <b>an olive-bulk.</b> It follows that the phrase “any leaven” teaches that if one sacrificed less than an olive-bulk of a handful that was leaven, he is liable.
<b>And Rava says: There is no</b> such entity as <b>a handful</b> that is <b>less than</b> the size of <b>two olives,</b> and consequently the mitzva not to burn leaven is referring initially to a full handful of two olive-bulks. <b>And</b> Rava holds that <b>there is no</b> such matter as a halakhically significant <b>burning</b> of a handful if it is <b>less than</b> the volume of <b>an olive-bulk.</b> Therefore, one cannot derive from the phrase “as any leaven” that one can be liable for sacrificing leaven of less than one olive-bulk. Instead, the phrase must be referring to a case where half the handful is leaven.
§ The Gemara discusses another dispute between Abaye and Rava on this topic: <b>It was stated:</b> With regard to <b>one who offers up</b> a mixture made <b>of leaven and of honey on the altar, Rava says:</b> He is flogged with four sets of lashes for this act, as the verse: “As any leaven and any honey, you shall not burn any of it as an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11), includes four separate prohibitions. He <b>is flogged</b> one set <b>due to</b> the prohibition against sacrificing <b>leaven, and he is flogged</b> a second set <b>due to</b> the prohibition against sacrificing <b>honey,</b> and <b>he is flogged</b> a third set <b>due to</b> the prohibition against sacrificing <b>mixtures of leaven, and</b> he is flogged a fourth set <b>due to</b> the prohibition against sacrificing <b>mixtures of honey.</b>
<b>Abaye says: One is not flogged for a general prohibition,</b> i.e., a single mitzva in the Torah that includes many different prohibited acts. Since all these actions are covered by the prohibition: “You shall not burn,” it is considered a general prohibition, for which one is not flogged.
The Gemara cites a dispute between the Sages with regard to the opinion of Abaye. <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Abaye concedes that <b>in any event</b> the offender is <b>flogged</b> with <b>one</b> set of lashes for sacrificing leaven, and he is also flogged a second set of lashes for sacrificing honey, as these are not considered general prohibitions. Since the phrase: “You shall not burn,” is referring to both leaven and honey, it is as though it were written: You shall not burn leaven; you shall not burn honey.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that Abaye maintains that the offender <b>is not even flogged</b> with <b>one</b> set of lashes, <b>as the prohibition</b> he transgressed <b>is not specific</b> to one matter, <b>like the prohibition against muzzling.</b> The principle that one is liable to be flogged for violating a prohibition is derived from the juxtaposition of the mitzva: “You shall not muzzle an ox while it treads out the grain” (Deuteronomy 25:4), with the verses that mention lashes. It is inferred from this juxtaposition that one is not liable to be flogged for violating prohibitions whose circumstances are not similar to that of muzzling, e.g., a general prohibition that is not referring to one specific action.

Daf 59a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>There are</b> four types of meal offerings: Those <b>that require</b> both <b>oil and frankincense,</b> those that require <b>oil but not frankincense,</b> those that require <b>frankincense but not oil,</b> and those that require <b>neither frankincense nor oil.</b>
The mishna elaborates: <b>And these</b> are the meal offerings that <b>require</b> both <b>oil and frankincense: The fine-flour meal offering,</b> as it is stated: “And he shall pour oil upon it, and put frankincense thereon” (Leviticus 2:1); <b>the</b> meal offering prepared in <b>a pan</b> (see Leviticus 2:5–6); <b>the</b> meal offering prepared in <b>a deep pan</b> (see Leviticus 2:7–10); <b>and the</b> meal offering baked in an oven, which can be brought in the form of <b>loaves or</b> in the form of <b>wafers</b> (see Leviticus 2:4).
Additional meal offerings that require both oil and frankincense are <b>the meal offering of priests; the meal offering of the anointed priest,</b> i.e., the griddle-cake offering brought by the High Priest every day, half in the morning and half in the evening; <b>the meal offering of a gentile; a meal offering</b> brought <b>by women;</b> and <b>the <i>omer</i> meal offering</b> (see Leviticus 23:15).
<b>The meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations</b> that accompany burnt offerings and peace offerings <b>requires oil but does not require frankincense. The shewbread requires frankincense but does not require oil.</b>
<b>The two loaves</b> brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i> (see Leviticus 23:17), <b>the meal offering of a sinner, and the meal offering of jealousy</b> brought by a <i>sota</i> <b>require neither oil nor frankincense.</b> The two loaves do not require oil or frankincense because these additions are not mentioned with regard to it. The meal offering of a sinner does not require them, as it is written: “He shall not put oil upon it, neither shall he give any frankincense upon it; for it is a sin offering” (Leviticus 5:11). With regard to the meal offering brought by a <i>sota</i>, it is similarly written: “He shall pour no oil upon it, nor give frankincense upon it, for it is a meal offering of jealousy, a meal offering of memorial, bringing iniquity to remembrance” (Numbers 5:15).
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rav Pappa stated</b> a principle with regard to all the <i>mishnayot</i> in tractate <i>Menaḥot</i>: <b>Anywhere that we learned</b> in a mishna that one brings a meal offering, <b>we learned</b> that one must bring <b>ten</b> items of the same type, either loaves or wafers. The Gemara explains: This statement of Rav Pappa serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Shimon, who says:</b> One who takes a vow to bring a meal offering baked in an oven must bring ten items. If he wishes, he may bring ten loaves or ten wafers, and if he wishes <b>he may bring half</b> of them as <b>loaves and</b> the other <b>half</b> as <b>wafers.</b> Rav Pappa <b>teaches us</b> that the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna maintains <b>that</b> one may <b>not</b> do so; all ten must be of the same type.
§ The mishna teaches that the <i>omer</i> meal offering requires both oil and frankincense. With regard to this meal offering, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And you shall put oil upon it</b> and lay frankincense upon it; it is a meal offering” (Leviticus 2:15). From this it can be inferred: One must put oil specifically “upon it,” <b>but</b> one does <b>not</b> place <b>oil upon the shewbread.</b>
<b>As</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: Could <b>this not</b> be derived through an <i>a fortiori</i> <b>inference,</b> to conclude that the shewbread should require oil? The <i>baraita</i> explains: <b>And if the meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations</b> that accompany burnt offerings and peace offerings, <b>which does not require frankincense,</b> nevertheless <b>requires oil,</b> then with regard to <b>the shewbread,</b> for which the <i>halakha</i> is more stringent in <b>that</b> it <b>requires frankincense, is it not logical that</b> it should also <b>require oil?</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states “upon it,”</b> which indicates that one places <b>oil upon it,</b> the <i>omer</i> meal offering, <b>but</b> one does <b>not</b> place <b>oil upon the shewbread.</b>
