The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the exclusion was derived <b>from there,</b> i.e., the verse in Leviticus, which is referring to offerings, <b>I would say:</b>It <b>is the offering</b> of nazirites <b>that</b> the gentiles <b>cannot bring, but naziriteship takes effect upon them</b> if they vow to become a nazirite. Therefore, the exclusion of naziriteship by the verse in Numbers <b>teaches us</b> that a gentile cannot become a nazirite at all.
§ The Gemara discusses a related matter. <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 7:6): <b>Rabbi Shimon said: The court instituted seven ordinances</b> with regard to the financial aspects of offerings and consecrations. <b>And this</b> ordinance, namely, that the cost of the libations accompanying the sacrifice of a found sacrificial animal is borne by the public, <b>is one of them.</b> These are the other ordinances: If <b>a gentile sent his burnt offering from a country overseas,</b> and <b>he sent with it</b> money for the purchase of the <b>libations</b> that must accompany it, the libations <b>are offered at his</b> expense. <b>And if</b> the gentile did <b>not</b> cover the cost of the libations, it is a condition of the court that the libations are <b>sacrificed at the public’s</b> expense, with funds taken from the Temple treasury. Evidently, a gentile can offer libations as well as burnt offerings.
The Gemara suggests: <b>Let us say</b> that this mishna rules in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and not</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b> The Gemara rejects this assumption: <b>You</b> may <b>even say</b> that this mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> and he holds that a gentile can bring <b>a burnt offering and all its accessories,</b> including the libations.
The Gemara asks: <b>Who</b> is the <i>tanna</i> who <b>taught that which the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to libations: “All who are <b>home born</b> shall do these things after this manner” (Numbers 15:13), which teaches that those who are <b>home born,</b> i.e., Jews, can <b>bring libations</b> as a separate offering, <b>but a gentile cannot bring</b> such <b>libations.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that a gentile’s <b>burnt offering should not require</b> the standard accompanying <b>libations.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “So</b> it shall be done for one bull” (Numbers 15:11), which indicates that every offering requires libations. <b>Whose</b> opinion is this? It is <b>not</b> that of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili and not</b> that of <b>Rabbi Akiva.</b>
The Gemara explains the question: <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili, doesn’t he say</b> that a gentile may <b>even</b> bring <b>wine</b> by itself, and not only as a libation? <b>If</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva, doesn’t he say</b> that with regard to <b>a burnt offering, yes,</b> a gentile may bring it, but with regard to <b>something else</b> other than the offering itself, <b>no,</b> a gentile may not bring it?
The Gemara answers: <b>If you wish, say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili; and if you wish, say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva. If you wish, say</b> it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yosei HaGelili,</b> and <b>omit from that</b> <i>baraita</i> that the <i>tanna</i> allows gentiles to bring <b>wine,</b> as he holds that gentiles cannot bring wine by itself. <b>And if you wish, say</b> that it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> and interpret his opinion to be that a gentile may bring <b>a burnt offering and all its accessories.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to the <b>meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of the <b>priests,</b> a handful is removed, and the entire offering is sacrificed upon the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>From where is this matter</b> derived?
The Gemara answers: It is derived <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>. The verse states with regard to the meal offering of a sinner: “And he shall bring it to the priest, and the priest shall take his handful of it as the memorial of it, and burn it on the altar…it is a sin offering. And the priest shall make atonement for him for his sin that he has sinned in any of these matters, and he shall be forgiven; and the remainder shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering” (Leviticus 5:12–13). Since the phrase <b>“And</b> the remainder <b>shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering”</b> is seemingly unnecessary, as these verses are discussing a meal offering, it therefore teaches <b>that its</b> sacrificial <b>rite would be valid</b> even when performed <b>by</b> a priest who has brought the offering for his own sin.
The <i>baraita</i> discusses the matter: <b>Do you say that</b> this verse teaches that <b>the rite</b> of the meal offering of a sinner <b>would be valid</b> when performed <b>by him? Or is it only</b> necessary <b>to permit</b> the eating of the remainder of the <b>meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of the <b>priests. And</b> if so, <b>how do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse that states: <b>“And every meal offering of the priest shall be offered in its entirety; it shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:16)? Perhaps that is referring to <b>his voluntary meal offering, but his obligatory</b> meal offering <b>may be eaten.</b>
Therefore, <b>the verse states: “And it shall be the priest’s as the meal offering.”</b> In this way, the verse <b>compares</b> the priest’s <b>obligatory</b> offering <b>to his voluntary</b> offering: <b>Just as his voluntary</b> offering <b>is not eaten, so too, his obligatory</b> offering <b>is not eaten.</b> In disagreeing with the previous interpretation, <b>Rabbi Shimon said: Is it stated: And it shall be the priest’s, as his meal offering? But it states only: “As the meal offering,”</b> referring to the meal offering of a non-priest. <b>Rather,</b> this verse serves <b>to compare</b> and render the <i>halakha</i> of

Daf 74a

<b>the meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of the <b>priests</b> as <b>equivalent to</b> the status of <b>a meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by an Israelite. Just as</b> with regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by an Israelite, a handful is removed, so too,</b> with regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of the <b>priests, a handful is removed.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> challenges this: <b>If</b> so, then say as follows: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by an Israelite, a handful is removed and its remainder is eaten, so too,</b> with regard to the <b>meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of the <b>priests, a handful</b> should be <b>removed and its remainder eaten.</b>
Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And the remainder shall be <b>the priest’s, as the meal offering,”</b> which is interpreted to mean that <b>with regard to</b> the rite performed by <b>the priest,</b> his meal offering is <b>like the meal offering</b> of the Israelite, <b>but</b> it is <b>not like the meal offering</b> of the Israelite with regard to consumption <b>by the fires</b> of the altar. <b>How</b> is <b>this</b> possible? In what ways does the meal offering of a priest resemble that of an Israelite in some respects and not in others? The priest’s <b>handful is sacrificed by itself,</b> like that of the Israelite, <b>and the remainder is sacrificed by itself,</b> unlike those of the Israelite, which are eaten.
§ According to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> in the <i>baraita</i> cited earlier, a priest may perform the rites of a meal offering of a sinner that he brings for himself based on the verse “And the remainder shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering.” The Gemara now asks: With regard to <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>that its rite is valid</b> when performed <b>by him,</b> is it <b>derived from here?</b>
It is <b>derived from there,</b> another verse cited in a <i>baraita</i>, which states: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>with regard to a priest that</b> he may <b>come and sacrifice his offerings at any time and at any hour that he desires,</b> even when it is not during the period of his priestly watch? <b>The verse states:</b> “And if a Levite comes from any of your gates from all of Israel, where he lives, <b>and comes with all the desire of his soul</b> to the place which the Lord shall choose, <b>then he shall serve</b> in the name of the Lord his God, as all his brothers the Levites do, who stand there before the Lord” (Deuteronomy 18:6–7).
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> were derived <b>from there,</b> the verse in Deuteronomy, <b>I would say: This statement,</b> that a priest may perform his rites whenever he chooses, applies only to <b>a matter that does not come</b> to atone <b>for a sin,</b> as the verse is referring to an offering that he desires to bring. <b>But</b> with regard to a <b>matter that comes</b> to atone <b>for a sin, I would say</b> that he may <b>not</b> perform the rite himself. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> of the meal offering of a sinner must be derived from the verse in Leviticus: “And the remainder shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering.”
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> that a priest may perform the rite of his own sin offering <b>also derived from here,</b> i.e., the verse: “And the remainder shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering”? It is <b>derived from there: “And the priest shall effect atonement for the soul that sins unwittingly, when he sins unwittingly”</b> (Numbers 15:28). The term “for the soul that sins unwittingly” <b>teaches that the priest</b> may <b>effect atonement</b> even <b>through himself,</b> when he performs the rite.
The Gemara answers: <b>If</b> the <i>halakha</i> were derived <b>from that</b> latter verse, <b>I would say: This statement,</b> permitting him to effect his own atonement, applies when the offering is brought <b>for</b> a sin committed <b>unwittingly. But</b> with regard to an offering brought <b>for</b> a sin committed <b>intentionally,</b> the priest may <b>not</b> effect his own atonement. Therefore, the verse that states: “And the remainder shall be the priest’s, as the meal offering,” <b>teaches us</b> that the priest may perform the rite even for an offering that he brings for an intentional sin.
The Gemara clarifies: With regard to an offering brought <b>for</b> a sin committed <b>intentionally, how can you find these</b> circumstances? The Gemara answers: You can find them <b>in</b> the instance of a meal offering brought as atonement for <b>intentionally</b> taking a false <b>oath</b> of testimony that he was not aware of a certain incident involving another individual. The priest may perform the rites for a meal offering that he brings to atone for such a sin.
§ With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon that a handful of the meal offering of a sinner brought by a priest is separated and offered upon the altar, it <b>is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> With regard to <b>the meal offering of a sinner</b> brought <b>by</b> one of <b>the priests, a handful is removed; and the handful is sacrificed by itself, and the remainder is sacrificed by itself. Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, says: The handful is sacrificed by itself, and the remainder is scattered upon the place of the ashes.</b>
With regard to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan discusses it</b> and asks: <b>To which place of the ashes</b> in the Temple is he referring? <b>If</b> he is referring to the one <b>that is above,</b> upon the altar, his opinion <b>is</b> identical to that of <b>his father,</b> Rabbi Shimon, who stated that the remainder is offered and burned upon the altar, after which the ashes are swept onto the ash heap upon the altar. If so, according to both opinions, the remainder is taken to the same place. And <b>if</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, is referring <b>to</b> the ash heap <b>that is below</b> the altar, that is difficult: Do <b>you have</b> any <b>item that is sacrificed below</b> the altar?
<b>Rabbi Abba said to</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Abba: <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, means that the remainder is scattered there <b>to be wasted.</b> When the Sages heard this, <b>they laughed at him,</b> saying: <b>But</b> do <b>you have</b> any <b>item that is sacrificed</b> as part of the Temple service in order <b>to be wasted?</b>
The Gemara answers that there are consecrated items that are intentionally wasted. With regard to such items, <b>the father of Rabbi Avin teaches: “And every meal offering of the priest shall be offered in its entirety; it shall not be eaten”</b> (Leviticus 6:16). Why must this verse, which follows those discussing the High Priest’s daily griddle-cake offering, state that it shall not be eaten, after it already states that it is entirely offered? The verse teaches: <b>I have likened</b> the meal offering of a sinner brought by a priest to the daily griddle-cake offering brought by the High Priest <b>with regard to eating,</b> insofar as it is not eaten, <b>but</b> I have <b>not</b> likened it <b>with regard to another matter,</b> i.e., that the meal offering of a sinner is not burned in the manner of the griddle-cake offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is he saying,</b> as the verse states explicitly that it must be entirely offered? <b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this is what</b> he <b>is saying:</b> This is how the verse is to be read: <b>“Every meal offering of the priest…shall not be eaten,”</b> when the offering is sacrificed to fulfill <b>his obligation,</b> such as the meal offering of a sinner. It is neither eaten nor completely burned, but rather placed on the ash heap. When the verse states: <b>“Shall be offered in its entirety,”</b> this is referring to <b>his gift</b> offering, which is completely burned in the manner of a griddle-cake offering. <b>Rava said to him:</b> This reading is like a <b>sharp knife cutting the verses</b> to pieces, as it interprets the beginning and end of the verse together, ignoring the middle.
<b>Rather, Rava says:</b> When the verse states: <b>“Every meal offering of the priest shall be offered in its entirety,”</b> this is referring to <b>his gift</b> offering, which is entirely offered. When the verse states that it <b>“shall not be eaten,”</b> this is referring to <b>his obligatory</b> meal offering, which is neither eaten nor entirely offered.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why should the verse be read that way? <b>I</b> can <b>reverse</b> the interpretation and say that the priest’s obligatory meal offering is entirely offered, and his gift offering shall be neither eaten nor entirely offered. The Gemara answers: It <b>stands to reason</b> that <b>his gift offering should be included</b> in the phrase “shall be offered in its entirety,” <b>as</b> it resembles the griddle-cake offering and differs from the meal offering of a sinner in several respects, namely, <b>that</b> it is <b>frequent,</b> that the priest bringing it <b>did not sin,</b> and that <b>its scent is fragrant,</b> as it is mixed with oil, and frankincense is added to it.
The Gemara asks: <b>On the contrary,</b> the verse <b>should</b> be interpreted <b>to include his obligatory</b> meal offering, <b>as</b> the obligatory meal offering is similar to the griddle-cake offering in that, unlike the gift offering, it comprises <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah and bringing it is <b>an obligation.</b> The Gemara responds: Because <b>these</b> similarities between the gift offering and the griddle-cake offering <b>are</b> more <b>numerous</b> than those between the obligatory offering and the griddle-cake offering, it is logical that the verse is comparing the gift offering to the griddle-cake offering.
§ After discussing the opinions of Rabbi Shimon and Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, the Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for the opinion of <b>the Rabbis</b> that no handful is removed from any of the meal offerings of the priests, with regard to <b>this</b> verse: <b>“And every meal offering of the priest shall be offered in its entirety; it shall not be eaten,” what do they do with it?</b> How do they interpret the superfluous phrase: “It shall not be eaten”?
The Gemara answers: <b>They require it for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Concerning the griddle-cake offering, the verse states: “It shall be entirely smoked for the Lord” (Leviticus 6:15). From this verse and the verse that follows it, which states: “And every meal offering of the priest shall be offered in its entirety; it shall not be eaten,” <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the griddle-cake offering mentioned <b>above,</b> in the first verse, is subject <b>to: “It shall be entirely smoked,” and</b> that other meal offerings of priests mentioned <b>below,</b> in the second verse, are subject <b>to: “It shall not be eaten.”</b>
<b>From where</b> is it derived <b>to apply</b> the prohibition <b>that was said about this</b> case <b>to that</b> case, <b>and</b> the prohibition <b>that was said about that</b> case <b>to this</b> case, to teach that the priests’ meal offerings shall be entirely smoked and the griddle-cake offering shall not be eaten? <b>The verse states: “Entirely,”</b> in the first verse, and: <b>“Entirely,”</b> in the second, to be utilized <b>as a verbal analogy: It is stated here,</b> with regard to the priests’ meal offerings: <b>“Entirely,” and it is stated there,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering: <b>“Entirely.”</b>
<b>Just as there,</b> the offering is subject <b>to</b> the prohibition of: <b>“It shall be entirely smoked,” so too here,</b> the offerings are subject <b>to</b> the prohibition of: <b>“It shall be entirely smoked.” And just as here,</b> with regard to the meal offering of the priest, the verse serves <b>to impose a prohibition upon eating it, so too there,</b> with regard to the griddle-cake offering, the verse serves <b>to impose a prohibition upon eating it.</b>
§ With regard to the prohibition against eating from certain offerings derived from the verse that states: “Shall be offered in its entirety; it shall not be eaten,” <b>Ravina asks:</b> In the case of <b>a priest who ate from the sacrificial portions, what is</b> the <i>halakha</i>? As to whether this priest violates <b>the prohibition of a non-priest</b> eating certain types of sacrificial meat, expressed in the verse: “No non-priest shall eat of the sacrificial meat” (Leviticus 22:10),

Daf 74b

<b>I do not raise the dilemma. When I raise the dilemma,</b> it is with regard to the <b>prohibition of: “Shall be offered in its entirety;</b> it shall not be eaten.” <b>What</b> is the <i>halakha</i>? Is this prohibition applicable only to the meal offering of a priest mentioned in the verse, or does it apply to a priest who eats from the sacrificial portions as well?
<b>Rav Aharon said to Ravina: Come</b> and <b>hear</b> an answer to this question from that <b>which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> With regard to <b>every</b> sacrificial item, not just the meal offering of a priest, such as the sacrificial portions, <b>which is</b> included <b>in</b> the category of <b>“shall be offered in its entirety”</b> that requires it to be burned, the verse serves <b>to impose a prohibition against eating it.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The meal offering of priests, the meal offering of the anointed priest,</b> i.e., the High Priest, <b>and the meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations</b> that accompany burnt offerings and peace offerings are burned in their entirety <b>on the altar, and there is no</b> part <b>of them for the priests. And in</b> the case of those offerings, <b>the power of the altar is greater than the power of the priests. The two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering on Shavuot of two loaves baked from new wheat, <b>and the shewbread,</b> i.e., the twelve loaves that were placed on the sacred Table in the Sanctuary each Shabbat, <b>are eaten by the priests, and there is no part of them</b> burned <b>on the altar. And in</b> the case of those offerings, <b>the power of the priests is greater than the power of the altar.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>And are there no additional</b> cases of sacrificial items that are completely placed on the altar, with none of their parts given to the priests? <b>But isn’t there the burnt offering,</b> which is completely burned on the altar? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> the burnt offering’s <b>hide,</b> which is given <b>to the priests.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there the bird</b> sacrificed as <b>a burnt offering,</b> whose skin is not given to the priests? The Gemara answers: <b>There is</b> the bird burnt offering’s <b>crop and its feathers,</b> which are not burned upon the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there</b> wine <b>libations,</b> which are completely poured onto the altar? The Gemara answers: The libations <b>go to the drainpipes,</b> and pouring the wine into the drainpipes is not considered placing it upon the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is meant when the mishna emphasizes: <b>And in</b> the case of those offerings, the power of the altar is greater than the power of the priests, indicating that there are other items that one might have thought are burned entirely on the altar as well? The Gemara answers: The mishna’s wording serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of Shmuel, as Shmuel said: One who donates wine brings it and pours it over the fires</b> of the altar, such that it is offered in the manner of an animal offering and not as a libation. Therefore, the mishna’s wording <b>teaches us that</b> wine donated in this manner <b>goes to the drainpipes,</b> unlike according to the opinion of Shmuel that it is entirely burned.
The Gemara adds: With regard to another ruling, the mishna <b>supports</b> a different statement <b>of Shmuel. As Shmuel said: One who donates oil</b> to the Temple <b>removes a handful</b> and sacrifices it on the altar, <b>and its remainder is eaten</b> by the priests. Shmuel’s ruling is in accordance with the mishna, which does not list a donation of oil as one of the offerings given completely to the altar.
§ According to the mishna, with regard to <b>the two loaves and the shewbread,</b> the power of the priests is greater than the power of the altar. The Gemara asks: <b>And are there no more</b> cases of sacrificial items that are given completely to the priests, with none of their parts placed upon the altar? <b>But isn’t there the bird</b> sacrificed as a <b>sin offering,</b> which is eaten entirely by the priests, and none of it is placed upon the altar? The Gemara answers: <b>There is its blood,</b> which is sprinkled upon the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the <b><i>log</i> of oil of a leper</b> that he brings on the day that he becomes ritually clean, which is given completely to the priests? The Gemara answers: It is not given completely to the priests, as <b>there are its placements,</b> when oil is sprinkled seven times “before the Lord” (Leviticus 14:16), and applied to the leper’s right ear, thumb, and big toe (see Leviticus 14:17).
The Gemara asks: <b>And what</b> is meant when the mishna emphasizes: <b>And in</b> the case of those offerings, the power of the priests is greater than the power of the altar? The Gemara answers: This wording serves <b>to exclude</b> the opinion <b>of the one who says: The two loaves that are brought by themselves,</b> unaccompanied by the requisite two lambs, may not be offered, and instead of being eaten <b>they go to be burned.</b> By emphasizing that the two loaves and the shewbread are eaten by the priests and not placed on the altar, the mishna <b>teaches us that in this</b> case, <b>the power of the priests is always greater,</b> even if the two lambs are not offered with the two loaves.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the meal offerings that are prepared in a vessel,</b> e.g., the offerings prepared in a pan or deep pan, <b>require three placements of oil,</b> listed here in the reverse order of their placement: <b>Pouring</b> oil on the cakes after they have been cooked, <b>and mixing</b> oil into the flour, <b>and placement of oil into the vessel prior to preparation</b> of the meal offerings.
In the meal offerings that come as loaves, it is after the flour has been baked into <b>loaves</b> that one breaks them into pieces and <b>mixes them</b> with oil; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> It is with <b>fine flour</b> that one mixes the oil. Although <b>the loaves</b> of the meal offering baked in an oven <b>require mixing</b> of their flour with oil, <b>wafers</b> do not require mixing, but rather a <b>smearing</b> of oil on them after baking. <b>How does one smear</b> oil on <b>them?</b> He does so in a shape <b>similar</b> to the Greek letter <b>chi,</b> Χ, <b>and the rest</b> of the oil remaining after smearing is <b>eaten by priests.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the statement of the mishna that all the meal offerings prepared in a vessel require three placements of oil, the Gemara asks: <b>To exclude what</b> does the mishna specify: Meal offerings prepared in a vessel? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The mishna serves <b>to exclude</b> the oven-<b>baked meal offering,</b> whose preparation does not require the use of a service vessel, as it is merely baked in an oven. Such a meal offering does not require the pouring of the oil.
With regard to the three placements of oil in a pan meal offering and a deep-pan meal offering, <b>the Sages taught</b> that the verse states: <b>“And if your offering is a deep-pan meal offering, it shall be made of fine flour in oil”</b> (Leviticus 2:7). This <b>teaches that it requires</b> the <b>placement of oil in</b> an empty <b>vessel,</b> and the flour is added afterward. In addition, the term <b>“your offering”</b> in this verse and the term <b>“your offering”</b> (Leviticus 2:5), written with regard to the meal offering prepared in a pan, are understood <b>to</b> teach <b>a verbal analogy:</b>

Daf 75a

<b>Just as here,</b> with regard to the deep-pan meal offering, the <b>placement of oil in</b> an empty <b>utensil</b> is required, to which the flour is added only afterward, <b>so too there,</b> with regard to the meal offering prepared in a shallow pan, the <b>placement of oil in</b> an empty <b>utensil</b> is required. <b>And just as there,</b> with regard to the meal offering prepared in a shallow pan, <b>pouring and mixing</b> are required, as the verse states: “Mixed with oil…and pour oil upon it” (Leviticus 2:5–6), <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the deep-pan meal offering, <b>pouring and mixing</b> are required.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to meal offerings that come as loaves, i.e., those prepared in a shallow pan or deep pan or those baked in an oven, it is after the flour has been baked into <b>loaves</b> that one breaks them into pieces and <b>mixes them</b> with oil; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> It is with <b>fine flour,</b> before the baking, that one mixes the oil.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to the meal offering prepared in a shallow pan, the verse states: “It shall be of <b>fine flour</b> unleavened, <b>mixed</b> with oil.” This <b>teaches that it is mixed</b> while still <b>flour. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> It is after the flour has been baked into <b>loaves</b> that he <b>mixes them, as it is stated:</b> “And when you bring a meal offering baked in the oven, it shall be unleavened <b>loaves</b> of fine flour <b>mixed</b> with oil” (Leviticus 2:4). The Rabbis <b>said to him: But is it not with regard to loaves of a thanks offering</b> that <b>it is stated:</b> “Unleavened <b>loaves</b> mixed with oil…and loaves mixed with oil, of fine flour soaked” (Leviticus 7:12), <b>and it is not possible to mix them when they are loaves,</b> but <b>only</b> when they are <b>fine flour?</b>
The Gemara explains the procedure of mixing the oven-baked meal offerings according to the Rabbis. <b>How does</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the rite? He <b>places oil in a utensil before</b> the placement of the flour <b>is done, and</b> then he <b>places</b> the flour into the utensil. <b>And he</b> then <b>places oil upon it and mixes it, and kneads it</b> in lukewarm water, <b>and bakes it</b> in a shallow pan or a deep pan, in accordance with his vow. <b>And</b> then <b>he breaks it</b> into pieces, <b>and he</b> again <b>places oil upon</b> the pieces, which constitutes the required pouring, <b>and</b> he <b>removes a handful</b> for the altar.
<b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> After the meal offerings have been baked into <b>loaves,</b> one breaks them into pieces and <b>mixes them</b> with oil, <b>as it is stated: “Loaves</b> of fine flour <b>mixed with oil.” How does</b> the priest <b>perform</b> the rite? He <b>places oil in a utensil before</b> the placement of the flour <b>is done, and</b> then he <b>places</b> the flour into the utensil. <b>And</b> then <b>he kneads it</b> in lukewarm water, <b>and bakes it</b> in a shallow pan or deep pan, <b>and breaks</b> the loaves into pieces, <b>and places oil upon the</b> pieces <b>and mixes</b> them, <b>and again places oil upon</b> the pieces, which constitutes the pouring of the oil, <b>and removes a handful</b> to be burned on the altar.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the difficulty that <b>it is not possible</b> to mix them when they are loaves, <b>which the Rabbis said to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>what</b> is <b>it</b> that makes it impossible? The Gemara answers that <b>Rabbi Shmuel bar Rav Yitzḥak says:</b> Since only <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of oil is</b> used, <b>how could it be divided among a number of loaves?</b> As this is not sufficient oil to mix with baked offerings, it must be that the oil is mixed with the unbaked flour.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>The loaves</b> of the meal offering baked in an oven <b>require mixing</b> of their flour with oil, <b>and wafers</b> require only <b>smearing. The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse specifies with regard to the oven-baked meal offering: “And when you bring a meal offering baked in the oven, it shall be unleavened <b>loaves</b> of fine flour <b>mixed</b> with oil” (Leviticus 2:4). This indicates that only the loaves are mixed, <b>but the wafers are not mixed.</b> This derivation is necessary, as one <b>might</b> have thought: Could the opposite conclusion <b>not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference? And if loaves, which do not require smearing,</b> do <b>require mixing,</b> then <b>is it not logical</b> that <b>wafers, which require smearing,</b> also <b>require mixing?</b> To counter this inference, <b>the verse states: “Loaves</b> of fine flour <b>mixed,” but wafers are not mixed.</b>
With regard to wafers, the same verse teaches that <b>wafers are smeared</b> with oil, <b>but loaves are not smeared.</b> This derivation is necessary, <b>as</b> one <b>might</b> have thought: Could the opposite conclusion <b>not</b> be derived through <b>logical inference,</b> namely: <b>And if wafers, which do not require mixing,</b> do <b>require smearing,</b> then <b>is it not logical</b> that <b>loaves, which require mixing,</b> also <b>require smearing?</b> To counter this inference, <b>the verse states</b> that <b>wafers are smeared</b> with oil, <b>but loaves are not smeared.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation?</b> Why are the terms “mixed” and “smeared” not interpreted to be referring to both varieties of oven-baked meal offerings? The Gemara answers: <b>Rava said:</b> If this were the intention, then the Torah <b>should not omit</b> this description completely, <b>and let it write</b> in some other verse: <b>Smeared loaves and mixed wafers.</b> The fact that the Torah never describes the loaves as smeared and wafers as mixed indicates that loaves are not smeared and wafers are not mixed.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>How does one smear</b> oil on <b>them?</b> He does so in a shape <b>similar</b> to <b>chi, and the rest</b> of the oil <b>is eaten</b> by priests. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Similar</b> to <b>chi? Rav Kahana said:</b> It is smeared in a shape <b>similar</b> to the <b>Greek</b> letter <b>chi,</b> Χ.
§ Concerning the mixing of oil into the loaves and the smearing of oil upon the wafers, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: An oven-baked <b>meal offering that comes as half loaves and half wafers,</b> i.e., five of each, may be brought according to the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, who does not require ten items of a uniform type. How is the oil applied to this offering? According to one opinion, he <b>brings a <i>log</i> of oil,</b> which is the requisite quantity to accompany a tenth of an ephah of flour, <b>and divides it into two</b> parts. <b>Half of</b> the oil is used <b>for</b> the <b>loaves, and half of</b> the oil is used <b>for</b> the <b>wafers.</b>
As for <b>the loaves,</b> he <b>mixes them</b> with the oil, <b>and</b> as for <b>the wafers,</b> he <b>smears</b> them. <b>And</b> he <b>smears</b> the oil on <b>the wafer over the entire surface,</b> not in the shape of the letter chi, <b>and he returns the rest of the oil to</b> mix into <b>the loaves. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> He <b>smears them</b> in a shape <b>similar</b> to the letter <b>chi, and the rest</b> of the oil <b>is eaten by the priests.</b>
<b>It is taught</b> in <b>another</b> <i>baraita</i>: In the case of ten <b>wafers that come by themselves</b> as a meal offering baked in the oven, and not as part of another offering, he <b>brings a <i>log</i> of oil and smears them, and he again smears them</b> repeatedly <b>until all the oil in the <i>log</i> is finished. Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon:</b> He <b>smears them</b> in a shape <b>similar</b> to the letter <b>chi, and the rest of the oil is eaten by the priests.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the meal offerings that are prepared in a vessel require breaking</b> into pieces.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>To exclude what</b> does the mishna state that this <i>halakha</i> applies specifically to meal offerings prepared in vessels? <b>Rav Pappa said:</b> The mishna serves <b>to exclude the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering on Shavuot of two loaves baked from new wheat, <b>and the shewbread,</b> the twelve loaves that were placed on the Table in the Sanctuary each Shabbat. Since these are baked in an oven and not prepared in vessels, they do not require breaking into pieces.
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the verse discussing a meal offering prepared in a pan states: <b>“You shall break it in pieces,</b> and pour oil upon it; it is <b>a meal offering”</b> (Leviticus 2:6). The fact that the verse concludes with the phrase: “It is a meal offering,” indicates that the Torah means <b>to include all the meal offerings</b> in the requirement <b>of breaking</b> into pieces. One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even the two loaves and the shewbread.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “You shall break <b>it</b> in pieces”; i.e., the meal offering baked in a pan, but not the two loaves and the shewbread.
The <i>baraita</i> continues that the same verse states: <b>“And you shall pour oil</b> upon it; it is <b>a meal offering.”</b> The fact that the verse concludes with the phrase “It is a meal offering” indicates that the Torah means <b>to include all the meal offerings</b> in the requirement <b>of pouring.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even the</b> oven-<b>baked meal offering.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall pour <b>oil upon it,”</b> i.e., upon this meal offering, but not upon the oven-baked meal offering.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: Perhaps <b>I should exclude</b> only <b>the loaves</b> from the requirement of pouring, <b>but I should not exclude the wafers.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “It</b> is a meal offering,” indicating that wafers are also excluded. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation,</b> by which the term “it” excludes wafers specifically? Perhaps <b>I will say:</b> The term serves <b>to exclude the meal offering of priests</b> from the requirement of pouring.

Daf 75b

<b>Rabba says:</b> This is the reason that wafers are also excluded from the mitzva of pouring, while a meal offering brought by a priest is not excluded: The verse uses two expressions of exclusion: “Upon it,” and: “It is a meal offering.” <b>What is the matter that requires two exclusions? You must say: It is the</b> oven-<b>baked meal offering,</b> of which there are two types of offerings: Wafers and loaves.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In breaking <b>the meal offering of an Israelite</b> into pieces, the priest <b>folds [<i>kofel</i>] one</b> into two <b>and two into four and separates</b> it at the folds. In breaking into pieces <b>the meal offering of priests,</b> the priest <b>folds one into two and two into four and does not separate</b> it at the folds. Because no handful is removed, separation is unnecessary. In the case of the griddle-cake <b>meal offering of the anointed priest, he would not fold it. Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In neither <b>the meal offering of priests nor the meal offering of the anointed priest is there breaking</b> into pieces, <b>because in</b> those meal offerings <b>there is no removal of a handful. And any</b> meal offering <b>in which there is no removal of a handful there is no breaking</b> into pieces. <b>And</b> in <b>all</b> meal offerings that are broken into pieces, the priest <b>breaks them</b> into <b>olive-bulk-</b>sized pieces.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the difference between the meal offering of an Israelite and that of a priest detailed in the mishna, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“You shall break</b> it in pieces” (Leviticus 2:6). One <b>might</b> have thought that it should be broken <b>into</b> only <b>two</b> pieces. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Break it in <b>pieces,”</b> indicating that each of these two pieces is subsequently broken into more pieces. <b>If</b> the Torah requires <b>pieces,</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>he should</b> repeatedly break it into pieces until he <b>renders it</b> into <b>crumbs.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “Break <b>it,”</b> i.e., break <b>it in pieces, and</b> do <b>not</b> break <b>its pieces into</b> additional <b>pieces.</b>
<b>How so?</b> In the case of <b>the meal offering of an Israelite,</b> the priest <b>folds one into two and two into four and separates</b> the pieces. In breaking into pieces <b>the meal offering of priests and</b> the <b>anointed priest,</b> the priest <b>folds it</b> into two, as it is stated: “In broken pieces you shall sacrifice the offering” (Leviticus 6:14). The Gemara asks: With regard to the meal offering of the anointed priest, <b>didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna: <b>He would not fold it? Rabba says:</b> He <b>does not fold it into four,</b> as it does not use the doubled phrase: “You shall break it in pieces [<i>patot otah pitim</i>],” <b>but</b> he does <b>fold it into two.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> In neither <b>the meal offering of priests nor the meal offering of the anointed priest is there breaking</b> into pieces…and in all meal offerings that are broken into pieces, one breaks them into olive-bulk pieces. <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> Over <b>this cooked dish, which contains pieces</b> of bread that are the size of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> before eating it <b>one recites upon it</b> the blessing of: <b>Who brings forth bread from the earth.</b> Over that same cooked dish, <b>if it does not contain pieces</b> of bread that are the size of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> before eating it <b>one recites upon it</b> the blessing of: <b>Who creates the various kinds of nourishment.</b>
<b>Rav Yosef said: From where do I say this</b> <i>halakha</i>? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The first time an Israelite <b>would stand and</b> instruct a priest to <b>sacrifice meal offerings in Jerusalem</b> on his behalf, he would <b>recite: Blessed</b> are You, Lord our God, King of the universe, <b>Who has given us life and sustained us</b> and brought us to this time, as it is the first time that the Israelite fulfills the mitzva of bringing that offering. Following the removal of the handful, when the priest <b>would take</b> the meal offerings in order <b>to eat them, he would</b> first <b>recite</b> the blessing of: <b>Who brings forth bread from the earth. And we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>And</b> in <b>all</b> meal offerings that are broken into pieces, the priest breaks them into <b>pieces</b> the size <b>of an olive-bulk.</b> This proves that over pieces of bread that are the volume of an olive-bulk, one recites the blessing of: Who brings forth bread from the earth.
<b>Abaye said to</b> Rav Yosef: <b>But according to the <i>tanna</i> of the school of Rabbi Yishmael, who said</b> with regard to meal offerings: <b>He crushes them</b> continuously <b>until he restores them to</b> the form they had when <b>they</b> were <b>flour,</b> would you say <b>that so too,</b> in that case, one who eats a meal offering so prepared <b>does not recite</b> the blessing of: <b>Who brings forth</b> bread from the earth?
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>indeed,</b> one does not recite that blessing over these meal offerings, that is difficult: <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: With regard to <b>one who gathered</b> a portion the volume of <b>an olive-bulk from all of</b> the crumbs of the meal offerings <b>and ate it, if it was</b> an offering of <b>leavened bread</b> like that of a thanks offering, and he ate it on Passover, his act is <b>punishable by <i>karet</i>. If</b> it <b>was</b> an offering <b>of unleavened bread, a person fulfills his obligation</b> to eat <i>matza</i> <b>on Passover through</b> the consumption of those pieces. This indicates that pieces of bread, regardless of their volume, are always considered bread.
Rav Yosef answered him that this is not the <i>halakha</i>, and one does not recite a blessing over crumbs of bread as he would over actual bread. Rather, <b>what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> one kneaded the crumbs of bread together and <b>pressed them [<i>beshe’eirsan</i>]</b> into a single mass.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>If so, that which is taught about</b> the ruling in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>And this is</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>when he ate</b> all of the crumbs that constitute the volume of an olive-bulk <b>in</b> the time it takes <b>to eat a half-loaf [<i>peras</i>]</b> of bread, is difficult. As, <b>if</b> it is a case <b>where he pressed them</b> into a single mass, the <i>baraita</i> <b>should have</b> taught: <b>When he ate it,</b> in the singular, as it is a single item. <b>Rather, what are we dealing with here?</b> We are dealing with a case <b>where</b> the crumbs <b>came from a large</b> loaf of <b>bread.</b> Although the crumbs themselves are each smaller than an olive-bulk, since they were broken from a large loaf, they are considered significant.
The Gemara asks: With regard to the blessing recited on the cooked dish with pieces less than an olive-bulk in volume, <b>what</b> halakhic conclusion <b>was</b> reached <b>about it? Rav Sheshet says: Even</b> when eating <b>pieces</b> of bread <b>that do not have</b> the volume of <b>an olive-bulk,</b> one recites the blessing of: Who brings forth bread from the earth. <b>Rava said: And</b> this <b>is</b> limited to a case <b>where</b> the crumbs still <b>have the appearance [<i>torita</i>] of bread,</b> and they did not dissolve completely.

Daf 76a

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All the meal offerings require rubbing three hundred</b> times <b>and striking five hundred</b> times with one’s fist or palm. <b>Rubbing and striking</b> are performed <b>on the wheat</b> kernels to remove their husks prior to grinding them into flour. <b>And Rabbi Yosei says:</b> They are performed <b>on the dough</b> to ensure a smooth product. <b>All of the meal offerings come</b> as <b>ten</b> loaves or <b>ten</b> wafers from each one tenth of an ephah of flour, <b>except for the shewbread and the griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of the High Priest, which come</b> as <b>twelve</b> loaves or wafers; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda. Rabbi Meir says: They all come</b> as <b>twelve</b> loaves <b>except for</b> the four types of <b>loaves</b> that accompany <b>the thanks offering and</b> the two types of loaves that accompany the peace offering of <b>naziriteship, which come</b> as <b>ten each.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> A <i>tanna</i> <b>taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that the rubbing and striking are done in the following manner: He <b>rubs once</b> and <b>strikes twice.</b> Then he <b>rubs twice</b> and <b>strikes three</b> times. This sequence is repeated one hundred times, so that he rubs three hundred times and strikes five hundred times. <b>Rabbi Yirmeya raises a dilemma</b> with regard to the rubbing: Is the rubbing of the hand <b>back and forth</b> over the surface of the item considered <b>one</b> rubbing, <b>or</b> is <b>perhaps</b> rubbing <b>back and forth</b> considered <b>two</b> distinct rubbings? <b>What</b> is the correct count? The Gemara states: The dilemma <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Rubbing and striking</b> are performed <b>on the wheat</b> kernels, while <b>Rabbi Yosei says:</b> They are performed <b>on the dough.</b> The Gemara comments: <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: Does Rabbi Yosei mean that these actions are performed <b>on the dough and not on the wheat</b> kernels? <b>Or perhaps</b> he means that they are performed not only on the kernels but <b>also on the dough.</b> The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution, <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rubbing and striking</b> are performed <b>on the wheat</b> kernels. <b>Rabbi Yosei says: Rubbing and striking</b> are performed <b>on the dough.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that according to the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda, <b>all of the meal offerings come</b> as ten loaves or wafers, except for the shewbread and the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest, which come as <b>twelve</b> loaves or wafers. The Gemara examines the sources for these exceptions: With regard to <b>the shewbread, it is written explicitly of it:</b> “And you shall take fine flour and bake twelve cakes of it” (Leviticus 24:5).
That the <b>griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of the High Priest</b> is also offered as twelve units is <b>derived from</b> a verbal analogy of the word “obligation,” written in the context of the verse discussing the <b>shewbread.</b> With regard to the griddle-cake offering, the verse states: “And the anointed priest…shall offer it; it is an <b>obligation</b> forever” (Leviticus 6:15), and the verse states with regard to the twelve loaves of the shewbread: “And it shall be for Aaron and his sons…a perpetual <b>obligation”</b> (Leviticus 24:9).
§ The Gemara asks: According to Rabbi Yehuda, who states in the mishna with regard to <b>all the meal offerings that they come</b> as <b>ten</b> loaves or <b>ten</b> wafers, <b>from where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers that he <b>derives</b> it <b>from the loaves of the thanks offering. Just as there,</b> there are <b>ten</b> loaves, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to all other meal offerings, there are <b>ten</b> loaves. The Gemara challenges: <b>But let him derive it from the shewbread: Just as there,</b> there are <b>twelve</b> loaves, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to all other meal offerings, there must be <b>twelve.</b>
The Gemara explains: It <b>stands to reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the other meal offerings <b>from the loaves of the thanks offering, as</b> the other meal offerings resemble the loaves of the thanks offering and differ from the shewbread in several respects: They are offered by <b>an individual</b> and not by the public; they are brought by <b>one who donates</b> and not as obligatory offerings; <b>oil</b> is used in their preparation; they are <b>disqualified</b> when left overnight, whereas, by contrast, the rite of the shewbread demands that it be left on the Table for eight days; they are <b>not</b> brought <b>on the Sabbath,</b> unlike the shewbread, whose rite is performed on the Sabbath; <b>and</b> they are <b>not</b> brought <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> unlike the shewbread, which is brought even in a state of impurity.
The Gemara responds: <b>On the contrary,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>should derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the other meal offerings <b>from the shewbread, as</b> they resemble the shewbread in several respects: They are <b>consecrated</b> property of the most sacred order, whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are of lesser sanctity; <b>and</b> they are brought with <b>frankincense,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are not; they are brought only as <b>unleavened bread,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering include some leavened bread; <b>and</b> each is brought as an offering by <b>itself,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are brought together with an animal sacrifice.
The Gemara explains: <b>These</b> analogies between other meal offerings and the loaves of the thanks offering <b>are</b> more <b>numerous</b> than the analogies between other meal offerings and the shewbread. Therefore, the <i>halakha</i> of other meal offerings is derived from the loaves of the thanks offering.
The Gemara posited previously that according to Rabbi Yehuda, a verbal analogy teaches that, like the shewbread, the griddle-cake offering of the High Priest is brought as twelve units. The Gemara asks: <b>And if we hold</b> that <b>a matter learned through a verbal analogy may subsequently teach as a paradigm, let us derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the other meal offerings <b>from the griddle-cake</b> offering <b>of the High Priest: Just as there,</b> the meal <b>offering</b> comprises <b>twelve</b> units, <b>so too here,</b> other meal offerings should consist of <b>twelve</b> units.
The Gemara responds: It <b>stands to reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda <b>should derive</b> their <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the loaves of the thanks offering, as</b> the other meal offerings resemble the loaves of the thanks offering and differ from the griddle-cake offering in several respects: They are brought by <b>an ordinary</b> person and not by the High Priest; they are brought by <b>one who donates</b> and not as obligatory offerings; and they are only brought whole, while the High Priest’s griddle-cake offering is brought in <b>halves,</b> half in the morning and half in the afternoon.
In addition, they are disqualified <b>as <i>piggul</i>,</b> i.e., when they are sacrificed with the intent to be consumed after their appointed time, unlike the griddle-cake offering, which is not eaten at all; they are <b>not</b> brought <b>on the Sabbath,</b> unlike the griddle-cake offering; <b>and</b> they are <b>not</b> brought <b>in</b> a state of <b>ritual impurity,</b> whereas the griddle-cake offering is brought by the High Priest even while impure.
The Gemara challenges: <b>On the contrary,</b> Rabbi Yehuda <b>should have derived</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the other meal offerings <b>from the High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, <b>as</b> the other meal offerings resemble the griddle-cake offering in several respects: They both contain <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of fine flour, whereas the loaves of the thanks offering contain several tenths of an ephah; they are consecrated when placed in a service <b>vessel,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are consecrated when the thanks offering is slaughtered; they are <b>consecrated</b> property of the most sacred order, whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are of lesser sanctity; <b>and</b> they are brought with <b>frankincense,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are not.
In addition, they are brought only of <b>unleavened bread,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering include some leavened bread; <b>and</b> each is brought as an offering <b>itself,</b> whereas the loaves of the thanks offering are brought together with an animal sacrifice; part of their rite is <b>bringing</b> them <b>near</b> the southwest corner of the altar, unlike the loaves of the thanks offering; <b>and</b> parts or all of them are placed on <b>the fires of the altar,</b> unlike the loaves of the thanks offering. The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> indeed, <b>these</b> similarities between other meal offerings and the griddle-cake offering <b>are</b> more <b>numerous</b> than the similarities between other meal offerings and the loaves of the thanks offering. Therefore, it seems more appropriate to derive the number of loaves from the griddle-cake offering.
The Gemara answers: Nevertheless, Rabbi Yehuda <b>prefers</b> to learn the <i>halakha</i> of the other meal offerings, which are brought by <b>an ordinary</b> person, <b>from</b> the loaves of the thanks offering, which are brought by <b>an ordinary</b> person.
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Meir says: They all come</b> as <b>twelve</b> loaves. The Gemara explains: <b>What does</b> he <b>hold? If he holds that a matter learned through a verbal analogy</b> is <b>subsequently</b> used to <b>teach as a paradigm,</b> he <b>derives</b> the number of loaves in other meal offerings <b>from the High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, which was itself derived from a verbal analogy, <b>as these</b> similarities between other meal offerings and the griddle-cake offering enumerated above <b>are</b> more <b>numerous.</b>
And <b>if he holds that a matter learned through a verbal analogy is not subsequently</b> used to <b>teach as a paradigm,</b> then he <b>derives</b> the number of loaves in other meal offerings <b>from</b> the twelve loaves of <b>the shewbread.</b> This is because Rabbi Meir <b>prefers</b> to derive the status of the other meal offerings, which are <b>consecrated</b> property of the highest order, <b>from</b> the shewbread, which is also <b>consecrated</b> property of the highest order, in contrast to the loaves of the thanks offering, which are of lesser sanctity.
§ The mishna teaches that Rabbi Meir says: They all come as twelve loaves <b>except for</b> the <b>loaves</b> of the <b>thanks offering and</b> the loaves that accompany the guilt offering of <b>naziriteship, which come</b> as <b>ten each.</b> The Gemara explains the exceptions: With regard to <b>the loaves of the thanks offering, it is written explicitly of them</b> that these loaves are brought in units of ten, based on a verbal analogy: With regard to the thanks offering, the verse states: “And of it he shall present one out of each offering for a gift [<i>teruma</i>] to the Lord” (Leviticus 7:14), and with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe it is stated: “You shall set apart of it a gift [<i>teruma</i>] for the Lord, a tithe of the tithe” (Numbers 18:26). Just as the <i>teruma</i> of the tithe consists of one portion of ten, so too, the loaves of the thanks offering are brought in units of ten (see 77b).
That ten loaves accompany the guilt offering of <b>naziriteship</b> is derived from a verse, <b>as the Master says:</b> The verse describing the thanks offering states: “With cakes of leavened bread he shall present his offering with the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanksgiving” (Leviticus 7:13). The term <b>“his peace offerings”</b> serves <b>to include</b> the loaves of the <b>peace offering of the nazirite.</b> Just as each of the four varieties of loaves accompanying the thanks offering are brought in units of ten loaves, so too, the peace offering of the nazirite comprises ten loaves.
§ The loaves of the thanks offering consist of ten of each of the following four types: Leavened loaves, unleavened wafers, standard unleavened loaves, and unleavened loaves made from flour mixed with water and oil. With regard to these loaves, <b>Rav Tovi bar Kisna says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> In the case of <b>loaves of</b> the <b>thanks offering that one baked as</b> only <b>four loaves,</b> one of each of the four types, where each loaf is the size of ten loaves, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> do <b>we</b> not <b>require forty</b> loaves? The Gemara answers: Forty loaves are brought in order <b>to</b> fulfill the <b>mitzva</b> in the optimal fashion, but he has nevertheless fulfilled his obligation with four loaves, one of each type.
The Gemara challenges this: <b>But</b> an individual who brings the loaves as an offering <b>is required to separate <i>teruma</i> from them</b> by designating one loaf of each type to be given to the priests, which cannot be done where only one loaf of each type exists. <b>And if you would say that he</b> may <b>separate</b> a tenth-sized piece <b>from each and every</b> loaf, that is difficult: Doesn’t <b>the Merciful One state:</b> “And of it he shall present <b>one</b> out of each offering for a gift [<i>teruma</i>] to the Lord,” which teaches <b>that he may not take sliced</b> bread, but rather a whole loaf? The Gemara answers: This is a case <b>where he separated it while kneading,</b> so that it is not considered separating a slice.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Shmuel from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All the meal offerings where</b> one <b>increased the measure of their loaves or where</b> one <b>decreased the measure of their loaves</b> are nevertheless <b>fit, except for the</b> twelve loaves of <b>shewbread, and the</b> twelve loaves of the <b>High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, <b>and</b> the ten <b>loaves</b> of each variety for the <b>thanks offering and</b> the ten loaves that accompany the guilt offering of <b>naziriteship.</b> Evidently, no fewer than forty loaves are fit for the thanks offering, in contradiction to the statement of Shmuel. The Gemara answers: <b>He</b>

Daf 76b

<b>states</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All the meal offerings where</b> one <b>increased the measure of their loaves or where</b> one <b>decreased the measure of their loaves</b> are nevertheless <b>fit, except for</b> the twelve loaves of <b>the shewbread and</b> the twelve loaves of <b>the High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering. <b>And some say: Even the</b> ten <b>loaves</b> of each variety <b>of the thanks offering and</b> the ten loaves that accompany the guilt offering of <b>naziriteship</b> are fit only when brought in their prescribed measures. Shmuel agrees with the first <i>tanna</i>, according to whom the loaves of the thanks offering and the loaves of naziriteship are fit even when not offered in the proper quantities.
§ <b>Rav Huna says:</b> With regard to an oven-<b>baked meal offering that</b> one <b>baked</b> as only <b>one loaf,</b> although he did not bring the mandated quantity, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>What is the reason?</b> It is that the verse states with regard to the oven-baked meal offering: “And when you bring a meal offering baked in the oven, it shall be unleavened loaves of fine flour” (Leviticus 2:4). The term <b>“unleavened loaves [<i>matzot</i>]” is written</b> without the letter <i>vav</i>, which is generally used with regard to the plural form. Therefore, it may be read in the singular as <b>unleavened loaf [<i>matzat</i>],</b> which teaches that even one unleavened loaf is fit.
<b>Rav Pappa objects to this</b> derivation: <b>The reason</b> Rav Huna gives is <b>that it is written</b> in the singular form of <b><i>matzat</i>. But</b> if it were <b>written: <i>Matzot</i>,</b> would this <b>not</b> be the <i>halakha</i>? <b>But</b> what about the verse <b>concerning the loaves of the thanks offering, where it is written “<i>matzot</i>”</b> with a <i>vav</i>, indicating the plural form, in the verse: “Then he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanksgiving unleavened loaves mixed with oil” (Leviticus 7:12), <b>and</b> yet <b>Rav Tovi bar Kisna said</b> that <b>Shmuel said:</b> In the case of <b>loaves of the thanks offering that were baked as four loaves,</b> such that each of the four varieties of loaves is baked as only one loaf, he has <b>fulfilled</b> his obligation. The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> statement of Shmuel <b>disagrees</b> with the opinion of Rav Huna, according to whom four loaves are not fit for the thanks offering.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>The <i>omer</i> offering,</b> i.e., the measure of barley brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan, <b>would come</b> from <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah of flour sifted <b>from three <i>se’a</i></b> of barley. <b>The two loaves</b> would come from <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah of flour sifted <b>from three <i>se’a</i></b> of wheat. <b>The shewbread</b> would come from <b>twenty-four tenths</b> of an ephah of flour sifted <b>from twenty-four <i>se’a</i></b> of wheat.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that according to the mishna, the relatively large amount of three <i>se’a</i> of barley is necessary to yield a single tenth of an ephah of flour for the <i>omer</i> offering? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> it <b>comes from</b> the fresh <b>new</b> crop, which contains a large amount of refuse, <b>and</b> it <b>comes from barley,</b> which is coarser than wheat, <b>a choice tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>comes only from</b> a minimum of <b>three <i>se’a</i></b> of barley.
The Gemara asks: Why does the mishna rule that <b>the two loaves</b> would come from <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah of flour sifted <b>from three <i>se’a</i></b> of wheat, whereas only a tenth of an ephah is used from the same amount of grain for the <i>omer</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the loaves <b>come from wheat,</b> which is of superior quality to barley, <b>although</b> they <b>come from</b> the <b>new</b> crop and require sifting, the grains are clean enough that <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah <b>come from</b> the sifting of <b>three <i>se’a</i></b> of grain.
The mishna stated that <b>the shewbread</b> would come from <b>twenty-four tenths</b> of an ephah of flour sifted <b>from twenty-four <i>se’a</i></b> of wheat. <b>What is the reason?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> they <b>come from wheat, and</b> they <b>come from</b> the <b>old</b> crop, which contains relatively little refuse, the grains are so clean that <b>a choice tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>comes from one <i>se’a</i></b> of grain, and twenty-four tenths of an ephah come from twenty-four <i>se’a</i>.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>All the meal offerings where</b> one <b>increased the measure of their tenth</b> of an ephah of flour by collecting it with a vessel larger than a tenth of an ephah, <b>or where</b> one <b>decreased the measure of</b> their <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour by collecting it with a vessel smaller than a tenth of an ephah, <b>are disqualified.</b> If he <b>increased the measure of their <i>se’a</i></b> of grain <b>or decreased the measure of their <i>se’a</i></b> of grain, e.g., if he used two or four <i>se’a</i> instead of three, but sifted until he was left with the correct measure of a tenth of an ephah of flour, they are <b>fit</b> offerings. This is because the number of <i>se’a</i> mentioned in the mishna is necessary only for the optimal fulfillment of the mitzva, but is not indispensable.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The flour of <b>the <i>omer</i> was sifted with thirteen sifters,</b> each finer than its predecessor, and the flour that emerged from the final sifter was sacrificed. The flour of <b>the two loaves</b> was sifted <b>with twelve</b> sifters, <b>and</b> the flour of <b>the shewbread</b> was sifted <b>with eleven</b> sifters. <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They have no fixed</b> number of sifters; <b>rather,</b> it was <b>fine flour</b> that was <b>completely sifted</b> that <b>one would bring</b> for all of these offerings, <b>as it is stated: “And you shall take fine flour and bake it”</b> (Leviticus 24:5), indicating that one does not fulfill his obligation <b>until</b> the flour <b>will be completely sifted.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> When a fine sifter was used, the small, dust-like particles emerged and the fine flour was caught in the sifter, and when a coarse sifter was used, the fine flour emerged and the bran was caught in the sifter. With regard to the sifting of the flour, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The sifting would begin <b>in</b> a sifter of <b>slight</b> holes, and the flour that remained would then be sifted <b>in</b> a sifter of <b>large</b> holes. The flour that emerged would again be sifted <b>in</b> a sifter with <b>slight</b> holes that were not quite as small as the first one with small holes, and again <b>in</b> a sifter of <b>large</b> holes that were not quite as large as the first one with large holes. All the sifting would proceed in this manner. <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar says: There were thirteen sifters in the Temple, this</b> one <b>above,</b> i.e., preceding, <b>that</b> one, <b>and this</b> one <b>above that</b> one. The <b>highest</b> sifter would <b>collect bran,</b> parts of the kernel aside from the actual pure flour, and the <b>lowest</b> sifter would <b>collect fine flour.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that in contrast to the first <i>tanna</i>, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: They have no fixed</b> number of sifters; but the flour would be sifted as many times as was necessary, based on the verse: “And you shall take fine flour, and bake it.” In addition, <b>the Sages taught:</b> When the verse states with regard to the shewbread: “And you shall take <b>fine flour and bake it,”</b> this <b>teaches that fine flour is acquired</b> after it has been sifted for the baking of the shewbread.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that even wheat</b> kernels may be purchased before they are ground and sifted? <b>The verse states: “And you shall take,”</b> indicating that the grain should be taken <b>in any case</b> and in any state. One <b>might</b> have thought that it is <b>so even for other meal offerings.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “And you shall take fine flour and bake <b>it,”</b> indicating that the shewbread alone may be acquired as kernels <b>because</b> of <b>the sparing [<i>haḥissaḥon</i>].</b>
<b>Rabbi Elazar says: What is</b> the meaning of: <b>Because</b> of <b>the sparing? Rabbi Elazar says: The Torah spared the money of the Jewish people.</b> Due to the large quantity of grain needed for the shewbread every week, purchasing sifted fine flour would be a substantial expense. The Gemara explains: <b>Where is the allusion</b> to this principle? It is found in a verse, <b>as it is written</b> that when the Jewish people were thirsty in the wilderness in the aftermath of Miriam’s death, God instructed Moses: “And speak to the rock before their eyes, so that it will give forth its water; and you shall bring forth to them water out of the rock; <b>so you shall give drink for the congregation and for their cattle”</b> (Numbers 20:8). Evidently, the miracle of extracting water from the rock was performed even for the purpose of providing water for the livestock.

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The flour for the loaves accompanying <b>the thanks offering would come</b> from a measure of <b>five Jerusalem <i>se’a</i> offering, which are</b> equivalent to <b>six wilderness</b> <i>se’a</i>. The <i>se’a</i> referred to in the Bible when the Jewish people were in the wilderness is smaller than the <i>se’a</i> used later in Jerusalem. This is equivalent to <b>two ephahs,</b> each <b>ephah</b> being <b>three</b> wilderness <b><i>se’a</i>.</b> These two ephahs are <b>twenty</b> measures of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah. <b>Ten</b> of these tenths were used <b>to</b> make <b>leavened</b> loaves <b>and ten</b> of these tenths were used <b>to</b> make unleavened loaves, i.e., <b><i>matza</i>.</b>

Daf 77a

The mishna elaborates: There are <b>ten</b> tenths <b>for the</b> loaves of <b>leavened bread, a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>per loaf. And</b> there are <b>ten</b> tenths <b>for the</b> loaves of <b><i>matza</i>. And among</b> the loaves of <b><i>matza</i></b> there are <b>three types: Loaves, wafers, and</b> those <b>poached in water,</b> ten loaves of each type. <b>Consequently,</b> there are <b>three-and-one-third tenths</b> of an ephah <b>for each and every type, three loaves per tenth</b> of an ephah.
<b>And in the Jerusalem measure there were thirty <i>kav</i>, fifteen</b> <i>kav</i> <b>for</b> the loaves of <b>leavened bread and fifteen for</b> the loaves of <b><i>matza</i>.</b> The mishna elaborates: There are <b>fifteen</b> <i>kav</i> <b>for</b> the loaves of <b>leavened bread, one and one-half <i>kav</i> per loaf.</b> And there are <b>fifteen</b> <i>kav</i> <b>for</b> the loaves of <b><i>matza</i>. And among</b> the loaves of <b><i>matza</i></b> there are <b>three types: Loaves, wafers, and</b> those <b>poached in water. Consequently,</b> there are <b>five <i>kav</i> for each and every type, two loaves per <i>kav</i>.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches: The flour for the loaves accompanying <b>the thanks offering would come</b> from a measure of <b>five Jerusalem <i>se’a</i>,</b> which are equivalent to six wilderness <i>se’a</i>. The <i>se’a</i> referred to in the Bible when the Jewish people were in the wilderness is smaller than the <i>se’a</i> used later in Jerusalem. This is equivalent to two ephahs, each ephah being three wilderness <i>se’a</i>. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters,</b> i.e., that there are three <i>se’a</i> in an ephah, derived? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> They are derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “The ephah and the <i>bat</i> shall be of one measure”</b> (Ezekiel 45:11). Therefore, <b>just as the <i>bat</i>,</b> a measure for liquids, is <b>three <i>se’a</i>, so too the ephah,</b> a measure for dry goods, <b>is three <i>se’a</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the <i>bat</i> itself, from where do we</b> derive its measure? <b>If we say</b> that we derive it <b>from</b> that <b>which is written</b> in the same verse: <b>“That the <i>bat</i> may contain the tenth-part of a <i>ḥomer</i>,”</b> and since one <i>ḥomer</i> consists of thirty <i>se’a</i>, one <i>bat</i> is equivalent to three <i>se’a</i>, there is a difficulty: With regard to <b>an ephah as well, isn’t it written</b> in the same verse: <b>“And the ephah the tenth-part of a <i>ḥomer</i>”?</b> Why, then, must the measure of an ephah be derived from that of a <i>bat</i>? <b>Rather, I do not know how much</b> the measure of <b>a <i>ḥomer</i></b> is; consequently, when the verse states that the ephah is one-tenth of one <i>ḥomer</i>, this does not demonstrate the measure of the ephah. <b>Here too, I do not know how much</b> the measure of the <i>bat</i> is.
<b>Rather,</b> derive the volume of the ephah <b>from here,</b> from a subsequent verse, where it is written with regard to separating <i>teruma</i>: <b>“And the set portion of oil, the <i>bat</i> of oil, shall be the tithe of the <i>bat</i> out of the <i>kor</i>, which is ten <i>bat</i>, even a <i>ḥomer</i>; for ten <i>bat</i> are a <i>ḥomer</i>”</b> (Ezekiel 45:14). The verse states that there are ten <i>bat</i> in one <i>kor</i> and ten <i>bat</i> in one <i>ḥomer</i>. Since it is known that one <i>kor</i> is equivalent to thirty <i>se’a</i>, the verse indicates that there are also thirty <i>se’a</i> in one <i>ḥomer</i>. It can therefore be derived from the verse that there are three <i>se’a</i> in one <i>bat</i>, and consequently, three <i>se’a</i> in one ephah.
§ The mishna teaches that the Sages increased the size of the measures so that five Jerusalem measures are equal to six wilderness measures. With regard to the practice of augmenting measures, <b>Shmuel says:</b> If the residents of a certain place want to change the standard of their measures and augment them by a certain fraction, <b>they may not increase the measures</b> by <b>more than one-sixth, and</b> they may <b>not</b> increase the value of <b>a coin</b> by <b>more than one-sixth</b> of its previous value. <b>And one who profits</b> from his sales <b>may not profit</b> by <b>more than one-sixth.</b>
The Gemara analyzes these statements. When Shmuel said: They may not increase the measures by more than one-sixth, <b>what is the reason</b> for this? <b>If we say</b> it is <b>because</b> doing so causes market <b>prices to rise,</b> the same concern should apply to raising the prices by <b>one-sixth,</b> and therefore that should <b>also not</b> be allowed.
<b>Rather,</b> one might say that the prohibition is <b>due to</b> concern for <b>exploitation;</b> and they may increase the measures only by up to one-sixth so <b>that there will not be nullification of the transaction,</b> as the transaction is nullified only when the disparity is more than one-sixth of the value of the item. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>But doesn’t Rava say:</b> With regard to <b>any item that</b> is otherwise subject to the <i>halakhot</i> of exploitation, and it is sold <b>by measure, or by weight, or by number, even</b> if the disparity was <b>less than the measure of exploitation</b> in the transaction, the transaction is <b>reversed?</b> A disparity of one-sixth between the value of an item and its price constitutes exploitation only in cases where there is room for error in assessing the value of an item. In a case where the details of the item are easily quantifiable, any deviation from the designated quantity results in a nullification of the transaction. The statement of Shmuel concerns sales involving measures.
<b>Rather,</b> the prohibition is for the benefit of <b>the merchant, so that there will not be a loss</b> suffered <b>by</b> a merchant who might not realize that a new standard was issued, and might sell in accordance with the old standard. Since a merchant usually enjoys a profit of one-sixth of the value of an item, if the standard is not increased by more than this amount he will not suffer a loss, as at worst he will forfeit his profit margin. The Gemara notes: This explanation is also difficult, since even if the aim is to ensure <b>that there will not be a loss</b> for the merchant, <b>does he not need</b> to earn <b>a profit?</b> There is a well-known adage in this regard: If you <b>buy and sell</b> without earning any profit, <b>will</b> you <b>be called a merchant?</b> A merchant must profit from his sales; therefore, if this decree was instituted for the protection of merchants, the Sages should have ensured that they earn a profit.
<b>Rather, Rav Ḥisda said:</b> The prohibition is not based on logical reasoning. Instead, <b>Shmuel found a verse and interpreted it homiletically: “And the shekel shall be twenty <i>gera</i>; twenty shekels, five and twenty shekels, ten, and five shekels, shall be your <i>maneh</i>”</b> (Ezekiel 45:12). According to this verse, the sum of all of these numbers, sixty shekels, is equivalent to a <i>maneh</i>. This is problematic: How can <b>a <i>maneh</i></b> consist of sixty shekels? Since each biblical shekel is equivalent to four dinars, if a <i>maneh</i> is equal to sixty shekels, a <i>maneh</i> <b>is two hundred and forty</b> dinars. But a <i>maneh</i> is actually equal to twenty-five shekels, which are one hundred dinars.
<b>Rather,</b> one can <b>learn from</b> the verse <b>three</b> matters: <b>Learn from it</b> that the <b>sacred <i>maneh</i> was doubled,</b> so that it equaled two hundred, not one hundred, dinars. <b>And</b> furthermore, as Ezekiel stated that the <i>maneh</i> will be sixty shekels, not fifty, <b>learn from it</b> that a community may <b>increase measures, but they may not increase</b> them by <b>more than one-sixth. And learn from it</b> that <b>the one-sixth</b> is calculated <b>from the outside,</b> i.e., it is one-sixth of the final sum, which is one-fifth of the previous sum.
<b>Ravina said: The mishna is also precisely</b> formulated so as to reflect the fact that the one-sixth increase is calculated from the outside, <b>as it teaches:</b> The flour for the loaves accompanying <b>the thanks offering would come</b> from a measure of <b>five Jerusalem <i>se’a</i></b> of flour, <b>which are</b> equivalent to <b>six wilderness</b> <i>se’a</i>. One can infer that the <i>se’a</i> could be increased by only one-sixth from the outside. The Gemara affirms: Indeed, <b>conclude from it</b> that this is the <i>halakha</i>.

Daf 77b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>From all</b> of the four types of loaves accompanying the thanks offering, <b>one takes one</b> loaf <b>from</b> each set of <b>ten as <i>teruma</i>,</b> to be given to a priest, <b>as it is stated: “And he shall present from it one of each offering as a <i>teruma</i> unto the Lord;</b> to the priest that sprinkles the blood of the peace offerings against the altar it shall be given” (Leviticus 7:14). The verse is analyzed: <b>“One”</b> indicates <b>that one should not take a sliced</b> loaf; <b>“of each offering”</b> indicates <b>that all the offerings should be equal,</b> i.e., <b>that one should not take</b> a loaf <b>from</b> one type of <b>offering for another</b> type; <b>“to the priest that sprinkles the blood of the peace offerings against the altar it shall be given,” and the rest</b> of the loaves are <b>eaten by the owner.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches some of the <i>halakhot</i> of <i>teruma</i> to be taken from the loaves of the thanks offering that are derived from the verse: “And he shall present from it one of each offering as a <i>teruma</i> unto the Lord.” The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> that interprets the same verse: <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The phrase <b>“And he shall present from it”</b> indicates that the loaves must all be as one, i.e., <i>teruma</i> may be taken <b>from</b> the loaves only when they are joined <b>together</b> in one place. <b>“One”</b> indicates <b>that one should not take a sliced</b> loaf. <b>“Of each offering”</b> indicates <b>that all the offerings should be equal,</b> i.e., <b>that one should not take</b> a loaf <b>from one</b> type of <b>offering for another</b> type. When the verse states: <b>“As a <i>teruma</i> unto the Lord,” I do not know from how many</b> loaves the <i>teruma</i> <b>is</b> taken.
