<b>I</b> therefore <b>derive</b> this from a verbal analogy: It <b>is stated here,</b> in the passage of the loaves describing the thanks offering: <b>“<i>Teruma</i>,” and</b> it <b>is stated with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe:</b> “Then you shall set apart from it <b>a <i>teruma</i></b> for the Lord, even a tithe of the tithe” (Numbers 18:26). <b>Just as below,</b> with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>one</b> out of every <b>ten</b> is separated as <i>teruma</i>, <b>so too here,</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering, <b>one</b> out <b>of</b> every <b>ten</b> loaves is separated as <i>teruma</i>.
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way</b> and derive the measure from a different verbal analogy: It <b>is stated here: “<i>Teruma</i>,” and</b> it <b>is stated with regard to first fruits: “<i>Teruma</i>”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:17). <b>Just as below,</b> with regard to first fruits, <b>it has no measure, so too here,</b> say that <b>it has no measure.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Let us consider to which</b> of the two cases, <i>teruma</i> of the tithe or the first fruits, the case of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering is more <b>similar.</b> It is logical that <b>one derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a <i>teruma</i> that is not followed by</b> another <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> such as <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering, <b>from a <i>teruma</i> that is not followed by</b> another <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> such as <i>teruma</i> of the tithe. <b>And</b> the case of the <b>first fruits will not</b> serve as <b>proof, since they are followed by</b> another <b><i>teruma</i>,</b> as <i>teruma</i> and tithes are taken after the first fruits are separated.
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way</b> and reason that <b>one derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b><i>teruma</i></b> of the loaves of the thanks offering, <b>which is eaten in a sacred place,</b> in Jerusalem, <b>from <i>teruma</i></b> of the first fruits, <b>which is eaten in a sacred place,</b> in Jerusalem. <b>And</b> the case of <b><i>teruma</i> of the tithe will not</b> serve as <b>proof, as it may be eaten anywhere.</b>
Since both of these comparisons are equally plausible, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering: <b>“From it…a <i>teruma</i> unto the Lord,” and,</b> similarly, <b>it is written with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe: “From it a <i>teruma</i>,” to</b> indicate that there is <b>a verbal analogy</b> between the two, from which it can be derived that one separates one out of every ten loaves of the thanks offering as <i>teruma</i>.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>We have learned with regard to <i>teruma</i></b> of the loaves of the thanks offering <b>that its</b> measure is <b>one</b> out <b>of</b> every <b>ten. But I do not know</b> from this verbal analogy <b>from how much</b> flour each leavened <b>loaf</b> is to be prepared. <b>I</b> therefore <b>derive</b> this from a verbal analogy: It <b>is stated here,</b> in the passage concerning the loaves of the thanks offering: <b>“Bread”</b> (Leviticus 7:13), <b>and</b> it <b>is stated there, with regard to the two loaves,</b> i.e., the public offering on <i>Shavuot</i> of two loaves from the new wheat: <b>“Bread”</b> (Leviticus 23:17). <b>Just as there,</b> with regard to the two loaves, one prepares the loaves with <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>per loaf, so too here,</b> with regard to the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering, one prepares the loaves with <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>per loaf.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way</b> and derive the <i>halakha</i> from a different verbal analogy: It <b>is stated here,</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering: <b>“Bread,” and it is stated</b> there, <b>with regard to the shewbread: “Bread”</b> (Leviticus 24:7). One can conclude that <b>just as there,</b> with regard to the shewbread, each of the twelve loaves is baked from <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah flour, <b>so too here,</b> each of the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering should be baked from <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah of flour.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Let us consider to which</b> of the two cases, the two loaves or the shewbread, the case of the leavened loaves of the thanks offering is more <b>similar.</b> It is logical that <b>one derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering, which is <b>a meal offering that comes</b> as <b>leavened bread</b> along <b>with an animal offering, from</b> another <b>meal offering that comes</b> as <b>leavened bread</b> along <b>with an animal offering,</b> such as the two loaves, which are also leavened, and which come with animal offerings (see Leviticus 23:17–19). <b>And the shewbread will not</b> serve as <b>proof, since it does not come</b> as <b>leavened bread,</b> nor does it come <b>with</b> an animal <b>offering.</b>
<b>Or</b> perhaps, <b>go this way</b> and reason that <b>one derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering, which is <b>a meal offering that</b> can <b>come from</b> the grain of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>or</b> of <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>from new</b> grain <b>or from old</b> grain; <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the shewbread, which is also <b>a meal offering that can come from</b> the grain of <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>or from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>from new</b> grain <b>or from old</b> grain. <b>And the two loaves will not</b> serve as <b>proof, since they</b> can <b>come only from new</b> grain <b>and from Eretz</b> Yisrael.
Since both of these comparisons are equally plausible, <b>the verse states</b> concerning the two loaves: <b>“You shall bring out of your dwellings two loaves of waving”</b> (Leviticus 23:17). <b>As</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state: “You shall bring,” what,</b> then, is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “You shall bring”?</b> This indicates <b>that whatever,</b> i.e., any meal offering, <b>you bring from a different place,</b> it must <b>be like this,</b> i.e., the two loaves. Therefore, <b>just as there,</b> in the case of the two loaves, the measure is <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>per loaf, so too here,</b> in the case of the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering, the measure is <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah <b>per loaf.</b>
But <b>if</b> so, perhaps one can derive that <b>just as there,</b> in the case of the two loaves, the entire measure for the two loaves is <b>two-tenths</b> of an ephah, <b>so too here,</b> in the case of the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering, the entire measure for all ten loaves of leavened bread is <b>two-tenths.</b> To exclude this possibility, <b>the</b> same <b>verse states: “They shall be,”</b> to indicate that each leavened loaf is prepared from a tenth of an ephah. Accordingly, the ten loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering are prepared with a total of ten tenths of an ephah.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>We have learned</b> that there are <b>ten</b> tenths of an ephah of flour <b>for the</b> loaves of <b>leavened bread</b> accompanying the thanks offering. <b>From where</b> is it derived that there are <b>ten</b> tenths of an ephah <b>for the</b> thirty loaves of <b><i>matza</i>? The verse states:</b> “If he brings it for a thanks offering, then he shall bring with the thanks offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour poached. <b>With cakes of leavened bread</b> he shall present his offering, with the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanks” (Leviticus 7:12–13).
By mentioning all the loaves of unleavened bread in one verse and the loaves of leavened bread in the subsequent verse, it is indicated that one must <b>bring</b> the <b><i>matza</i></b> in a measure <b>corresponding to</b> the measure of the loaves of <b>leavened bread. Consequently,</b> there are <b>twenty tenths</b> of flour for the <b>loaves of the thanks offering, ten for the</b> loaves of <b>leavened bread, and ten for the <i>matza</i>.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that one brings <b>ten</b> loaves of <b><i>matza</i>,</b> and that <b>all of them shall be of only one type.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “If he brings it for a thanks offering, then he shall bring with the thanks offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour poached.</b> With cakes of leavened bread he shall present his offering.” The verse indicates that one must bring three types of <i>matza</i>. <b>Consequently,</b> there are <b>three-and-one-third</b> of a tenth of an ephah of flour <b>for each and every type, and three loaves to a tenth</b> of an ephah. <b>And consequently,</b> there are a total of <b>forty loaves of the thanks offering.</b> The owner of the offering <b>takes four of them,</b> one loaf of each type, <b>and gives</b> them <b>to the priest, and the remaining</b> loaves <b>are eaten by the owner</b> and any ritually pure Jew to whom he wishes to give the loaves. This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
§ The Gemara analyzes the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Master said: “And he shall present from it,”</b> indicates that the <i>teruma</i> may be taken <b>from</b> the loaves only when they are joined <b>together</b> in one place. The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then concerning that <b>which is written</b> in the verse with regard to the sacrificial portions of the sin offering consumed on the altar: <b>“And all the fat thereof he shall take off from it</b> and make it smoke upon the altar” (Leviticus 4:19), <b>there, what is there</b> to be joined <b>together?</b>
The Gemara responds: The sacrificial portions of the sin offering must be sacrificed from that which is joined together, <b>in accordance with</b> that <b>which Rav Ḥisda</b> says that <b>Avimi says, as Rav Ḥisda says</b> that <b>Avimi says:</b> The priest <b>may not cut up the meat</b> of the offering <b>before taking</b> from it <b>the sacrificial portions</b> that are to be burned upon the altar.
§ <b>The Master said:</b> It <b>is stated here,</b> in the passage of the loaves of the thanks offering: <b>“<i>Teruma</i>,” and</b> it <b>is stated with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe: “<i>Teruma</i>.”</b> Just as one-tenth of the tithe is separated as <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, so too one out of every ten loaves of the thanks offering is separated as <i>teruma</i>.
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let us derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering <b>from <i>teruma</i></b> that was taken following the war <b>of</b> the Jewish people against <b>Midian,</b> where the word <i>teruma</i> also appears (see Numbers 31:28–30). The measure of the <i>teruma</i> there was not one of ten. The Gemara responds: <b>One derives</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b><i>teruma</i></b> of the loaves of the thanks offering, <b>which is practiced for</b> all <b>generations, from <i>teruma</i></b> of the tithe, <b>which is</b> also <b>practiced for</b> all <b>generations. And <i>teruma</i> of Midian shall not</b> serve as <b>proof, as it is not practiced for</b> all <b>generations.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>And let us derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering <b>from <i>teruma</i> of <i>ḥalla</i>,</b> i.e., the portion of dough given to the priest, as the verse refers to it as a <i>teruma</i> (see Numbers 15:19–20). That measure is one in twenty-four. The Gemara responds: <b>The school of Rabbi Yishmael taught</b> that <b>one derives a matter,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering, <b>of which it is stated: “From it a <i>teruma</i> unto the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 7:14), <b>from a matter,</b> i.e., <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, <b>of which it is stated:</b> “From it <b>a <i>teruma</i> for the Lord”</b> (Numbers 18:26). This serves <b>to exclude <i>teruma</i> of <i>ḥalla</i>, of which it is not stated: From it a <i>teruma</i> for the Lord.</b>
§ <b>Rava raises a dilemma:</b> With regard to <b><i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering,</b> is a non-priest who intentionally partakes <b>of it liable</b> to receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven, as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning a non-priest who intentionally consumes <i>teruma</i> of the tithe? <b>And</b> similarly, is a non-priest who unwittingly partakes of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering liable to pay the value of what he consumed as well as an additional <b>one-fifth</b> of that value, as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning a non-priest who partakes of <i>teruma</i> of the tithe unwittingly (see Leviticus 22:9, 14)? <b>Or is one not</b> liable to receive <b>death</b> at the hand of Heaven <b>or</b> to pay an additional <b>one-fifth for their</b> consumption?
Rava elaborates: <b>Since</b> <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering <b>is compared to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe,</b> perhaps <b>it is considered like <i>teruma</i> of the tithe,</b> and the same penalties are incurred. <b>Or perhaps,</b> since the verse uses restrictive terms with regard to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe, as the verse states of one who intentionally partakes of it: “They shall die <b>due to it”</b> (Leviticus 22:9), and the verse states with regard to one who unwittingly partakes of it: “Then he shall put <b>its fifth-part</b> unto it” (Leviticus 22:14), <b>the Merciful One restricted</b> this <i>halakha</i> specifically to the case of <i>teruma</i> of the tithe.
Rava raises another dilemma based on the comparison of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering and <i>teruma</i> of the tithe: Does <i>teruma</i> of the loaves of the thanks offering that fell into non-sacred produce <b>render the mixture</b> forbidden, as is the <i>halakha</i> concerning <i>teruma</i> of the tithe? <b>Or</b> does the comparison of <i>teruma</i> of the loaves to <i>teruma</i> of the tithe apply only with regard to the proper measure, and it <b>does not render the mixture</b> forbidden? The Gemara comments: These dilemmas <b>shall stand</b> unresolved.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>The verse states: “They shall be,”</b> indicating that each leavened loaf must come from a tenth of an ephah, so that the loaves of <i>matza</i> of the thanks offering are prepared from ten tenths of an ephah. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> for this? How is this derived from “they shall be”?

Daf 78a

<b>Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi said: “They shall be” [<i>tihyena</i>] is written</b> with two instances of the letter <i>yod</i>. The superfluous <i>yod</i>, whose numerical value is ten, is interpreted to indicate that the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering must be prepared from ten tenths of flour. The Gemara raises an objection: <b>Say</b> that the superfluous <i>yod</i> indicates that the loaves must be prepared with <b>ten half-kav,</b> a smaller measure than ten tenths of an ephah? <b>Rava says:</b> One cannot say this, since <b>the verse</b> habitually <b>spoke of tenths</b> of an ephah and not other measures.
§ The Gemara continues its analysis of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>We have learned</b> that there are <b>ten</b> tenths of an ephah of flour <b>for the</b> loaves of <b>leavened bread</b> accompanying the thanks offering. <b>From where</b> is it derived that there are <b>ten</b> tenths of an ephah <b>for</b> the thirty loaves of <b><i>matza</i>? The verse states: “With cakes of leavened bread,”</b> after mentioning the three types of <i>matza</i> accompanying the thanks offering (Leviticus 7:12–13), indicating that one must <b>bring</b> the <b><i>matza</i></b> in a measure <b>corresponding to</b> the measure of the loaves of <b>leavened bread.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But can a matter that was derived by comparison</b> then <b>come back and teach</b> the matter <b>by comparison</b> with regard to consecrated matters? Since the <i>halakha</i> that the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering are prepared from ten tenths of an ephah is itself derived by comparison to the two loaves, can one then derive from it that the <i>matza</i> loaves of the thanks offering consist of ten tenths of an ephah? The Gemara responds: The <i>halakha</i> that the loaves of leavened bread consist of ten loaves made from ten tenths of an ephah is not derived solely by comparison to the two loaves; rather, <b>it is</b> derived <b>from itself,</b> as the <i>halakha</i> that there are ten loaves is stated in the verse concerning the thanks offering, <b>and</b> from <b>another matter, and any</b> <i>halakha</i> derived <b>from itself and</b> from <b>another matter is not</b> considered <b>a comparison.</b> Consequently, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <i>matza</i> loaves may be derived from it.
The Gemara asks: <b>This works out well according to the one who says</b> that a <i>halakha</i> derived from itself and from another matter <b>does not constitute a comparison, but according to the one who says</b> that a <i>halakha</i> derived from itself and from another matter <b>does constitute a comparison, what is there to say?</b> The Gemara responds: According to that opinion, the <i>halakha</i> that each loaf is prepared from a tenth of an ephah is derived from that which the verse states with regard to the two loaves: <b>“You shall bring”</b> (Leviticus 23:17), which <b>is</b> a term of <b>amplification</b> that serves to teach that the loaves of leavened bread of the thanks offering consist of ten tenths of an ephah of flour. Since this <i>halakha</i> is derived not by comparison but by amplification from the two loaves, one can derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the <i>matza</i> loaves by comparison to the loaves of leavened bread.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> The loaves that accompanied the ram of <b>the inauguration</b> of the Tabernacle <b>would come parallel to the</b> three types of <b><i>matza</i> that</b> accompany <b>the thanks offering: Loaves, wafers, and</b> loaves <b>poached</b> in water and made with oil (see Leviticus 8:26). The loaves of leavened bread that accompany the thanks offering were not brought with the ram of inauguration.
The loaves that accompany the offering that the nazirite brings upon completion of his period of <b>naziriteship would come</b> with only <b>two parts</b> of the three types of <i>matza</i> that accompany the thanks offering, namely, <b>loaves and wafers, but there is no</b> <i>matza</i> <b>poached</b> in water (see Numbers 6:15). <b>Consequently,</b> the loaves of the offering of a nazirite are from <b>ten <i>kav</i></b> of fine flour according to the <b>Jerusalem</b> measure, as taught in the previous mishna that each type of the loaves of <i>matza</i> comes from five <i>kav</i> of flour, <b>which</b> equal <b>six-and-two-thirds tenths</b> of an ephah according to the wilderness measure, as each type of the loaves of <i>matza</i> comes from three-and-one-third tenths of an ephah.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the loaves that accompanied the ram of the inauguration of the Tabernacle consisted of the three types of <i>matza</i> brought with a thanks offering: Loaves, wafers, and loaves poached in water and made with oil. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>Rav Ḥama bar Gurya said:</b> It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>the verse states: “And out of the basket of unleavened bread that was before the Lord, he took one unleavened cake, and one cake of oiled bread, and one wafer”</b> (Leviticus 8:26). <b>Granted, “cakes”</b> are <b>cakes,</b> and <b>“wafer”</b> is <b>a wafer.</b> But <b>what is “oiled</b> bread” referring to? Is this <b>not</b> referring to <i>matza</i> <b>poached</b> in water and made with oil?
<b>Rav Avya objects to this:</b> One can <b>say</b> that “oiled bread” is referring to <b>a cake of oil. Rather,</b> derive it <b>as Rav Naḥman bar Rav Ḥisda taught in the name of Rabbi Tavla,</b> that the verse states: <b>“This is the offering of Aaron and of his sons, which they shall bring to the Lord on the day when he is anointed:</b> The tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a meal offering perpetually, half of it in the morning and half of it in the evening. On a pan it shall be made with oil; when it is poached, you shall bring it in; in broken pieces shall you bring the meal offering for a pleasing aroma to the Lord. And the anointed priest that shall be in his stead from among his sons shall bring it” (Leviticus 6:13–15).
One can ask: <b>And what have we learned with regard to</b> Aaron’s <b>sons,</b> i.e., the ordinary priests, from the instructions for the High Priest <b>on the day that he is anointed? Rather,</b> the verse <b>juxtaposes</b> the meal offering brought by an ordinary priest during <b>his inauguration with</b> the meal offering brought by the High Priest when <b>he is anointed.</b> This juxtaposition teaches that <b>just as</b> the meal offering brought by the High Priest when <b>he is anointed is poached in water, so too</b> the meal offering brought by an ordinary priest during <b>his inauguration is poached in water.</b> Similarly, the loaves brought with the ram of the inauguration of the Tabernacle included loaves poached in water.
§ Concerning the matter of the High Priest’s meal offering on the day of his inaugural service in the Temple, <b>Rav Ḥisda says: A High Priest who approaches the</b> Temple <b>service</b> on the day that he is anointed is <b>required</b> to bring two meal offerings consisting of <b>two tenths of an ephah, one for</b> the fact that <b>he is anointed</b> as the High Priest and must bring the daily meal offering of the High Priest, <b>and one for his inauguration. Mar bar Rav Ashi says:</b> He requires <b>three</b> tenths of an ephah.
<b>And they do not disagree. This</b> one, Rav Ḥisda, is referring to a High Priest <b>who</b> already <b>performed</b> the Temple <b>service as an ordinary priest.</b> Accordingly, he has already brought a meal offering for his inauguration as an ordinary priest. He therefore brings only two tenths of flour, one for his inauguration as High Priest and one for the daily meal offering of the High Priest. And <b>that</b> one, Mar bar Rav Ashi, is referring to a High Priest <b>who has not</b> yet <b>performed</b> the Temple <b>service as an ordinary priest.</b> He must therefore bring three tenths, one for his inauguration as an ordinary priest, one for his inauguration as High Priest, and one for the daily meal offering of the High Priest.
§ The mishna teaches: The loaves that accompany the offering that the nazirite brings upon completion of his period of <b>naziriteship would come</b> with only <b>two parts, parallel to the</b> types of <b><i>matza</i> that</b> come <b>with the thanks offering,</b> i.e., loaves and wafers, but not <i>matza</i> poached in water.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the loaves brought with a thanks offering: “If he sacrifices it for a thanks offering, then he shall sacrifice with the thanks offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour poached. With cakes of leavened bread he shall present his offering with the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanks” (Leviticus 7:12–13). <b>“His peace offerings”</b> serves <b>to include the nazirite’s peace offering in</b> the <i>halakhot</i> that its accompanying meal offerings must consist of <b>ten Jerusalem <i>kav</i> and one-quarter</b> of a <i>log</i> <b>of oil,</b> just like the measurements required for the cakes and wafers of the thanks offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought that the verse indicates that the meal offering of the nazirite’s peace offering is equivalent to the loaves of the thanks offering <b>concerning all that is stated with regard to the matter</b> of the thanks offering, and that one brings three types of <i>matza</i> consisting of fifteen Jerusalem <i>kav</i> and half a <i>log</i> of oil. Therefore, <b>the verse states</b> with regard to the nazirite’s peace offering: “And a basket of <b>unleavened bread,</b> loaves of fine flour mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil” (Numbers 6:15), to indicate that the nazirite’s meal offering consists only of <i>matza</i> loaves and <i>matza</i> wafers, and not <i>matza</i> poached in water.
The Gemara clarifies: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> by which “<i>matza</i>” indicates that loaves poached in water were not brought? <b>Rav Pappa says:</b> The verse indicates that the nazirite brings <i>matza</i> specifically from <b>an item of which it was stated: “<i>Matzot</i>.”</b> This serves <b>to exclude</b> loaves <b>poached in water, of which it is not stated: <i>Matzot</i>.</b> In addition, <b>the school of Rabbi Yishmael taught: “Unleavened bread”</b> is <b>a generalization; “loaves</b> of fine flour mingled with oil, <b>and</b> unleavened <b>wafers</b> spread with oil” <b>is a detail.</b> When the Torah states <b>a generalization and a detail, the generalization includes only what is in the detail.</b> Therefore, <b>loaves and wafers are</b> included in the nazirite’s meal offering, while <b>other items are not.</b>

Daf 78b

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>one who slaughters the thanks offering</b> in its proper place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> at that time <b>its</b> forty <b>loaves were outside the wall, the loaves were not consecrated.</b> Likewise, <b>if he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>before the surface</b> of the loaves <b>formed a crust in the oven, and even</b> if the surface of all the loaves <b>formed a crust except for one of them, the loaves were not consecrated.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Gemara clarifies: <b>What</b> is meant by <b>outside the wall? Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that it means <b>outside the wall of Beit Pagei</b> in Jerusalem. <b>And Reish Lakish says</b> that it means <b>outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that it means <b>outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> because the verse states with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering: “Then he shall sacrifice with [<i>al</i>] the thanks offering unleavened cakes mingled with oil” (Leviticus 7:12). And <b>we require</b> that the thanks offering be slaughtered strictly <b>“with [<i>al</i>]”</b> the accompanying loaves, i.e., with the loaves <b>nearby.</b> If the loaves are outside the wall of the Temple courtyard, they are not considered nearby.
<b>And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If the loaves were <b>outside the wall of Beit Pagei,</b> they are not consecrated, because it is prohibited to eat the loaves outside the wall of Beit Pagei. Since if they were taken outside the wall of Beit Pagei, they would be disqualified because they were removed from their permitted area, they cannot be consecrated if they are there. <b>But</b> if they were merely <b>outside the</b> Temple <b>courtyard,</b> where they may be eaten, they are <b>consecrated. And we do not require</b> that the thanks offering be slaughtered strictly <b>“with”</b> the accompanying loaves, i.e., <b>nearby.</b>
The Gemara objects: Why is it necessary for Rabbi Yoḥanan and Reish Lakish to disagree with regard to a case where the loaves were situated outside the wall when the thanks offering was slaughtered? <b>But didn’t they</b> already <b>disagree with regard to this</b> matter <b>one</b> other <b>time?</b>
This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Pesaḥim</i> 63a) with regard to the slaughtering of the Paschal offering: <b>One who slaughters the Paschal offering with leavened bread</b> still in his possession <b>transgresses a prohibition,</b> as the verse states: “You shall not sacrifice the blood of My offering with [<i>al</i>] leavened bread; neither shall the offering of the festival of Passover be left until the morning” (Exodus 34:25). <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: Even</b> one who slaughters <b>the daily</b> afternoon <b>offering</b> on Passover eve with leavened bread in his possession transgresses the prohibition. <b>And Reish Lakish says: Actually, one is not liable unless</b> the leavened bread <b>is</b> in the possession <b>of the one who slaughters</b> the offering, <b>or the one who sprinkles</b> its blood, <b>or one of the members of the group,</b> and the leavened bread is <b>with</b> that person <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard. And Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> One is liable <b>even if</b> the leavened bread <b>is not with</b> that person <b>in the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> Evidently, they already disagree with regard to the meaning of the word “<i>al.</i>”
The Gemara replies: It is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute concerning both matters. <b>As, if</b> their disagreement <b>were stated</b> only <b>with regard to that</b> matter of the Paschal offering, one might think that only <b>with regard to that</b> matter <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> that one is liable even if the leavened bread is not inside the Temple courtyard, <b>since wherever there is</b> leavened bread, its owner <b>stands in</b> violation of <b>the prohibition</b> against owning leavened bread at that time. <b>But with regard to the matter of the consecration of</b> the <b>loaves</b> of the thanks offering, one could <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Reish Lakish that if</b> the loaves are <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard when the thanks offering is slaughtered, they are <b>consecrated,</b> but if they are <b>outside,</b> they are <b>not consecrated.</b>
<b>And if</b> their disagreement <b>were stated</b> only <b>with regard to this</b> matter of the loaves of the thanks offering, one might think that only <b>with regard to this</b> matter <b>Reish Lakish says</b> that the loaves are consecrated only if they were within the walls of the Temple courtyard. <b>But with regard to that</b> matter of the Paschal offering, one could <b>say</b> that <b>he concedes to Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that one is liable for slaughtering the Paschal offering while in possession of leavened bread even if it was not with him inside the Temple courtyard, as wherever there is leavened bread, its owner stands in violation of the prohibition against owning leavened bread at that time. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> to state the dispute concerning both matters.
The Gemara notes: <b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> In the case of <b>one who slaughters the thanks offering inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> at that time <b>its loaves were outside the walls of Beit Pagei, the loaves were not consecrated.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If <b>he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>before the surface of the loaves formed a crust in the oven,</b> the loaves were not consecrated. The next mishna also teaches: If one slaughtered the thanks offering not for its sake, the loaves were not consecrated.
The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>As the Sages taught:</b> The verse states with regard to the loaves accompanying the thanks offering: <b>“With cakes of leavened bread he shall present his offering with the sacrifice</b> of his peace offerings for thanks” (Leviticus 7:13). This <b>teaches that the loaves are not consecrated unless the surface</b> of the loaves <b>formed a crust in the oven,</b> as only then can they be considered “cakes of leavened bread.” The phrase <b>“he shall present his offering with the sacrifice” teaches that the loaves are consecrated only upon the slaughtering of the offering.</b> The phrase <b>“the sacrifice</b> of his peace offerings <b>for thanks” teaches that if one slaughtered</b> the offering <b>not for its sake, the loaves were not consecrated.</b>
§ On a similar note, <b>the Sages taught:</b> One <b>fulfills</b> the obligation to eat <i>matza</i> on Passover <b>with half-done,</b> i.e., not fully baked, <b><i>matza</i>, and with <i>matza</i> made in a stewpot [<i>ilpas</i>]</b> rather than baked in an oven. The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> constitutes <b>half-done <i>matza</i>? Rav Yehuda says</b> that <b>Shmuel says:</b> It is <b>any</b> <i>matza</i> that is sufficiently baked such <b>that</b> if <b>one breaks it, threads</b> of dough <b>are not drawn from it.</b>
<b>Rava said: And so</b> this is the <i>halakha</i> <b>with regard to the matter of the loaves of the thanks offering,</b> i.e., if the loaves were already half-done at the time of the slaughter of the thanks offering, they are consecrated. The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary for Rava to state this? Isn’t it <b>obvious? Here,</b> with regard to <i>matza</i>, the term <b>“bread” is written</b> (Deuteronomy 16:3), <b>and here,</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering, the term <b>“bread” is written.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Lest you say</b> that since <b>the Merciful One states</b> with regard to the loaves of the thanks offering: “And of it he shall present <b>one</b> out of each offering for a gift unto the Lord” (Leviticus 7:14), this indicates <b>that one may not take sliced</b> bread for the thanks offering, <b>and this</b> half-done bread <b>is considered like one that is sliced,</b> as it will break apart upon being lifted, and it should consequently be disqualified for the bread of the thanks offering, therefore Rava <b>teaches us</b> that once it is baked to that point, it is considered as one loaf and it is valid for the thanks offering.
§ It <b>was stated</b> that there is a dispute among the <i>amora’im</i> with regard to <b>a thanks offering that one slaughtered</b> accompanied <b>by eighty loaves</b> rather than the required forty. <b>Ḥizkiyya says: Forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated, and Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Not</b> even <b>forty of</b> the <b>eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated.</b>
With regard to this dispute, <b>Rabbi Zeira says: Everyone,</b> even Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>concedes</b> that in a case <b>where</b> the individual bringing the offering <b>said: Let forty of</b> the <b>eighty</b> loaves <b>be consecrated, that</b> forty <b>are consecrated.</b> Likewise, everyone concedes that where he said: <b>Forty should not be consecrated unless eighty will be consecrated,</b> that <b>they were not consecrated. They disagree when</b> one brings eighty loaves <b>without specification.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds: He intends</b> to consecrate only forty of them, but he brought eighty in order <b>to guarantee</b> that there will be sufficient loaves. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds: He intends to</b> bring <b>a large offering</b> of eighty loaves; consequently, none of the loaves are consecrated.
<b>Abaye</b> offered another explanation of the dispute and <b>said: Everyone</b> agrees that <b>he intends to guarantee</b> that there will be sufficient loaves, <b>and they disagree with regard to</b> whether <b>service vessels consecrate</b> the appropriate measure <b>without</b> the <b>intention</b> of the one bringing the offering. One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds</b> that <b>service vessels consecrate</b> items <b>without intention.</b> Accordingly, the knife that slaughters the thanks offering and consecrates its accompanying loaves consecrates forty of the eighty. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>service vessels do not consecrate</b> items <b>without intention.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa</b> offered another explanation of the dispute and <b>said: Everyone</b> agrees that <b>service vessels consecrate</b> items <b>without intention, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether this is also the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the slaughtering <b>knife.</b> One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds</b> that <b>the knife consecrates</b> items <b>as a service vessel</b> does. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that <b>since the knife has no inside, it does not consecrate</b> items <b>as a service vessel</b> does.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>Rav Pappa said: Everyone</b> agrees that <b>service vessels consecrate</b> items <b>only with intention, and here they disagree with regard to the</b> ability of the slaughtering <b>knife</b> to consecrate without intention. One <b>Sage,</b> Ḥizkiyya, <b>holds</b> that the power of <b>the knife</b> to consecrate items <b>is stronger than</b> that of other <b>service vessels, as even though it has no inside it consecrates</b> items, and therefore it also consecrates items without intention. <b>And</b> one <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan, <b>holds</b> that the power of <b>the knife</b> to consecrate items <b>is not stronger than</b> that of other <b>service vessels,</b> and like all service vessels, it does not consecrate items without intention.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering with the intent to partake of it or to burn the sacrificial portions <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area,</b> and the offering was rendered <i>piggul</i> or was disqualified, respectively, <b>the loaves were consecrated</b> and either rendered <i>piggul</i> or disqualified. If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>and it was discovered</b> that it was <b>an animal with a wound that would have caused it to die within twelve months [<i>tereifa</i>], the loaves were not consecrated,</b> as the cause of the animal’s disqualification preceded its slaughter.
If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>and it was discovered</b> that it is <b>a blemished</b> animal that may not be sacrificed <i>ab initio</i> but if it ascended the altar it may be sacrificed, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> He has <b>consecrated</b> the loaves, since if the offering ascends the altar it is sacrificed. <b>And the Rabbis say:</b> He has <b>not consecrated</b> the loaves, since it may not be sacrificed <i>ab initio</i>.
If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>not for its sake</b> but for the sake of another offering, <b>and likewise,</b> if one slaughtered <b>the ram of inauguration</b> not for its sake, <b>and likewise,</b> if one <b>slaughtered the</b> communal peace offering of <b>two sheep</b> that accompany the two loaves on <b><i>Shavuot</i> not for their sake, the loaves were not consecrated.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one slaughtered the thanks offering with the intent to partake of it beyond its designated time or outside its designated area, the loaves become consecrated. The mishna also teaches that if the thanks offering was slaughtered and it was discovered that it was a <i>tereifa</i>, the loaves were not consecrated, but if it was discovered to have a blemish, Rabbi Eliezer says that the loaves were consecrated, and the Rabbis say that they were not. The Gemara asks: <b>Whose</b> opinion is expressed in <b>the mishna?</b> It is the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>This is the principle: Any</b> instance in <b>which</b> the <b>disqualification</b> of the thanks offering <b>preceded</b> its <b>slaughter, the loaves were not consecrated,</b> and any instance in which <b>its disqualification</b> came into existence <b>after</b> its <b>slaughter, the loaves were consecrated.</b> Therefore, if one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering with the intent to partake of it or to burn the sacrificial portions <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time or outside its</b> designated <b>area, the loaves were consecrated,</b> as the offering remained fit until after its slaughter. But if one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>and it was discovered</b> that it was <b>a <i>tereifa</i>, the loaves were not consecrated,</b> as the cause of the animal’s disqualification preceded its slaughter.

Daf 79a

If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>and it was discovered</b> that it is <b>a blemished</b> animal, <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The loaves were <b>consecrated,</b> and <b>Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> The loaves were <b>not consecrated.</b> This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir,</b> consistent with the dispute appearing in the mishna.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>Rabbi Yehuda said: Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua did not disagree with regard to</b> a case where <b>he slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>and it was discovered</b> that it is <b>a <i>tereifa</i>,</b> as all agree <b>that it was not consecrated; and</b> they did not disagree <b>with regard to</b> a case where he slaughtered the thanks offering with the intent to partake of it or to burn the sacrificial portions <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time,</b> as all agree <b>that it was consecrated; and</b> they did not disagree <b>with regard to</b> a case where he slaughtered the thanks offering and it was discovered that it is <b>a blemished</b> animal, as all agree <b>that it was not consecrated. And with regard to what</b> case <b>did they disagree?</b> They disagree <b>with regard to</b> a case where he slaughtered the thanks offering with the intent to partake of it or to burn the sacrificial portions <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, as Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> It <b>was consecrated, and Rabbi Yehoshua says:</b> It <b>was not consecrated.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: In explanation of his opinion, <b>Rabbi Eliezer said: Since</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time is disqualified and</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area is disqualified,</b> it is reasonable that <b>just as</b> in the case of intent to partake of it <b>beyond its time</b> the loaves <b>were consecrated, so too</b> in the case of intent to partake of it <b>outside its area</b> the loaves <b>were consecrated. Rabbi Yehoshua said: Since</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area is disqualified and</b> an offering discovered to be <b>a blemished</b> animal <b>is disqualified,</b> it is reasonable that <b>just as</b> in the case of <b>a blemished</b> animal the loaves <b>were not consecrated, so too</b> in the case of intent to partake of it <b>outside its area</b> the loaves <b>were not consecrated.</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him: I compared</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area <b>to</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, and you compared it to</b> an offering discovered to be <b>a blemished</b> animal. <b>Let us consider to which it is similar. If it is similar to</b> an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, we will deduce its</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> that of an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time. If it is similar to</b> an offering discovered to be <b>a blemished</b> animal, <b>we will deduce its</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> that of an offering discovered to be <b>a blemished</b> animal.
<b>Rabbi Eliezer began to reason: We deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a disqualification</b> due to improper <b>intention from</b> that of <b>a disqualification</b> due to an improper <b>intention,</b> i.e., the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who slaughters the animal with intent to partake of it outside its designated area should be deduced from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who slaughters it with the intent to partake of it outside its designated time. <b>And we do not deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a disqualification</b> due to improper <b>intention from</b> that of <b>a disqualification</b> due to a blemish in <b>the</b> physical <b>body</b> of the offering.
<b>Rabbi Yehoshua began to reason</b> to the contrary: <b>We deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to <b>a disqualification that does not</b> include liability for <b>excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>],</b> i.e., an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area, <b>from</b> that of <b>a disqualification that does not</b> include liability for <b><i>karet</i>,</b> i.e., an offering discovered to be a blemished animal. And the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time should</b> not be brought <b>as proof, as</b> it is <b>a disqualification that</b> includes liability for <b><i>karet</i>. And furthermore,</b> even according to Rabbi Eliezer, who says that we deduce the <i>halakha</i> from a disqualification due to improper intention, <b>let us deduce</b> the <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> that of an offering slaughtered <b>not for its sake, as</b> it is <b>a disqualification</b> due to improper <b>intention and</b> it also <b>does not</b> include liability for <b><i>karet</i>,</b> and the loaves of such an offering were not consecrated.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>And Rabbi Eliezer was silent,</b> conceding to Rabbi Yehoshua. In any event, it is clear in the <i>baraita</i> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> who says that if the thanks offering was slaughtered and discovered to be a <i>tereifa</i> the loaves were not consecrated, but if it was discovered to be a blemished animal Rabbi Eliezer holds that the loaves were consecrated, <b>what is different</b> if <b>he slaughtered it and it was discovered to be a <i>tereifa</i></b> such <b>that it is</b> considered a case where <b>its disqualification precedes</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> and the loaves were not consecrated; <b>and what is different</b> if <b>he slaughtered it and it was discovered to be a blemished</b> animal such <b>that it is not</b> considered a case where <b>its disqualification precedes</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> and the loaves were consecrated according to Rabbi Eliezer?
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Meir is referring <b>to</b> a blemish <b>on the cornea of the eye, and</b> his ruling is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Akiva, who said</b> with regard to this type of blemish: Although animals with such a blemish are disqualified as an offering <i>ab initio</i>, <b>if they ascended</b> the altar <b>they shall not descend,</b> and they are sacrificed on the altar. The Gemara adds: <b>And Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who holds that if the animal is discovered to be blemished the loaves are not consecrated, says: <b>When Rabbi Akiva said</b> that <b>if they ascended</b> the altar, <b>they shall not descend,</b> he was referring to the <b>disqualification of</b> the offering <b>itself,</b> i.e., that once it ascended it shall not descend. <b>But with regard to the consecration of the loaves</b> through the slaughter of such an animal, he did <b>not</b> say this.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer and Rabbi Yehoshua in the <i>baraita</i>: It <b>was stated:</b> With regard to <b>a sin offering that one slaughtered</b> with intent to partake of it <b>beyond its</b> designated <b>time, if it ascended</b> the altar <b>it shall not descend.</b> If one slaughtered it with intent to partake of it <b>outside its</b> designated <b>area, Rava says: It shall descend</b> and shall not be burned, and <b>Rabba says: It shall not descend.</b>
The Gemara suggests: <b>Rava</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> who deduces the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a thanks offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area from that of an offering discovered to have a blemish. Accordingly, just as a blemished sin offering descends from the altar even if it has already ascended, so too a sin offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area descends. <b>And Rabba</b> holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer,</b> who deduces the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a thanks offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area from that of an offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it beyond its designated time. Accordingly, just as a sin offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it beyond its designated time does not descend from the altar, so too a sin offering that was slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area does not descend.
<b>And Rabba retracted</b> his opinion <b>in favor of</b> the opinion <b>of Rava</b> and ruled that a sin offering slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area descends from the altar, <b>since Rabbi Eliezer retracted</b> his opinion <b>in favor of</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua,</b> as the <i>baraita</i> teaches that he was silent and accepted the reasoning of Rabbi Yehoshua. Accordingly, the <i>halakha</i> with regard to an animal slaughtered with intent to partake of it outside its designated area should be deduced from that of an offering discovered to have a blemish.
<b>And there are</b> those <b>who say: Even though Rabbi Eliezer retracted</b> his opinion <b>in favor of</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehoshua, Rabba did not retract</b> his opinion <b>in favor of</b> the opinion <b>of Rava,</b> because <b>there,</b> with regard to the consecration of the loaves of the thanks offering, Rabbi Eliezer conceded to Rabbi Yehoshua because Rabbi Yehoshua <b>said to him: Let us deduce its</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> that of an offering slaughtered <b>not for its sake. But here, if you deduce its</b> <i>halakha</i> <b>from</b> that of an offering slaughtered <b>not for its sake,</b> then the <i>halakha</i> should be that <b>if it ascended</b> the altar <b>it shall not descend.</b>
§ The mishna teaches: If one <b>slaughtered</b> the thanks offering <b>not for its sake,</b> and likewise, if one slaughtered the ram of inauguration not for its sake, and likewise, if one slaughtered the communal peace offering of two sheep that accompany the two loaves on <i>Shavuot</i> not for their sake, the loaves were not consecrated. <b>Rav Pappa said</b> in bewilderment: Why does <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna <b>omit</b> the case of the loaves of the <b>nazirite’s ram, which is common</b> and is also not consecrated if the ram was slaughtered not for its sake, <b>and teach</b> instead <b>the ram of the inauguration</b> of the Tabernacle, which was brought only by the Jewish people in the wilderness? The Gemara responds: <b>And</b> what is the reasoning of <b>the <i>tanna</i> of our</b> mishna? <b>He taught</b> the ram of the inauguration because it was <b>the primary matter,</b> i.e., it was the first offering to be brought with loaves.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In a case where <b>the libations</b> that accompany the offerings <b>were sanctified in</b> a service <b>vessel</b> when the animal was slaughtered <b>and the offering was discovered</b> to be <b>unfit, if there is another offering</b> that was slaughtered and requires libations, the libations <b>should be sacrificed with</b> that offering; <b>and if not, they should be disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight,</b> and then burned.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to statement of the mishna concerning a case where the libations of an animal offering were consecrated and the animal was then discovered to be unfit, <b>Ze’eiri says: Libations are sanctified only upon the slaughter of the offering. What is the reason</b> for this? The <b>verse states:</b> “To bring an offering made by fire unto the Lord, a burnt offering, and a meal offering, <b>a sacrifice, and libations,</b> each on its own day” (Leviticus 23:37), indicating that the libations complement the offering and are consecrated only upon its slaughter.
The Gemara poses a difficulty to the statement of Ze’eiri from that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: In a case where <b>the libations were sanctified in</b> a service <b>vessel</b> when the animal was slaughtered <b>and the offering was discovered</b> to be <b>unfit, if there is another offering</b> that was slaughtered and requires libations, the libations <b>should be sacrificed with</b> that offering; <b>and if not, they should be disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight,</b> and then burned.
<b>What, is it not</b> so that the mishna is referring to a case <b>where</b> the offering <b>became unfit through</b> its <b>slaughter,</b> and consequently the libations were not sanctified by the slaughter of the offering? Why, then, must the libations be left overnight in order to disqualify them? Evidently, the libations are sanctified being placed in a service vessel and not upon the slaughter of the offering, in contradiction to the statement of Ze’eiri. The Gemara rejects this: <b>No,</b> the mishna is referring to an offering <b>that became unfit through the sprinkling</b> of the blood; the libations were sanctified upon the slaughter of the offering, and therefore they must be disqualified by being left overnight.
The Gemara seeks to clarify: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this mishna? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> If an offering has <b>two factors that permit</b> it for consumption or for sacrifice, <b>they can each elevate</b> it to sanctified status <b>without the other.</b> Accordingly, although the slaughter of the animal and the sprinkling of its blood are both permitting factors for the libations, the libations were sanctified through the slaughter of the animal, despite the fact that the animal became unfit through the sprinkling of its blood.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Even</b> if <b>you say</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon,</b> who disagrees with Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and holds that both permitting factors must be performed in order to confer sanctity upon the libations, the mishna can still be explained as follows: <b>Here, we are dealing with</b> a case <b>where</b> the priest <b>collected its blood in the cup</b> for the purpose of sprinkling it on the altar, <b>but</b> the blood <b>spilled</b> out of the cup and could not be sprinkled. Nevertheless, the libations were sanctified, as the blood was fit for sprinkling upon the altar.

Daf 79b

<b>And Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>his father</b> in this matter, <b>as</b> Rabbi Shimon <b>said: Any</b> blood of an offering <b>that stands</b> fit <b>to be sprinkled</b> upon the altar <b>is considered as</b> if it were already <b>sprinkled.</b> Accordingly, although the blood was spilled after it was collected in the cup and was not actually sprinkled, it is nevertheless considered as if it were sprinkled.
§ <b>The Master said</b> in the mishna: <b>If there is another offering</b> that was slaughtered and requires libations, the libations <b>should be sacrificed with</b> that offering. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t Rav Ḥisda say</b> that <b>oil that</b> one <b>separated for the sake of this</b> one <b>meal offering</b> is <b>unfit</b> to be brought <b>for the sake of another meal offering?</b> Likewise, shouldn’t libations separated for one offering be unfit for sacrifice with another offering? <b>Rabbi Yannai says: The court tacitly stipulates concerning</b> the libations that <b>if they were required</b> for the offering for which they were separated, <b>they were required</b> and are brought with that offering. <b>But if not,</b> e.g., where the offering was disqualified, <b>they should be</b> brought with <b>another offering.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then shouldn’t it be that the court tacitly stipulates concerning <b>the oil as well?</b> The Gemara responds: <b>The oil is</b> part <b>of the meal offering itself</b> and cannot be brought for the sake of another meal offering, whereas the libations merely accompany the offering and are not an integral part of it.
The Gemara challenges: If it is so that the court tacitly stipulates concerning the libations, then <b>let</b> the court tacitly <b>stipulate concerning them that</b> if the offering they are meant to accompany is disqualified, <b>they shall emerge to non-sacred</b> status altogether. The Gemara responds: It is a rabbinic <b>decree</b> that the court does not tacitly make this stipulation, <b>lest</b> people who are unaware of such a stipulation see that an item that was previously sanctified has become non-sacred, and <b>they will</b> mistakenly <b>say: One may remove</b> sanctified items <b>from service vessels to</b> become <b>non-sacred.</b>
The Gemara objects: If the Sages did not tacitly make such a stipulation because they were concerned that people might mistakenly conclude that items that were already consecrated in service vessels can become non-sacred, then <b>now as well,</b> where the court tacitly stipulates that the libations should be sacrificed with another offering, let there be a rabbinic <b>decree</b> against such a stipulation, <b>lest</b> people <b>say: Libations that one separated for the sake of one offering are fit for the sake of a different offering</b> <i>ab initio</i>.
The Gemara responds: <b>Mattitya ben Yehuda teaches</b> that the mishna is referring specifically to a case <b>where there was</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time.</b> In such a case, there is no concern that people will reach this mistaken conclusion, as one who sees that the libations are sacrificed immediately with the other offering will simply assume that they were separated for the sake of that offering from the outset.
The Gemara objects to this: According to the explanation of Mattitya ben Yehuda, it can be inferred from the mishna that if there is another offering that was slaughtered at the same time, then the libations are sacrificed with that offering; <b>but</b> if <b>there is not</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time,</b> then <b>what</b> should be done with the libations? They should be <b>disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight.</b> If so, <b>rather than teaching</b> in <b>the latter clause</b> of the mishna: <b>And if</b> there is <b>not</b> another offering that requires libations, <b>they should be disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight; let</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>distinguish and teach</b> the distinction <b>within the</b> case <b>itself</b> as follows: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where there was</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time. But if there is not</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time,</b> the libations are <b>not</b> sacrificed with another offering.
The Gemara responds: <b>That is also what</b> the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna <b>is saying: In what</b> case <b>is this statement said?</b> It is said in a case <b>where there was</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time. But if there is not</b> another <b>offering</b> that was <b>slaughtered at the same time,</b> the libations <b>are</b> immediately <b>considered as if they were disqualified by</b> being <b>left overnight, and</b> they are <b>disqualified.</b>
The Gemara explained above that the mishna is also in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Shimon, and that he holds in accordance with the opinion of his father that any blood that stands fit to be sprinkled is considered as if it has been sprinkled. The Gemara also explained that the mishna allows for the sacrifice of the libations with another offering because the court tacitly stipulates that the libations should be brought with another offering if the first offering becomes disqualified. In light of this, the Gemara asks: <b>But does Rabbi Shimon ben Elazar,</b> i.e., the father of Rabbi Elazar, <b>accept</b> the principle that <b>the court tacitly stipulates concerning</b> the libations?
<b>But didn’t Rav Idi bar Avin say</b> that <b>Rav Amram said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak said</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said:</b> With regard to animals that were designated as <b>daily offerings</b> but <b>that</b> in the end <b>were not needed for</b> use by <b>the public,</b> and have inherent sanctity, how shall they be redeemed? <b>According to the statement of Rabbi Shimon, they may not be redeemed</b> as long as they are <b>unblemished,</b> since they retain the status of offerings. But <b>according to the statement of the Rabbis, they may be redeemed</b> even when they are <b>unblemished,</b> as the court initially stipulates that if they are not needed they will not assume the status of an offering. Since Rabbi Shimon disagrees with the Rabbis, it may be inferred that according to Rabbi Shimon, one does not say that the court tacitly stipulates concerning the offerings.
The Gemara responds: In general, Rabbi Shimon holds that the court stipulates concerning them. And <b>it is different there,</b> in the case of the daily offerings, <b>because they have</b> an alternative <b>arrangement through</b> which their total loss may be avoided, as they may be left in the field to <b>graze</b> until they develop a blemish, at which point they may be sold. Since there is no arrangement for the libations save for sacrificing them with another offering, even Rabbi Shimon holds that the court stipulates concerning them.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>the offspring</b> of an animal designated as <b>a thanks offering, or</b> an animal that is <b>its substitute;</b> or in a case where <b>one separated</b> an animal as <b>a thanks offering and it was lost and he separated another in its stead,</b> and the first animal was then found, in all three cases, the second animal, i.e., the offspring, the substitute, or the replacement, is sacrificed, but it <b>does not require</b> the bringing of accompanying <b>loaves.</b> This is <b>as it is stated:</b> “If he sacrifices it for a thanks offering, <b>then he shall sacrifice with the thanks offering</b> unleavened cakes mingled with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and cakes mingled with oil, of fine flour poached” (Leviticus 7:12). The verse indicates that <b>the</b> initial <b>thanks offering requires loaves, but neither its offspring, nor its replacement, nor its substitute requires loaves.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is it</b> that the verse teaches when it <b>states: He sacrifices for a thanks offering?</b> The verse states: <b>If he sacrifices for a thanks offering. From where</b> is it derived that <b>with regard to one</b> who <b>separated</b> an animal as <b>his thanks offering and it was lost and he separated another in its stead, and the first animal was</b> then <b>found, and</b> now <b>they both stand</b> fit to be sacrificed, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that he may sacrifice whichever</b> one <b>of them he wishes, and its loaves</b> are brought along <b>with it? The verse states</b> that <b>he shall sacrifice the thanks offering,</b> i.e., as long as he sacrifices some thanks offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that the second</b> animal also <b>requires loaves</b> to be brought with it. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “He sacrifices it,”</b> indicating that only <b>one</b> thanks offering requires loaves, <b>but not two. Since the verse included</b> the second animal as fit for sacrifice <b>and excluded</b> it from the requirement to bring loaves with it, <b>from where</b> is it derived that the verse also <b>includes</b> a thanks offering’s <b>offspring, replacements, and substitutes</b> as fit <b>for sacrifice?</b> From the fact that <b>the verse states: “If for a thanks offering,”</b> one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>they would require loaves</b> to be brought with them. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Then he shall sacrifice with the thanks offering,”</b> indicating that the initial <b>thanks offering</b> itself <b>requires loaves, but neither its offspring, nor its replacement, nor its substitute requires loaves.</b>
§ With regard to the offspring, substitute, and replacement of a thanks offering, the Gemara relates: <b>Rav Ḥanina sent</b> a letter from Eretz Yisrael to the Sages in Babylonia containing the following statement <b>in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> that the offspring, replacement, and substitute do not require loaves <b>only</b> in a case where they were sacrificed <b>after</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement,</b> i.e., where the initial thanks offering was already sacrificed with its loaves; <b>but</b> if they were sacrificed <b>before</b> he achieved <b>atonement, they require loaves.</b>
<b>Rav Amram discussed this</b> <i>halakha</i> sent in the name of Rabbi Yoḥanan and asked: <b>To which</b> <i>halakha</i> in the mishna is this referring? <b>If we say</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan is referring <b>to the replacement for an obligatory thanks offering,</b> then there is no novelty in his statement. <b>If</b> his intention is to teach that where the thanks offering was found <b>before</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with its replacement, the replacement requires loaves, <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> this in the <i>baraita</i>, as it states: He may sacrifice whichever one of them he wishes, and its loaves are brought along with it. And <b>if</b> his intention is to teach that where the thanks offering was found <b>after</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with the replacement, the thanks offering does not require loaves, this too <b>we</b> already <b>learned</b> in the <i>baraita</i>, as it teaches that only the first offering requires loaves.

Daf 80a

<b>Rather,</b> perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring not to the replacement for an obligatory thanks offering, but <b>to the replacement for a voluntary thanks offering.</b> This too is difficult, because <b>whether</b> the initial thanks offering was found <b>before</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with the replacement <b>or after</b> he achieved <b>atonement,</b> both offerings <b>require loaves,</b> as the owner <b>is</b> considered one who <b>increases thanks offerings.</b> That is, since he was not required to bring a replacement for the offering, if he brings another offering it is considered an additional voluntary offering, and a voluntary thanks offering requires loaves.
<b>Rather,</b> perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring <b>to the offspring of a voluntary thanks offering.</b> This too is difficult, because <b>whether</b> the offspring was sacrificed <b>before</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement</b> with its mother <b>or after</b> he achieved <b>atonement,</b> offspring <b>do not require loaves,</b> as <b>this is</b> considered <b>a leftover of the thanks offering,</b> which does not require loaves. <b>Rather,</b> perhaps Rabbi Yoḥanan was referring <b>to the offspring of an obligatory thanks offering.</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan teaches that if the offspring was sacrificed <b>before</b> the owner achieved <b>atonement, it requires loaves,</b> but if it was sacrificed <b>after</b> he achieved <b>atonement, it does not require loaves.</b>
The Gemara asks: According to this explanation, <b>what is</b> Rav Ḥanina <b>teaching us</b> by sending this letter? He teaches us <b>that Rabbi Yoḥanan holds: A person achieves atonement with the enhancement of consecrated</b> property, even though it is not the initial consecrated property. If one sacrifices the offspring of an obligatory thanks-offering before the thanks-offering itself, he achieves atonement with the offspring, even though it is an enhancement of the consecrated thanks-offering. Accordingly, if he offers it before its mother, it requires loaves. The Gemara notes: <b>Abaye also discusses</b> the letter sent by Rav Ḥanina <b>in this way</b> and reaches conclusions similar to those of Rav Amram.
With regard to the conclusions of Rav Amram and Abaye, it <b>was also stated: Rav Yitzḥak bar Yosef says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> If one achieves atonement with <b>the replacement for a voluntary thanks offering, whether</b> the thanks offering was found <b>before</b> he achieved <b>atonement or after</b> he achieved <b>atonement,</b> the replacement <b>requires loaves,</b> as the owner <b>is</b> considered one who <b>increases thanks offerings. The offspring of a voluntary thanks offering, whether</b> it was sacrificed <b>before</b> he achieved <b>atonement or after</b> he achieved <b>atonement, does not require loaves,</b> as offspring <b>is</b> considered <b>a leftover of the thanks offering. And</b> with regard to <b>the offspring of an obligatory thanks offering,</b> if it was sacrificed <b>before</b> he achieved <b>atonement, it requires loaves,</b> but if it was sacrificed <b>after</b> he achieved <b>atonement, it does not require loaves.</b>
§ The Gemara cites additional <i>halakhot</i> with regard to the loaves of a thanks offering that was lost and another animal was taken as its replacement: <b>Shmuel says:</b> In <b>any</b> situation <b>in which a sin offering</b> would be placed in isolation for it <b>to die,</b> if that same situation occurs <b>with a thanks offering, it does not require loaves.</b> And in <b>any</b> situation <b>in which a sin offering</b> would be placed in the field to <b>graze</b> until it develops a blemish, if that same situation occurs <b>with a thanks offering, it requires loaves.</b>
<b>Rav Amram raises an objection</b> from the <i>baraita</i> cited on 79b: <b>What is it</b> that the verse teaches when it <b>states: He sacrifices for a thanks offering? From where</b> is it derived that <b>one who separated</b> an animal as <b>his thanks offering and it was lost and he separated another in its stead, and the first animal was</b> then <b>found, and</b> now <b>they both stand</b> fit to be sacrificed, <b>from where</b> is it derived <b>that he may sacrifice whichever</b> one <b>of them he wishes, and its loaves</b> are brought along <b>with it? The verse states: He sacrifices for a thanks offering.</b> One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that the second</b> animal also <b>requires loaves</b> to be brought with it. <b>The verse states: “He sacrifices it,”</b> indicating that only <b>one</b> thanks offering requires loaves, <b>but not two.</b>
Rav Amram continues: <b>Whereas with regard to a sin offering in a case like this,</b> the Rabbis hold that the animal <b>is</b> placed in the field to <b>graze, as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Temura</i> 22b): If <b>one separated his sin offering and it was lost, and he separated another</b> animal <b>in its stead, and the first</b> sin offering <b>was found, and both</b> animals <b>stand</b> fit for sacrifice, then he <b>achieves atonement with one of them and the second</b> animal <b>shall</b> be left to <b>die;</b> this is <b>the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. <b>And the Rabbis say: A sin offering</b> is left to <b>die only</b> if it <b>was found after its owner achieved atonement.</b> It may be inferred from the opinion of the Rabbis <b>that</b> if it is found <b>before the owner achieved atonement,</b> it is placed in the field to <b>graze.</b>
The Gemara responds: <b>Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said:</b> An animal separated as a sin offering that was <b>lost at the time of the separation</b> of its replacement, even if it was found before the replacement was sacrificed, is left to <b>die.</b> The principle stated by Shmuel is therefore correct, since in every situation in which a sin offering is left to die, a thanks offering does not require loaves.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that even in such a case the second sin offering is left to die, <b>how can you find</b> a case where the sin offering is placed in the field to <b>graze according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi? The Gemara responds: It can be found in a case <b>like that of Rabbi Oshaya, as Rabbi Oshaya says:</b> If <b>one separated two sin offerings,</b> one to achieve atonement for his sin and the other <b>as a guarantee</b> in case the first one is lost, <b>he may achieve atonement with whichever of them he wishes, and the second shall</b> be placed in the field to <b>graze.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>But in a case like this</b> involving <b>a thanks offering,</b> the animal <b>does not require loaves.</b> Therefore, if Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that in such a case the sin offering is placed in the field to graze, then Shmuel cannot hold in accordance with his opinion, since according to Shmuel, in circumstances where a sin offering would be left to graze, a thanks offering in the same circumstances would require loaves. <b>Rather, Shmuel holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Shimon, who said:</b> There are <b>five sin offerings</b> that are left to <b>die;</b> one is a sin offering that was lost and found before its replacement was sacrificed, and another is the case where a sin offering was separated as a guarantee.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> it cannot be that Shmuel holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, since <b>Rabbi Shimon does not hold</b> that there are <b>any</b> circumstances in which a sin offering is placed in the field to <b>graze.</b> Accordingly, if Shmuel holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Shimon, how can he say: And in any situation in which a sin offering would be placed in the field to graze until it develops a blemish, if that same situation occurs with a thanks offering, it requires loaves?
The Gemara responds: In fact, <b>Shmuel also stated</b> only <b>one</b> principle: In <b>any</b> situation <b>in which a sin offering</b> is placed in isolation for it <b>to die,</b> if that same situation occurs <b>with a thanks offering, it does not require loaves.</b> He did not state the second principle. The Gemara asks: <b>What is</b> Shmuel <b>teaching us?</b> The Gemara responds: Shmuel teaches us his statement <b>to exclude</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said: A person achieves atonement with the enhancement of consecrated</b> property. According to Rabbi Yoḥanan, the offspring of an obligatory thanks offering requires loaves if it is sacrificed before its mother. Shmuel <b>teaches us that</b> one does <b>not</b> achieve atonement with the enhancement of consecrated property, and the offspring of a thanks offering does not require loaves, which corresponds to the fact that the offspring of a sin offering is left to die.
§ With regard to the loaves of a thanks offering, <b>Rabbi Abba says:</b> If one volunteered to bring a thanks offering, and said: <b>This</b> animal <b>is a thanks offering and this</b> flour <b>is</b> designated for <b>its loaves,</b> then if <b>the loaves were lost, he brings other loaves.</b> If <b>the thanks offering was lost, he does not bring another thanks offering,</b> and the loaves are not sacrificed. <b>What is the reason</b> for this? <b>The loaves are</b> brought <b>on account of the thanks offering;</b> therefore, if there is no thanks offering, there are no loaves. <b>But the thanks offering is not</b> brought <b>on account of the loaves;</b> consequently, if the loaves were lost, the thanks offering is still sacrificed, and one brings different loaves.
§ <b>And</b> with regard to the distinctions between a thanks offering and its accompanying loaves, <b>Rava says:</b> In the case of one who <b>separated money for his thanks offering</b>

Daf 80b

<b>and</b> some of the money <b>remained</b> after he purchased the offering, <b>he brings,</b> i.e., purchases, <b>with</b> the remaining money <b>loaves</b> to accompany the thanks offering. If he separated money <b>for the loaves of the thanks offering and</b> some of the money <b>remained</b> after he purchased the loaves, <b>he may not bring a thanks offering with</b> the remaining money.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason? If we say</b> that it is <b>due to</b> the statement <b>of Rav Kahana,</b> that is difficult. <b>As Rav Kahana said: From where</b> is it derived that <b>the loaves of a thanks offering are</b> themselves <b>called a thanks offering?</b> It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated</b> in the verse: <b>“Then he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanks offering loaves”</b> (Leviticus 7:12). The juxtaposition of the words “thanks offering” and “loaves” indicates that the loaves are themselves called a thanks offering. Therefore, one who separated money for a thanks offering may use that money for the loaves as well. The Gemara explains the difficulty: <b>If that is so, the opposite</b> should <b>also</b> be the <i>halakha</i>, i.e., the thanks offering is called loaves, and it should therefore be permitted to use the money remaining from the loaves for the thanks offering. The Gemara rejects this: <b>The loaves are called a thanks offering,</b> but <b>the thanks offering is not called loaves.</b>
§ <b>And Rava says:</b> If <b>one separated</b> an animal as <b>his thanks offering and it was lost, and he again separated another in its stead, and it</b> too <b>was lost, and he again separated another in its stead, and the first</b> two animals <b>were</b> then <b>found, and the three of them stand</b> fit to be sacrificed, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If <b>he achieved atonement with the first</b> animal, <b>the second does not require loaves,</b> as it is the replacement for the first, and the first was sacrificed with its loaves. But <b>the third requires loaves,</b> because it is the replacement for the second, which does not require loaves.
If <b>he achieved atonement with the third,</b> then <b>the second does not require loaves,</b> because its replacement, i.e., the third, was sacrificed with loaves, but <b>the first requires loaves,</b> because its replacement, i.e., the second, will be sacrificed without loaves. If he achieved atonement <b>with the middle,</b> i.e., the second animal, <b>both of them,</b> i.e., the first and the third, <b>do not require loaves,</b> because the replacement for the first, i.e., the second, was sacrificed with loaves, and the third is the replacement for the second, which was sacrificed with loaves. <b>Abaye says: Even if he achieved atonement with</b> any <b>one of them,</b> the other <b>two do not require loaves,</b> as <b>they are all replacements for one another.</b>
<b>Rabbi Zeira says: And so</b> is the <i>halakha</i> <b>for the matter of sin offerings:</b> If <b>one separated</b> an animal as <b>his sin offering and it was lost, and he separated another in its stead, and it</b> too <b>was lost, and he separated another in its stead, and the first</b> two animals <b>were</b> then <b>found, and the three of them stand</b> fit to be sacrificed, the <i>halakha</i> is as follows: If <b>he achieved atonement with the first, the second is</b> left <b>to die,</b> as is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a sin offering whose owner has already achieved atonement, and <b>the third is</b> placed in the field to <b>graze</b> until it develops a blemish and can be redeemed, since it is the replacement for a sin offering that was not sacrificed.
If <b>he achieved atonement with the third, the second is</b> left <b>to die,</b> because its replacement, i.e., the third, was already sacrificed, <b>and the first is</b> placed in the field to <b>graze,</b> because its replacement, i.e., the second, will not be sacrificed.
