If <b>he achieved atonement with the middle, both of them,</b> i.e., the first and the third, <b>are</b> left <b>to die,</b> because the second was sacrificed as a replacement for the first, and the third would have been the replacement of the second. <b>Abaye says: Even if he achieved atonement with</b> any <b>one of them,</b> the other <b>two are</b> left <b>to die,</b> as <b>they are all replacements for one another.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> does Rabbi Zeira mean by: <b>And so</b> is the <i>halakha</i> for the matter of sin offerings? Why is it necessary for Rabbi Zeira to teach this seemingly identical <i>halakha</i> with regard to three sin offerings? The Gemara responds: It is necessary to teach that these <i>halakhot</i> apply with regard to sin offerings as well, <b>lest you say</b> that <b>there,</b> in the case of the thanks offerings, if one achieved atonement with the first animal then the third requires loaves, <b>since it can be said</b> that the owner <b>is one who increases thanks offerings; but here,</b> in the case of the sin offerings, <b>since it cannot be said</b> that the owner <b>is one who increases sin offerings,</b> as one cannot volunteer a sin offering, <b>I would say</b> that the same <i>halakhot</i> do <b>not</b> apply, and if one achieved atonement with the first sin offering, the third is left to die. Rabbi Zeira therefore <b>teaches us</b> that the third sin offering is considered the replacement for the second and is therefore left to graze.
§ The mishna teaches that the substitute of a thanks offering does not require loaves. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya teaches:</b> In the case of an animal separated as <b>a thanks offering that was intermingled with its substitute,</b> and it is not known which is the thanks offering and which is the substitute, <b>and one of them died, the other has no remedy. What should we do?</b> If <b>we bring loaves with it,</b> this may be improper, because <b>perhaps it is a substitute,</b> which does not require loaves. If <b>we do not bring loaves with it,</b> this may be improper, because <b>perhaps it is the</b> actual <b>thanks offering,</b> which requires loaves.
The Gemara asks: <b>What are the circumstances</b> of this case? <b>If</b> it is a case where the owner <b>said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring a thanks offering, in which case he is required to replace the thanks offering in the event of its loss, then why is there no remedy? Is it <b>not sufficient if he does not bring another animal and loaves, and says: If the one remaining</b> from the intermingled group <b>is the substitute,</b> then let <b>this</b> additional animal <b>be the thanks offering and these its loaves;</b> and <b>if the one remaining is the thanks offering,</b> then let it be the thanks offering and <b>these its loaves, and let this</b> additional animal <b>be its guarantee,</b> which does not require loaves?
The Gemara responds: <b>No,</b> the statement of Rabbi Ḥiyya is <b>necessary</b> in a case in <b>which</b> one <b>said: This</b> animal <b>is</b> a thanks offering. Since he consecrated a specific animal as a thanks offering, he is not required to provide a guarantee in the event of its loss, and the above remedy is not applicable.
§ The Gemara raises a series of challenges with the statement of Rabbi Ḥiyya that if a thanks offering was intermingled with its substitute and one of them died, there is no remedy for the other. The Gemara provides <b>a mnemonic</b> for remembering the names of the Sages that raise these challenges: <b><i>Lemudim</i>,</b> i.e., Levi, who was known as <i>Lemedin</i> before Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi; <b><i>middat</i>,</b> i.e., Rav Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta; <b><i>ala</i>,</b> i.e., Ulla bar Abba; <b><i>shish</i>,</b> i.e., Rav Shisha, son of Rav Idi; <b><i>sheken</i>,</b> an acronym for Rav Ashi and Rav Kahana; <b><i>dedamah</i>,</b> i.e., Rav Dimi, son of Rav Huna of Dimhorya; <b><i>de’i</i>,</b> i.e., Ravina of Ikla. An additional mnemonic is provided for recalling the topics of these questions: <b><i>Ḥalash</i>,</b> a contraction of <i>ḥullin</i>, i.e., non-sacred items, and <i>shelamim</i>, peace offerings; <b>leftover; substitute; outside; Ḥizkiyya; separated a sin offering; for a guarantee.</b>
<b><i>Lemedin</i>,</b> i.e., Levi, <b>said before Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>But</b> why is there no remedy in this case? <b>Let him bring loaves</b> for the thanks offering <b>and let him say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant</b> from the intermingled pair <b>is the thanks offering,</b> then <b>these are its loaves,</b> and they will be consumed as the loaves of the thanks offering. And <b>if not,</b> i.e., if the extant animal is the substitute, which is sacrificed without loaves, then <b>let</b> these loaves <b>go out to</b> be consumed as <b>non-sacred</b> loaves. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him:</b> But the loaves of a thanks offering must be waved in the Temple courtyard, <b>and do we</b> intentionally <b>bring non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard?</b>
Levi challenges: <b>And let him bring</b> another <b>animal with loaves and let him say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then let <b>this</b> additional animal be <b>the thanks offering and these its loaves. If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then let <b>these</b> be <b>its loaves, and this</b> additional animal <b>should be a peace offering,</b> which does not require loaves. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him:</b> This cannot be done, <b>because he</b> thereby <b>reduces</b> the time period permitted <b>for consuming the peace offering,</b> which is generally two days and one night. A thanks offering may be consumed only on the day it is sacrificed and the following night.
<b>Levi said to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>And let him bring</b> another <b>animal with loaves and let him say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then let <b>this</b> be <b>the thanks offering and these its loaves. And if that</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then let <b>these</b> be <b>its loaves and this will be the leftover of the thanks offering,</b> which does not require loaves. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to him: It seems to me that he has no brain in his skull.</b>

Daf 81a

Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi explains why: <b>And does one separate</b> an animal <b>as a leftover <i>ab initio</i>?</b>
The Gemara suggests another solution: <b>Rabbi Yitzḥak bar Shmuel bar Marta was sitting before Rav Naḥman, and he was sitting and saying: And let him bring</b> another <b>animal with loaves and let him say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then let <b>this</b> be <b>the thanks offering and these its loaves. And if this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then let <b>these</b> be <b>its loaves and this will be a substitute,</b> as the substitute of a thanks offering is not sacrificed with loaves, and it may be consumed for the same duration as the thanks offering itself.
Rav Naḥman <b>said to him: Answer me, my Master:</b> The <i>halakha</i> is that one who separates a substitute is liable to receive <b>forty</b> lashes <b>on his shoulders, and</b> yet you say it is <b>fit</b> to separate a substitute <i>ab initio</i>?
The Gemara relates that <b>Rav Ila took ill,</b> and <b>Abaye and the Sages went to</b> visit <b>him, and they were sitting and saying: If</b> one <b>accepts</b> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said:</b> If the loaves of the thanks offering were within Jerusalem, i.e., the area of consumption of a thanks offering and its loaves, even if they were <b>outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard</b> when the thanks offering was slaughtered they are <b>consecrated,</b> then <b>let</b> the owner <b>bring loaves and set them outside the wall of the</b> Temple <b>courtyard and let him say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then let <b>these</b> be <b>its loaves, and if</b> it is <b>not, let them go out</b> and be consumed <b>as non-sacred</b> loaves.
The Gemara responds: This too is not a valid remedy, <b>because there are four</b> loaves of the forty that one must <b>wave. How would he perform</b> the mitzva of waving them? <b>Shall he wave them outside</b> the Temple courtyard? He may not, since “waved for a wave offering <b>before the Lord”</b> (Leviticus 7:30) <b>is written</b> in the verse, and waving performed outside the Temple courtyard is not considered “before the Lord.” Shall he wave them <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard? <b>He</b> will have <b>brought non-sacred food into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard. Therefore,</b> it is <b>not possible.</b>
<b>Rav Sheisha, son of Rav Idi, objects to this: If</b> one <b>accepts</b> the ruling <b>of Ḥizkiyya, who said</b> with regard to a thanks offering that one slaughtered accompanied by eighty loaves rather than the required forty: <b>Forty of the eighty</b> loaves <b>are consecrated,</b> then let the owner <b>bring an animal and let him bring eighty loaves with it and say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then <b>this</b> additional animal <b>should also be a thanks offering and these eighty</b> loaves should be <b>for both of them.</b> And <b>if this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then let <b>this</b> additional animal be <b>a thanks offering and these</b> shall be <b>its loaves, and let forty of the eighty be consecrated for it.</b>
The Gemara rejects this: This is not a valid remedy, <b>because it reduces</b> the <b>consumption of the forty</b> additional loaves, as the priests may not be able to consume the four loaves given from the additional forty, and the owner cannot consume them because they may be the portion of the priest.
<b>Rav Ashi said to Rav Kahana: If</b> one <b>accepts</b> the ruling <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said:</b> If <b>one separated a pregnant</b> animal as <b>a sin offering and it gave birth,</b> if <b>he wants he can achieve atonement with it,</b> and if <b>he wants he can achieve atonement with its offspring;</b> then <b>let</b> the owner <b>bring a pregnant animal and wait until it gives birth, and let him bring eighty</b> loaves <b>with it and say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then <b>this</b> and its offspring <b>are thanks offerings, and these eighty</b> loaves should be <b>for both of them. And if this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then <b>this</b> mother should also be <b>a thanks offering, and these eighty</b> loaves should be <b>for both of them, and let this</b> offspring <b>be the leftover of the thanks offering.</b>
Rav Kahana <b>said to him: Who shall say to us that</b> the reasoning of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> is that he <b>said</b> that the offspring is considered the property of the one who dedicated the pregnant mother, such that <b>if he reserved it</b> for a specific consecration it is considered <b>reserved</b> for that consecration? <b>Perhaps</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan holds that <b>if he reserved it, it is not</b> considered <b>reserved, and this is the reason that Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> holds that one can achieve atonement with the offspring of a pregnant animal separated as a sin offering, <b>as he said: A person achieves atonement with the enhancement of consecrated</b> property, such as the offspring of an animal that was consecrated when pregnant.
<b>Ravina happened</b> to come <b>to Dimhorya. Rav Dimi, son of Rav Huna from Dimhorya, said to Ravina: And let</b> the owner <b>bring an animal and say: It is</b> incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring an animal for a thanks offering, and let him separate this animal in fulfillment of his vow, <b>and</b> then <b>let him bring another animal, and let him bring eighty</b> loaves <b>with it and say: If this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the substitute,</b> then <b>these two</b> additional animals are <b>thanks offerings and these eighty</b> loaves should be <b>for both of them. And if this</b> animal <b>that is extant is the thanks offering,</b> then <b>this one</b> for <b>which I said:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me, should also be a thanks offering, and these eighty</b> loaves are <b>for both of them, and let the other</b> animal <b>be for a guarantee,</b> to be sacrificed if my thanks offering gets lost, and it does not require loaves.
Ravina <b>said to him: The Torah said: “Better is it that you should not vow, than that you should vow and not pay”</b> (Ecclesiastes 5:4), <b>and you say: Let him rise up and vow <i>ab initio</i>?</b> Taking a vow to bring an offering is not encouraged. As all possible remedies have been rejected, the statement of Rabbi Ḥiyya, that there is no remedy in a case where a thanks offering and its substitute were intermingled and one of them died, stands.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>One who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering, must bring it and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money in his possession and not second-tithe money. Since he said: It is incumbent upon me, bringing the offering is an obligation, and one may not fulfill an obligation with second-tithe money.

Daf 81b

If one said: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering from non-sacred</b> money <b>and its loaves from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money, <b>he must bring</b> the thanks offering <b>and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money. If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money <b>and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money, <b>he may bring</b> it in that manner. Likewise, if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring a thanks offering <b>and its loaves from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money, <b>he may bring</b> it in that manner. <b>And he may not bring</b> the loaves <b>from second-tithe wheat; rather,</b> he purchases the flour <b>with second-tithe money.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to the various ways in which one can take a vow to bring a thanks offering and its loaves, <b>Rav Huna says: One who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>loaves of a thanks offering, must bring a thanks offering and its loaves,</b> even though he did not expressly take upon himself the obligation to bring the thanks offering itself. <b>What is the reason? This man knows that loaves are not brought without a thanks offering, and</b> by stating the vow in <b>this</b> manner, he was effectively <b>saying:</b> It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering and its loaves. And</b> the reason he <b>stated</b> his vow in <b>this</b> manner, namely, by saying: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>loaves of a thanks offering,</b> was that <b>he was citing the end of the matter,</b> as the sacrifice of a thanks offering is completed with the bringing of the loaves.
The Gemara raises a difficulty with the statement of Rav Huna from that which <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money <b>and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money, <b>he may bring</b> it <b>as he vowed.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of Rav Huna that one who takes a vow to bring the loaves of a thanks offering intends to bring the thanks offering as well, <b>why</b> does the mishna state that he may bring the thanks offering from second-tithe money? <b>Since he said: Its loaves from non-sacred</b> money, <b>he should bring</b> a thanks offering <b>and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money.
The Gemara responds: <b>It is different there,</b> in the case of the mishna, <b>as since he said</b> initially: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money, and then said: And its loaves from non-sacred money, <b>he is considered as one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>loaves to exempt the thanks offering of so-and-so.</b> His vow to bring the loaves is not considered a new vow, but rather as a vow to bring loaves for the specific offering he vowed to bring.
The Gemara asks: <b>If that is so,</b> then with regard to <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna, <b>which teaches</b> that if one says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering from non-sacred</b> money <b>and its loaves from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money, then <b>he must bring</b> the thanks offering <b>and its loaves from non-sacred</b> money, <b>here too</b> let it be said that <b>he is considered as one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering to exempt the loaves of so-and-so,</b> and he therefore should bring a thanks offering from second tithe. His initial vow to bring a thanks offering from non-sacred money should not include the bringing of the loaves.
The Gemara rejects this: <b>How can</b> these cases <b>be compared? Granted,</b> in a case where one says: It is incumbent upon me to bring a thanks offering from second-tithe money and its loaves from non-sacred money, it can be said that he intends that the loaves should be brought to complete the vow of one who is obligated to bring a thanks offering, because <b>loaves come to exempt the thanks offering.</b> But in a case where one says: It is incumbent upon me to bring a thanks offering from non-sacred money and its loaves from second-tithe money, it cannot be said that the thanks offering is meant to complete the vow of one who is obligated to bring the loaves of a thanks offering, as <b>does a thanks offering come to exempt the loaves?</b>
The Gemara continues to discuss the statement of Rav Huna that one who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring loaves of a thanks offering, must bring a thanks offering and its loaves. <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a proof from a <i>baraita</i> that contradicts the opinion of Rav Huna: In the case of <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering without loaves, or</b> an animal <b>offering without libations,</b> the court <b>coerces him, and he brings a thanks offering with its loaves,</b> or <b>an offering with its libations.</b>
The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he is coerced to bring a thanks offering with its loaves is <b>that he said</b> that it is incumbent upon himself to bring a thanks offering. <b>But</b> if <b>he did not say</b> that it is incumbent upon himself to bring <b>a thanks offering,</b> but instead said that it is incumbent upon himself to bring the loaves of a thanks offering, he would <b>not</b> be coerced to bring a thanks offering with the loaves, in contradiction to the opinion of Rav Huna.
The Gemara rejects this: Actually, <b>the same is true even if he did not say</b> that it is incumbent upon himself to bring <b>a thanks offering,</b> but said only: It is incumbent upon me to bring the loaves. <b>And</b> this is the reason that the <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> mentions specifically the case of one who renders himself obligated to bring a thanks offering without loaves: <b>Since</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>wants to teach</b> the case of one who renders himself obligated to bring an animal <b>offering without libations,</b> concerning <b>which</b> he could <b>not teach</b> a case where one renders himself obligated to bring <b>libations without an offering,</b> because, unlike the loaves of a thanks offering, libations are in fact brought on their own and one can take a vow to bring them on their own, <b>he</b> therefore <b>also taught</b> the case of one who renders himself obligated to bring <b>a thanks offering.</b>
The Gemara addresses the actual statement of the <i>baraita</i> and asks: <b>Why</b> is he coerced to bring a thanks offering and its loaves? Isn’t <b>this</b> an instance of <b>a vow with its</b> inherent <b>opening?</b> That is, the vow should be dissolved entirely on the grounds that the one who took the vow may claim that he thought it was possible to bring a thanks offering without loaves, and now that he has been made aware that he cannot, he regrets taking the vow.
<b>Ḥizkiyya said:</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this</b> <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai, who say:</b> In the case of one who stated a declaration comprising two contradictory statements, <b>attend</b> to only <b>the first statement. As we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Nazir</i> 9a): If one says: <b>I am hereby a nazirite from dried figs and from</b> pressed <b>figs,</b> which is a contradictory statement, as figs are not prohibited to a nazirite, <b>Beit Shammai say:</b> He is a full-fledged <b>nazirite,</b> as one attends only to the first statement, i.e., I am hereby a nazirite, and the second part is discounted. <b>And Beit Hillel say:</b> The second part of his statement is not discounted, and therefore <b>he is not a nazirite,</b> as he did not accept naziriteship upon himself.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: You</b> may <b>even say</b> that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Hillel,</b> and the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>with regard to one who says: Had I known that one does not vow</b> in <b>this</b> manner, i.e., to bring a thanks offering without loaves or an animal offering without libations, <b>I would not have vowed</b> in <b>this</b> manner <b>but</b> in <b>that</b> manner, i.e., I would have vowed to bring a thanks offering with its loaves. There is therefore no opening for a dissolution. <b>And what</b> does the <i>baraita</i> mean when it states that the court <b>coerces</b> him? Why would he require coercion if he says that he would have willingly taken the proper vow? The <i>baraita</i> is referring to a case <b>where,</b> despite the fact that he would have taken the proper vow initially, <b>he</b> now <b>wants to retract his</b> vow altogether.
The Gemara cites a <i>baraita</i> in support of the response of Ḥizkiyya: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear:</b> In a case involving <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering without loaves, or:</b> It is incumbent upon me to bring an animal <b>offering without libations, and</b> the Sages <b>said to him: Bring a thanks offering with its loaves, or:</b> Bring an animal <b>offering with its libations, and he says: Had I known that such</b> is the requirement <b>I would not have vowed</b> at all; the <i>halakha</i> is that the court <b>coerces him, and says to him: “Observe and hear”</b> (Deuteronomy 12:28).
The Gemara continues: <b>Granted,</b> this <b>works out well according to Ḥizkiyya,</b> who says that the <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai that one attends only to the first statement, since this <i>baraita</i> can also be explained in accordance with the opinion of Beit Shammai. <b>But according to Rabbi Yoḥanan,</b> who says that the <i>baraita</i> discusses a case where the person who took the vow says: Had I known that one does not vow in this manner I would have vowed to bring a thanks offering with its loaves, this <i>baraita</i> presents <b>a difficulty,</b> as although the individual claims that he would not have taken any vow, he must still bring a thanks offering and its loaves. The Gemara responds: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> could have <b>said to you: This</b> latter <i>baraita</i> <b>is certainly</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Beit Shammai,</b> but the previous <i>baraita</i> may still be explained in accordance with the opinion of Beit Hillel.
The Gemara turns to analyze the <i>baraita</i> itself: <b>What</b> is the relevance of the phrase in the verse that says: <b>“Observe and hear,”</b> to one who vows to bring a thanks offering without its loaves? <b>Abaye says: “Observe”</b> means: <b>Bring a thanks offering; “and hear”</b> means: <b>Bring its loaves. Rava says: “Observe”</b> means: <b>Bring a thanks offering and its loaves; “and hear”</b> means <b>that you should not act</b> in <b>this</b> manner <b>regularly.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that if one states: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a thanks offering and its loaves from</b> second-<b>tithe</b> money, <b>he shall bring</b> it in that manner. The Gemara asks: Why does the mishna teach: <b>He shall bring,</b> which suggests that he must bring the thanks offering and loaves from second-tithe money? Is it <b>not sufficient</b> to fulfill his vow even <b>if he does not bring</b> it from second-tithe money but from non-sacred money? In fact, it is preferable that he bring the offering from non-sacred money. <b>Rav Naḥman and Rav Ḥisda say:</b> The mishna does not mean that he must bring it specifically from second-tithe money; rather, if he <b>wants, he brings</b> it from second-tithe money, and if he <b>does not want, he does not</b> need to <b>bring</b> it from second-tithe money.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>And he may not bring</b> the loaves <b>from second-tithe wheat; rather,</b> he purchases the flour <b>with second-tithe money.</b> With regard to this, <b>Rav Naḥman and Rav Ḥisda both say:</b> The mishna <b>taught only</b> that the loaves may not be brought <b>from second-tithe wheat</b> itself, <b>but he may bring</b> the loaves <b>from wheat purchased with second-tithe money.</b>
The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi Yirmeya was sitting before Rabbi Zeira, and he was sitting and saying:</b> The mishna <b>taught only</b> that the loaves may not be brought <b>from second-tithe wheat</b> itself, <b>but he may bring</b> the loaves <b>from wheat purchased from second-tithe money.</b> Rabbi Zeira <b>said to him: My teacher,</b> do <b>you say so? I say</b> that <b>he may not bring</b> the loaves <b>even from wheat purchased from second-tithe money. And I will say my reasoning and I will say your reasoning. I will say your reasoning</b> first: <b>From where do you derive</b> that the loaves of <b>a thanks offering</b> may be brought from wheat purchased with second-tithe money? You derive it from the <i>halakha</i> of <b>a peace offering.</b> A thanks offering is a type of peace offering, as the verse states: “And the flesh of the sacrifice of his peace offerings for thanks” (Leviticus 7:15), and a peace offering may be brought from second-tithe money.

Daf 82a

<b>And</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a peace offering</b> may be brought from second-tithe money is derived by a verbal analogy between <b>“there”</b> and <b>“there” from</b> the verse discussing second <b>tithe.</b> The verse states with regard to a peace offering: “And you shall sacrifice peace offerings and you shall eat there” (Deuteronomy 27:7), and the verse states with regard to second tithe: “And you shall eat before the Lord your God, in the place that He shall choose to cause His name to dwell there” (Deuteronomy 14:23). <b>And from this</b> it may be concluded: <b>Just as peace offerings are not themselves</b> brought from second <b>tithe,</b> as they are not produce, <b>so too</b> with regard to the loaves of <b>a thanks offering, they are not themselves</b> brought from second <b>tithe. And that wheat which is purchased with second-tithe money is also not itself</b> second <b>tithe;</b> it may therefore be used for the loaves of the thanks offering.
Now <b>I will say my reasoning</b> for why one may not prepare the loaves of a thanks offering with wheat that was purchased with second-tithe money: <b>From where do I derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a thanks offering</b> may be brought from second-tithe money? I derive it <b>from</b> the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>a peace offering. And</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a peace offering</b> may be brought from second-tithe money is derived by a verbal analogy between <b>“there”</b> and <b>“there” from</b> second <b>tithe.</b> Therefore, <b>just as a peace offering is not</b> of the same <b>species</b> as second <b>tithe, so too</b> the loaves of <b>a thanks offering</b> may <b>not</b> be of the same <b>species</b> as second <b>tithe.</b> This serves <b>to exclude wheat purchased with second-tithe money, which is</b> of the same <b>species</b> as second <b>tithe.</b>
§ <b>Rabbi Ami says:</b> In a case involving <b>one who designates second-tithe money for a peace offering,</b> the money does <b>not assume</b> the status of <b>a peace offering. What is the reason?</b> The reason is <b>that the sanctity of the peace offering is not strong</b> enough <b>to take effect upon</b> items that have <b>the sanctity of second tithe.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a mishna (<i>Ma’aser Sheni</i> 1:4): Ideally, one should use second-tithe money to purchase peace offerings. If one purchases a peace offering with second-tithe money, only the flesh of the animal is consecrated, while its hide is non-sacred. The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>one who</b> uses second-tithe money in an improper manner and <b>purchases an undomesticated animal for a peace offering,</b> a purpose for which an undomesticated animal cannot be used, <b>or</b> purchases <b>a domesticated animal for meat of desire,</b> i.e., ordinary meat, the Sages penalized him and decreed that <b>the hide does not become non-sacred.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Is that not to say that</b> the hide of the animal purchased with the second-tithe money <b>assumes</b> the status of <b>a peace offering,</b> and it must be sold and the money used to purchase a peace offering, in contradiction to the statement of Rabbi Ami?
The Gemara rejects this: <b>Wasn’t it stated concerning that</b> mishna that <b>Rav said:</b> The hide of the animal purchased with the second-tithe money does <b>not assume</b> the status of <b>a peace offering; and what</b> is the meaning of the mishna that <b>the hide does not become non-sacred? This</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> The hide, as part of an undomesticated animal, is <b>not in the category of</b> a peace offering at all so that its <b>hide would become non-sacred. What is the reason? Rabba says:</b> Since he used the second-tithe money in an improper manner, <b>it is considered as if he purchased an ox for plowing,</b> to which no sanctity of second tithe applies.
§ It <b>was stated</b> that there is an amoraic dispute with regard to <b>one who designates second-tithe money for a peace offering. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The money <b>assumes</b> the status of a peace offering, and <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> The money does <b>not assume</b> the status of a peace offering.
The Gemara elaborates: <b>And according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yehuda, who said:</b> Second <b>tithe is non-sacred property, everyone agrees that</b> the money <b>assumes</b> the status of a peace offering. <b>When they disagree,</b> it is <b>according to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Meir, who said:</b> Second <b>tithe is property</b> belonging to the <b>Most High. The one who says</b> that the money does <b>not assume</b> the status of a peace offering holds <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> and one may not designate property of the Most High for another purpose. <b>And the one who says</b> that the money <b>assumes</b> the status of a peace offering holds that <b>since</b> second <b>tithe is called a peace offering,</b> as an animal purchased with second-tithe money without specification is brought as a peace offering, <b>when he designates</b> the money for a peace offering, it <b>as well</b> is <b>designated</b> with the sanctity of a peace offering.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabbi Elazar from a <i>baraita</i>: In a case involving <b>one who designates second-tithe money for a peace offering,</b> the sanctity of a peace offering is applied to this money in addition to the sanctity of second tithe. Therefore, <b>when he redeems</b> this money, <b>he adds to it two-fifths:</b> One-fifth <b>for the</b> redemption of the <b>sacrificial</b> sanctity of a peace offering <b>and</b> one-fifth <b>for</b> the redemption of second <b>tithe.</b> Evidently, the sanctity of a peace offering does take effect on second-tithe money.
The Gemara responds: <b>Do you maintain</b> that this <i>baraita</i> <b>is agreed</b> upon <b>by everyone?</b> In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yehuda,</b> who holds that second-tithe money is non-sacred property. Accordingly, the sanctity of a <b>peace</b> offering takes effect on the money. Rabbi Elazar holds in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Meir.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>From where</b> is it derived with regard to <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering, that he may bring</b> it <b>only from non-sacred</b> money? It is derived from a verse, as <b>the verse states: “And you shall sacrifice the Paschal offering to the Lord your God, of the flock and the herd”</b> (Deuteronomy 16:2). The verse is difficult: <b>Doesn’t the Paschal offering come only from lambs and goats? If so, why does the verse state: “The flock and the herd”?</b> It is <b>to juxtapose all</b> offerings <b>that come from the flock and from the herd to</b> the <b>Paschal offering,</b> teaching that <b>just as</b> the <b>Paschal offering</b> is <b>a matter of obligation and comes only from non-sacred</b> money, <b>so too any matter of obligation comes only from non-sacred</b> money.
<b>Therefore,</b> in the case of <b>one who says: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering,</b> or: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a peace offering, since</b> these offerings <b>come</b> as <b>an obligation</b> due to his vow, <b>they may be brought only from non-sacred</b> money. <b>And libations, in any case, may be brought only from non-sacred</b> money, and not from second-tithe money, because second-tithe money must be used to purchase items eaten by people, while libations are poured out next to the altar.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that the <i>halakha</i> that any matter of obligation must be brought from non-sacred property is derived from the <i>halakha</i> of the Paschal offering. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> concerning <b>the Paschal offering itself, from where do we</b> derive that it is brought only from non-sacred property? <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Eliezer says: “Paschal offering” is stated</b> in the Torah <b>with regard to</b> the offering sacrificed in <b>Egypt</b> (see Exodus 12:3), <b>and “Paschal offering” is stated with regard to</b> the yearly obligation throughout the <b>generations</b> (see Exodus 12:25). Therefore, <b>just as the Paschal offering stated with regard to Egypt was brought only from non-sacred</b> property, as there was no second tithe in Egypt, <b>so too the Paschal offering stated with regard to</b> the obligation throughout the <b>generations may be brought only from non-sacred</b> property.
<b>Rabbi Akiva said to him: But does one derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible?</b> Does one derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations, when there exists the possibility of using second-tithe money, from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering sacrificed in Egypt, when there was no second tithe? Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him: Even though</b> it was <b>impossible</b> to bring the Paschal offering in Egypt from consecrated money, <b>it is a great proof, and we shall derive</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>from it.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva then presented a different logical derivation</b> to reject the proof of Rabbi Eliezer: One cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations from that of the Paschal offering in Egypt, as <b>what</b> is notable <b>about the Paschal offering</b> sacrificed in <b>Egypt?</b> It is notable in <b>that</b> it <b>did not require</b> the <b>placement of blood</b> on the altar nor that the <b>sacrificial portions</b> be consumed <b>by the altar.</b>

Daf 82b

Can <b>you say</b> the same <b>with</b> regard to <b>the Paschal offering</b> of the <b>generations, which requires</b> the <b>placement of blood</b> on the altar <b>and</b> that the <b>sacrificial portions</b> be consumed <b>by the altar?</b>
Rabbi Eliezer <b>said to him:</b> The Paschal offerings should be compared, <b>as the</b> verse <b>states</b> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations: “And it shall be when the Lord shall bring you into the land of the Canaanite, and the Hittite, and the Amorite, and the Hivite, and the Jebusite, which He swore to your fathers to give you, a land flowing with milk and honey, <b>that you shall perform this service in this month”</b> (Exodus 13:5). This indicates <b>that all the services of this month</b> for the generations <b>shall be like this,</b> the Paschal offering of Egypt.
The Gemara discusses the opinion of Rabbi Akiva: Initially, Rabbi Akiva rejects the statement of Rabbi Eliezer based on the claim that one cannot derive the possible from the impossible. He then rejects the statement of Rabbi Eliezer on a technicality, namely that the two Paschal offerings have different sacrificial requirements. The Gemara therefore challenges: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva, if he holds that one does not derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> then <b>let him stand by his statement.</b>
And <b>if he retracted</b> and conceded that one derives the possible from the impossible, <b>and</b> the fact <b>that he did not derive</b> the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations <b>from</b> the <i>halakha</i> of <b>the Paschal offering</b> in <b>Egypt is due to that refutation</b> that he proposed, i.e., that the Paschal offerings are different, then <b>the Paschal offering</b> that was sacrificed in the second year in <b>the wilderness will prove</b> that this refutation is incorrect. That offering did require placement of the blood and sacrificial portions on the altar, yet it was brought only from non-sacred money, as there were no tithes in the wilderness.
The Gemara explains: Rabbi Akiva <b>stated</b> this objection <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Eliezer.</b> He meant as follows: <b>According to my</b> opinion, <b>one does not derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> and this is a sufficient reason why one cannot derive the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations from the <i>halakha</i> of the Paschal offering in Egypt. And even <b>according to your</b> opinion, in <b>which you said</b> that <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> this comparison can be refuted: <b>What</b> is notable <b>about the Paschal offering</b> sacrificed in <b>Egypt?</b> It is notable in <b>that</b> it <b>did not require</b> the <b>placement of blood</b> on the altar nor that the <b>sacrificial portions</b> be consumed <b>by the altar.</b> Can <b>you say</b> the same <b>with regard to the Paschal offering</b> of the <b>generations, which requires</b> the <b>placement of blood</b> on the altar <b>and</b> that the <b>sacrificial portions</b> be consumed <b>by the altar?</b>
<b>And</b> in response to this, <b>Rabbi Eliezer said to him</b> that the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations should be derived from the <i>halakha</i> of the Paschal offering in Egypt, since the verse states with regard to the Paschal offering of the generations: <b>“That you shall keep</b> this service in this month.”
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why must <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> cite this verse? <b>Let him say to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>The Paschal offering</b> brought in <b>the wilderness will prove</b> that this refutation is incorrect, since it did require placement of the blood and consumption of sacrificial portions on the altar, yet it was brought only from non-sacred money.
The Gemara responds: Rabbi Eliezer <b>stated</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Akiva.</b> He meant as follows: <b>In my</b> opinion, <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible. And as</b> for <b>that refutation</b> that you raised, that the Paschal offering in Egypt and the Paschal offering of the generations have different sacrificial requirements, <b>the Paschal offering</b> of <b>the wilderness will prove</b> that this is not a valid refutation. <b>According to your</b> opinion, in <b>which you said</b> that <b>one does not derive</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> the verse states: <b>“That you shall keep</b> this service in this month,” indicating that the Paschal offering of the generations is compared to the Paschal offering in Egypt.
The Gemara challenges: <b>But even now, let</b> Rabbi Akiva <b>refute</b> this comparison by the same claim that one cannot derive the possible from the impossible. <b>Rav Sheshet says: That is to say</b> that <b>one cannot refute a juxtaposition,</b> i.e., one cannot refute such a derivation based on reasoning.
<b>And in the study hall [<i>uvetarbitza</i>]</b> they discussed the statement of the mishna that the <i>halakha</i> that all obligatory offerings must be brought from non-sacred property is derived from the Paschal offering of the generations, and <b>they said: But can a matter derived via juxtaposition,</b> i.e., the Paschal offering of the generations, whose <i>halakha</i> is derived by juxtaposition from the Paschal offering in Egypt, <b>again teach a matter via</b> another <b>juxtaposition?</b> The Gemara responds: This is not considered an instance of a matter derived by juxtaposition teaching a matter derived by another juxtaposition. Rather, the statement of the mishna that all offerings are juxtaposed to the Paschal offering <b>was stated in a general</b> manner, since <b>the entire Paschal offering is one matter.</b> The Paschal offering in Egypt and the Paschal offering of the generations are both referred to as a Paschal offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who rejects the proofs of Rabbi Eliezer, <b>from where does he</b> derive <b>that the Paschal offering comes only from non-sacred</b> money? The Gemara responds: Rabbi Akiva <b>derives it from that which Shmuel said in the name of Rabbi Eliezer:</b> It is stated: <b>“This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the inauguration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings”</b> (Leviticus 7:37). This verse connects all of the specified offerings, such that individual aspects of each offering are applicable to all of the offerings.
The Gemara details these aspects. The verse states: “Of the <b>burnt offering,”</b> to teach that all of the offerings are like a burnt offering in that <b>just as a burnt offering requires a utensil</b> in its preparation, <b>so too do all</b> animal offerings <b>require a utensil. What</b> is the <b>utensil? If we say</b> it is <b>a bowl,</b> a utensil used for collecting the blood, as is learned from the burnt offerings that were sacrificed at Mount Sinai, that cannot be correct, as a utensil for collecting blood does not need to be learned from a burnt offering. <b>With regard to communal peace offerings it is also written:</b> “And they offered burnt offerings, and they sacrificed peace offerings…<b>And Moses took half of the blood and put it in basins”</b> (Exodus 24:5–6).
<b>Rather,</b> the term utensil must be referring to <b>a knife,</b> as the slaughter may be performed only with a knife and not with a sharp stone or reed. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> with regard to <b>a burnt offering itself, from where do we</b> derive that it must be slaughtered with a knife? This is learned from <b>that which is written: “And Abraham stretched forth his hand, and took the knife to slaughter his son”</b> (Genesis 22:10); <b>and there,</b> Abraham was sacrificing <b>a burnt offering, as it is written: “And offered it up for a burnt offering instead of his son”</b> (Genesis 22:13).
The Gemara continues to expound the aforementioned verse (Leviticus 7:37). When the verse mentions <b>a meal offering,</b> it teaches that <b>just as a meal offering is eaten only by males of</b> the <b>priesthood</b> (see Leviticus 6:9–11), <b>so too are all</b> of the offerings mentioned in this verse <b>eaten only by males of</b> the <b>priesthood.</b> The Gemara asks: With regard to <b>what</b> offering <b>is it</b> that this <i>halakha</i> must be derived? <b>If</b> one suggests that it is with regard to the <b>sin offering and</b> the <b>guilt offering,</b>

Daf 83a

this <i>halakha</i> <b>is explicitly written</b> of them. With regard to the sin offering, it is stated: “Every male among the priests may eat it” (Leviticus 6:22), and with regard to the guilt offering, it is stated: “Every male among the priests may eat of it” (Leviticus 7:6).
<b>If</b> one suggests that the <i>halakha</i> must be derived with regard to <b>communal peace offerings,</b> i.e., the two lambs that were sacrificed as communal offerings on <i>Shavuot</i> together with the offering of the two loaves (see Leviticus 23:19), this <i>halakha</i> <b>is derived from</b> the <b>amplification of the verse</b> stated with regard to meal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings. The verse states: <b>“In a most sacred place shall you eat of it; every male may eat it”</b> (Numbers 18:10), and it is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse <b>teaches with regard to communal peace offerings that they are eaten only by males of priestly</b> families.
The Gemara explains: <b>It is</b> a dispute between <b><i>tanna’im</i>. There is</b> one <i>tanna</i> <b>who cites it,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that only males of priestly families may eat of the communal peace offering, <b>from here,</b> i.e., the precedent mentioned explicitly with regard to the meal offering; <b>and there is</b> one <i>tanna</i> <b>who cites it from there,</b> i.e., the amplification of the verse stated with regard to meal offerings, sin offerings, and guilt offerings.
The Gemara continues expounding the verse: “This is the law of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the inauguration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings.” <b>“Sin offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering,</b> whatever it touches <b>is sanctified through</b> the substance that becomes <b>absorbed, so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, whatever they touch <b>is sanctified through</b> the <b>absorbed</b> portions.
<b>“Guilt offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, a fetal sac and a placenta are not sacred within it,</b> because a guilt offering is always male and as such never holds a fetal sac or a placenta, <b>so too</b> for <b>any</b> of the offerings mentioned in the verse, <b>a fetal sac and a placenta are not sacred</b> if found <b>within it.</b> The Gemara notes: Evidently, this <i>tanna</i> <b>holds</b> that with regard to <b>offspring of sacrificial</b> animals, <b>they are sanctified</b> only <b>as they are</b> from the moment of their births, but not in utero. <b>And</b> he also holds that <b>one derives</b> the <b>possible from</b> the <b>impossible,</b> so that the <i>halakha</i> of a fetal sac and a placenta in the case of female animals may be derived from the <i>halakha</i> of a male animal.
<b>“Inauguration offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>inauguration offering,</b> the rams and the bread of which were brought during the seven days of inauguration of the Tabernacle and which the priests ate, <b>their leftovers</b> were disposed of <b>by incineration,</b> as is stated: “And if any of the flesh of the inauguration offering, or of the bread, remain until the morning, then you shall burn the remainder with fire” (Exodus 29:34), <b>and</b> there were <b>no living animals</b> counted <b>among their leftovers</b> disposed of <b>by incineration, so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned, <b>their leftovers are</b> disposed of <b>by incineration, and there are no living animals</b> counted <b>among their leftovers</b> disposed of <b>by incineration.</b> Accordingly, if one sanctifies two animals so that either one may be brought if the other is lost, when one animal is sacrificed, the surviving animal is not killed and incinerated.
<b>“Peace offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to the <b>peace offering,</b> its components may <b>render</b> components of the offering <b><i>piggul</i> and</b> are <b>rendered <i>piggul</i>, so too</b> with regard to <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, their components <b>render</b> components of the offering <b><i>piggul</i> and are rendered <i>piggul</i>.</b>
§ <b>It was taught in a <i>baraita</i> in the name of Rabbi Akiva</b> that the verse states: <b>“This is the law</b> of the burnt offering, of the meal offering, and of the sin offering, and of the guilt offering, and of the inauguration offering, and of the sacrifice of peace offerings” (Leviticus 7:37). From the term <b>“meal offering”</b> it is derived: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering,</b> whatever it touches <b>is sanctified through</b> the substance that becomes <b>absorbed,</b> as it is stated: “Whatever shall touch them shall be sacred” (Leviticus 6:11), <b>so too</b> for <b>all</b> offerings mentioned in this verse, whatever they touch <b>is sanctified through</b> the <b>absorbed</b> portions.
The Gemara notes: <b>And it was necessary to write</b> the <i>halakha</i> of absorption <b>with regard to a sin offering, and it was necessary to write</b> the <i>halakha</i> of absorption <b>with regard to a meal offering. As, had the Merciful One written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a meal offering,</b> I would say <b>that since it is soft, it is absorbed</b> and therefore sanctifies what it touches; <b>but</b> with regard to the meat of <b>a sin offering, I would say</b> that it does <b>not</b> sanctify what it touches. <b>And had the Merciful One written</b> this <i>halakha</i> only <b>with regard to a sin offering,</b> I would say that it is <b>because, on account of its fattiness, the meat penetrates [<i>kadeir</i>]</b> into whatever it touches and sanctifies it; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>a meal offering, I would say</b> that it does <b>not</b> sanctify what it touches. Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the Torah to write both.
The cited <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>“Sin offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as a sin offering is brought only from non-sacred</b> animals, <b>and</b> it is sacrificed specifically <b>in the daytime, and</b> its service must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand, so too all</b> offerings mentioned <b>are brought only from non-sacred</b> animals, <b>and</b> are sacrificed specifically <b>in the daytime, and</b> each one’s service must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand.</b>
<b>And</b> with regard to <b>a sin offering itself, from where do we</b> derive that it is brought only from non-sacred animals? <b>Rav Ḥisda said:</b> It is derived from a verse, <b>as the verse states: “And Aaron shall present the bull of the sin offering, which is his”</b> (Leviticus 16:11). This teaches that the animal must come <b>from his</b> cattle, <b>and not from</b> money with which the second <b>tithe</b> has been redeemed.
The Gemara asks: Why is it necessary to derive from the <i>halakha</i> of a sin offering that an offering is sacrificed <b>in the daytime?</b> Isn’t this principle <b>derived from</b> the expression: <b>“On the day of His commanding”</b> (Leviticus 7:38), which is understood to be referring to all offerings? The Gemara answers: Indeed, the <i>baraita</i> <b>cited</b> the principle from the model of a sin offering <b>for no reason [<i>kedi</i>],</b> and it was mentioned here on account of the other principles.
The Gemara asks: Why must the <i>baraita</i> teach that the <i>halakha</i> of the sin offering teaches that the rites of offerings must be performed <b>with</b> the priest’s <b>right hand?</b> Isn’t this <b>derived from</b> the statement <b>of Rabba bar bar Ḥana? As Rabba bar bar Ḥana says</b> that <b>Reish Lakish says:</b> In <b>any place</b> in the Torah <b>that it is stated</b> that an action is performed with <b>a finger, or</b> that it is performed by <b>priesthood,</b> the <i>halakha</i> is that the rite is performed <b>only</b> with the <b>right</b> hand. This is derived from the Torah’s statement with regard to the leper: “And the priest shall dip his right finger” (Leviticus 14:16). The Gemara answers: The <i>baraita</i> <b>cited</b> the principle from the model of a sin offering <b>for no reason,</b> since it is actually derived from Rabba bar bar Ḥana’s statement.
The cited <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>“Guilt offering”</b> teaches: <b>Just as</b> with regard to <b>a guilt offering, its bones</b> have no sanctity and <b>are permitted</b> for any use, <b>so too</b> with regard to <b>any</b> mentioned offering, <b>its bones are permitted.</b>
The mishna teaches that the verse that states: “And you shall sacrifice the Paschal offering to the Lord your God, of the flock and the herd” (Deuteronomy 16:2), indicates by juxtaposition that every obligatory offering, like the Paschal offering, may be brought only from non-sacred money. The Gemara therefore asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Akiva,</b> who derives this from the verse: “This is the law of…the sin offering,” <b>that</b> verse: <b>“And you shall sacrifice the Paschal offering,”</b>

Daf 83b

<b>what does he make of it,</b> i.e., what does he derive from it? <b>He requires it for that</b> which was stated <b>by Rav Naḥman, as Rav Naḥman says</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh says: From where</b> is it derived <b>that a leftover Paschal offering,</b> an animal consecrated but not ultimately sacrificed on Passover eve, <b>is sacrificed as a peace offering</b> afterward? It is derived from <b>that</b> which <b>is stated: “And you shall sacrifice the Passover offering unto the Lord, your God, of the flock and the herd.”</b> The verse is difficult: <b>But isn’t a Paschal offering brought only from the sheep and from the goats? Rather,</b> it is derived from here <b>that a leftover Paschal offering should be</b> sacrificed <b>as</b> an offering <b>brought</b> both <b>from the flock and from the herd,</b> i.e., a peace offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But is it derived from here</b> that a leftover Paschal offering is sacrificed as a peace offering? <b>It is derived from</b> the verse <b>that Shmuel’s father</b> cites: <b>As it is written:</b> “And <b>if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings</b> to the Lord <b>is of the flock”</b> (Leviticus 3:6); <b>and Shmuel’s father said:</b> This teaches that an offering <b>that is brought</b> only <b>from the flock,</b> i.e., the Paschal offering, <b>will be a sacrifice of peace offerings.</b>
<b>But still</b> it must be asked: <b>Is it derived from here? It is derived from there,</b> from the verse cited in the following <i>baraita</i>. <b>And isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Even though the verse already states that peace offerings come from the flock, as it is written: “And if his offering for a sacrifice of peace offerings to the Lord be of the flock, male or female, he shall sacrifice it without blemish” (Leviticus 3:6), the verse goes on to specify: “If he bring a lamb for his offering…and if his offering be a goat” (Leviticus 3:7–12). The word <b>“lamb”</b> is written <b>to include the Paschal offering in</b> the requirement that the <b>fat tail</b> be sacrificed on the altar, which is written subsequently with regard to a peace offering (Leviticus 3:9), since this <i>halakha</i> is not mentioned in the verses concerning the Paschal offering.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “If</b> he brings <b>a lamb,”</b> it is <b>to include in all the mitzvot of peace offerings a Paschal offering whose</b> first <b>year has passed</b> and is therefore too old to be sacrificed as a Paschal offering, <b>and peace offerings brought due to a Paschal offering.</b> Specifically, this indicates <b>that they require placing hands</b> on the head of the offering, <b>libations, and the waving of</b> the <b>breast and thigh.</b>
<b>And when</b> the verse <b>states:</b> “And <b>if</b> his offering is a <b>goat,” it interrupted the</b> previous <b>matter</b> and <b>taught that the</b> sacrifice of <b>a goat does not require</b> that the <b>fat tail</b> be burned on the altar. In any event, the verse indicates that a Paschal offering that was disqualified as such because it has reached its second year, i.e., the leftover of a Paschal offering, is sacrificed as a peace offering. It may therefore be asked: Why are there three verses to indicate this one <i>halakha</i>?
<b>Rather,</b> none of these derivations are superfluous, as <b>three verses are written</b> that teach the <i>halakha</i> that a Paschal offering that is sacrificed not on Passover eve is sacrificed as a peace offering. <b>One</b> verse teaches this <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice, Passover eve, <b>has passed, and its</b> first <b>year has</b> also <b>passed,</b> disqualifying it for sacrifice as a Paschal offering. <b>And one</b> verse teaches the <i>halakha</i> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice <b>has passed, but not its</b> first <b>year. And</b> the third <b>one</b> teaches a case where <b>neither its time</b> of sacrifice <b>nor its</b> first <b>year has passed,</b> but it was sacrificed before Passover eve.
<b>And</b> all these verses <b>are necessary. As had the Merciful One written</b> only the case <b>where</b> both <b>its</b> first <b>year and its time</b> of sacrifice <b>have passed,</b> one could say that only such a Paschal offering should be sacrificed as a peace offering, <b>as it was completely rejected from</b> its status as <b>a Paschal offering; but</b> in a case where <b>its time</b> of sacrifice <b>has passed but its</b> first <b>year</b> has <b>not</b> passed, in <b>which</b> case it is still <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed as a Paschal offering on the <b>second <i>Pesaḥ</i>, I would say</b> that it is <b>not</b> sacrificed as a peace offering.
<b>And if</b> the Torah <b>had taught us</b> only that a leftover Paschal offering <b>whose time has passed but whose year has not passed</b> is sacrificed as a peace offering, one might think that this is <b>because</b> the Paschal offering <b>was rejected from the first <i>Pesaḥ</i>; but</b> in a case <b>where neither its time</b> of sacrifice <b>nor its</b> first <b>year have passed,</b> in <b>which</b> case it is still <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed as <b>a Paschal offering</b> on Passover eve, <b>I would say</b> that it is <b>not</b> sacrificed as a peace offering. Therefore, all three verses <b>are necessary.</b>

<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All communal and individual</b> meal <b>offerings</b> may <b>come from</b> produce grown in <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael <b>and from outside Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>from the new</b> crop, i.e., the current year’s crop, <b>and from the old</b> crop from previous years. This is the <i>halakha</i> of all meal offerings <b>except for the <i>omer</i>,</b> i.e., the measure of barley brought as a communal offering on the sixteenth of Nisan, <b>and the two loaves,</b> i.e., the communal offering brought on the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, <b>as they come only from the new</b> crop <b>and from Eretz</b> Yisrael.
<b>And all</b> meal offerings <b>come only from the optimal-</b>quality grain. <b>And which</b> places have the <b>optimal</b> grain <b>for them?</b> Fields in <b>Makhnis and Zateḥa</b> are the <b>primary [<i>alfa</i>]</b> source <b>for fine flour. Secondary to them</b> is <b>Aforayim in the valley.</b>
A<b>ll the regions were valid</b> as the source of the grain<b>, but</b> it is <b>from here,</b> the primary and secondary places, that <b>they would bring</b> grain, because it was of optimal quality.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that the <i>omer</i> meal offering and the two loaves are prepared only from the new crop. The wording of the mishna indicates that this is an essential requirement. The Gemara notes: <b>The mishna is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>An <i>omer</i></b> meal offering <b>that comes from the old</b> crop is <b>valid.</b> Similarly, <b>the two loaves that come from the old</b> crop <b>are valid, but</b> by bringing them from the old crop one <b>lacks</b> the proper fulfillment of its <b>mitzva.</b>
The Gemara provides the biblical sources for the rulings of the <i>baraita</i>: The source for the ruling concerning the <b><i>omer</i></b> meal offering is <b>as it is written:</b> “And when you shall bring a meal offering of first fruits to the Lord, it is ripened grain, toasted over fire, even groats of the fresh ear, <b>you shall bring the meal offering of your first fruits”</b> (Leviticus 2:14). The superfluous repetition of the term “you shall bring” teaches that the <i>omer</i> is valid <b>even</b> if brought <b>from</b> an old crop that was stored away in <b>the attic.</b>
The source for the ruling concerning the <b>two loaves</b> is <b>as it is written:</b> “And you shall offer a new meal offering to the Lord. <b>From your dwellings you shall bring</b> two wave-loaves” (Leviticus 23:16–17). The term “your dwellings” is a reference to Eretz Yisrael. Therefore, the verse indicates that the two loaves must be brought from grain grown there, <b>and not from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. Furthermore, the term <b>“from your dwellings”</b> teaches that the offering may come from any grain grown in Eretz Yisrael <b>and even from</b> an old crop that was stored away in <b>the attic.</b>
The Gemara asks how two <i>halakhot</i> can be derived from the same term: <b>Didn’t you</b> already <b>expound that</b> term to teach that one can use grain only if it is grown in Eretz Yisrael? How can you also derive from it that the grain can be brought from an old crop? The Gemara explains: That is derived from the next term, as <b>the verse states:</b> “From your dwellings <b>you shall bring”</b> (Leviticus 23:17), which teaches that one may bring them from any grain grown in Eretz Yisrael <b>and even from</b> an old crop that was stored away in <b>the attic.</b>
The Gemara questions this answer: <b>But that</b> term <b>is necessary</b> to teach <b>that any</b> leavened bread offering <b>that you bring in another instance,</b> i.e., the loaves of the thanksgiving offering, <b>is to be like this</b> offering of the two loaves, i.e., the same requirements apply to it (see 77b). How, then, can you expound the term to also teach that grain from an old crop can be used for the two loaves? The Gemara explains: <b>If so,</b> that the term is written only to teach about the requirements for other leavened bread offerings, then <b>let the verse write: You shall bring [<i>tavi</i>],</b> using the singular form. For <b>what</b> reason then, does it write: <b>“You shall bring [<i>tavi’u</i>],”</b> using the plural form? It is written so that one can <b>learn from it two</b> different <i>halakhot</i>.
The Gemara questions the ruling of the <i>baraita</i> that the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves are valid even if brought from an old crop: <b>But isn’t</b> the term <b>“first” written</b> with regard to both the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves? This indicates they must come from the new crop. The <i>omer</i> is referred to as “the first of your harvest” (Leviticus 23:10), and the two loaves are referred to as “an offering of the first” (Leviticus 2:12). The Gemara answers: The term indicates that only the new crop should be used, but that is only <b>for</b> the proper fulfillment of the <b>mitzva.</b> If an old crop was used, the offerings are still valid.
The Gemara asks: But <b>isn’t it written</b> with regard to the two loaves: <b>“A new</b> meal offering” (Leviticus 23:16), which indicates that only the new crop can be used? The fact that with regard to the two loaves the Torah repeats this requirement twice suggests that it is indispensable. The Gemara answers: The word “new” cannot teach that the use of the new crop is essential, as <b>it is necessary for that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Natan and Rabbi Akiva said</b> that even if <b>the two loaves are brought from the old</b> crop, they are <b>valid. How do I realize</b> the meaning of: <b>“A new</b> meal offering”? This teaches that the two loaves <b>are to be the first of all the</b> other <b>meal offerings.</b> No other meal offerings may be brought from the new crop until the meal offering of the two loaves has been brought.
§ The Gemara defines the limits of the dispute between the mishna and <i>baraita</i>: <b>They disagree only with regard to</b> whether it is essential for the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves to be brought from <b>the new</b> crop.

Daf 84a

<b>But with regard to</b> the requirement to use grain grown in <b>Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>they do not disagree that</b> if <b>the <i>omer</i> and the two loaves</b> come <b>from Eretz</b> Yisrael, <b>indeed,</b> they are valid, but if they come <b>from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, they are <b>not</b> valid.
<b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion is this? <b>It is not in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>this</b> following <b><i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei, son of Rabbi Yehuda, says</b> that <b>the <i>omer</i></b> may <b>come from outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael. <b>How do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse that introduces the obligation to bring the <i>omer</i>: <b>“When you come into the land</b> which I give to you” (Leviticus 23:10)? This verse appears to indicate that the bringing of the <i>omer</i> is restricted to Eretz Yisrael. That verse teaches <b>that</b> the Jewish people <b>were not obligated in</b> the mitzva of bringing <b>the <i>omer</i> before they entered Eretz</b> Yisrael.
The Gemara explains the basis of Rabbi Yosei’s opinion: <b>And he holds</b> that even <b>outside of Eretz</b> Yisrael, consuming the <b>new</b> crop <b>is</b> prohibited <b>by Torah law, as it is written: “From all your dwellings”</b> (Leviticus 23:17), which <b>indicates</b> that the prohibition applies <b>anywhere that you dwell,</b> even outside of Eretz Yisrael. Accordingly, the earlier verse, which introduces the prohibition with: <b>“When you come</b> into the land which I give to you” (Leviticus 23:10), <b>is</b> a reference to <b>the time</b> of the Jewish people <b>entering</b> Eretz Yisrael, and it indicates that the prohibition takes effect only from that time. <b>And since</b> Rabbi Yosei holds that the new crop outside of Eretz Yisrael <b>is</b> prohibited for consumption <b>by Torah law,</b> he consequently holds that <b>one may also offer</b> the <i>omer</i> from crops grown there.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 4:1): The <b>guards</b> who are appointed by the court to protect some <b>of</b> the <b>produce that grew without being purposely planted [<i>sefiḥin</i>] during the Sabbatical</b> Year, in order that it can be used for the <i>omer</i> and the offering of the two loaves, <b>collect their wages from the collection of the</b> Temple treasury <b>chamber.</b>
<b>Rami bar Ḥama raises a contradiction to Rav Ḥisda: We learned</b> in that mishna that <b>the guards of <i>sefiḥin</i> during the Sabbatical</b> Year <b>collect their wages from the collection of the</b> Temple treasury <b>chamber.</b> This indicates that even in the Sabbatical Year, the <i>omer</i> is brought from that year’s crop. <b>And one can raise a contradiction</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And the Sabbatical Year of the land shall be for you <b>for eating”</b> (Leviticus 25:6), which indicates it is to be used for eating, <b>but not for burning.</b> Accordingly, since the <i>omer</i> is burned on the altar, it should not be brought from produce of the Sabbatical Year.
Rav Ḥisda <b>said to him: The Merciful One said to you</b> about the <i>omer</i>: “It is a statute forever <b>throughout your generations”</b> (Leviticus 23:14), indicating that the mitzva can be fulfilled in all times, <b>and you say</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>should be canceled</b> in a Sabbatical Year?
Rami bar Ḥama <b>said to him: But am I saying</b> that the <i>omer</i> <b>should be canceled?</b> Certainly not. <b>Let one bring</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>from</b> grain that sprouted during <b>the previous year,</b> concerning which there is no prohibition against burning it. Rav Ḥisda rejects this suggestion: But to fulfill the mitzva <b>I require that</b> the grain be of the <b>“fresh ear”</b> (Leviticus 2:14), i.e., young grain, <b>and</b> this requirement <b>is not</b> fulfilled with grain that sprouted during the previous year, as it has already been growing a long time.
Rami bar Ḥama persists: <b>But let one bring</b> the <i>omer</i> <b>from the young grain</b> that was cut during the harvest <b>of</b> the <b>previous year,</b> when it was still fresh. Rav Ḥisda rejects this suggestion: <b>The verse states: “Fresh ear, you shall bring”</b> (Leviticus 2:14). The juxtaposition of the mitzva to bring the grain with the requirement that it be young indicates that <b>I need</b> it to still be <b>young grain at the time of offering</b> it, <b>and</b> this condition <b>is not</b> fulfilled if one uses grain from the previous year’s harvest. Young grain is soft (see 66b), whereas grain that was reaped during the previous year would have become brittle.
§ An amoraic dispute <b>was stated</b> concerning the source of the <i>halakha</i> that the <i>omer</i> may not be brought from the previous year’s crop: <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> it is derived from: <b>“Fresh ear, you shall bring,”</b> as Rav Ḥisda explains. <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> it is derived from the fact that the <i>omer</i> is referred to as: <b>“The first of your harvest”</b> (Leviticus 23:10), which indicates that the <i>omer</i> is brought only from <b>the first of your harvest,</b> i.e., from the first produce of the current year’s crop, <b>and not from the last of your harvest,</b> i.e., from produce taken from the remainder of the previous year’s crop.
<b>Rabba raises an objection</b> to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion, from a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: <b>“And when you shall bring a meal offering of first fruits</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:14). <b>The verse is speaking of the <i>omer</i> meal offering. From which</b> type of grain <b>does it come?</b> It comes <b>from barley. Do you say</b> that it comes <b>from barley, or</b> does <b>it</b> come <b>only from wheat?</b>
<b>Rabbi Eliezer says</b> that it <b>is stated “in the ear,” with regard to</b> the plague of hail in <b>Egypt:</b> “And the flax and the barley were smitten; for the barley was in the ear, and the flax was in bloom” (Exodus 9:31), <b>and it is stated “in the ear”</b> with regard to the mitzva of the new crop, which is <b>for</b> all <b>generations. Just as</b> the term <b>“in the ear” that is stated with regard to</b> the plague of hail in <b>Egypt</b> is referring to <b>barley,</b> as is clear from the next verse: “But the wheat and the spelt were not smitten; for they ripen late” (Exodus 9:32), <b>so too</b> the term <b>“in the ear” that is stated</b> with regard to the new crop <b>for</b> all <b>generations</b> is referring to <b>barley.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> cites another proof that the <i>omer</i> offering is brought from barley. <b>And Rabbi Akiva says: We found an individual who brings his obligation</b> of a meal offering <b>from wheat,</b> which is brought by a poor person for a false oath of testimony, a false oath of utterance, or for entering the Temple while ritually impure, <b>and</b> one who brings <b>his obligation</b> of a meal offering <b>from barley,</b> in the case of a sinner’s meal offering or the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>. <b>And</b> we also found with regard to the <b>community that they bring their obligation</b> of a meal offering <b>from wheat,</b> in the case of the two loaves offering of <i>Shavuot</i>, and therefore, to keep the <i>halakha</i> of the offering of a community parallel to that of an individual there should be a case where the community <b>brings their obligation</b> of a meal offering <b>from barley. And if you say</b> that the <i>omer</i> offering <b>comes from wheat,</b> then <b>we</b> will <b>not</b> have <b>found</b> a case of <b>a community that brings their obligation</b> of a meal offering <b>from barley.</b> Consequently, it must be that the <i>omer</i> offering comes from barley.
Rabbi Akiva suggests another proof: <b>Alternatively, if you say</b> that the <b><i>omer</i></b> offering <b>comes from wheat,</b> then <b>the two loaves</b> offering would <b>not</b> be brought from the <b>first fruits.</b> The verse states that the two loaves offering of <i>Shavuot</i> should come from the first fruits: “Also in the day of the first fruits, when you bring a new meal offering to the Lord in your feast of weeks” (Numbers 28:26). If the <i>omer</i> is from wheat, then the two loaves offering would not be the first offering of the first fruit, as the <i>omer</i> offering of Passover precedes it. Therefore, the <i>omer</i> offering must come from barley. Rabba explains the objection to Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion: <b>Evidently,</b> the <i>omer</i> offering is brought from the new crop <b>because</b> the grain used is referred to as <b>first fruits,</b> i.e., “the first of your harvest.” The Gemara concludes: This <i>baraita</i> is <b>a conclusive refutation</b> of Rabbi Yoḥanan’s opinion.
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>elsewhere</b> (<i>Bikkurim</i> 1:3): <b>One may bring first fruits only from the seven species</b> with which Eretz Yisrael is praised in the verse: “A land of wheat and barley, vines, figs and pomegranates, a land of olive oil and honey” (Deuteronomy 8:8). <b>But</b> one may <b>not</b>

Daf 84b

bring them <b>from dates that</b> grow <b>in the mountains, and</b> one may <b>not</b> bring them <b>from produce that</b> grows <b>in the valleys.</b> Such produce is of inferior quality and may not be used. <b>Ulla says:</b> Even <b>if one did bring</b> such produce, <b>he does not</b> thereby <b>consecrate</b> it, i.e., it does not attain the consecrated status of first fruits.
<b>Rabba sat</b> in the study hall <b>and stated this <i>halakha</i>. Rabbi Aḥa bar Abba raised an objection to Rabba</b> from a <i>baraita</i>: The Torah refers to the two loaves offering as: <b>“A first offering</b> to the Lord” (Leviticus 2:11), which indicates <b>that it is to be the first of all the meal offerings</b> that come from the new crop. <b>And similarly</b> the verse <b>states</b> with regard to the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>: “On the day of the first fruits, <b>when you bring a new meal offering to the Lord”</b> (Numbers 28:26). By designating the two loaves as “new,” the verse indicates that they should be brought from the first of the new crop.
<b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that it must be <b>new,</b> i.e., the first, <b>of</b> all <b>wheat</b> meal offerings. <b>From where</b> do I derive that it must also be <b>new,</b> i.e., the first, <b>of</b> all <b>barley</b> meal offerings, e.g., the meal offering of a <i>sota</i>? With regard to the two loaves, <b>the verse states</b> the word <b>“new,”</b> and again states the word <b>“new,”</b> once in Numbers 28:26 and again in Leviticus 23:16. <b>If</b> the second mention <b>is not</b> needed to teach the <b>matter of</b> being the <b>new</b> meal offering <b>of wheat, apply it to the matter of</b> being the <b>new</b> meal offering <b>of barley.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the two loaves <b>precede</b> the bringing of the <b>first fruits</b> as well? <b>The verse states: “And you shall make for yourself a festival of <i>Shavuot</i>, the first fruits of the wheat harvest”</b> (Exodus 34:22). The order of the verse teaches that the offering of the Festival, which is the two loaves offering, precedes the bringing of the first fruits of the wheat harvest. <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the two loaves precede the <b>first fruits of the wheat harvest. From where</b> do I derive that they also precede the bringing of the first fruits of <b>the barley harvest? The verse states</b> with regard to the festival of <i>Shavuot</i>: <b>“And the festival of the harvest, the first fruits of your labors, which you will sow in the field”</b> (Exodus 23:16). The order of the verse teaches that the offering of the Festival, which is the two loaves offering, precedes all forms of first fruits that are sown in the field, which includes barley.
From this verse, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the two loaves precede the bringing of the first fruits <b>that</b> sprouted from seeds <b>you sowed,</b> as the verse states: “Which you will sow.” <b>From where</b> do I derive that they precede even the bringing of first fruits <b>that sprouted by themselves? The</b> continuation of that <b>verse states: “In the field”</b> (Exodus 23:16). The term is superfluous and serves to include even produce that sprouted by itself.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: From this verse, <b>I have</b> derived <b>only</b> that the two loaves precede the bringing of produce that grew <b>in a field. From where</b> do I derive <b>to include</b> even produce <b>that</b> grew <b>on a roof, or that</b> grew <b>in a ruin, or that</b> grew <b>in a flowerpot, or that</b> grew <b>on a ship? The verse states</b> with regard to the priestly gifts: <b>“The first fruit of all that grows in their land,</b> which they shall bring to the Lord, shall be yours” (Numbers 18:13). The term “first fruits” in this verse is referring to all types of first fruits. This teaches that when the two loaves are referred to as the first fruits (see Exodus 34:22), the intention is that they should be brought first before all other types of produce.
The <i>baraita</i> concludes: <b>From where</b> is it derived <b>that</b> the offering of the two loaves <b>is to precede</b> both <b>the</b> bringing of <b>libations</b> from grapes of the new crop <b>and</b> the bringing of the first <b>fruits of the tree? It is stated here,</b> with regard to the two loaves: <b>“The first fruits of your labors”</b> (Exodus 23:16), <b>and it is stated there</b> at the end of that verse: <b>“When you gather in the products of your labors from the field.” Just as there,</b> the term “your labors” is referring both to fruits used for <b>the libations and the fruit of the tree, so too, here,</b> the term is referring to both fruits used for <b>the libations and the fruit of the tree.</b>
Rabbi Aḥa bar Abba explains how the <i>baraita</i> poses a challenge to Ulla’s ruling: <b>In any event, it was taught</b> in this <i>baraita</i> that bringing the two loaves must precede even the bringing of produce <b>that</b> grew <b>on a roof, that</b> grew <b>in a ruin, that</b> grew <b>in a flowerpot, or that</b> grew <b>on a ship.</b> This indicates that all these types of produce are valid to be brought as first fruits, despite the fact that they are of inferior quality. This would appear to contradict Ulla’s ruling that dates that grow in the mountains and produce grown in the valleys are not fit to be brought as first fruits.
