So, for example, to calculate one-half of a <i>hin</i>, Moses filled the vessel of one <i>hin</i> and divided it equally into two vessels. Then, to calculate one-quarter of a <i>hin</i>, he would equally divide the liquid in one of those vessels into another two vessels. When pouring from a large vessel into a smaller one, the overflow on the outer walls of the larger vessel does not enter the smaller vessel but instead falls to the ground. Therefore, the <b>overflow is excluded</b> from the calculation. Accordingly, there is no basis to say that the overflow is consecrated.
<b>Abaye said: Everyone,</b> both Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Meir, agrees that with regard to the <b>overflow of measuring vessels, one could say</b> that <b>they are consecrated and one could say</b> that <b>they are not consecrated,</b> i.e., their dispute is unrelated to this issue. <b>But here they disagree with regard to</b> the meaning of the term <b>“full”</b> in the verse: “And his offering was one silver dish, its weight was one hundred and thirty shekels, one silver basin of seventy shekels, after the shekel of the Sanctuary; both of them full of fine flour mixed with oil for a meal offering” (Numbers 7:13).
<b>The one who said</b> that the vessels should be listed <b>in descending</b> order of size, i.e., Rabbi Meir, <b>holds</b> that the term <b>“full”</b> indicates that the size of each vessel should be exact, i.e., <b>that it should</b> hold <b>neither less nor more</b> than the prescribed amount. If one calculates the various sizes by first filling a vessel of the largest size, one <i>hin</i>, and then dividing its contents carefully between two smaller vessels and so on, one will arrive at accurate measurements. By contrast, if one starts with the smallest size and uses it multiple times to calculate larger quantities, then each time one pours he includes the overflow of the smaller vessel, and so the quantities calculated are slightly larger than prescribed.
<b>And the one who said</b> that the vessels should be listed <b>in ascending</b> order of size, i.e., Rabbi Yehuda, <b>holds</b> that the intention of the term <b>“full”</b> is that the size of each vessel <b>should not</b> hold <b>less</b> than the prescribed amount, <b>but</b> if <b>it</b> holds <b>more,</b> that <b>is</b> still <b>called full.</b> Accordingly, the various quantities can be calculated by starting with the smallest vessel.
In the mishna and the <i>baraita</i> cited above <b>the Master said</b> that in contrast to the opinion of the Rabbis, <b>Rabbi Shimon says: There was no</b> vessel <b>there</b> in the Temple that held one <b><i>hin</i>,</b> as what purpose could a one-<i>hin</i> vessel serve? That volume of liquid was never used in an offering. The Gemara comments: <b>Rabbi Shimon is saying well to the Rabbis,</b> i.e., this is a reasonable objection. <b>And</b> what would <b>the Rabbis</b> say? Why is there a measuring vessel of one <i>hin</i>? The Gemara answers: <b>It was</b> the vessel of one <b><i>hin</i> that Moses fashioned</b> in the wilderness <b>for</b> measuring the <b>anointing oil</b> with which the Tabernacle, its vessels, and the priests were anointed, <b>as it is written: “And of olive oil a <i>hin</i>.</b> And you shall make it a holy anointing oil” (Exodus 30:24–25).
The Gemara explains the dispute between Rabbi Shimon and the Rabbis. One <b>Sage,</b> Rabbi Shimon, <b>holds</b> that <b>since there was no</b> further <b>need</b> for the vessel of one <i>hin</i> <b>in</b> future <b>generations,</b> Moses <b>fashioned it</b> only <b>for</b> the sake of that <b>time, and</b> then afterward <b>it was sequestered. And the other</b> Sage, the Rabbis, holds that <b>since it was</b> fashioned and used in the time of Moses, <b>it was</b> kept in the Temple despite the fact there was no longer a need for it.
<b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i> that after claiming that there was no vessel of one <i>hin</i>, Rabbi Shimon asked: If so, <b>which</b> size vessel shall <b>I bring in its stead</b> to complete the tally of seven vessels? The Gemara asks: <b>Is it not possible to</b> simply <b>not include</b> a seventh vessel? What compels him to list a seventh? The Gemara explains: It is just <b>as Ravina said</b> with regard to a different matter: It <b>is learned</b> as a tradition that there are <b>two</b> instances in which <b>placing hands</b> on the head of the offering is required <b>for communal</b> offerings. <b>Here too,</b> one must say that it <b>is learned</b> as a tradition that <b>there were seven measuring vessels for liquids in the Temple.</b>
The mishna teaches: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says:</b> It was not necessary to have separate vessels for the meal offerings and libations of each type of animal. Rather, <b>there were graduations on</b> the vessel that held one <b><i>hin</i></b> indicating the measures for the various offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>But doesn’t</b> Rabbi Eliezer, son of Rabbi Tzadok, <b>have</b> the tradition that there were <b>seven measuring vessels?</b> The Gemara concedes: <b>He does not have</b> that tradition. <b>And if you wish, say</b> instead that he has that tradition, but he understands that <b>what</b> is meant by <b>seven measuring vessels?</b> It means that <b>seven</b> fixed ways of <b>measuring</b> should exist, but not that there must be seven different vessels.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>What</b> purpose <b>did</b> the <b>quarter-</b><i>log</i> measuring vessel <b>serve?</b> It was used to measure <b>a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of water for</b> the purification of <b>the leper, and a quarter-</b><i>log</i> <b>of oil for</b> the wafers and loaves that <b>the nazirite</b> brings on the day that his term of naziriteship ends.
<b>What</b> purpose <b>did</b> the <b>half</b>-<i>log</i> measuring vessel <b>serve?</b> It was used to measure <b>a half-</b><i>log</i> <b>of water for</b> the rite of <b>the <i>sota</i> and a half-</b><i>log</i> <b>of oil for</b> the three types of loaves of <i>matza</i> accompanying <b>the thanks offering.</b>
<b>And with</b> the vessel of one <b><i>log</i>, one would measure</b> the oil <b>for all the</b> standard <b>meal offerings.</b>
Each tenth of an ephah of flour requires one <i>log</i> of oil. Accordingly, <b>even</b> if one brings <b>a meal offering of sixty tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>one adds to it sixty <i>log</i></b> of oil. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> Each meal offering, irrespective of its volume, <b>even a meal offering of sixty tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, requires <b>only its</b> single <b><i>log</i></b> of oil, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to the offering brought by a poor leper on the day of his purification: “And a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil <b>for a meal offering, and a <i>log</i> of oil”</b> (Leviticus 14:21). The juxtaposition of “a meal offering” with “a <i>log</i> of oil” teaches a principle for all meal offerings: Each offering requires only one <i>log</i> of oil.
The mishna lists the quantities of oil and wine that were required for the meal offerings and libations that accompanied the sacrifice of an animal. <b>Six</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one<b>-</b>half of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a bull; and four</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one-third of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a ram; and three</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one-quarter of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a lamb.</b>
In addition, <b>three and a half</b> <i>log</i> of oil were required <b>for the Candelabrum,</b> as there were seven lamps and <b>a half-<i>log</i></b> was required <b>for each lamp.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>was sitting</b> in study <b>and posed a difficulty: For what</b> purpose <b>was</b> the <b>quarter-</b><i>log</i> measuring vessel <b>anointed</b> with the anointing oil, thereby consecrating it a service vessel? <b>If</b> you suggest it was necessary in order to measure the water used in the purification of <b>a leper,</b>

Daf 88b

one can counter that the rite <b>is</b> performed <b>outside</b> the Temple, and so it does not require a service vessel. <b>And if</b> you suggest it was for measuring the oil for the loaves of <b>a nazirite,</b> one can counter that the <b>loaves of a nazirite are consecrated through the slaughter of</b> the <b>ram</b> he brings, and there is no need for the oil to have been consecrated through a service vessel.
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said to</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: The consecration of the quarter-<i>log</i> measuring vessel was necessary, <b>as with it one would measure</b> oil <b>for</b> the <b>High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, as <b>a quarter</b>-<i>log</i> <b>of oil</b> is used <b>for each and every loaf.</b> In praise for resolving his difficulty, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>read</b> the verse <b>about</b> Rabbi Ḥiyya, who had traveled from Babylonia to join Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi in Eretz Yisrael: <b>“The man of my counsel from a far country”</b> (Isaiah 46:11).
§ The mishna teaches: <b>What</b> purpose <b>did</b> the <b>half-<i>log</i></b> measuring vessel <b>serve?</b> It was used to measure a half-<i>log</i> of water for the <i>sota</i> and a half-<i>log</i> of oil for the thanks offering. The Gemara relates: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>was sitting</b> in study <b>and posed a difficulty: For what</b> purpose <b>was</b> the <b>half-<i>log</i></b> measuring vessel <b>anointed</b> with the anointing oil, thereby consecrating it a service vessel? <b>If</b> you suggest it was necessary in order to measure the water used in the rite of the <b><i>sota</i>,</b> one can counter: <b>Is</b> the water that was used <b>non-sacred</b> such <b>that it is necessary to consecrate</b> it? Isn’t <b>it written:</b> “And the priest shall take <b>holy water</b> in an earthen vessel” (Numbers 5:17)? And <b>if</b> you suggest that it was for measuring the oil for the loaves of <b>a thanks offering,</b> one can counter that the <b>loaves of a thanks offering are consecrated through the slaughter of</b> the <b>thanks offering,</b> and so there is no need for the oil to have been consecrated through a service vessel.
<b>Rabbi Shimon, son of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>said to</b> his father: The consecration of the half-<i>log</i> measuring vessel was necessary, <b>as with it one would distribute a half-<i>log</i> of oil to each and every lamp</b> of the Candelabrum. Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to</b> his son in praise: <b>Lamp of Israel!</b> Indeed, <b>that was</b> its use.
§ Apropos the lamps of the Candelabrum, the Gemara relates that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> If there is <b>a lamp whose</b> flame <b>went out</b> during the night, <b>the oil</b> in the lamp <b>is</b> halakhically <b>rendered as ashes</b> and <b>the wick is rendered as ashes,</b> and they may no longer be used. <b>How</b> should the priest <b>act? He removes the ashes,</b> i.e., the oil and wick, from the lamp, <b>and puts</b> new <b>oil</b> and a new wick <b>into it and kindles it.</b>
<b>Rav Zerika was sitting</b> and studying this <i>halakha</i> <b>and raised a dilemma: When</b> the priest <b>puts oil</b> in the lamp, does he fill it <b>with</b> the <b>same quantity</b> of oil that was <b>initially</b> used, i.e., a half-<i>log</i>, <b>or</b> does he just fill it <b>with</b> an amount <b>equal to what it</b> now <b>lacks,</b> in order to replace the oil that was removed?
<b>Rabbi Yirmeya said:</b> It is <b>obvious that</b> he fills it <b>with</b> the <b>same quantity</b> of oil that was <b>initially</b> used, <b>as, if</b> he were to fill <b>with</b> an amount <b>equal to what it</b> now <b>lacks,</b> there would be a difficulty: <b>How do we know how much</b> oil it <b>lacks? And if you would say that</b> the priest <b>calculates it</b> using a measuring vessel, one could counter that <b>if so,</b> there would not be only <b>seven measuring vessels</b> for liquids; rather, <b>there would</b> have to be <b>many more measuring vessels</b> of a whole range of volumes.
In praise for resolving his difficulty, Rabbi Zerika <b>read</b> the verse <b>about</b> Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>“And in your majesty prosper, ride on, on behalf of truth and meekness and righteousness”</b> (Psalms 45:5).
An amoraic ruling <b>was also stated</b> in accordance with the explanation of Rabbi Yirmeya: <b>Rabbi Abbahu says</b> that <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says, and some say</b> that <b>Rabbi Abba says</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥanina says</b> that <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> If there is <b>a lamp whose</b> flame <b>went out</b> during the night, <b>the oil</b> in the lamp <b>is rendered as ashes</b> and <b>the wick is rendered as ashes,</b> and they may no longer be used. <b>How</b> should the priest <b>act? He removes the ashes,</b> i.e., the oil and wick, from the lamp, <b>and puts into it oil of</b> the <b>same quantity</b> that was <b>initially</b> used, with a new wick, <b>and kindles it.</b>
§ <b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Yehuda, says</b> that <b>Rav Sheshet says:</b> Each <b>lamp of</b> the Candelabrum <b>in the Temple was movable,</b> as the branches holding it were thin and flexible. They could therefore be bent over in order to tip out any ashes, remaining oil, or wicks from the lamps. The basis for his opinion is the verse: “And you shall make a Candelabrum of pure gold, of beaten work the Candelabrum shall be made, its base, and its shaft; its cups, its knobs, and its flowers, will be from it…of a talent of pure gold it shall be made” (Exodus 25:31, 39).
The Gemara explains that Rav Sheshet <b>holds</b> that <b>when it is written</b> that the Candelabrum is to be fashioned from a single <b>talent</b> of gold, <b>and</b> that it <b>be beaten</b> into its form, <b>it is written with regard to</b> both the frame of <b>Candelabrum and</b> each of <b>its lamps,</b> i.e., they must all be fashioned together from a single piece of gold beaten into its form. Perforce, the lamps must have been movable, because <b>since it is necessary to remove the ashes</b> from the lamps, <b>were</b> each lamp <b>not movable, it would not be</b> possible <b>to remove the ashes.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to Rav Sheshet’s opinion from a <i>baraita</i>: <b>How</b> would the priest <b>act</b> when removing the ashes from the lamps? <b>He</b> would <b>remove</b> the lamps from the Candelabrum <b>and place them in the Tent</b> of Meeting, i.e., the Sanctuary, <b>and scrub them with a sponge [<i>bisfog</i>]</b> to remove any remaining oil. <b>And</b> then he would <b>put</b> fresh <b>oil into them and kindle them.</b> Evidently, the lamps and the frame of the Candelabrum were separate parts.
The Gemara explains that there is a dispute between <i>tanna’im</i> concerning this issue and Rav Sheshet <b>states</b> his opinion <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>that <i>tanna</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The Rabbis say</b> that when removing the ashes, the priest <b>would not move</b> the lamp <b>from its place;</b> rather, he would remove the ashes while the lamp was still attached to the frame.
The Gemara raises a difficulty: But <b>from the fact</b> that the <i>baraita</i> states that the priest would not move the lamp from its place, it would appear <b>that if one wanted to move it, he was able to move it</b> from its place. Apparently, then, the lamps were independent parts. The Gemara explains: <b>Rather,</b> emend the <i>baraita</i> to <b>say:</b> The lamp <b>would not move from its place,</b> as the lamps were not independent removable parts but were formed together with the frame from a single piece of gold.
The Gemara asks: <b>And whose</b> opinion is expressed by <b>the Rabbis</b> in the <i>baraita</i>? <b>It is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Elazar, as it is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Elazar, son of Rabbi Tzadok, says: There was a kind of gold plate [<i>tas</i>] for</b> each lamp, which was placed <b>on top of it</b> and which served as a cover for the lamp. The plate was attached to one side of the lamp, to the lamp’s head, and the wick emerged from the other side, from the lamp’s mouth. <b>When</b> the priest <b>would</b> come to <b>remove the ashes</b> from the lamp, <b>he would</b> first <b>push</b> up on the part of the plate <b>at the mouth of</b> the lamp, thereby exposing its contents. The lamp would then be bent over and its contents tipped out. And <b>when he would</b> come to <b>place</b> fresh <b>oil</b> and a wick <b>in</b> the lamp, <b>he would</b> place the new wick at its mouth and then <b>push</b> down on the plate <b>at the head of</b> the lamp, thereby closing it, then he would straighten it up and pour in the oil through a hole in the middle of the plate.
The Gemara comments: <b>And</b> whether or not the lamps were independent removable parts <b>is the subject of a dispute</b> between <b>these</b> following <b><i>tanna’im</i>, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: Both the frame of the <b>Candelabrum and its lamps are produced</b> together <b>from the</b> same <b>talent</b> of gold. <b>But its tongs and its pans,</b> which were the implements used for removing the ashes, <b>were not</b> fashioned <b>from that</b> same gold <b>talent. Rabbi Neḥemya says:</b> Only the frame of the <b>Candelabrum is produced from the talent</b> of gold, <b>but its lamps and its tongs and its pans are not produced from that</b> same gold <b>talent;</b> rather, they are formed independently. The lamps are then positioned on the frame, but can still be removed from it.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what do</b> these <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree?</b> The Gemara explains: They disagree <b>with regard to</b> the exposition of <b>this verse, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: From the verse: <b>“Of a talent of pure gold it shall be fashioned</b> with all these vessels” (Exodus 25:39), <b>we learned about the</b> frame of the <b>Candelabrum that</b> it <b>is produced from the</b> gold <b>talent. From where</b> is it derived <b>to include its lamps,</b> that they should also be fashioned together with the frame from the same talent? <b>The verse states:</b> “It shall be fashioned <b>with all these vessels.”</b> This indicates that not only the frame, but also additional parts should be fashioned from the same talent. If so, one <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even its tongs and its pans.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “It</b> shall be fashioned.” The additional word “it” teaches that only the frame and the lamps are to be fashioned from the gold talent. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Neḥemya.</b>
The Gemara interrupts the citation of the <i>baraita</i> and notes that the <b>statement of Rabbi Neḥemya</b> in this <i>baraita</i>, in which he claims the lamps were fashioned from the talent with the frame, is <b>difficult,</b> as it is contradicted <b>by</b> the <b>statement of Rabbi Neḥemya</b> in the other <i>baraita</i>, in which he claims the lamps were independent parts. The Gemara explains: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Neḥemya.</b>
The Gemara resumes its citation of the <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yehoshua ben Korḥa says:</b> Only the frame of the <b>Candelabrum was produced from the talent</b> of gold, <b>but its tongs and its pans and its lamps were not produced from the talent. Rather, how do I realize</b> the meaning of the verse: “Of a talent of pure gold it shall be fashioned <b>with all these vessels”?</b> It teaches only <b>that</b> all the <b>vessels</b> associated with the Candelabrum <b>were</b> made <b>of gold,</b> even though they were not fashioned from the same gold talent from which the Candelabrum and its lamps were.
The Gemara questions the need for the derivation of the <i>baraita</i>: But the requirement that the vessels be made of <b>gold is explicitly written in</b> the verse: <b>“And you shall fashion its lamps seven, and they shall kindle its lamps, and it will enlighten toward its face. And its tongs and its pans shall be of pure gold”</b> (Exodus 25:37–38); why then is it necessary for the <i>baraita</i> to derive this from the phrase “with all these vessels”? The Gemara explains: This derivation of the <i>baraita</i> <b>is necessary only to</b> teach that the same applies <b>to</b> the <b>mouth of</b> the <b>lamps,</b> where the wicks rest. Otherwise, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since</b> the <b>mouth of</b> the <b>lamps blackens</b> and is damaged by the burning wick, therefore the principle that <b>the Torah spared the money of the Jewish people</b> should be applied,

Daf 89a

<b>and</b> consequently, <b>let</b> the mouth of the lamps <b>be fashioned from gold of any</b> quality, not necessarily from pure gold. Therefore, the <i>baraita</i> <b>teaches us</b> that even the mouth of the lamps must be fashioned from pure gold.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>A half-<i>log</i> of oil</b> was used to measure oil <b>for the thanks offering.</b> The thanks offering was accompanied by four different types of loaves; three types were unleavened and one was leavened, as the verse states: “If he offers it for a thanks offering, than he shall offer with the sacrifice of thanks offering: Unleavened loaves mixed with oil; and unleavened wafers spread with oil; and poached fine flour, loaves mixed with oil. With loaves of leavened bread he shall present his offering, with the sacrifice of his peace offerings for a thanks offering” (Leviticus 7:12–13).
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Akiva says: Why</b> must <b>the verse state: “With oil,” “with oil,”</b> writing it <b>twice;</b> why was the first time not sufficient? Because <b>were</b> the term <b>“with oil” stated only once, I would have said</b> that, with regard to the amount of oil required, the meal offerings that accompany the thanks offerings <b>are like all</b> other <b>meal offerings to</b> the extent that they require one <b><i>log</i></b> of oil. <b>Now that</b> the verse <b>wrote “with oil,” “with oil,” it constitutes</b> one <b>amplification following</b> another <b>amplification, and</b> the principle is that one <b>amplification following</b> another <b>amplification</b> serves <b>only to restrict</b> the extent of the <i>halakha</i>. Accordingly, in this case <b>the verse restricted</b> the amount of oil used in the three types of unleavened meal offerings <b>to a half-<i>log</i></b> for all of them together.
The Gemara interjects the citation of the <i>baraita</i> to ask: Is this a case of one <b>amplification following</b> another <b>amplification?</b> It would appear that there is only <b>one amplification,</b> as according to the <i>baraita</i> the first mention of the term “with oil” is necessary to teach the basic requirement that the meal offerings of the thanks offering require oil, like other meal offerings. How then can it be considered an amplification?
<b>Rather,</b> Rabbi Akiva’s statement should be emended, as follows: <b>Were</b> the term <b>“with oil,” not written at all, I would</b> still <b>have said</b> that the thanks offering meal offerings <b>are like all</b> other <b>meal offerings to</b> the extent that they requires one <b><i>log</i></b> of oil. <b>Now that</b> the verse <b>wrote “with oil,” “with oil,” it constitutes</b> one <b>amplification following</b> another <b>amplification, and</b> the principle is that one <b>amplification following</b> another <b>amplification</b> serves <b>only to restrict</b> the extent of the <i>halakha</i>. Accordingly, in this case <b>the verse restricted</b> the amount of oil used in the three types of unleavened meal offerings <b>to a half-<i>log</i></b> for all three together.
The Gemara resumes its citation of the <i>baraita</i>: Once it has been established that the meal offerings require only a half-<i>log</i> of oil, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>this half-<i>log</i> should be</b> equally <b>divided between</b> the <b>three types</b> of unleavened meal offerings, i.e., one-sixth of a <i>log</i> <b>for</b> the <b>loaves,</b> one-sixth <b>for</b> the <b>wafers, and</b> one-sixth <b>for</b> the <b>poached</b> loaves. <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “With oil,” with regard to</b> the <b>poached</b> loaves, that is seemingly superfluous, <b>as</b> there is <b>no</b> need for <b>the verse to state</b> the requirement to use part of the half-<i>log</i> of oil, being that this requirement has already been established. It must therefore serve to <b>amplify</b> the amount of <b>oil</b> used <b>for a poached</b> loaf as opposed to the other two types. <b>How so? One brings a half-<i>log</i> of oil and divides it</b> equally into two. <b>Half of it</b> is further divided and used both <b>for</b> the ten regular <b>loaves and for</b> the ten <b>wafers, and</b> the other <b>half of it</b> is used entirely <b>for</b> the ten <b>poached</b> loaves.
<b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya said to</b> Rabbi Akiva: <b>Akiva,</b> even <b>if you</b> were to <b>amplify</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>the entire day</b> from the terms <b>“with oil,” “with oil,” I</b> would <b>not listen to you</b> and accept your claims. <b>Rather,</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a half-<i>log</i> of oil</b> is required <b>for</b> the <b>thanks offering, and</b> similarly, the <i>halakha</i> that <b>a quarter-<i>log</i> of oil</b> is required <b>for</b> the loaves of <b>a nazirite, and</b> the <i>halakha</i> that a woman who experiences an emission of blood during the <b>eleven days that are between</b> one seven-day period of <b>menstruation</b> and the next period of <b>menstruation</b> is a <i>zava</i>, each of these is <b>a <i>halakha</i></b> transmitted <b>to Moses from Sinai;</b> they are not derived from verses.
§ The mishna states that with the vessel of one <b><i>log</i> one would measure</b> the oil for all the standard meal offerings. It then cites a dispute between the Rabbis, who hold that one <i>log</i> of oil is required for each tenth of an ephah of flour used, and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, who holds that each meal offering, irrespective of its size, requires only one <i>log</i> of oil.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>With regard to a poor leper,</b> who cannot afford the standard offerings that are required as part of the purification process and is instead required to bring one lamb as a guilt offering and a tenth of an ephah of flour as a meal offering, <b>it is written:</b> “And <b>a tenth</b>-<b>part</b> of an ephah of fine flour <b>mixed</b> with oil for a meal offering, <b>and a <i>log</i></b> of oil” (Leviticus 14:21). The verse juxtaposes the need for a <i>log</i> of oil with the fact the offering is made of a tenth of an ephah of flour. Accordingly, it <b>teaches about</b> each <b>tenth</b> of an ephah of flour <b>that it requires</b> one <b><i>log</i> of oil;</b> this is <b>the statement of the Rabbis.</b>
<b>Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer say:</b> Each meal offering, irrespective of its size, and <b>even a meal offering of sixty tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, requires <b>only its</b> single <b><i>log</i></b> of oil, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to offering of a leper: “And a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil <b>for a meal offering, and a <i>log</i> of oil.”</b> The juxtaposition of “a meal offering” with “a <i>log</i> of oil” teaches a principle for all meal offerings: Each offering requires only one <i>log</i> of oil.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, what do they do with this</b> verse: “And <b>a tenth</b>-<b>part</b> of an ephah of fine flour <b>mixed</b> with oil for a meal offering <b>and a <i>log</i></b> of oil,” which links the need for a <i>log</i> of oil with the fact the offering is made of a tenth of an ephah of flour? The Gemara explains: <b>That</b> verse is required <b>to</b> teach the matter <b>itself, as the Merciful One states: Let</b> a poor leper <b>bring</b> an offering of just <b>a tenth of an ephah</b> of flour. Accordingly, it cannot be used to teach a principle about meal offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the other,</b> i.e., the Rabbis, how do they respond to this claim? They maintain that <b>it is not necessary to</b> teach the matter <b>itself,</b> as <b>from</b> the fact <b>that the Merciful One revealed with regard to a leper</b> who is not poor that he must bring <b>three</b> animal <b>offerings and</b> a meal offering of <b>three-tenths</b> of an ephah as part of his purification process, it may be inferred that <b>here,</b> with regard to a poor leper, <b>who</b> brings only <b>one offering,</b> that he similarly brings a meal offering of only <b>a tenth of an ephah.</b> Accordingly, the fact that the verse mentions that his offering is only a tenth of an ephah is superfluous and can teach a principle for all meal offerings.
The Gemara continues to ask: <b>And</b> as for <b>the other,</b> Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer, how would they respond to this claim? They maintain that it <b>was necessary</b> for the verse to state the size of his meal offering, as otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>since the Merciful One spared</b> the money of the poor leper by allowing him <b>to bring</b> an offering affordable <b>in poverty,</b> one might <b>say</b> that the Merciful One <b>does not require from him</b> to bring any meal offering <b>at all.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the other,</b> the Rabbis, how would they respond to this? They claim that <b>we do not find</b> that the Torah <b>entirely</b> exempts a poor person from the offerings of the purification process, only that it provides a less expensive way to complete that process.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the Rabbis, what do they do with</b> the juxtaposition in the end of <b>this</b> verse: <b>“For a meal offering and a <i>log</i> of oil,”</b> from which Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer derive the principle that each meal offering requires only one <i>log</i> of oil? The Gemara explains: The Rabbis maintain that <b>that</b> the juxtaposition teaches <b>about one who donates a meal offering,</b> without specifying its size, <b>that he should not</b> bring <b>less than an amount</b> of flour <b>that requires</b> one <b><i>log</i>. And what is this</b> amount? <b>A tenth</b> of an ephah. The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the other,</b> Rabbi Neḥemya and Rabbi Eliezer, from where do they derive that <i>halakha</i>, as they maintain the verse teaches the principle for all meal offerings? The Gemara explains: They maintain that <b>two</b> <i>halakhot</i> <b>can be derived from</b> this verse.
§ The mishna lists the quantities of oil and wine that were required for the meal offerings and libations that accompanied the sacrifice of an animal. <b>Six</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one-half of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a bull; and four</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one-third of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a ram; and three</b> <i>log</i>, i.e., one-quarter of a <i>hin</i>, <b>for</b> those of <b>a lamb.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive these quantities? We derive them from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And their libations shall be one-half of a <i>hin</i> of wine for a bull,</b> and one-third of a <i>hin</i> for the ram, and one-quarter of a <i>hin</i> for a lamb” (Numbers 28:14).
The Gemara elaborates: Now, one <b><i>hin</i> is twelve <i>log</i>, as it is written: “And of olive oil a <i>hin</i>”</b> (Exodus 30:24), <b>and it is written</b> afterward in the same verse: <b>“Sacred anointing oil, this [<i>zeh</i>] shall be for Me, throughout your generations.”</b> The <b>numerical value [<i>gimatriyya</i>] of <i>zeh</i> is twelve.</b> Once it is established that one <i>hin</i> is twelve <i>log</i>, it is possible to calculate how may <i>log</i> are in one-half, one-third, and one-quarter of a <i>hin</i>.
§ The mishna teaches: <b>Three and a half</b> <i>log</i> of oil were required <b>for the Candelabrum,</b> as there were seven lamps and <b>a half-<i>log</i></b> was required <b>for each lamp.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? They are derived from a verse, <b>as the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the Candelabrum: “Aaron and his sons shall arrange it <b>from evening to morning,</b> before the Lord” (Exodus 27:21). This indicates that <b>you shall put into</b> each lamp <b>its</b> required <b>quantity</b> of oil <b>so that it will continue burning from evening until morning. Alternatively,</b> the phrase <b>“from evening to morning”</b> indicates that the mitzva is fulfilled throughout the night, and <b>you have no</b> other <b>rite that is valid from evening until morning except for this one alone. And the Sages calculated</b> that <b>a half-<i>log</i></b> of oil for each lamp is necessary to ensure that they continue burning <b>from evening until morning.</b>
How did the Sages reach the conclusion that a half-<i>log</i> of oil is needed? <b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> that the Sages <b>calculated</b> it <b>by</b> initially using a large quantity of oil, more than necessary to burn throughout the night, and then <b>decreasing</b> the quantity by a small amount each night until they saw that at the end of the night there was no oil remaining. <b>And there are</b> those <b>who say</b> that <b>they calculated</b> it <b>by</b> initially using a small quantity of oil and then <b>increasing</b> the quantity each night until they saw that the quantity was sufficient to allow the lamps to burn throughout the night.
The Gemara elaborates: The <b>one who said</b> that <b>they calculated</b> it <b>by increasing</b> the quantity each night holds that they did so in accordance with the principle that <b>the Torah spared the money of the Jewish people,</b> so the Sages wished to minimize the financial cost of their experimentation. <b>And</b> the <b>one who said</b> that <b>they calculated</b> it <b>by decreasing</b> the quantity each night holds that in the Temple one’s actions should not be motivated by a concern for the financial cost, as <b>in a place of wealth there is no poverty.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> Many animal offerings are brought together with a meal offering and a wine libation. These additions are collectively referred to as libations. <b>One may mix together the libations of bulls with the libations of rams;</b> the meal offerings may be mixed as they both share the same ratio of flour to oil, i.e., two <i>log</i> of oil for each tenth of an ephah of flour. Likewise, one may mix together <b>the libations of lambs with the libations of</b> other <b>lambs,</b> as the meal offerings both share the same ratio of three <i>log</i> of oil for each tenth of an ephah of flour. And one may mix together the libations <b>of</b> the offering of <b>an individual with</b> those <b>of a communal</b> offering.

Daf 89b

And one may mix together the libations <b>of</b> an offering brought on one <b>day with</b> those <b>of the day before,</b> if the meal offerings have the same ratio of oil to flour.
<b>But one may not mix together the libations of lambs with the libations of bulls or</b> the libations of <b>rams,</b> as the meal offerings have different ratios of oil to flour. <b>And</b> nevertheless, <b>if one intermingled</b> the flour and oil of <b>these</b> lamb offerings <b>by themselves and</b> the flour and oil of <b>these</b> bull or ram offerings <b>by themselves, and</b> only then <b>were they mixed together,</b> then they remain <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed. <b>If</b> they were mixed together <b>before</b> the oil and flour of each offering <b>were</b> independently <b>intermingled</b> to form the meal offering, then they are <b>disqualified.</b>
With regard to <b>the lamb</b> offering <b>that comes with the <i>omer</i></b> meal offering, which is accompanied by another meal offering and a wine libation, <b>even though</b> the quantity of flour used in <b>its meal offering is doubled,</b> i.e., one uses twice the amount that is generally used for meal offerings that accompany the sacrifice of a lamb, <b>its</b> oil and wine <b>libations were not doubled;</b> rather, three <i>log</i> of oil and three <i>log</i> of wine were used, per the standard quantities used for a lamb.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that different types of libations may be mixed together provided that the meal offerings have the same flour to oil ratio. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> to this from a <i>baraita</i> discussing the verse: “And he shall sacrifice, from the peace offerings, a fire to the Lord: The fat covering the innards, and all the fat that is on the innards, and the two kidneys with the fat that is on them, which is over the loins; and the diaphragm with the liver, with the kidneys, he shall take away. And Aaron’s sons shall burn it on the altar, apart from the burnt offering, which is on the wood that is on the fire; it is a fire of a pleasing aroma to the Lord” (Leviticus 3:3–5).
The direct object of the term: <b>“And they shall burn,”</b> i.e., the pronoun “it,” is singular, despite referring to the many types of fats listed in the verse. This indicates <b>that one may not mix fats</b> of one offering <b>with the fats</b> of a different offering, but should burn the parts from each offering separately. Similarly, it follows that the libations accompanying different animal offerings should not be mixed together.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> The mishna <b>stated</b> only that <b>if</b> libations of different offerings <b>were mixed</b> together one may still sacrifice them, but not that this is permitted <i>ab initio</i>. Accordingly, there is no contradiction between the mishna and <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara infers: <b>If that is so,</b> then when the mishna states in its first clause: <b>And one may not mix together the libations of lambs with the libations of bulls or</b> the libations of <b>rams,</b> the intention is that <b>even</b> after the fact, if <b>they were mixed together,</b> they are <b>also not</b> valid. The Gemara challenges: <b>But from</b> the fact <b>that the latter clause teaches:</b> If <b>one intermingled</b> the flour and oil of <b>these</b> lamb offerings <b>by themselves and</b> the flour and oil of <b>these</b> bull or ram offerings <b>by themselves and</b> only then <b>were they mixed together</b> then they remain <b>fit</b> to be sacrificed, which is explicitly referring to the <i>halakha</i> after the fact, <b>it may be inferred that the first clause stated</b> the <i>halakha <b>ab initio</b></i><b>.</b>
<b>Abaye said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> When different animal offerings are sacrificed, <b>their wine</b> libations <b>may be mixed together</b> <i>ab initio</i>, but only <b>if their fine flour and their oil</b> from their respective meal offerings <b>were</b> already <b>mixed together,</b> albeit improperly.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> is it correct that one may <b>not</b> mix together the <b>wine</b> libations of different offerings <b><i>ab initio</i></b> unless their flour and oil were already mixed? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in the continuation of the <i>baraita</i> just cited: <b>In what</b> case <b>is this statement,</b> that one may not mix together parts from different offerings, <b>said?</b> It is said only <b>with regard to flour and oil. But one may mix together</b> the <b>wine</b> libations of different offerings. The implication is that this is the <i>halakha</i> even if their meal offerings had not been mixed together.
<b>Rather, Abaye said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying:</b> With regard to offerings of similar types of animals, <b>where their fine flour and their oil</b> from their respective meal offerings <b>have been burned</b> on the altar, <b>one may mix together</b> the <b>wine</b> libations <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b> And even <b>where</b> their fine flour and their oil <b>have not been burned, if their fine flour and their oil have</b> at least <b>been mixed together, one may mix together their wine</b> libations <i>ab initio</i>. <b>But if</b> the fine flour and oil have <b>not</b> been mixed together, then <b>one may not mix</b> the libations <b>together.</b> The reason is that if one does mix the libations, <b>perhaps one will come to mix together</b> their <b>flour and oil <i>ab initio</i>,</b> which is prohibited.
§ The mishna teaches: With regard to <b>the lamb</b> offering <b>that comes with the <i>omer</i></b> meal offering, the quantity of flour used in its meal offering is doubled, i.e., one uses twice the amount that is generally used for meal offerings that accompany the sacrifice of a lamb, but the quantities of oil and wine are not doubled. <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states with regard to the <i>omer</i> meal offering: <b>“And its meal offering shall be two tenths”</b> (Leviticus 23:13). This verse <b>teaches about</b> the <b>lamb that comes with the <i>omer</i> that</b> the size of <b>its meal offering is doubled.</b>
One <b>might</b> have thought that <b>just as its meal offering is doubled, so</b> too <b>its wine</b> libation should be <b>doubled,</b> i.e., instead of using a quarter-<i>hin</i>, as is generally done for lambs, one should use a half-<i>hin</i>. To counter this, <b>the verse states,</b> in its continuation: <b>“And its libation shall be of wine, a quarter-<i>hin</i>”</b> (Leviticus 23:13). One <b>might</b> have thought that it is only <b>its wine</b> libation that <b>should not be doubled, as it is not intermingled with</b> the flour of <b>its meal offering, but its oil should be doubled, as it is intermingled with</b> the flour of <b>its meal offering.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “And its libation</b> shall be of wine, a quarter-<i>hin</i>,” which teaches that <b>all of its libations shall be only a quarter</b>-<b><i>hin</i></b>, but no more.
The Gemara elaborates on the final proof in the <i>baraita</i>: <b>What is the</b> biblical <b>derivation</b> here? <b>Rabbi Elazar says:</b> There is an ambiguity as to whether the possessive pronoun in the term “and its libation” is referring to the lamb offering or the meal offering, both of which are mentioned previously in the verse. This is due to a disparity between the way the Hebrew word for the term is written and the way it is vocalized. <b>It is written</b> as <b><i>veniskah</i>,</b> with the possessive pronoun in the feminine form. This would be referring to the meal offering [<i>minḥa</i>], which is a feminine noun. Accordingly, this means: The libation of the meal offering, and it is referring to the oil that is intermingled in the meal offering. <b>And we read it</b> as <b><i>venisko</i>,</b> with the possessive pronoun in the masculine form. This would be referring to the lamb offering itself [<i>keves</i>], which is a masculine noun. Accordingly, this means: The libation of the lamb offering, which is a reference to the wine libation that accompanies the lamb offering.
<b>How</b> can this be explained? It teaches that <b>the libation of the meal offering,</b> i.e., its oil, <b>is like the libation of</b> the lamb <b>of wine: Just as</b> the quantity of <b>wine</b> used is <b>a quarter</b>-<i>hin</i>, <b>so too,</b> the quantity of <b>oil</b> used is <b>a quarter</b>-<i>hin</i> and no more.
§ The Gemara cites a related discussion: A guilt offering brought by a leper as part of his purification process is distinct from other guilt offerings in that there is an additional requirement that it must be brought together with a meal offering and a wine libation. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> In the case of <b>a guilt offering of a leper that one slaughtered not for its own sake,</b> although the leper can therefore no longer fulfill his obligation with it, the offering continues to be regarded as a guilt offering of a leper and still <b>requires libations,</b> i.e., a meal offering and a wine libation; <b>as if you do not say this, you have disqualified it.</b> To bring it without libations one would have to regard it as a standard guilt offering, but the <i>halakha</i> is that an offering may not be sacrificed for a different purpose than the one for which it was originally consecrated.
<b>Rav Menashya bar Gadda objects to this: If that is so,</b> that whenever an offering is consecrated for a specific purpose that requires various additional conditions to be fulfilled beyond those normally required for that type of offering, then even if it is then slaughtered not for its own sake those conditions must still be fulfilled in order for the offering to be valid; then with regard to the <b>lamb</b> offering <b>that comes with the <i>omer</i></b> meal offering the <i>halakha</i> should likewise be that if <b>one slaughtered it not for its own sake,</b> the flour in <b>its meal offering should</b> still <b>be doubled</b> in quantity, as normally required for the <i>omer</i> meal offering, because it continues to be regarded as an <i>omer</i> meal offering, <b>as if you do not say this, you have disqualified it.</b>
<b>And</b> similarly, with regard to the <b>daily morning offering,</b> if <b>one slaughtered it not for its own sake, it should</b> still <b>require</b> the arrangement of <b>two logs</b> of wood on the fire on the altar <b>by one priest,</b> because it continues to be regarded as a daily morning offering; <b>as if you do not say this, you have disqualified it. And</b> similarly, with regard to the <b>daily afternoon offering,</b> if <b>one slaughtered it not for its own sake, it should</b> still <b>require</b> the arrangement of <b>two logs</b> of wood on the fire on the altar <b>by two priests,</b> because it continues to be regarded as a daily afternoon offering; <b>as if you do not say this, you have disqualified it.</b> The fact that Rabbi Yoḥanan did not mention these <i>halakhot</i> suggests that he holds they are not correct, but then his opinion is logically inconsistent.
The Gemara deflects the objection: <b>Yes, it is indeed so</b> that Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling should be extended to other cases, as Rav Menashya bar Gadda claimed. <b>Rather, Abaye said:</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>mentioned</b> just <b>one of them</b> as an example, even though they are all correct.
<b>Rabbi Abba said</b> that there is a different resolution: Actually, Rabbi Yoḥanan’s ruling is limited to a guilt offering of a leper. The other offerings that Rav Menashya bar Gadda mentioned would be valid even if the additional conditions that originally applied to them were not fulfilled. The reason for this is as follows: <b>Granted, these</b> other offerings that Rav Menashya bar Gadda mentioned would be valid, as <b>they are burnt offerings;</b>

Daf 90a

therefore, even <b>if they are no</b> longer <b>fit to</b> be sacrificed as <b>obligatory burnt offerings,</b> for which they were originally consecrated, having now been slaughtered not for their own sake <b>they can</b> still <b>be sacrificed as voluntary burnt offerings,</b> without the need to fulfill the additional conditions that originally applied to them. <b>But here,</b> with regard to the guilt offering of a leper, <b>if you do not maintain it in accordance with its</b> original <b>status</b> and require it to be brought together with its libations, it can no longer be considered a guilt offering at all, as <b>is there a voluntary guilt offering?</b>
The Gemara notes that it <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> In the case of <b>a guilt offering of a leper that one slaughtered not for its own sake, or</b> in a case <b>where one did not place</b> some <b>of its blood upon</b> the leper’s right <b>thumb and big toe, this</b> guilt offering <b>is</b> still <b>brought up upon the altar and requires libations,</b> i.e., a meal offering and wine-libation; <b>but</b> since it was sacrificed incorrectly, the leper <b>needs</b> to bring <b>another guilt offering to permit him</b> to partake of offerings.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All measuring vessels that were in the Temple were</b> such that they held the volume that they measured when their contents were <b>heaped</b> above the rim, <b>except for</b> the measuring vessel used to measure the flour for the griddle-cake offering <b>of the High Priest, as its heaped</b> measure, i.e., the quantity of flour held by a tenth of an ephah measuring vessel when heaped, <b>was contained within its</b> walls when the flour was leveled with the rim. This was due to the fact that the measuring vessel for the griddle-cake offering was slightly larger than the tenth of an ephah measuring vessel.
With regard to <b>measuring vessels for liquids, their overflows,</b> i.e., that which flows onto the outside of vessel’s walls, <b>are sacred, but</b> with regard to <b>measuring vessels for dry</b> substances, <b>their overflows are non-sacred.</b>
<b>Rabbi Akiva says</b> that the reason for this difference is that since the <b>measuring vessels for liquids</b> are themselves <b>sacred, therefore their overflows are sacred,</b> and since the <b>measuring vessels for dry</b> substances are <b>non-sacred, therefore their overflows are non-sacred. Rabbi Yosei says:</b> The difference is <b>not due to that</b> factor. <b>Rather,</b> it is <b>because the</b> overflow of <b>liquid</b> was originally inside the vessel, where it became consecrated, and <b>was</b> then <b>displaced,</b> whereas <b>the</b> overflow of <b>a dry</b> substance <b>was not displaced</b> from inside the vessel, so it had not become consecrated.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna and Gemara on 87a cite a dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Meir concerning the number and nature of the measuring vessels used for dry substances. In light of that dispute, the Gemara asks: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion is the mishna here? <b>If</b> you suggest it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir,</b> that is difficult: He holds that there were two measuring vessels that held a tenth of an ephah, but only <b>one</b> of them <b>was</b> such that it held its measure <b>when heaped;</b> the other one held its measure when leveled. And <b>if</b> you suggest it is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> that is difficult: They hold <b>there was</b> only <b>one</b> measuring vessel that held a tenth of an ephah, <b>and</b> it held its measure when <b>leveled.</b> How can the mishna state that all measuring vessels in the Temple were heaped?
<b>Rav Ḥisda said: Actually,</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Meir</b> that only one of two measuring vessels that held a tenth of an ephah was such that it held its measure when heaped. <b>And what</b> does the mishna means when it states: <b>All measuring vessels [<i>kol middot</i>]</b> in the Temple were heaped? It means that that <b>all measurements [<i>kol medidot</i>]</b> performed with that measuring vessel were done when its contents were heaped above its rim.
§ The mishna discusses the status of overflows: The first <i>tanna</i> states simply that with regard to <b>measuring vessels for liquids, their overflows are sacred,</b> but with regard to measuring vessels for dry substances, their overflows are non-sacred. Rabbi Akiva explains that this distinction is a function of whether the measuring vessel is itself sacred. Rabbi Yosei explains it is function of whether the overflow had initially been inside the vessel. The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> matter <b>do</b> these three <i>tanna’im</i> <b>disagree?</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>The first <i>tanna</i> holds</b> that the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>liquid</b> items, e.g., wine for libations and oil, were <b>anointed</b> and thereby consecrated <b>both on</b> the <b>inside and on</b> the <b>outside.</b> Therefore, the overflow is consecrated as it comes in contact with the outside of the vessel’s walls. The <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items, such as the flour for meal offerings, <b>were anointed</b> and consecrated only <b>on</b> the <b>inside, but were not anointed on</b> the <b>outside.</b> Therefore, the overflow is not consecrated when it comes into contact with the outside of the vessel’s walls.
<b>And Rabbi Akiva,</b> who states the difference is due to whether the vessel is sacred or non-sacred, <b>holds</b> that the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>liquid</b> items <b>were anointed on</b> the <b>inside and were not anointed on</b> the <b>outside,</b> whereas the <b>measuring</b> vessels for <b>dry</b> items <b>were not anointed at all,</b> and they remained non-sacred and so could not consecrate the overflow.
<b>And Rabbi Yosei holds</b> that <b>this and that,</b> i.e., both types of measuring vessels, <b>were anointed</b> only <b>on the inside but were not anointed on the outside, and</b> so <b>here, this is the reason</b> behind whether the overflow was sacred: <b>As</b> the overflow <b>of liquid</b> was originally inside the vessel and <b>was</b> then <b>displaced, and it comes from the inside of the vessel,</b> it is therefore consecrated. <b>But the</b> overflow of <b>a dry</b> substance <b>was not</b> originally inside the vessel and then <b>displaced,</b> and so it is never consecrated.
The Gemara questions this explanation of Rabbi Yosei’s opinion: <b>But</b> even <b>if</b> the overflow <b>was</b> previously inside the vessel and then <b>displaced, what of it? A person intends</b> to consecrate only <b>that which he requires,</b> and so even if the overflow had been inside the vessel it would not have been consecrated.
<b>Rav Dimi bar Shishna said in the name of Rav: That is to say</b> that <b>service vessels consecrate</b> their contents even <b>without</b> the <b>intent</b> of the person using them. <b>Ravina said: Actually, I will say to you</b> that <b>service vessels consecrate</b> their contents <b>only with</b> the <b>intent</b> of the person using them, and by Torah law the overflows are not sacred. <b>But</b> the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> to regard them as sacred, <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>one may transfer</b> a substance that has been consecrated <b>in a service vessel to non-sacred</b> status.
<b>Rabbi Zeira raised an objection</b> to this explanation from a mishna (100a): Each Shabbat, new shewbread and bowls of frankincense were arranged on the Table in the Sanctuary. They remained there until the following Shabbat, at which point the frankincense was burned, thereby permitting the shewbread to be eaten. If the priest <b>arranged the bread and the bowls</b> of frankincense on the Table <b>after Shabbat,</b> during the week, <b>and</b> then <b>he burned the</b> frankincense in the <b>bowls on</b> the <b>Shabbat</b> at the end of that week, the bread is <b>disqualified,</b> as it had not been on the Table for a full seven days from one Shabbat to the next. <b>How</b> then <b>should one proceed</b> to prevent the disqualification? <b>He should leave</b> the bread on the Table <b>until the following Shabbat, as even if it remained on the Table for many days,</b> there is <b>nothing</b> wrong <b>with that,</b> provided that it is there for at least seven days. The frankincense may then be burned and it will permit the bread to be eaten.
Rabbi Zeira explains his objection: <b>But why</b> is it permitted to leave the bread on the Table for more than seven days? <b>There too, let us say</b> that the Sages issued <b>a decree</b> disqualifying the bread <b>lest</b> people <b>say</b> that <b>one can store</b> sacred items <b>in a service vessel</b> overnight and that will prevent them becoming disqualified. Evidently, the Sages did not issue such decrees, and it follows that also with regard to using the measuring vessels they did not issue a decree.
The Gemara rejects this claim: <b>Are you raising a contradiction</b> between a rite performed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., the arrangement of the shewbread, <b>and</b> a rite performed <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary, i.e., using the measuring vessels? Since in the case of a rite performed <b>inside</b> the Sanctuary <b>not everyone is aware</b> of what is happening, there is no concern that people will misinterpret what is going on and so there is no need to issue a decree concerning it. In the case of a rite performed <b>outside</b> the Sanctuary <b>everyone is aware</b> of what is happening, and there is a need to issue a decree to prevent people from drawing mistaken conclusions.
§ The Gemara continues to discuss the overflow of measures. <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 10b): <b>The surplus libations</b> were sold and the proceeds used <b>to</b> purchase <b>supplementary</b> offerings <b>of the altar [<i>keitz hamizbe’aḥ</i>].</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the meaning of: <b>Surplus libations?</b>
<b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef says:</b> It means <b>the overflows of measuring vessels. Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> Surplus libations are <b>like that which we learned</b> in another mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 13a): In the case of <b>one who accepts upon himself to supply fine flour at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> its market price <b>stood at three</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, he is required to fulfill his commitment and <b>supply</b> fine flour <b>at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>.

Daf 90b

If one committed to supply fine flour <b>at three</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> its market price decreased until it <b>stood at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, he must <b>supply</b> fine flour <b>at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>. The reason for this <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the</b> Temple <b>treasury is at an advantage.</b> In the latter case, the merchant ends up providing the Temple with a greater quantity of flour than had initially been intended. Consequently, the Temple has more flour than it requires. The extra amount is referred to as surplus libations, and it is sold in order to purchase supplementary offerings.
The Gemara comments: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef,</b> and it <b>is taught</b> in another <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Yosef: These overflows of measuring vessels, what would be done with them?</b> They are gathered, and <b>if there is another offering</b> to be sacrificed that day, the priests <b>sacrifice</b> this liquid <b>with it</b> as part of its libations. <b>And if</b> there is no other offering that day, and instead the overflows <b>were left overnight</b> without being sacrificed, <b>they are disqualified by being left overnight. And if</b> the overflows were <b>not</b> sacrificed with another offering and were not disqualified by being left overnight, they are sold, and the proceeds from their sale <b>are used to</b> purchase animals to <b>supplement</b> the offerings of <b>the altar. And these supplementary</b> offerings, <b>what</b> form do they take? They are <b>burnt offerings; their flesh</b> is entirely burned on the altar <b>to God, and the hides</b> are given <b>to the priests.</b>
It <b>is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> In the case of <b>one who accepts upon himself to supply fine flour at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> its market price <b>stood at three</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, he is required to fulfill his commitment and <b>supply</b> fine flour <b>at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>. If one committed to supply fine flour <b>at three</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, <b>and</b> its market price decreased until it <b>stood at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>, he must <b>supply</b> fine flour <b>at four</b> <i>se’a</i> for a <i>sela</i>. The reason for this <i>halakha</i> is <b>that the</b> Temple <b>treasury is at an advantage. And</b> it is to <b>this</b> later case <b>that</b> we referred when <b>we learned</b> in the mishna: <b>The surplus libations</b> were sold and the proceeds used <b>to</b> purchase <b>supplementary</b> offerings <b>of the altar.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> <b>All offerings,</b> whether <b>communal or individual, require libations,</b> i.e., a meal offering and a wine libation, <b>except for the firstborn</b> offering, <b>the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>the Paschal offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering,</b> with which libations are not brought. <b>But</b> the exception to this exception is <b>that</b> the <b>sin offering of a leper and his guilt offering</b> do <b>require libations.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> <b>The Sages taught</b> a <i>baraita</i> that derives each of the rulings of the mishna from the verses that state the requirement to accompany animal offerings with the sacrifice of libations. The Torah states: “And you will make a fire offering to the Lord, a burnt offering, or a sacrifice, in fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered, or as a gift, or on your Festivals, to make a pleasing aroma to the Lord, of the herd or of the flock. And he who brings his offering to the Lord shall sacrifice a meal offering of a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with a quarter-<i>hin</i> of oil; and wine for a libation, a quarter-<i>hin</i>, you shall make it with the burnt offering or for the sacrifice, for the one lamb” (Numbers 15:2–5). The Torah then proceeds to detail the quantities of flour, oil, and wine for a ram and a bull.
The verse states: <b>“And you will make a fire offering to the Lord.”</b> Accordingly, one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>any</b> offering <b>that is raised up</b> on the altar <b>as a fire offering shall require</b> that <b>libations</b> be brought with it, <b>even a meal offering. The verse</b> then <b>states: “A burnt offering,”</b> which teaches that the requirement of libations applies only to animal burnt offerings, but not to meal offerings. If so, <b>from where</b> is it derived that <b>a peace offering</b> requires libations? <b>The verse states: “A sacrifice.” From where</b> is it derived that <b>a thanks offering</b> requires libations? <b>The verse states: “Or a sacrifice.”</b> The superfluous word “or” serves to include thanks offerings.
One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that I</b> should <b>include even the firstborn</b> offering, <b>the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>the Paschal offering, the sin offering, and the guilt offering.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states: “In fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered, or as a gift.”</b> This teaches that an offering that <b>comes in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow or</b> as <b>a gift</b> offering <b>requires libations,</b> whereas each of these offerings, <b>which do not come in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow or</b> as <b>a gift</b> offering but only as obligatory offerings, do <b>not require libations.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues: It has been <b>derived,</b> then, that one should <b>exclude these</b> offerings from the requirement of libations, as they are obligatory. Perhaps then <b>I will</b> likewise <b>exclude</b> the <b>obligatory</b> offerings <b>that come on account of the pilgrimage Festival,</b> which are sacrificed <b>on the pilgrimage Festival, and what are these? Burnt offerings of appearance</b> in the Temple <b>and Festival peace offerings,</b> both of which are brought on the three pilgrimage Festivals. To counter this, <b>the verse states: “Or on your Festivals,”</b> which indicates that <b>any</b> offering <b>that comes on your Festivals,</b> even if it is obligatory, <b>requires libations.</b>
It has been <b>derived,</b> then, that one should <b>include</b> even <b>these</b> Festival offerings, despite the fact that they are obligatory. Perhaps then <b>I will</b> likewise <b>include</b> the <b>goat sin offerings</b> brought as part of the additional offerings on the Festivals, <b>since they come</b> as <b>obligatory</b> offerings <b>on the pilgrimage Festival.</b> To counter this, <b>the verse states</b> in the continuation of that passage: <b>“And when you make a young bull</b> as a burnt offering” (Numbers 15:8), and proceeds to state the requirement to bring libations with it.
Now, the requirement to bring libations with <b>a young bull was</b> already included <b>in the general</b> requirement to bring libations with any fire offering, as stated in the beginning of that passage; <b>and why,</b> then, <b>was it singled out</b> and mentioned explicitly? This is in order <b>to equate</b> all other offerings <b>to it,</b> teaching that the requirement of libations applies only to offerings similar to a young bull: <b>Just as a young bull is distinct</b> in that it <b>can come in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow or</b> as <b>a gift</b> offering, <b>so too, any</b> offering that <b>comes in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow or</b> as <b>a gift</b> offering requires libations.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: The verses at the beginning of the passage state: <b>“To make a pleasing aroma to the Lord, of the herd or of the flock.” What</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states</b> this? <b>Since</b> in the previous verse <b>it is stated: “A burnt offering,” I</b> would <b>derive</b> that all types of burnt offerings require libations, and <b>even a bird</b> sacrificed as a <b>burnt offering is indicated.</b> Therefore, <b>the verse states: “Of the herd or of the flock,”</b> which limits the requirement to offerings of animals such as sheep or cattle, but not to bird offerings; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yoshiya.</b>
<b>Rabbi Yonatan says: This</b> verse <b>is unnecessary, as</b> the verse <b>states: “A sacrifice,” and a bird</b> offering <b>is not</b> referred to as <b>a sacrifice. If so, what</b> is the meaning when <b>the verse states: “Of the herd or of the flock”? Since it is stated</b> with regard to a burnt offering: <b>“A person, when he sacrifices from you an offering to the Lord, of the animals: Of the herd and of the flock,</b> you shall sacrifice your offering” (Leviticus 1:2), one <b>might</b> have thought that <b>one who</b> takes a vow by <b>saying: It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering,</b> without specifying which type of animal he will bring, that he must <b>bring</b> animals <b>of</b> both of <b>these two</b> types, i.e., from the herd and the flock. To counter this, <b>the verse states: “Of the herd or of the flock,”</b> separating the two types with the word “or,” thereby indicating that if <b>he wanted</b> to bring <b>one</b> of them, he may <b>bring</b> just one, and if he <b>wanted</b> to bring <b>two,</b> he may <b>bring</b> two. This concludes the <i>baraita</i>.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan, why do I</b> need an independent <b>verse</b> to teach that one who takes a vow to bring a burnt offering does not have to bring both types? <b>Didn’t</b> Rabbi Yonatan himself <b>say</b> an exegetical principle that whenever the Torah mentions two details together with regard to a <i>halakha</i>, it is presumed that the <i>halakha</i> is fulfilled even when only one of the details is realized, <b>unless the verse specifies</b> that both details are required by writing the word: <b>Together,</b> in the verse? Accordingly, when the verse states: “Of the herd or of the flock,” the intention is that either one is sufficient, and there should be no need for an independent verse to teach this.
The Gemara answers: Despite his principle, an independent verse <b>was necessary</b> to teach this, as it might <b>enter your mind to say:</b>

Daf 91a

<b>Since</b> in Leviticus 1:2 <b>it is written: “And of the flock,”</b> and not merely: Of the flock, <b>it is as though</b> the word: <b>Together, was written</b> in the verse. Therefore, the verse in Numbers 15, which does state: “Or of the flock,” is necessary to teach that this is not the case.
The Gemara asks: <b>And according</b> to the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya, who said</b> that <b>even though it is not</b> explicitly <b>written</b> in the verse: <b>Together, it is as though it is written: Together,</b> i.e., it is presumed that the <i>halakha</i> is fulfilled only when both details are realized, <b>a verse should be required.</b> Yet, in the <i>baraita</i>, Rabbi Yoshiya expounds the phrase “of the herd or of the flock” to teach a different <i>halakha</i>. From where, then, does he derive that one who takes a vow to bring a burnt offering does not need to bring both types of animals?
The Gemara explains: <b>Isn’t it written: “If his offering is a burnt offering of the herd”</b> (Leviticus 1:3), and then in a separate verse it states: <b>“And if his offering is of the flock”</b> (Leviticus 1:9)? The fact that these possibilities are presented in two disjointed verses is an explicit indication that the burnt offering can be brought from even just one of these animals. Therefore, even Rabbi Yoshiya concedes that there is no reason to presume a burnt offering must be brought from both types there.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> as for <b>the other</b> <i>tanna</i>, Rabbi Yonatan, why does he require a verse at all? The Gemara explains: It <b>was necessary</b> to have a verse to teach this, because otherwise it might <b>enter your mind to say: These statements,</b> i.e., the verses that indicate it is sufficient to bring just one type of animal, concern a case <b>where one specifies</b> in his vow that he intends to bring just one animal, and the verses indicate that it is valid to bring just one. <b>But</b> if one vowed <b>without specification,</b> one might say: <b>Let him bring</b> burnt offerings <b>from both of them.</b> Therefore the phrase “of the herd or of the flock” <b>teaches us</b> that even in that case, it is sufficient to bring just one type of animal.
§ The Gemara continues to analyze the <i>baraita</i>. <b>The Master said</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: From where is it derived that a peace offering requires libations? The verse states: “A sacrifice.” <b>From where</b> is it derived that <b>a thanks offering</b> requires libations? <b>The verse states: “Or a sacrifice.”</b> The superfluous word “or” includes thanks offerings. The Gemara asks: <b>Is that to say</b> that <b>a thanks offering is not</b> referred to as <b>a sacrifice?</b> It certainly is. Why, then, is it only included through the word “or”? The Gemara answers: An independent inclusion <b>was necessary,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say: Since</b> in any event <b>there is bread</b> brought <b>together with</b> the thanks offering, <b>it should not require libations.</b>
The Gemara raises a question concerning this explanation: <b>But</b> in <b>what</b> way <b>is</b> a thanks offering <b>different from a nazirite’s ram, as there is bread</b> brought <b>together with it</b> also, <b>and</b> yet <b>it requires libations?</b> The verse states with regard to the ram of a nazirite: “And one unblemished ram for a peace offering, and a basket of unleavened bread, cakes of fine flour mixed with oil, and unleavened wafers spread with oil, and their meal offering, and their libations” (Numbers 6:13–15).
The Gemara answers: It might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that one should differentiate between the thanks offering and a nazirite’s ram as <b>there,</b> together with the nazirite’s ram, he brings only <b>two types</b> of bread, i.e., loaves and wafers, whereas, <b>here,</b> together with the thanks offering, one brings <b>four types</b> of bread. Therefore, one might have concluded that since there are many types of loaves it does not require libations. For that reason it is necessary to have an independent derivation that <b>teaches us</b> that it does require libations.
The Gemara analyzes another one of the derivations of the <i>baraita</i>. The verse states: And you will make a fire offering to the Lord, a burnt offering, or a sacrifice, in fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered, or as a gift.” This teaches that an offering that comes in fulfillment of a vow or as a gift offering requires libations. The Gemara challenges: <b>But</b> if that is the <i>halakha</i>, then <b>let the Merciful One write</b> only: <b>“In fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered, or as a gift,” and it would be unnecessary</b> to write: <b>“A burnt offering,”</b> as a burnt offering is a type of offering that can be brought as a vow or gift offering.
The Gemara explains: <b>Had the Merciful One not written “a burnt offering,” I would say</b> that the verse should be expounded as follows: <b>“And you will make a fire offering to the Lord”</b> is <b>a generalization,</b> indicating that all offerings require libations. But then it states: <b>“In fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered, or as a gift,”</b> which is <b>a detail,</b> indicating that the requirement applies only to offerings brought in fulfillment of a vow or as a gift. But with <b>“to</b> make <b>a pleasing aroma</b> to the Lord” <b>it then generalized.</b> If so, this is <b>a generalization, and a detail, and a generalization,</b> and according to the principles of exegesis <b>you may deduce</b> that the verse is referring <b>only</b> to items <b>similar to the detail: Just as the detail is explicit</b> in referring to an offering <b>that does not come</b> to atone <b>for a sin,</b> but comes to fulfill a vow or as a gift, <b>so too any</b> offering <b>that does not come</b> to atone <b>for a sin</b> requires libations.
Accordingly, <b>I</b> would <b>exclude a sin offering and a guilt offering</b> from the requirement to have libations, <b>as they come</b> to atone <b>for a sin,</b> and <b>I</b> would <b>include the firstborn</b> offering, <b>the</b> animal <b>tithe</b> offering, <b>and the Paschal offering, as they do not come</b> to atone <b>for a sin.</b> In order to preclude the possibility of expounding the verses in this way, <b>the verse states: “Burnt offering,”</b> as an additional detail, which serves to further exclude offerings that are brought only in fulfillment of an obligation.
The Gemara asks: <b>Now that it is written: “Burnt offering,” what do you include through</b> the <b>generalization and detail</b> and generalization in this verse? The Gemara explains: <b>Just as the detail</b> of a burnt offering <b>is explicit</b> in referring to an offering <b>that one had not always been obligated</b> to bring, as it is referring to a burnt offering brought in fulfillment of a vow, which one became obligated to bring only once the vow was taken, <b>so too, any</b> offering <b>that one had not always been obligated</b> to bring requires libations.
This serves <b>to include</b> in the requirement for libations the <b>offspring of consecrated</b> animals, e.g., of a female peace offering; <b>and substitutes of</b> consecrated animals, i.e., a non-sacred animal with regard to which one stated that it should be a substitute for a consecrated animal, in which case the result is that both animals are consecrated and must be sacrificed; <b>and a burnt offering that comes from</b> the proceeds of having sold <b>surpluses</b> of items donated to the Temple that were not needed.
<b>And</b> this also serves to include <b>a guilt offering</b> whose owner either died or achieved atonement through sacrificing another animal and <b>which was</b> therefore <b>consigned to grazing</b> until it developed a blemish, at which point it should be sold and the proceeds used to purchase supplementary offerings for the altar. If instead, the guilt offering itself was sacrificed as a burnt offering, it is valid. In such a case, the offering requires libations. <b>And</b> this also serves to include <b>all offerings that were slaughtered not for their own sake.</b> Such offerings were brought to fulfill the owner’s obligation. Since they were not sacrificed for the sake of that purpose, the owner does not fulfill his obligation, but nevertheless the offerings are valid. In such a case, these offerings also require libations.
The Gemara asks: <b>And now that you have said</b> that the word <b>“or”</b> in the phrase “or a sacrifice” is necessary <b>for the derivation</b> that teaches that the thanks offering requires libations, I can similarly ask <b>why do I</b> need the word “or” in the phrase <b>“in fulfillment of a vow clearly uttered or as a gift,” to separate</b> between <b>them?</b> The Gemara explains: <b>It was necessary</b> to write “or” in that phrase, as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>until one brings</b> both <b>a vow</b> offering <b>and a gift</b> offering together <b>they do not require libations.</b> The word “or” <b>teaches us</b> otherwise, <b>that</b> even <b>if one brings a vow</b> offering <b>by itself it requires libations, and if one brings a gift</b> offering <b>by itself he must bring libations.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>This works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoshiya,</b> as he holds that whenever the Torah does not explicitly separate between two details stated with regard to a <i>halakha</i>, it is presumed that the <i>halakha</i> is fulfilled only when both details are realized. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yonatan,</b> who holds that in general it is presumed that either detail is sufficient, <b>why do I</b> need the word “or”? The Gemara explains: Were it not for this word, it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that although the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>if one brings a vow</b> offering <b>by itself</b> it <b>requires libations,</b> and if <b>one brings a gift</b> offering <b>by itself</b> it <b>requires libations,</b> nevertheless, if <b>one brings</b> both <b>a vow</b> offering <b>and a gift</b> offering together, <b>it would be sufficient</b> to <b>bring libations for</b> just <b>one</b> of them. Therefore, the word “or” <b>teaches us</b> that libations are required for each offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>Why do I</b> need the word “or” in the phrase <b>“or on your Festivals”?</b> The Gemara answers: It <b>was necessary,</b> as it might <b>enter your mind to say</b> that <b>this matter,</b> that even when two offerings are brought together libations are required for each of them, applies only when they are distinct both in the type of offering and in the nature of the obligation to bring them, such as <b>where one brings a burnt offering in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow and a peace offering as a gift</b> offering, <b>or vice versa.</b>
<b>But where one brings a burnt offering and a peace offering</b> both <b>in</b> fulfillment of <b>a vow,</b> or <b>alternatively, a burnt offering and a peace offering</b> both <b>as gift</b> offerings, one might have said that since in the former case both offerings are of <b>a single type of</b> commitment, i.e., <b>a vow, and</b> in the latter case both are of <b>a single type of</b> commitment, i.e., <b>a gift</b> offering, therefore <b>it would be sufficient</b> to <b>bring libations for</b> just <b>one</b> of them. Consequently, the word “or” in the phrase <b>“or on your Festivals” teaches us</b> that even if they are distinct only in the type of offering, libations are required for each offering.
The Gemara continues its analysis: <b>Why do I</b> need the word “or” in the verse: <b>“And when you prepare a young bull for a burnt offering or for a sacrifice”</b> (Numbers 15:9)?
