<b>Rabbi Ḥanina says:</b> It was rectangular, with a wide base and two parallel walls with an open space between them, <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides. <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat,</b> i.e., a triangular-shaped boat with a narrow base from which two walls rise at angles. Since the boat does not have a wide base it rocks from side to side.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <b>bowls of frankincense could rest</b> upon it. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat, how would</b> the <b>bowls rest</b> upon it? The Gemara answers: The baker <b>prepared</b> a flat <b>place for</b> the bowls to rest, on the side of the shewbread.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <b>rods could rest</b> upon the it. The shewbread was placed on the Table in two arrangements. In each arrangement the lowest loaf was placed on the Table and the remaining loaves were set one above the other, with rods separating the loaves. There were fourteen rods for each arrangement, each loaf being placed upon three rods, except for the uppermost loaf, which was placed on only two rods. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat, how were</b> the <b>rods resting</b> upon the shewbread? Since the loaves had a narrow base, they would rest on only one rod. The Gemara answers: The baker <b>would make a protrusion in</b> the base of the loaves, which would slightly widen their pointed base, enabling them to rest with stability upon the rods.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, <b>this is</b> the reason <b>that</b> the <b>panels would support the loaves.</b> There were four gold panels that stood at the two sides of the Table and rose up above the height of the Table, and the rods rested on these panels. The loaves were placed lengthwise along the entire width of the Table, and the panels supported the two sides of the loaves, preventing them from falling to the ground. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat, how would</b> the <b>panels support the loaves?</b> Since the sides of the shewbread rose at an angle, the panels would touch only the upper edges of the shewbread. The Gemara answers <b>that</b> the panels <b>would be made to curve</b> inward at an angle corresponding to the angle of the shewbread, so that the panels supported the loaves along their entire length.
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat, this is</b> the reason <b>that we require panels.</b> Since the loaves do not have a wide base they cannot stand on their own without the support of the rods and panels. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, <b>why do I</b> need <b>panels?</b> The loaves could stand without the assistance of rods and panels. The Gemara answers: If there were no panels supporting the loaves from the sides and the loaves were placed on top of each other, <b>due to the weight of</b> the upper <b>loaves</b> the lower loaves <b>would break [<i>telaḥ</i>].</b>
The Gemara comments: <b>Granted, according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat,</b> it is evident that the <b>panels are placed on</b> the <b>Table,</b> in order to prevent the slanted loaves from falling to the ground. The Gemara asks: <b>But according to the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, <b>where would</b> the priest <b>place</b> the <b>panels?</b> Since the wide base of the loaves reached the edge of the Table, there was no room for the panels there. <b>Would</b> the priest <b>place them on the ground?</b> The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> the panels were placed on the ground, <b>as Rabbi Abba bar Memel said: According to the statement of the one who says</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat,</b> the <b>panels are placed on the Table,</b> whereas <b>according to the statement of the one who says</b> the shewbread was <b>like a box that is open</b> on two sides, the <b>panels are placed on</b> the <b>ground.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>In accordance with whose</b> opinion <b>is that which Rabbi Yehuda said: The loaves support the panels and the panels support the loaves,</b> i.e., they lean against one another? It is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat,</b> i.e., Rabbi Yoḥanan. According to the opinion of Rabbi Ḥanina, the panels stood on the ground and did not require the support of the loaves.

Daf 95a

The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Yoḥanan from another <i>baraita</i>: <b>There was</b> a mold <b>in the oven for</b> the shewbread that was <b>similar to a barrel</b> made of reeds, as it was perforated to enable the bread to bake well, <b>and</b> in its shape <b>it resembled a type of rectangular tablet [<i>tavla</i>].</b> This indicates that the shewbread was rectangular. The Gemara answers: <b>Say</b> that <b>the opening,</b> i.e., the upper section of the mold, <b>resembled a type of rectangular tablet,</b> and that the mold tapered down to a point.
<b>It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>in accordance with the one who said</b> the shewbread was <b>like a rocking boat, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>There were four gold panels there,</b> on the Table, which <b>split up at their upper ends</b> so that <b>they were like forked</b> reed branches. The panels were forked <b>because the bread, which resembled a type of rocking boat, was supported by them.</b>
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: During the era of the Tabernacle, was <b>the shewbread disqualified during the journeys</b> of the Jewish people in the wilderness, <b>or was it not disqualified during the journeys?</b> When the Jewish people would travel from one place to another in the wilderness, the Tabernacle would be dismantled and the Table would be carried with the loaves upon it. The dilemma is about whether or not the loaves were disqualified, since they left the boundaries of the Sanctuary. This matter is the subject of a dispute between <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. One says</b> the loaves were thereby <b>disqualified, and one says</b> they were <b>not disqualified.</b>
The Gemara explains their respective reasons: <b>The one who says</b> the shewbread was <b>disqualified</b> derives his opinion from a verse, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the journeys: “Then the Tent of Meeting shall journey with the camp of the Levites in the midst of the camps; <b>as they encamp, so shall they journey,</b> every man in his place, by their banners” (Numbers 2:17). The verse juxtaposes the encampments with the journeys, indicating that <b>just as when</b> the Tabernacle is <b>encamped</b> the shewbread is <b>disqualified when</b> it <b>leaves</b> the Tabernacle courtyard, <b>so too, when</b> the Tabernacle <b>journeys</b> the shewbread is <b>disqualified when</b> it <b>leaves</b> the courtyard.
<b>The one who says</b> the shewbread was <b>not disqualified</b> during the journeys derives his opinion from a verse, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the journeys: “And upon the Table of shewbread they shall spread a cloth of blue…<b>and the continual bread shall remain upon it”</b> (Numbers 4:7). The verse refers to the shewbread as “the continual bread” even during the journeys, indicating that as long as the loaves are on the Table they retain their sacred status.
The Gemara asks: <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>amora</i>, who maintains the shewbread was not disqualified during the journeys, <b>isn’t it written: “As they encamp, so shall they journey,”</b> indicating that the shewbread is disqualified when it leaves the Tabernacle during the journeys? The Gemara replies that according to this opinion, the juxtaposition of the encampments with the journeys is interpreted <b>in the other direction: Just as when</b> the Tabernacle is <b>encamped, if</b> the shewbread <b>does not leave its place</b> and remains on the Table it is <b>not disqualified, so too, when</b> the Tabernacle <b>journeys, if it does not leave its place</b> on the Table it is <b>not disqualified.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>amora</i>, who maintains the shewbread was disqualified during the journeys, <b>isn’t it written: “And the continual bread shall remain upon it,”</b> indicating that the shewbread retains its sanctity as long as it is on the Table? <b>Rather, when Rav Dimi came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said</b> that the explanation of the dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi is different. With regard to a case <b>where</b> the shewbread <b>is arranged</b> on the Table, <b>everyone agrees</b> the shewbread is not disqualified during the journey. <b>Rather, when they disagree</b> it is in a case <b>where</b> the shewbread <b>is removed</b> from the Table before the journey.
The Gemara explains their respective reasons: <b>The one who says</b> the shewbread <b>is disqualified</b> derives his opinion from a verse, <b>as it is written:</b> “Then the Tent of Meeting shall journey with the camp of the Levites in the midst of the camps; <b>as they encamp, so shall they journey,</b> every man in his place, by their banners” (Numbers 2:17). The verse juxtaposes the encampments with the journeys, indicating that <b>just as when</b> the Tabernacle is <b>encamped</b> the shewbread is <b>disqualified when</b> it <b>leaves</b> the Tabernacle courtyard, <b>so too, when</b> the Tabernacle <b>journeys</b> the shewbread is <b>disqualified when</b> it <b>leaves</b> the courtyard.
<b>According to the one who says</b> the shewbread <b>is not disqualified</b> during the journeys, this is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “Then the Tent of Meeting shall journey,”</b> indicating that <b>even though it has journeyed it is</b> still considered <b>the Tent of Meeting,</b> and therefore the shewbread is not disqualified.
The Gemara asks: <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>amora</i>, who maintains the shewbread was not disqualified during the journeys, <b>isn’t it written: “As they encamp, so shall they journey,”</b> indicating that the shewbread is disqualified when it leaves the Tabernacle during the journeys? The Gemara replies that according to this opinion, the juxtaposition of the encampments with the journeys is interpreted <b>in the other direction: Just as when</b> the Tabernacle is <b>encamped, if</b> one <b>does not take</b> the shewbread <b>out</b> of the courtyard <b>it is not disqualified, so too, when</b> the Tabernacle <b>journeys, if</b> one <b>does not take</b> the shewbread <b>out</b> of the courtyard <b>it is not disqualified.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But also</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>amora</i>, who maintains the shewbread was disqualified during the journeys, <b>isn’t it written: “Then the Tent of Meeting shall journey,”</b> indicating that the Tent of Meeting retains its sanctity during the journeys and therefore the shewbread should not be disqualified? The Gemara answers: <b>That</b> verse is not referring to the sanctity of the Tent of Meeting during the journeys. Rather, <b>it comes to</b> teach the position of the Tent of Meeting between the <b>banners</b> of the different tribes during the journeys.
The Gemara asks: <b>And</b> according to <b>the other</b> <i>amora</i>, from where does he derive the position of the Tent of Meeting during the journeys? The Gemara replies: He <b>derives</b> this <b>from</b> the continuation of the verse: <b>“With the camp of the Levites in the midst of the camps”</b> (Numbers 2:17).
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> from a <i>baraita</i> to the opinion that the shewbread was not disqualified during the journeys: <b>At the time of the dismantling</b> of the Tabernacle in order to commence the <b>journeys,</b> when the curtains surrounding the Tabernacle courtyard are removed, the <b>sacrificial</b> food <b>is disqualified</b> from being consumed, <b>as</b> it is considered to have <b>left</b> the Tabernacle courtyard. <b>And <i>zavim</i> and lepers are sent out of the partitions of their</b> camps; the <i>zavim</i> are sent out of the Levite camp, while lepers are sent out of the Israelite camp. <b>What, is it not</b> referring <b>even</b> to <b>the shewbread,</b> indicating that it is disqualified during the journeys? The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> the <i>baraita</i> means that most sacrificial food is disqualified, <b>except for the shewbread.</b>
The Gemara challenges: <b>Whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, this explanation is difficult. <b>If</b> the phrase: “Then the <b>Tent of Meeting</b> shall journey,” <b>is</b> meant <b>exactly,</b> i.e., literally, and it still has the status of the Tent of Meeting even during the journeys, then <b>even</b> other <b>sacrificial</b> food should not be disqualified during the journeys. <b>If</b> “then the <b>Tent of Meeting</b> shall journey,” <b>is not</b> meant <b>exactly,</b> and it does not have the status of the Tent of Meeting during the journeys, then <b>even the shewbread</b> should be disqualified.
<b>Rather, when Ravin came</b> from Eretz Yisrael to Babylonia <b>he said</b> that there is actually no dispute between Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi. This <b>Master,</b> who stated that the shewbread is not disqualified during the journeys, <b>stated</b> his ruling <b>with regard to</b> loaves <b>that are arranged</b> on the Table; <b>and</b> that <b>Master,</b> who stated that the shewbread is disqualified during the journeys, <b>stated</b> his ruling <b>with regard to</b> loaves <b>that were removed</b> from the Table. <b>And</b> the two <i>amora’im</i> <b>do not disagree,</b> as each was referring to a different case.
§ The aforementioned <i>baraita</i> states that when the Tabernacle was dismantled the sacrificial food was disqualified, as it was considered to have left the Tabernacle courtyard. <b>Abaye said:</b> One may <b>conclude from</b> the <i>baraita</i> that <b>there</b> could <b>be</b> a case where the <b>dismantling</b> of the Tabernacle in order to commence the <b>journeys</b> would take place <b>at night.</b> This is a necessary conclusion, <b>as if it</b> should <b>enter your mind</b> to say that <b>there</b> could <b>not be</b> a case where the <b>dismantling</b> of the Tabernacle in order to commence the <b>journeys</b> would take place <b>at night, when would</b> the curtains surrounding the Tabernacle <b>be removed?</b> If they were removed right away <b>in the morning, why</b> was the sacrificial food disqualified <b>specifically due to</b> the fact that it <b>left</b> the Tabernacle courtyard? <b>I may derive that it was disqualified</b> because of the fact that it was <b>left overnight.</b>
The Gemara challenges: It is <b>obvious</b> that the Tabernacle could be dismantled at night, as it <b>is written:</b> “And the Lord went before them by day in a pillar of cloud, to lead them the way; and by night in a pillar of fire, to give them light; <b>that they might go by day and by night”</b> (Exodus 13:21). The Gemara answers that Abaye’s observation is necessary <b>lest you say</b> that <b>this statement,</b> that they would travel at night, applies only in a case <b>where</b> the Jewish people <b>dismantled</b> their camp and began to journey <b>by day,</b> in which case they would continue to travel at night. <b>But</b> in a case <b>where they did not dismantle</b> their camp <b>by day they could not dismantle</b> the camp and leave <b>at night.</b> Abaye therefore <b>teaches us</b> that they could set out even at night.
§ The aforementioned <i>baraita</i> teaches that even when the Tabernacle was dismantled, <i>zavim</i> and lepers were sent outside the camp, as the sanctity of both the Levite camp and the Israelite camp remained intact even while the Tabernacle was dismantled. <b>And</b> the Gemara <b>raises a contradiction</b> from another <i>baraita</i>: Once <b>the curtain</b> surrounding the Tabernacle courtyard <b>was rolled up, the <i>zavim</i> and</b> the <b>lepers were permitted to enter into that</b> area where the Tabernacle had stood. This indicates that the camps did not retain their sacred status once the Tabernacle was dismantled. <b>Rav Ashi said:</b> This is <b>not difficult; this</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer</b> and <b>that</b> <i>baraita</i> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>:

Daf 95b

<b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> One <b>might</b> have thought that if <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers pushed</b> their way in <b>and entered the Temple courtyard during</b> the sacrifice of <b>a Paschal offering that is brought in</b> a state of <b>impurity,</b> i.e., when the majority of the nation are ritually impure due to contact with a corpse, that perhaps the <i>zavim</i> and lepers are liable. In other words, one <b>might</b> have thought that since it is prohibited for <i>zavim</i> and lepers to enter even under such circumstances, <b>they would be liable</b> to receive excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>]. Therefore, <b>the verse states: “That they send out from the camp any leper and any <i>zav</i> and anyone impure by reason of a corpse”</b> (Numbers 5:2). The verse indicates that <b>at a time when those who are impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse are sent out</b> of the Temple, <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers are</b> also <b>sent out</b> of the Temple and are liable to receive <i>karet</i> if they enter it.
But when <b>those who are impure</b> with impurity imparted <b>by a corpse are not sent out</b> of the Temple, <b><i>zavim</i> and lepers are</b> also <b>not sent out,</b> i.e., they are not liable to receive <i>karet</i> if they enter the Temple. The <i>baraita</i> that teaches that once the curtain surrounding the Tabernacle courtyard was rolled up it was permitted for <i>zavim</i> and lepers to enter the place where it had stood, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Eliezer. The reason is that once the curtain was rolled up it was permitted for those who were impure with impurity imparted by a corpse to enter; it was prohibited for them to enter only the Temple courtyard, and this had been dismantled. According to Rabbi Eliezer, it was permitted even for <i>zavim</i> and lepers to then enter the camp. The <i>baraita</i> that rules that even when the Tabernacle was dismantled <i>zavim</i> and lepers were sent outside the camp, is in accordance with the opinion of the Rabbis.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> In the case of <b>both the two loaves and the shewbread, the kneading of their</b> dough <b>and the forming of their</b> loaves take place <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>but their baking</b> takes place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard. <b>And their</b> preparation <b>does not override Shabbat. Rabbi Yehuda says: All of the procedures</b> involved in <b>their</b> preparation take place <b>inside</b> the courtyard. <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One <b>should always be accustomed to say</b> that <b>the two loaves and the shewbread are fit</b> if they were prepared <b>in the Temple courtyard and they are</b> also <b>fit</b> if they were prepared <b>in Beit Pagei,</b> outside the Temple Mount, as he maintains that they may be baked outside the Temple courtyard.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna states that according to the opinion of the first <i>tanna</i> the two loaves and the shewbread are kneaded and shaped outside the Temple courtyard, but they are baked inside the courtyard. The Gemara comments: <b>This itself</b> is <b>difficult.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: <b>You said</b> initially that <b>the kneading of their</b> dough <b>and the forming of their</b> loaves take place <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard. One can infer from this that <b>apparently,</b> the <b>dry measure,</b> i.e., the vessel used in the Temple for measuring dry substances, e.g., flour, <b>was not consecrated.</b> If the dry measure sanctified the items placed in them, the flour brought for the two loaves and the shewbread would already be sanctified, and these loaves could not be kneaded and shaped outside the courtyard. And the mishna subsequently states that <b>their baking</b> takes place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard. One can infer from this that <b>apparently,</b> the <b>dry measure was consecrated.</b> If the flour had not been sanctified by being placed in the measuring vessel, why must the loaves be baked inside the Temple courtyard? <b>Rabba says: A formidable man, who is</b> as <b>tough as iron, raised</b> this <b>difficulty. And who is</b> that Sage? This is referring to <b>Rav Sheshet.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>What</b> is the <b>difficulty? Perhaps</b> the measure of <b>a tenth</b> of an ephah, which is used to measure the flour for the two loaves and the shewbread, <b>does not sanctify</b> that which is placed inside it, but the <b>oven sanctifies</b> the loaves that are baked in it, and therefore they must be baked inside the Temple courtyard.
<b>Rather, if</b> the mishna <b>is difficult, this is difficult:</b> The mishna states that <b>the baking</b> of the two loaves and the shewbread takes place <b>inside</b> the courtyard. <b>Evidently,</b> the <b>oven sanctifies</b> that which is baked inside it. And the mishna subsequently states that kneading, shaping, and baking the loaves <b>does not override Shabbat.</b> If these procedures were performed before Shabbat in a vessel that sanctifies them, the loaves would be <b>disqualified by</b> virtue of the fact that they were <b>left overnight</b> without having been placed on the Table. <b>Rather, Rava says: A formidable man, who is</b> as <b>tough as iron, raised</b> this <b>difficulty. And who is</b> that Sage? This is referring to <b>Rav Sheshet.</b>
<b>Rav Ashi said: What</b> is the <b>difficulty? Perhaps</b> the oven does not sanctify the loaves that are baked in it, and therefore the two loaves and the shewbread are not disqualified by being left overnight. And accordingly, <b>what is</b> the meaning of the statement: Their baking takes place <b>inside?</b> This is not referring to inside the Temple courtyard. Rather, it means they are baked <b>in a place</b> where there are priests who are <b>vigilant</b> in their efforts, who will supervise the loaves as they are baked and ensure they do not become leavened.
The Gemara notes: <b>And this</b> statement attributed <b>to Rav Ashi is an error [<i>baruta</i>],</b> as <b>whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it, it is difficult: <b>If we require vigilant</b> priests for the <b>baking</b> of the two loaves and the shewbread, <b>we</b> should <b>also require vigilant</b> priests for the <b>kneading and forming</b> of the loaves. <b>And if we do not require vigilant</b> priests for the <b>kneading and forming</b> of the loaves, <b>we</b> should <b>also not require vigilant</b> priests for the <b>baking.</b> Rav Ashi’s explanation does not explain why the mishna differentiates between the kneading and forming of the loaves on the one hand, and their baking on the other hand. <b>Rather,</b> the statement attributed <b>to Rav Ashi is an error.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that <b>Rabbi Yehuda says: All the procedures</b> involved in the preparation of the two loaves and the shewbread take place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, whereas Rabbi Shimon maintains that even their baking may take place outside the courtyard. <b>Rabbi Abbahu bar Kahana says: Both</b> Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon derived their opinions from <b>the same verse,</b> which <b>they interpreted homiletically.</b> When David fled from King Saul he came to Nov, where he requested bread from Ahimelech the priest. Ahimelech replied: “There is no non-sacred bread under my hand, but there is sacred bread” (I Samuel 21:5), i.e., the shewbread. David then said to Ahimelech: <b>“But it is a non-sacred manner, and yet it shall be consecrated today in the vessel”</b> (I Samuel 21:6).
Both Sages understand David’s response to be a halakhic critique: <b>Rabbi Yehuda holds</b> that David <b>found</b> the priests <b>baking</b> the shewbread <b>on a weekday.</b> David <b>said to them:</b> Why <b>are you baking</b> the shewbread in <b>a non-sacred manner,</b> i.e., on a weekday, rather than on Shabbat? <b>“Yet it shall be consecrated today in the vessel,”</b> i.e., it will be consecrated today when it is baked in the oven, and <b>it will be disqualified</b> tomorrow <b>because</b> it will have been <b>left overnight.</b> Rabbi Yehuda infers from David’s criticism that the shewbread must be baked on Shabbat in the Temple courtyard, as it is consecrated in the oven.
<b>Rabbi Shimon holds</b> that David <b>found</b> the priests <b>baking</b> the shewbread <b>on Shabbat.</b> David <b>said to them: Aren’t you required to prepare it</b> in <b>a non-sacred manner,</b> i.e., on a weekday? <b>Does the oven consecrate</b> the shewbread? No, <b>it is</b> the <b>Table that consecrates</b> it when the shewbread is placed there. The loaves are therefore not disqualified by being left overnight.
The Gemara asks: <b>And how can you say that</b> David <b>found</b> the priests <b>at the time of baking? But isn’t it</b> subsequently <b>written: “And the priest gave him sacred bread, for there was no bread there but the shewbread that was taken from before the Lord”</b> (I Samuel 21:7)? This indicates that David received shewbread that had already been on the Table, not loaves that had just been baked.
<b>Rather, what</b> is the meaning of the statement: “But it is <b>a non-sacred manner,</b> and yet it shall be consecrated today in the vessel,” <b>which</b> David <b>said to</b> the priests? The Gemara replies: <b>This is</b> what the priests <b>said to him:</b> There is <b>no bread</b> here <b>except “the shewbread that was taken from before the Lord,”</b> and the shewbread is prohibited for consumption by non-priests.
David <b>said to</b> the priests: <b>It is not necessary</b> to say that it is permitted for me to eat <b>this</b> shewbread, which has already been removed from the Table. This is <b>because</b> the frankincense placed in the bowls that were on the Table has been burned. <b>Since</b> the shewbread <b>has been removed from</b> having the status of items to which the <i>halakhot</i> of <b>misuse</b> of consecrated property apply, <b>it is</b> considered <b>a non-sacred matter,</b> i.e., permitted to priests for consumption. <b>But even the other</b> shewbread, <b>which “shall be consecrated today in the vessel,”</b> i.e., the shewbread placed on the Table today, <b>you should give him,</b> i.e., you should give me, <b>to eat.</b>

Daf 96a

This is because <b>he is,</b> i.e., I am, <b>dangerously</b> ill, being utterly famished, and a non-priest may eat sacrificial food in a life-threatening situation. <b>And</b> with regard to <b>Rabbi Yehuda and Rabbi Shimon,</b> their dispute does not stem from the interpretation of the verses. Rather, <b>they disagree with regard to a tradition,</b> as they had divergent traditions as to whether or not the oven consecrates the shewbread.
The language of the mishna <b>is also precise, as it teaches</b> that <b>Rabbi Shimon says:</b> One <b>should always be accustomed to say</b> that <b>the two loaves and the shewbread are fit</b> if they were prepared <b>in the Temple courtyard and they are</b> also <b>fit</b> if they were prepared <b>in Beit Pagei.</b> The term: One should always be accustomed to say, indicates that Rabbi Shimon’s opinion is based on an oral tradition and not on the interpretation of a verse. The Gemara concludes: One may <b>conclude from</b> the mishna that this is the case.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to the twelve loaves of the <b>High Priest’s griddle-cake</b> offering, of which six are offered in the morning and six in the evening, <b>their kneading, the forming of their</b> loaves, <b>and their baking</b> take place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> all types of labor involved in those actions <b>override Shabbat.</b> These labors cannot be performed prior to Shabbat, as once the loaves are consecrated in a service vessel they are disqualified if they are left overnight. <b>Grinding their</b> flour <b>and sifting their</b> flour <b>do not override Shabbat. Rabbi Akiva stated a principle: Any labor that can be performed on Shabbat eve does not override Shabbat, but</b> one <b>that cannot be performed on Shabbat eve overrides Shabbat.</b>
<b>All</b> preparatory procedures of <b>the meal offerings</b> that take place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard, e.g., kneading and forming the High Priest’s griddle cakes, <b>involve</b> the <b>use</b> of a service <b>vessel</b> that consecrates the offerings. <b>But</b> any preparatory procedures that take place <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard, e.g., kneading and forming the two loaves and the shewbread, <b>do not involve</b> the <b>use</b> of a service <b>vessel.</b>
With regard to <b>the two loaves, their length is seven handbreadths, their width is four handbreadths, and</b> they have hornlike <b>protrusions</b> made of dough that is attached to each of their corners, which are <b>four fingerbreadths</b> high. With regard to the loaves of <b>shewbread, their length is ten handbreadths, their width is five handbreadths, and</b> each loaf’s hornlike <b>protrusions</b> is <b>seven fingerbreadths</b> high.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The following letters are a mnemonic so <b>that you will not err</b> and forget the dimensions of the two loaves: <b><i>Zayin</i>, <i>dalet</i>, <i>dalet</i>.</b> The numerical value of the letter <i>zayin</i> is seven and the numerical value of the letter <i>dalet</i> is four. The mnemonic therefore represents the length of seven handbreadths, the width of four handbreadths, and the height of four fingerbreadths, respectively. The following letters are a mnemonic for the dimensions of the shewbread: <b><i>Yod</i>, <i>heh</i>, <i>zayin</i>,</b> which stand for the length of ten handbreadths, the width of five handbreadths, and the height of seven fingerbreadths, respectively. <b>Ben Zoma says</b> that it is written: <b>“And you shall set upon the Table shewbread [<i>leḥem panim</i>] before Me always”</b> (Exodus 25:30). The term <b><i>leḥem panim</i></b> indicates <b>that it should have</b> vertical <b>sides [<i>panim</i>]</b> rather than a rounded shape.
As for <b>the Table, its length is ten</b> handbreadths <b>and its width is five</b> handbreadths, as the Torah states that the Table is two cubits long and one cubit wide (see Exodus 25:23), and Rabbi Yehuda holds that the cubit used as the unit of measurement for the construction of the Temple vessels was equal to five handbreadths. With regard to <b>the shewbread, its length is ten</b> handbreadths <b>and its width is five</b> handbreadths.
The priest <b>places the length</b> of the two shewbread arrangements <b>across the width of</b> the <b>Table,</b> which leaves five handbreadths of each loaf protruding from the Table. <b>And he folds</b> the protruding <b>two and a half handbreadths</b> upward <b>on this</b> side of the Table, <b>and</b> the protruding <b>two and a half handbreadths</b> upward <b>on that</b> side of the Table. One <b>finds,</b> therefore, that <b>the length</b> of the shewbread <b>covers the width of the Table.</b> Similarly, since the width of each loaf is five handbreadths, the width of the two loaves filled the entire length of the Table. This is <b>the statement of Rabbi Yehuda.</b>
<b>Rabbi Meir says:</b> With regard to <b>the Table, its length is twelve</b> handbreadths <b>and its width is six</b> handbreadths, as the measure of a cubit used in the construction of the Temple vessels was equal to six handbreadths. Concerning <b>the shewbread, its length is ten</b> handbreadths <b>and its width is five</b> handbreadths.
Rabbi Meir continues: The priest <b>places the length</b> of the shewbread <b>across the width of</b> the <b>Table,</b> which leaves four handbreadths of each loaf protruding from the Table. <b>He folds</b> the protruding <b>two handbreadths</b> upward <b>on this</b> side of the Table, <b>and</b> the protruding <b>two handbreadths</b> upward <b>on that</b> side of the Table. The width of the two arrangements of shewbread occupies only ten of the twelve handbreadths of the length of the Table, <b>and</b> this leaves <b>a space of two handbreadths in the middle,</b> between the two arrangements, <b>so that the wind will blow between them</b> and prevent the loaves from becoming moldy.
<b>Abba Shaul says: There,</b> in the space between the two arrangements, the priests <b>would place</b> the <b>two bowls of frankincense that</b> accompany <b>the shewbread.</b> The Sages <b>said to him: But isn’t it already stated: “And you shall place pure frankincense upon [<i>al</i>] each arrangement,</b> that it may be for the bread as a memorial part, an offering made by fire to the Lord” (Leviticus 24:7)? The verse indicates that the frankincense is placed upon the shewbread and not next to it. Abba Shaul <b>said to</b> the Sages in response: <b>Isn’t it already stated: “And next to him [<i>alav</i>] shall be the tribe of Manasseh”</b> (Numbers 2:20)? Just as the preposition “<i>alav</i>” in this verse means that the tribe of Manasseh pitched camp next to the tribe of Ephraim and not upon it, so too, the preposition “<i>al</i>” means that the frankincense was placed next to the arrangements of the shewbread.
The mishna continues to describe the shewbread Table: <b>And there were four panels of gold there,</b> which stood on the ground and rose above the height of the Table, and <b>they split up at their upper ends,</b> above the Table, so <b>that</b> the rods upon which the shewbread was placed could rest upon the panels. In this manner the panels <b>would support</b> the shewbread. There were <b>two</b> panels <b>for this arrangement and two</b> panels <b>for that arrangement, and</b> there were <b>twenty-eight rods,</b> each of which was shaped <b>like half of a hollow reed.</b> There were <b>fourteen</b> rods <b>for this arrangement and fourteen</b> rods <b>for that arrangement.</b>
<b>Neither</b> the <b>arranging of</b> the <b>rods</b> for the new shewbread, <b>nor their removal</b> from the arrangement of the old shewbread, <b>overrides Shabbat. Rather,</b> a priest <b>enters</b> the Sanctuary <b>on Shabbat eve,</b> i.e., Friday before sundown, <b>and removes</b> each of the rods from between the loaves. <b>And</b> according to Rabbi Meir he then <b>places</b> each rod in the space between the two arrangements, <b>along the length of the Table.</b> Then, on Shabbat, he places the new shewbread on the Table without the rods, and he inserts the rods between the loaves at the conclusion of Shabbat.
The mishna concludes: <b>All the vessels that were in the Temple,</b> including the Table, were placed so that <b>their length was</b> from east to west, <b>along the length of</b> the <b>Temple.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that <b>all</b> preparatory procedures of <b>the meal offerings</b> that take place <b>inside</b> the Temple courtyard <b>involve</b> the <b>use</b> of a service <b>vessel</b> that consecrates the offerings. The Sages <b>asked Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi: <b>From where</b> is <b>this</b> <i>halakha</i> derived? Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>said to them: Doesn’t</b> the verse <b>state: “And he said to me: This is the place where the priests shall cook the guilt offering and the sin offering, where they shall bake the meal offering; that they do not bring them out to the outer courtyard,</b> to sanctify the people” (Ezekiel 46:20)? Cooking the meat of the guilt offering and the sin offering requires the use of a vessel, and the verse indicates that this must be performed inside the Temple courtyard, as the meat may not be brought to the outer courtyard.
Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi explains: The verse compares the meal offering to the guilt offering and the sin offering, indicating that the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>meal offering is similar to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of the <b>guilt offering and the sin offering. Just as</b> the <b>guilt offering and</b> the <b>sin offering require</b> the use of a service <b>vessel</b> in order to cook the sacrificial meat, and this is performed inside the Temple courtyard, <b>so too,</b> the <b>meal offering also requires</b> a service <b>vessel</b> for its preparation, which is performed inside the Temple courtyard.
§ The mishna cites the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda: As for <b>the Table, its length is ten</b> handbreadths and its width is five handbreadths. Five handbreadths of each loaf of the shewbread, each of which is bent upward, protrude from the Table; two and a half handbreadths on each side. Rabbi Meir holds that the width of the Table is six handbreadths. Therefore, only four handbreadths of each loaf protrude from the Table and two handbreadths are bent upward on each side.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>one folds</b> up <b>two and a half handbreadths</b> from each side of the loaves, <b>it emerges</b> that the <b>Table consecrates fifteen handbreadths above</b> it, as there were six loaves on each side of the Table, which were each two and a half handbreadths high. And <b>according to the statement of the one who says</b> that <b>one folds</b> up <b>two handbreadths</b> from each side of the loaves, <b>it emerges</b> that the <b>Table consecrates twelve handbreadths above</b> it.
The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there rods</b> between the loaves? The total height of the arrangements should therefore be more than fifteen handbreadths according to Rabbi Yehuda, and more than twelve handbreadths according to Rabbi Meir. The Gemara answers that the rods did not add to the height of the arrangement, as the loaves were shaped with indentations so that <b>the rods were embedded</b> in them.
The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that the rods are required? They are required <b>because</b> the <b>bread</b> is apt to <b>become moldy.</b> The rods prevent this by enabling the air to circulate between the loaves. But if the rods are sunk into the loaves, <b>ultimately</b> the <b>bread will become moldy.</b> The Gemara answers <b>that</b> the priest <b>would raise</b> the rods <b>slightly</b> above the loaves. The rods were not completely embedded in the loaves, and there was a small gap between the loaves that enabled the air to circulate.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>isn’t there that slight</b> gap between each of the six loaves, causing the total height of each arrangement to be more than fifteen or twelve handbreadths? The Gemara answers: <b>Since</b> the gaps <b>did not</b> amount to a single <b>handbreadth,</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>did not count them.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there</b> also the <b>bowls</b> of frankincense that are placed above the arrangements, adding to the total height of the items consecrated by the Table? The Gemara answers: The bowls of frankincense <b>would rest inside</b> the middle <b>of the bread and</b> consequently <b>their</b> height <b>corresponded with that of the bread.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there</b> the hornlike <b>protrusions</b> of the shewbread, which are seven fingerbreadths in height? These protrusions should be added to the total height of the arrangements. The Gemara answers: With regard to the <b>protrusions,</b> the priest <b>would fold them into</b> the <b>bread, and</b> the loaf of <b>bread</b> above <b>rested upon them.</b> The protrusions therefore did not increase the height of the arrangements.

Daf 96b

The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> the Table’s decorated <b>frame,</b> which ran around its perimeter and was one handbreadth wide, as the verse states: “And you shall make for it a frame of a handbreadth” (Exodus 25:25)? Since the arrangements are placed on the Table’s frame, they rise one additional handbreadth above the Table.
The Gemara answers: Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement is <b>in accordance with the</b> opinion of the <b>one who said</b> the Table’s <b>frame was</b> not above the Table’s surface but <b>below</b> it, and therefore it did not add any height to the arrangements on the Table. <b>And</b> furthermore, even <b>according to the one who said</b> the Table’s <b>frame was above</b> the Table’s surface, it did not add to the height of the arrangements. This is because the frame <b>was tilted</b> outward, <b>but</b> the <b>bread was set within</b> the area <b>of</b> the <b>Table’s</b> surface.
The Gemara cites the dispute with regard to the location of the frame: <b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>Rabbi Yosei says: There were no panels there</b> at all, as they were not required in order to support the loaves. <b>Rather, the Table’s frame supported the bread,</b> as the frame was above the Table’s surface. The Rabbis <b>said to</b> Rabbi Yosei: The Table’s <b>frame was below</b> the Table’s surface, and therefore the panels were required to support the loaves.
§ <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: According to the statement of the one who says</b> that the Table’s <b>frame was below</b> the Table’s surface, the surface was merely a flat board. It is a halakhic principle with regard to wooden utensils that only rounded utensils are susceptible to ritual impurity, but not flat utensils. It is known that the shewbread Table was susceptible to impurity. One may therefore infer from this that a flat <b>board is susceptible to impurity,</b> provided <b>that</b> it <b>can be turned over</b> and used on both sides. This is because the wide surface of the board renders it functionally similar to a concave receptacle.
Rabbi Yoḥanan continues: <b>According to the statement of the one who says</b> that the Table’s <b>frame was above</b> the Table’s surface, the Table served as a receptacle. One therefore cannot infer the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a flat <b>board that can be turned over</b> from the case of the Table, and <b>you must</b> still <b>raise the dilemma</b> as to whether it is susceptible to ritual impurity.
The Gemara asks: One can conclude <b>by inference</b> from Rabbi Yoḥanan’s statement <b>that</b> the <b>Table is susceptible to ritual impurity.</b> But <b>it is a wooden vessel designated to rest</b> in a fixed place, <b>and any wooden vessel</b> that is <b>designated to rest</b> in a fixed place <b>is not susceptible to impurity.</b>
The Gemara explains: <b>What is the reason</b> for this <i>halakha</i>? The verse states with regard to items that are rendered impure by the carcasses of creeping animals: “And anything upon which any of them fall when they are dead shall be impure, whether it is any vessel of wood, or cloth, or leather, or sack” (Leviticus 11:32). The verse juxtaposes wooden vessels with sacks, indicating that <b>we require</b> a wooden vessel to be <b>similar to a sack</b> in order to be susceptible to ritual impurity. <b>Just as a sack is carried</b> both when it is <b>full and</b> when it is <b>empty, so too, any</b> wooden vessel that is <b>carried</b> both <b>full and empty</b> is susceptible to impurity. Since the Table is designated to rest in a fixed place and not to be carried, it should not be susceptible to impurity.
The Gemara answers: The <b>Table is also carried</b> both <b>full and empty,</b> i.e., even when the shewbread is upon it, <b>in accordance with</b> the statement <b>of Reish Lakish.</b> This is <b>as Reish Lakish said: What</b> is the meaning of that <b>which is written:</b> “And you shall set them in two arrangements, six in an arrangement, <b>upon the pure Table</b> before the Lord” (Leviticus 24:6)? The term “the <b>pure</b> Table” teaches <b>by inference that there is</b> a case where the Table becomes <b>impure,</b> and therefore the Torah states that the Table must be pure when the shewbread is set upon it. This conclusion is difficult, as the principle that a wooden vessel designated to rest in a fixed place is not susceptible to impurity indicates that the Table should not be susceptible to impurity.
<b>Rather,</b> the verse <b>teaches that</b> the priests would <b>lift</b> the Table with its shewbread <b>to display the shewbread to the pilgrims</b> standing in the Temple courtyard, <b>and</b> a priest would <b>say to them: See</b> how <b>beloved you</b> are <b>before,</b> i.e., in the eyes of, <b>the Omnipresent,</b> Who constantly performs a miracle with regard to the shewbread. For this reason, the Table is susceptible to ritual impurity.
This is <b>in accordance with the statement of Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi, as Rabbi Yehoshua ben Levi said: A great miracle was performed with the shewbread:</b> Its condition at the time of <b>its removal</b> from the Table, after having been left there for a week, was <b>like</b> its condition at the time of <b>its arrangement</b> on the Table; <b>as it is stated: “To place hot bread on the day when it was taken away”</b> (I Samuel 21:7), indicating that it was as hot on the day of its removal as it was on the day when it was placed on the Table.
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> why is it necessary to derive that the Table is susceptible to impurity due to the fact that it is not designated to rest in a fixed place? <b>I may derive</b> that it is susceptible to impurity <b>due to</b> its gold <b>covering. Didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 22:1): Consider the case of <b>the table and the <i>dulbeki</i>,</b> a small table upon which the food and drink are placed before being served at the dining table, <b>that were</b> partially <b>broken, or that one covered with marble</b> stone, which is not susceptible to impurity. If <b>an area of their</b> surface large enough for <b>placing cups</b> there <b>was left</b> unbroken or uncovered with marble they remain <b>susceptible to impurity. Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The remaining surface <b>area</b> must be large enough for <b>placing pieces</b> of meat and bread as well.
One can infer from the mishna that if one <b>left</b> part of the surface area of the table without covering it with marble, <b>yes,</b> it remains susceptible to impurity. But if <b>he did not leave</b> part of the table without covering it with marble it is <b>not</b> susceptible to impurity. Evidently, the status of a vessel is determined according to the material of its external covering and not according to its main material. Consequently, since the shewbread Table was covered with gold it should have the status of a metal vessel, which is susceptible to ritual impurity even if it is designated to rest in a fixed place.
<b>And if you would say</b> the case of the shewbread Table is different, as <b>here,</b> with regard to the marble-covered table, the mishna is referring <b>to a permanent covering</b> that is fixed to the table with nails, whereas <b>there,</b> in the case of the shewbread Table, the discussion is referring <b>to a covering that is not permanent,</b> as the gold was not attached to the shewbread Table with nails, this explanation is difficult. <b>But didn’t Reish Lakish raise a dilemma to Rabbi Yoḥanan:</b> Is the mishna that discusses the marble-covered table referring only <b>to a permanent covering, or</b> even <b>to a covering that is not permanent?</b> Is it referring only to a case <b>where</b> one <b>covered</b>

Daf 97a

the Table’s <b>rim [<i>levazbazin</i>]</b> as well as the Table itself, <b>or</b> even to a case <b>where</b> one <b>did not cover</b> its <b>rim? And</b> Rabbi Yoḥanan <b>said to</b> Reish Lakish: The case of <b>a permanent covering is not different, and</b> the case of <b>a covering that is not permanent is not different.</b> Likewise, the case where one <b>covered</b> the <b>rim is not different, and</b> the case where one <b>did not cover</b> the <b>rim is not different.</b> In any case a vessel’s status is determined according to the material of the external covering, and the shewbread Table should be susceptible to impurity because its external covering was of gold. It is therefore not necessary to derive that the Table is susceptible to impurity due to the fact that it is not designated to rest in a fixed place.
The Gemara suggests another explanation: <b>And if you would say</b> that the <b>acacia wood</b> from which the shewbread Table is fashioned is different, as it is <b>an important,</b> valuable type of wood <b>and</b> therefore the Table’s status as a wooden vessel <b>is not negated</b> by the fact that it was covered with gold, there would still be a difficulty. <b>This</b> explanation <b>works out well according to</b> the opinion of <b>Reish Lakish, who said:</b> The mishna <b>taught</b> that the status of a wooden vessel is determined according to the material of its covering <b>only with regard to vessels</b> made <b>of</b> medium-grade <b><i>akhsalgos</i></b> wood, <b>which come from overseas, but vessels</b> made <b>of</b> expensive <b><i>masmas</i></b> wood <b>are important, and</b> therefore their status as wooden vessels <b>is not negated</b> by the covering. According to this opinion the ruling works out <b>well,</b> as the acacia wood of the shewbread Table is also valuable. <b>But according to</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan, who said</b> the importance of <b><i>masmas</i> vessels is also negated</b> by the covering, <b>what is there to say?</b>
The Gemara answers: The <b>Table is different, because the Merciful One called it wood, as it is stated: “The altar was of wood, three cubits high,</b> and <b>its length two cubits, and so its corners; and its length, and its walls were also of wood, and he said to me: This is the Table that is before the Lord”</b> (Ezekiel 41:22). This verse is referring to the shewbread Table, and it describes it as being made of wood, even though the wood was not visible. This indicates that its status is like that of all wooden vessels, which are not susceptible to impurity unless they are carried both when empty and when full.
The Gemara challenges: Why does the verse <b>begin with the</b> word <b>“altar” and conclude with the</b> word <b>“Table,”</b> even though both terms are referring to the same item? <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan and Rabbi Elazar both say</b> the following interpretation: <b>When the Temple is standing,</b> the <b>altar effects atonement for</b> the transgressions of <b>a person, but now that the Temple is not standing, a person’s table effects atonement for his</b> transgressions, if he provides for the poor and needy from the food on his table.
§ The mishna describes the shewbread Table (96a): <b>There were four panels of gold there,</b> which split up at their upper ends, above the Table, and there were twenty-eight rods that rested upon the panels. The Gemara asks: <b>From where are these matters</b> derived? <b>Rav Ketina said: The verse states</b> with regard to the Table: <b>“And you shall make its dishes and its pans, <i>uksotav umnakkiyyotav</i>,</b> with which it shall be covered; of pure gold you shall make them” (Exodus 25:29).
Rav Ketina interprets the verse: <b>“Its dishes,” these are</b> the <b>molds</b> in which the loaves are kneaded, baked, and placed after baking (see 94a). <b>“Its pans,” these are</b> the <b>bowls</b> for the frankincense that is placed on the Table with the shewbread. <b>“<i>Kesotav</i>,” these are</b> the four <b>panels</b> of gold. <b>“<i>Umnakkiyyotav</i>,” these are</b> the <b>rods,</b> which rest on the notches in the panels and bear the loaves, one on top of the other. <b>“With which it shall be covered,”</b> this indicates <b>that the bread is covered by</b> the rods.
<b>Rava raises an objection</b> to this interpretation, which indicates that the rods are required by Torah law: The mishna states: <b>Neither the arranging of the rods</b> for the new shewbread, <b>nor their removal</b> from the arrangement of the old shewbread, <b>overrides Shabbat. And if it enters your mind</b> to say the rods are required <b>by Torah</b> law, <b>why does</b> their arrangement <b>not override Shabbat?</b>
<b>Rava then said: That which I said,</b> that one can infer from the mishna that the rods are not required by Torah law, <b>is not correct, as we learned</b> in the mishna that <b>Rabbi Akiva stated a principle: Any labor that can be performed on Shabbat eve does not override Shabbat. And these</b> actions, arranging and removing the rods, <b>can also</b> be performed in a manner <b>that does not</b> require <b>overriding Shabbat for them,</b> as the rods can be removed before Shabbat, and the rods can be arranged for the new loaves once Shabbat has ended.
Rava explains why the rods can be arranged after Shabbat: <b>What is the reason</b> that the rods are required? They are necessary in order to create a gap between the loaves, so that the <b>bread does not become moldy. In</b> such a short time <b>period as this,</b> from when the new loaves are placed on the Table on Shabbat until the arrangement of the rods after Shabbat, the loaves will <b>not become moldy.</b>
This is <b>as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the removal and arrangement of the rods: <b>How</b> does the priest proceed? <b>He enters</b> the Sanctuary <b>on Shabbat eve and removes</b> the rods from between the loaves. <b>And he places them</b> in the space of two handbreadths between the two arrangements, <b>along the length of</b> the <b>Table. And</b> at <b>the conclusion of Shabbat he enters</b> the Sanctuary again. <b>He raises the ends of a loaf</b> of the shewbread <b>and inserts a rod underneath it, and again raises the ends of a loaf and inserts a rod underneath it.</b>
The <i>baraita</i> continues to describe the placement of the rods: Each arrangement contains six loaves. The <b>four loaves</b> in the middle of the six <b>require three</b> for the first of the four middle loaves, and likewise <b>three rods</b> for each of the other middle loaves, totaling twelve rods. <b>The upper</b> loaf <b>requires only two</b> rods, <b>as</b> the <b>weight</b> of another loaf <b>does not</b> bear <b>upon it.</b> Each arrangement therefore requires a total of fourteen rods, and the two arrangements require twenty-eight rods. As for <b>the lowest</b> loaf of each arrangement, <b>it does not require</b> rods <b>at all, as it rests on the Table itself.</b>
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Kelim</i> 17:10) that <b>Rabbi Meir says: All</b> the <b>cubits that were</b> mentioned <b>with regard to the Temple</b> were <b>medium</b> cubits, consisting of six handbreadths, <b>except</b> in the case <b>of</b> the following items: <b>The golden altar,</b> which was one cubit long and one cubit wide; each protruding <b>corner</b> of the external altar, which were one cubit long, one cubit wide, and one cubit high; <b>the surrounding ledge</b> of the external altar, which was five cubits high and one cubit wide; <b>and the base</b> of the altar, which was one cubit high and one cubit wide. In all these cases, the cubit was of five handbreadths. <b>Rabbi Yehuda says:</b> The measure of <b>a cubit</b> that was used with regard to the <b>building</b> of the Temple was a cubit of <b>six handbreadths, but</b> the cubit mentioned <b>with regard to</b> the Temple <b>vessels,</b> e.g., the Table, the Candelabrum and the golden altar, was a smaller cubit of <b>five</b> handbreadths.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: And both</b> Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda <b>derived</b> their opinions from <b>the same verse: “And these are the measures of the altar by cubits: The cubit is a cubit and a handbreadth,</b>

Daf 97b

<b>and the bottom shall be a cubit, and the breadth a cubit, and its border by its edge round about shall be the one span. And this shall be the higher part of the altar”</b> (Ezekiel 43:13). The first section of this verse is referring to the outer altar: <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit,” this is</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar. “And <b>the breadth a cubit,” this is</b> the <b>surrounding ledge</b> of the altar. <b>“And its border by its edge round about shall be the one span,” these are</b> the protruding <b>corners</b> of the altar, which were one cubit wide and one cubit high. “And <b>this shall be the higher part of the altar,” this is</b> referring to <b>the golden altar,</b> which stood inside the Sanctuary and was also measured with small cubits.
Rabbi Yoḥanan explains that Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda disagree with regard to the inference from the phrase “And this shall be the higher part of the altar.” <b>Rabbi Meir maintains</b> that one can infer that it <b>is this,</b> the golden altar, which is measured <b>with a cubit of five</b> handbreadths, <b>but all</b> the <b>cubits</b> of the other <b>vessels</b> in the Temple are measured <b>with a cubit of six</b> handbreadths. <b>And Rabbi Yehuda maintains</b> that one can infer that <b>like this</b> small cubit <b>shall be all</b> the <b>cubits</b> of the other <b>vessels</b> in the Temple.
The Gemara discusses the interpretation of the verse: It might <b>enter your mind</b> to say that the verse is referring to the height of the sections of the altar, i.e., <b>from the base</b> of the altar <b>until</b> the <b>surrounding ledge</b> the <b>height</b> is measured <b>with a cubit of five</b> handbreadths. <b>And what</b> is the meaning of the phrase <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit, and the breadth a cubit”? This</b> is what the verse <b>is saying: From</b> the <b>cubit</b> at the <b>bottom,</b> i.e., the base of the altar, <b>until</b> the <b>cubit</b> of the <b>breadth</b> of the surrounding ledge shall be measured <b>with a cubit of five</b> handbreadths.
The Gemara explains the difficulty with this interpretation: According to this interpretation, <b>how many</b> cubits is <b>the height of the altar?</b> It is <b>ten cubits. Six</b> of these cubits, from the ground up to the surrounding ledge, are measured <b>with</b> a cubit of <b>five</b> handbreadths <b>each,</b> totaling thirty handbreadths. <b>And</b> the remaining <b>four</b> cubits, from the ledge up to the top of the corners of the altar, are measured <b>with</b> a cubit of <b>six</b> handbreadths <b>each,</b> totaling twenty-four handbreadths.
Accordingly, <b>how many</b> handbreadths is the height of the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>fifty-four</b> handbreadths. <b>How many</b> handbreadths is the height of <b>half of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>twenty-seven</b> handbreadths. <b>How many</b> handbreadths is the height <b>from</b> the top of the <b>corners</b> of the altar <b>until</b> the <b>surrounding ledge?</b> It is <b>twenty-four</b> handbreadths, four cubits of six handbreadths each. Therefore, <b>how many</b> handbreadths is the surrounding ledge <b>short of half</b> the height <b>of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>three</b> handbreadths above the halfway mark. <b>And we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 3:1): <b>A red line encircled</b> the altar <b>in the middle, in order to separate between the blood</b> that must be presented on the <b>upper</b> part of the altar and <b>the blood</b> that must be presented on the <b>lower</b> part of the altar.
<b>But</b> this interpretation is contradicted by <b>that which is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> <b>with regard to the bird burnt offering,</b> the blood of which must be presented on the upper part of the altar: The priest <b>would ascend the ramp and turn to the surrounding ledge and arrive at</b> the <b>southeast corner. He would pinch off the</b> bird’s <b>head across its nape, and separate</b> it from its body. <b>He would</b> then <b>squeeze out its blood on the wall of the altar</b> beside him. <b>And if</b> the priest <b>performed</b> the squeezing <b>below his feet,</b> i.e., below the surrounding ledge, <b>even</b> one <b>cubit</b> beneath the ledge, it is <b>valid.</b>
The Gemara explains the difficulty: According to the previous calculation, the surrounding ledge was only three handbreadths above the halfway mark. Therefore, if one squeezes out the blood one cubit, of five handbreadths, below the ledge, <b>isn’t he putting</b> the blood of an offering that must be presented on the <b>upper</b> part of the altar, <b>two handbreadths below</b> the middle of the altar?
<b>Rather,</b> the verse must be interpreted differently. It is not referring to the height of the altar but to the width of each of its levels, as follows: <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit”:</b> From the top of the external side of the base of the altar, the wall of the altar is <b>inset</b> by one cubit of five handbreadths. “And <b>the breadth a cubit,”</b> this is referring to the width of the surrounding ledge of the altar, as at this point the wall is again <b>inset</b> by one cubit of five handbreadths. <b>“Its border by its edge round about</b> shall be the one span,” this is referring to the width of the corners of the altar, which is also a cubit of five handbreadths, causing the area of the top of the altar to be <b>inset</b> by an additional cubit.
The Gemara explains the <i>halakha</i> with regard to the bird burnt offering according to this interpretation: <b>How many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height of the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>sixty</b> handbreadths, ten cubits of six handbreadths each. <b>How many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height of <b>half of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>thirty</b> handbreadths. <b>How many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height <b>from</b> the top of the <b>corners</b> of the altar <b>until</b> the <b>surrounding ledge?</b> It is <b>twenty-four</b> handbreadths, four cubits of six handbreadths each. Therefore, <b>how many</b> handbreadths is the surrounding ledge <b>short of half</b> the height <b>of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>six</b> handbreadths above the halfway mark. <b>And we learned</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: And <b>if</b> the priest <b>performed</b> the squeezing <b>below his feet, even</b> one <b>cubit</b> beneath the ledge, it is <b>valid.</b> According to this calculation, one cubit below the surrounding ledge is still part of the upper section of the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>To what</b> part of the altar <b>did you interpret</b> the verse to be referring? It is referring <b>to</b> the width by which each section of the altar is <b>inset. And can you interpret</b> the verse as referring <b>to</b> the width by which each section is <b>inset? But didn’t we learn</b> in a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 3:1): The measurements of the base of the <b>altar were thirty-two</b> cubits <b>by thirty-two</b> cubits. Once the altar <b>rose</b> to the height of one <b>cubit</b> it was <b>inset</b> by one <b>cubit</b> on each side. <b>This</b> lower section <b>was</b> the <b>base</b> of the altar. One therefore <b>finds</b> that the second section of the altar measured <b>thirty</b> cubits <b>by thirty</b> cubits.
If the width of the base is measured with a cubit of five handbreadths, then the second section of the altar does not measure thirty cubits by thirty cubits. Since the rest of the altar is measured with a cubit of six handbreadths, the second section measures <b>thirty</b> cubits <b>and two handbreadths.</b>
<b>And furthermore,</b> the aforementioned mishna continues: Once the altar <b>rose</b> to the height of six cubits, i.e., <b>five</b> cubits above the base, it was <b>inset</b> by one <b>cubit</b> on each side, forming a ledge. <b>This is</b> the <b>surrounding ledge.</b> One therefore <b>finds</b> that the third section of the altar measured <b>twenty-eight</b> cubits <b>by twenty-eight</b> cubits. If the width of the base and the surrounding ledge are measured with a cubit of five handbreadths, the third section measures <b>twenty-eight</b> cubits <b>and four handbreadths.</b>
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>since</b> the additional area <b>is not</b> a full <b>cubit</b> the mishna <b>did not count it,</b> this explanation is difficult, as the mishna continues: The <b>area</b> taken up by each of the four <b>corners</b> of the altar was <b>one cubit on this</b> side, along the length of the altar, <b>and one cubit on that</b> side, along the width of the altar. One therefore <b>finds</b> that the area of the top of the altar, within the corners, is <b>twenty-six</b> cubits <b>by twenty-six</b> cubits.
If the corners of the altar were also measured with a cubit of five handbreadths, then the top of the altar was a full cubit of six handbreadths wider, as the wall of the altar was inset three times on each side by a cubit of five handbreadths rather than six handbreadths. The area of the top of the altar <b>was</b> therefore <b>twenty-seven</b> cubits by twenty-seven cubits, which the mishna should not have referred to as twenty-six cubits. The Gemara answers that the <i>tanna</i> <b>was not precise,</b> as he should indeed have stated that the altar measured twenty-seven cubits by twenty-seven cubits.
The Gemara rejects this explanation, as the mishna continues: Within the corners of the altar there was <b>an area where the priests set</b> their <b>feet</b> as they circuited the altar. This area was <b>one cubit on this</b> side, along the length of the altar, <b>and one cubit on that</b> side, along the width of the altar. One therefore <b>finds</b> that an area of <b>twenty-four</b> cubits <b>by twenty-four</b> cubits remained as the <b>area for the arrangement</b> of wood on the altar. If the total area of the top of the altar was twenty-seven cubits by twenty-seven cubits, the remaining area <b>would be twenty-five</b> cubits by twenty-five cubits, not twenty-four by twenty-four.
<b>And if you would say</b> that <b>here too,</b> the <i>tanna</i> <b>was not precise,</b> that is difficult: <b>But isn’t it written: “And the hearth shall be twelve cubits long by twelve wide, square</b> on its four sides” (Ezekiel 43:16)? The hearth is the area for the arrangement of wood on the altar. One <b>might</b> have thought <b>that</b> the area for the arrangement of wood was <b>only twelve</b> cubits <b>by twelve</b> cubits. <b>When</b> the verse <b>states: “On its four sides,”</b> this <b>teaches that</b> one <b>measures from the middle</b> of the altar <b>twelve cubits in each and every direction,</b> i.e., the area for the arrangement of wood was twenty-four cubits by twenty-four cubits, not twenty-five by twenty-five.
The Gemara rejects an alternative explanation: <b>And if you would say</b> that when the mishna states that the base of the altar was thirty-two cubits by thirty-two cubits, with regard to <b>six of those</b> cubits the mishna <b>initially counted them as cubits of five</b> handbreadths, this explanation is difficult. <b>If so,</b> the base of the altar measures six handbreadths less, totaling only thirty-one cubits of six handbreadths, in which case the vacant area in the <b>Temple courtyard would be</b> one cubit <b>wider</b> than it actually was.
The Gemara elaborates: This is <b>as we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Middot</i> 5:1): The dimensions of <b>the entire Temple courtyard were a length of 187</b> cubits <b>by a width of 135</b> cubits. The length of the courtyard <b>from east to west</b> was <b>187</b> cubits, divided as follows: <b>The area</b> of the Israelite courtyard, <b>where</b> it was permitted for <b>Israelites to set their feet,</b> was <b>eleven cubits</b> long, <b>and the area where</b> it was permitted only for <b>the priests to set their feet</b> was <b>eleven cubits</b> long. <b>The altar</b> was <b>thirty-two</b> cubits long. The area designated as: <b>Between the Entrance Hall and the altar,</b> was <b>twenty-two cubits,</b> and <b>the Sanctuary</b> was <b>one hundred cubits</b> long. There was an additional <b>eleven cubits</b> of space <b>behind the Hall of the Ark Cover,</b> i.e., behind the Holy of Holies, which was at the western end of the Sanctuary. If the altar was actually only thirty-one cubits long, the mishna accounts for the length of only 186 cubits.
<b>Rather,</b> the verse must be interpreted differently: <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit,”</b> this is referring <b>to the height of</b> the base. <b>“The breadth a cubit,”</b> this is referring to the width of the surrounding ledge, where the wall of the altar is <b>inset</b> by one cubit. <b>“Its border by its edge round about</b> shall be the one span,”

Daf 98a

this is referring to the measurements of the corners of the altar, concerning which there <b>is no difference</b> with regard to <b>this,</b> their height, <b>and</b> there <b>is no difference</b> with regard to <b>that,</b> their width, as both are measured with a cubit of five handbreadths.
Accordingly, <b>how many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height of the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>fifty-eight</b> handbreadths high, as only eight of its cubits are of six handbreadths, while two cubits, those of the base and of the corners, are of five handbreadths. <b>How many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height of <b>half of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>twenty-nine</b> handbreadths. <b>How many</b> handbreadths <b>is</b> the height <b>from</b> the top of the <b>corners</b> of the altar <b>until</b> the <b>surrounding ledge?</b> It is <b>twenty-three</b> handbreadths, as the corners of the altar are five handbreadths high, and the upper section of the altar is three cubits of six handbreadths.
Therefore, <b>how many</b> handbreadths is the surrounding ledge <b>short of half</b> the height <b>of</b> the <b>altar?</b> It is <b>six</b> handbreadths above the halfway mark. <b>And</b> this correlates with that which <b>we learned</b> in the <i>baraita</i>: And <b>if</b> the priest <b>performed</b> the squeezing <b>below his feet, even</b> one <b>cubit</b> beneath the ledge, it is <b>valid.</b> According to this calculation, one cubit below the surrounding ledge is still part of the upper section of the altar.
The Gemara adds that the language of the verse <b>is also precise.</b> The verse indicates that although it is referring to the height of the base, it is referring to the width of the surrounding ledge, <b>as it is written</b> with regard to the base: <b>“The bottom shall be a cubit,”</b> whereas with regard to the ledge it is written: <b>“And the breadth a cubit.”</b> Since the verse mentions the breadth only with regard to the surrounding ledge one can infer that the previous term is referring not to the width but to the height. The Gemara concludes: One may <b>conclude from</b> the language of the verse that this is the correct interpretation.
§ The Gemara (97a) cited a dispute between Rabbi Meir and Rabbi Yehuda. According to Rabbi Meir all the cubits mentioned with regard to the Temple were medium cubits, except for the measurements of the golden altar, the corners of the external altar, its surrounding ledge, and its base. The Gemara asks: <b>And how many</b> handbreadths is <b>a medium cubit? Rabbi Yoḥanan says:</b> It is <b>six handbreadths. Rabbi Yosei bar Avin says: We learn</b> in a mishna (96a), <b>as well: Rabbi Meir says: The Table, its length is twelve</b> handbreadths <b>and its width is six</b> handbreadths. Since the Torah states that the length of the Table was two cubits and its width one cubit (see Exodus 25:23), this indicates that the cubit is six handbreadths.
The Gemara asks: May one derive <b>from the fact</b> that the cubit of six handbreadths is referred to as a medium cubit <b>that there is a cubit that is larger than</b> the medium cubit? The Gemara answers: <b>Yes,</b> there is a larger cubit, <b>and</b> so <b>we learned</b> in a mishna (<i>Kelim</i> 17:9): <b>There were two</b> rods for measuring <b>cubits in</b> the chamber of <b>Shushan the capital,</b> which was located above the eastern gate of the Temple Mount, <b>one in the northeast corner and one in the southeast corner.</b> The one <b>that was in the northeast corner was longer than</b> the cubit used <b>by Moses</b> in the building of the Tabernacle, which was of six handbreadths, by <b>half a fingerbreadth,</b> and the one <b>that was in the southeast corner was longer than</b> the other one by another <b>half a fingerbreadth.</b> One therefore <b>finds it longer than Moses’</b> cubit by a full <b>fingerbreadth.</b>
The mishna continues: <b>And why did</b> the Sages <b>say</b> that there should be two measures of a cubit, <b>one large and one small?</b> It was <b>so that the artisans</b> who were working in the Temple <b>would take</b> payment according the amount of work they did, as measured <b>by the small</b> cubit, <b>and return</b> it to the Temple through their work, as measured <b>by the large</b> cubit, <b>so they would not come to misuse consecrated property.</b> If they would accept any payment that they did not deserve, they would be misusing consecrated property.
The Gemara asks: <b>And why do I</b> need <b>two</b> large cubits? The Gemara answers: <b>One,</b> the shorter of the two, was used <b>to</b> measure <b>silver and gold.</b> Since silver and gold were valuable, the difference between the two measurements was set at only half a fingerbreadth, so that the artisans would not suffer too great a loss. <b>And</b> the other <b>one,</b> which was longer than Moses’ cubit by a full fingerbreadth, was used <b>in</b> the <b>construction</b> of wood and stone structures.
§ The Gemara discusses the depiction of Shushan the capital: <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Middot</i> 1:3): One of the five gates of the Temple Mount was <b>the eastern gate upon</b> which <b>Shushan the capital</b> was <b>depicted.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Shushan the capital was depicted on a gate of the Temple Mount?
There is a dispute with regard to this matter between <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi. One said</b> that Shushan was depicted <b>so that</b> those who passed through the gate <b>would know from where</b> it was that <b>they had come</b> back to Jerusalem. The Jews returned once Persia had conquered Babylonia, and therefore they should give thanks to the Persian Empire for releasing them from exile. <b>And one said</b> that it was depicted <b>so that the fear of</b> the Persian <b>Empire would be upon them,</b> to prevent them from rebelling.
The Gemara continues to discuss giving a king his due: <b>Rabbi Yannai says:</b> The <b>fear of kingship should always be upon you,</b> even when the king does not deserve it, <b>as it is stated</b> that Moses said to Pharaoh, when he warned him about the forthcoming plague of the firstborn: <b>“And all these, your servants, shall come down to me, and bow down to me, saying:</b> Get out, you and all the people who follow you, and after that I will go out” (Exodus 11:8). Although ultimately Pharaoh would himself come to Moses, Moses mentioned only that Pharaoh’s servants would come to him, <b>whereas he did not say</b> this <b>to</b> Pharaoh <b>about</b> Pharaoh <b>himself,</b> because of giving a king his due.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan said</b> this principle may be derived <b>from here, as it is stated: “And the hand of the Lord was on Elijah, and he girded up his loins, and ran before Ahab to the entrance of Jezreel”</b> (I Kings 18:46). Despite Ahab’s wickedness, Elijah acted in this manner out of respect for the king.
§ The Gemara cites another dispute between Rav Ḥisda and Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi: With regard to the fruit trees that in the future will grow on either side of a river that will emerge from the Temple, the verse states: “And by the river upon its bank, on this side and on that side, shall grow every tree for food, whose leaf shall not wither, neither shall its fruit fail. It shall bring forth new fruit every month, because its waters issue out of the Sanctuary, and its fruit shall be for food, <b>and its leaf for healing [<i>litrufa</i>]”</b> (Ezekiel 47:12). The Gemara interprets the term “<i>litrufa</i>” as a contraction of <i>lehatir peh</i>, meaning: To unlock the mouth, and there is a dispute between <b>Rav Ḥisda and Rav Yitzḥak bar Avdimi</b> with regard to the meaning of this term.
<b>One said</b> the leaf shall serve <b>to unlock</b> the <b>mouth that is above,</b> i.e., in the person’s head. The leaves will unlock the mouths of the mute and they will be capable of speech. <b>And one said</b> the leaf shall serve <b>to unlock</b> the <b>mouth that is below,</b> i.e., the womb, enabling barren women to give birth. <b>It was</b> likewise <b>stated</b> that <b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> The leaf shall serve <b>to unlock</b> the <b>mouth of the mute,</b> whereas <b>bar Kappara says:</b> It shall serve <b>to unlock</b> the <b>mouth,</b> i.e., the womb, <b>of the barren</b> women.
§ The Torah states with regard to the shewbread: “And you shall take fine flour, and bake twelve cakes from it; two-tenths of an ephah shall be in one cake. And you shall set them in two arrangements, six in an arrangement, upon the pure Table before the Lord” (Leviticus 24:5–6). <b>The Sages taught: Had</b> the Torah <b>stated: “And you shall take fine flour, and bake twelve cakes from it…And you shall set them in two arrangements,” but</b> had it <b>not stated</b> the continuation <b>“six</b> in an arrangement,” <b>I would have said</b> there may be <b>one</b> arrangement <b>of four</b> loaves <b>and one of eight</b> loaves, i.e., the arrangements do not have to be of equal size. <b>Therefore, it is stated: “Six</b> in an arrangement.”
The <i>baraita</i> continues: <b>And had</b> the Torah <b>stated: “Two arrangements, six in an arrangement,” but</b> had it <b>not stated: “Twelve</b> cakes,” <b>I would have said</b> that the total number of loaves may be more than twelve, and the phrase “six in an arrangement” teaches that one may bring another arrangement of six loaves in addition to the two mentioned in the verse, so that there are <b>three</b> arrangements <b>of six</b> loaves <b>each. Therefore, it is stated: “Twelve</b> cakes.”
<b>And had</b> the Torah <b>stated: Twelve cakes…And</b> you shall set them in <b>arrangements, but</b> had it <b>not stated: “Two” and “Six,” I would have said</b> that the twelve loaves should be divided into <b>three</b> arrangements <b>of four</b> loaves <b>each. Therefore, it is stated: “Two</b> arrangements,” <b>and: “Six</b> in an arrangement.” <b>Therefore, until these three</b> phrases in the <b>verses were stated we could not learn</b> how to set the shewbread on the Table.
<b>How</b> are <b>these</b> arrangements actually set on the Table? The priest <b>places</b> on the Table <b>two arrangements of six</b> loaves <b>each. And if he placed one</b> arrangement <b>of four</b> loaves <b>and one</b> arrangement <b>of eight</b> loaves <b>he has not fulfilled</b> the obligation. If he added two loaves, so that there were <b>two</b> arrangements <b>of seven</b> loaves <b>each, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: One views the upper</b> loaf of each arrangement <b>as though it is not</b> there, and he has fulfilled the obligation. The Gemara asks: <b>But don’t we require</b> that the frankincense be placed upon the shewbread, as it is stated: <b>“And you shall place</b> pure frankincense <b>upon [<i>al</i>]</b> each arrangement, that it may be for the bread as a memorial part” (Leviticus 24:7)?
