This causes a situation where <b>one brings one-tenth</b> of an ephah, which constitutes one meal offering as fulfillment of the individual’s obligation, <b>from two</b> separate <b>tenths</b> of an ephah. <b>And</b> similarly, the two meal offerings require two <i>log</i> of oil, each of which is sanctified in a separate vessel, and it turns out that each meal offering includes <b>one <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>from two</b> separate <b><i>log</i>.</b>
Abaye answered: This is not difficult, as <b>we have heard that Rabbi Shimon said</b> that <b>if one brought one-tenth</b> of an ephah as a meal offering <b>from two</b> separate <b>tenths, and</b> similarly, if one brought <b>one <i>log</i></b> of oil <b>from two</b> separate <b><i>log</i>, he has fulfilled</b> his obligation.
The Gemara asks: <b>But how does one remove a handful</b> from this meal offering, which consists of both loaves and wafers? The Gemara answers <b>that he stipulates and says: If</b> I specified in my vow that I would bring <b>loaves only, or</b> similarly if <b>I said</b> that I would bring <b>wafers only, let the handful that I remove from the loaves be for the loaves,</b> and <b>let the handful that I remove from the wafers be for the wafers. If I said</b> in my vow that I would bring a meal offering that is <b>half wafers and half loaves, let the handful that I remove from the loaves be for half the loaves and half the wafers, and let the handful that I remove from the wafers be for half the wafers and half the loaves.</b>
The Gemara challenges this suggestion: <b>But</b> if the vow was to bring a meal offering that is half loaves and half wafers, <b>it requires removing one handful from the loaves</b>

Daf 106a

<b>and wafers</b> together; <b>and</b> according to this suggestion, <b>he removes a handful from the loaves for the wafers and</b> a handful <b>from the wafers for the loaves.</b>
The Gemara answers: <b>We have heard that Rabbi Shimon said: If</b> one brought a meal offering that is part loaves and part wafers, and the priest <b>removed a handful, and</b> that which <b>came up in his hand</b> was only <b>from one of the two</b> types, either only loaves or only wafers, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation of removing a handful.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there</b> a problem with <b>the surplus oil?</b> The Gemara (75a) states that if a meal offering is brought half as loaves and half as wafers, the oil is divided equally between them; half is mixed with the loaves and half is applied to the wafers. The surplus oil from the wafers may also be mixed in with the loaves. But if the meal offering is baked entirely as wafers, the oil that remains is given to the priests. Therefore, Abaye’s explanation of the mishna is problematic, <b>because if</b> the person <b>said</b> in his vow that he would bring <b>half loaves and half wafers, one brings back the surplus oil</b> and mixes it in <b>with the loaves.</b> But <b>if he said</b> that <b>the entire</b> offering shall be <b>wafers, the surplus oil</b> should be <b>eaten by the priests.</b>
The Gemara resolves this problem <b>in accordance with</b> the statement of <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Shimon ben Yehuda says in the name of Rabbi Shimon</b> that the oil of a meal offering baked half as loaves and half as wafers is applied as follows: <b>One anoints</b> the wafers <b>in the shape of</b> the Greek letter <b>chi,</b> Χ, <b>and the surplus oil is eaten by the priests.</b> Consequently, the surplus oil of a meal offering baked half as loaves and half as wafers is used the same way as that of a meal offering baked entirely as wafers.
§ <b>Rav Kahana said to Rav Ashi:</b> If one specifies in his vow which meal offering he will bring, and subsequently forgets, why does he bring only five types of meal offerings? <b>Isn’t there</b> room <b>to be uncertain</b> with regard to another type of meal offering, namely, the <b>meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations</b> that accompany various burnt offerings? This meal offering can also be brought independently as a gift, <b>as Rava said: A person may volunteer a meal offering</b> brought with the <b>libations every day,</b> if he so wishes.
The Gemara answers that there is no uncertainty with regard to the possibility that he said that he would bring a meal offering brought with the libations, because it is completely different than the other types of meal offerings. <b>When one is uncertain</b> as to which meal offering he vowed to bring, the uncertainty is only with regard to certain meal offerings. The Gemara presents <b>a mnemonic</b> for these differences: <b>Individual, due to, frankincense, with a <i>log</i>, removes a handful of it.</b>
The Gemara elaborates: The uncertainty with regard to which meal offering one vowed to bring is with regard to a meal offering that <b>is brought</b> exclusively <b>due to</b> the obligation of <b>an individual.</b> But <b>one is not uncertain</b> with regard to a meal offering that <b>is brought due to</b> the obligation of <b>the public,</b> e.g., a meal offering brought with libations, which accompany communal offerings as well as individual ones; he certainly did not vow to bring this type of meal offering.
Furthermore, <b>when one is uncertain</b> it is with regard to a meal offering that <b>is brought due to its own</b> obligation. But <b>one is not uncertain</b> with regard to a meal offering <b>brought</b> with libations <b>due to</b> the requirements of <b>an offering.</b>
<b>When one is uncertain</b> it is with regard to a meal offering that <b>requires</b> that <b>frankincense</b> be brought with it. But <b>one is not uncertain</b> with regard to a meal offering brought with libations, <b>which does not require frankincense.</b>
<b>When one is uncertain,</b> it is with regard to a type of meal offering that <b>is brought with</b> one <b><i>log</i></b> of oil. But <b>one is not uncertain</b> if it <b>is brought with three <i>log</i></b> of oil or more, which is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to meal offerings brought with libations (see Numbers 15:5–6, 9).
<b>When one is uncertain</b> it is only with regard to a meal offering that <b>requires removal of a handful.</b> But <b>one is not uncertain</b> with regard to a meal offering <b>that does not require removal of a handful,</b> which is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to a meal offering brought with libations.
§ The mishna teaches: If one says: <b>I specified a meal offering of tenths</b> of an ephah but I do not remember how many I specified, according to the Rabbis he must bring a meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah. According to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi he must bring sixty meal offerings, each with a different number of tenths, from one to sixty.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: If one says: <b>I specified</b> that I would bring <b>a meal offering, and I established</b> that they must be brought <b>in</b> one <b>vessel of tenths</b> of an ephah, <b>but I do not know what</b> number of tenths <b>I specified, he must bring</b> one <b>meal offering of sixty-tenths</b> of an ephah. This is <b>the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He must bring</b> sixty <b>meal offerings of tenths</b> in sixty vessels, each containing an amount <b>from one</b>-tenth <b>until sixty</b>-tenths, <b>which are</b> in total <b>1,830</b> tenths of an ephah.
The <i>baraita</i> continues: If one said: <b>I specified</b> a certain type of meal offering with a certain number of tenths of an ephah to be brought in one vessel, <b>but I do not know what I specified, or which</b> type <b>of</b> meal offering <b>I specified, and I do not know how many</b> tenths of an ephah <b>I specified, he must bring</b> the <b>five</b> different types <b>of meal offerings,</b> and each one must contain <b>sixty-tenths</b> of an ephah, <b>which are</b> in total <b>three-hundred-</b>tenths of an ephah. This is <b>the statement of the Rabbis. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He must bring five</b> different types of <b>meal offerings,</b> and for each type he must bring <b>sixty</b> meal offerings, each with a different number of tenths, <b>from one until sixty, which are</b> in total <b>9,150</b> tenths of an ephah.
The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle <b>do</b> the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>disagree? Rav Ḥisda said: They disagree with regard to</b> whether it is <b>permitted to bring non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard. Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>it is prohibited to bring non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> Therefore, it is necessary to bring sixty meal offerings of each type, as if one merely brings one meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah in a single vessel, he may be in violation of this prohibition, as it is possible that he vowed to bring less than that amount, and the surplus amount is non-sacred. <b>And the Rabbis hold</b> that <b>it is permitted to bring non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard.</b> Therefore, even if the meal offering is of a greater volume than necessary, it is inconsequential.
<b>Rava said</b> that the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi is with regard to a different issue: <b>Everyone</b> agrees that <b>it is prohibited to bring non-sacred</b> items <b>into the</b> Temple <b>courtyard, and here they disagree with regard to</b> whether it is permitted <b>to mix</b> an offering that fulfills <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering.
<b>The Rabbis hold</b> that <b>it is permitted to mix</b> an offering that fulfills <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, and therefore one may bring sixty-tenths in one vessel and stipulate that the amount beyond his obligation will be a gift offering. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that <b>it is prohibited to mix</b> an offering that fulfills <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, and therefore one cannot make such a stipulation; every possible meal offering requires its own vessel. Concerning each vessel, he stipulates that if this one can fulfill his vow, it should count as fulfillment of his vow, and otherwise it should serve as a gift offering.
<b>Abaye said to Rava: According to the Rabbis, who say</b> that <b>it is permitted to mix</b> an offering that fulfills <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, and one vessel with sixty-tenths of an ephah can serve in part to fulfill the obligation and in part as a gift offering, there is a difficulty: <b>Don’t we require</b> the removal of <b>two handfuls,</b> one for the obligatory meal offering and one for the gift offering? Rava answered: According to the Rabbis, it is required <b>that</b> the priest <b>removes a handful and again removes a handful.</b>
Abaye said to Rava: <b>But</b> if so, since the tenths that fulfill an obligation and the tenths that are a gift are mixed together in a single vessel, when the priest removes a handful, <b>isn’t he removing a handful from</b> tenths that fulfill <b>an obligation</b> to account <b>for</b> tenths that are <b>a gift</b> offering, <b>and</b> removing a handful <b>from</b> tenths that are <b>a gift</b> offering to account <b>for</b> tenths that fulfill <b>an obligation?</b>
Rava answered Abaye: This is not difficult, <b>as</b> the one who brings the meal offering <b>renders it dependent on the intent of the priest, as he says: Wherever the priest’s hand reaches now,</b> when he removes the first handful, shall be the location of the tenths that fulfill my <b>obligation, and</b> wherever his hand reaches <b>at the end,</b> when removing the second handful, shall be <b>a gift</b> offering.
Abaye asked Rava: <b>But how does</b> the priest <b>burn</b> the handful upon the altar? If the priest <b>will burn</b> the handful from the <b>gift</b> offering <b>first, how can he</b> then <b>burn</b> the handful <b>of the</b> tenths that fulfill the <b>obligation? Perhaps the entire</b> meal offering <b>is</b> for the <b>obligation,</b> as the vow was to bring sixty-tenths of an ephah, and everything apart from the first handful, including the second handful, is the remainder, <b>and</b> by burning part of it the priest causes <b>the remainder to be lacking.</b>
<b>And the Master said:</b> With regard to the <b>remainder</b> of a meal offering <b>that became lacking between the removal of the handful and the burning</b> of the handful upon the altar, the <i>halakha</i> is that <b>one does not burn the handful on its</b> account, as it is not considered a valid meal offering.
Alternatively, if the priest <b>will burn</b> the handful that fulfills the <b>obligation first, how can he burn</b> the handful <b>of the gift</b> offering?

Daf 106b

<b>But perhaps</b> the vow was to bring sixty-tenths of an ephah, in which case <b>the entire</b> meal offering <b>is</b> necessary to fulfill the <b>obligation.</b> Consequently, only one handful may be removed, and all the rest is considered the remainder. <b>And</b> there is a principle: <b>Whatever is partly</b> burned <b>in the fire</b> on the altar <b>is subject to</b> the prohibition of: <b>You may not make as an offering</b> (see Leviticus 2:11). This principle states that if part of an item, such as the blood of an animal offering or the handful of a meal offering, has been sacrificed, one who sacrifices any other part of it that is not designated for sacrifice has violated a prohibition. In this case, the second handful is considered part of the remainder of the meal offering, and burning it is prohibited.
<b>Rabbi Yehuda, son of Rabbi Shimon ben Pazi, said:</b> The priest does not burn the oil as an offering but <b>burns it for the sake of wood,</b> i.e., not as a sacrificial rite, <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer. As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> The verse states: “No meal offering that you shall bring unto the Lord shall be made with leaven; for you shall make no leaven, nor any honey, smoke from it as an offering made by fire unto the Lord. As an offering of first fruits you may bring them unto the Lord; but they shall not come up for a pleasing aroma on the altar” (Leviticus 2:11–12). This verse indicates that <b>you may not offer up</b> leaven and honey <b>as a pleasing aroma,</b> i.e., as an offering. <b>But you may offer up</b> leaven and honey and other substances <b>for the sake of wood,</b> not as an offering.
<b>Rav Aḥa, son of Rava, said to Rav Ashi: But perhaps everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is permitted to mix</b> an offering that fulfills <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, <b>and here</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi and the Rabbis <b>disagree with regard to</b> the statement <b>of Rabbi Eliezer</b> that it is permitted to burn on the altar as fuel even items that are prohibited from being burned as offerings. <b>As the Rabbis accept</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> and therefore they allow one to bring one meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah, since the handful removed from it may be burned, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not accept</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer.</b>
Rav Ashi <b>said to him:</b> This cannot be the dispute, as <b>if it enters your mind</b> that <b>according to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>it is permitted to mix</b> an offering brought as <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, <b>and he does not accept</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer,</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would not require sixty separate vessels. Instead, <b>one could bring sixty-</b>tenths of an ephah <b>in one vessel, and one</b> additional tenth <b>in one</b> other <b>vessel,</b> from which the handful of the gift offering would be removed. <b>And</b> he could <b>touch them,</b> i.e., place them so they touch each other, so that they are considered as one, <b>and</b> the priest could then <b>remove a handful</b> from that tenth for the gift, and remove another handful from the vessel with sixty-tenths to fulfill the obligation.
<b>Rava said</b> that there is an alternative explanation of the dispute between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>Everyone agrees</b> that <b>it is permitted to mix</b> an offering brought as <b>an obligation</b> together <b>with a gift</b> offering, <b>and everyone accepts</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi Eliezer. And here they disagree with regard to</b> the issue that is the subject of <b>the dispute between Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov and the Rabbis.</b>
<b>As we learned</b> in a mishna (88a): Each tenth of an ephah of flour requires one <i>log</i> of oil. Accordingly, <b>even</b> if one brings <b>a meal offering of sixty-tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, <b>one adds to it sixty <i>log</i></b> of oil. <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says:</b> Each meal offering, irrespective of its volume, <b>even a meal offering of sixty-tenths</b> of an ephah of flour, requires <b>only its</b> single <b><i>log</i></b> of oil, <b>as it is stated</b> with regard to the offering brought by a poor leper on the day of his purification: “And a tenth of an ephah of fine flour mixed with oil <b>for a meal offering, and a <i>log</i> of oil”</b> (Leviticus 14:21). The juxtaposition of “a meal offering” with “a <i>log</i> of oil” teaches a principle that pertains to all meal offerings, that each offering requires only one <i>log</i> of oil.
Rava explains: <b>The Rabbis</b> in the mishna <b>hold in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis,</b> who disagree with Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov and <b>who said:</b> A meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah requires <b>sixty <i>log</i></b> of oil. Therefore, in a case of uncertainty, it is possible to bring sixty-tenths of an ephah, <b>and each and every</b> measurement of <b>one-tenth takes</b> one <b><i>log</i>.</b>
<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov, who said</b> that a meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah <b>has only its</b> one <b><i>log</i></b> of oil. <b>And</b> therefore, when one is uncertain about his vow and brings sixty-tenths, he cannot bring them with one <i>log</i> of oil, as <b>we do not know whether</b> the entire sixty-tenths <b>is one meal offering,</b> so <b>that one <i>log</i> suffices for it,</b> or <b>whether they are two meal offerings,</b> one that is obligatory and one that is a gift, <b>which require two <i>log</i></b> of oil. For this reason, there is no way of resolving the uncertainty except by bringing sixty separate meal offerings, with one <i>log</i> of oil for each.
<b>Rav Ashi said</b> that there is alternative explanation of the disagreement between the Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi: <b>They disagree with regard to</b> the <i>halakha</i> of one who is obligated to bring <b>a small</b> offering <b>and</b> instead <b>brings a large</b> offering. <b>The Rabbis hold</b> that if one is obligated to bring <b>a small</b> offering <b>and brings a large</b> one instead <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation, <b>and Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that in such a case <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation. Therefore, in the case of the uncertainty in the mishna, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi holds that by bringing one meal offering of sixty-tenths of an ephah one does not fulfill his obligation if he vowed to bring a smaller offering.
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t they</b> already <b>disagree about this</b> topic <b>once? As we learned</b> in a mishna (107b) that if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a small</b> bull, <b>and he brought a large</b> bull instead, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the value of a small bull is included in the value of a large bull. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the offering that he brought did not correspond to his vow.
The Gemara answers: It is <b>necessary</b> for the dispute to be mentioned with regard to both cases, <b>as had</b> their dispute <b>been stated</b> only <b>with regard to this</b> case of one who vows to bring a small meal offering and brings a large one instead, there would be room to reason that it is only <b>in this</b> case that <b>the Rabbis say</b> that he has fulfilled his obligation, <b>because</b> both <b>this</b> small meal offering <b>and that</b> large meal offering are identical with regard to the portion of the offering that is sacrificed on the altar; in both cases <b>it is a handful. But there,</b> in the case of one who vows to bring a small bull but brings a large one, <b>since the sacrificial portions are greater,</b> i.e., larger, there is room to <b>say</b> that the Rabbis <b>concede to Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi that he has not fulfilled his obligation.
<b>And had</b> their dispute <b>been stated</b> only <b>in that</b> case of one who vows to bring a small bull and brings a big one, there would be room to reason that only <b>in that</b> case <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says</b> that the person has not fulfilled his obligation, because the sacrificial portions are larger. <b>But in this</b> case of bringing a large meal offering instead of a small one, there is room to <b>say</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>concedes to</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Therefore, it is <b>necessary</b> for the mishna to teach both cases.
§ The Gemara gives <b>a mnemonic</b> for the <i>halakhot</i> discussed in the upcoming <i>mishnayot</i>: <b>Wood, gold, wine, burnt offering, thanks offering, bull.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to donate pieces of <b>wood</b> as fuel for the altar, <b>must</b> donate <b>no fewer than two logs.</b> One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>frankincense, must</b> bring <b>no less than a handful.</b>
The mishna states tangentially: <b>There are five</b> <i>halakhot</i> pertaining to <b>handfuls. One who says:</b> It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring an offering of <b>frankincense, may not</b> bring <b>less than a handful. One who pledges</b> to bring <b>a meal offering must bring with it a handful of frankincense. One who</b> intentionally <b>offers up a handful</b> of a meal offering <b>outside</b> the Temple courtyard is <b>liable</b> to receive excision from the World-to-Come [<i>karet</i>]. The <b>two bowls</b> of frankincense that accompany the shewbread are <b>required</b> to have <b>two handfuls</b> of frankincense.
One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to donate <b>gold</b> to the Temple treasury, <b>must</b> give <b>no less than a gold dinar.</b> One who says: It is incumbent upon me to donate <b>silver</b> to the Temple treasury, <b>must</b> give <b>no less than</b> the value of <b>a silver dinar.</b> One who says: It is incumbent upon me to donate <b>copper</b> to the Temple maintenance, <b>must</b> give <b>no less than</b> the value of <b>a silver <i>ma’a</i>.</b> One who says: <b>I specified</b> the amount of gold, silver, or copper, <b>but I do not know what I specified, must bring</b> the maximum amount of gold, silver, or copper, <b>until</b> it reaches an amount <b>where he says:</b> I am certain that <b>I did not intend to</b> donate <b>that</b> much.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> With regard to one who pledges to donate wood, <b>the Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: The verse states: “And when one brings a meal offering [<i>korban minḥa</i>]<b>”</b> (Leviticus 2:1). The superfluous word “<b><i>korban</i></b>” <b>teaches that one can voluntarily give wood</b> as an offering for the altar. <b>And how much</b> wood must one bring if he does not specify an amount? <b>Two logs. And</b> the support for the fact that wood can be brought as a voluntary offering is <b>as</b> the verse <b>states: “And we cast lots for the wood offering”</b> (Nehemiah 10:35). <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> This voluntary donation of <b>wood is an offering</b> like a meal offering, <b>and</b> therefore it <b>requires salt and requires bringing</b> to the corner of the altar, like a meal offering.
<b>Rava says: According to the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>wood</b> donated in this manner <b>requires</b> the <b>removal of a handful;</b> just as in the case of a meal offering, a portion of the wood must be removed and sacrificed separately. <b>And Rav Pappa says</b> that <b>according to the statement of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, since it is an offering for the altar, the <b>wood</b> that is brought as an offering <b>needs</b> to be placed on other <b>wood</b> to burn, like any other offering that is burned on wood on the altar.
The mishna teaches: One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>frankincense, may not</b> bring <b>less than a handful.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>From where do we</b> derive this <i>halakha</i>? The Gemara answers: It is derived from a verse, <b>as it is written: “And he shall take up from it his handful, of the fine flour of the meal offering, and of its oil, and all the frankincense</b> which is upon the meal offering, and shall make the memorial part of it smoke upon the altar for an aroma pleasing to the Lord” (Leviticus 6:8). The Torah <b>juxtaposes</b> the <b>frankincense with the taking up</b> of a handful <b>of the meal offering.</b> This indicates that <b>just as</b> the <b>taking up from a meal offering</b> is referring to <b>a handful, so too,</b> the minimum size of <b>a frankincense</b> offering is <b>also a handful.</b>
§ <b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> which discusses vows to bring frankincense that one who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>to the altar,</b> and does not specify what he will bring, <b>must bring frankincense, as you have nothing that is</b> entirely <b>sacrificed on the altar other than frankincense.</b> One who says: <b>I specified</b> what I intended to bring to the altar, <b>but I do not know what I specified, must bring</b> one <b>of everything that is sacrificed on the altar.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And is there nothing else</b> that is entirely sacrificed on the altar other than frankincense? <b>But isn’t there a burnt offering,</b> which is entirely burned on the altar? The Gemara answers that <b>there is its hide,</b> which is given <b>to the priests</b> and not burned on the altar.
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there a bird burnt offering,</b> which is entirely burned on the altar, including its skin? The Gemara answers: <b>There are</b>

Daf 107a

<b>the crop and feathers,</b> which are thrown on the ground next to the altar and are not burned.
The Gemara asks: <b>But aren’t there</b> wine <b>libations,</b> which are poured entirely onto the altar? The Gemara answers that the wine is not actually poured onto the altar; it is poured into ducts on the side of the altar and <b>goes</b> down <b>to the drainpipes.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But isn’t there a meal offering</b> brought with <b>libations,</b> which is entirely burned on the altar? The Gemara answers that when one says: It is incumbent upon me to bring to the altar, his intent is clearly to bring a type of offering that is only sacrificed on the altar. A meal offering brought with libations is a type of meal offering. Therefore, <b>since there are</b> other types of <b>a meal offering from which the priests eat,</b> after a handful has been removed from it and burned, a meal offering brought with libations <b>is not a clear</b> example of an offering that is sacrificed on the altar in its entirety, and certainly was not <b>his</b> intent. Therefore, his intent must have been to bring frankincense.
§ The mishna teaches that one who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to donate <b>gold</b> to the Temple treasury, <b>must</b> donate <b>no less than a gold dinar.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> his intention in using the word gold is not to a coin at all, but to a small <b>piece [<i>naskha</i>]</b> of gold. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The case of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>where he said</b> the word <b>coin.</b> The Gemara challenges further: <b>But perhaps</b> his intention is not to a dinar, but to smaller coins, such as <b><i>perutot</i>. Rav Pappa said: People do not make <i>perutot</i> of gold.</b> Therefore, it is unlikely that this was his intent.
§ The mishna teaches that one who says: It is incumbent upon me to donate <b>silver</b> to the Temple maintenance, <b>must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the value of a silver <b>dinar.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But perhaps</b> his intention in using the word silver is not to a coin at all, but to a small <b>piece</b> of silver. <b>Rabbi Elazar said:</b> The case of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>where he said</b> the word <b>coin.</b> The Gemara challenges further: <b>But perhaps</b> his intention is not to a dinar, but to smaller coins, such as <b><i>perutot</i>. Rav Pappa said:</b> The <i>halakha</i> of the <i>baraita</i> is stated <b>with regard to a place where silver <i>perutot</i> do not circulate.</b>
§ The mishna teaches that one who says: It is incumbent upon me to donate <b>copper</b> to the Temple maintenance, <b>must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the value of <b>a silver <i>ma’a</i>. It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>Rabbi Eliezer ben Ya’akov says: He must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the amount needed to forge <b>a small copper hook.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>For what</b> use <b>is</b> that <b>suitable</b> in the Temple? <b>Abaye said: They scrape</b> the <b>wicks</b> from the Candelabrum <b>with it and clean</b> the <b>lamps</b> of the Candelabrum <b>with it.</b>
The mishna discusses pledges of gold, silver, and copper. What is the <i>halakha</i> if one says: It is incumbent upon me to donate <b>iron? It is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> that <b>others say:</b> He <b>must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> the amount that can be made into a base and spike designed to <b>eliminate the ravens [<i>mikkalya orev</i>].</b> The Gemara asks: <b>And how much</b> is that? <b>Rav Yosef said:</b> One <b>cubit</b> in width <b>by</b> one <b>cubit</b> in length.
<b>There are</b> those <b>who say</b> another version of this <i>baraita</i> and the subsequent explanation: One who pledges to donate iron <b>must</b> donate <b>no less than</b> one <b>cubit</b> in width <b>by</b> one <b>cubit</b> in length. The Gemara asks: <b>For what is</b> this amount of iron <b>suitable? Rav Yosef said:</b> It is suitable <b>for</b> a base and spike designed to <b>eliminate the ravens.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring a libation of <b>wine, must</b> bring <b>no less than three <i>log</i>,</b> as that is the minimum amount of wine brought as a libation accompanying an animal offering. One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>oil, must</b> bring <b>no less than a <i>log</i>,</b> as the smallest meal offering includes one <i>log</i> of oil. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> He must bring no less than <b>three <i>log</i>,</b> as that is the amount of oil in the meal offering that accompanies the sacrifice of a lamb, which is the smallest amount in any of the meal offerings that accompany the sacrifice of an animal.
One who says: <b>I specified</b> how many <i>log</i> I vowed to bring <b>but I do not know what</b> amount <b>I specified, must bring</b> an amount of oil <b>equivalent to</b> the amount brought on the <b>day</b> that the <b>largest</b> amount of oil is sacrificed in the Temple.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The Torah states with regard to libations: “All that are native born shall do these things in this manner, in presenting an offering made by fire, of a pleasing aroma to the Lord” (Numbers 15:13). As this verse is superfluous, the various terms in it are used to derive <i>halakhot</i>. The term <b>“native born” teaches that one may pledge libations</b> independently, even when they are not sacrificed together with an offering. <b>And how much</b> is the minimum size that is offered? <b>Three <i>log</i>,</b> which is the smallest measurement of a libation in the Torah and is offered with a lamb.
<b>And from where</b> is it derived <b>that if one desires to add</b> to this amount, <b>he may add</b> to it? <b>The verse states</b> with regard to libations associated with the additional offerings for the New Moon: “And their libations: Half a <i>hin</i> of wine <b>shall be</b> for the bull, and the third part of a <i>hin</i> for the ram, and the fourth part of a <i>hin</i> for the lamb (Numbers 28:14). From the superfluous “shall be” one may understand that there are other amounts of wine that may be brought as independent libations. One <b>might</b> have thought that he can <b>decrease</b> the amount of wine in a libation to less than three <i>log</i>. Therefore, <b>the verse states:</b> “All that are native born shall do these things, <b>in this manner”</b> (Numbers 15:13), i.e., one may not bring less than three <i>log</i> of wine.
The mishna teaches that if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>oil, he must</b> bring <b>no less than a <i>log</i>,</b> as the smallest meal offering includes a <i>log</i> of oil. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says:</b> He must bring no less than <b>three <i>log</i>.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>With regard to what</b> principle do they <b>disagree?</b>
<b>The Sages said before Rav Pappa:</b> The Rabbis and Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>disagree with regard to</b> the proper method of logical derivation when deriving the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one matter from the <i>halakha</i> with regard to another matter. One opinion holds that the proper method is to <b>infer from it, and</b> again <b>from it,</b> i.e., equate the two cases in all aspects, while the other holds that the comparison extends only to one specific issue derived from the primary case, in accordance with the principle: <b>Infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place,</b> i.e., in all other aspects the cases are not equated.
The Sages explained: <b>The Rabbis hold</b> by the principle: <b>Infer from it, and</b> again <b>from it.</b> The Gemara explains the application of this principle: <b>Just as a meal offering is contributed, so too oil is contributed,</b> as inferred from the verse addressing the meal offering. <b>And</b> again one infers <b>from</b> this source: <b>Just as a meal offering</b> requires <b>a <i>log</i></b> of oil, <b>so too here,</b> an offering of oil alone must be <b>a <i>log</i> of oil.</b>
<b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>holds</b> that the proper method is to <b>infer from it but interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place: Just as a meal offering is contributed, so too oil is contributed. But</b> with regard to all other aspects of this <i>halakha</i>, <b>interpret</b> the <i>halakha</i> according <b>to its</b> own <b>place,</b> and its status is <b>like</b> that of <b>libations,</b> which are similar to oil in that they are also poured onto the altar: <b>Just as</b> one contributes <b>libations</b> of <b>three <i>log</i>, so too</b> when one contributes <b>oil,</b> one contributes <b>three <i>log</i>.</b>
<b>Rav Pappa said to</b> the Sages who suggested this interpretation: <b>If Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>derived</b> the source of the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> the verse addressing the <b>meal offering,</b> he would not disagree with the Rabbis, <b>as everyone</b> employs the principle of: <b>Infer from it, and</b> again <b>from it. Rather, Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>derives</b> the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> a verse concerning libations: “All that are <b>native born</b> shall do these things in this manner, in presenting an offering made by fire” (Numbers 15:13). Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi derives from here that just as one may contribute wine libations, so too one may contribute oil. Therefore, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi compares oil to wine libations: Just as one contributes libations of three <i>log</i>, so too one contributes three <i>log</i> of oil.
<b>Rav Huna, son of Rav Natan, said to Rav Pappa: And how can you say that</b> according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi the source of the gift offering of oil is not from the meal offering? <b>But isn’t it taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the verse: “And when one brings a meal offering <b>[<i>korban minḥa</i>]”</b> (Leviticus 2:1), that the superfluous word <i>korban</i> <b>teaches that one may contribute oil. And how much</b> must one contribute? <b>Three <i>log</i>.</b> The Gemara explains the question: <b>Who did you hear that says</b> the gift offering of oil is <b>three <i>log</i>? This is</b> the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and</b> yet he <b>cites</b> the source of the gift offering of oil <b>from</b> the word <b><i>korban</i>,</b> which is referring to a meal offering. Rav Pappa <b>said to him: If</b> this <i>baraita</i> <b>is taught, it is taught,</b> and I cannot take issue with it.
The mishna teaches that one who says: <b>I specified</b> how many <i>log</i> I vowed to bring <b>but I do not know what</b> number <b>I specified, must bring</b> an amount of oil <b>equivalent to</b> the amount brought on the <b>day</b> that the <b>largest</b> amount of oil is sacrificed in the Temple. The Sages <b>taught:</b> He must bring an amount of oil <b>equivalent to</b> the amount that is brought on <b>the first day of the Festival,</b> i.e., <i>Sukkot</i>, <b>when it occurs on Shabbat.</b> The offerings brought on that day include the additional offerings for <i>Sukkot</i> and also the additional offerings for Shabbat, and the total amount of oil brought on that day is 140 <i>log</i>.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering, must bring a lamb,</b> which is the least expensive land animal sacrificed as an offering. <b>Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya says:</b> He may bring <b>either a dove or a pigeon,</b> as a bird burnt offering.
One who says: I vowed to bring a burnt offering, and <b>I specified</b> that it would be <b>from the herd, but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified, must bring a bull and a male calf,</b> as a burnt offering is brought only from male animals. One who says: I vowed to bring a burnt offering and I specified that it would be <b>from the animals but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified, must bring a bull and a male calf, a ram, a large male goat, a small male goat, and a male lamb.</b> One who says: I vowed to bring a burnt offering, and <b>I specified</b> what type of burnt offering it would be, <b>but I do not know what I specified,</b>

Daf 107b

<b>adds a dove and a pigeon</b> to the previous list.
One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a thanks offering and a peace offering, must bring a lamb,</b> which is the least expensive land animal sacrificed as an offering. One who says: I vowed to bring a peace offering <b>and I specified</b> that it would be <b>from the herd but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified, must bring a bull and a cow,</b> and <b>a male calf and a female calf.</b> One who says: I vowed to bring a burnt offering and specified that it would be <b>from the animals, but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified, must bring a bull and a cow, a male calf and a female calf, a ram and a ewe, a large,</b> i.e., adult, <b>male goat and a large female goat, a small,</b> i.e., young, <b>male goat and a small female goat,</b> and <b>a male lamb and a female lamb.</b>
One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a bull</b> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>must bring</b> the bull, its accompanying meal offering, <b>and its libations, with</b> the total value of <b>one hundred dinars.</b> One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a calf, must bring</b> the calf, its accompanying meal offering, <b>and its libations, with</b> the total value of <b>five</b> <i>sela</i>, which equal twenty dinars. One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a ram, must bring</b> the ram, its accompanying meal offering, <b>and its libations, with</b> the value of <b>two</b> <i>sela</i>, which equal eight dinars. One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a lamb, must bring</b> the lamb, its accompanying meal offering, <b>and its libations, with</b> the value of one <b><i>sela</i>,</b> which equals four dinars.
One who says: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a bull with</b> the value of <b>one hundred dinars</b> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>must bring</b> the bull <b>with</b> the value of <b>one hundred dinars excluding its</b> accompanying meal offering and <b>libations.</b> One who says: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a calf with</b> the value of <b>five</b> <i>sela</i> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>must bring</b> the calf <b>with</b> the value of <b>five</b> <i>sela</i> <b>excluding its</b> accompanying meal offering and <b>libations.</b> One who says: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a ram with</b> the value of <b>two</b> <i>sela</i> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>must bring</b> the ram <b>with</b> the value of <b>two</b> <i>sela</i> <b>excluding its</b> accompanying meal offering and <b>libations.</b> One who says: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a lamb with</b> the value of one <b><i>sela</i></b> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>must bring</b> the lamb <b>with</b> the value of one <b><i>sela</i> excluding its</b> accompanying meal offering and <b>libations.</b>
If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a bull with</b> the value of <b>one hundred dinars</b> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>and he brought two</b> bulls <b>with</b> a combined value of <b>one hundred dinars,</b> he <b>has not fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>And</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if <b>this</b> bull has the value <b>of one hundred dinars less one dinar and that</b> bull has the value <b>of one hundred dinars less one dinar.</b>
If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a black</b> bull, <b>and he brought a white</b> bull; or said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a white</b> bull, <b>and he brought a black</b> bull; or said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a large</b> bull, <b>and he brought a small</b> bull, in all these cases <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation. But if he said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a small</b> bull, <b>and he brought a large</b> bull, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the value of a small bull is included in the value of a large bull. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the offering that he brought did not correspond to his vow.
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one vows to bring a burnt offering and does not specify which animal he will bring, according to the first <i>tanna</i> he must bring a lamb, and according to Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya he may bring a dove or a pigeon. The Gemara explains: <b>And they do not disagree</b> in principle. This <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale, and</b> that <b>Sage</b> rules <b>in accordance with</b> the custom of <b>his locale.</b> In the locale of the first <i>tanna</i>, when people would say: Burnt offering, they would be referring to a land animal, whereas in the locale of Rabbi Elazar ben Azarya, when people would say: Burnt offering, they would also be referring to a bird.
<b>The Sages taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering with</b> the value of one <b><i>sela</i> for the altar, must bring a lamb; as you have no</b> animal <b>that is sacrificed on the altar</b> and has the value <b>of</b> one <b><i>sela</i> but a lamb.</b> One who says: When I made my vow <b>I specified</b> that I will bring an item <b>that is sacrificed</b> on the altar and has the value <b>of</b> one <b><i>sela</i>, but I do not know what I specified, must bring</b> one <b>of every</b> animal <b>that is sacrificed on the altar</b> and has the value <b>of</b> one <b><i>sela</i>.</b> Although this condition generally indicates a lamb, since the person specified a particular animal but does not remember which, one cannot be certain that he specified a lamb.
§ The mishna teaches that if one says: I vowed to bring a peace offering, and <b>I specified</b> that it would be <b>from the herd, but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified, he must bring a bull and a calf.</b> The Gemara asks: <b>Why? Let him bring a bull,</b> as <b>whichever</b> way <b>you</b> look at it he has fulfilled his vow. If he vowed to bring a bull, he has done so. If he vowed to bring a calf, he has fulfilled his vow, because the value of a calf is included in the value of a bull.
The Gemara answers: In accordance with <b>whose</b> opinion <b>is this? It is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who said</b> that if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a small</b> bull, <b>and he brought a large</b> bull, <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation.
The Gemara asks: <b>If</b> the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a bull with</b> the value of <b>one hundred dinars, and he brought two</b> bulls <b>with</b> the combined value of <b>one hundred dinars,</b> he <b>has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, <b>and</b> that is the <i>halakha</i> <b>even</b> if <b>this</b> bull has the value <b>of one hundred dinars less one dinar and that</b> bull has the value <b>of one hundred dinars less one dinar.</b>
If one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a black</b> bull, <b>and he brought a white</b> bull; or said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a white</b> bull, <b>and he brought a black</b> bull; or said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a large</b> bull, <b>and he brought a small</b> bull, in all these cases <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation. But if he said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a small</b> bull, <b>and he brought a large</b> bull, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the value of a small bull is included in the value of a large bull. <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>says: He has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the offering that he brought did not correspond to his vow.
If the first clause, which teaches that one who vowed to bring an offering from the herd must bring both a bull and a calf, is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, then it turns out that <b>the first clause and the last clause</b> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>and the middle clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Can that be so?
The Gemara answers: <b>Yes, the first clause and the last clause</b> are in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, and <b>the middle clause</b> is in accordance with the opinion of <b>the Rabbis. And this</b> is what the mishna <b>is saying: This matter,</b> i.e., the ruling that one who vows to bring an offering from the herd must bring a bull and a calf, is not universally accepted. Rather, it <b>is</b> subject to <b>a dispute</b> between <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>and the Rabbis.</b>
§ <b>We learned</b> in a mishna <b>there</b> (<i>Shekalim</i> 18b): There were <b>six</b> collection horns in the Temple <b>for</b> the collection of donations for communal <b>gift</b> offerings, i.e., burnt offerings that were sacrificed when the altar was idle. The Gemara asks: <b>To what</b> did these six horns <b>correspond?</b> The Gemara gives <b>a mnemonic</b> for the names of the five Sages who give answers to this question: <b><i>Kuf</i>, <i>mem</i>, <i>peh</i>, <i>shin</i>, <i>ayin</i>.</b>
<b>Ḥizkiyya says:</b> These six collection horns <b>corresponded to</b> the <b>six</b> extended <b>patrilineal families of priests</b> who served each week in the Temple. There was one collection horn for each family, <b>which the Sages installed for them so that there would be peace between one another</b> and they would not quarrel. The hides of the burnt offerings are given to the priests, and by keeping the money for the offerings sacrificed by each family separate, they would not come to quarrel over those hides.
<b>Rabbi Yoḥanan says: Since the</b> money for the communal <b>gift</b> offerings was <b>plentiful,</b> as much money was donated for this purpose, there was a concern that if too many coins were placed in one collection horn, only the uppermost coins would be taken and the bottom ones would deteriorate. Therefore, the Sages <b>installed many</b> collection <b>horns for them, so that</b> each horn would contain fewer coins and <b>the coins would not decay.</b>
<b>And Ze’eiri says:</b> The six collection horns <b>correspond to</b> the six types of animals from which burnt offerings can be brought: <b>A bull, a calf, a ram, a lamb, a small goat, and a large goat. And</b> each type of animal required its own collection horn, because the mishna <b>is</b> in accordance with the opinion of <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi, <b>who says</b> that if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a small</b> bull <b>and he brought a large</b> bull, <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation, as the offering that he brought did not correspond to his vow.
<b>And bar Padda says:</b> The six collection horns <b>correspond to</b> the six types of animals from which sin offerings and guilt offerings can be brought. If an animal designated for a guilt offering or a communal sin offering was lost, another animal was consecrated in its stead, and then the first animal was found, the value of that animal is placed into one of these collection horns, and a communal gift offering is brought with it. One was for the value of <b>the bulls</b> brought as communal sin offerings. <b>And</b> one was for the value of <b>the rams</b> brought as guilt offerings for robbery or for misuse of consecrated property,

Daf 108a

<b>And</b> one was for the value of <b>the lambs</b> brought as a nazirite’s or a leper’s guilt offering. <b>And</b> one was for the value of <b>the goats</b> brought as communal sin offerings on Festivals. <b>And</b> one was for <b>the surplus</b> coins of one who designated money to purchase one of those offerings and had money left over after purchasing the animal. <b>And</b> one was for <b>the</b> additional silver <b><i>ma’a</i></b> paid as a premium in a case when two people brought their half-shekel jointly as one shekel.
After citing these four opinions, the Gemara explains: <b>All of</b> the other Sages <b>do not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Ḥizkiyya</b> that the six collection horns are to prevent quarrels between the families of priests, <b>as</b> they hold that <b>we are not concerned about quarreling</b> between the priests. There is no reason for them to fight, <b>as each and every</b> family <b>serves on its</b> own <b>day</b> and receives the hides of the animals sacrificed on that day.
The other Sages <b>do not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Yoḥanan</b> that the six horns are to prevent the coins from decaying, as <b>we are not concerned that</b> the coins will <b>decay.</b>
The other Sages <b>do not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Ze’eiri</b> that the mishna is in accordance with the opinion of Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, because <b>we do not interpret</b> a mishna <b>in accordance with an individual</b> opinion against the majority opinion.
The other Sages <b>also do not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>bar Padda</b> that the six collection horns were for the value of bulls, rams, lambs, and goats that had been lost, for the surplus coins left over after purchasing an offering, and for the <i>ma’a</i> paid as a premium in addition to the half-shekel of two people. This is because they hold that there is no reason to differentiate between <b>the surplus</b> and the value of specific animals, as <b>all of</b> the animals that were lost and another offered in their place are <b>also surplus,</b> and their value is surplus after the replacement offering was purchased.
The other Sages <b>also</b> do not agree with bar Padda’s explanation that the sixth collection horn was for the <b><i>ma’a</i>,</b> because they hold that the <i>ma’a</i> <b>goes toward</b> the same purpose as the regular <b>shekels, as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to the <i>ma’a</i>: <b>Where would this premium [<i>kalbon</i>] go,</b> i.e., what was done with it? It would be added <b>to the shekels</b> themselves, which would be used to buy the daily and additional offerings; this is <b>the statement of Rabbi Meir. Rabbi Eliezer says:</b> It would be used <b>for</b> communal <b>gift</b> offerings.
The Gemara cites two additional explanations for the purpose of the six collection horns. <b>And Shmuel says:</b> These six horns <b>correspond to</b> the surplus coins left over after purchasing six offerings, namely: The <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a sin offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a guilt offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a nazirite’s guilt offering,</b> brought if he comes into contact with a corpse during his term of naziriteship; <b>and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a leper’s guilt offering,</b> brought as part of his purification process; <b>and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a meal offering of a sinner;</b> and the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering sacrificed <b>by the High Priest</b> each day, half in the morning and half in the evening.
<b>And Rabbi Oshaya says</b> that there is a different explanation for the six collection horns: They <b>correspond to</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a sin offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a guilt offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a nazirite’s guilt offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a leper’s guilt offering; and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after the purchase of <b>pairs</b> of doves or pigeons by women after childbirth, by <i>zavim</i> as part of their purification process, and others; <b>and</b> the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a meal offering of a sinner.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Shmuel does not say in accordance with</b> the explanation of <b>Rabbi Oshaya</b> that one of the collection horns was for the surplus coins left over after purchasing pairs of birds? The Gemara answers: A collection horn for coins for <b>pairs</b> of birds is already <b>taught</b> in <b>the first clause</b> of the mishna in tractate <i>Shekalim</i> (18a), among the list of seven collection horns that served purposes other than the communal gift offerings.
The Gemara asks: <b>And does Rabbi Oshaya teach</b> the mishna <b>without teaching</b> that one of the collection horns was for <b>pairs</b> of birds? Does he have a different version of the mishna? <b>But doesn’t Rabbi Oshaya teach</b> the mishna explicitly, <b>teaching</b> in his version of the mishna that there was a collection horn for <b>pairs</b> of birds? The Gemara answers that <b>one</b> of the collection horns was for coins designated <b>for</b> purchasing <b>pairs</b> of birds, <b>and one</b> collection horn was <b>for the surplus</b> coins remaining after purchasing <b>pairs</b> of birds.
The Gemara asks: <b>And what is the reason</b> that <b>Rabbi Oshaya does not say in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>Shmuel?</b> The Gemara answers that <b>he holds like the one who says</b> that the <b>surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest</b> are not used to purchase other offerings but are left to <b>rot; as it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i>: <b>The surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the meal offering of</b> are used for the purchase of a communal <b>gift</b> offering. <b>The surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>a meal offering</b> are left to <b>rot.</b>
The Gemara clarifies the opaque wording: <b>What is</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>saying? Rav Ḥisda said</b> that <b>this</b> is what the <i>baraita</i> <b>is saying: The surplus</b> coins left over from the purchase of <b>a meal offering of a sinner</b> are used for the purchase of a communal <b>gift</b> offering. <b>The surplus</b> coins left over from purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest</b> are left to <b>rot.</b>
<b>Rabba</b> offered an alternative interpretation of the <i>baraita</i> and <b>said: Even the surplus</b> coins left over from purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest</b> are <b>also</b> used for the purchase of a communal <b>gift</b> offering. <b>Rather, the surplus</b> coins left over from purchasing <b>the loaves</b> accompanying <b>a thanks offering</b> are left <b>to rot.</b>
The Gemara points out that the opinions of Rav Ḥisda and Rabba correspond to opinions raised <b>in the dispute</b> among earlier <i>amora’im</i>, as with regard to <b>the surplus</b> coins left over from purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest, Rabbi Yoḥanan says</b> that they are used to buy a communal <b>gift</b> offering, while <b>Rabbi Elazar says</b> that they must be left <b>to rot.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the opinion of Rabbi Elazar from a mishna (<i>Shekalim</i> 6b): <b>The surplus</b> coins that had been designated for <b>shekels are non-sacred</b> property; <b>but</b> with regard to <b>the surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> meal offering, <b>and the surplus</b> money that had been designated to purchase offerings that are brought due to ritual impurity or a sin, such as <b>the pairs</b> of birds <b>of <i>zavim</i>, the pairs</b> of birds <b>of <i>zavot</i>, the pairs</b> of birds <b>of women after childbirth, and sin offerings, and guilt offerings,</b> in these cases, <b>the surplus</b> coins must be used for a communal <b>gift</b> offering.
The Gemara explains the objection: <b>What</b> is the meaning of the phrase: The tenth of an ephah meal offering? <b>Is it not</b> referring to <b>the surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the High Priest’s tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering?
The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> it is referring to <b>the surplus</b> coins left over after purchasing <b>the meal offering of a sinner,</b> which is also brought from a tenth of an ephah of fine flour (Leviticus 5:11).
<b>Rav Naḥman bar Rav Yitzḥak said: It is reasonable</b> to accept the opinion of <b>the one who said: The surplus</b> coins left over from purchasing <b>the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest</b> are left to <b>rot.</b>
<b>As it is taught</b> in a <i>baraita</i> with regard to a sinner’s meal offering: The verse states: “But if his means are not sufficient for two doves or two pigeons, then he shall bring his offering for that which he has sinned, the tenth part of an ephah of fine flour for a sin offering; <b>he shall put no oil upon it, nor shall he put any frankincense upon it, for it is a sin offering”</b> (Leviticus 5:11). <b>Rabbi Yehuda said</b> that the phrase “it is a sin offering” is interpreted as a restriction: <b>It is called a sin offering, and no other</b> meal offering <b>is called a sin offering.</b> This <b>taught that with regard to the tenth of an ephah</b> griddle-cake meal offering <b>of the High Priest, it is not called a sin offering, and</b> consequently it <b>requires frankincense.</b>
Rav Naḥman inferred: <b>And since it is not called a sin offering, its surplus</b> coins should not be used to buy communal gift offerings like the surplus coins of sin offerings; rather, they should be left to <b>rot.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to one who said: <b>This bull is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and</b> subsequently <b>it became blemished [<i>venista’ev</i>]</b> and was disqualified from sacrifice, he should redeem the bull and with that money purchase another bull as an offering in its stead. <b>If he wishes, he may bring two</b> bulls <b>with its</b> redemption <b>money</b> instead of one. If one says: <b>These two bulls are</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and</b> subsequently <b>they became blemished,</b> if <b>he wishes he may bring one</b> bull <b>with their</b> redemption <b>money. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> this <b>prohibited,</b> and holds that he must bring two bulls.
In a case where one said: <b>This ram is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished, if he wishes he may bring a lamb with its</b> redemption <b>money.</b> In a case where one said: <b>This lamb is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished, if he wishes he may bring a ram with its</b> redemption <b>money. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> it <b>prohibited</b> for one to bring one type of animal with redemption money from another type of animal.

Daf 108b

<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The mishna teaches that if one vows to bring a certain bull as a burnt offering and it became blemished, he may bring two bulls with its redemption money. The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t you say in the first clause,</b> i.e., in the previous mishna (107b), that if one said: It is incumbent upon me to bring <b>a bull with</b> the value of <b>one hundred dinars</b> as a burnt offering or peace offering, <b>and he brought two</b> bulls <b>with</b> a combined value of <b>one hundred dinars,</b> he <b>has not fulfilled</b> his obligation? If so, why does the mishna here teach that one may bring two bulls with the redemption money of one bull?
The Gemara answers that these two cases are not comparable. The previous mishna was referring to a case where one vowed to bring a bull worth one hundred dinars, without referring to a specific bull. Therefore, he is obligated to fulfill the specific conditions of his vow. By contrast, this mishna is referring to a case where one said: <b>This bull</b> is hereby a burnt offering, <b>and</b> therefore, if the bull <b>becomes blemished</b> and disqualified as an offering the <i>halakha</i> <b>is different.</b> Since he was only ever obligated to sacrifice this bull, and is no longer able to sacrifice it, he is no longer obligated by his vow, and may bring any number of offerings with its value.
The mishna teaches that if one says: <b>These two bulls are</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and they became blemished,</b> if <b>he wishes he may bring with</b> the <b>money</b> of <b>their</b> redemption <b>one</b> bull. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> this <b>prohibited,</b> and holds that he must bring two bulls. The Gemara asks: <b>What is the reason</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi deems it prohibited to bring only one bull?
The Gemara answers: <b>Because it is</b> similar to a case where one vowed to bring <b>a large</b> bull <b>and he brought a small</b> bull, in which case he has not fulfilled his vow. Similarly, in this case, he vowed to bring two bulls and brought only one. <b>And although</b> he is not actually obligated to bring two bulls, as the bulls that he consecrated <b>became blemished</b> and he needs only to bring an offering with their redemption money, nevertheless <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>does not permit</b> bringing two bulls instead of one <b><i>ab initio</i>.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But</b> if so, <b>let</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi <b>disagree in the first clause</b> of the mishna <b>as well,</b> which states that if one consecrated a specific bull as a burnt offering and it subsequently became blemished, he may purchase two bulls with its redemption money. There, too, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi should prohibit bringing two bulls <i>ab initio</i>, as it is similar to a case where one vowed to bring a small bull and brought a large one, in which case Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi also holds that he has not fulfilled his obligation.
The Gemara answers: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>disagrees with</b> this <b>entire matter,</b> both in the first and latter clauses of the mishna; <b>but he waited until the Rabbis had completed their statement, and then disagreed with them</b> with regard to both cases.
<b>Know</b> that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi disagrees with the statement of the Rabbis in the first clause of the mishna as well, <b>as</b> the mishna <b>teaches</b> that if one said: <b>This ram is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished,</b> if <b>he wishes he may bring a lamb with its</b> redemption <b>money.</b> In a case where one said: <b>This lamb is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished,</b> if <b>he wishes he may bring a ram with its</b> redemption <b>money. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> it <b>prohibited</b> for one to bring one type of animal with the redemption money of another type of animal, even if he wishes to bring a ram with the redemption money of a lamb. Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi disagrees with the Rabbis even in a case where one consecrated a small animal and wishes to bring a large animal with its redemption money. <b>Conclude from it</b> that he also disagrees in a case where one vowed to bring a certain animal which subsequently became blemished; the person may not bring two animals with the redemption money.
§ <b>A dilemma was raised before</b> the Sages: According to the Rabbis, <b>what</b> is the <i>halakha</i> with regard to one who wishes to use the redemption money <b>from</b> an animal of one <b>species</b> which became blemished <b>to</b> purchase a different <b>species</b> of animal? For example, if one vowed to bring a bull which subsequently became blemished, may he bring rams with its value instead?
The Gemara suggests: <b>Come</b> and <b>hear</b> a resolution from that which is taught in a <i>baraita</i>: If one said: <b>This bull is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished, he may not bring a ram with its</b> redemption <b>money,</b> as a ram is not worth as much as a bull. <b>But he may bring two rams with its</b> redemption <b>money,</b> if together they are equal in value to the bull. <b>And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> this <b>prohibited,</b> the reason being that one must bring two meal offerings to accompany his two rams. These meal offerings must be brought in two vessels, <b>because there is no mixing</b> permitted. Accordingly, bringing two offerings runs counter to the person’s vow, which involved bringing only one meal offering. <b>Conclude from</b> this <i>baraita</i> that according to the Rabbis it is permitted to use the redemption money from one species of animal to purchase a different species.
The Gemara asks: <b>If so,</b> if the Rabbis deem it permitted to bring a different species of animal, <b>why</b> does the <i>baraita</i> <b>specifically</b> state that one may bring <b>two</b> rams in place of a bull? The same <i>halakha</i> would apply <b>even</b> for <b>one</b> ram, <b>as</b> although one ram is smaller than one bull, <b>in</b> a case where the animal <b>became blemished, according to the Rabbis, there is no difference whether</b> one brings <b>a large</b> animal <b>or a small</b> animal. If one vowed to bring a ram he may bring a lamb instead, so why not a ram in place of a bull?
The Gemara answers: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of the Rabbis.</b> The <i>tanna</i> of the mishna holds that the Rabbis deem it permitted to bring a small animal in place of a large animal that became blemished. The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> holds that the Rabbis do not deem it permitted to bring a small animal in place of a large animal.
The <i>baraita</i> states: <b>Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> it <b>prohibited</b> to bring two rams with the redemption money of a bull, <b>because there is no mixing.</b> The Gemara infers: <b>The reason</b> that he deems it prohibited is <b>because there is no mixing. But</b> had there <b>been mixing,</b> then according to Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi it would be <b>permitted.</b>
The Gemara asks: <b>But didn’t we learn</b> in the mishna that if one said: <b>This ram is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished,</b> if <b>he wishes he may bring a lamb with its</b> redemption <b>money.</b> If one said: <b>This lamb is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, and it became blemished, he may bring a ram with its</b> redemption <b>money. And Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi <b>deems</b> it <b>prohibited</b> for one to bring one type of animal with the redemption money of another type of animal. Evidently, Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi prohibits any kind of divergence from the animal that was consecrated, regardless of whether mixing is permitted.
The Gemara answers: There are <b>two <i>tanna’im</i>, and</b> they disagree <b>with regard to</b> the opinion <b>of Rabbi</b> Yehuda HaNasi. The <i>tanna</i> of the <i>baraita</i> holds that Rabbi Yehuda deems it prohibited to switch to a different type of animal only if it affects the accompanying meal offering, whereas the <i>tanna</i> of the mishna holds that Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi deems any kind of change prohibited.
The Gemara cites the latter clause of the <i>baraita</i>: All of the cases in the mishna and <i>baraita</i> are referring to a case where the animal became blemished; <b>and with regard to pure</b> animals, i.e., those that are not blemished, if one vowed to bring <b>a calf and brought a bull</b> instead, or he vowed to bring <b>a lamb and brought a ram</b> instead, <b>he has fulfilled</b> his obligation. The Gemara explains that the <b>unattributed</b> last clause of the <i>baraita</i> is <b>in accordance with</b> the opinion of <b>the Rabbis.</b> Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi would disagree in this case as well.
§ The mishna teaches that if one vows to bring a certain bull as a burnt offering, and it became blemished, if <b>he wishes, he may bring two</b> bulls <b>with its</b> redemption <b>money. Rabbi Menashya bar Zevid says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one said: This bull is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering. But</b> if he <b>said: This bull</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring as <b>a burnt offering,</b> his responsibility for it in a case where it became blemished <b>is fixed,</b> and he must bring one bull with its redemption money, not two.
The Gemara challenges Rav’s opinion: <b>But perhaps</b> when <b>he said:</b> This bull is incumbent upon me, he meant: It is incumbent <b>upon me to bring it</b> as an offering, but he did not intend to accept responsibility in case it becomes blemished.
<b>Rather, if it was stated</b> that there is a case where one is responsible if the animal becomes blemished, <b>it was stated as follows: Rabbi Menashya bar Zevid says</b> that <b>Rav says:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> this <i>halakha</i> <b>only</b> in a case <b>where one said: This bull is</b> hereby <b>a burnt offering, or he said: This bull</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring as <b>a burnt offering. But</b> if <b>he said: This bull and its value</b> are incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring as <b>a burnt offering,</b> his responsibility for it in a case where it becomes blemished <b>is fixed,</b> and he must bring one bull with its redemption money, and not two.
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> With regard to <b>one who says: One of my lambs is consecrated, or: One of my bulls is consecrated, and he has two</b> lambs or bulls, <b>the larger of them is consecrated.</b> If he has <b>three</b> lambs or bulls, <b>the middle-sized</b> animal <b>among them is consecrated.</b> If one says: <b>I specified</b> the lamb or bull that is to be consecrated <b>but I do not know what</b> animal <b>I specified</b> in my vow, <b>or</b> he says <b>that: My father said to me</b> before his death that he consecrated one of the lambs or the bulls, <b>but I do not know what</b> animal he consecrated, <b>the largest of them is consecrated.</b>
<strong>GEMARA:</strong> The first clause of the mishna teaches that if one says: One of my lambs is consecrated, and he has two lambs, the larger one is consecrated. The Gemara infers: <b>Apparently, one who consecrates, consecrates generously.</b> But <b>say the latter clause</b> of the mishna: If he has three lambs, <b>the middle-sized</b> animal <b>among them is consecrated. Apparently, one who consecrates, consecrates sparingly.</b> How can this contradiction be resolved?
<b>Shmuel said:</b> The presumption is that one who consecrates, consecrates generously. When the latter clause of the mishna states that the middle-sized animal is consecrated, it does not mean that only the middle-sized animal is consecrated. Rather, the larger animal is consecrated, and additionally <b>we are concerned,</b> i.e., we must take in consideration the possibility, <b>that the</b> middle-sized animal is consecrated, as <b>compared to</b> consecrating <b>the small</b> animal, consecrating the middle-sized animal <b>is generous.</b> Therefore, the vow could have been referring to either the large animal or the middle-sized animal.
The Gemara asks: <b>How should he act?</b> He consecrated only one of them, and it is uncertain which animal should be sacrificed. <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya bar Rav said: He should wait until</b> the middle-sized animal <b>becomes blemished and</b> then <b>desacralize it</b> by transferring its sanctity <b>onto the large</b> animal, which is then sacrificed on the altar.
§ The mishna teaches that if one had three lambs or bulls, the middle-sized animal is consecrated. <b>Rav Naḥman said</b> that <b>Rabba bar Avuh said:</b> The Sages <b>taught</b> that the middle-sized animal is consecrated <b>only when he said: One of my bulls is</b> hereby <b>consecrated. But</b> if <b>he said: A bull</b> from <b>among my bulls is</b> hereby <b>consecrated,</b> only <b>the largest of them is consecrated.</b> It is as if <b>he said: The</b> most valuable <b>bull</b> from <b>among my bulls [<i>tora betorai</i>]</b> is consecrated.
The Gemara asks: <b>Is that so? But didn’t Rav Huna say</b> that <b>Rabbi Ḥiyya said in the name of Ulla: One who says to another: I am selling you a house</b> from <b>among my houses, can show him an loft [<i>aliyya</i>],</b> since he did not specify which house he is selling? Is this <b>not because</b> the loft is the <b>worst</b> of his houses? If so, when one says: A bull from among my bulls is hereby consecrated, he is presumably referring to the least valuable of his bulls. The Gemara answers: <b>No,</b> Ulla did not say that the seller gives the purchaser a loft, but rather <b>the best [<i>me’ula</i>] of</b> his <b>houses.</b>
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabba bar Avuh from a <i>baraita</i>: If one said: <b>A bull</b> from <b>among my bulls is consecrated, or similarly</b> if <b>a consecrated bull became mixed with other</b> non-consecrated bulls, <b>the largest of them is consecrated, and all of the</b> other bulls <b>must be sold</b> to people who vowed to bring burnt offerings, <b>for the purpose of</b> bringing them as <b>burnt offerings,</b> since it is uncertain which one of them was consecrated, <b>and the payment for them is non-sacred.</b> Evidently, if one says: I hereby consecrate a bull from among my bulls, all of his bulls have uncertain consecrated status.
The Gemara answers: <b>Interpret</b> this as referring only <b>to a consecrated bull that became mixed with others.</b> The Gemara challenges: <b>But doesn’t</b> the <i>baraita</i> <b>say: And similarly,</b> indicating that this <i>halakha</i> applies to both cases? The Gemara answers: <b>Interpret</b> it as referring <b>to</b> the <i>halakha</i> that <b>the largest</b> of the bulls is consecrated. That <i>halakha</i> does apply to both cases, but the <i>halakha</i> that the rest of the bulls have uncertain consecrated status applies only to the latter case.
The Gemara <b>raises an objection</b> to the statement of Rabba bar Avuh from a <i>baraita</i>: If one says to another: <b>I am selling you a house</b> from <b>among my houses, and</b> one of the houses subsequently <b>fell, he can show him</b> the <b>fallen</b> house, and say to him: This is the one I sold you. Similarly, if one says to another: <b>I sell you a slave</b> from <b>among my slaves, and</b> one of the slaves <b>dies, he can show him</b> the <b>dead</b> slave and say: This is the slave I sold you.

Daf 109a

<b>But</b> according to the opinion of Rabba bar Avuh, <b>why</b> can the seller automatically give the purchaser the fallen house or the dead slave? <b>Let him see which</b> house <b>fell,</b> or <b>which</b> slave <b>died,</b> as according to Rabba bar Avuh, the sale should apply to the house or slave that was the most valuable at the time of the sale.
The Gemara answers: <b>Are you saying</b> that the statement of Rabba bar Avuh applies in the case of <b>a purchaser? A purchaser is different, as</b> there is a principle in the <i>halakhot</i> of commerce that in a case involving a dispute between the seller and the purchaser, <b>the owner of the document</b> of sale, i.e., the purchaser, <b>is at a disadvantage,</b> as a document is always interpreted as narrowly as possible. Therefore, the seller can claim that he has sold the buyer the fallen house or the dead slave.
The Gemara adds: <b>Now that you have arrived at this</b> explanation, the objection posed earlier to the statement of Rabba bar Avuh from the statement of Ulla can be rejected easily. Ulla said that if one says to another: I am selling you a house from among my houses, since he did not specify which house he is selling, he can show him an attic [<i>aliyya</i>]. Although this was explained above as referring not to a loft but to the best [<i>me’ula</i>] of his houses, now <b>you</b> may <b>even say</b> that it is referring to <b>a loft, which is the worst</b> of his houses, due to the principle that <b>the owner of the document is at a disadvantage.</b>
<strong>MISHNA:</strong> One who says: <b>It</b> is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering, must sacrifice it in the Temple</b> in Jerusalem. <b>And if he sacrificed it in the temple of Onias</b> in Egypt, <b>he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation. One who says: It is incumbent <b>upon me</b> to bring <b>a burnt offering that I will sacrifice in the temple of Onias, must sacrifice it in the Temple</b> in Jerusalem, <b>but if he sacrificed it in the temple of Onias, he has fulfilled</b> his obligation. <b>Rabbi Shimon says</b> that if one says: It is incumbent upon me to bring a burnt offering that I will sacrifice in the temple of Onias, <b>it is not</b> consecrated as <b>a burnt offering;</b> such a statement does not consecrate the animal at all.
If one says: <b>I am hereby a nazirite,</b> then when his term of naziriteship is completed <b>he must shave</b> the hair of his head and bring the requisite offerings <b>in the Temple</b> in Jerusalem; <b>and if he shaved in the temple of Onias, he has not fulfilled</b> his obligation.
